DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Nov. 1, or the 19th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1755: A severe earthquake devastates the Portuguese city of Lisbon, killing between 30,000 and 60,000 people.
1856: Britain declares war on Persia after Persia invades Afghanistan to occupy Herat.
1928: The Central Bank of China is established in Shanghai with T.V. Soong (Sung Tzu-wen) as its governor.
1934: The Boy Scouts of China is founded.
1936: Tuan Chi-jui, who led the Anhwei faction in the fight against the joined forces of Tsao Kun of the Chihli faction and Chang Tso-lin of the Fengtien faction in the war between the Chihli and Anhui warlords, dies in Shanghai at the age of 72.
1946: The Chinese chambers of commerce at a joint meeting in Nanking pass a resolution establishing Nov. 1 as Businessmen's Day.
1950: The Communist Chinese announce they will provide aid to the North Koreans in their fight against U.N. forces.
1952: The first batch of U.S.-supplied fighter planes arrives at Keelung Harbor. After the outbreak of the Korean War, the U.S. government decided to supply large quantities of military equipment and materials to the Republic of China.
1952: The United States explodes its first hydrogen bomb, on Elugelab Atoll in the northeast of the Pacific Marshall Islands.
1954: The Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen under the Executive Yuan, aimed at coordinating operations for assistance to and placement of retired military personnel, is established with Yen Chia-kan serving as its chairman.
1955: Dale Carnegie, U.S. educator known for his self-improvement book "How to Win Friends and Influence People," dies at the age of 67.
1959: Veterans General Hospital is formally inaugurated in Shihpai, Taipei County.
1963: Ngo Dinh Diem, president of South Vietnam, and his brother Ngo Dinh Nhu are killed in a military coup.
1973: Chien Chun, deputy governor of the Central Bank of China, and Chao Chi-chang, director of the Ministry of Finance, leave for Washington to attend a meeting of the International Monetary Fund.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan addresses the opening ceremony of the Second Asian-Scholars Convention in Taipei.
1976: The Taipei-Keelung section of the North-South Freeway opens to traffic.
1979: Rodrigo Altmann Ortiz, first vice president of the Republic of Costa Rica, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1980: The Consumers' Foundation, ROC, is founded, with Chai Sunglin serving as its board chairman.
1983: Dr. Wu Ta-you takes over the presidency of Academia Sinica, succeeding Dr. Chien Shih-liang.
1987: More than 90 members, mostly veteran revolutionaries, including Deng Xiaoping, step down from the Chinese Communist Party's guiding Central Committee.
1990: President Lee Teng-hui receives an Outstanding International Alumnus Citation from Cornell University.
1993: The Maastricht Treaty comes into effect, creating a new "European Union."
1996: Junius Richard Jayewardene, former president of Sri Lanka, dies at the age of 90.
1999: A three-day symposium whose theme is the 101-year-old Madame Chiang Kai-shek and her role in contemporary China begins in Taipei.
2000: The Presidential Science and Technology Consulting Committee is formally inaugurated at the Taipei International Conference Center.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian urges the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in his new book "The Premiere Voyage of the Century: Reflections on the Party's 500 Days of Transition" to work harder toward further transformation.
2001: Lee Chen-yuan, a member of Academia Sinica and a senior advisor to President Chen Shui-bian, dies of illness at National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital at the age of 86.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "All men have a mind which cannot bear to see the sufferings of others. The ancient kings had this commiserating mind, and they had likewise, as a matter of course, a commiserating government."

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-GREEN' VOTE ALLOCATION COOPERATION WON'T BE PROBLEM: TSU OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) official said Monday that there shouldn't be any problems in "pan-green camp" cooperation in employing its vote allocation campaign strategy for the year-end legislative elections.

TSU Secretary-General Lin Jih-jia said that he has contacted Lee Ying-yuan, deputy secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), over the matter and that the two of them will discuss using the strategy in five constituencies in the near future.

The "pan-green camp" of the DPP has long used the vote allocation strategy with success to raise the number of its candidates elected under the current multi-member district, single-vote electoral system.

Lin said the "pan-green camp" could first cooperate in five constituencies -- namely in Tainan, Taichung, Keelung and Hsinchu cities, and the northern region of Kaohsiung City -- and then decide later whether to expand the vote allocation strategy to other constituencies.

He pointed out that the "pan-green camp" candidates in Tainan and Taichung cities have begun joint campaigning operations and that cooperation in the other three constituencies could begin immediately as the election situation there is not too complicated.

Noting that "it is not important for the 'pan-green camp' to have individual political stars, " Lin said that although vote allocation might lead to some grievances among some candidates, the benefits to them in the long run are greater.

A record high of 387 candidates have registered to run for seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan. The DPP has the most candidates at 92, followed by the Kuomintang at 74, the People First Party at 41, the TSU at 30 and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union at 26.

President Chen Shui-bian, who doubles as the DPP chairman, has set the goal of taking 100 legislative seats in the year-end elections and thus command a comfortable majority with its ally the TSU in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VENTURES SEEK A-SHARE LISTING IN M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: More and more Taiwan companies or joint ventures are seeking a domestic A-share listing on mainland China's stock exchanges, mainly to raise funds to help them survive in the fast-changing, increasingly competitive mainland market, a capital broker said Monday.

Taiwan business operations have been forced to seek A-share listing on the Shanghai Stock Exchange or the Shenzhen Stock Exchange for a variety of reasons, including cash restraints as a result of China's efforts to cool its overheated economy; difficulties in acquiring funds from Taiwan; the appreciating mainland Chinese currency; and mainland Chinese stocks' comparatively higher price/earnings (P/E) ratios, according to Liu Fang-rong, CEO of the Friendly Business Group.

Liu, whose firm operates financial consulting services in both Taipei and Shanghai, said that first of all, mainland China's measures to cool its economy have made life much harder for mainland-based Taiwan companies in terms of obtaining loans and borrowing cash.

Secondly, he continued, the mainland-based Taiwan companies have experienced difficulties in securing funds from Taiwan due to Taiwan's 40-percent ceiling policy aimed at controlling the amount of Taiwan capital that flows into the mainland. This policy has also dampened these companies' willingness to seek listing back on Taiwan's stock market, he noted.

Thirdly, Liu added, the appreciating renminbi and its potential to stay strong in the months and even years ahead is another incentive spurring the Taiwan companies to seek A-share listing on the mainland.

Mainland Chinese stocks' relatively higher P/E ratios -- higher than those in Singapore, Hong Kong and Taiwan -- is the fourth factor leading the Taiwan companies to seek listing on mainland stock exchanges, Liu said.

Besides, he said, even though the mainland's P/E ratios are relatively higher, they are currently at their lowest levels in eight years, representing a golden opportunity for investors to return to the market before a definite bottoming-out.
Liu offered his analysis in a column carried Monday on the Taiwan Business Web site forum run by the Central News Agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO TOP US$160 B. THIS YEAR: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports are expected to top US$160 billion for 2004, marking the highest figure ever, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Monday.

Addressing the opening of the Fifth National Industrial Development Conference, Ho said that 2004 has been a brilliant year for Taiwan's economy, with both industrial production and export trade expanding remarkably thanks mainly to the general recovery of the world economy.

Quoting the latest report issued by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , Ho said that Taiwan's economy flashed a 10th consecutive yellow-red light in October, reflecting a heating-up in the domestic economy according to a five-color rating system. This is the best performance since 1994, Ho said.

According to the five-color rating system designated by the CEPD, a red light indicates an overheated economy, yellow-red indicates a heating up economy, green means steady growth, yellow-blue signals sluggishness, and blue points to recession.

Meanwhile, Ho said, Taiwan's economy posted a growth of 7.2 percent for the first half of this year, for the best performance since 1997. During the period, industrial production registered a growth of 15 percent, while investment from the private sector surged a whopping 28.3 percent. It is estimated that investment from the private sector will top NT$1.4 trillion (US$41.9 billion) for the whole of 2004, she added.
However, Ho also said that Taiwan's economy still faces challenges posed by political and economic variables at home and abroad.

In addition, she said, Taiwan's manufacturing industries and service industries -- the two major pillars of Taiwan's economy -- need to be upgraded structurally in order to increase Taiwan's international competitiveness.
To catch up with the industrially-advanced countries, Taiwan must seek breakthroughs on several fronts, including innovation, the nurturing of talent, tax incentives, technology, and so on.

Solution policies that the Ministry of Economic Affairs has moved to push include increasing government investment in and providing government incentives for the development of the semiconductor, telecommunications, nanotechnology and biotechnology industries, and knowledge-based services, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange ended lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 49.76 points to close at 5,656.17.

The bourse opened at 5,725.65 and fluctuated between 5,732.7 and 5,628.25 during the day's trading. A total of 2.41 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$52.5 billion (US$1.56 billion).
One of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up 0.6 percent.

Seven other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.4 percent, foodstuff issues at 1 percent, cement stocks at 0.8 percent, paper and pulp issues and plastics and chemicals shares both at 0.7 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 515 to 148, with 123 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER LISTS TAIWAN'S ACCOMPLISHMENTS IN FOREIGN TRADE, INVESTMENTS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said on Monday that foreign trade and industrial production have shown dramatic growth this year and that the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics has estimated that this year's economic growth could reach 5.87 percent.
The premier made the remarks when he addressed the opening of a two-day national industrial development conference in Taipei, which was sponsored by the Ministry of the Economic Affairs.
Thanks to the world economic recovery and the concerted efforts of the government and private sectors, the premier said that exports and imports this year have shown a remarkable increase.
In the first nine months of this year, exports increased by 24.2 percent, while imports increased by 34.3 percent, showing the strength of Taiwan's foreign trade, the premier said.
Industrial production during the nine-month period have also grown by 12 percent when compared with the same period last year.

The premier said that Taiwan's excellent investment environment has won world recognition, noting that the World Economic Forum ranks Taiwan fifth in 2003, up from 10th place in 2000 in its global competitiveness report.

Taiwan also moved up to 12th this year in global competitiveness as ranked by the Lausanne-based Institute of International Management. The Economist Intelligence Unit also predicted that Taiwan's business environment will be very good in the next five years, ranking it 15th around the world, or third in Asia, he said.

Faced with global competitiveness and dramatic changes in the domestic and foreign economic environments, the premier said that his administrative team mapped out the "challenge 2008 national development project" two years ago, which is aimed at restructuring industry.
The premier said that as of the end of October, the government has attracted 203 enterprises to set up operations headquarters in Taiwan, and the number is expected to grow to 660 by 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL TASK FORCE OPENS TO WIPE OUT RED FIRE ANTS WITHIN 3 YEARS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) set up a national task force Monday in Taipei to eliminate the infestations of South American red fire ants within three years.

The National Red Fire Ant Control Center, located at the Center for Biotechnology of the prestigious National Taiwan University (NTU) , was officially inaugurated Monday by council Chairman Lee Chin-lung, Ketagalan Institute President Lee Hong-hsi and Yang Ping-shih, an NTU professor of entomology who is also director of the new facility.

Lee said during a ceremony marking the inauguration that the new center has been tasked to carry out the Cabinet's policy of tackling the ant infestation in three years, with the help of experts and scientists from research units of nationwide academic institutes including Academia Sinica, NTU, National Chung Hsing University, National Chiayi University and National Pingtung University of Science and Technology.

The red ant control center's current tasks include monitoring and reporting on the infestation, providing professional consultancy and control services, conducting assessments of efforts to eliminate the foreign insects, and organizing presentations around the island to raise public awareness of the ants that entered Taiwan on cargo ships from the United States.

According to the agriculture council's latest statistics, the red fire ants have been found in agricultural and non-agricultural areas around the country, with those in the counties of Taoyuan, Chiayi and Taipei being the most affected.

The agriculture council chairman said 20,000 Kilograms of insecticides have been prepared as well as liquid nitrogen to stop the invasion of the South America-originated ants. However, he noted that the red fire ant infestation is basically already under control.
Lee pointed out that 21 cities and rural townships, as well as 49 schools around the nation are currently in the "yellow light" state, meaning that the fire ants are being exterminated.

The code is part of a light rating system, similar to a traffic light, set up by the new ant control center to show the seriousness of a red fire ant colony in a particular location, with red indicating the discovery of the insects but no action having been taken; yellow indicating that ants are currently being exterminated; and green indicating that the foreign insects have been eradicated.
However, Lee urged farmers not to deal with the red fire ants by themselves when discovering a colony. He warned that any careless move to disturb the ant colony will result in a wider infestation.

The official said the method of freezing the fire ants with liquid nitrogen that was developed by a team from Academia Sinica has proved to be able to eradicate the ants in an effective and environmentally friendly way.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH DEPARTMENT ON ALERT TO PREVENT REOCCURRENCE OF SARS

TEXT.P: In a bid to prevent a resurgence of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) announced Monday that passengers from Greater China will have their temperatures taken upon arrival, starting the same day.
The decision was made based on a conclusion reached in a DOH meeting held Oct. 21, as peak winter season of epidemics approaches, a spokesman for the DOH's Center for Disease Control (CDC) said.

Although no any SARS case has been reported anywhere in the world this fall, the spokesman said that the CDC is on a high alert against the spread of the potentially deadly disease by requiring visitors coming from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau to fill a questionnaire upon their arrival and conduct self-health management by having their temperatures taken for 10 days in a row.

In line with the move, the CDC asked personnel and medical staffers at countrywide nursing homes, halfway houses and residences for the disabled across the country to report to health authorities if they find anyone with symptoms, such as fever, the spokesman said.
The CDC also encouraged kindergartens and elementary and junior high schools to fully abide by a rule of having children with a fever to stay at home, he added.

According to a SARS response level designated by an inter-ministerial SARS Committee, the current "0" SARS response level imposed by the CDC refers to a situation in which no cases have been reported globally.
The response level will be lifted to "A" by the DOH when the world's first confirmed case is reported.

A "B" level signals a situation in which the first confirmed case of primary transmission is reported at home, while a "C" level points to a development when the first confirmed case and a secondary transmission are reported domestically. The SARS Committee will be in charge of all arrangements at the "B "and "C"response levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF TAIWAN TRADING COMPANIES GROWS: BOFT

TEXT.P: The number of trading companies in Taiwan grew by 23 percent over the past decade, with their average business volumes increasing by 36 percent, according to statistics compiled by the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT).

BOFT statistics show that there were 88,978 trading companies in Taiwan in 1993, with an average business volume of US$1.82 million for that year. The number of trading companies rose to 109,446 in 2003, with an average transaction turnover standing at US$2.47 million last year.

In 1993, the country's top 100 trading companies generated US$43 billion worth of business, or 26 percent of the country's overall export and import trade, according to the same tallies. But the ratio rose to 39 percent in 2003 recording a value of US$105.3 billion.

On the other hand, performance and space of Taiwan's small trading firms were further squeezed. Small trading companies, around 90 percent in the sector in 2003, an increase compared to 82 percent in 1993, did only 10 percent of the business.

According to a BOFT analysis, large manufacturing companies generated most of the business for Taiwan's foreign trade sector over the past 10 years. Taiwan trading firms should shift their focus to service-oriented businesses to play a bigger role in the world's
system of labor division and help foreign companies better explore the domestic market, BOFT officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEBERTHAL ARRIVES IN TAIWAN FOR FOUR-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: Kenneth Lieberthal, former United States National Security Council's Senior Director for Asian Affairs, arrived in Taiwan Monday for a four-day visit.

Reports noted that Lieberthal, a professor of political science at the University of Michigan and a supporter of U.S. Senator John Kerry, comes just 48 hours from the heated U.S. presidential election on Nov. 2.

Lieberthal, at the invitation of the Mainland Affairs Council, will attend a seminar on grassroots democracy in mainland China held at the Institute of International Relations at National Chengchi University Nov. 2-3 and deliver a speech. Also attending will be MAC Chairman Joseph Wu and other scholars.
Lieberthal may meet President Chen Shui-bian during his stay in Taiwan.

Lieberthal, a China-hand who proposed the idea of an "interim agreement" in which Taipei and Beijing would sign on to the concept of "one China" but would put off the idea of unification for 50 years, amended his view earlier this year.

Lieberthal co-wrote a story with David Lampton, director of China studies at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, to promote the idea of "establishing a stable framework across the Strait for a long period -- counted not in years but in decades.'

The story, which appeared in the Washington Post in April, said that for such a framework to be effective, all sides must agree on its fundamentals and its minimum duration, and they must seek the support of the international community in reinforcing it.
Under such an arrangement, Taiwan could continue to assert its sovereign status, but would take the additional step of turning de facto independence into de jure independence.
While the mainland could continue to assert that there is only "one China" of which Taiwan is a part, it would have to give up its threat of using force to change Taiwan's status.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE AWARD-WINNING WRITER MAY VISIT TAIWAN SOON

TEXT.P: The author of the memoir, "The Past Doesn't Disappear Like Smoke, " which won an award from the literary organization PEN for independent Chinese-language writers Oct. 30, will probably visit Taiwan in late November or early December to promote her book, sources from China Times Publishing said Monday.

Zhang Yihe, the author of the vivid account of her personal perspective on the heart-rending history and political upheavals in modern China since the building of the People's Republic of China, received the PEN award in Beijing.
PEN, a collection of poets, playwrights, essayists, editors and novelists was formed in 1921 to promote cooperation among writers.
Zhang is the daughter of Zhang Bojun, one of the first ministers of Mao Zedong's "new China" government, who later was persecuted as the "No. 1 rightist" in Communist China.

The book, first published in Beijing in January this year, became a hot after item soon after Beijing announced a ban on it because the authorities did not like what she reminisced about the Chinese Communists during the Mao era.
Pirated copies of the book have been selling briskly around mainland China ever since.

Taipei-based China Times Publishing has recently published a Taiwan edition of the memoir, making it the third of its kind since Zhang's memoir written in simplified Chinese characters was published in Beijing last year. The original copy appeared with many lines deleted or censored.
The second edition was published by Oxford University Publishing in Hong Kong sometime this year under the title, "The Last Noble." It recovered most of the missing sections and sentences.

The Taiwan edition, or the China Times version, comes with the original title, "The Past Doesn't Disappear Like Smoke, " with tradition Chinese characters and is a complete, unabridged version, the most "wholesome" version of the memoir, according to China Times Publishing management.
Academia Sinica tried to invite Zhang to Taiwan for a visit, but the invitation hit a snag for unknown reasons.
Zhang was the second mainland Chinese citizen to receive the PEN award for independent Chinese writers. Her predecessor was Wang Lixiong for his book, "Yellow Peril."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORGED GREENBACK COUNTERFEITER BUSTED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A counterfeiter with a long criminal record for banknote forgery was busted in Sanchung, Taipei County Monday for counterfeiting US$100 banknotes, the Investigation Bureau reported.

Koo Chuan-chen, 52, a criminal on parole, was arrested red-handed early Monday at his print shop, where investigators discovered US$140,000-worth of faked, finished US$100 notes and some US$3 million-worth of semi-finished notes.
The suspect admitted that he planned to trade his notes at a price equivalent to one-tenth of their face value.
Based on that, the police estimated that the forged bills would have fetched some NT$100 million for Koo.

Koo said he chose to counterfeit notes with a DF prefix to the serial number instead of notes with a CB prefix because most of the CB bills are rejected by Taiwan banks, even though they are genuine bills issued by banks in the United States.

Koo, who has been in the printing business since he was around 20 years old, was previously sentenced to a 17-year jail term for forging NT$1,000 bills. He was released on parole late last year after serving one-third of his time.
Supposedly unable to find a job, Koo began to make molds in April this year to forge US$100 greenbacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL TALKS DIRECT WAY TO RESOLVE CROSS-STRAIT PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: If President Chen Shui-bian and mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao could meet for discussions, it would be the most direct way to resolve cross-Taiwan Strait problems, the president of Taiwan's most prestigious research body, Academia Sinica, said Monday.

Lee Yuan-tseh, who is also a Nobel laureate, has been appointed by President Chen Shui-bian to represent him at the informal summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum slated to take place Nov. 20 in Chile. He made the remarks while answering questions during a legislative committee meeting.

Lee said he is not sure whether or not he will have an opportunity to contact Hu during the Chile leadership meeting, although he had brief talks in private with the mainland leader on the occasion of a APEC meeting last year.

However, he told legislators that without careful arrangement, it might not be easy to have talks on any cross-strait issues, but he expressed hope that there will one day be an opportunity for Chen and Hu to talk.
Asked if he would be willing to serve as a convener of cross-strait negotiations, Lee said that "this is not what I do."

DOC.HEADLINE: VP CALLS FOR PRIVATE SECTOR PARTICIPATION IN DEFENSE INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called on the private sector Monday to participate in the defense industry development to help strengthen the nation's defense capabilities.

Addressing a defense industry forum organized by the Ministry of National Defense along with the 2004 Reserve Duty Research and Development Achievements Exhibition being held in Taipei, Lu said that the participation in the reserve duty program of the private sector, particularly the technology industry, is very important to the country's defense industry development.

In the face of mainland China's growing military buildup that poses a serious threat to Taiwan's security, Lu said, Taiwan can only maintain cross-Taiwan Strait peace by obtaining sufficient defense capabilities.
Taiwan is a major country in terms of the development of advanced technology and the government is conducting nine programs for technology development classified as being on a national scale.

Based on common use by the military and civilian sectors, Lu noted, more than 12,000 individuals have contributed their expertise to the country's defense industry development since the defense industry reserve duty system was established in 1980.
The defense industry reserve duty program is aimed at supplying sufficient skilled labor for the research and development of weapons.

The exhibition opened Oct. 29 with the participation of more than 1,000 organizations and units wishing to demonstrate the promising results of applying the private sector's R&D resources to the defense industry. It will run through Nov. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRUGGLING LEGISLATIVE ASPIRANTS IN 'HIGH-RISK' GROUP FOR GRAFT

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan said Monday that legislative aspirants who are struggling to be elected are in a "high-risk" group in terms of likelihood of resorting to bribery and that they will be the main target of ongoing anti-graft operations.

Chen made the remarks after he and Wu Ying-chao, state public prosecutor-general, unveiled the plaque of an anti-graft task force at the State Public Prosecutor-General's Office, to prepare for the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Noting that the year-end elections will be extremely fierce as it will be last elections using the multi-seat, one vote system, he said the law enforcement authorities have reason to believe that those who are struggling on the threshold of being elected could attempt to use bribery to ensure victory.
A record 387 legislative aspirants have registered to vie for a seat in the 225-member Legislative Yuan, but from the next legislature on, the number of seats will be halved.

Also, the election system for legislators will be changed to a "single seat, two votes" system, meaning that there will be one winner in each of the smaller constituencies, with voters given one vote for the election candidate and one for the political party they support.

Commenting on the statement issued by the Prosecutors' Association that the association members do not want to claim anti-graft cash awards, Chen expressed admiration, but said that the measure will continue.

Chen explained that the cash award for prosecutors and citizens is different, noting that a citizen reporting bribery can claim half of the cash award of NT$5 million (US$149,700) if a prosecutor establishes a case and files a suit. If the first trial results in a conviction, the citizen can then claim the remaining half.
Prosecutors, however, can only claim the first half of the cash after the first ruling and the remaining half after the final ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES MUSEUM INAUGURATED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The China Airlines (CAL) Museum was inaugurated in Taipei Monday, according to an announcement by CAL officials.
The purposes of the museum are to mark the company's upcoming 45th anniversary in December and to present its rich flight history.

The museum is divided into five display sections, including plane models, plane maintenance facilities, documents about the staff and a device that is supposed to signify that the company will reach a new peak.
Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san and CAL Chairman Chiang Yao-tsung jointly cut a ribbon to mark the inauguration of the museum.
CAL was established in 1959. It has a fleet of 62 jets and destinations in 47 cities in 21 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY PIRACY POLICE UNIT INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: A new 220-man police unit specializing in preventing intellectual property rights infringements was inaugurated Monday.

A spokesman for the National Police Administration said that the establishment of the specially commissioned unit will further increase the efficiency of the government's efforts to crack down on intellectual property piracy.

It will contribute to the improvement of Taiwan's international image and will help attract foreign investment to Taiwan by creating a more friendly investment environment, according to the spokesman.
Since Jan. 1 last year, a total of 220 police officers have been assigned to perform the mission in the form of an ad hoc task force.

They have busted 2,970 cases of intellectual property rights infringement so far, with a total value of NT$14.35 billion (US$427.2 million) in terms of market price involved and 1,811 suspects brought to justice, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN SUES KMT-HELD RADIO STATION FOR RETURN OF LAND

TEXT.P: In a move signaling its resolve to demand that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) return national property that the Cabinet alleges was embezzled by the main opposition party, the Executive Yuan sued a KMT-held affiliate Monday for the return of national land.

Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai made the announcement at a news conference after a group of lawyers commissioned by the Executive Yuan filed a civil suit against the KMT-controlled Broadcasting Corporation of China (BCC) at the Panchiao District Court, seeking the return of eight plots of BCC-held land in Panchiao City in accordance with the Civic Code and relevant laws.
Chen said that the government has repeatedly tried to settle the issue with the KMT through negotiations, but KMT Chairman Lien Chan has refused to discuss the issue.

The group of lawyers launched the lawsuit in the name of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) and the former Directorate-General of Telecommunications -- the predecessor of the now privatized Chunghwa Telecom Co., Ltd. -- requiring the Panchiao District Court to rescind the BCC's registration as owner of the eight land plots, valued at NT$1.053 billion (US$31.4 million).

According to lawyer Lin Yung-sung, the eight land lots were national territory originally under registration of the then Directorate-General of Telecommunications and the Directorate-General of Posts affiliated to the MOTC.

But the BCC became the administrator of the land June 5, 1981 and according to official documents, it further turned out to be the land's owner Aug. 5, 1985 through a registration of ownership transfer, Lin pointed out.
Lin claimed that the BCC did not pay to acquire the land and he demanded that the KMT return what he called the inappropriately obtained national property to the country.

The legal battle comes at a time when the "pan-green camp" led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is striving to win a majority in the next Legislative Yuan against the opposition "pan-blue alliance" led by the KMT as the Dec. 11 legislative elections approach.
What the DPP calls "improperly obtained national assets of the KMT" is always a high-profit target of the DPP against the main opposition party at election time.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT INVITES BUSINESSMEN TO VISIT LATIN AMERICA

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu invited domestic businessmen Monday to accompany her on a visit to Latin America next spring.

Addressing the 2004 Golden Businessman Awards ceremony and a rally in celebration of Businessmen's Day, organized by the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, Lu praised the nation's businessmen for their contributions to Taiwan's economic development.

Taiwan's economy enjoyed cumulative growth of 8.05 percent, with exports increasing by 42 percent and the country's foreign exchange reserves doubling over the past four years since 2000 when President Chen Shui-bian was inaugurated for his first term, with a negative annual economic growth rate of 2.18 percent and exports decreasing by 17.2 percent, Lu noted.

Thanks to joint efforts from the business sector, Taiwan's economy has been on a steady recovery, Lu said, adding that the government has a plan to advance toward Latin America next year to explore business opportunities there.
She encouraged domestic businessmen to take the opportunity to carry out their global deployment programs and to accompany her to visit that part of the world next spring.

A total of 19 domestic businessmen, six foreign individuals and six foreign missions, including Panama's embassy in Taipei, were awarded at the ceremony for their outstanding performance in doing business or contributing to Taiwan's foreign trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL BANKS OVERDUE LOAN RATIOS AVERAGE AT 3.3 PERCENT: FSC

TEXT.P: Overdue loan ratios recorded by local banks have been steadily dropping, with their average standing at 3.31 percent at the end of September, representing a total value of NT$504.9 billion (US$15.1 billion) , the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) reported Monday.
As of the end of September, 12 local banks posted overdue loan ratios of more than 5 percent, with two of them recording ratios of over 15 percent, the FSC said.

Bau Hwa Bank and the Medium Business Bank of Hualien District registered overdue loan ratios of 21.09 percent and 17.91 percent as of the end of that month, down from the August levels of 22.16 percent and 30.7 percent, respectively, according to the FSC.

The rest of the 10 local banks with overdue loan ratios of more than 5 percent include the Chung Shing Bank, the ChinFon Commercial Bank, the Farmer Bank of China, the Bank of Overseas Chinese and the Medium Business Bank of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT MEETING OPENS

TEXT.P: A two-day national meeting on crafting strategies for Taiwan's industry opened Monday, with more than 700 representatives from the government, academic and industrial sectors taking part.

Focusing on the meeting's theme of industrial innovation in the fast-changing global market, participants suggested that the government help cultivate highly skilled professional talent, give its full support to industrial development, strengthen links between innovative industries and provide comprehensive management of intellectual property rights protection.

Strategies can be devised on a wide range of fronts, including stepping up exchanges of talent with mainland China, lndia and countries in Eastern Europe, and revising the current military service law to lure more reserve duty officers with national defense and economic backgrounds, they proposed.

They also suggested that a free flow of specialists among the government, academia and enterprises should be further stepped up by encouraging the private sector to offer more training opportunities for students at universities and post-graduate schools.
The national industry meeting has been held every three years since 2001. Prior to that, it was held every five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD CONFERENCE ON SMALL ISLANDS OPENS ON KINMEN

TEXT.P: The Eighth Islands of the World International Conference opened Monday on Kinmen, a Taiwan-controlled frontline island in the Taiwan Strait, with the participation of 250 scholars from 30 countries.
The discussions in the five-day meeting will center on the sustainable development of small islands in the changing world, the organizers said.
Topics of the meeting, chaired by Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng, include economic, social, cultural and historical development and environmental issues that affect small islands.

Keynote speakers in the first-day session included Gillian Cambers, convener of UNESCO's Coast and Small Islands Unit in Paris, Grant McCall of the Center for South Pacific Studies, Yeh Jiunn-rong, chairman of the Research Development and Evaluation Commission under the Executive Yuan, and Chang Jin-sen, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development.
A total of 130 theses are expected to be presented in the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Nov. 2, or the 20th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1795: James K. Polk, the 11th president of the United States, is born. His term was marked by the establishment of the 49th parallel as the country's northern border west of the Great Lakes.
1810: The United States establishes freedom of trade with France.
1865: Warren Harding, the 29th president of the United States, who died in office, is born. He made several misguided appointments that led to a corrupt administration.
1917: The Lansing-Ishii Agreement is signed in an attempt to reconcile conflicting American and Japanese interests in China.
1917: The British government issues the "Balfour Declaration," presented by British Foreign Minister Arthur James Balfour, furthering the possibility of a permanent national homeland for the Jews in Palestine.
1923: A major battle breaks out at Changteh in China's Hunan Province when Japanese troops try to gain control of all of the resources of Lake Tungting in northern Hunan.
1930: Ras Tafari, King of Ethiopia, is crowned Emperor Haile Selassie I in Addis Ababa.
1950: George Bernard Shaw, the Irish-born British playwright who won the 1925 Nobel Prize for literature, dies at the age of 94. A founder of the Fabian Society, he wrote plays of iconoclastic social criticism, including "Arms and the Man," "Pygmalion" and "Saint Joan."
1963: Archaeologists in America discover evidence of the presence of Vikings in the "New World" 500 years before the arrival of Columbus.
1971: The China Steel Corporation, a Sino-Austrian venture set up to build Taiwan's first integrated steel mill, is inaugurated.
1971: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Peru.
1976: A delegation headed by Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Council for Sino-Korean Economic Cooperation, leaves for Seoul to meet with its Korean counterpart.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan receives visiting Lt. Gen. Victor H. Krulak, president of Copley News Service.
1976: Democratic outsider Jimmy Carter, the former governor of Georgia, defeats incumbent Republican Gerald Ford to become the 39th president of the United States.
1976: The 100,000-barrel Taoyuan Refinery, Taiwan's second oil refinery, begins operations.
1976: A 23-member Uruguay mission headed by Dr. Juan Carlos Blanco, the foreign affairs minister, and Valentin Arismendi, the economic and finance minister, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1978: Two Soviet cosmonauts return to earth from the Salyut 6 space station after setting a new endurance record of 140 days in space.
1978: The ROC government announces that tourist passports will be issued in the following year to encourage people-to-people diplomacy.
1979: ROC Premier Sun Yun-suan leaves for South Korea to attend the state funeral of President Park Chung Hee.
1985: More than 130 scholars from home and abroad meet for a four-day seminar on Dr. Sun Yat-sen and modern Chinese history held in Kaohsiung to rectify the Communist Chinese' distortion of modern Chinese history.
1987: The ROC Red Cross Society begins accepting applications from local residents wishing to visit relatives in mainland China.
1991: King Taufa'ahau Tupou IV of the Kingdom of Tonga arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1998: Hurricane Mitch fades after a week-long rampage through Central America, during which time it killed an estimated 9,000 people.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of the Brilliant Star with a Violet Grand Cordon on Samuel Noordhoff, founder of the Noordhoff Craniofacial Foundation, for his devoted service to local citizens over the past four decades.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian accepts Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare's apology for his government's recent mistakes in handling relations with the Republic of China.
2001: International scholars on Dunhuang studies (Buddhist arts and artifacts uncovered in grottoes on the western frontier of ancient China) attend a two-day conference Nov. 2-3 at Chung Cheng University in Chiayi, central Taiwan.
2001: Ted Lipman, the representative of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei, flies to Kinmen to study the operation of the "mini three links" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. The "mini three links" refers to direct trade, transportation and postal service between Kinmen and the mainland Chinese city of Xiamen in Fujian province, as well as between the Taiwan-held frontline island of Matsu and the mainland Chinese city of Mawei in Fujian province.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "If you know that something is unrighteous, then put an end to it with all dispatch; why wait till next year?"

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS SUBJECT TO 14 ANTI-DUMPING INVESTIGATIONS FROM JAN-JUNE
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Nov. 1 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked second among all countries and customs territories in terms of the number of anti-dumping investigations initiated against its exports in the first half of this year, according to World Trade Organization (WTO) statistics released Monday.

A total of 14 anti-dumping investigations were initiated by other WTO members against Taiwan exports in the Jan.-June period. Mainland China's exports topped the list with 23 investigations, up from 17 for the same period the previous year, according to the statistics.

Sixteen WTO members initiated a total of 101 anti-dumping investigations in the first half of 2004, up slightly from the 98 initiated for the same period a year earlier. A total of 23 countries or customs territories encountered anti-dumping investigations against their exports.

The United States led with 21 anti-dumping investigations initiated during the first half of 2004, followed by the European Union and Turkey, with 13 investigations each. Mainland China initiated 11 investigations during the same period.

The largest number of anti-dumping investigations initiated during the Jan.-June involved products classified in the base metals sector, at 20 investigations, followed by the chemicals and plastics sector at 18, and the textiles sector at 15, according to the statistics.

During the period, 18 WTO members imposed a total of 52 "final anti-dumping measures" against exports from 24 countries or customs territories, representing a significant decline from the 114 final anti-dumping measures imposed for the same period a year earlier.
Mainland China once again topped the list in terms of the number of final anti-dumping measures imposed against its exports at 16.

Nevertheless, the WTO said the same day that "the statistics are based on information from WTO members having submitted semi-annual reports to the WTO anti-dumping committee for the relevant periods, and are incomplete to the extent that members have not submitted reports or have submitted incomplete reports."

DOC.HEADLINE: DIPLOMATIC STRAITS TO BE WEIGHED IN CAL PRIVATIZATION DRIVE: YU

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday that the government policy of privatizing state-owned enterprises will remain unchanged, but he added that the nation's diplomatic predicament will be taken into account in privatizing China Airlines (CAL).

Yu made the remarks after Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said a day earlier that the government will review its policy of privatizing China Airlines, Taiwan's largest air carrier, because Taiwan must have a national carrier. Lin's statement has caused concern about the possibility of the government making an about-face regarding its privatizing policy.
Yu said the government will not backpedal on its privatization policy because continuity and consistency have been important elements in its policy formulation.
"The government will do its utmost to privatize all state-owned enterprises in line with its established policy," Yu said.

Nevertheless, he said, the government has to work out a special schedule and formula for the CAL privatization in consideration of Taiwan's diplomatic constraints caused by Beijing's unrelenting efforts to suppress the island in the international arena.

Over the years, Yu said, China Airlines has offered convenient flight services for outbound Taiwan citizens. In view of mainland China's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, he said, the government must conduct a careful review of the situation before fully privatizing the carrier.
