DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY TO LAUNCH SERVICES NEXT OCTOBER AS SCHEDULED

TEXT.P: The high-speed railway will begin operating in October 2005 as scheduled despite delays caused by electrical system problems, Taiwan High Speed Rail Co. (THSRC) officials said Tuesday.
The company made the clarification after Japanese media had reported that the launch date was likely to be postponed to 2006 owing to the electrical system problems.

Chiang Chin-shan, a public relations officer at the THSRC, admitted that the company has postponed trial runs originally set for late October because the electrical system work has not yet been completed.
However, Chiang added that the delay will not affect the launch of high-speed rail services in October of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA FORMS SPECIAL TASK FORCE TO KEEP ABREAST OF U.S. ELECTION

TEXT.P: With the U.S. presidential race in the home stretch, the Minisry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday it has formed a special task force to monitor the latest developments in the U.S. political arena.

Speaking at a regular news conference, MOFA deputy spokeswoman Anna Kao said Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen himself serves as convener of the special task force whose members include Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau and officials of relevant MOFA departments.

"The special task force has been closely monitoring the developments in the U.S. presidential race and will keep close contact with a similar election watch team at our representative office in Washington, D.C., " Kao said, adding that the task force will also maintain contact with key members of both the Republican and Democratic campaign headquarters.

Kao said the MOFA will come up with a comprehensive report on the possible developments in Taiwan-U.S. relations in the wake of the election in terms of either the re-election of President George W. Bush or the victory of his challenger, Sen. John Kerry of the Democratic Party.
The report will also outline the Republic of China representative office's future work agenda and prospects, Kao said.

Moreover, he said, the MOFA has prepared two different congratulatory message versions. When the U.S. election outcome is announced, the MOFA will direct the ROC representative to the United States, David Ta-wei Lee, to forward the congratulatory message to the U.S. government, he said.

In preparation for possible changes in U.S. personnel in charge of Taiwan affairs in the wake of the presidential election, Kao said, the MOFA has begun efforts to understand and develop contacts with influential members of both the Bush and Kerry camps.

DOC.HEADLINE: KERRY WOULD FOLLOW EXISTING U.S. TAIWAN POLICY: FORMER U.S. OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The results of the U.S. presidential election are not expected to affect Washington's policy toward Taiwan, a visiting former senior White House official said Tuesday.

Kenneth Lieberthal, former Senior Director for Asia of the National Security Council, who is now one of the top aides to Democratic presidential candidate John Kerry, made the remarks during an interview with Taiwanese media, after attending a symposium in Taipei on mainland China's grassroots democracy.
Lieberthal pointed out that Kerry has said he will comply with the existing policy of the United States toward Taiwan if he is elected the next president.
However, Lieberthal said incumbent President George W. Bush has toughened its stand toward Taiwan, which he said indicates Bush's changeability and his frustration over the cross-strait issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. RELATIONS WILL BE SOLID AFTER NOV. 2 ELECTION: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The fundamentals between Taiwan and the United States are good, and the outcome of the U.S. presidential election will not affect Taipei-Washington relations, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday.
The premier made the remarks while fielding questions at a general question and answer session at the Legislative Yuan.

Yu said that it would be inappropriate for Taiwan to comment on the U.S. election, adding that Taiwan has always maintained good relations with the United States, and this will not change regardless who the next president is.

Touching on recent remarks regarding Taiwan by U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell, the premier said that the U.S. State Department has clarified his words inasmuch as when Powell advocated cross- strait "reunification" as a goal that both sides desire, he actually meant a "settlement."

In addition, the premier said Powell had spoken positively of Taiwan during his recent Asian visit, including continuing arms sales to Taiwan despite pressure from mainland China, and telling mainland Chinese leaders to seize the opportunity for negotiations that President Chen Shui-bian made during his May 20 second inauguration address to resume bilateral dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER ASKS KMT TO APOLOGIZE AND REPAY MONEY TO BANK OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) on Tuesday asked the Kuomintang (KMT) to apologize to the public and return the money it owes the Bank of Taiwan, while the KMT said the delay in repayment has been caused by its dire financial straits.

TSU Legislator Chen Chien-ming noted that KMT officials have long been able to enjoy a premium 18 percent deposit rate at the Bank of Taiwan, with the KMT paying 16.5 percent of the interest and the bank paying the other 1.5 percent. However, as the party has not been remitting the money for the 16.5 percent interest payments to the bank since the March 20 presidential election, it now owes the bank an accumulated NT$300 million (US$8.64 million) for the KMT officials' deposits.

Chen questioned why the KMT officials enjoy such a premium deposit rate when the average citizen only gets a deposit rate of around 1.5 percent for a one-year term deposit. He urged the KMT to face the issue squarely, apologize to the people soon, and return the due interest payments.

In response to reports that the Bank of Taiwan plans to seek repayment from the KMT and to terminate its contract with the party, a KMT official said it is still actively coordinating with the bank on repaying the money.

Lin Yung-jui, deputy director of the KMT administrative management committee, said the party is still discussing with the bank on how to repay the money, adding that there are no plans to terminate the contract.

Liu Chien-sung, president of the KMT workers guild, said the party, in order to take care of party officials who retired before Feb. 28, 1997, signed a contract with the Bank of Taiwan to allow the retirees the same premium treatment given by the government to retired servicemen, civil servants and teachers, meaning an 18 percent deposit rate for deposits of up to NT$1.8 million.

Liu said that the NT$300 million is only the "tip of the iceberg" of the party's financial difficulties, noting that the KMT officials who retired in August have yet to get their retirement payments, while those who retired in September were asked to wait for the payments, with no interest payments during the waiting period.
Meanwhile, the TSU also pointed out the problem of the veterans over claiming subsidies for up to NT$12.2 billion over a period of more than a decade.

Due to negligence on the part of Veterans Affairs Commission (VAC) officials, Legislator Chen Chien-ming said 6,700 veterans who are not qualified to claim subsidies have received a monthly stipend of NT$13,550, or around NT$180,000 a year for more than 10 years, resulting in losses amounting to NT$12.2 billion to the national coffers.
Chen asked the VAC to review the situation, seek to return the money, and punish the negligent officials over the matter.
In response, the VAC said that the veterans that are put on the list to receive subsidies for 2005 has already been cut.

VAC officials said that with veterans aging and passing away, and with some others who no longer require subsidies due to the improvement of their lives, the number of veterans who will be on the subsidized list will be 98,000 in 2005, down 6,700 from 2004.

The officials said the commission regularly checks the status of the veterans and will stop subsidies once their lives are improved. The VAC will ask local veteran service centers and nursing homes to step up verification of the conditions of the veterans.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST TAIWANESE LITERATURE SEMINAR IN FRANCE SET TO OPEN NOV. 2

TEXT.P: An international seminar will begin Nov. 2 in France to discuss Taiwanese literature and the current situations of its research and reception around the world.

The three-day seminar is jointly organized by the Center of Studies and Researches on the Far East (CEREO) of Universite Michel de Montaign -- Bordeaux 3, France, and the Institute of Chinese Literature and Philosophy of Academia Sinica, Taiwan.

According to Angel Pino, director of the CEREO, the center is the first French academic institution to do research on Taiwanese literature. This is also the first time that such an international seminar will be held in France to discuss Taiwanese literature.

In 1998, Prof. Pierre Trolliet of the Institute of Oriental Languages in Paris, had held a seminar to discuss Taiwanese culture, including paintings and movies, but he did not touch on literature topics during the occasion.

According to the organizers, a total of 20 scholars from Taiwan, France, Germany and Singapore will participate in the seminar to be held at International Maison of pole universitaire europeen in Bordeaux.
Four prominent Taiwanese writers have been invited to attend the seminar and to meet with local readers at bookstores in Bordeaux and in Paris.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 103.44 points to close at 5,759.61.
The bourse opened at 5,670.77 and fluctuated between 5,759.61 and 5,648.29 during trading. A total of 2.56 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$56.86 billion (US$1.69 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 2.6 percent, followed by cement stocks at 2.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 2.3 percent, construction issues at 1.5 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.8 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 521 to 138, with 125 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Ukrainian Candidates One Point Apart.
Less than one percentage point separated Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovych and opposition leader Viktor Yushchenko in preliminary results Monday, sending Ukraine's presidential election into a runoff that looked set to be decided by who picks up the left-wing vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: STABILITY IS TOP PRIORITY IN CROSS-STRAIT TIES: LIEBERTHAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan and mainland China should make stability their current top priority and put aside the pursuit of a "peaceful resolution" of cross-strait disputes for the future, a visiting former senior White House official said Tuesday.

Kenneth Lieberthal, former Senior Director for Asia of the National Security Council, made the remarks during an interview with Taiwanese media, after attending a symposium in Taipei on grassroots democracy on the mainland. Lieberthal is now one of the top aides to Democratic presidential candidate John Kerry.
Lieberthal said long-lasting peace and stability should be the main topic for discussion in the case of resumption of cross-strait dialogue.
However, with the large number of disagreements existing between both sides, they should prioritize the quest for stability by building up mutual trust and increasing exchanges, Lieberthal said.
Without mutual trust, it would be impossible for both sides to reach a "peaceful resolution" on their political disputes, according to Lieberthal.
He again proposed that Taipei and Beijing sign an interim agreement for maintaining the status quo of cross-strait relations for 50 years to pave the way for further negotiations on disputed issues.

He said the United States is obliged by the Taiwan Relations Act to provide Taiwan with defensive weapons against possible invasion from the mainland, and Washington will respect the decision by Taipei and Beijing if they are able to reach an agreement on security issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.022 to close at NT$33.482.
A total of US$607 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$33.561 and hit a low of NT$33.384.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECCT TO SEEK E.U. BACKING FOR TAIWAN WHO BID: CEPD

TEXT.P: The European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) will relay Taiwan's desire to join the World Health Organization (WHO) to the European Union (EU) next week when it pays a visit to E.U. headquarters in Brussels, according to a government official.
Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , made the remarks Monday during a meeting with an ECCT delegation led by Chairman Paul Zeven.

Zeven submitted a proposal report to Hu thanking the Taiwan administration's efforts in improving the domestic investment climate over the past year and said that the ECCT will suggest that the E.U. support Taiwan's bid to join the WHO when it visits its headquarters in Brussels next week.
It would benefit both the Taiwan people and European business interests should Taiwan gain membership at the WHO, ECCT officials said.
By request of the ECCT, the CEPD will call an inter-ministerial coordination meeting in the near future to further study allowing more mainland professional talent to work in Taiwan, Hu said.

Claiming that the government always attaches a great importance to foreign companies' suggestions, Hu said that relevant government agencies will cooperate in granting a greater access to professionals from mainland China or mainland spouses and children of foreign managers to stay in Taiwan.
At the same time, the threshold for foreign students to receive training in Taiwan will also be further reviewed, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PEACE AND STABILITY FRAMEWORK' SIMILAR TO INTERIM PACT: MAC

TEXT.P: The concept of establishing a dynamic "peace and stability framework" for interactions across the Taiwan Strait is similar to that of signing a cross-strait interim agreement, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday.

Wu made the remarks in a keynote speech delivered at an international symposium on grassroots democracy in mainland China, organized by the Institute of International Relations at National Chengchi University.

According to Wu, the proposal of forging a viable "peace and stability framework" for cross-strait interactions broached in President Chen Shui-bian's second inaugural address is similar to that of signing a cross-strait interim accord advocated by Kenneth Lieberthal, a U.S. political science professor who once served as senior director for Asia at the National Security Council.

The nation's top mainland policy planner said Taiwan intensely hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can resume dialogue on non-political issues and mutually beneficial topics to forge a cooperative rather than confrontational relationship and create an environment conducive to the establishment of a dynamic "peace and stability framework" for bilateral interactions.
Noting that Taiwan has been endeavoring to establish an accountable and efficient political system, Wu said smooth regular political elections indicate that Taiwan has become a liberal democracy.

Wu said Taiwan has continued pursuing measures to enhance its governing efficiency, including a constitutional re-engineering plan. The legislative reform program passed by the Legislative Yuan in August was part of the constitutional re-engineering plan, Wu said, adding that he hopes the United States can understand Taiwan's efforts to deepen and consolidate its young democracy.
"Taiwan has been inspired by the United States to develop a democratic system and we hope to catch up with the United States in democratic development," Wu said.

However, Wu said, Taiwan's "democracy-deepening" drive is facing challenges from mainland China. "We look forward to holding direct dialogue and consultations with mainland China without setting any prerequisites or premises so as to foster mutual understanding and trust," he added.

Speaking on the same occasion, Lieberthal, who arrived in Taipei Monday for a four-day visit, said mainland China has not been democratized but nor is it a completely totalitarian regime. From Taiwan's and South Korea's experiences, Lieberthal said, mainland China will eventually move toward democratization if it can continue economic liberalization and openness.

In his view, Lieberthal, now a professor of political science at the University of Michigan, said mainland China should not regard global interdependence as a threat and should instead take it as an opportunity.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES SOAR ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market soared Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November gained 134 points to close at 5,751, with 31,618 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December moved up 118 points to finish at 5,747, with 206 contracts traded, while March futures gained 109 points to finish at 5,720, with seven contracts traded.
June futures gained 64 points to finish at 5,715, with nine contracts traded, while September futures surged 118 points to close at 5,630, with six contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,617 for November, 5,629 for December, 5,611 for March, 5,651 for June and 5,512 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

November TE futures moved up 6.3 points to close at 211.95, with 6,047 contracts traded, while December TE futures gained 6.55 points to finish at 211.7, with 43 contract transactions and September TE futures lost 8.05 points to close at 200.05, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

November TF futures gained 14.8 points to end at 1,020.8 with 8,137 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved up 15.2 points to close at 1,019, with 117 contracts traded and March TF futures surged 6.2 points to close at 1,001, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SMOKING DRIVE LAUNCHED ON TAIWAN RAILWAYS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Administration and Department of Health have jointly hired 100 workers to promote non-smoking concepts among passengers at 60 railway stations around the island, officials said Tuesday.
According to the Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act passed in 1997, smoking is prohibited in a number of public establishments including public transportation facilities.
However, there are still passengers who violate the ban, and authorities have received 17 cases of public complaints about passengers smoking in railway stations or on train over past year.
The 100 workers will raise smokers' awareness to the hazards of second-hand smoke for non-smokers via questionnaires and advice, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOMINATIONS FOR FIRST PRESIDENTIAL AGRICULTURE AWARDS BEGIN

TEXT.P: To encourage public services to enhance agricultural standards, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture has organized a new award program, offering NT$1 million (US$29,880) to each winner.
Vice COA Chairman Lee Jen-chyuan announced Tuesday at a Taipei news conference that nominations for the first Presidential Agriculture Awards have already begun and will continue until Dec. 15.

He also said that a nominee can be an individual, a group or an institute, regardless of nationality, gender or age. However, the nomination can only be recommended by either governments or legally registered groups and institutes worldwide, he said.

The agricultural awards are divided into five categories, which include the Food Security Award, the Agricultural Innovation Award, the Agricultural Service Award, the Sustainable Development Award, and the Agricultural Equilibrium Award.

Lee said that the awards are aimed at honoring those who have made great contributions to agricultural development and innovation, or to rural development and international agricultural businesses, or those who are devoted to agricultural resources conservation.

For each category, a winner will be selected and then be awarded by President Chen Shui-bian. Aside from the NT$1 million, a certificate and a medal will be presented to the winners at a grand ceremony next Feb. 4, according to a COA statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTITUTION COULD BE REVISED OR REDONE FROM SCRATCH: PREMIER YU

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's proposal to introduce a "new version of the Constitution" could be attained either through amending the existing Constitution or drafting a completely new one, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday.

Speaking during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, Yu said the constitutional re-engineering project will be carried out in accordance with President Chen's second inaugural address on May 20.
If the reform is to be achieved via a referendum, the Constitution must first be amended to include referendums as a method for constitutional reform, Yu said.
In his second inaugural address, Chen said he hopes to hand to the people of Taiwan and the country "a new version of our Constitution" by the time he completes his presidency in 2008.
Chen said the government will follow the rules set out in the existing Constitution and its amendments while carrying out the plan.

After proposed amendments are passed by the Legislative Yuan, members of the ad hoc National Assembly will be elected and charged with the task of ratifying the proposed amendments, according to Chen's proposal.
The proposed amendments will cover one aimed at abolishing the National Assembly itself and incorporating into the Constitution the people's right to referendums on constitutional amendments.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS ALLIANCE CONFERENCE TO OPEN NOV. 8

TEXT.P: The 2004 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference will open Nov. 8 at the Taipei International Convention Center, organizers of the event said Tuesday.

They noted that the upcoming conference's topics will focus on three industrial fields where Taiwan enjoys great potential for developing leading businesses in the world market. The fields are biotechnological medicine, information services and semiconductor design.

The organizers also indicated that a news conference will be held a day before the conference opens, and that executives of large foreign investments on the island, such as Sony Taiwan Ltd. and Microsoft Taiwan Corporation, will be invited to share their successful investment experiences with local businesses at the news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT BILL FAILS TO BE PUT ON LEGISLATIVE AGENDA

TEXT.P: A draft bill to authorize a special budget for a major arms purchase from the United States failed to be put on the agenda for review in the Legislative Yuan Tuesday, dashing the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) hope of having the bill reviewed before the year-end legislative elections.

The DPP wanted to review the bill before the legislature goes into a one-month recess Nov. 10 to prepare for the Dec. 11 legislative elections. The budgets for the arms procurement can be reviewed when the legislators reconvene after the elections.

The "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) differed sharply on whether to put the bill on agenda.
DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung said that the arms purchase bill should be put on the legislative agenda Friday, and then undergo committee review.

But PFP Legislator Lee Yung-ping said that many legislators have made their support or opposition to the arms purchase part of their election platforms and that it makes more sense to see how the public reacts to these candidates, and this will be an indicator of public opinion on the issue for legislators to follow.

Serious sparring between the two camps erupted with both sides traded such barbs as "China party" and "warmongering party." The "pan-green camp" then bowed out in protest, and the "pan-blue alliance" voted to suspend the draft bill due to its majority.
Meanwhile, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said he "regretted" and "was very disappointed" to hear that the bill had failed to be put on the legislative agenda.

Yu also criticized KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong for "inconsistencies, " noting that arms procurement is crucial to national security and combat readiness is the best way to prevent war.

He noted that the arms purchase from the U.S. proposal was mapped out during the time when Lien served as premier, and that Soong supported arms procurements while running in the 2000 and 2004 presidential elections. They seem to think that "national security no longer matters after losing the elections," he added.
The premier promised that there will be no kickback for the arms procurement deal and that if there are violators, they will be severely dealt with.

The premier also said before he steps down in February in accordance with constitutional practice, the government will not increase taxes to finance the arms procurement, The Cabinet proposed in June for a special budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) to buy six batteries of anti-missile Patriot-III systems, eight diesel-fueled submarines and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft.
The budgets for the arms procurement will be paid over a 15-year period starting in 2005 and will not harm the expenditures for other social welfare items, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Gladiators of America prepare for their fate.
The high priests of polling ordained that George Bush and John Kerry should both hold last rallies next to each other under the cliffs of downtown Milwaukee yesterday -- Hector and Achilles finally meeting beneath the walls of Troy.
Financial Times: Kerry and Bush hunt down the last votes as polls open.
John Kerry and George W. Bush will continue campaigning well after Americans start voting on Tuesday, seeking to eke out any final advantage in a nation as evenly divided on election day as it was four years ago. In the first presidential election since terrorists struck on Sept. 11, 2001, the argument of the election year was distilled into a clear-cut disagreement over who is better able to keep America safe.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA HOPES TO WIN RIGHT TO HOST 2008 WORLD HAIRDRESSING CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Tuesday expressed hope that Taiwan can win the right to host the world hairdressing championship in 2008.

Hsu Cheng-chi, executive secretary-general of MOFA's NGO Affairs Committee, noted that Taiwan hairdressers will take part in Hairworld 2004, which will be held in Milan, Italy Nov. 6-8, for the first time.
Hsu expressed the hope that Taiwan participants can perform well during the event, often dubbed the Olympics for coiffure, so that Taiwan might be able to host the 2008 contest.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TRUTH COMMISSION' MEMBERS VISIT INVESTIGATION BUREAU

TEXT.P: Members of the "319 Truth Commission" paid a visit to the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) Tuesday in the hope of gaining an understanding of the current state of the bureau's investigations into the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.

Wang Ching-feng, spokeswoman for the controversial commission created under the authorization of the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan to investigate the shooting a day before the March 20 presidential election, said the commission wants to know whether the MJIB received any information ahead of the shooting of Chen on the campaign trail in the southern city of Tainan, as well as its role in the probe of the incident.
"We also hope to know the working situation of the special '319' investigative team and the investigative procedures in the wake of the incident," Wang explained.

MJIB Director Yeh Mao-sheng and other bureau officials warmly received the commission members, headed by Shih Chi-yang, convener of the "319 Truth Commission" who once served as president of the Judicial Yuan.
Wang told the media after the visit that on the eve of the election, a dark-blue van was parked at the intersection of Chinhua Road and Yunghua Road in Tainan near the scene of the shooting.

"As the place was on the route to be taken by President Chen's motorcade, the vehicle was supposed to have been moved in advance. However, the van stayed there even after the shooting. It was decorated with Chen's campaign banners, " Wang claimed, adding that the truth commission will offer NT$100,000 as a reward to whoever can provide leads that prove helpful in investigating the so-called "suspicious van."

Responding to the truth commission's appeal, however, the law enforcement team already investigating the shooting issued a press statement saying that the van had been ruled out of connections with the incident.

The team said the van belongs to a volunteer firefighter in Tainan surnamed Lee. It joined the street parade at Minghsing Road without prior approval and thus was stopped by traffic police and ordered to park at the entrance to No. 2, Sec. 3, Chinhua Road.
"Neither the investigative team nor the Criminal Investigation Bureau have ever received any inquiries from the truth commission about the van," the press statement said.

Meanwhile, the investigation bureau renewed its call for local people to provide leads or clues to locate a "suspicious man dressed in gray" who was shown on video monitors to be at the "hot area" on the day. The bureau said it would offer NT$53 million as a reward to whoever provides useful leads to help resolve the mysterious case.

Chen won re-election a day after the shooting that mildly gazed his abdomen. Without providing any evidence, his challenger, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, insinuated that the shooting was staged by Chen to win sympathy votes. Lien has filed two lawsuits to invalidate Chen's re-election victory and even the entire election so that a new one can be held. The Taiwan High Court will announce its verdict on the election victory annulment suit this Thursday.

Meanwhile, the Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) is scheduled to announce its interpretation of the legality and constitutionality of the "truth commission" in two months. The Cabinet claims that the truth commission is unlawful and unconstitutional and thus applied for a CGJ interpretation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES S.E. ASIA WILL OPEN FINANCIAL SERVICES TO FOREIGN FIRMS

TEXT.P: Taiwan expects Southeast Asian governments to further open their financial services sectors in line with World Trade Organization (WTO) criteria by allowing Taiwanese firms to operate in their countries, Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) officials said Tuesday.
According to the BOFT, Taiwan has engaged in more than 40 rounds of bilateral talks with other WTO member nations on the issue of market opening since 2002.

Huang Li-huei, deputy director of the BOFT's Multilateral Trade Affairs Division, said the government has requested that Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand allow Taiwanese securities firms to set up branch offices and subsidiaries there, and that Singapore has promised to ease its restrictions on foreign securities firms.

As far as the insurance sector is concerned, Taiwan has negotiated with Malaysia, Hong Kong, the Philippines and Thailand in the hope that Taiwanese insurance companies will be allowed to establish offices there, Huang said.

In the area of banking services, Taiwan has asked Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines to relax their restrictions on foreign banks intending to set up branch offices in their countries, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ROLE AS ASIAN FLU VACCINATION OUTPUT HUB UNDER PROJECTION

TEXT.P: A project to make Taiwan into a production hub for flu vaccinations in Asia has gained approval from the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), a council spokesman said Tuesday.

According to the CEPD spokesman, the project put forward by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH) , which was approved a day earlier by the CEPD, outlines four major development directions and will require a budget of as much as NT$6 billion (US$179 million).

As Taiwan is not a member to the World Health Organization (WHO), the country has to heed its special needs for the sake of its people's health should a global flu outbreak occur and Taiwan receives no assistance from the international organization, the spokesman said.

The flu vaccination plan is aimed mainly at providing the Taiwan people with sufficient injections to secure their health in case of an epidemic and secondly to promote Taiwan as a production base for flu vaccine, he said.

WHO assessments show that some 1.2 billion people in the world belong to a high-risk group prone to flu infection. But in 2002, only about 263 million vaccinations were provided to these people, according to the WHO report.

To mend a similar gap in Taiwan, the government hopes to implement its vaccine hub plan, in addition to purchasing flu vaccine from both home and abroad, the volume of which amounted to more than 2 million vaccinations per year, falling short of the country's overall need of between 3.5 million and 4 million injections, he said.
Of this 4 million, around 1 million are to satisfy the demand from the public willing to pay for vaccination by themselves, he noted.
The CDC project also suggests forging joint ventures or mergers between local and foreign companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROCSAT PROGRAM MAINLY FOR SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday that ROCSAT-II is an upper atmospheric satellite mainly for the purpose of scientific research and environmental monitoring.

The premier made the remarks as he was fielding questions in a general interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan when Legislator Chiu Yung-jen of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party asked if the satellite program could be used for military purposes in view of the military threat from mainland China.
The premier said that if there is a national security need, military use for the satellite could also be considered.
National Science Council Chairman Wu Mao-kun also said the ROCSAT-III will be used to get complete atmospheric information and to provide more precise forecasting of the direction of typhoons.

ROCSAT-II, which was launched early this year, is part of the government's 15-year space technology development plan implemented in 1991 and focusing on three satellites with different missions. ROCSAT-I was launched in 1999 and ROCSAT-III is scheduled to lift off in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE WOMEN MARRYING OLDER: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The average age at which Taiwanese women get married has been increasing over the years, with 53.2 percent of women between 25 to 29 years old remaining single from 2001 to 2003, according to a report released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The figure is 14.7 percentage points higher than the levels of the 1990s, according to the report.
In line with the rise in marriage age, the average age at which women give birth to their first child is also rising.
While women gave birth to their first child at the average age of 25.2 in 1993, the average age was 26.7 in 2003, according to the report.
Meanwhile, the birth rate continues to fall, with only 48.7 percent of the babies born in 2003 being second or later children, compared with 56.3 percent in 1993.
The birth rate was registered at 1.2 children per woman in 2003, the report shows.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARENTS CULPRITS IN MOST CHILD ABUSE CASES: MOI

TEXT.P: Biological or non-biological parents were the culprits in more than 70 percent of the child abuse cases reported in the first half of this year, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Tuesday.

MOI tallies show that county and city governments around the island received a total of 8,418 reports of child abuse in the first half of this year, with Taipei County accounting for the most with 1,743 cases.

Among them, 3,877 were confirmed as abuse cases, with 3,008 involving children aged under 12 and 869 involving children aged between 12 and 18. Of the victims, 860 resided in Taipei County, 472 in Taichung County and 371 in Kaohsiung County.
In terms of the forms of abuse, physical abuse accounted for the most at 30 percent, followed by negligence at 27 percent and mental abuse at 10 percent.
Biological or adoptive parents were the culprits in 78 percent of the confirmed cases, followed by caregivers at 5 percent and relatives at 3.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSCD SIGNS MOUS WITH JAPANESE COUNTERPARTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Securities Central Depository Co. (TSCD) signed memorandums of understanding (MOUs) on cooperation Tuesday with Japan Securities Settlement and Custody Inc. (JSSC) and the Japan Securities Depository Center (JSDC).

The signing ceremony was held in Taipei. TSCD President Chu Fu-chun, JSSC President Toshitsugu Shimizu and JSDC President Yoshinobu Takeuchi inked the documents to signify a new era of cooperation between the Taiwan and Japan stock markets.

According to the terms of the MOUs, all the parties involved agree to make more efforts to improve bilateral operating procedures for mutual benefit and in order to contribute to the development of the two countries' financial services.
They will also conduct personnel exchanges, provide training courses for each other, maintain information exchange channels and build up online operations to facilitate efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: G.O.P. in Ohio Can Challenge Voters at Polls.
In a day of see-sawing court rulings, a Federal appeals court ruled early Tuesday morning that the Republican Party could place thousands of people inside polling places to challenge the eligibility of voters, a blow to Democrats who argued those challengers will intimidate minority voters.
The Wall Stree Journal: Bush, Kerry Make Final Push.
Bush and Kerry played a last frenzied game of aerial hopscotch over a well-traversed battleground map before leaving the field to get-out-the-vote troops who will try to produce turnout of a size that could scramble the picture of stalemate polls paint.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELEASE OF ANIMALS INTO WILD TO BE BANNED

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed the first reading of a draft revision to the existing animal protection law Tuesday to ban the release of animals into the wild as a so-called "charitable" act.

Legislator Lu Po-chi of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, who initiated the draft revision bill, said he hopes the legislature can complete a third reading of the bill and make it law as early as possible to better protect wildlife and natural ecology.

Some religious groups advocate the release of captive animals into the wild -- an activity they see as an "act of charity" and have sponsored large-scale animal release campaigns in recent years. However, Lu pointed out that such activities have prompted unscrupulous businessmen to capture local birds or import rare birds from abroad. Sometimes, Lu said, religious followers even purchase protected species on the black market for their wildlife release rituals. Most of the animals die, as they are unable to survive in the wild.

Quoting the results of a survey by an animal research association, Lu said nearly 60 percent of the birds sold at 155 local bird shops surveyed were captured by hunters hired by shop owners for sale to religious followers.
The association spent two years surveying 155 bird shops in Taipei County, Taipei City, Taichung City, Taichung County, Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County.

According to the report released by the association, at least 600,000 birds have been injured or have died in the process of capture and transportation before ever being "release into the wild" by religious followers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME FOR PEOPLE TO LEARN TO ISSUE MANDATES: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: After going through three direct presidential elections, now is the time for the people of Taiwan to learn how to really issue mandates in a democracy, President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday,
Chen, who also serves as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), made the comments in a weekly meeting of the party's Central Standing Committee.

Now that the country has already held three presidential elections, now is the time for its people to learn how to be the boss in a democratic society in which obligations and rights, freedom and responsibilities, go hand in hand, Chen said.

Stressing that all nationals should be united once an election is over, Chen said that the highest value of a democracy lies in the fact that the people are entitled to make their own choice every time there is an election.

In the wake of his March 20 presidential election, the president said, he outlined four major goals -- national unity, cross-Taiwan Strait peace, social stability and economic prosperity -- as the government's focal policies during his second four-year term, in an effort to fend off a larger conflict in society due to the election outcome.

He said he hopes to help lay a sound foundation for national solidarity and democratic progress and pointed out that Taiwan's continued development should take precedence over personal gains or a party's benefits.

"The DPP is determined to do its utmost to cement Taiwan's democratization and turn it into a normal nation by overcoming ethnic differences and political unfairness with respect and understanding, " he claimed, adding that " Taiwan will never walk back along its old path in its search for a profound transformation."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EXPECTS NO CHANGE IN U.S. TAIWAN POLICY AFTER ELECTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday he believes that U.S. policy toward Taiwan and mainland China will not change, no matter who wins the U.S. presidential election.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with visiting members of a pro-Taiwan group in the European Parliament, the legislative arm of the 25-state European Union.

"I think countries around the world are all concerned about the U.S. presidential election. The outcome of the race will become clear between 8 a.m. and 10 a.m. Wednesday (Taipei time) but I believe that no matter who wins, U.S. policy regarding the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will remain unchanged," Chen told his guests.

Chen expressed his gratitude for the European Parliament's encouragement and support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) and the World Health Assembly (WHA) , and he said he hopes Taiwan can realize its goal of becoming an observer in the WHA -- the WHO's governing body -- in the near future, so that Taiwan does not become a hole in the global anti-pandemic network.

Praising the European Parliament for its opposition to the lifting of a 15-year-old E.U. ban on arms sales to mainland China due to Beijing's poor human rights record, Chen also thanked the European Parliament for its call for Beijing to remove the hundreds of missiles it has deployed against Taiwan and to resolve cross-strait disputes through peaceful dialogue with Taiwan.

The delegation was headed by Georg Jarzembowski, chairman of the pro-Taiwan group in the European Parliament, and its members included Aloyzas Sakalas, vice chairman of the pro-Taiwan group, as well as European Parliament members Philip Claeys, Ryszard Czarnecki and Amneli Jaatteenmaki.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND LAMENTS ARMS PACKAGE FAILURE AT LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) lamented Tuesday the failure of a legislative committee to put a high-profile arms procurement budget plan on its agenda for review, and called for public support for the program.

The MND made the comments in a statement issued shortly after its budget draft to buy defensive weapons from the United States failed to clear the National Defense Committee under the Legislative Yuan.

Stating that national security is everyone's obligation regardless of his or her political stance, the MND said, it deeply regrets that the draft arms purchase budgets, worth a total of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion ) , missed the chance of being rationally discussed in the legislature.

Maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait is in the best interests of both Taiwan and the United States, and a weak national defense will eventually take its toll on Taiwan's 23 million people and the nation's sovereignty, the MND said, urging the public to support the weapons procurement plan that it claims will safeguard the country.

Only a capable national defense will provide full security for Taiwan's people and the military buildup needs their backing, it said, adding that "cowards do not deserve peace" and that "strength is the best weapon at the negotiating table."

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR NOV. 3 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, Nov. 3:
09: 00, The weekly Cabinet meeting will be held at the Executive Yuan.
09:00, The Legislative Yuan's various committees will start their sessions for the day.
09: 20, The 2004 Taiwan Technomart will open at the Taipei World Trade Center.
11: 00, Former President Lee Teng-hui will officiate at the commencement of a workshop at the Lee Teng-hui School for Japanese to be held at the Taiwan Advocates offices in Tamsui, Taipei County.
12: 30, A keynote speech on cross-Taiwan Strait peace and development will be held at the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China.

14: 00, A seminar on the regulations and laws relating to the digital content industry development on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be held at the Information Service Industry Association of the ROC.
14: 30, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will chair an interministerial conference on maintaining the social order at the Executive Yuan.
15:00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive alumni of Ketagalan Institute's courses for national leadership and development strategy at the Presidential Office.
15: 00, A roundtable seminar on the 2004 U.S. presidential election will be held at the Institute of International Relations of National Chengchi University.
16: 00, The Insurance Bureau under the Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SUSTAINABLE HEALTH INDUSTRY PROMISING: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's sustainable health industry is promising, based on a domestic market scale of NT$1 trillion (US$29.85 billion), a public health expert said Tuesday.

Wang Jung-der, dean of the Public Health College of National Taiwan University, said that the output of the domestic medical and health service industry totaled NT$450 billion in 2001, while the production of the foodstuff and beverage industries amounted to NT$380 billion.
The total production of the sustainable health industry will top NT$1 trillion if the figures include the output of the beauty and fitness service industry, Wang predicted.
The Institute for Biotechnology and Medicine Industry has organized the Sustainable Health Trend Show 2004 at the Taipei World Trade Center Nov. 5-7 to promote the industry's development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Nov. 3, or the 21st day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1493: Christopher Columbus discovers the island of Dominica.
1839: The Opium War breaks out between China's Ching dynasty and Britain.
1852: Emperor Meiji of Japan is born. During his rule, he moved the capital from Kyoto to Edo, which he renamed Tokyo.
1903: Panama declares independence from Colombia.
1912: Former Paraguayan President Alfredo Stroessner is born.
1917: The Bolsheviks seize supreme power in Russia.
1925: The Soviet Union founds the Sun Yat-sen University in Moscow.
1937: The Nine-Power Conference opens in Brussels to mediate the Sino-Japanese War. The mediation talks later failed.
1949: Japanese nuclear scientist Hideki Yukawa wins the Nobel Prize in physics. He was the first Japanese citizen to win the laureateship.
1957: The Soviet Union fires the Sputnik II satellite into orbit with a dog on board.
1958: The Chinese communists fire 36,000 artillery shells at Kinmen, the Kuomintang-held frontline island opposite Fujian Province.
1965: Peng Ming-min, a political dissenter who was given an eight-year prison term, is granted amnesty by Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek.
1966: Lin Yueh-sheng, assistant managing editor and city editor of the Wen Wei Pao, a Hong Kong-based pro-Beijing newspaper, defects to Taiwan.
1972: The ROC approves a US$36.3 million Ford Motor Company investment project to manufacture cars and engines in Taiwan.
1973: El Salvadoran Foreign Minister Mauricio Alfredo Borgonovo Pohl arrives in the ROC for a three-day visit.
1974: Former Colombian President Misael Pastrana Borrero arrives in the ROC for a six-day visit.
1975: A three-day educational conference opens in Taipei with some 120 educators, specialists, and senior administrators participating.
1977: The Department of Environmental Sanitation of Taipei City begins the monitoring of air and water pollution.
1978: The Legislative Yuan approves revision of regulations concerning the appointment of public functionaries under the job classification system.
1987: ROC literary master Liang Shih-chiu dies at the age of 85.
1988: The Mainland Affairs Council approves a revision in regulations allowing mainland compatriots to visit sick relatives or attend their funerals in Taiwan.
1998: Hurricane Mitch hits Central America and the Caribbean, killing 25,000 and leaving 2.78 million homeless.
1999: The name of the Republic of China's representative office in Thailand is formally changed to the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Thailand.
2000: National Taiwan University President Chen Wei-chao confers an outstanding alumni award on Chen Pei-hong, president of U.S.-based Broadvision Co., for his outstanding contributions to information technology.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian launches a self-penned book titled "The Premiere Voyage of the Century: Reflections on the Party's 500 Days of Transition" about his first 500 days in office at anews conference, calling it an accounting to himself, to the people and to history.
2001: Fredrick Chien, president of the Control Yuan, leaves for New York as President Chen Shui-bian's special envoy to pay homage to those killed in the terroist attacks on the World Trade Center on September 11.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "All men have a mind which cannot bear (to see the sufferings of) others."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ESTABLISHES FORMAL DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH VANUATU

TEXT.P: The Republic of China established formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of Vanuatu Wednesday, Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen announced at a press conference held in the morning.
Taiwan began to engage in "mutual recognition" relations with the southwest Pacific nation in September 1992. Vanuatu had maintained formal diplomatic ties with mainland China since March 1982.
After nearly 80 years of joint French and British colonial administration, Vanuatu became an independent nation on July 30, 1980, changing its official designation to Vanuatu from New Hebrides.

Located between Australia and Fiji, Vanuatu has a population of about 210,000, with some 3,000 people of Taiwanese or Chinese origin. Over 100 hundred languages are spoken in Vanuatu, with Bislama, a type of pidgin English that combines mainly English words and Melanesian grammar, being commonly used throughout the country.
A member of the United Nations, Vanuatu is also a member of the South Pacific Forum and the South Pacific Commission.
An agricultural country, Vanuatu exports dried coconut meat, coconut oil, cocoa and beef. Its major trade partners include France, the United States, Japan and Australia.
Two-way trade between Taiwan and Vanuatu stood at US$6.4 million in 2001, with Taiwan's exports to the country totaling US$5.6 million.
Chen's announcement of the establishment of diplomatic ties with Vanuatu increases the number of nations with which the ROC maintains formal diplomatic relations to 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELITE OVERSEAS STUDY PROGRAM TO KICK OFF AS EARLY AS NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Under a government program to send elite students abroad for advanced study, the first group of such students could be heading overseas to top-notch universities and research institutes in early 2005, the Ministry of Education (MOE) said Wednesday.
Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng said the program will cover students in three major areas -- namely basic sciences, humanities and social sciences, and key technology fields.

Students in the program can receive scholarships of US$30,000 per year. Those studying humanities or social sciences can receive scholarships for three years, while those studying natural sciences are encouraged to apply for scholarships at their schools during the second year of study, he said.
Tu noted that his ministry, the National Science Council (MSC), and the Council for Economic Planning and Development will jointly put forward NT$450 million (US$13.43 million) for the program.

The MOE and the NSC will jointly use two-thirds of the budget to select students for advanced studies overseas, while colleges and the universities will use the remaining one-third to select students for priority subjects.
Hu stressed that the program is aimed at nurturing talent to meet expected demand between 2010 and 2015 in national development, including industrial development.

DOC.HEADLINE: VANUATU BECOMES ROC'S 27TH DIPLOMATIC ALLY

TEXT.P: The government of the south Pacific nation of Vanuatu forged a communique with the Republic of China government on the establishment of formal diplomatic relations Wednesday, becoming the 27th diplomatic ally of Taiwan.

Visiting Vanuatuan Prime Minister Serge Vohor and ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen jointly signed the communique on behalf of their respective countries based on the principles of equality and reciprocity and the common wish of further developing bilateral ties.
The communique was signed at a ceremony held at the Ministry of the Foreign Affairs Wednesday.
In the communique, the governments of the two countries vowed to further bolster economic, cultural, fishery, tourism and technological cooperation and exchanges.
Also in the communique, Vanuatu reiterated its firm support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other international and regional organizations.
According to the communique, Taiwan diplomatic officials have already visited Vanuatu's capital of Port-Vila to prepare for the opening of an ROC embassy there.
Taiwan began to engage in "mutual recognition" relations with Vanuatu in September 1992. Vanuatu had maintained formal diplomatic ties with mainland China since March 1982.
After nearly 80 years of joint French and British colonial administration, Vanuatu became an independent nation on July 30, 1980, changing its official designation to Vanuatu from New Hebrides.

A member of the United Nations and the Commonwealth, Vanuatu is also a member of the World Bank, Asian Development Bank, International Monetary Fund, World Health Organization, South Pacific Forum, and South Pacific Commission. It now holds observer status in the World Trade Organization. Currently, Vanuatu maintains formal diplomatic relations with 74 countries around the world.

Located between Australia and Fiji, Vanuatu is made up of 80-odd islands and isles. With an economic zone of about 680,000 square kilometers, Vanuatu's fishery production and maritime resources are an important source of wealth for the country.
Taiwan and Vanuatu have maintained close fishery ties over the years, with some 30 Taiwan-based snagline fishing boats operating regularly in the Vanuatuan economic zone.

Vanuatu has a population of about 202,000, with some 3,000 people of Taiwanese or Chinese origin. Three major languages are spoken in Vanuatu, namely English, French and Bislama -- a type of pidgin English that combines mainly English words and Melanesian grammar.

An agricultural country, Vanuatu exports dried coconut meat, coconut oil, cocoa and beef. Offshore banking services, boat registration services and tourism are also important cash earners for the country. Its major trade partners include France, the United States, Japan and Australia. Per capita annual income stands at about US$3,000.
Two-way trade between Taiwan and Vanuatu stood at US$6.4 million in 2001, with Taiwan's exports to the country totaling US$5.6 million.
Taiwan visitors enjoy the privilege of landing visas in Vanuatu, which they can reach via direct flights from Australia or New Zealand.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN SUFFERS MINOR INJURIES AFTER ENTERING LION'S PIT AT ZOO

TEXT.P: A man suffered minor bite wounds after climbing over a two-storey high concrete wall and jumping into the lion's pit at Taipei City Zoo in Mucha Wednesday, according to zoo officials.

At first, the big cats paid no attention to the 46-year-old man, who then began waving his jacket like a bull fighter. The provoked lions then attacked the man, who was rescued by guards before he was seriously hurt, witnesses said.

Suspected of suffering for a mental disorder, the man was immediately rushed to the nearby Wan Fang Hospital for treatment. He suffered light bite wounds to his arms and legs, hospital authorities said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TAIWAN POLICY WILL NOT CHANGE AFTER ELECTION: AIT

TEXT.P: Washington's policy toward Taiwan is not expected to change after the U.S. presidential election, American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) spokeswoman Dana Shell Smith said Wednesday.
Smith said economic and domestic issues as well as the U.S. role in Iraq have been the main focuses in the election, and Taiwan has not become an issue in the race.

Smith made the remarks during an interview with Taiwanese media at an information center for the 2004 U.S. presidential election in Taipei, which was set up by the AIT to serve American citizens who are interested in knowing the latest developments in the election.
The AIT is the de facto embassy of the United States in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAMESE WOMAN ARRESTED FOR DRUG TRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: A Vietnamese woman has been arrested for attempting to smuggle into Taiwan a batch of heroin coated with sugar and disguised as candies, police said Wednesday.

Nguyen Thi Tuyen, 24, who is married to a Taiwanese national residing in Taitung County, was caught as soon as she arrived at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport from Ho Chi Minh City late Tuesday night, police said.
Hundreds of sugarcoated heroin pills with a total weight of about 410 grams were found in her luggage, police said.

Supporters of Ukrainian opposition leader Viktor Yushchenko on Tuesday accused the Central Elections Commission of dragging its feet in counting votes from Kiev and western Ukraine, where Yushchenko's support is strongest, in what they said was an attempt to preserve a narrow lead for Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovych.

DOC.HEADLINE: CALM URGED PRIOR TO COURT RULING ON ELECTION LAWSUIT

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan asked for calm and order Wednesday on the eve of a verdict from the Taiwan High Court over an election result nullification lawsuit filed by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP).

Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai said that in view of the the possibility that large numbers of "pan-blue alliance" supporters might converge on the Taiwan High Court building to challenge the ruling Thursday, he has asked the National Police Administration under the Ministry of the Interior to be on high alert for possible confrontations and clashes.

The "pan-blue alliance" filed the election result nullification suit March 29 after KMT Chairman Lien Chan lost the March 20 presidential election by 29,518 votes, or 0.228 percent of the more-than 13 million ballots cast, to incumbent President Chen Shui-bian. The suit resulted in an unprecedented full-scale recount that started May 10, with special attention given to the record 337,297 invalid ballots. The alliance also filed a separate lawsuit April 5 seeking to invalidate the entire election, citing what it claims were "irregularities" in the voting.

Chen Chi-mai also asked the Taipei city government to rigorously carry out its responsibility in maintaining order. He also urged Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who concurrently serves as a KMT vice chairman, to exert his influence within the party to ease possible clashes between the citizens and police.
He further reminded the public that according to the Assembly and Rally Law, courts are off-limit areas for such activities.

Chen said the Executive Yuan will respect the verdict, which he refused to predict. He also urged all political party leaders to respect the ruling, saying that "Taiwan cannot stay forever on March 19" and that no-one "should incite ethnic hatred and rivalry." He also appealed for a return of "calm and peace in society."

Meanwhile, KMT Chairman Lien said in a regular KMT Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday that his party has high expectations for the justice system and expressed hope that it will be the last guardian of social justice.

Participants in the meeting listened to a report from lawyer Lee Chung-teh on "the effect of a fair justice ruling on the nation's democracy, " after which, Lien said that one can see that the ballots received by President Chen were incorrect.
Lien said that Chen, the defendant in the lawsuit, violated the referendum law by holding Taiwan's first referendum on the same day as the March 20 presidential election for his own benefit.

He also claimed that there is evidence to show that the election-eve shooting of Chen was staged to win sympathy votes in the bitterly fought election, but he yet again failed to back his claim by actually producing any of the so-called evidence.

With the year-end legislative elections approaching, Lien said he does not want the public to ask the question that if a president can illegally link a referendum to a presidential election, "what will happen in future elections? " and he urged the people to monitor future elections.
Lien said that everyone is equal in democracy and that if someone uses fraud to win an election, others should be able to stand up against him.
Lien's words drew immediate flak from the ruling party.

Cheng Wen-tsang, director of the DPP's information department, said that Lien's words are the most serious "misspoken remarks" he has made since the March 20 election, that he is the worst example of a political figure and that he should apologize to the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES SURGE ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 103.24 points to close at 5,862.85.
The bourse opened at 5,761.48 and fluctuated between 5,862.85 and 5,744.42 during trading. A total of 3.49 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$82.73 billion (US$2.48 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics stocks moving up the most at 3 percent, followed by construction stocks at 1.8 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.7 percent, plastics and chemicals issues at 0.7 percent, cement stocks and textile shares each at 0.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.5 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 505 to 130, with 146 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN PASSENGER ARRESTED FOR SMUGGLING PARROTS

TEXT.P: An Indonesian passenger was arrested for trying to smuggle 28 parrots into Taiwan, custom officials reported Wednesday.

The officials said the Indonesian, identified as Sugiharto, arrived at CKS International Airport aboard a China Airlines plane Tuesday night, whereupon customs officials found the 28 parrots hidden in his luggage.

As the parrots are from an area affected by avian flu, custom officials immediately asked the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture to send staff to deal with the birds, which were put into quarantine. Specimens taken from the parrots were also sent to the inspection bureau for examination.
For safety reasons, customs officials notified all the passengers on the plane to take self health-management measures and to look out for flu symptoms.
The officials also urged passengers not to carry animals or related products from epidemic-affected areas, saying that culprits face prison terms of more than three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH VANUATU PRIME MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with visiting Vanuatu Prime Minister Serge Vohor Wednesday to celebrate the establishment of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries earlier in the day.

"This is a historic day. After 12 years of efforts, Taiwan and Vanuatu have finally forged full diplomatic ties. It is belated good news and the tie-up deserves celebration by the governments and peoples of our two countries," Chen told his guest.

Chen attributed the success in forging ties in part to Vohor's long-term friendship and support for the Republic of China. Chen recalled that Taiwan and Vanuatu already signed a joint communique on mutual recognition in 1992 to pave the way for establishing diplomatic ties during Vohor's tenure as Vanuatu foreign minister.
"Thanks to Vohor's unwavering support for Taiwan, the two countries have finally been able to forge full diplomatic ties 12 years later, "Chen said jubilantly.

Chen also lauded Vohor for his achievements in promoting democratic reform in his country, especially in leading its coalition government in carrying out a series of constitutional reforms and winning a majority in the parliament.

"These achievements indicate that Vohor has outstanding leadership capability and political wisdom, " Chen said, adding that the fact Vohor's party controls 32 seats in the 52-seat parliament has helped ensure that his reform programs have been carried out smoothly.
Noting that both Taiwan and Vanuatu are maritime states, Chen said he hopes the two countries can strengthen fishery cooperation. Vanuatu has a booming fishery industry.
"With shared values of freedom, democracy and peace, our two countries should work together in the future to promote regional peace, stability and prosperity," Chen said.

For his part, Vohor said he looks forward to seeing the two countries develop mutually beneficial relations on an equal and reciprocal basis. He also assured Chen that Vanuatu will support Taiwan's cause in the international arena.

Vohor also expressed his hope that Taiwan will provide its successful economic development experience for his country's reference or emulation. "Let our two sides expand exchanges and cooperate closely in pursuing common interests and benefits, " he added.

The establishment of diplomatic ties with the South Pacific island state marked a modest victory in Taiwan's efforts to break mainland China's diplomatic embargo. The tie-up brings the number of countries that have official diplomatic relations with the ROC back to 27, after after the Caribbean island of Dominica switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in March.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said after signing a joint communique with Vohor on the establishment of formal diplomatic ties that Taiwan's pursuit of an "international space" cannot be suppressed by mainland China's missile threat.
Speaking on the same occasion, Vohor said his country's decision to establish diplomatic ties with the ROC is not designed to anger any country in the world or to make an enemy of mainland China.
"We do not refuse to be friends with China, but the decision was made based on the welfare of our people," Vohor said.

About 200,000 people live in Vanuatu, a group of 80 or so islands 2,250 km northeast of Australia. Vanuatu formed formal diplomatic ties with mainland China in 1982. It remains unclear whether Beijing would cut ties with Vanuatu after the island nation forged diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE VICE MINISTER TO TAKE OVER AS PUBLIC PROSECUTOR-GENERAL

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Justice Hsieh Wen-ting will be sworn in as public prosecutor-general Friday, replacing Wu Kuo-ai, who will become chief prosecutor at the State Public Prosecutor General's Office.
Shih Mao-lin, head of the Taipei District Public Prosecutor's Office, will take over as vice minister of justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET
