DOC.HEADLINE: AUTO SALES IN TAIWAN FOR 2004 EXPECTED TO HIT 500,000

TEXT.P: The sales volume of automobiles in the domestic market is expected to total 500,000 units for the whole of 2004 on the back of strong performance in the first three quarters, according to tallies published by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

The estimated figure is much higher than the original target of about 400,000 units set early this year, business sources said, adding that the combined sales in the first nine months already reached 330,000 units, leaving only a gap of around 30,000 units compared with the 2003 total level.

Statistics compiled by the MOEA's Industrial Technology Information Service (ITIS) show that Taiwan's automobile industry (including the motorcycle and the bicycle sectors) yielded NT$377.8 billion (US$11.27 billion) in output value and services, up by 17.4 percent compared to the previous year's level.
The motorcycle and the bicycle sectors generated NT$60.8 billion and NT$33 billion, up by 17.8 percent and 14.7 percent, respectively, over their year-earlier levels.

Benefiting from a stronger euro, Taiwan-made motorcycles and bicycles have gained an increased presence in the European market, with orders from that part of the world during the first three quarters growing to 480,000 units, a surge of 25 percent from the year-earlier level, ITIS researchers said, adding that sales of locally made bicycles rose by 14.7 percent in the domestic market for the same nine-month period.
Automobile sales are a key indicator of a country's economic situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CONTINUE BOLSTERING TIES WITH U.S.: EXECUTIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to strengthen bilateral ties with the United States on the existing basis, regardless of who is elected the new U.S. president, the spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Wednesday.

Chen Chi-mai said at a press conference that Taiwan and the United States share a great number of common interests, including security and stability of the Asia-Pacific region, economic and trade cooperation, and values of democracy and human rights.
Based on this, Chen said, Taiwan will continue its efforts to optimize bilateral ties with the United States after Wednesday's U.S. presidential election.

Meanwhile, he added, the government is paying close attention to the results of the election, which is unprecedentedly close, with President George W. Bush and challenger John Kerry racing neck-and-neck in pre-election polls.

The National Security Council under the Presidential Office convened a meeting Wednesday to observe the developments in the election, while other Cabinet agencies, including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Washington, were also closely monitoring the situation, Chen noted.
Chen said that Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen would issue a formal statement on the election after the last polls closed at about 12 p.m. Wednesday (EST).

In related news, the foreign affairs minister said that no matter who wins, the government believes that U.S. Taiwan policy will not change drastically and that Taiwan affairs will be handled in a steady manner based on the existing foundation.

Chen said that although there could be some departure, the basic stance of U.S. policy toward Taiwan is not expected to change dramatically. Taking an incident during the time of the Bill Clinton administration as an example, Chen said that bilateral communications between Taiwan and the United States returned to normal soon after Taiwan sought U.S. clarification when Clinton made some remarks that were considered by Taiwan as not very friendly.

Meanwhile, David J. Keegan, deputy director of the American Institute in Taiwan, said at an election observation center established at a Taipei hotel Wednesday that regardless of who wins the presidential election, the American people will be the final winners.

DOC.HEADLINE: XPEC ENTERTAINMENT TO COOPERATE WITH JAPAN'S NAMCO TV GAMES

TEXT.P: XPEC Entertainment Inc. of Taiwan signed a contract with Japan's Namco TV Games Wednesday to cooperate in developing new TV games.

Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, who was invited to witness the signing ceremony, noted that the prospects for TV games are brighter than those of PC games with the increasing popularity of digital television, and is expected to be the prime mover of Taiwan's efforts to develop a digital content industry.
Ho also expressed the hope that the Japanese TV game company will set up a research and development center in Taiwan.

Ho said that the digital content industry is expected to be the country's two rising stars -- with biotechnology being the other -- and that the government hopes to help transform the industry so that Taiwan can become an Asian and Chinese digital content design, development and production center.
To promote this goal, the ministry has pushed for a series of international cooperation meetings that resulted in the cooperation contract between Namco and XPEC Entertainment.

DOC.HEADLINE: HI-TECH FIRMS TO PROVIDE 1,800 OPENINGS FOR RESERVE DUTY OFFICERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's high technology sector will provide 1,800 openings this year for talented new servicemen, to enable them to complete their military service while working at privately run companies, authorities from National Cheng Kung University said Wednesday.

The 2004 Reserve Duty Program Exhibition is scheduled to be moved to Tainan, southern Taiwan for a two-day run beginning Nov. 7 on the NCKU Kuangfu campus, where 50 high-tech firms will provide job openings for 1,800 new conscripts who are holders of doctorates or master's degrees, NCKU authorities said at a press conference.

So long as these graduates pass the reserve duty officer examination set by the Ministry of National Defense, they can enter the 50 companies, in February 2005 at the earliest, to work on an alternative military service basis, according to NCKU authorities.

Applicants who win the opportunity to work at the private companies for salaries the same as those for ordinary staff will have to extend their alternative military service from the normal 22 months to four years.

Allowing elite graduates to serve their compulsory military service in private hi-tech companies will help keep the roots of the Taiwanese hi-tech companies at home in Taiwan at a time when the global economy is regaining momentum, which is in turn spurring economic recovery in Taiwan, NCKU officials said.

Many of the 50 companies are big names in their respective fields, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., United Microelectronics Corp., the Hon Hai Group, Chi Mei Optoelectronics and Nannstar Display.
Last year, only 30-odd companies offered job openings for such applicants.
Meanwhile, more than 12,000 individuals have contributed their expertise to the country's defense industry development since the defense industry reserve duty system was established in 1980.
The defense industry reserve duty program is aimed at supplying sufficient skilled labor for the research and development of weapons.

The 2004 Reserve Duty Program Exhibition opened in Taipei Oct. 29 with the participation of more than 1,000 organizations and units that wished to demonstrate the promising results of applying the private sector's R&D resources to the defense industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$117 MILLION-WORTH OF HEROIN SEIZED ABOARD TAIWAN FISHING BOAT

TEXT.P: Law enforcement officers uncovered 24.5 kg of high-grade heroin aboard a Taiwan fishing boat in the southern county of Pingtung Wednesday and arrested two key suspects in a cross-border drug trafficking operation.

Kuo Jung-fu, a 50-year-old Taiwan man, was accused of having colluded with a mainland Chinese man nicknamed "black dog" in attempting to smuggle the heroin, worth an estimated NT$117 million in street value, into Taiwan from the southeastern mainland Chinese port city of Xiamen in Fujian Province.
Kuo and the mainland man were nabbed when they showed up at the Hsiaoliuchiu fishing port in Pingtung County early Wednesday morning to pick up the drugs hidden aboard the Chiyifa.

Initial investigations show that Kuo and the mainland man formed a drug trafficking ring in October that purchased heroin from Thailand late last month. The drugs were first sent to Xiamen and then shipped to Taiwan aboard the Chiyifa.

Acting on a tipoff, the Criminal Investigation Bureau's (CIB's) southern Taiwan crime-fighting center formed a special investigative team in cooperation with coast guard and prosecution authorities in late October. The team had been monitoring the fishing vessel's activities since it left Hsiaoliuchiu for Xiamen Oct. 28. The boat returned to Hsiaoliuchiu Oct. 30, but Kuo and his mainland accomplice did not show up at the port until Wednesday.
CIB officials said they will continue to track down other ring members involved in the drug trafficking operation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: With Echoes of 2000 Vote, Ohio Count Is at Issue.
John Kerry's campaign said it would not abandon the campaign until all the votes in Ohio were counted.
The Wall Stree Journal: Bush Takes Lead in Close Race.
President Bush moved close to winning re-election last night in a tight race against John Kerry, with the outcome turning on the hotly contested -- and potentially legally disputed -- battleground of Ohio.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LAMENTS UNDEMOCRATIC REMARKS BY RIVAL

TEXT.P: Taipei, Nov. 3 (CAN) President Chen Shui-bian lamented Wednesday what he described as the undemocratic remarks of his campaign rival in the March 20 presidential election on the eve of a verdict by the Taiwan High Court on an election result nullification lawsuit filed by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP).

The president was responding to claims made earlier in the day by KMT Chairman Lien Chan that there is evidence to show that the election-eve shooting of the president was staged to win him sympathy votes in the bitterly fought election.
For a man who won the election through fraud and foul play, anyone can stand up against him, Lien said.
The president expressed regret over Lien's remarks, made even before the court had meted out the ruling, asking "what kind of a society is this, and what kind of democratic manner is this?"

The "pan-blue alliance" filed a lawsuit March 29 seeking to nullify the result of the election, which Chen won by a margin of 29,518 votes. The lawsuit resulted in an unprecedented full-scale recount that began May 10 of the more-than 13 million votes cast. After the initial recount, all the controversial votes were submitted to a high court panel to rule on their validity. If the number of questionable ballots exceeds 30,000, Lien could dispute the result of the election.
The alliance also filed a separate suit in April 5 to nullify the election altogether, citing what it claimed were rampant voting irregularities, and to demand a new election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LINKS WITH MAINLAND CHINA UNDENIABLE: MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's language, cultural and blood links with mainland China are an undeniable fact and the two sides should try to understand each other to forge peace across the Taiwan Strait, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Wednesday.
Wu made the remarks while giving a speech at the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China at the invitation of Chairman Gary Wang.

Stating that the government led by President Chen Shui-bian of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has no intention of conducting a de-sinicization of Taiwan, Wu said that language, history, culture and race links between Taiwan and the mainland are a fact that no one can deny.

Therefore, he said, there is no so-called de-sinicization problem in Taiwan, and after Chen's May 20 inauguration, the government has been extending olive branches to the mainland in an effort to boost cooperation and create peace between the two sides.

Echoing Wu's words, Wang said that Taiwan, as the world's sole democratic society built by ethnic Chinese, should pride itself by standing tall as a lighthouse of human rights and democracy for all the Chinese people around the world.
In addition to pursuing what Taiwan needs, the government should also seek to explore what the mainland thinks, in order to improve bilateral relations, Wang suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA CHIEF HOPING TIFA TALKS WITH WASHINGTON WILL BE RESUMED SOON

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh expressed hope Wednesday that suspended talks on a Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) between Taiwan and the United States will soon be resumed.

Speaking to reporters, Ho said the MOFA is monitoring the U.S. presidential election, but she added that whoever wins will not make any major changes to existing U.S. policies because the country is run by a solid and healthy democratic system.
The minister further predicted that once the new U.S. president officially assumes office, Taiwan-U.S. economic and trade relations will be further improved.

Regarding the severed Taipei-Washington TIFA negotiations, Ho said that after Taiwan made positive responses to issues of concern to the United States, such as problems relating to telecommunications and intellectual property rights protection, most disputed problems have already been resolved.
Taiwan is the eighth-largest trading partner of the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN EMERGES AS TAIWAN'S TOP AGRICULTURAL EXPORT MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan exported US$2.63 billion-worth of agricultural products in the first nine months of this year, with Japan its largest export outlet, the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday.
According to DGBAS tallies, Taiwan's agricultural trade amounted to US$9.28 billion in the January-September period, up 14.6 percent from the year-earlier level.
Of the amount, exports accounted for US$2.63 billion, representing a 9 percent increase from the year-earlier level, while imports made up US$6.65 billion for a 17 percent year-on-year rise.
Taiwan incurred a deficit of US$4.03 billion in agricultural trade for the nine-month period, an increase of US$750 million from the year-earlier level.

By area, Japan was Taiwan's largest agricultural export market, purchasing US$1.01 billion-worth of agricultural goods for a 13.5 percent year-on-year rise. Hong Kong and mainland China imported a total of US$610 million-worth of farm produce from Taiwan during the same period and the United States came in third, importing US$270 million-worth of Taiwan agricultural products.
Taiwan's top three agricultural import sources were the United States (US$1.95 billion) , Australia (US$460 million) and Japan (US$430 million), in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Huge turnout puts Bush presidency on knife edge.
Americans flocked to the polls in record numbers yesterday to leave President Bush's chances of clinging to power hanging by a thread. After a tumultuous four years in which Mr Bush responded to the September 11 attacks by twice going to war, Republicans were forced to sweat through a cliffhanger of an election night.
Financial Times: 13bn Airbus deal threatened.
The Ministry of Defence has warned a consortium led by Airbus parent EADS that it risks losing a 13bn deal to equip the Royal Air Force with new refuelling aircraft - as early as next month - unless it quickly agrees to change its proposed contract.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN KEY HUB OF PAN-ASIA SUPPLY CHAIN: MASTERCARD

TEXT.P: Taiwan has emerged as a key hub of the Pan-Asia supply chain following a "twin revolution" in terms of consumption and outsourcing that is transforming the region into a high-performance economy, according to a report released Wednesday by MasterCard International.

Yuwa Hedrick-Wong, MasterCard's economic advisor for the Asia-Pacific region, said the massive expansion of the middle class and the "new young" market in Asia is boosting domestic consumption in many countries in the region.

By 2010, the population of the middle class -- defined as those earning US$5,000 or more per year -- will have reached 155 million in mainland China, 23 million in Taiwan, 42 million in South Korea and 21 million in Thailand, Hedrick-Wong predicted.

In addition, young people aged between 25 and 35, who constitute 12 percent of the population in the Asia-Pacific region, are expected to account for 47 percent of discretionary spending in the region by 2007, he said.
Both the rise of domestic consumption power and young consumers will stimulate the advent of high value-added services, according to Hedrick-Wong.
Meanwhile, the new trend in intra-regional trade has been driven by the outsourcing revolution, with the fastest-growing products being the most technology- and knowledge-intensive, he said.

Of the 27 products identified by the Standard Industrial Trade Classification (SITC) as the fastest-growing in intra-regional trade from 1995 to 2001, 13 are classified as high-skill-, technology- and knowledge-intensive, he pointed out.
While 11 are classified as medium-skill, medium-capital and scale-intensive manufacturing, only three are classified as low-skill, labor-intensive manufacturing, he added.
The lowering of tariffs and bilateral free-trade agreements have also eased the development of a "Pan-Asia" supply chain, of which Taiwan has emerged as a key hub, he said.

The share of Taiwan's exports accounted for 41.1 percent in the Asia-Pacific region in 2001, and Taiwan's trade complementarity index with Asia-Pacific nations stood at 68.5 during the same period, up from 43.4 recorded in 1985, he said.

However, Hedrick-Wong said Taiwan needs to increase its spending on research and development to become a knowledge-based economy, pointing out that Taiwan's R&D spending accounted for only 2.3 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP) in 2003, which was lower than the 4.7 percent of Israel and the 2.9 percent of South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: TALKS ON CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICES POSSIBLE: MAC

TEXT.P: The nation's top mainland China policy planner said Wednesday that there could be a chance for both sides of the Taiwan Strait to discuss cross-strait charter flight services for passengers and cargo after the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks when he was invited by the General Chamber of Commerce of the ROC to give a speech on peace and development -- the creation of a win-win situation for both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Wu noted that "it will be no problem for Taiwan" whether cross-strait charter flights are limited to the Chinese New Year holiday period or whether charter flight services for passengers and cargo are extended to other times, as long as Beijing agrees.

But he noted that the mainland has proposed two-way charter flights without rerouting via third places. Although Taiwan will not be opposed to such a proposal and that there is precedence for such charter flight services from Taiwan to the mainland, bilateral consultations will still be required before charter planes can cross the Taiwan Strait directly.

Charter flight services during the 2003 Chinese New Year holiday period to pick up Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China were opened on a trial basis, but the flights were one-way only and had to made stopovers in Hong Kong or Macau.

Wu noted that judging from recent remarks by the Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office, Beijing has budged a little on the matter and that there is a chance of starting consultations on the issue after the legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 TAIWAN TECHNOMART OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The two-day 2004 Taiwan Technomart opened Wednesday in Taipei, with exhibits ranging from nanotechnologies and biotechnologies to various patent technologies.
According to the Taiwan Technology Marketplace Integrated Service Center -- the show's organizer, more than 500 items are on display at this year's event, which is the third of its kind since 2002.

They cover five major fields including "communications and optoelectronics, " "machinery and aerospace, " "raw materials and chemical engineering, " "biotech and medicine" and "sustainable development," officials from the center said.
A total of 145 exhibitors from the United States, Japan, South Korea, Germany, Belarus, Israel and Taiwan are participating in the show, the officials said.
A series of seminars on technology matching, international technology transfer and technology transfer via industrial cooperation programs are also being held during the exhibition, they said.
Also available are forums featuring international experts on issues related to intellectual property, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF FORESEES NO FUNDAMENTAL CHANGE IN U.S. POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Wednesday he foresees no fundamental changes in U.S. policy toward Taiwan after the U.S. presidential election.

Wu made the remarks at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting where opposition People First Party Legislator Lee Ching-hua asked about Wu's views on Washington's "one China" policy and U.S. scholar Kenneth Lieberthal's suggestion that Taiwan vow not to declare independence in exchange for Beijing's renunciation of the use of force against the island.
The nation's top mainland policy planner said Washington's "one China" policy does not imply any prerequisites.

"The United States just says it acknowledges Beijing's claim that there is only one China, " Wu said, adding that the United States intends to promote Taiwan-mainland China negotiations without imposing any prerequisites or premises. In contrast, Beijing has been pressuring Taiwan to accept its "one China" principle as a precondition for resuming talks with Taiwan.

As to Lieberthal's "Taiwan no independence, China no use of force" proposal, Wu said the concept is worth considering. Noting that Beijing's renunciation of the use of force is Taiwan's wish, Wu said no declaration of independence is not a problem for him.

"President Chen Shui-bian already expounded on the government's stance on independence in his May 20 second inauguration address. Taiwan is already an independent, sovereign state and need not declare independence again," Wu explained.

Legislator Lee also asked Wu whether the campaign to rectify Taiwan's official designation from the current "Republic of China" to "Taiwan" or "Republic of Taiwan" advocated by some diehard pro-independence fundamentalists could succeed.

This will depend on the general international environment and conditions, Wu said, adding that the so-called "rectification of Taiwan's name" is not the present Democratic Progressive Party administration's policy.

Lieberthal, a political science professor at the University of Michigan who once served as senior director for Asia at the U.S. National Security Council, is currently on a four-day visit in Taipei at the MAC's invitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INVESTORS' MOOD INDICATOR LOOKING UP: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Investors in Taiwan's stock market were upbeat last month, as a newly conducted poll showed that more than half of Taiwan's retail investors are optimistic about the market's performance in the months ahead.

According to the results of the survey jointly carried out by Win-Win Weekly magazine and Shih Hsin University, 55.8 percent of stock investors polled in October said that they are optimistic about the bourse's performance in the coming three months -- marking a surge compared to the result of the same poll in August.

During the same time, the weighted index -- the key barometer of the Taiwan Stock Exchange -- rose from 5,352 points to 5,772 points, an indication that investors' mood was closely related to the market's ups and downs, survey analysts said.
In October, only 8.3 percent held a pessimistic view of the domestic stock market, a drop from 41.5 percent in August, the survey found.

It also discovered that optimism about meeting investment targets, finding a job and a positive sentiment about the market's short-term performance are the main factors behind the clear upward trend in the indicator.

According to the poll results, men are more optimistic than women, while backers of the "pan green" camp formed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union are less worried than swing voters and supporters of the opposition "pan blue" alliance of the Kuomintang and the People First Party.

Stock investors with higher salaries and educational backgrounds usually had a higher mood indicator, but their indicator points tended to fall with increased age. People under the age of 29 form the most optimistic group, while those aged over 60 are the leading pessimists.
Investment experiences and residence locations have no effects on the indicator, the survey pointed out.

The random telephone poll, made Oct. 7 to Oct. 18, collected 1,072 valid questionnaires from respondents aged over 18 who had bought shares over the past year. It is conducted every two months and has a margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU VOWS TO CUT BUDGET FOR UNNECESSARY CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: A pro-independence lawmaker took the central government to task for its budget appropriation to subsidize personnel exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

Chen Chien-ming, deputy convener of the legislative caucus of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said 23 central government agencies had set aside a total of NT$343.12 million in the 2005 budget plan for subsidizing mainland Chinese academics or professional groups to visit Taiwan or for Taiwan officials to conduct study tours of mainland China.

"This phenomenon is outrageous, " Chen said. "Why does the government have to use taxpayers' money to subsidize cross-strait exchanges? China has never subsidized Taiwan academics or experts' mainland visits on a reciprocal basis."
If mainland scholars or officials want to understand Taiwan's present social situation, Chen said, they should pay their travel expenses out of their own pockets.

Chen further said some government agencies have also appropriated funds for sending their staff members to study mainland market trends as well as various economic, social and legal systems. In his view, Chen said many of the planned inspection items listed in the budget bill are ridiculous.

For instance, he said, the highway administration department under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications earmarked NT$102,000 in its budget plan for organizing a delegation to look into mainland China's highway construction and maintenance systems. "Does Taiwan's civil engineering technology and maintenance system lag China's? Is it truly necessary to make such an inspection tour? "he asked.
Chen said the TSU legislative caucus will carefully review the central government's cross-strait exchange budget plans and will cut or freeze unnecessary spending projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC CENTRAL SECURITIES DEPOSITORY GROUP TO SET UP WEB SITE

TEXT.P: The Asia-Pacific Central Securities Depository Group (ACG) decided Wednesday to establish a Web site to increase communications and exchange of information and experiences among its members.

The ACG made the decision at its eighth annual meeting that concluded on that same day after two-day discussions in Taipei. Some 50 heads and representatives of securities depository institutions from more than 10 countries attended the meeting.
According to a resolution adopted by the ACG meeting, the Taiwan Securities Central Depository Co. (TSCD) will be responsible for establishing and maintenance of the Web site.
TSCD officials said that Taiwan will become the communications center of securities depository institutions in the Asia-Pacific region after the Web site is established.
The ACG, formed in 1997, has now 21 members from the Asia-Pacific region. The next ACG annual meeting will be held in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPTOELECTRONICS INDUSTRY POSTS MARKED GROWTH IN OUTPUT VALUE

TEXT.P: The domestic optoelectronics industry posted a more than 40 percent annual growth rate in its output value for the first three quarters of this year, a research unit under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Wednesday.

The MOEA's Industrial Technology Information Services (ITIS) said that the domestic industry's production value for the first nine months totaled NT$746.3 billion (US$22.3 billion), up by 44.9 percent over the previous year's record.
The ITIS forecast that its production value for the whole of this year will amount to NT$1.135 trillion, a 38 percent increase compared to the 2003 level.

The output value contributed by the digital camera sector fell, while the display panel sector registered a considerable growth to increasingly become the key engine of the industry, ITIS officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MAINLAND TOURISTS ABSCOND FROM CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Two mainland Chinese tourists absconded shortly after arriving at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport -- Taiwan's main gateway -- along with a tour group Wednesday.

The two mainland tourists, identified as Ai Hungying, 51, and Jia Yaqi, 32, got off a tour bus while the tour guide was reporting the arrival of the 21-member mainland tour group to the Tourism Bureau's office at the CKS Airport.

The tour group was organized by a travel agency in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan. The group is scheduled to stay in Taiwan for seven days. Other members will continue their local travel itinerary.

Travel sources said the two absconded tourists had both registered their birth places as Shengyang in the northeastern mainland province of Liaoning. In the past, absconded mainland tourists mostly came from Fujian province which lies opposite Taiwan.
Police said they have intensified their search for the two latest absconded mainland tourists.
Taiwan now allows mainland citizens to make group tours of the island after they have toured third countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: 241 INVESTMENT VENTURE PLANS FOR 2003: DGBAS

TEXT.P: A total of 241 investment venture plans were approved by the government in 2003, up by 24 from the 2002 number, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Wednesday.

Investment capital worth NT$16.54 billion (US$493.4 million) was funneled into the domestic market, with a focus on the semiconductor and optoelectronics industries, which accounted for a combined 40 percent of the total investment value, DGBAS officials said.
Some 78 percent of the investment money came from domestic institutional investors, mainly in the form of investment funds and asset management companies, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES GOVERNMENT AGENCIES TO CHECK UNUSUAL CAPITAL FLOWS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged government agencies, particularly law enforcement units and financial supervisory institutions, to enhance their monitoring operations against unusual capital flows to prevent vote-buying activities in the upcoming legislative elections.
Yu made the instruction at an inter-ministerial meeting on maintaining social order held at the Executive Yuan.
Yu said that he has repeated on various occasions the government's determination to eliminate corrupt "black gold" politics and to protect the citizen's rights to elect public officials.

The efforts are aimed at preventing unscrupulous candidates from using financial institutions to launder their money for vote-buying in the run-up to the elections slated for Dec. 11, the premier noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Nov. 4, or the 22nd day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1935: The Republic of China government proclaims the nationalization of all silver, making notes issued by the Central Bank of China and the Bank of Communications legal tender.
1946: The Republic of China and the United States sign a five-year Treaty of Friendship, Commerce and Navigation.
1946: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) is formed.
1957: Dr. Hu Shih is appointed president of Academia Sinica, the Republic of China's highest academic research organization.
1959: France announces the completion of the making of its first atomic bomb.
1979: Minister of Economic Affairs Chang Kuang-shih presides over a ceremony at the Grand Hotel Taipei to formally inaugurate the Republic of China's first nuclear power plant.
1992: Republic of China Vice Minister of Economic Affairs P.K. Chiang leads an observer delegation to the Geneva meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) Council of Representatives after the ROC's absence of 21 years.
1995: Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin is assassinated to death.
