DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CONGRATULATES BUSH ON RE-ELECTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday sent his congratulations to U.S. President George W. Bush on his re-election and offered Taiwan's assistance in efforts to maintain stability in the Asia-Pacific region.

President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu separately sent congratulatory messages to U.S. President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney immediately after Bush's challenger, Sen. John Kerry, conceded defeat and the U.S. president's camp declared victory, top presidential aide Su Tseng-chang said at a press conference Thursday.

In his message to Bush, President Chen said that the governments and people of Taiwan and the United States have maintained close ties and exchanges and have shared common values in democracy and human rights.

Based on this, President Chen reiterated the Republic of China's willingness to cooperate with the United States to joint maintain peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region and to actively seek dialogue with mainland China so as to optimize the development of cross-strait relations, according to Su.
President Chen stressed that Taiwan is also willing to cooperate with the United States in arresting the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and terrorism and in enhancing world peace.
As a member of the international community, Chen said, Taiwan would like to contribute further in terms of humanitarian aid to needy peoples around the world, according to Su.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH TO FURTHER PUSH FOR CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE: U.S. SCHOLARS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 3 (CNA) (By W.C. Lin, J.L. Chi and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Several U.S. scholars in Washington, D.C., and former U.S. diplomats said Wednesday that President Bush is expected to be more active during his second term in pushing for cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue.
They also said that Taiwan and the United States might also need to strengthen their dialogue in the future.
Bush won the presidential election held the same day after a tough race against his Democratic opponent, Sen. John Kerry.

The scholars, including Bonnie Glaser, research fellow with the Center for Strategic and International Studies; John Tkacik, research fellow with the Heritage Foundation; Nat Bellocchi, former director of the American Institute in Taiwan; and Mark Pratt, former State Department official who had been stationed in Taipei and Beijing, made the remarks while attending a seminar organized by the Formosan Association of Public Affairs, a pro-Taiwan organization in the United States.

According to Glaser, the central thought of the U.S. cross-strait policy will remain unchanged, although there might be some minor adjustments. However, she said that it is expected that the United States will further encourage Taipei and Beijing to engage in direct dialogue since the lack of such dialogue during the past several years may have harmed their interests.

The scholar pointed out that U.S. National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice had asked Beijing what role Washington could play in pushing for such dialogue during her recent visit to mainland China. Glaser added that the United States could pass on the same message to Taiwan in order to better understand what it can do to stabilize the situation in the Taiwan Strait and maintain cross-strait peace.
Bellocchi, noting that Taipei and Beijing need to engage in dialogue, said that Taipei and Washington might also need to strengthen their communications.

Meanwhile, Tkacik said that Bush's re-election will put Taiwan more at ease as Sen. John Kerry seemed to be inclined to mainland China and to recognizing the mainland's increasing influence in the Pacific region.

If Taiwan wants to improve its relations with the United States, the people of Taiwan should reach a consensus on the island's future, he said, adding that if Taiwan wants to stand closer to the mainland politically and internationally, then a veto against a special budget on arms procurement will not be important.

If the Taiwan people want to separate from the mainland, then their top priority is to have the capability to defend themselves, Tkacik further said, noting that if Taiwan assumes the attitude of "bystander" in terms of its own military defense, then the Bush administration might have relatively less patience in relevant matters.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
It's four more years for Bush.
President George W. Bush has won a second term in office, winning the popular vote with a decisive majority of more than 3.5 million, a margin of victory not seen since 1988.
His Democratic party rival Senator John F. Kerry was reported to have called him at the White House yesterday to concede defeat, recognising that he did not have the votes to challenge the Bush camp's claim to victory.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Bush is continue as American president.
President George W. Bush has won the presidential election.
His Democratic party rival Senator John F. Kerry was reported to have called him at the White House yesterday to concede defeat, recognising that he did not have the votes to challenge the Bush camp's claim to victory.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT TO HAND DOWN RULING ON PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION RESULT SUIT

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court is scheduled to issue its ruling Thursday on a lawsuit filed by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party to try to have the March 20 presidential election result nullified.
The court will hand down its ruling in the high-profile case at 4 p.m. and call a press conference to explain the reasons behind the ruling.

In expectation of a convergence of a large number of supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" in front of the Taiwan High Court building and possible clashes, 400 police officers have been mobilized and barriers erected to help maintain order.
The court said that it has already given out 20 passes to members of local and foreign media and 36 passes to regular citizens to hear the ruling.
The "pan-blue alliance" filed the lawsuit on March 29 shortly after its presidential candidate, Lien Chan, lost to incumbent President Chen Shui-bian by a razor-thin margin in the March 20 election.

According to the regulations of the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law, an election result nullification suit can only be won if the election involved illegal deeds or the vote count was incorrect.

To clarify the first part, or the opposition allegations that the election-eve shooting of President Chen was staged to win sympathy votes and that a national security mechanism was activated which prevented many military personnel and police from leaving their posts to cast their ballots, the court had summoned key personnel between Aug. 31 and mid-September.

The officials summoned included Huang Shih-Cheng, former chairman of the Central Election Commission, former National Defense Minister Tang Yiau-min, former Presidential Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, former National Security Council Secretary-General Kang Ning-hsian, former president's top bodyguard Chen Tsai-fu, presidential medical team executive secretary Huang Fang-yen and others.

As the court's hearings on the two contentious issues -- the shooting and the activation of the national security mechanism -- were conducted in a closed-door way for security reasons, it is yet to be seen on what the court will base its ruling or whether relevant agencies have provided any written records or documents to back up their testimonies.

To clarify concerns about the vote count, an unprecedented islandwide recount of the more than 13 million ballots cast began May 10, focusing on the record number of 337,297 invalid ballots and other contentious ballots.

Informed sources said that the court, after reexamining the questionable ballots, will rule that the final vote count be changed, adding however that the new vote count will not affect the re-election of Chen. They also said the court will likely rule that "no serious vote-fixing" could be established.

The court will also announce the final tallies of the votes garnered by Chen and Lien in its ruling. According to the earlier announcement by the Central Election Commission, President Chen obtained 6,471,970 votes, while Lien garnered 6,442,452.

The Taiwan High Court, after summoning poll station staff for testimony, found that most of the discrepancies or irregularities in the ballots were caused by the holding of Taiwan's first national referendum simultaneously with the presidential election, resulting in election "flaws," but no "gross vote-fixing."
Meanwhile, the "pan-blue alliance" said Thursday that no matter what the Taiwan High Court's ruling is, it will be a "flawed" one because it will fail to clarify many contentious points.
The alliance called for calm among its supporters and said that it will continue to appeal to the court for the truth of the election result.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW YORK STATE ASSEMBLYMAN-ELECT ON WAY HOME TO TAIWAN FOR CONFAB
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Nov. 3 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: New York-based businessman and community leader Jimmy K. Meng, who was elected a New York State Assemblyman in Tuesday's legislative elections, is on his way home to Taiwan to take part in a meeting to be convened by the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission.

Meng, a graduate of National Taiwan Normal University and a master's degree holder in administrative management from a university in New York, defeated his two challengers in New York's 22nd District for a landslide victory.
Meng will become the first Asian-American member of the New York State Legislature after taking office shortly.

A Queens businessman who formerly headed the Flushing Chinese Business Association, Meng beat New York State Assemblyman Barry Grodenchik in the Democratic primaries in September to enter the race against two candidates from two other parties for the assembly seat.

Meng, who emigrated to the United States in 1974, has been an active community leader in New York over the past decades. He was chosen the man of the year in New York State in 1997. In the same year, he won the Ellis Island Medal of Honor awarded to outstanding immigrants.

According to John Liu, who in 2000 became the first Asian-American elected to the City Council of New York, the Asian-American community could potentially become a powerful political force. "The numbers continue to grow quickly, and the voter turnout rates are potentially much greater than the overall turnout rates of other groups," he said.
Meng is returning to Taipei to take part in the meeting in his capacity as an overseas Chinese affairs commissioner of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN EXTENDS CONGRATULATIONS TO BUSH ON RE-ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has extended its congratulations to U.S. President George W. Bush for his re-election on behalf of the Republic of China government and the people, a spokesman of the Executive Yuan said Thursday.

Chen Chi-mai was also positive about the sportsmanship displayed by Democratic opponent John Kerry, noting that the senator, in conceding defeat in the bitterly fought presidential race, called for unity.

On future Taiwan-U.S. relations, Chen said that the two countries share common interests in trade exchanges and strategic cooperation, as well as on such issues as Asia-Pacific peace and stability and anti-terrorism, adding that both sides will continue to strengthen bilateral communication and cooperation.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Mainland Affairs Council also extended their congratulations to U.S. President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney for re-election victory.

They said that the two countries have enjoyed close relations and have shared values and ideals in the promotion of democracy and respect for human rights, which will lay a solid basis for the continued development of bilateral relations.

The ROC government reaffirmed that it is willing to work with the United States in the battle against terrorism and the prevention of the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, as well as in the promotion of peace and humanitarian assistance to fulfill its duty as a member of the international community.

The ROC government will also continue to cooperate with the U.S. government to safeguard regional peace and stability, and actively seek dialogue with mainland China for cross-strait peace and development.

Kau Ying-mao, vice foreign affairs minister, said that the U.S. policy toward Taiwan will remain unchanged and that the ROC will continue to communicate with the United States over any differences between the two sides.

Kau noted that the Bush administration gave a positive response to President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration address and his Double Ten National Day speech, which he said demonstrates that communications between Taiwan and the United States will continue to be good.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH RE-ELECTION MEANS CONTINUITY IN U.S. CROSS-STRAIT POLICY: EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Nov. 3 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior U.S. expert for East Asian affairs said in Los Angeles Wednesday that the re-election of U.S. President George W. Bush means the United States' cross-Taiwan Strait policy of the past four years will continue unchanged.
Bush won re-election Tuesday after a tough race against his Democratic rival, Sen. John Kerry.

Charles Wolf, senior advisor at the RAND Corporation, a renowned U.S. think tank, said the Bush administration will honor its commitment to the island and will continue to sell arms to Taiwan as well as support Taiwan in its efforts to join international organizations.

Noting that President Bush has always attached great importance to the Taiwan Relations Act, the expert said that the president also considers that all issues regarding the future of Taiwan should be resolved peacefully and with the consent of the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES MORE HOUSES TO PARAGUAYAN LOW-INCOME FAMILIES
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Nov. 3 (CNA) (By Lee Pei-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China donated 72 more houses to Paraguay Wednesday as part of its efforts to help improve impoverished Paraguayan people's lives.
ROC Ambassador to Paraguay Yen Ping-fan presented the houses to Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte in a donation ceremony on behalf of the ROC government.

Duarte said after receiving the donated houses on behalf of the Paraguayan people that his administration and average Paraguayan citizens alike deeply appreciate Taiwan's long-term generous aid to their country.

According to Duarte, Taiwan has donated 1,150 housing units to low-income Paraguayan families so far this year. In the next four months, he said, 1,200 similar Taiwan-financed housing units will be completed in the Paraguayan capital of Asuncion and other areas.

For his part, Yen said he takes great pleasure in seeing 72 housing units completed as scheduled to provide better living conditions for low-income Paraguayan families. The new houses are located in Florencio Villamayor City. There is a kindergarten in the community and a school to be accredited by Paraguay's Education Ministry will be established in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MOVING FROM CUSTOMIZATION TO OWN BRANDING: PREMIER YU

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday that Taiwan is gradually moving from customizing on an OEM basis to creating its own brand names.
The premier made the remarks when he addressed the opening of a one-day conference in Taipei of the Marketing Communication Executives International (MCEI) on Asian brand names in the world.

The premier said the MCEI, in choosing Taiwan to hold the conference, has been an encouragement and recognition of Taiwan's development in the marketing communication industry, noting that at a time of economic globalization, the businesses will have to rely on research and development and the creation of their own brands to ensure profits.
As Taiwan moves from customization to it own branding, it will also take stock of experience gained from international branding, the premier said.

He noted that the top 10 brand names in Taiwan created a production value of NT$121.1 billion (US$3.65 billion) in 2003, compared with NT$140 billion this year, or a growth of 15.58 percent. The production value of the top three brands -- Trend Micro Enterprise, ASUStek Computer, and Acer -- increased to NT$80.2 billion, or a growth of 18.38 percent.

Kao Chi-shan, president of the MCEI Taipei Chapter, expressed the hope that the conference will enable the participants to exchange experiences and develop friendships to bring about opportunities for future cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS TO REBUILD MUTUAL TRUST WITH U.S.: ACADEMICS

TEXT.P: Taiwan must work harder to re-establish communication channels and trust with the United States now that President George W. Bush has been re-elected, a group of Academics said Thursday.

The United States' Taiwan policy is not expected to change and will still be governed by the Three Communiques, namely the Shanghai Communique, the Communique Establishing US-PRC Diplomatic Relations and the US-PRC Joint Communique on arms sales; and the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), said Cheng Tuan-yao, a research fellow with the Institute of International Relations, National Chengchi University.

Nevertheless, Cheng noted, U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's comment on cross-strait relations needing "a reunification that all parties are seeking, " although later clarified by Powell as meaning that the goal " really is to have a peaceful resolution of the problem, " should serve as a reminder that Taiwan should be much more careful than before in handling the cross-strait situation, beginning with efforts to regain Washington's trust while bolstering communications with officials there.
In his second term, Bush is expected to push harder for both sides to resume dialogue since resumption of cross-strait talks is a path that must be taken by both sides, Cheng said.
Cheng noted, however, that whether the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue will be resumed next year as President Chen Shui-bian has proposed remains to be seen.

Meanwhile, Professor Chen Yu-chun from Chinese Culture University's Institute of American Studies said that Washington's stance that "Taiwan shall not seek independence while China refrains from using force and both sides of the Taiwan Strait resolve their differences via peaceful negotiations" is becoming more applicable as Bush begins his second term in the White House.

Yang Yung-ming, an associate professor with National Taiwan University, echoed Professor Chen's remarks, saying that President Bush is expected to stick to the "one China" policy in regard to cross-Taiwan Strait issues and will continue to use the Three Communiques and the TRA as the bedrock of policies that the United States applies to both sides of the Strait.
Yang noted, however, that all of these take into account the primary interests of the United States.
He added that he expects that Washington will step in to push both sides to resume cross-strait talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN-SOONG LOSE SUIT AGAINST CHEN-LU

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court Thursday rejected a request from defeated presidential candidate Lien Chan and his running mate James Soong to invalidate the re-election of President Chen Shui-bian and his running mate Annette Lu.

DOC.HEADLINE: 156 O'SEAS CHINESE DELEGATES TO RETURN HOME FOR ANNUAL CONFAB: OCAC

TEXT.P: A total of 156 overseas Chinese delegates from around the world are arriving in Taipei to take part in the annual conference of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) slated for Nov. 4-7, OCAC authorities said Thursday.

The delegates coming from 31 countries in five continents include New York-based businessman and community leader Jimmy K. Meng, who was elected a New York State Assemblyman in Tuesday's legislative elections.

Meng, who becomes the first Asian-American member of the New York State Legislature after taking office shortly, is expected to arrive in Taipei in time for a welcoming party at the Howard Hotel Thursday evening.

Meng, who emigrated to the United States in 1974, has been an active community leader in New York over the past decades. He was chosen the man of the year in New York State in 1997. In the same year, he won the Ellis Island Medal of Honor awarded to outstanding immigrants.

The 2004 OCAC Conference will formally open Friday, with OCAC Minister Chang Fu-mei presiding, followed by a working report by her; an audience with President Chen Shui-bian; and debating and screening proposals; in that order.

On Saturday, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Y.M. Kau and Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu will deliver keynote speeches to the conference, which will also include two-way discussions, OCAC officials said.

The delegates are also expected to exchange views with government officials on overseas efforts in campaigning for rectifying the name of Taiwan and efforts to push for Taiwan's accession to the United Nations and other world organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH TO CONTINUE FRIENDSHIP WITH TAIWAN: REPUBLICANS ABROAD REP.
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Nov. 4 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush is expected to continue his policy of friendship toward Taiwan based on the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) during his second term in office, an official of the Republicans Abroad said Thursday.

Ross Darrell Feingold, chairman of the Asia-Pacific chapter of the Republicans Abroad, said Bush's re-election was mainly due to his advantage over Democratic challenger John Kerry in terms of his policies on anti-terrorism, the economy, medical and education reform.
The election results also reflected voters' disapproval of the negative campaigning adopted by Kerry, Feingold said.
On Washington's policy toward Taiwan, Feingold said Bush is expected to continue to befriend Taiwan in accordance with the TRA in the next four years.

Feingold pointed out that the term "Taiwan Relations Act" was left out deliberately from the China policy statement posted on the Democratic Party's Web site during the run-up to the presidential election.
Therefore, Feingold argued, Washington's policy toward Taiwan would have become unpredictable had Kerry been elected president.
Now that Bush has been re-elected, a number of bilateral cooperation programs including the on-going arms sales will carry on, Feingold added.
He said the recent remarks by U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell on the status of Taiwan should not be misinterpreted as Washington toughening its stance on cross-strait issues.
As a full-fledged democracy, the United States always publicizes major policy changes, if any, via a news conference, but never via a TV interview of one of its officials, according to Feingold.
He said the subsequent clarification by the U.S. Department of State and Powell proved that his previous words had been a slip of the tongue.

The fact that Bush approved an arms sales package to Taiwan soon after he assumed office in 2000 and reaffirmed Washington's commitment to defending Taiwan indicates his firm friendship toward Taiwan, Feingold noted.

Most importantly, unlike the administration of President Bill Clinton, which appointed a professional diplomat to serve as the director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan, Bush has assigned Douglas Paal for the post in view of his political influence in the U.S. government, Feingold said.
This decision was meant to upgrade the unofficial relations between Taipei and Washington, and such policy will remain in place after Bush's re-election, he said.

He predicted that the Bush administration will continue to urge Taiwan and mainland China to seek a peaceful resolution to their political dispute via dialogue, saying cross-strait stability is in the interests of the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST DEVELOP ITS OWN COMPETITIVE EDGE: ECONOMIC STRATEGIST

TEXT.P: The nation's top economic planner said Thursday that the government must actively promote its six-year national development plan and help domestic manufacturers set up operations, and research and development centers in Taiwan to develop their own competitive edge.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, pointed to the attractive investment nature of mainland China because of its cheap labor, which has resulted in Taiwan businesses relocating their manufacturing and assembly operations to the mainland.

For this reason, Taiwan must make a distinctive separation from mainland China, Hu said, adding that through the government's "Challenge 2008" six-year national development plan, it will upgrade domestic economic levels and attract foreign and domestic enterprises to set up operations in Taiwan, as well as research and develop centers.

He noted that Taiwan must ensure that major parts and components are assembled in Taiwan, with minor sections manufactured in the mainland. After assembly, the products will be sold under the name of Taiwan-made to create more added value.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange ended lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 2.12 points to close at 5,860.73.

The bourse opened at 5,864.12 and fluctuated between 5,890.95 and 5,831.55 during the day's trading. A total of 3.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$74.01 billion (US$2.22 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 0.3 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.

Five other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.4 percent, construction issues at 0.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.4 percent and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 360 to 250, with 176 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHERMEN DETAINED IN RUSSIA IN GOOD HEALTH: TAIWAN OFFICIALS
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, Nov. 4 (CNA) (By Vlogya Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative office in Moscow has reported the crew of a Taiwan deep-sea fishing vessel is in good health after being detained off the Kuril Islands for trespassing into Russian waters in late September.
Three officials from the office, including economic section chief Tsao Su-yang, consular secretary Wei Hsin-chou and adviser Peng Shou-shan, made the report after they visited the crew.

The trio flew nearly nine hours from Moscow to the Kuril Islands. During their visit Oct. 28-31, they went to Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk to call on related agencies to learn about the situation surrounding the detained ship and went to Korsakov Harbor to see the crew of the ship, the Kaohsiung-registered "Chenghui No. 1."
The officials originally wanted to go aboard to meet with the crew, but the Russian side later arranged a ferry to let ship captain Yen Jui-cheng come ashore because of turbulent seas.
Yen expressed appreciation to the officials for visiting and bringing them fresh fruits and chocolates.

Yen said that the ship has five Taiwanese crew members, including himself, and that Russian law enforcers have been friendly to them. As they don't speak Russian or English, they asked Taiwan officials to convey to the Russians that they had no intention of running away.

The health and the spirit of the crew is fine, he said, adding that there is enough rice, frozen vegetables, meat and fuel for the time being. In the daytime, the ship is moored at sea, and sails nearer land to avoid inclement weather.

According to Leskova, a local lawyer commissioned by the Taiwanese owner of the ship, past experience in dealing with similar cases has shown that as long as the owner provides a certain amount of money to pay the fines, the ship and its crew will be released.

After the meeting, the officials expressed appreciation to Kastornov, the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs 's representative to the Kuril Islands, and appealed for him to complete the investigation and trial as soon as possible so that the crew can be released, and in the meantime, give necessary protection to them.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP EXPECTS STRENGTHENING OF U.S.-TAIWAN TIES IN BUSH'S 2ND TERM

TEXT.P: The re-election of U.S. President George W. Bush will be beneficial to the consolidation of Taipei-Washington relations and U.S. support for Taiwan, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) politicians said Thursday.
Lee Chun-yi, a leader of the DPP legislative caucus, said he is confident that the relations between Taiwan and the United States will continue to develop in a favorable direction as in past years.
The arms sales package to Taiwan, approved by Bush in his first term, will remain the most important policy of the United States toward Taiwan, Lee said.

Tsai Huang-liang, another leader of the caucus, said Bush has been the friendliest U.S. president to Taiwan, which he said was shown in the privileged treatment granted by the Bush administration to President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu during their transit stops in the United States.

According to Tsai, it is an overall diplomatic strategy of the Bush administration to contain mainland China, and Taiwan must continue to play a balancing role in the Asia-Pacific region in the future to secure Washington's support for Taiwan.

Sharing a similar view, Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Legislator Chen Chien-ming said the national interests of the United States have always been the main consideration of Washington's diplomatic policies.
The triangular relations between Taipei, Washington and Beijing will remain the same as before, Chen said.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP), however, said Bush's re-election will mean heavier pressure on the government of President Chen, saying Bush has "drawn a red line" for cross-strait relations.

Huang Teh-fu, whip of the KMT legislative caucus, said President Chen must not make another attempt to break through the "red line, " which Huang said would come at the cost of Washington's trust in Taiwan.

PFP Legislator Chou Hsi-wei claimed that the recent remarks by U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell on the status of Taiwan have indicated that the U.S. cross-strait policy is slanting toward mainland China.
Chou urged President Chen to take concrete steps to try to improve the country's relations with both the United States and the mainland instead of paying lip service.
TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen, meanwhile, called on the "pan-blue alliance" to learn from the graceful manner of Democrat John Kerry and admit defeat in the March 20 presidential election.
Saying the results of the election have been decided upon by the people, Huang asked the alliance to stop wasting social resources on meaningless legal processes.
Disagreeing with the argument, KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said there is no comparison between the case of Taiwan and that of the United States.
Without the interference of an election-eve shooting of the president and other irregularities, the results of the U.S. election are definitely not as disputable as that of Taiwan's, Chang claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE PING-HUNG COULD BE TAIWAN'S FIRST BLIND LAWYER

TEXT.P: Proving that justice is indeed blind, a young Taiwan man with a severe visual impairment passed the bar exam, it was announced Thursday.
Lee Ping-hung, 25, was one of the 399 aspirants who managed to pass this year's bar exam. Only 8 percent of the 4,979 hopefuls passed the test. Lee ranked 128th among those who made it.

"The result didn't come as an accident. It's a hard-won achievement, and I believe that other physically challenged people can make it so long as they make devoted efforts, " said Lee, who is almost totally blind.
Lee, a graduate of National Taipei University, said he is grateful for his parents' encouragement and full support in his academic and career pursuit.
"I once intended to give up after failing twice in the annual lawyer qualification examination. Thanks to my parents' encouragement, I continued preparations for this year's test, " Lee recalled.
Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen presented souvenirs to Lee Thursday after unveiling the list of this year's successful hopefuls.

Noting that Taiwan doesn't have any blind lawyer presently, Yao urged local legal firms to offer opportunities for Lee to work as an apprentice. Lee must undergo a five-month apprenticeship before he can formally become a lawyer.
Among Asian countries, Japan already has two blind lawyers. Yao said Lee would be Asia's third blind lawyer.

Yao, himself a lawyer, said blind people face many challenges in their daily life and at the workplace. Taiwan's court system and bar associations may not be prepared for having a blind lawyer, Yao said, adding that certain practical issues, such as whether to allow a blind lawyer to appoint an assistant to read legal documents on his behalf in courtrooms, has to be addressed now.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November gained 6 points to close at 5,836 with 26,726 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December moved down 6 points to finish at 5,827, with 230 contracts traded, while March futures gained 25 points to finish at 5,830, with one contract traded.
June futures gained 45 points to finish at 5,810, with four contracts traded, while September futures moved down 17 points to close at 5,750, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,830 for November, 5,833 for December, 5,805 for March, 5,765 for June and 5,767 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
November TE futures moved down 0.85 points to close at 217.10, with 6,284 contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 0.85 points to finish at 217, with 60 contract transactions.
March TE futures lost 1.3 points to close at 216.1, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.
November TF futures moved up 3.2 points to finish at 1,030.2, with 6,177 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved up 4 points to end at 1,028, with 106 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved down against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange market Thursday, giving up NT$0.0142 to close at NT$33.285.
A total of US$937 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.427 and dipped to a low of NT$33.271 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ACCEPTS RESIDENCY APPLICATIONS FROM CHINESE HI-TECH TALENT

TEXT.P: The government is offering permanent residency rights in Taiwan to mainland Chinese hi-tech professionals in a bid to enrich the island's technological capability, officials said Thursday.

According to rules drawn up by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , mainland residents with outstanding achievements in technologies that are helpful to upgrading Taiwan's industrial sector are eligible to apply for permanent residence here.

Also eligible are those who are professionally trained in skills related to rising industries, key technology or key components or products that are needed by Taiwan or difficult to acquire in a short period of time, according to the regulations.

By sector, the technologies considered useful to Taiwan include digital content, image display, optoelectronics, semiconductors, electronics, information, communications, industrial automation, material application, biotechnology, nanotechnology, pharmaceuticals, medical equipment, special chemicals, health food, resources development and utilities, and energy saving.
Eligible mainland residents can file their applications along with documents proving their credentials after they have legally resided in Taiwan for two years.

After the applications have passed screening by the MOEA, they will need to undergo final review by the Ministry of the Interior, which will ensure that the number of mainland residents in Taiwan does not exceed the quota set by the government, MOEA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU URGES LIEN, SOONG TO APOLOGIZE FOR CAUSING DISORDER

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) urged the defeated presidential and vice presidential candidates Thursday to apologize for causing social disorder over the past few months due to their refusal to concede defeat.

The TSU, an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), made the call shortly after the Taiwan High Court rejected an opposition "pan-blue alliance" lawsuit contesting the March 20 presidential election and upheld President Chen Shui-bian's narrow re-election victory.

Legislator Hung Chung-yuan, who concurrently serves as the TSU's legislative whip, said the "pan-blue alliance's" two top leaders -- Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman (PFP) James Soong -- who teamed up to challenge Chen and Vice President Annette Lu's re-election bid -- should make a public apology for all the disturbances and chaos in the wake of the March 20 vote simply because of their refusal to concede defeat.

Huang also urged Lien and Soong, as well as their supporters, to respect the court ruling and to refrain from staging violent street protests as they did in the wake of the election. He further suggested that the two opposition leaders give up their right to petition their case to the Supreme Court to avoid a further waste of national resources.
Moreover, Huang suggested that Lien and Soong publicly concede defeat and offer their congratulations to Chen and Lu in a show of sportsmanship and democratic spirit.

After more than seven months of investigations, the High Court rejected the opposition's claims that the vote was marred by fraud and a shooting that slightly injured Chen a day before his victory by a razor-thin margin.

The ruling ended seven months of hearings, ballot recounting, cross-debates, consultations and investigations into various contentious points that posed a serious challenge to one of Asia's youngest democracies. The disputed vote was only Taiwan's third direct presidential election.
Wu Ching-yuan, the High Court's presiding judge, said: "We announce hereby that the petition to nullify the election outcome is rejected."

According to the results of an unprecedented islandwide vote recount, the verdict said, Chen actually garnered 6,461,177 ballots compared to Lien's 6,435,614, in the bitterly fought race. Chen won by a slim margin of 25,563 ballots, down some 3,000 from the vote count announced by the Central Election Commission after the election.
Describing the 400-page verdict as a "precedent-setting masterpiece, " High Court spokesman Wen Yao-yuan said the ruling can withstand stringent scrutiny.
"We hope all social quarters can respect our judicial system and refrain from complicating the case. Judicial cases should be resolved by judicial means," Wen said.
According to Article 114 of the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law, Wen said, the plaintiff can appeal the case to the Supreme Court.

Lien has insisted that the election should be held again because of alleged ballot tampering. He also claimed that thousands of police and soldiers could not vote because the president put them on special alert after the shooting. Chen's administration has denied Lien's allegations, and the opposition has consistently failed to provide any compelling evidence to support it's claims.
Before the ruling was handed down, Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang called on the opposition to refrain from protesting violently.
"Our nation can't be split any more. We need unity. Society needs stability," Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR PROPOSES MAKING TAIWAN NUCLEAR-FREE COUNTRY

TEXT.P: To display the government's resolve to maintain peace and prevent Taiwan from being attacked by nuclear arms, a scholar has raised the concept of making Taiwan and the Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu islands into nuclear-free zones.

Yuan I, a researcher at the Institute of International Relations of National Chengchi University, raised the idea Wednesday at a seminar jointly sponsored by the institute and the Academia Sinica Institute of European and American Studies to discuss the U.S. presidential election and Taipei-Beijing-Washington ties.

Yuan said that although Taiwan and mainland China have been under separate rule for more than 50 years, a situation not contemplated by the existing modes applied in the world's non-nuclear states, relevant international practices could serve as an important reference for Taiwan.

According to Yuan, non-nuclear countries are banned from using nuclear material for nuclear weapons and their exports of nuclear material and equipment must be conducted in ways consistent with the objectives underlined by the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Program.
Currently, the non-nuclear countries are mainly in Latin America, the South Pacific, Africa and Southeast Asia, he said.

Yuan suggested that the government openly declare that it will only use Taiwan's nuclear materials and facilities for peaceful purposes and pledge that it will not store, use, manufacture, possess or deploy any form of nuclear arms.

A public declaration to make Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu into nuclear-free zones is aimed at inviting Beijing to reciprocate by renouncing its use of nuclear weapons against Taiwan and providing a security guarantee to Taiwan, he said.

He claimed that such a declaration would be the first step toward ending an arms race between Taiwan and the mainland and a historic turning point for the two sides to show mutual respect and mutual trust.
At the same time, it would be an effective way to underline Taiwan's non-nuclear determination to the world and provide the country with insurance that it would be free from nuclear attack, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG HARBOR FREE TRADE ZONE TO BEGIN OPERATIONS NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: A free trade zone (FTZ) project at Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan obtained government approval Thursday from the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), with initial operations slated to begin in October next year.

CEPD Vice Chairman Yeh Ming-feng said that the FTZ has been projected by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) to accommodate container shipping, distribution and warehousing companies because of the port's vast hinterland, convenient location and comprehensive facilities.
Yeh said that the government plans to develop the port into a full-dimension international port by introducing processing and manufacturing businesses in the FTZ.

According to the CEPD vice chairman, Taichung Harbor has a total area of 3,760 hectares, with 2,800 hectares of land area. The Changpin Industrial District, the Chungkang Export Processing Zone, the Central Taiwan Science-based Industrial Park and the Chingchuankang International Airport are located nearby.
At present, more than 10 enterprises, including Evergreen Marine Corp (Taiwan) Ltd., Taiwan's largest container shipping company, have expressed willingness to open up shop in the FTZ, Yeh said.

In the initial stage, 181 hectares of land will be available for the zone's first-phase operations, while an additional 278 hectares of land will be allocated for the second-phase business scheduled to begin in October 2006, he said.
Taichung Harbor will become the third Taiwan port to have an FTZ after Keelung in the north and Kaohsiung in the south, MOTC officials said.
The Keelung FTZ is receiving applications from companies wishing to set up there, while the Kaohsiung FTZ is scheduled to begin operations in January next year.

In the future, there will be at least seven FTZs around the country, which are expected to attract 1,000 companies and to create about 30,000 jobs, with total investment capital amounting to NT$67.8 billion and an overall production value of NT$162.5 billion (US$4.85 billion), they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURIST ARRIVALS UP BY NEARLY 40 PERCENT IN NINE MONTHS

TEXT.P: Foreign tourist arrivals to Taiwan in the first nine months of this year topped 2.13 million, up by nearly 40 percent compared to the previous year's level, the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) reported Thursday.

According to bureau statistics, foreign tourists made a total of more than 2.13 million visits to Taiwan in the first three quarters of the year, marking a rise of 39 percent over the year-earlier level, although still a slight drop of 1.92 percent from the 2002 level.
Taiwan's tourism-related businesses were seriously hit last year by the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) around the world.
With a government drive to promote Taiwan tourism that started early this year, the number of foreign tourist arrivals has been increasing now that the SARS threat has abated.

Compared to the 2002 records, the number of travelers from South Korea in the nine-month period grew by about 70 percent, bureau officials said, attributing the increase to newly established charter flight services between the two countries. The number of visitors from Malaysia has also increased for two consecutive years, they added.

However, they pointed out that the numbers of tourists from Japan, Hong Kong and Macau were still smaller for the January-September period compared to the 2002 numbers, with those from Japan posting the largest fall of 14 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA REAFFIRMS VALIDITY OF ROC-VANUATU DIPLOMATIC TIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reaffirmed Thursday the validity of the establishment of full-fledged diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and the South Pacific island nation of Vanuatu a day earlier.
MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said the rumor of the so-called "invalidity" of the newly formed ROC-Vanuatu diplomatic ties was deliberately spread by the mainland Chinese embassy in Vanuatu.

"As Vanuatu's top political leader, Prime Minister Serge Vohor is definitely eligible to sign a joint communique with the ROC on the establishment of diplomatic ties on behalf of the Vanuatu government and people," Lu said.

Commenting on foreign wire service reports that Vohor's signing of the joint communique with ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen in Taipei was a "personal act" without the prior approval of the Vanuatu government, Vice Foreign Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau said the reports were incorrect.
Kau said Vohor consulted with the Vanuatuan Cabinet before he left for Taiwan.
Moreover, Kau said, Vohor informed the Vanuatu deputy prime minister Wednesday evening of the signing of the joint communique.
"Vohor has asked his deputy to inform the other Cabinet members of the event, " Kau said, adding that the establishment of ROC-Vanuatu diplomatic ties is valid and beyond question.

Kau said Vohor had to keep his Taipei trip secret to avoid pressure from mainland China. Vanuatu forged diplomatic ties with Beijing in 1982 and signed an agreement with Taipei on mutual recognition in 1992 when Vohor was Vanuatu's foreign minister.

"Twice before, Vanuatu has had the intention of establishing diplomatic relations with the ROC, but because Beijing exerted pressure, the relationship did not completely come to fruition, " Kau said, without elaborating.
Stressing that Vanuatu is a sovereign state, Kau said it is free to choose its friends. Moreover, Kau went on, Vohor has also expressed his desire for continued friendship with the mainland.

Kau further said the ROC has no intention of conducting a "zero-sum" game with the mainland in the diplomatic arena. "What we want is to expand our international space. We look forward to peaceful co-existence with mainland China," he added.

The establishment of diplomatic ties with the South Pacific island state marks a modest victory in Taiwan's efforts to break the mainland's diplomatic embargo. The tie-up brings the number of countries that have official diplomatic relations with the ROC back to 27, after the Caribbean island nation of Dominica switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in March.
Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen said after signing the joint communique that Taiwan's pursuit of an "international space" cannot be suppressed by the mainland's missile threat.
Speaking on the same occasion, Vohor said his country's decision to establish diplomatic ties with the ROC is not designed to anger any other country or to make an enemy of the mainland.
"We do not refuse to be friends with China, but the decision was made based on the welfare of our people," Vohor said.
About 200,000 people live in Vanuatu, a group of around 80 islands located between Australia and Fiji.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CANADIAN REPRESENTATIVE HAILS TWO-WAY TIES WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Canada's new representative to Taiwan hailed Thursday the sound relations between the two countries and expressed his hope for increased bilateral exchanges.
Gordon Houlden made the remarks during a meeting with the local press.

Claiming that the "one China" policy upheld by Canada has not affected his country's frequent exchanges with Taiwan since Ottawa shifted its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1970, Houlden called for widened and upgraded Taiwan-Canada exchanges in education, culture and economics.
In particular, he invited more Taiwan students to study in Canada, saying that universities in Canada offer the world's top learning environment coupled with low tuition fees.
Taiwan was Canada's 11th-largest trading partner last year, with two-way trade totaling US$3.2 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PLEASED WITH COURT RULING ON ELECTION: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu are pleased with a Taiwan High Court ruling against an opposition "pan-blue alliance" lawsuit contesting the March 20 presidential election, Chen's chief of staff said Thursday.

Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang made the remarks after the High Court earlier in the day rejected the lawsuit filed by the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) and upheld the Chen-Lu ticket's narrow re-election victory.

"Chen and Lu are pleased with the court ruling and hope all politicians and citizens will stand united to defend Taiwan's young democracy, " Su said, adding that Taiwan cannot be split and needs unity and stability.
Noting that the rule of law is the foundation of democracy, Su said democracy cannot mature and flourish without respect for this basic principle.

"The president and vice president have also asked me to convey their gratitude for the hard work of High Court judges and all the other people involved in the grueling vote recount as well as investigation and trial of contentious points over the past seven months," Su said.
Su said Chen will continue to do his utmost to unify the country in line with the principles of "listening, understanding, and respect for law."

The High Court rejected the opposition's claims that the vote was marred by fraud and a shooting that slightly injured Chen a day before his victory by a razor-thin margin over his challenger, KMT Chairman Lien Chan.

The ruling ended seven months of hearings, ballot recounting, cross-debates, consultations and investigations into various contentious points that posed a serious challenge to one of Asia's youngest democracies. The disputed vote was only Taiwan's third direct presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LOSES CASE AGAINST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court ruled against defeated presidential candidate Lien Chan and his running mate James Soong in a lawsuit they brought seeking to invalidate the re-election of President Chen Shui-bian and his running mate, Vice President Annette Lu.

After seven months of trial, a panel of three High Court judges ruled that the plaintiffs failed to prove their claims that the ballot counting in the election was not accurate and that Chen and Lu had deliberately prevented some voters from exercising their right to vote.

A spokesman for the court who explained to the media the main reasons behind the decision said a recount of the ballots found that both the Lien-Soong ticket and the Chen-Lu ticket garnering fewer votes than the Central Election Commission had declared. However, this would not reverse the results of the election, as Lien and Soong were still 25,563 votes short of Chen and Lu after the recount.

There is no evidence to substantiate the plaintiffs' claim that Chen engineered an assassination attempt against himself on the eve of the March 20 election to attract sympathy votes, the spokesman said, citing an investigation report presented by U.S. forensic expert Henry Lee.

Even if the incident is clouded by question-marks -- as the plaintiffs claim -- the spokesman quoted the judgment as saying that this does not constitute grounds to believe the assassination was a political ploy by Chen.

As for the plaintiffs' claim that Chen skewed the election in his favor by holding a referendum concurrently with the election, the court said this is not a totally groundless argument, but nor is it an obstruction to the public's free exercise of the right to vote, which under the law would render the victory of the winner in the election invalid.

For the same reason, the court said, the plaintiffs' claim that Chen and Lu deliberately postponed their appearance in public after the shooting to fuel public agony in an attempt to manipulate public opinion to their favor is also no justification to negate their election victory.

Regarding to the plaintiffs' argument that the precautionary measures taken by the government for national security after the March 19 shooting unreasonably stripped some military personnel and police officers of their right to vote, the court said that the Ministry of National Defense, the National Police Agency and the Coast Guard Administration all denied that they increased the number of staff on duty or on reserve duty after the March 19 shooting.

In addition to overruling the plaintiffs' requests, the court ordered Lien and Soong to bear the cost of the lawsuit, but did not say whether this would include the NT$70 million (US$2.1 million) for the recount.
The copy of the judgment, numbering about 400 pages with an additional 7,500 pages of appendix, will be send to the parties in the case next week, according to the court.
Lien and Soong who did not show up in court to hear the judgment, appeared at a joint news conference later and said they will appeal against the judgment to the Supreme Court.
Calling the day a dark day in the history of Taiwan's democracy, Lien said he was disappointed with the court's ruling and will not stop the "fight for justice" in the case.

Claiming that many irregularities in the election were not investigated in the trial, the Kuomintang (KMT) chairman urged the supporters of his party and of Soong's People First Party (PFP) to translate their indignation with the judgment into votes for the KMT and the PFP in the upcoming legislative election.

PFP lawmaker Liu Wen-hsiung said his party was disappointed but not surprised by the judgment, claiming that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) had already hinted at the outcome of the trial beforehand.
However, Liu said his party will contend the case in the court rather than on the streets via demonstrations.

The DPP was pleased by the results of the trial. Its whip at the Legislative Yuan, Tsai Huang-liang, said the two opposition parties should respect the court's decision and reconcile themselves to the result.
The DPP's political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, called on the KMT and PFP to apologize to Chen.
In anticipation of the failure of Lien and Soong in the case, a group of their supporters rallied outside the court before the results of the trial were released at 4 p.m.

Waving posters reading "justice is dead" and "no end to protest until truth is out." they were kept out of the court by barricades erected by police and dispersed after only a short confrontation with the police.
Lien and Soong brought the lawsuit against Chen and Lu initially March 20, hours after the ballots had been counted.
That suit was rejected by the court on the grounds that the Central Election Commission (CEC) had not yet officially declared the results.
Lien and Soong initiated the suit again March 29, or three days after the CEC declared Chen and Lu the winners.
It was the first time a defeated candidate had challenged the results of a presidential election in court.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Nov. 5, or the 23rd day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1556: The 13-year-old Mogul leader Akbar defeats his only rival, the Afghan general Hemu, at the second Battle of Panipat. It was at the first Battle of Panipat in 1526 that Akbar's grandfather Babar defeated Sultan Ibrahim II to establish the Mogul dynasty.
1854: British and French forces defeat the Russians at the Battle of Inkerman during the Crimean War.
1892: John Haldane, English physiologist and geneticist who pioneered research in population genetics and evolution, is born.
1911: U.S. pilot C.P. Snow completes the first transcontinental flight across the United States.
1912: Taking advantage of a split in the Republican opposition, Woodrow Wilson wins the U.S. presidential election to become the first Democrat in the White House in 20 years.
1912: American actor Roy Rogers, known as "King of the Cowboys" for his role as a singing cowboy in films and on television, is born.
1913: British film actress Vivien Leigh, best known for her Oscar-winning role as Scarlett O'Hara in "Gone with the Wind," is born.
1914: Cyprus is annexed to Britain.
1924: Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, is forced to leave his palace in the Forbidden City in Peking by warlord Feng Yu-hsang, who has taken control of the city.
1940: Franklin D. Roosevelt is re-elected president of the United States for the third time.
1946: John F. Kennedy is elected to the U.S. House of Representatives for the first time.
1951: The fifth session of the U.N. General Assembly rejects a Soviet proposal to discuss the issue of "China's representation" in the assembly's sixth session.
1956: Soviet tanks crush the revolt in the Hungarian capital of Budapest.
1957: The Republic of China Navy sinks six Communist Chinese warships off Matsu, a Kuomintang-held frontline island opposite mainland China's Fujian Province.
1964: Mainland Chinese Premier Zhou Enlai arrives in Moscow to attend a Communist conference.
1965: The first International Conference of Chinese Buddhists opens in Taipei.
1968: Richard Nixon wins the U.S. presidential election by defeating Hubert Humphrey by a narrow margin.
1974: A Republic of China technical cooperation team leaves for a six-week fact-finding tour of African countries.
1980: President Chiang Ching-kuo sends a congratulatory message to President-elect Ronald Reagan, expressing confidence that the United States will play a more positive role in advancing the cause of world freedom and justice.
1984: A joint committee of the Legislative Yuan adopts a revised version of the Copyright Law, extending protection to computer software.
1999: Hong Kong business tycoon Lim Por-yen is sentenced to two years and two months in prison by the Taiwan High Court on charges of bribery in a corruption scandal in Taiwan.
1999: The Federation of World Hakkas opens its 15th biennial gathering in Kuala Lumpur, with Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad attending as one of the dignitaries.
2000: A charity auction of Ju Ming's artistic works raises NT$59.38 million (US$1.84 million) for the post-quake reconstruction by the Buddhist Tzu Chi Foundation of more than 50 schools in central Taiwan.
2001: Four members of the Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee under the Republic of China Legislative Yuan arrives in Moscow for a four-day visit.
2001: The Honduran Investment and Export Development Foundation (HIEDF) and the Taiwan Textile Federation (TTF) ink a cooperative agreement in order to lure more Taiwan businessmen to invest in Honduras.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "Opportunities of time vouchsafed by Heaven are not equal to advantages of situation afforded by the earth, and advantages of situation afforded by the earth are not equal to the strength arising from the accord of men."
