DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES 'PAN-BLUE' TICKET TO LEARN FROM KERRY, GORE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shui-kun on Friday urged Lien Chan, the "pan-blue alliance" candidate in the March 20 presidential election, and his running mate, James Soong, to learn from Al Gore and John Kerry and come to terms with the reality of their election loss with an open mind.

The premier made the appeal after the Taiwan High Court, after court proceedings lasting over seven months, on Thursday ruled against the lawsuit filed by the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) to try to have the election result nullified. Both Lien and Soong have said they will appeal the decision to the Supreme Court.

Premier Yu said the "pan-blue alliance" couldn't provide evidence to back up their claims of voting irregularities in the high court trials, adding that the ruling has cleared the names of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
The premier said that both the KMT and the PFP should have national unity in mind and stop their headstrong actions for the sake of the wellbeing of the public.

Yu said that even if Lien can't concede defeat graciously as Kerry did after the U.S. presidential election, he can at least learn from Gore, who said after the 2000 election that while he strongly disagrees with the Supreme Court's ruling, he accepts it.

The premier said that Gore and Kerry are models for Lien and Soong, criticizing both "pan-blue alliance" candidates for plunging society into ethnic rivalry and in turn affecting the stock market and the economy over the past seven months simply to maintain their leadership of the KMT and the PFP.
They must now try to open their minds and accept the facts to work for the nation's long-term wellbeing, the premier urged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINGSTON TECH TO FOOT BILL FOR 'PAN BLUE' LAWSUIT

TEXT.P: California-based Kingston Technology Corp. will foot part of the bill for the March 20 presidential election vote recount and the legal costs for the suit filed by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" to try to have the election result nullified.

The Taiwan High Court on Thursday upheld the narrow re-election of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu and ruled that the "pan-blue alliance" challengers -- Lien Chan of the Kuomintang (KMT) and his running mate James Soong of the People First Party (PFP) -- would have to pay a portion of the legal costs of the suit and the nationwide vote recount which together are estimated at more than NT$77 million (US$2.3 million).

As a result, Lien and Soong will only have to pay some NT$16.96 million (US$507,784) for the expenses. The Lien-Soong ticket had already put forward NT$60 million as a guarantee deposit prior to the kick-off of the recount on May 10 of the 16,507,179 ballots which took nine days to complete.

Kingston Tech, co-founded by Chinese-Americans John Tu and David Sun, donated NT$100 million (US$2.99 million) in April to help pay for the recount in the hopes of ending the election controversy and allowing the social situation in Taiwan to return to normal. Sun then consigned the private Judicial Reform Society to manage the fund in Taipei.
Kingston Tech is one of the leading module manufacturers in the world.
A spokesman for the Judicial Reform Society said Thursday that so long as Lien and Soong do not appeal, the company will make the NT$16.96 million payment at once.

The money left over after Lien and Soong's legal fees are paid should go to charity to promote ethnic harmony in Taiwan in accordance with Sun's intentions when he made the donation, the spokesman said.

Upon making the donation in April, Sun said it was non-political and had nothing to do with his pro-alliance sentiments. "Ethnic divisions appeared after the election, and the generosity and forbearance among the people was destroyed, " he claimed, adding however that "with the passage of time, the wounds should be healed through tolerance and rationality."

Sun and Tu became millionaires when they sold a large chunk of their memory chip-making company in 1996 and made headlines when they decided to share US$100 million of the windfall with their employees, which numbered roughly 450 at the time.

Thursday's ruling ended seven months of hearings, ballot recounting, debates, consultations and investigations into various contentious points that posed a serious challenge to Taiwan's system of democracy.

Supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" staged several large protest rallies in the days after the March 20 election against what they perceived as an "unfair election" which they claimed was marred by voting irregularities and the election-eve shooting of Chen and Lu.

The protestors demanded a ballot recount as well as the establishment of an independent committee to investigate the shooting that they said swayed the election in Chen's favor. Although both Chen and Lien agreed to a recount, differences remained between the two sides on who should foot the bill.

Lien and Soong filed a lawsuit hours after the March 20 election, but the suit was rejected by the court on the grounds that the Central Election Commission (CEC) had not yet officially declared the results. They then initiated another suit on March 29, three days after the CEC declared Chen and Lu the winners.
It marked the first time in Taiwan's history that a defeated candidate challenged the results of a presidential election in court.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND TOUGHENS ATTITUDE AGAINST TAIWAN'S TRM QUESTIONS AT WTO: SOURCE
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Nov. 4 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Mainland China has toughened its attitude in dealing with questions raised by Taiwan within the World Trade Organization (WTO) Transitional Review Mechanism (TRM) which evaluates Beijing's compliance with its WTO accession agreement, a well-placed trade source said in Geneva Thursday.
According to its accession agreement, mainland China is subject to eight years of evaluation by the TRM from the time of becoming a member of the world trade regulatory body in 2001.

The source said that mainland China has basically been against the TRM and has continued since its accession to frustrate the efforts of WTO members, including Taiwan, in using the mechanism to evaluate its trade policies.

Various WTO committees began from the end of this September's TRM meetings to examine China's transitional trade policies, and mainland delegates have refused to give responses to questions raised by Taiwan, claiming that they did not receive the written questions sent by the island's delegation to the WTO and pointing out that the written materials put forth by Taiwan were "ineffective documents, " according to the source.

The source cited the TRM meeting held by the WTO Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Committee Thursday as an example, saying that although the WTO secretariat had sent written questions raised by Taiwan on Oct. 20 to all the WTO members Oct. 22, mainland China's representatives still claimed at the meeting that they had not received any such questions.

The source said that compared with the last two years, mainland China has adopted a tougher attitude in dealing with TRM questions raised by Taiwan this year. In the previous two years, mainland China at least gave indirect answers to Taiwan's TRM questions.

As a matter of fact, mainland China has also dealt insincerely with the TRM questions raised by other WTO members, including the United States, the European Union and Japan, causing much frustration among the WTO members, according to the source.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABDUCTED TAIWAN BUSINESSMAN FREED THROUGH CROSS-STRAIT COOPERATION

TEXT.P: A Taiwan businessman abducted in mainland China late last month has been freed thanks to close cooperation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said Friday.

The businessman, surnamed Wang, currently runs a shoe factory in Foshan in the southeastern mainland Chinese province of Guangdong. He called his wife in Tainan, southern Taiwan Oct. 25, asking her to raise a ransom of NT$2.5 million (US$75,300) , but the figure was increased to NT$6 million two days later.

His wife, after checking with the company's employees, found that Wang and his mainland Chinese chauffeur were abducted by five knife-wielding and gun-toting men when he was getting into his car after shopping.

The CIB was enlisted to help in the case. It provided related information to the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , a quasi-official body formed to handle cross-strait affairs resulting from cross-strait exchanges, which in turn contacted security police in mainland China.
Mainland Chinese security police on Thursday made a raid on the place where Wang was being held and arrested six mainland Chinese involved in the abduction operation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW HEAD OF PUBLIC PROSECUTORS' OFFICE OF TAIWAN HIGH COURT SWORN IN

TEXT.P: Former Vice Minister of Justice Hsieh Wen-ting was sworn in Friday as prosecutor-general of the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court.
On assuming his new post, Hsieh promised to continue the government's efforts to crack down on vote-buying, corruption, organized crime and financial crime.

In addition to being a vice minister of justice, Hsieh had served as director of the Ministry of Justice's Department of Prosecutorial Affairs; prosecutor-general of the Hsinchu, Ilan and Kinmen District Public Prosecutors Offices; a prosecutor and chief clerk of the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court; a judge of the Taiwan High Court; chief prosecutor of the Taipei District Public Prosecutors Office; and a prosecutor of the Taipei and Taichung District Public Prosecutors Offices.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO STANCE ON OTHER COUNTRIES' DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH ROC: U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 4 (CNA) (By W.C. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department took no position Thursday on whether other countries should establish diplomatic relations with Taiwan, saying it is up to each country to decide whether or not it wants to establish such relations.

The statement was in response to a question raised at a daily briefing by a journalist who asked State Department Spokesman Richard Boucher whether or not countries should establish diplomatic relations with Taiwan and what the U.S. position is on diplomatic relations between Taiwan and third countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER VISITS SENEGAL TO CHAIR MEETING OF AFRICAN MISSION CHIEFS

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen left for the Republic of China's West African ally Senegal Friday to chair a meeting of the ROC's diplomatic mission chiefs in Africa.
The annual conference will be held in the Senegal capital of Dakar to review the nation's diplomatic work in various African countries as well as chart future work directions and agendas.

In addition to ambassadors and representatives stationed in various African countries, officials of the Government Information Office, the Board of Foreign Trade, the African Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and the International Cooperation and Development Fund will also attend the meeting.

Topics to be addressed at the conference will include progress in bilateral and multilateral cooperative projects with various African countries, as well as regional political, economic and social development trends and initiatives for further boosting Taiwan's exchanges and cooperation with African states, MOFA officials said.
During his stay in Dakar, Chen will meet with senior Senegal officials and inspect the achievements of bilateral cooperative projects.
He will also visit The Gambia, another ROC West African ally, to further cement bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL ISLAND CONFERENCE CLOSES IN KIMMEN

TEXT.P: Participants in the eighth international conference on islands issued a declaration after closing its five-day meeting in the outlying island of Kinmen Friday.

Grant McCall, president of the International Small Islands Studies Association (ISISA), read the "Kinmen Declaration " on behalf of more than 250 scholars from 30 countries who took part in the meeting titled "Islands of the World VIII -- Changing Islands, Changing Worlds."

The declaration noted that the more-than 120 papers read at the conference show that with smaller size, limited natural and human resources, as well as natural and man-made disasters, small islands face unique challenges.

The participants made an eight-point suggestion in the declaration, including one suggesting that the governments of small islands set up a professional island research center to accomplish the goal of the sustainable development of small islands.
Islands of the World is a biennial international convention with the main theme being the study of common environmental problems and development policies of small island countries and areas.
The next convention will be held in Maui, Hawaii, in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP PUSHES FOR 'TAIWAN FRIENDS ASSOCIATIONS' AROUND THE WORLD

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu exhorted members of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Friday to make the most of their good relations with communities around the globe to establish "Taiwan friends associations" in all major cities.

Addressing the opening of the 2004 annual conference of the OCAC in Taipei, Lu urged OCAC members to help optimize Taiwan's diplomatic efforts by tying overseas Chinese affairs to the diplomatic front.

Lu said that all Taiwan citizens should feel proud and fortunate to be Taiwanese. Although Taiwan is geographically small, she went on, the country is big in terms of global competitiveness, economic growth, export capacity and women's participation in politics.
Taiwan is too strategically important to let go from mainland China, which has for long schemed to build itself into a new Chinese empire -- a giant map that would include Taiwan, Lu said.

Lu said that Beijing has maintained a mentality of denial toward the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -ruled Republic of China government over the past four years in the belief that President Chen Shui-bian would not be re-elected.
But a Taiwan High Court ruling Thursday that reconfirmed the validity of Chen's re-election leaves no room for Beijing to ignore the DPP any longer, Lu argued.
Beijing officials will have no other option but to return to the negotiating table after the DPP scores another victory in the year-end legislative elections, Lu said.
She added that Taiwan is ready for a resumption of the cross-strait dialogue, while working to establish a cross-strait peace development committee.

Meanwhile, OCAC Minister Chang Fu-mei urged in a report delivered at the conference all OCAC members residing abroad to help accelerate the implementation of various projects that Lu has initiated to optimize Taiwan's diplomacy overseas.
The projects include the Democratic Pacific Assembly and agricultural promotion and city-building plans in Central and South America, Chang said.
A total of 156 overseas Chinese delegates from 31 countries on five continents are taking part in the annual OCAC conference, which will run until Sunday.
President Chen received the 156 overseas Chinese delegates at an audience held at the Presidential Office earlier that day.

On Saturday, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Y.M. Kau and Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu will deliver keynote speeches to the conference, which will also include two-way discussions, OCAC officials said.

The delegates are also expected to exchange views with government officials on overseas efforts in campaigning for changing the official name of the country and efforts to push for Taiwan's accession to the United Nations and other world organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC RENEWS CALLS FOR CHARTER FLIGHT TALKS WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) again urged mainland China Friday to respond to Taiwan's call for official talks on the opening of direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday.

At a regular press conference, MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Taiwan is ready in all aspects regarding talks over the charter flight issue and that the only thing absent is Beijing's willingness to discuss the issue.
So long as Beijing responds, any time would be suitable to begin the talks, Chiu stressed.

Whether the New Year charter flight talks will materialize in the near future hinges on three key issues: Beijing's willingness; the technical issues about which Beijing is concerned; and Beijing's attitude toward Taiwan after Taiwan's Dec. 11 legislative elections, Chiu added.
In late October, Chiu urged Beijing to authorize an appropriate person or persons to negotiate with Taiwan on the opening of direct charter flights for the New Year season.

Chiu said the Republic of China government has demonstrated goodwill and flexibility toward the proposal that carriers from both sides of the Taiwan Strait could operate direct non-stop charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday, which will begin Feb. 6, 2005 and run through Feb. 13.

"We are hopeful that neither side will set any political prerequisite for negotiations on the services, which are for the convenience of Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China who intend to return home for family reunions, " Chiu said, adding that the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, will name a representative to discuss relevant technical details as soon as possible.
With Beijing's consent, Taiwan carriers operated special charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during the 2003 Chinese New Year period.

Such services were not offered during the 2004 Chinese New Year holiday because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers be allowed to offer the same services, while declining to negotiate the technical details with Taiwan. The ROC government said that as the opening of two-way, non-stop cross-strait charter flight services involves the exercise of public authority, prior negotiations are necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO ADDITIONAL SPENDING AFTER NT$610.8 B ARMS PROCUREMENT PACKAGE: MND

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of National Defense Tsai Ming-hsien said Friday that a special budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) for arms procurements from the United States will obtain three major items and will not require extra major spending afterwards, as had been speculated.

Tsai was referring to the special budget proposal made by the Executive Yuan in June to buy six batteries of anti-missile Patriot III missiles, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft over a 15-year period starting 2005, saying that all relevant weaponry systems and parts are included in the special budget.

He said that the government will monitor spending carefully, adding that the expenditure for repair and maintenance, as well as the logistics for the three major arms procurement items, will be appropriated in annual budgets and will not require a need for further special budgets.
Tsai made the remarks during an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan, reaffirming again the necessity and importance of obtaining the weapons.

Legislator Wang Chung-yu of the opposition Kuomintang questioned remarks by Premier Yu Shyi-kun that those who oppose the arms procurement are in the same league as mainland China, which he said has blocked the opportunity for rational debate on the issue.
The premier pointed out that the mainland is the one who least wants Taiwan to procure arms.

Yu also said that the items in the new package are more advanced and therefore more expensive than those purchased in the past and that the legislators should not question the government on the items or the spending, but should engage in rational debate.

Meanwhile, more than 100 mothers and their children, accompanied by Legislator Lee Wen-chung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), read a declaration in front of the Legislative Yuan stating that children should be allowed to grow in peace and happiness, to lend support to the arms procurement proposal.

A bill authorizing the arms purchase failed to be put on the agenda for legislative review earlier this week, dashing the hopes of the DPP to have it reviewed before the Dec. 11 legislative elections, as the legislature is scheduled to go into a one-month recess from Nov. 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP BLOCKS PFP-PROPOSED 'CROSS-STRAIT PEACE BILL'

TEXT.P: A "cross-strait peace promotion bill" raised by the opposition People First Party (PFP) was blocked Friday by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which considers the bill impractical and superfluous.

The bill was aimed at authorizing legislators to form an unofficial team to negotiate with mainland China on a cross-strait peace accord and the opening of direct cross-strait shipping and air links. It was obstructed at the first reading owing to objections from the DPP.

Tsai Huang-liang, a leader of the DPP legislative caucus, accused the PFP of trying to boost its chances in the Dec. 11 legislative elections by proposing the bill even though it does not truly desire cross-strait peace.
Tsai said the bill is impractical because it is not up to Taiwan to decide whether to resume cross-strait dialogue that was suspended by the mainland in the first place.

In addition, the PFP's proposal to set up a special committee in charge of cross-strait peace talks, as stipulated in the bill, is redundant when the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) are already in full operation, Tsai said.
He said the bill would be in violation of executive powers and the Constitution if it were to be passed into law.
Disagreeing with Tsai, PFP Legislator Lee Tung-hao said the DPP is blocking the bill because it is insincere about restarting talks with Beijing.
Lee claimed that the government needs to authorize the private sector to conduct negotiations with Beijing, since the mainland refuses to talk with either the MAC or the SEF.
Liu Wen-hsiung, another PFP legislator, said the DPP's move proves that the peace overture offered by President Chen Shui-bian in his second inaugural and National Day addresses was a lie.
The PFP lawmakers alleged that the DPP intends to overturn the Constitution and provoke a war across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Menatep Prepares to Sue Kremlin.
Yukos' core shareholder, Group Menatep, has taken the first step toward suing Russia in international courts for compensation over the massive drop in Yukos' share value since the legal onslaught against it began, Menatep director Tim Osborne said Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: President to Consider Changes for New Term; High-Profile Departures Are Rumored.
President Bush said yesterday that he will spend the weekend considering changes in his Cabinet for his second term, feeding speculation inside and outside the White House over shake-ups in key agencies in coming weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 70.58 points to close at 5,931.31.
The bourse opened at 5,936.31 and fluctuated between 5,959.88 and 5,896.07 during trading. A total of 4.26 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$98.07 billion (US$2.96 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 4.1 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 3.5 percent, construction issues and textile stocks both at 2.9 percent, banking and financial shares at 2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.5 percent, cement stocks at 1.3 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 496 to 161, with 129 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TIES SEEN TO AFFECT WORLD SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 5 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The cross-Taiwan Strait situation will affect the development of the semiconductor industry, which will in turn impact the global economy, a U.S. business leader said Friday.

Rupert Hammond-Chambers, chairman of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, said that if tension across the Taiwan Strait escalates, the semiconductor industries in both Taiwan and mainland China will be affected and consequently have an adverse impact on the world's overall economy.

Almost all of the multinational telecom and high-technology big names have come to rely on Taiwan and the mainland for electronic components, parts and hardware, Hammond-Chambers said, adding that this is doomed to trigger a domino effect if the cross-strait situation worsens.

Hammond-Chambers said that he has noticed that over the past year, the mainland has continued to build up its military capability while refusing to renounce the option of force to address the cross-strait differences. This is indeed a source of anxiety for business circles, he said.

The issue will be elaborated upon further during the 2nd semiconductor industry meeting, which will be held in San Jose, California, Dec. 7 under the joint auspices of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council and the Taiwan-U.S. Business Council, Hammond-Chambers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.21 to close at NT$33.075.
A total of US$1.29 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.285 and hit a low of NT$33.025.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 OPPORTUNE TIME TO RESUME CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: EX-AIT HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 4 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: 2005 might be an opportune time for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume long-stalled cross-strait dialogue, former American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush said Thursday.

Beijing is still adopting a "wait and see" attitude toward Taiwan and is not expected to make any new moves prior to Taiwan's Dec. 11 legislative elections, which should see Taiwan's political landscape reshaped somewhat, said Bush, who is currently director of the Northeast Asian Studies Center under the Brookings Institution, a Washington-based think-tank.

During a discussion sponsored by the institute, Bush said he sees 2005 as a golden opportunity for officials from Taiwan and mainland China to return to the negotiating table, although, he added, it is still up to Beijing whether it is willing to grasp the opportunity.

According to Bush, the George W. Bush administration will become even more active and upbeat in pushing for a resumption of the cross Taiwan Strait dialogue after the president begins his second term.

Bush said the U.S. administration has begun to probe what it should do but has not yet done and what role the United States should play in efforts to help readdress the political impasse across the Taiwan Strait.

The key point now is that Beijing still lacks trust in President Chen Shui-bian, Bush said, adding that a resumption of the cross-strait dialogue is the only option to defuse the mutual distrust across the strait.

He backed his theory by pointing out that the mainland did not trust the United States before the two countries normalized their relations but the two countries established formal diplomatic ties eventually, after a long series of talks.

Bush also stressed that in addition to pushing for cross-strait dialogue, the Bush administration is also expected to pay closer attention to Taiwan's possible constitutional reforms and related activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAY PARADE SET FOR NOV. 6

TEXT.P: Some 60 social groups representing politics, academy, culture, the arts and entertainment are expected to join in an alternative lifestyle parade in downtown Taipei Saturday launched by homosexuals in the capital city, an organizer of the event said Friday.

The Taiwan Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual and Transgender Pride Parade's organizing committee executive secretary, Wu Hsu-niang, noted that the planned march has also won the support of many popular singers and TV celebrities, including Sandee Chen, who will participate in a musical rally at the Red Theater in Hsimenting at the end of the parade.

Although the annual march no longer enjoys the financial support it received last year from the city government, when it drew a great deal of attention from local and foreign media, Wu said, they will still put on a colorful activity filled with music to project the "happy image of the homosexual street party."

Wu said the parade will feature colorful and dazzling costumes to show the community's rich diversity and will highlight the need for society to respect all individuals regardless of their sexual orientation.

A statement released by the parade organizing committee said that as citizens of Taipei, gays and lesbians need to come out and be a part of the city. They must also understand that they have the responsibility to teach the next generation that there is no "wrong" identity and that differences must be acknowledged and respected.
The march will set off from the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall and wind through the 228 Park to the Red Theater.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES 'SPORTSMANSHIP' IN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday that election results are determined by the people and not by lengthy litigation, and that the candidates should show "sportsmanship."

The premier made the remarks in a general interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan one day after the Taiwan High Court threw out a lawsuit filed by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) to contest the result of the March 20 presidential election. Lien Chan, KMT chairman and 2004 presidential candidate, said that he will appeal the decision in the Supreme Court.

Yu said that confrontations between the ruling and the opposition parties have been going on for four-and-a-half years -- ever since the 2000 presidential election -- and added that "the legislature is crucial to a stable political situation."

Yu noted that U.S. President George W. Bush won a second term, while his Republican Party controls over half the seats in both the Senate and the House of Representatives, so that the U.S. politics should be stable.

He said that the candidates in Taiwan should display "sportsmanship" in the same way that U.S. presidential candidate John Kerry conceded defeat even before the final results of the contentious state of Ohio were announced, to avoid allowing the contention to splinter the country.

The premier had earlier urged Lien to learn from Kerry and Al Gore, another election failure, adding that even if Lien cannot graciously concede defeat, he can at least learn from Gore's behavior following the Florida vote dispute after the 2000 election and accept the election result even if he strongly disagrees with the court's verdict.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY MULLING FORUM OF PRESIDENTS OF SE ASIAN UNIVERSITIES

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University in southern Taiwan is planning to establish a forum of the presidents of Southeast Asian Universities, the first grouping of its kind.

The university said that it will invite the presidents of eight national universities in Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam to convene the first organization meeting Nov. 8 so that the forum can become a regular academic organization.

Cheng Kung officials said the participants in the forum will discuss such issues as the goals, mission, charter and organization of the forum, as well as the annual activities of the forum, during the organization meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARITIME RESEARCH CENTER SET UP ON PRATAS ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government announced Friday the launch of an international maritime research center on the Pratas Islands, known in Chinese as the Dongsha Islands, in the South China Sea.
The research center has been set up at the fishermen's service center operated by the Taiwan government on the archipelago, according to the Kaohsiung City Maritime and Harbor Bureau.
The archipelago is currently under the mandate of the city government.
Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said the research center will be aimed at improving the conservation of maritime resources around the islands.
Hsieh said domestic and foreign experts will be invited to the research center to promote international cooperation on the protection of natural and cultural resources.

The archipelago comprises Dongsha Island and two coral reefs. In addition to the fishermen's service center, the Taiwan government has established a hospital, power station and runway there. The island group is also an outpost for the ROC Navy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November gained 84 points to close at 5,920, with 30,446 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December moved up 100 points to finish at 5,927, with 543 contracts traded, while March futures gained 90 points to finish at 5,900, with one contract traded.
June futures gained 40 points to finish at 5,850, with four contracts traded, while September futures moved up 67 points to close at 5,830, with six contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,836 for November, 5,827 for December, 5,810 for March, 5,810 for June and 5,763 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
November TE futures moved up 1.9 points to close at 219, with 6,821 contracts traded, while December TE futures gained two points to finish at 219, with 96 contract transactions.
June TE futures moved up 7.25 points to end at 218.1, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and September.
November TF futures gained 24.8 points to finish at 1,055, with 9,626 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved up 24 points to end at 1,052, with 440 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CARGO VOLUME AT OFFSHORE TRANSSHIPPING CENTER TO GROW 10% IN 2004

TEXT.P: The container volume of the offshore transshipping center of Kaohsiung Port is expected to rise 10 percent in 2004 over last year, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Friday.
The volume of containers handled by the transshipping center has increased every year since it started operations in April 1997, MOTC officials said.
While the container volume amounted to some 127,000 twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs) in 1997, it rose to 400,000 TEUs in 1998, the officials pointed out.
With the volume continuing to expand, it reached 2.91 million TEUs in 2003 and stood at 3.41 million TEUs as of the end of September this year, they noted.
Meanwhile, the volume of the center's joint sea-air freight services amounted to 86,000 kg in 2001, the year the services were first launched, the officials went on.
The volume of the services increased to 1.3 million kg in 2003 and further rose to 1.87 million kg as of the end of September this year, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS FACING HURDLE CLOSE TO 6,000 POINTS

TEXT.P: Political factors at home and abroad that might influence the domestic stock market have been largely removed, but share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange are still facing strong pressure to overcome the 6,000-point mark, analysts said Friday.

With the recent re-election of U.S. President George W. Bush and the Taiwan High Court ruling securing the validity of President Chen Shui-bian's March 20 re-election, foreign and domestic political uncertainties were gone, in principle giving a boost to the domestic bourse, market watchers said.
Asian markets overall made gains Thursday on good cheer over Bush's victory, whose administration is widely viewed as business-friendly.
The weighted index, the key barometer of the Taiwan Stock Exchange, was slightly down by two points a day earlier, but advanced by 70.58 points to finish Friday at 5,931.31.

However, the analysts pointed out that international oil prices will be the leading element affecting the domestic stock market in the mid term and that the value of the local currency will be another major factor influencing the domestic bourse in the short term as the weighted index approaches the 6,000-point level.

It is worth observing whether a stronger new Taiwan dollar will have a negative impact on high-tech shares, as its noticeable appreciation in recent days has fueled pressure on their exports, the analysts said, forecasting that the weighted index will hover in a narrow range between 5,900 and 6,000 points in the short term.

Meanwhile, the new Taiwan dollar surged by NT$0.142 to end at 33.285 against the U.S. dollar Thursday. It further gained ground against the greenback to close at 33.075 Friday -- a six-month high -- in anticipation of a higher mainland China's renminbi.
Foreign institutional dealers have overbought the local currency for seven days in a row with a value of NT$43.92 billion -- a level close to the October's total of NT$46.98 billion.

Market sources said there has been an obvious foreign capital influx in recent days and that it seems the central bank has adopted a hands-off policy to allow the local currency to gain in value to ease growing inflationary pressure in the home market.
They opined that the U.S. dollar will not go up against other major currencies despite Bush's victory, citing the long-standing U.S. trade deficits and federal fiscal deficits.
The new Taiwan dollar had a high of 30.5 against the U.S. dollar in 2000, leaving room for the local currency to further appreciate, they pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAYS HE WOULD RATHER LOSE ELECTION THAN RULE OF LAW

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday he would rather lose a presidential election than see the nation's interests, democratic system and rule of law principles undermined.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with a group of commissioners of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) who have returned from their countries of residence to attend an annual OCAC congress.

As the meeting came a day after the Taiwan High Court ruled against an opposition "pan-blue alliance" lawsuit contesting the March 20 presidential election, Chen told OCAC commissioners that he would never pursue electoral success at the expense of national interests and the democratic spirit.

"Elections are ephemeral, while the nation is eternal. We have only one nation, while elections take place once every few years or many times a year. We cannot afford to lose our country simply because of a single election. We would rather lose an election than lose our country. We would rather lose an election than see our democratic system and respect for rule of law undermined," Chen said.
He hailed 2004 as a year when Taiwan has made further progress in its democratic development.

"The 2000 presidential election ushered in Taiwan's first-ever peaceful transition of power between different political parties. Even though this year's presidential election result was contested, we have managed to address it through judicial means in line with the principles of democracy and rule of law. The pursuit of judicial judgment has helped push forward our democratic development, " Chen said.
Compared with advanced democratic countries, Chen went on, Taiwan still has much to do to improve and deepen its young democracy.

Stressing that democracy and rule of law should be Taiwan's founding spirit, Chen said his administration will continue to upgrade the quality of Taiwan's democratic rule and boost the development of its civic society.

Chen also promised to make every possible effort to promote mutual respect and harmony among the various domestic ethnic groups, as well as to craft a more modern and efficient governing framework and constitutional system that fits Taiwan's present reality and can contribute to its global competitiveness.
The High Court rejected a day earlier the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" lawsuit contesting Chen's narrow re-election victory.

The ruling ended seven months of hearings, a ballot recount, cross-debates, consultations and investigations into the various contentious points that posed a serious challenge to one of Asia's youngest democracies. The disputed vote was only Taiwan's third direct presidential election.

The "pan-blue alliance's" two top leaders -- Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman (PFP) James Soong -- who teamed up to challenge Chen and Vice President Annette Lu's re-election bid -- have insisted that the Chen-Lu's re-election should be nullified because of alleged ballot tampering and an election-eve shooting of Chen and Lu that they said swayed sympathy votes in the Chen-Lu ticket's favor.

The alliance also claimed that thousands of police and soldiers could not vote because the president put them on special alert after the shooting. Chen's administration has denied Lien's allegations, and the "pan-blue alliance" has consistently failed to provide any compelling evidence to support it's claims.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOALA LOANED FROM AUSTRALIA EUTHANIZED

TEXT.P: A koala loaned to Taipei Zoo from Australia was euthanized earlier this week, Taipei Zoo officials announced Friday.

The marsupial, named Haley, was suspected of having developed a tumor in his nose that was affecting his breathing and his appetite, so zoo officials, after consulting with Australian veterinarian Michael Pyne, decided to euthanize him Monday, the officials said.

The officials said that Pyne, who had brought two new koalas to Taiwan Oct. 28, said that even with continued treatment, the animal would have died in between two and four weeks, and that he should be put out of his misery.

A specimen of the tumor was sent for analysis and the results should come out in about 10 days. It was initially determined that the cause of Haley's death was different from that of Action, another koala loaned to Taipei Zoo who succumbed to lymphatic cancer in December 2002.

Chen Pao-chung, director of Taipei Zoo, said that the zoo had done everything possible to save Haley. The delay in announcing his death, he explained, was because the zoo was preoccupied with the 2004 joint annual conference of the Conservation Breeding Specialist Group and the World Association of Zoos and Aquariums running from Oct. 29 through Nov. 4, and could not spare time to deal with the press.
He pointed out that every year, more than 200 animals die in Taipei Zoo, but about the same number is born in the zoo, saying that this is normal in zoos.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Confident Bush Outlines Ambitious Plan for 2nd Term.
President Bush said he would begin work immediately on his proposal to overhaul Social Security.
The Wall Stree Journal: Bush Sets Plans To Revamp Taxes, Social Security.
Fresh from his re-election victory, President Bush laid out an ambitious economic agenda, signaling a broad overhaul of the tax code and promising to revamp Social Security.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENTS IN EXPORT PROCESSING ZONES SURPASS GOAL SET FOR 2004

TEXT.P: The investment and capital-increment projects approved for Taiwan's export processing zones in the first 10 months have surpassed the goal set for this year, the Export Processing Zone Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Friday.

Administration officials said that the approved investment in the first 10 months amounted to NT$6.13 billion (US$184.32 million) while the amounts for capital-increment projects amounted to NT$27.08 billion. The two combined showed an increase of 35.41 percent from the same period last year, surpassing the goal of attracting NT$30 billion for this year and the creation of around 4,000 jobs.

Among the new investments, the high-tech electronics sector led with NT$1.9 billion, accounting for 30.69 percent. Among the capital-increment projects, high-tech electronics again led with NT$18.1 billion, accounting for 66.94 percent.
The officials were upbeat about the new investment and capital-increment projects, saying that this shows that manufacturers are satisfied with the investment environment in the zones.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAILS GERMAN PARLIAMENT'S SUPPORT FOR CHINA ARMS EMBARGO

TEXT.P: Taiwan praised the German Federal Parliament Friday for passing a resolution opposing the lifting of the European Union's arms embargo against mainland China.
In a statement, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said the move was in compliance with mainstream public opinion and deserves the most positive recognition from the Taiwan government.
The ministry called the international community's attention to the significance of the move and urged the E.U. to continue to maintain its ban on arms sales to China.
The resolution was adopted on Oct. 28 with the support of the ruling coalition Social Democratic Party and the Greens.

According to the resolution, the German government is urged to press the E.U. to continue to monitor the mainland's progress on human rights protection and resolving conflicts via peaceful means as the criteria for whether to lift the arms embargo.
The German parliament asked the E.U. to work out binding measures on controlling arms exports by its member nations to China.

Before lifting the embargo, the E.U. must also consider China's progress in complying with the UN Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, protecting human rights and private property and improving the right to self-government of minority ethnic groups in China, the resolution said.

Other considerations should include the non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and rocket propulsion materials and technology as well as Beijing's attitude to a peaceful resolution of cross-Taiwan Strait disputes, it said.
The arms embargo was introduced in 1989 after a bloody crackdown ordered by the Chinese government on a pro-democracy demonstration in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.

Taiwan has launched an international campaign opposing the E.U.'s plan to lift the embargo on the grounds that China has targeted more than 600 missiles against Taiwan and is continuing its military buildup.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIOTECH INDUSTRY AIMS TO IMPROVE THE LIVES OF THE PEOPLE: VP LU

TEXT.P: The government will encourage the biotechnology sector in Taiwan to grow by 25 percent per year in the next five years to make life better for all the citizens of the nation, Vice President Annette Lu said Friday.

Speaking at the opening of the Sustainable Health Trend Show 2004, Lu said that there were over 3,000 suicides in Taiwan last year and that the biotechnology industry can work to improve the lives of the people while at the same time giving them a reason to live.
Biotechnology in Taiwan is one of two industries that the government hopes will create an annual output more than NT$1 trillion (US$30.23 billion) within a few years.
The government has earmarked NT$9 billion (US$272.12 million) in venture capital to help finance start-ups for biotechnology companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: FILIPINO MAYOR CALLS ON TAIWAN PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: Hagedorn, mayor of Puerto Princesa in Palawan, the Philippines, paid a courtesy call on the Taiwan Provincial Government in Taichung, central Taiwan Friday.
Hagedorn and his entourage were greeted by Lin Kuanghua, governor of Taiwan Province, and was given a briefing on the overall situation of the province.

Hagedorn, who is also the chairman of the Filipino Association of Mayors told Lin he is studying Taiwan's investment environment in hopes of drawing some lessons for his hometown in attracting foreign investment.
After the call, Hagedorn and his entourage went on to visit the Taichung Science-based Industrial Park, Puli Winery Corp. and Sun Moon Lake near Taichung.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST PEOPLE WANT LIEN-SOONG TICKET TO ACCEPT COURT RULING: POLL

TEXT.P: A majority of people responding to an opinion poll hope that the two top opposition "pan-blue alliance" leaders accept the court ruling against their lawsuit to try to have President Chen Shui-bian's re-election victory nullified, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative candidate said Friday.

Wu Ping-yu said the telephone survey of 1,080 randomly chosen adult residents was conducted by the DPP's Justice Alliance faction Thursday evening shortly after the Taiwan High Court announced its dismissal of the opposition petition.

According to the survey results, 68.9 percent of those interviewed said they think that all domestic political parties should accept the court's decision to uphold President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu's re-election victory; only 9.4 percent said they don't think that the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) should accept the ruling; and 21.8 percent said they don't know whether the opposition alliance should accept the ruling or not.

Meanwhile, 55.2 percent said they do not support the Lien-Soong ticket's decision to appeal the case to the Supreme Court; 22.4 percent gave a thumbs-up to the decision; and 22.4 percent didn't answer the question. A cross-analysis showed that 32 percent of the "pan-blue" supporters were opposed to the Lien-Soong plan to appeal.

The poll also found that 61 percent of the respondents were supportive of U.S. Democratic presidential candidate John Kerry's swift concession to his defeat in the Nov. 2 election; only 3 percent said they didn't agree to Kerry's move; and 36 percent didn't give an opinion.
The High Court rejected a day earlier the "pan-blue alliance's" lawsuit contesting the Chen-Lu ticket's narrow re-election victory.

The ruling ended seven months of hearings, a ballot recount, cross-debates, consultations and investigations into the various contentious points that posed a serious challenge to one of Asia's youngest democracies. The disputed vote was only Taiwan's third direct presidential election.

The "pan-blue alliance" has insisted that the re-election should be nullified because of alleged ballot tampering and an election-eve shooting of Chen and Lu that they said swayed sympathy votes in the Chen-Lu ticket's favor.

The alliance also claimed that thousands of police and soldiers could not vote because the president put them on special alert after the shooting. Chen's administration has denied Lien's allegations, and the "pan-blue alliance" has consistently failed to provide any compelling evidence to support its claims.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CPI GROWTH RATE MILD: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) grew by 1.62 percent year-on-year for the first 10 months of this year, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Friday.

DGBAS officials pointed to higher vegetable and meat prices in summer after a bad season of typhoons as the main factors behind the increase, but said that the growth is relatively mild compared to those posted by other countries.

The world's latest information shows that during the January-September period, the United States and mainland China recorded a CPI growth rate of 2.5 percent and 4.1 percent. South Korea had a growth rate of 3.7 percent, while Singapore and Japan posted rates of 1.7 percent and negative 0.2 percent.

The CPI stood at 102.54 points for October, up by 2.36 percent compared to the previous year's level, DGBAS statistics show. October's core price index expanded by 0.92 percent over the year-earlier level.

The wholesales price index (WPI) rose by an annual growth rate of 12.02 percent to 113.91 points last month -- the highest level since April, 1981, which DGBAS official attributed to soaring prices of oil, basic metals and chemical materials since early this year.
Taiwan's WPI increased by an average 6.97 percent for the first 10 months of the year.

Commenting on the effects of an appreciating local currency, DGBAS officials said its long- and mid-term courses are to assess, but pointed out that its short-term impact in the export and import sectors is obvious and imminent.
The local currency's rapid surge in value in recent days will bring down import product prices and help dilute increased inflationary pressure at home, they said.

The new Taiwan dollar closed Friday at a six-month high of 33.075 against the U.S. dollar, a rise of NT$0.21 over the Thursday finish, provoking grave concerns about a hike in domestic product prices.
A weaker U.S. dollar has led the world's hot money into Asian markets, including Taiwan, pushing up their currencies.
Transactions in the Taipei foreign exchange market broke the US$1 billion level in morning trading Friday and totaled US$1.29 billion for the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 MAINLAND WOMEN USING FAKE ROC PASSPORTS INTERCEPTED AT CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Two mainland Chinese women intending to enter the United States with bogus Republic of China passports and aircraft boarding passes were arrested in the control area of Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport Friday.
Both women came from the southeastern mainland province of Fujian. They arrived at CKS Airport via a Cathay Airways flight from Hong Kong.

The two women, whose real names are Chen Yodi and Chen Fang, told airport police that a man gave them the passports and boarding passes after they arrived at CKS Airport. They were intercepted by aviation police when they were going to the boarding gate for a U.S.-bound flight.
Asked about how much they had paid for the passports and boarding passes, the two women claimed that they had no idea because the deals were arranged by their parents.

Aviation police said the period from Halloween to New Year has traditionally been the peak season for illegal immigration to the United States. Would-be illegal immigrants usually buy fake passports of various countries with U.S. visa stamps for US$30,000 to US$60,000 each.

The two women were identified as Chang Chiu-feng and Lin Li-yueh on the bogus ROC passports, police said, adding that the entry and exit stamps on the "passports" were also fake and the U.S. visa stamps were rather vague. Police said they will track down the human smuggling ring behind the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SITS ON WORLD'S THIRD-LARGEST FOREX RESERVES

TEXT.P: Taiwan held foreign exchange reserves worth US$235.032 billion as of the end of October, the world's third-largest, the Central Bank of China (CBC) reported Friday.
The figure represents rises of US$2.026 billion and US$28.4 billion over the September level and the 2003 year-end level, according to CBC statistics.
Taiwan came after Japan and mainland China in this field, which possessed foreign exchange reserves of US$811.165 billion and of US$514.538 billion as of the end of September, respectively.

CBC tallies show that South Korea sat on US$177.529 billion in foreign exchange reserves as of late last month, while Hong Kong and Singapore held US$117.791 billion and US$101.422 billion worth of forex reserves as of the end of September, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAMESE WOMEN 'ON SALE' ORDERED TO LEAVE IN A WEEK

TEXT.P: Four Vietnamese women were ordered to leave Taiwan after attempting to auction themselves off for marriage in front of the famous Matsu Temple on the offshore island of Penghu. Prices ranged from NT$300,000 (US$9, 000) to NT$100,000 (US$3,000).
The four entered Taiwan on tourist visas and have been ordered by the National Police Administration (NPA) to leave within a week, a spokesman for the NPA said Friday.
According to the NPA officer, the four women from Vietnam will be repatriated in compliance with the Immigration Law if they don't do so before Nov. 10.

Police authorities in the island county of Penghu already issued the women a punishment notice for pandering, the spokesman noted, adding that what they did here was not compatible to their visa status and that they have seriously violated social morals.
The incident came to light after local media reported days ago that a group of foreign women, through arrangements by local brokers, were up for auction at the temple.
Lawmakers lashed out at the brokers' "incredible lawlessness" and called it a huge insult to Taiwan, which has always striven for human rights.
Legislators from various political parties and social service associations have asked government agencies to bring the alleged human cargo traffickers and their conspirators to justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT BEATS DRUM FOR TOURISM IN KINMEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian beat the drum for tourism in Kinmen, saying the former frontline island has developed into a gateway between Taiwan and mainland China after the launch of direct shipping links and direct trade between Kinmen and the mainland.

Opening a cultural exhibition of Kinmen at the Presidential Office, Chen said his government will push the remote island into the international limelight by developing it into an international sightseeing area.
The exhibition, which features Kaoliang liquor, ceramics and other products from Kinmen, will run until Dec. 31.
This is the 19th cultural exhibition regularly staged by the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY DENIES US$28 MILLION GRANT TO VANUATU

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Friday that he has heard nothing about the government promising to give Vanuatu a grant of US$28 million as reported by a wire service.

Michel Lu said Taiwan is talking with Vanuatu over cooperation plans after agreeing on diplomatic ties on Wednesday, and it is too early to say exactly how much grant money Taiwan will give the South Pacific nation.

Lu was asked about Friday's wire service report from Port Vila, Vanuatu, that a spokesman for Vanuatu Prime Minister Serge Vohor told a newspaper in Port Vila that Taiwan will offer grant money of up to US$28 million to his country next year in return for Vanuatu's diplomatic recognition.

Quoting Serge Vohor as saying in the same wire service report that his government would like to work with both China and Taiwan simultaneously, Lu said Vohor didn't back down on the agreement he entered into with Taiwan in Taipei.

As an independent state, Lu said, Vanuatu is free to choose its friends, and China should respect Port Vila's decision to maintain ties with both sides of the Taiwan Strait. Help should be given to Vanuatu rather than trying to force it to chose between Beijing and Taipei.
Noting that Vohor will discuss the diplomatic ties with Taiwan in a Cabinet meeting next week, Lu said his ministry is sure that Vanuatu will honor its agreement with Taiwan.
China, which considers Taiwan a renegade province, has always asked its allies not to associate with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORENSIC EXPERT'S '319 SHOOTING' REPORT POSTED ON WEB SITE

TEXT.P: Prosecution authorities on Friday published Chinese-American forensic expert Dr. Henry Lee's investigative report of the shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu on the eve of the March 20 presidential election.

Both the Chinese and English versions of the 133-page report were posted on the Web site of the State Public Prosecutor General's Office at http: //www.tps.moj.gov.tw/ for whomever is interested in the report to download.
Lee sent the report, completed by his forensic investigative team, to the supreme prosecutor's office from the United States via a diplomatic channel Aug. 30.

The supreme prosecutor's office asked the Criminal Investigation Bureau's (CIB) forensic department to translate the English version into Chinese. CIB forensic experts spent 10 days completing the Chinese version. After proofreading by Chuang Chun-shan, a prosecutor versed in English, the Chinese version was sent to Dr. Lee.

State Public Prosecutor General Wu Ying-chao said now is the "best time" to publish the report because the 319 shooting investigative team has completed investigations based on part of the report which had to be kept secret before.

Moreover, Wu said, the Taiwan High Court already handed down its ruling a day earlier against the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" petition to try to have Chen-Lu's narrow re-election victory nullified.

"The report had been open for lawyers of the plaintiffs and the defendants of the election lawsuit to read during the court proceeding. With a view to letting the general public understand facts about the shooting, we decided to publish the report," Wu said.

The report includes photos of Chen's and Lu's injuries, their clothing, and the two bullets that were found at the crime scene. So far, investigators have arrested no suspects, but have launched searches of illegal weapon manufacturers in an effort to find tools that might have been used in making the bullets.

According to the report, Lee and his team found scant evidence that could lead investigators to identify the shooter, in part because the scene was not secured immediately after the crime was committed.
"Many of the shooting incident details and the exact scenarios were not able to be reconstructed, due to the fact that the crime scene was not fully preserved," the report said.

The report pointed out that the following issues and questions cannot be scientifically or positively concluded -- (1) Whether the two bullets were fired from one or two different weapons with nearly identical barrel characteristics. (2) The exact muzzle velocity of each shot. (3) The impact velocity and impact energy of each shot. (4) The energy created by or associated with each shot. (5) Degree of damage created by each shot. (6) The exact ejection pattern of each of the casings.

Lee also concluded that two shots were fired at the two candidates within one second. But because no weapons were recovered, it was impossible to say "whether the two bullets were fired from one or two different weapons with nearly identical barrel characteristics," the report said, adding that if a weapon was found in the future, markings found on the bullets could help identify whether it was used in the shooting.

The "pan-blue alliance's" presidential candidate, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, claimed that the presidential vote was marred by fraud and unfairly influenced by the election-eve shooting. Lien even insinuated that the shooting was staged by Chen's camp to sway sympathy votes in his favor. However, the court ruled that Lien's claims were not sufficient grounds to nullify Chen-Lu's re-election. Lien and his running mate, James Soong, have vowed to appeal the case to the Supreme Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR NOV. 6 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Nov. 6:
06: 00, The 2004 Taroko International Marathon will kick off in Hualien, eastern Taiwan.
09:00, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu will deliver a speech at the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission's annual meeting at Howard Hotel in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S STANCE ON SOVEREIGNTY IS CONSISTENT AND CLEAR: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has made clear his stance on the country's sovereignty, its ties with China and constitutional reform, and critics should not misrepresent what he has said for political purposes, according to a statement issued by the Presidential Office Friday.

In a response to Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's claims that Chen is aggressively pushing for Taiwan independence and has a timetable for it, the statement said the president has made his stance on the issues clear in his 2000 inaugural address, 2004 second inaugural address and 2004 Double Ten National Day speech, and has stuck to it.
The statement said critics should not made groundless accusations against the president to cause the public alarm.
Lien made his claims in an interview with the London-based weekly the Economist, which was published this week.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAYS HIS TWO MAJOR TASKS ARE HISTORIC FOR THE COUNTRY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that he is a person who creates history and he wants to accomplish two major tasks: creating a constitution suitable for Taiwan and normalizing ties with China.

In an interview posted on the Time magazine Web site, the president reiterates that Taiwan is a sovereign state, its name is the Republic of China, and that his government does not accept Beijing's claim of "one China."
He urges mainland Chinese leaders to view ties with Taiwan in perspective.
Claiming that he had reached out to Beijing more than 30 times in the last four years, the president said Beijing has never bothered to respond but that he won't give up his efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Nov. 6, or the 24th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1429: Henry VI is crowned the King of England.
1813: Mexico declares independence from Spain.
1854: John Philip Sousa, U.S. composer of military marches, is born.
1860: Abraham Lincoln becomes the 16th president of the United States.
1893: Russian composer Pyotr I. Tchaikovsky dies at the age of 53.
1917: The U.S. state of New York passes legislation granting voting rights to women, becoming the first state to embrace women's suffrage.
1923: The German mark reaches the incredible figure of 4.2 trillion to the U.S. dollar, as compared to 4.2 to the dollar 10 years previous.
1928: Herbert Hoover is elected the 31st U.S. president.
1938: Chinese Communist leader Mao Tse-tung urges every Communist to grasp the truth, saying that "political power grows out of the barrel of a gun."
1948: The Battle of Hsu-Pang breaks out in northern China. Nationalist troops are defeated in a crucial episode in China's civil war that allowed the Chinese Communist regime to grab the whole of mainland China in the following year.
1949: Kuomintang troops stationed on Tengpu islet of the Chowshan Islands, opposite mainland China's Chechiang (Zhejiang) Province, crush invading Communist troops, killing 5,000 and capturing 2,000.
1962: The U.N. General Assembly adopts a resolution condemning South Africa for its policy of apartheid.
1970: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Italy.
1975: The United States announces its withdrawal from the International Labor Organization.
1976: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC's Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, and Edgardo Abella, president of the Chamber of Industry of Uruguay, sign an agreement to promote trade and economic cooperation between the two countries.
1986: The Democratic Progressive Party holds its first Representative Assembly and releases a draft of its charter and platform.
1987: Noboru Takeshita is sworn in as Japan's prime minister.
1988: Soviet human rights activist Andrei Sakharov visits the United States.
1990: Nawaz Sharif is sworn in as Pakistan's prime minister.
1991: President Boris Yeltsin of the Russian Federation issues a decree bringing the Ministry of National Defense, the Ministry of the Interior and the National Security Council under his direct jurisdiction. The decree also bans the Communist Party of the Soviet Union and nationalizes its property.
1996: Croatia becomes the 40th member of the Council of Europe.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui presides over a ceremony at Fu Hsing Kang College to mark the joint commencement of six military academies of the three branches of the Republic of China's armed forces.
1999: Indonesian Attorney-General Marzuki Darusman says the new Indonesian government will be "even-handed" in its treatment of ethnic Chinese and will avoid the racial discrimination of previous administrations.
2000: The Asian Pacific League for Freedom and Democracy issues a joint statement expressing strong support for the Republic of China's bid to enter the World Trade Organization and the World Health Organization.
2000: Taiwan's three major opposition parties decide to support their Legislative Yuan caucuses in a move to push forward a recall motion against President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu despite the president's televised apology apparently aimed at defusing the political crisis.
2001: Bankers from both sides of the Taiwan Strait attend a two-day symposium in Taipei to exchange views on the challenges facing the banking sector and opportunities after both mainland China and Taiwan are admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
2001: The 10th industrial cooperation meeting between the Republic of China and France is held in Taipei.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian opens the 2001 34th World Cup Baseball Tournament at the Tienmu Diamond in suburban Taipei.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The great man is he who does not lose his child's heart (of innocence)."

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:

The United Daily News: New Taiwan dollar rises sharply against U.S. dollar.
The Liberty Times: Chinese woman nabbed for using false Taiwan passport.

US orders women, kids out of Fallujah.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Guards and TV cammeras for all schools.
Every school in Singapore will be patrolled by security guards and fitted with up to 12 closed-circuit TV cameras over the next few months, as part of enhanced security measures announced yesterday.
The Lianhe Zaobao: All schools in Singapore hire Guards to stop the terrorist attack.
Singapore Government will help 351 schools in the whole country to hire security guards and Install 10 to 12 closed-circuit TV cameras over the nexy few mouths, as part of enhanced security measures announced yesterday.
