DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Palestininan leader Arafat in coma
PARIS, France -- Palestinian President Yasser Arafat is in a coma between life and death, a senior Palestinian official said yesterday, as some of the Palestinian president's powers have been transferred to his prime minister.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: AFTER WIFE'S APPEAL Iraq militants free Filipino accountant--Al Jazeera
BAGHDAD -- Filipino accountant Robert Tarongoy and a Nepalese kidnapped early this week by Iraqi militants have been released by their captors, the Arabic television station Al-Jazeera reported on Friday.
The Philippine Star: GMA: RP-US relations good Relations between the Philippines and the United States remain "good" despite Washington's displeasure over the withdrawal of Filipino troops from Iraq in July, President Arroyo said yesterday.
The Manila Times: Tarongoy, 1 other Iraq hostage freed BAGHDAD, Iraq -- Arabic television station Al-Jazeera said Friday a Filipino and a Nepalese kidnapped earlier in the week have been released by their captors. Nepalese officials confirmed the report but the Filipinos said they could not.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOTE ALLOCATION STRATEGY WOULD BE DIFFICULT FOR 'PAN-BLUE': WANG

TEXT.P: It would be difficult for the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) , People First Party (PFP) and New Party to employ the vote allocation strategy in the year-end legislative elections, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Saturday.
Wang, who doubles as KMT vice chairman, told journalists that the strategy would be difficult to execute for the KMT as the party's candidates attract supporters through personal charisma.
"Even if the candidates agree among themselves to evenly divide their support, their supporters won't necessary listen by shifting their support from one candidate to another," Wang said.

Another problem, Wang said, is that none of the three "pan-blue alliance" parties are sure that the support they command among them in a particular constituent is sufficient to ensure the election of all the "pan-blue" candidates, and dividing their support would only result in failure for all of them.
The case is especially true in southern Taiwan where the candidates canvass votes through their personal relations rather than their party affiliation, Wang said.

Wang said the best thing that the "pan-blue" candidates can do is campaign together, adding that the KMT would not grudge helping "pan-blue" candidates who are not certain of victory but have a chance.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG REITERATES PFP'S OPPOSITION TO ARMS PURCHASE PLAN

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong reiterated his party's opposition to the government's arms purchase plan Saturday.

Opening the campaign headquarters for a PFP legislative candidate in Taipei, Soong said his party won't back off from its opposition to the arms purchase plan because the US$18.23 billion price asked for by the United States is "exorbitant".

Noting that President Chen Shui-bian is leading the country on a collision course with mainland China by pressing for a new constitution and a new country, Soong said Chen's policy will bring disaster to the country.
He urged the public to avoid the disaster by voting for the "pan-blue alliance, " which groups the Kuomintang and PFP, in the year-end legislative elections because of the peace policy it advocates.

Meanwhile Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Tsai Huang-liang called on the public Saturday to punish Soong and his party for their stance on the arms purchase plan by denying them support in the elections, arguing that their opposition to the arms purchase will jeopardize the nation's security.
Tsai, who is the DPP whip at the Legislative Yuan, vowed to continue his party's efforts to push the arms purchase plan through the legislature as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WARNED TO BE WATCHFUL OF SOCIAL DISORDER IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan must be watchful of the possibility of mainland China resorting to nationalism to try to distract domestic attention from ongoing social disorder, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu warned Saturday.

Wu was referring to a Washington Post report which said the Beijing leadership has felt the challenge to the rule of the Chinese Communist Party after more than 58,000 public demonstrations occurred on the mainland last year.
Wu said Taiwan must not consider the problem as a purely domestic affair of mainland China.

In the face of domestic instability, mainland authorities are likely to resort to nationalism to try to strengthen unity within the country and distract the people's attention from the problem, according to Wu.
He warned that this situation could mean disaster for Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 FSA SUPPLIERS EXPO TAIWAN TO OPEN NOV. 11 IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The first Fabless Semiconductor Association (FSA) Suppliers Expo Taiwan is set to open Nov. 11 in Taipei, organizers said Saturday.
This will be the Asian equivalent of the FSA Suppliers Expo which has been held annually over the past decade in the Silicon Valley, California, the organizers said.

More than 50 noted chip makers, IC design and packaging and testing firms, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) , United Microelectronics, Cadence Design Systems, Agilent Technologies and Amkor Technology, are expected to participate in the show.

The Semiconductor Leaders Forum will be held simultaneously with the exhibition. Speakers at the event will include TSMC Chairman Morris Chang, MediaTek Chairman Tsai Min-kai and Cadence Executive Chairman Ray Bingham.

In addition, there will be a technology forum and luncheon on low-power design chain which will feature a number of industry leaders such as Christopher Chun, advanced power management system architect of Freescale Semiconductor Inc., and Richard Williams, engineering manager of ARM's foundry program and camb core implementation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: President Eager to Spend His New "Political Capital".
Declaring that this year's election had armed him with fresh "political capital, " President Bush said he would use that asset to try to fundamentally change Social Security and alter the federal tax code--twin goals certain to provoke strong opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Lottery cash used 'to boost Labour'.
More than half the National Lottery money raised for good causes is being diverted into a fund which props up the Government's pet projects, charity leaders said last night. As the lottery celebrates its tenth anniversary today, The Times can disclose that most charity leaders oppose plans by Tessa Jowell, the Culture Secretary, to redirect more lottery money to projects aligned with the Government, such as tackling obesity.
Financial Times: Warning from Sunni heartland as US assault on Falluja looms.
Iraqi's interim government is struggling to assert its authority in Samarra, the first town in the country's Sunni heartland to be wrested from rebel control, as National Guards, mostly from the capital and the Shia south, clash with local police.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DETAILS 'CHALLENGE 2008' PLAN IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: The "Challenge 2008" Six-Year National Development Plan is aimed at strengthening Taiwan's competitive edge to counter Beijing's suppression against Taiwan in the international community, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday.

Yu made the remarks at a symposium sponsored by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) at the National Museum of Natural Science in central Taichung City to explain to the public the achievements so far under the government's drive to promote the national development plan.

Stressing that the plan is designed to make Taiwan stronger and to further reach out to the world amid Beijing's all-dimension blockade, Yu said that if Taiwan were to do nothing, it would become an outcast in the international community by the time of the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games.

According to the premier, the six-year national development plan has seven targets, and some of the aims have already been met since it was launched two years ago. He added that he is confident that more of the targets will be reached ahead of schedule.

The main goals contained in the plan are cultivating talent for the e-generation, developing the cultural creativity industry, developing an industrial base for research and innovation, increasing value-added production, doubling the number of tourist arrivals, building a digital Taiwan, making Taiwan an operations center, improving transportation infrastructure, conserving the ecology and water resources, and constructing new hometown communities.

The government hopes to create at least 700,000 job opportunities, maintain an annual economic growth rate of more than 5 percent, lower the jobless rate to below 4 percent, and boast over 6 million broadband subscribers, he added.

Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng and Changhua County Magistrate Wong Chin-chu, who were also present on the occasion, gave the thumbs-up to the boost provided by the plan to local development and promised to fully cooperate with the central government in the drive.
The Executive Yuan is slated to host a second such symposium in southern Kaohsiung City after the current round in Taichung ends on Nov. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTED US$28 M. GRANT TO VANUATU AN 'IMAGINARY' FIGURE: MOFA

TEXT.P: An official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday that reports about Taiwan offering a grant of US$28 million to Vanuatu is an "imaginary" figure.

Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Kau Ying-mao made the remarks one day after a wire service report from Port-Vila, Vanuatu quoted a spokesman for Vanuatuan Prime Minister Serge Vohor as saying that Taiwan will offer grant money of up to US$28 million to his country next year in return for Vanuatu's diplomatic recognition.

Vohor and Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen jointly signed a communique on the establishment of formal diplomatic relations in Taipei Wednesday on behalf of their respective countries.
The South Pacific island nation became the 27th diplomatic ally of the ROC.

Kau noted that the ROC does provide economic assistance to its allies and that the ROC and Vanuatu have reached an understanding on such assistance, although the amount will be worked out later by the two governments.
Taiwan will have to assess the cooperation projects formally proposed by Vanuatu before it decides on the actual amount of such assistance, Kau said.
On the Vanuatuan spokesman's remarks that there will be a NT$28 million grant, Kau said that this is an "imaginary" figure, reiterating that the amount has not yet been finalized.
He noted that Vohor had returned to his country and called a press conference to announce the establishment of diplomatic relations with the ROC.
Although there are different views within the Vanuatuan government, Kau said that this is normal in democratic countries and that there is nothing to worry about.

Vohor will hold a Cabinet meeting next Monday to discuss the issue of establishing diplomatic relations with the ROC, and he will be able to resolve the differences within his government then, Kau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: YU HOPES FOR RATIONAL DEBATE IN LEGISLATURE ON ARMS PURCHASE PLAN

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday that the Legislative Yuan should have a rational debate on the major arms procurement plan from the United States.
He was referring to the Executive Yuan proposed special budget of NT$610.8 to buy six batteries of Patriot-III missiles, eight diesel-fueled submarines and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft.

The premier said that if the opposition parties support the plan but have different views on the price and items of the procurement, they can debate them in the legislature, instead of trying to block the plan through procedural matters.

Yu also said that a rational debate on the plan has been blocked from taking place because the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) does not control a majority in the 225-seat legislature, adding that if the party can win enough seats in the Dec. 11 elections, then holding a debate on the plan won't be a problem.

A bill authorizing the arms purchase plan failed to be put on the agenda for legislative review earlier this week, dealing a heavy blow to the DPP's hope to have it reviewed before the month-long recess that begins Nov. 10 ahead of the legislative elections.

Stressing the need for the arms purchase to defend national security, Yu said he's worried that if Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng won't coordinate a Procedure Committee meeting in the legislature, there won't be a chance for a rational debate on the arms purchase plan ahead of the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: KENYAN AND MAINLAND CHINESE RUNNERS WIN TAROKO INTERNATIONAL MARATHON

TEXT.P: Kenya's David Kariuki and mainland China's Hu Xiouyin won the men's and women's divisions, respectively, in the 2004 Taroko International Marathon held Saturday in Hualien, eastern Taiwan.
Kariuki finished the 42.195-km race with a time of 2: 24:26, and was followed by Poland's Marek Dryja and South Africa's Vladimir Kotov.
Hu won her second straight Taroko International Marathon, finishing with a time of 2: 59: 20. She also won the 2003 Taipei Marathon.
More than 8,000 runners from around the world took part in the event, including 1,052 runners in the full marathon, and the rest in a half Marathon or a shorter 5-km race, through Taroko Canyon.
The top ten winners were awarded medals and cash prizes ranging from NT$5,000-NT$80,000 (US$151-US$2,417).

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SHIPBUILDING SALES HIT NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: The China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSC) has registered brilliant performance for the first ten months of 2004, with sales hitting a record NT$30.6 billion (US$921.69 million) during the period and production lines expected to remain busy through 2007, company officials said Saturday.

The CSC built a total of 24 new vessels from January to October for five shipping companies, including Yang Ming Marine Transport, Wan Hai Lines, China Steel Express, Sincere Navigation, and Japan's Marubeni Corp., the officials said.

Of these 24 vessels, 14 were container ships with a loading capacity of 1,800 containers, four with a capacity of 4,250 containers, and four with a capacity of 6,000 containers. The other two were cargo ships with loading capacity of 200,000 tonnes and 176,000 tonnes, respectively.

Meanwhile, CSC officials said the company's efforts to expand its market have produced significant results, pointing out that the shipbuilding orders won by the CSC so far are expected to keep its production lines busy through 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY MEMBERS OF BUSINESSWOMAN KILLED IN MAINLAND FLY TO DONGGUAN

TEXT.P: Family members of a Taiwan businesswoman who was murdered in Dongguan, Guangdong Province last month flew to Dongguan Friday to claim her body, an official of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Saturday.
SEF Secretary-General Yen Wan-chin said the body of Liu Mei-chuan will be cremated in Dongguan before being carried back to her Taiwan home, citing unnamed members of Liu's family as saying.
Yen said the SEF has rendered aid to Liu's family to fly to Dongguan where Liu was doing business.

Liu left her Dongguan house on Oct. 26 and then disappeared. Her decapitated body was later found nearby, and all her money in a bank account was discovered to have been withdrawn. Three of her former employees have been arrested on charges of murder.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOODSTUFFS OUTPUT FOR JAN.-SEP. UP 7.3%

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foodstuffs output for the first three quarters of 2004 grew 7.32 percent over the figure for the same period a year earlier, according to tallies released by the Statistics Department under the Ministry of Economics Affairs.

The statistics showed that the foodstuffs sector, including sugar refining, frozen food production, brewing and preserved food production, enjoyed two-digit growth in output for the Jan.-Sep. period, with sugar production registering the largest growth at 96.59 percent.

Meanwhile, amid a surge in transportation costs and a stronger euro, the total value of general foodstuff imports to Taiwan during the nine-month period increased 13.06 percent over that of the same period a year earlier, the MOEA figures showed.

In the same period, Taiwan's foodstuff exports saw slight growth of 3.23 percent, with frozen products, seasonings and non-alcoholic beverages being the most exported to international markets, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT HONORED

TEXT.P: Chang Tsung-jen, president of National Sun Yat-sen University in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, on Saturday bestowed ahonorary doctoral degree on Gennady P. Turmov, president of Far Eastern State Technical University in Vladivostok, Russia.
Chang said that Turmov, a world-renowned shipbuilding expert, enjoys a high position in Russian academic circles and has so far published more than 400 articles in periodicals and authored 32 books.
Both schools will now actively make plans on bilateral exchanges, Chang said.

Turmov said that his university will send a research ship to the Bashi Channel near Taiwan next January to try to salvage a ship that was sunk during the First World War. After the salvage operations, the research vessel will moor at Kaohsiung and then visit National Sun Yat-sen University and provide valuable research information to the school to be used for future bilateral cooperation and exchanges.

Chang recalled that he signed an exchange agreement with Far Eastern State Technical University during his visit to Vladivostok in late July. He said that his school would invite professors from Far Eastern State Technical University to conduct research projects next summer, covering such fields as undersea technology, nanotechnology and biotechnology.

Both schools will also begin a student exchange program, although Chang admitted that students at National Sun Yat-sen University are not familiar with Russian at present. Far Eastern State Technical University has a department of oriental languages and literature.

National Sun Yat-sen University will also work with the Ministry of Education's plan to recruit foreign students and recruit students from the Vladivostok school so as to enhance bilateral cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAPID GAIN IN VALUE OF LOCAL CURRENCY MAY INVITE CBC INTERVENTION

TEXT.P: The local currency's rapid appreciation in recent days may invite intervention by the central bank at an appropriate time when the influx of foreign capital has eased, market analysts said Saturday.
Foreign exchange experts predicted that the U.S. dollar will continue depreciating against the world's major currencies due to the United States' huge trade and federal fiscal deficits.

With mainland China's interest rate hikes early this week and the re-election of U.S. President George W. Bush, the experts contended that global hot money will continue entering Asian markets, including Taiwan, on speculation of a stronger renminbi.

Although Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) seems to have taken a hands-off approach despite the recent gain in value of the new Taiwan dollar against the greenback, market watchers claimed that the CBC is very likely to intervene when the inflow of foreign capital slows.
They said that the CBC has not done so to ease growing inflationary pressure in the domestic market, despite the fact that the local currency shows upward trends in the mid term and long term.

The new Taiwan dollar ended Friday at a six-month high of NT$33.075 against the U.S. dollar, up by NT$0.21 over Thursday's finish. Some dealers forecast that the local unit may break the 33 level against the greenback in the coming days.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said a day earlier that an appreciating local currency will help reduce imported oil costs and dilute inflation.
Although a stronger new Taiwan dollar may affect the export sector, Hu said its short-term impact on Taiwan businesses should be limited as recent fluctuations are temporary.

According to the CEPD head, the local currency has come under fierce pressure to appreciate because the country holds the world's third-largest foreign exchange reserves, worth US$235.032 billion as of the end of October.
Giving free rein to market forces to decide the value of the local currency is much better to lure hot money to take advantage of currency exchange rates, he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL MAGAZINE CONFERENCE IN TAIPEI TO OPEN NOV. 15

TEXT.P: The 2004 International Magazine Conference in Taipei is slated to open Nov. 15, with participants to discuss topics focusing on the expanding Asian magazine market and its challenges.

The third annual conference will take place at the National Taiwan Science Education Center, with a handful of local and foreign experts in the magazine business to deliver speeches on topics like "English Magazines in Asia, " "The Magazine Market in Asia, " and "Fashion Magazines in Asia" during the three-day event, according to the organizer, the Magazine Business Association of Taipei.

The speakers will include Jan Hung-tze, chairman of the Magazine Business Association of Taipei; Patrick J. McGovern, founder and chairman of the U.S.-based International Data Group (IDG) ; Michael Vatikiotis, editor-in-chief of the Hong Kong-based journal Far Eastern Review; Anna Azilli, managing director of Hong Kong's Carat Media Services Asia Pacific Ltd.; Miyoko Wada, editorial producer of Japan's Shueisha Ltd.; and Christina S. Ahn, co-managing director of Hong Kong's Noblesse Ltd..
Details on the upcoming conference are available online at www.webs.xlab.com.tw/2004. Those who want to attend the conference can call (02) 2518-9922, according to the organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMERS' FOUNDATION CELEBRATES ANNIVERSARY, CHANGES GUARD

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation celebrated its 24th founding anniversary Saturday and swore in a new team of directors and supervisors.
Lee Fong-ao, the foundation's vice chairman, was sworn in as the new chairman, replacing Tsai Tzai-peng who suffered a stroke six months ago.
Meanwhile, Cheng Ren-hung was promoted to deputy chairman, with his secretary-general post being filled by Huang Yi-teng, an associated professor of law at Shih Hsin University.
Lee pledged to push for the establishment of a record system for food processing to monitor every step in food processing, and to continue the foundation's fight against inferior products.

As a non-profit private organization, the foundation is financed by consumers' donations. It has called more than a hundred news conferences over the last two years to draw public attention to low-quality products on the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC COOPERATION AND DEVELOPMENT SYMPOSIUM TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The International Economic Cooperation And Development Symposium will be held at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CHIER) in Taipei Nov. 9, CHIER officials said Saturday.

Keith Rockwell, World Trade Organization (WTO) spokesman, and Jean-Marie Metzger, director of trade of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) , will be on hand to deliver keynote speeches to share their hands-on experience in dealing with international economic affairs.

Several economic experts, including minister without portfolio Lin Yi-fu, CHIER Chairman Vincent Siew, CHIER President Chen Tain-jy and Bureau of Foreign Trade Deputy Director Wu Hsin-hua, will preside over the symposium.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10% OF COLLEGE STUDENTS HAVE ATTEMPTED SUICIDE IN LAST YEAR: SURVEY

TEXT.P: More than 10 percent of college students in southern Taiwan have attempted suicide over the past year, while some nine percent of elementary students in Tainan have tried to harm themselves during that period, according to a survey released Saturday.

The survey was conducted by Ke Hui-cheng, a professor at National Cheng Kung University's Institute of Behavioral Medicine, on 346 third- and fourth-graders at two elementary schools in Tainan, southern Taiwan, and on 3,488 college students in southern Taiwan.

Among the elementary students surveyed, 8.9 percent said they had tried to harm themselves during the past year, with the most common methods cited being scratching, hitting, or refraining from eating. A total of 269 valid samples were collected among the elementary students.

Meanwhile, 10.5 percent of the college students surveyed said they had attempted to take their own lives over the past year, with taking pills, burning charcoal, exposure to carbon monoxide, and jumping from a tall building being the most mentioned methods.
The main reasons cited by the college students for attempting suicide were not getting along with others and feeling that their performance was not good enough.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUP LOBBIES AGAINST LIFTING OF EU ARMS EMBARGO AGAINST CHINA

TEXT.P: Members of the pro-independence Taiwan Association of University Professors (TAUP) said Saturday that they will submit a formal petition to the European Union against proposals to lift its ban on arms sales to mainland China.

The TAUP will also join forces with European non-governmental organizations to lobby members of the European Parliament to support Taiwan's petition, according to TAUP Secretary-General Hsiao Chih-ju.
Hsiao said a lifting of the arms embargo on China would undermine the military balance in Asia and trigger an arms race, a situation which he said would be unfavorable to the European Union.

He said the TAUP has recently had the opportunity to meet with a group of European Parliament members to pass on the message to them during their visit in Taiwan, and that the European politicians have responded positively to Taiwan's cause.

The government of Taiwan has also launched an international campaign to lobby the European Union to maintain its arms embargo on the grounds that mainland China has deployed more than 600 missiles targeting Taiwan.
In what has been hailed by Taiwan as an inspiring move, the German Federal Parliament passed a resolution on Oct. 28 to express its opposition to a lifting of the ban.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT HOPES FOR PEACE ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu expressed the hope that "peace will replace war" across the Taiwan Strait, during a visit to the outlying island of Matsu on Saturday.

Presiding over the opening ceremony for a war museum at a peace memorial park in Matsu, Lu said the park is very meaningful to Matsu, which was always on the frontline during the old days of military confrontation between Taiwan and mainland China.

The park also symbolizes the replacement of war with peace for the residents of Matsu and Kinmen, who had not been able to enjoy democracy until later years owing to military control measures enforced there, Lu said.

Lu promised the government will continue to fund development projects in Matsu, even though the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) only obtained slightly more than 200 votes in Matsu in the March 20 presidential election.
The memorial park, which is still under construction, is expected to cost NT$100 million (US$3.01 million) . The museum is the first phase of the project.
Also during the trip, Lu checked out the tourism industry in Matsu and participated in the opening of the campaign headquarters of DPP legislative candidate Lin Huo-meng.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICY OF OPENING TO M'LAND TOURISTS REMAINS UNCHANGED: MAC

TEXT.P: The government's policy of opening up to mainland Chinese tourists will remain unchanged despite individual cases of mainland tourists absconding upon arriving in Taiwan, the nation's top mainland China policy charter said Saturday.
Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks when he attended the annual conference of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission.
He said that the issue of absconding mainland Chinese tourists has become a nagging problem for many countries around the world as it poses a potential threat to social order and national security.
Although the ratio of mainland Chinese tourists absconding in Taiwan is relatively lower among countries around the world, the government has not taken the problem lightly, he said.

He stressed that at the present stage, the government will strengthen the security management mechanism, including screening tourists before they board planes and checking on customs, in the hopes of establishing a comprehensive management network.
Related agencies could also carry out regular reviews if the management measures are carried out rigorously, he added.

Wu said that the opening policy will continue in order to allow mainland tourists the opportunity to appreciate the beautiful scenery of Taiwan as well as taste the democratic and free atmosphere on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE LIKE TO RUN OWN BUSINESSES: FAIR TRADE COMMISSION

TEXT.P: People in Taiwan are fond of running their own businesses as evidenced by the fact that the number of shops of the country's top 10 convenience store chains grew to 7,539 as of the end of last year, according to recent tallies published by the Fair Trade Commission.
The figure represents an increase of 9.06 percent as compared to the level at the end of the previous year, the commission statistics showed.

Of the more than 7,500 convenience stores across the country, 1,378 were directly run by their headquarters, while the remaining 6,161 were chain shops managed by individuals, or 81.72 percent of the total. The ratio of the franchised stores rose from 26.41 percent of the total in 2002 to 31.56 percent in 2003.

Commission officials attributed the increasing ratio of franchise shops in convenience store chains to the propensity of the Taiwan people for running their own businesses. Opening a franchised convenience shop is an easier and less risky way for many local people hoping to own a business.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE CAMPAIGNING HEATS UP AROUND TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The major political parties all geared up their campaigning efforts Saturday with slightly more than one month left before the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
The heavyweight members of each party were on the campaign trial around Taiwan to drum up support for their respective parties.

While Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh were seen at campaign rallies of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidates, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" featured Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
The DPP is appealing to voters to support the party in its bid to obtain a majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan to facilitate the implementation of President Chen Shui-bian's policies.
The "pan-blue alliance," on the other hand, is claiming that the opposition must continue to have control over the legislature to prevent the country from becoming a "one-party dictatorship."

A total of 387 candidates have officially registered to run in the elections. The 225 seats up for grabs will include 168 regional seats and eight aboriginal seats, as well as eight seats representing overseas Chinese and 41 at-large seats.
The overseas Chinese and at-large legislators will be produced through proportional representation based on the total number of ballots that each party garners in the elections.

DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: All Sides Prepare for American Attack on Falluja.
The U.S. ratcheted up preparations for what appeared to be an imminent assault on Falluja, while rebels set up a perimeter.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD WARNS AGAINST MILITARY ATTACK BY MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu warned Saturday that Beijing is increasingly prone to use military force against Taiwan and called for the public to strengthen its determination to deter any attacks from mainland China.
The MAC head made the remarks while giving a keynote speech on cross-Taiwan Strait ties at the 2004 annual conference of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission.

Pointing out that the mainland regime is more and more likely to resort to military means to achieve what it calls a cross-strait unification with Taiwan, Wu urged the Taiwan people to strengthen their determination and to build a capable self-defense force in case of war.

Mainland China's many military exercises in recent years have been principally aimed at Taiwan, and their increased scale each year is due to mainland authorities taking possible intervention by foreign countries into consideration, Wu analyzed.
He urged the Taiwan people never to underestimate the possibility of a mainland attack and warned against a devastating catastrophe should the Taiwan people fail to make full preparations.

In the face of a highly risky situation in the strait, Taiwan must do its best to promote security dialogue and cooperation with countries in East Asia, he said, stressing that support from the United States and Japan is particularly important to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Nov. 7, or the 25th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1659: The Franco-Spanish War, which broke out in 1648, ends.
1867: Nobel Prize-winning physicist Marie Curie is born.
1885: The coast-to-coast Canadian railroad, from Montreal to Post Moody, British Columbia, is completed.
1888: Chandrasekhara Venkata Raman, Indian physicist, is born. He won the Nobel Prize for physics in 1931 for his discovery of the changing wavelengths of light when diffused through transparent material.
1913: Albert Camus, French author associated with Existentialism, is born. He won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1957.
1916: Jeanette Rankin of Montana is elected to the U.S. House of Representatives, becoming the first female member of Congress.
1917: Russia's Bolsheviks, led by Vladimir Ilyich Ulyanov (known as Lenin), topple Aleksandr Kerensky's provisional government to establish the Communist regime in Russia.
1920: Serious famine breaks out in China.
1921: Benito Mussolini forms the National Fascist Party in Rome and names himself the leader of the party.
1931: The Chinese Communists hold the first meeting of national Soviet representatives in Reijin, Jiangxi Province, forming the "Soviet Republic of China."
1944: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt is re-elected for a record fourth term.
1960: Missiles appear for the first time at the annual parade in Moscow.
1961: Konrad Adenauer is elected German chancellor for the fourth time.
1966: Beijing's diplomats walk out of Bolshevik anniversary celebration in Moscow after hearing Soviet criticism of their government.
1976: U.S. House of Representatives members Marion G. Gnyner, William M. Kotchum, Thomas M. Hegedorn and Norman F. Lent arrive in the Republic of China for a four-day visit.
1976: The 1976 Overseas Affairs Conference of the ruling Kuomintang opens in Taipei with 360 representatives participating.
1979: Taiwan Province and the State of Indiana enter into sisterhood relations.
1980: Education Minister Chu Hui-sen and his Korean counterpart, Lee Kyu Ho, sign a five-year extension of the cultural exchange agreement between their two countries.
1988: An earthquake rocks China's mountainous southern border, killing some 600 people.
1990: The Republic of China restores diplomatic relations with Nicaragua after bilateral diplomatic ties were severed for nearly five years.
1992: Czechoslovakia's Alexander Dubcek, leader of the 1968 "Prague Spring" movement, dies at the age of 71.
1994: South Korean President Kim Young Sam announces the lifting of the ban on economic exchanges with North Korea.
1999: The seventh Asia-Pacific conference of the International Volunteers Association opens in Taipei with 27 volunteer groups from Israel, Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, Australia and the host ROC participating.
2000: Kaohsiung's Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, renowned for its success in liver transplants, completes its 100th such operation, setting a world record in recipient survival.
2000: The Legislative Yuan moves a step closer to dismissing President Chen Shui-bian by passing a revision requiring that any motion to oust the president be voted on in an open vote instead of by secret ballot.
2001: The Executive Yuan passes the relaxing of the government's "no haste, be patient" policy designed about a decade ago to curb Taiwan investment in mainland China.
2001: Jose Carreras, the world renowned tenor, flies into Taipei from Tokyo accompanied by his son for an outdoor concert at Taichung Stadium.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "I like fish, and I also like bears' paws. If I cannot get both together, I will let the fish go, and take the bears' paws. So I like life, and I also like righteousness. If I cannot keep the two together, I will let life go and choose righteousness."

THE EUPHORIA over the reported release of a Filipino hostage in Iraq Friday night has turned to dismay for his family and government officials, with the Department of Foreign Affairs unable to confirm it from independent sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: TNUA POISED TO BECOME TAIWAN'S ANIMATION ART CRADLE

TEXT.P: Tainan National University of the Arts (TNUA) is poised to become the cradle of Taiwan's animation industry with its well-established academic background and expanding plans and ambition to achieve that goal.

TNUA is running Taiwan's first graduate institute of animation, nurturing skilled talent in animation art and industry every year, and it is also bolstering cooperation with international groups and foreign institutes in related industries and research, according to TNUA President Huang Pi-twan.

One of Taiwan's two "digital design resources centers, " TNUA has been invited by the world renowned New Zealand film production company Oktobor, which produced cinema hits such as Lord of the Rings and Matrix, to join its production team for a new animated movie titled The Legend of the White Snake, said Huang.

Huang made the remarks during an exclusive interview with CNA marking the eighth anniversary of the university's establishment. TNUA, located in Kuantian rural township in the southern county of Tainan, was known as Tainan National College of the Arts until August of this year, when it was formally upgraded into a university.

TNUA has made the most of the limited NT$7 million (US$210,843) annual budget that the central government has allocated to the university for the development of digital design since 2003, to optimize related activities, including organizing two international forums on audio, video and digital arts, Huang noted.

Academics and digital designers who came to Taiwan for the second forum, which wrapped up on the TNUA campus last week, included production team members from Oktobor; scholars and lecturers from the Institute of Fine Arts under Australia's University of New South Wales, which has sisterhood ties with TNUA; and a professor from the University of Tokyo, Japan, which in recent years has emphasized animation and digital design.

According to Huang, the TNUA Institute of Animation has cooperated with world-renowned lecturers and experts in writing and translating a series of books on the science and art of animation. So far, the second of its kind has just been published.
The institute also runs its own animation design, production and development group, receiving orders for productions and entering cooperation with international agencies such as Oktobor, Huang added.

In addition, Huang said, TNUA is also planning to exploit a government program to send elite students abroad for advanced study, in the hope that the university will be able to allow several dozen students every year to study at top-notch universities and research institutes from 2005.
Under the government program, students can receive government scholarships of US$30,000 per year and those studying humanities or social sciences can receive scholarships for three years.
The program is aimed at nurturing talent to meet expected demand between 2010 and 2015 in national development, including industrial and cultural development, according to the Ministry of Education.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S DIPLOMATIC OFFENSIVE INCREASINGLY HEINOUS: FM
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 6 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland China's diplomatic suppression of Taiwan has become increasingly disgraceful and outrageous, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Saturday in an online speech broadcast at a Thanksgiving Day party in Washington, D.C.

Chen said he could only address the annual Thanksgiving Day dinner of the Taiwanese Association in the U.S. capital via the Internet rather than in person due to Beijing's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan.

"Although Taiwan is a sovereign state, its high-ranking government officials are barred from visiting the U.S. capital because of Beijing's diplomatic stranglehold, " lamented Chen, who once headed a large Taiwanese association in the United States.

Chen further said President Chen Shui-bian has offered many policy initiatives and has repeatedly extended olive branches to the mainland in recent months in an effort to safeguard peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

"Cross-strait peace is a common expectation of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and even the entire world. However, Beijing has so far not given any positive response or offered any constructive overtures. It has instead intensified its diplomatic suppression of Taiwan and its repressive tactics have become increasingly heinous and flagrant," he added.

Chen went to the United States to pursue a doctorate in physics. Due to his pro-Taiwan independence stance, he was barred from returning to Taiwan until the early 1990s, when Taiwan's democratic reforms shifted into high gear.

With the concerted efforts of Taiwan people at home and abroad, Chen said Taiwan is now a liberal democracy. He encouraged all Taiwanese expatriates and Taiwanese-Americans to cooperate closely to enhance their political influence and lobby the U.S. government and Congress to support Taiwan's cause.
"With perseverance and devotion, I believe we'll succeed in upgrading Taiwan's international profile and expanding its diplomatic frontiers in the future," he added.

In addition to Taiwanese Association members, Republic of China Representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee, former American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Nat Bellocchi and many other American friends also attended the Thanksgiving Day party.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU CASINO TYCOON INTERESTED IN OPENING PENGHU CASINO
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Nov. 7 (CNA) (By C.H. Jen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Macau casino godfather Dr. Stanley Ho said Saturday that he would be very interested in opening a casino/hotel on Taiwan's Penghu Island if the government gives a green light to such business.

During an interview with Taiwan media Saturday, Ho, a Hong Konger who owns a business empire in Macau and Hong Kong, principally involved in gambling, said his company, Melco International Development, would be glad to invest in Penghu if casino operations are permitted there.

Ho said that he has been to Penghu and came away with a strong impression of the scenic environment there. If Macau is given the chance, his company might channel investment to the tune of HK$15 billion (US$1.9 billion) into Penghu to build a casino kingdom there, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD BE INCLUDED IN INTERNATIONAL HEALTH REGULATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Nov. 7 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's bid to join the international health community has once again gained firm support from its diplomatic allies and the United States, according to a well-place health source in Geneva.
The country has failed to become an observer of the World Health Assembly (WHA) , the decision-making arm of the World Health Organization (WHO), despite years of efforts.

The WHO member states are engaged in a two-week session of inter- governmental working group meetings that began Nov. 1 on revisions of the organization's International Health Regulations (IHR) , with the goal of bringing the regulations up to date and increasing controls on the international spread of infectious disease.

The source said that both Taiwan's allies and the United States "implied" during the first few days of meetings that Taiwan should be allowed to join the international health community as well as being included in the IHR after the revisions of the regulations.

Although no WTO members touched directly on the Taiwan issue during the meetings, Nicaragua delegates proposed revising the current IHR articles related to the participation of non-members of the WHO in the regulations, saying that the articles should include those territories that have the ability to push for external health relations and to execute IHR affairs as other WHO members.

The proposal was supported by several Taiwan diplomatic allies, including Malawi, Sao Tome and Principe, Chad, Senegal, Haiti and Paraguay, the source said, adding that D.E. Hohman, deputy chief delegate of the U.S. delegation to the meetings, also voiced his support for the principle of universality, noting that the IHR's goal is to make the regulations suitable for use by all countries around the world.
Hohman also said that disease knows no boundaries and that in order to avoid global public health crises, the IHR should not be allowed to have any loopholes.

Washington has always said that the IHR should include Taiwan and it said during a WHA meeting held in Geneva in May that the world health body should include the nation in the IHR during its revision proceedings.

However, the source said, mainland China's delegates to the meetings strongly opposed Nicaragua's proposal, pointing out that the territory's concept does not have legal status since the WHO is an intergovernmental organization and IHR is a convention among nations.
According to Beijing's representatives, the current IHR, which entered into force in 1969, needs no revisions because the relevant articles mentioned by the proposal have not caused any problems.

Seventeen WHO members, including seven of Taiwan's diplomatic allies -- Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Burkina Faso, Kiribati, Honduras, Swaziland, and Belize -- and three of Beijing's supporters -- Congo, Bangladesh and Iran -- have registered to speak at the coming meetings. Japan and the Netherlands will also express their views during the meetings.

Health experts in Geneva have said that although a beneficial IHR revision for Taiwan does not necessarily mean that the country will be allowed to join the WHO, it will certainly be a breakthrough for Taiwan in its efforts to join the organization.

Pointing out that Beijing will make all-out efforts to obstruct Taiwan during the coming IHR meetings, the experts also said that any changes in the relevant IHR articles will benefit Taiwan. They added that the WHO's leading members have realized Taiwan's importance to the international health security network and that there is room for the nation to develop in the world health community.

Meanwhile, the source said that Taiwan's Department of Health has also put forth some proposals on the IHR revisions and has expressed its wish to participate in the IHR revision working group meetings.

DOC.HEADLINE: RICH UNDERSEA DEPOSITS OF 'FLAMMABLE ICE' SOUTHWEST OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Gas hydrate, commonly known as "flammable ice, " which could be used as an energy source at a time of widespread price wars over fossil fuels that could run out someday, is said to be present in rich deposits under the sea to Taiwan's southwest.

After preliminary surveys, the Central Geological Survey (CGS) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said Sunday that there are probably huge deposits of gas hydrate under the sea bed to Taiwan's southwest.

So long as Taiwan or any other country is technically capable of exploring the gas hydrate deposits, the "dormant energy" will probably become a key to solving the earth's energy problems, according to CGS officials.

Gas hydrate is formed of water and methane under high pressure and low temperatures. It is called "combustible ice" because it looks like ice crystals. It is also called methane hydrate because it releases methane gas when it is put under normal pressure at normal temperatures. When ignited, it burns continuously, earning itself the nickname of "combustible ice," CGS experts said.
Gas hydrate is generally known to be in great deposits mainly under the northern and southern polar icecaps, as well as under deep sea beside coastlines.

It is estimated that globally, deposits of gas hydrate are about 20,000 trillion cubic meters, containing about 10 trillion tons of organic carbon, which represents an amount equivalent to two-fold the entire deposits of organic carbon currently known to the world, CGS experts said.

Gas hydrate could be an important energy resource in the 21st century and could replace fossil fuels as major economic powers, including the United States, Japan, Canada and the European Union, even mainland China and India, have established national-level projects on the issue.

According to CGS Director Lin Chao-tsung, his agency has conducted preliminary surveys over the past several months, checking the sea bed about 100 km from Taiwan proper's southwest coast to a depth of 500-3,500 meters. The survey team found that methane hydrate was found in high density in that area, prompting the team to calculate that hundreds of millions cubic meters of methane are deposited in a hydrate form in the area.
If the deposits can be explored and used, it would be enough to provide Taiwan's entire energy consumption requirements for 50 years, Lin said.

The CGS plans to choose two locations in the area to begin geological prospecting from 2007 to determine the exact position of the gas hydrate deposits, the types of deposits and the approaches that the agency should use to explore the potential fuel source.

The other countries involved in exploring the possibility of gas hydrate extraction have scheduled 2015 as the year to begin commercial exploitation and the schedule could be moved ahead if prices for fossil fuels continue to skyrocket, Lin said.
Lin stressed, however, that so far, none of these countries have made any breakthroughs to surmount technical difficulties in gas hydrate exploration and use.

The most difficult or challenging problem about gas hydrate is that "it cannot be extracted, " Lin said, adding that once the material is unearthed, at normal temperatures and normal pressure, it immediately turns to water and methane and is useless.

The only useful option would be for the scientists operate undersea, turning the "combustible ice" into gas in a process undertaken under the sea bed and pipelining the transformed gas to the surface, Lin explained.

If operated inappropriately, the gas hydrate may release huge amounts of methane, resulting in a sudden surge in the temperature of sea water, which could cause a major disaster for global ecology, Lin added.

Noting that the issue is an issue for the entire global village to tackle, Lin said that he is confident that scientists will overcome technical difficulties eventually to "crack the treasure box" lying deep below the sea.

DOC.HEADLINE: HISTORY TO DOCUMENT 'LIEN-SOONG REBELLION:' PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun lashed out at two top opposition leaders -- Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong -- Sunday for their refusal to concede defeat in the March 20 presidential election, saying that history will document their post-election deeds as a "Lien-Soong rebellion."

In an unusually combative mood while stumping for Legislator Wang To of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, who is seeking re-election, Yu said Lien should have conceded defeat gracefully when the Taiwan High Court ruled against his election lawsuit Thursday.

"Lien missed a good opportunity to concede defeat and offer his congratulations to President Chen Shui-bian after the court dismissed his petition to have the presidential election result nullified and instead upheld Chen's re-election victory three days ago. This indicates that Lien lacks political wisdom," Yu said.

Instead of conceding defeat, Yu went on, Lien mobilized a large crowd of supporters to stage sometimes violent protests in front of the Presidential Office for seven days shortly after the election result was announced. Lien and his running mate Soong then filed two lawsuits demanding the annulment of Chen's re-election victory and even invalidation of the entire election on the claims that the vote was marred by fraud and a shooting that slightly injured Chen a day before his victory by a razor-thin margin.

Local society has been disturbed by the defiant posturing of Lien and Soong over the past seven-odd months, Yu said, adding that Lien and Soong do not trust the government, the Central Election Commission, or the hundreds of thousands of schoolteachers who assisted in handling the voting affairs.

"The court ruling ended the grueling series of hearings, ballot recounting, cross-debates, consultations and investigations into various contentious points that posed a serious challenge to our society. However, Lien still refused to concede defeat even after losing the suit. He has so far not made a public apology to election staff and schoolteachers," Yu lamented.
The premier said he believes that history will document the "dark period" in the wake of the presidential election.

"Even if textbooks for elementary schoolchildren may not include Lien-Soong's defiant acts, I'm convinced that political science students at universities will definitely touch on the event and characterize it as the 'Lien-Soong rebellion,'" Yu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER INSPECTS DEPOT EXPLOSION SITE

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Lee Jye made an inspection tour Sunday of an ammunition depot in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung where an explosion killed three soldiers a day earlier.
Lee also paid visits to the families of the three soldiers -- 2nd Lt. Hung Tuan-lung, Sgt. Huang Chien-che and PFC Yang Wu-chang -- to offer apologies and condolences.

In addition to ordering an immediate investigation into the cause of the explosion, Lee further suggested that a memorial be erected at the site to serve as a reminder for all military service members at the depot to raise vigilance during their work.

Family members of the three soldiers complained that they did not receive notice of the tragic accident until 4 p.m. Saturday, more than an hour after the explosion at 2: 50 p.m. They asked military authorities to probe the case thoroughly so that their loved ones will not have died in vain.

Lee said he was briefed on the accident and that ammunition experts from the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology will conduct a forensic investigation to determine the cause of the explosion. "The military will complete the investigation of the possible cause as soon as possible, " he told grieving family members.
Lee was accompanied by Chief of the General Staff Gen. Lee Tien-yu and Gen. Tai Po-teh on the inspection tour.

According to initial investigation, Tai said, the explosion might have occurred when the trio were moving mortar shells. "They might have accidentally hit a shell against a wall, causing it to explode, " he said.

The depot is located in a remote mountainous region between Kaohsiung County's Kouping village and Chishan township. As the depot covers a large area and is far from civilian houses, the explosion did not affect residents in the region. Huang and Yang were killed instantly, while Hung died en route to a hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LEADER URGED TO STOP CREATING PANIC WITH 'WAR' RUMOR

TEXT.P: A senior member of the Presidential Office staff urged opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong Sunday to stop using imaginary war scenarios to frighten people for the sake of his partisan political interests.

Su Tseng-chang, President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff, made the appeal after Soong said while stumping for a PFP legislative candidate in Taipei County earlier in the day that if the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) wins a clear majority in the new Legislative Yuan to be elected Dec. 11, Taiwan could face the threat of an attack from mainland China next year.
Soong said legend has it that definitive events happen once every 60 years. For instance, the United States was attacked by Japan in 1942 and then suffered terrorist attacks 60 years later in 2002.

Soong said 2005 will mark the 60th anniversary of Taiwan's return to China in 1945 after 50 years of Japanese colonial rule. If the "pan-green camp" wins a big victory in the year-end legislative elections, Soong said, Taiwan could face a "war threat."
Commenting on Soong's remarks, Su said Soong should refrain from using superstitious rhetoric designed to cause panic among the citizenry.

"I cannot understand what Soong was thinking when he made such outrageous, imaginary comments, " Su said, adding that Soong should pray for Taiwan's well-being in case there might be indeed a war threat for Taiwan next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALCOHOLISM RELATED TO HEREDITY: DOCTOR

TEXT.P: Alcoholism is related to heredity and the number of alcoholics is increasing steadily in Taiwan, a local psychiatrist said Sunday.
Chen Chiao-chi, deputy director of the Taipei City Psychiatric Center, said at a seminar on mental health that foreign academic studies have confirmed correlation between alcoholism and heredity.

"Statistics show that if one of the identical twins is an alcoholic, 75 percent of his or her sibling also suffer alcoholism,. The ratio among fraternal twins is 50 percent," Chen said, adding that the alcoholism is likelier to be passed onto males than to females among family members.
Studies also show that those born to alcoholic parents are 10 times likelier to suffer alcoholism than those from non-alcoholic families, Chen said.

In Taiwan, Chen said, about 1 percent of aboriginal tribesmen suffered alcoholism in the 1940s and the ratio among other local ethnic groups was 0.01 percent. The ratio among aborigines has surged to 20 percent or 30 percent by now, compared to 2 percent or 3 percent among people of other ethnic origins.
"The figures indicate that alcoholism has become increasingly rampant in Taiwan," Chen said, adding that he treats an average of 40 to 50 new alcoholism-related outpatient cases per month.

In foreign countries, Chen said, the average age of first-time drinking ranges between 15 and 17 and the average age of alcoholism ranges between 27 and 40. Foreign alcoholics usually die from cardiovascular diseases.

Chen further said local alcoholics' average life expectancy is only 44 years and their death rate is 10 times higher than non-alcoholics. Local alcoholics usually die from liver diseases or gastric diseases.

Chen attributed the rise in local alcoholics to a combination of factors, including increased accessibility to various alcoholic beverages due to market opening as well as progress in local wine production technologies. He suggested that the government impose stricter restriction on liquor commercials or advertisements to help curb alcoholism.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATE PRESIDENT YEN'S CENTENARY COMMEMORATED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lauded the late President Yen Chia-kan Sunday as an architect of Taiwan's economic miracle.
Chen made the commendation at a ceremony marking Yen's centennial birth anniversary.
"Yen was an architect of Taiwan's miraculous economic takeoff and he had laid a foundation for Taiwan's democratic development," Chen said.

The president further said two special things about Yen were worth mentioning. One was that Yen had never presided over any military meeting during his stints as the Republic of China's vice president and president.

"In terms of archives available to me, during Yen's tenure as vice president between 1972 and 1975, then-Premier Chiang Ching-kuo would chair weekly military meetings whenever his father then-President Chiang Kai-shek was unable to do so due for health reasons," Chen said.
During Yen's presidency from 1975 and 1978, Chen said, then-Premier Chiang Ching-kuo continued to preside over military meetings.

Another thing was that Yen was the first ROC president to be buried in line with the nation's state funeral regulations, Chen said, adding that the funerals of late President Chiang Kai-shek and late President Chiang Ching-kuo whose presidency ran from 1978 through his death in 1988 were both handled by then-ruling party Kuomintang.

Chen said Yen's state funeral was handled in a simple yet graceful manner. The nation flag flew at half-mast only on the funeral day, not for 30 days as the practice adopted after the two Chiang's deaths.

Yen once served as economics minister, finance minister, premier, vice president and president throughout his political career. "He had contributed much to Taiwan's transformation from an agricultural backwater to an industrial powerhouse," Chen said, adding that his self-effacing and unassuming character is equally worth respect and praise.

Chen's administration has organized a series of commemorative activities to mark Yen's centenary, including the issue of commemorative postage stamps and an exhibition of Yen-related documents and artifacts at the Presidential Office's art gallery.
Sunday's commemorative ceremony was held at Yen's previous residence which is only a block away from Chen's present official residence.
During the ceremony, Yen's fourth son Yen Chun-tai presented a silver badge left by his father to Chen in appreciation of Chen's respect for the late president.

The badge was presented by the United Nations' secretary-general in 1970 when Yen attended the U.N.'s 25th founding anniversary. The ROC was a U.N. founding member, but has been shut out of the world body since 1971 when the world body gave the China seat to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAX INCENTIVES MAY BE OFFERED TO PROMOTE ECO-FRIENDLY TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: The government may consider offering tax incentives to encourage the development of eco-friendly technologies, Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Administrator Chang Chu-en said Sunday.

Chang said the Cabinet will form a superaministerial task force to study the feasibility of lowering taxes for high-tech products that can meet the most stringent eco-friendly standards or greenhouse gas emission standards, such as vehicles utilizing hybrid electric-gasoline technologies or jet-engines to reduce emissions.

As the U.N.-sponsored Kyoto Protocol on greenhouse gas emissions will take effect soon, Chang said Taiwan must step up efforts to develop eco-friendly technologies and reduce energy consumption. Although Taiwan is not a Kyoto Protocol signatory, Chang said, Taiwan must abide by its regulations in order to stay competitive in the world market and avoid trade sanctions.

Noting that Premier Yu Shyi-kun already directed the Ministry of Economic Affairs to organize a meeting on sustainable national development in the near future, Chang said the EPA will join forces with other government agencies to work out measures to boost the development of eco-friendly technologies, including lowering taxes for eco-friendly high-tech cars and other products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER UNVEILS 10-YEAR PLAN FOR WIND POWER GENERATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) will invest more than NT$10 billion in developing wind power generation in the next 10 years, a company spokesman said Sunday.
The 10-year development plan is part of the state-owed firm's efforts to substantiate the government's eco-friendly "green power generation" policy.

Under the plan, Taipower will install at least 200 wind power generators with a total installed capacity of 300,000 kilowatts, the spokesman said, adding that the wind power generators will first be set up in coastal regions in western part of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MEDICAL ASSOCIATION TO LOBBY JAPAN SUPPORT FOR WHO BID

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City Medical Association (KCMA) will organize a delegation to visit Japan later this month to lobby Japanese support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO), a spokesman said Sunday.
KCMA President Chiu Yung-jen said he will personally head the delegation on the five-day Japan visit.
The delegation will leave for Tokyo Nov. 10, Chiu said, adding that the group will meet with Japanese parliamentarians as well as influential Japanese medical professionals and public health experts.
As 19 percent of the WHO funds are donated by Japan, Chiu said, Japan's support for Taiwan's WHO bid is very important.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENTS ARRIVE IN TEXAS ON EXCHANGE PROGRAM
DOC.DATELINE: Dallas, Texas, Nov. 6 (CNA) (By Chang Hui-yen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A group of 14 senior high school students from the northern Taiwan city of Hsinchu arrived in Plano, Texas Saturday to start a 15-day educational exchange program.
Hsinchu formed sisterhood relations with Plano last year and the student exchange program is part of the two cities' efforts to boost bilateral economic, cultural and educational exchanges.
The 14 students will get a taste of American campus life over the next two weeks. They will attend classes and extracurricular activities with American students at three high schools in Plano.
The Plano Sister Cities commission has also arranged for the Taiwan students to stay at 12 American families which all have a child studying at the three selected Plano high schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Nov. 8, or the 26th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1674: English poet John Milton, the author of "Paradise Lost," dies in London at the age of 66.
1827: The first English-language newspaper in the Far East, the Canton Register, starts publication in Kuangchou (Guangzhou).
1907: Two newspaper offices in London and Paris, respectively, successfully send telelectroscopes to each other.
1916: Tsai Ou, a general in the late Ching dynasty and early years of the republic who was the first to rise against Yuan Shih-kai's plot to become an emperor, dies at the age of 35 in Japan.
1933: Afghanistan's ruler Nadir Shah is assassinated and succeeded by his son Mohammed Zahir Shah.
1942: British and U.S. troops, commanded by Gen. Dwight D. Einsenhower, land in Morocco and Algeria in North Africa, beginning the Algeria-Morocco Campaign of World War Two.
1953: U.S. Vice President Richard Nixon visits the Republic of China.
1960: John F. Kennedy is elected president of the United States, defeating Republican Vice President Richard Nixon.
1964: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with the African nation of Senegal.
1966: Edward Brooke is elected to the U.S. Senate, becoming the first black senator in U.S. history.
1970: The construction of the ROC's first nuclear power plant begins in Shihmen Township, Taipei County.
1974: The 17th President's Conference of the Orient Airlines Association opens in Taipei with 11 airlines participating.
1975: The Taipei Operation Center of the Asia-Pacific Regional Permanent Committee on Food and Agriculture of the International Organization of Industrial, Spiritual and Cultural Advancement is inaugurated.
1976: Manuel Aguilar Bonilla, former vice president of the Republic of Costa Rica, arrives in the ROC for a five-day visit.
1976: The Voice of Free China begins broadcasts to Central and South America.
1988: George Bush wins the U.S. presidential election to become the 41st president of the United States.
1989: Douglas Wilder is sworn in as governor of the state of Virginia, becoming the first black state governor in U.S. history.
1990: The ROC decides to set up a representative office in Moscow to expand ROC-Russian relations.
1993: Mainland Chinese hijacker Wang Zhihua forces a jetliner of Zhejiang Airlines to land at Taiwan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
1997: Mainland Chinese engineers block the main channel of the Yangtze River to begin work on the controversial Three Gorges Dam, the world's largest hydroelectric power project.
1999: The results of a survey show that there are more than 2.76 million dogs in Taiwan, including 660,000 strays.
1999: Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho says that Beijing is beefing up efforts to woo overseas Chinese in line with its "diplomacy of power," with the ultimate goal of isolating Taiwan diplomatically.
1999: The UK-based Economist Intelligence Unit reveals its year 2000 risk report on 93 countries worldwide and rates Taiwan as the second least risky country on the list, behind only Singapore.
2000: After 30 years on the run, Fusako Shigenobu, a leftist Japanese Red Army leader responsible for terrorist massacres in Italy and Israel, is arrested in western Japan.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian confers the Order of Brilliant Star on aformer Fu Jen Catholic University president, Archbishop Stanislaus Lokuang, in recognition of his contribution to the promotion of Taipei-Vatican relations.
2001: A telephone hot line -- 118 -- for marine rescues is formally opened to the public after a ceremony presided over by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "Benevolence is the proper quality of man's mind, and righteousness is man's proper path."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA DENIES PROMISING US$27 M. GRANT TO VANUATU

TEXT.P: Taiwan has so far not promised any specific amount of cash aid to Vanuatu, with which Taiwan established formal diplomatic relations on Nov. 3, Vice Foreign Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau said Monday.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has only promised that Taiwan would talk with the Vanuatuan government about financial aid after the two countries forge full-fledged diplomatic ties, Kau said during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.
Kau denied categorically that the government has promised to give Vanuatu a grant of US$27 million as reported by a wire service.

Legislator John Chang quoted the wire service as reporting that a spokesman for Vanuatuan Prime Minister Serge Vohor, who signed a joint communique with Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen on the establishment of diplomatic ties in Taipei Nov. 3, said recently that Taiwan will give Vanuatu US$27 million in 2005 as grant money to help with various development projects in the South Pacific island country.
Chang said that the MOFA should deny and clarify the Vanuatuan spokesman's statement if there is no truth to it.

Meanwhile, Legislator Sun Ta-chian from the opposition People First Party asked Kau to explain whether it is true that the Vanuatuan government has different opinions from that of Prime Minister Vohor over the establishment of diplomatic ties between the two countries Nov. 3.
Sun said that he would like to know whether Taiwan indeed established "valid" formal diplomatic relations with Vanuatu.

Kau responded by saying that Taiwan and Vanuatu did indeed sign a joint communique establishing formal diplomatic ties and that Taiwan will establish its embassy in Vanuatu's capital of Port-Vila shortly. He added that Prime Minister Vohor has given his word to the MOFA that the Vanuatuan Parliament will surely support his move.

A wire service report from Port-Vila said last Friday that Vohor's signing of the joint communique with ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen in Taipei was a "personal act" without the prior approval of the Vanuatuan government.

The report said that a spokesman for Vanuatuan Prime Minister Serge Vohor told a newspaper in Port-Vila that Taiwan will offer grant money of up to US$28 million to his country next year in return for Vanuatu's diplomatic recognition.
The same report also quoted Vohor as saying that his government would like to work with both mainland China and Taiwan simultaneously.
Vanuatu forged diplomatic ties with Beijing in 1982 and signed an agreement with Taipei on mutual recognition in 1992 when Vohor was Vanuatu's foreign minister.

Commenting on the wire service report, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said last Friday that the rumor of the so-called "invalidity" of the newly formed ROC-Vanuatu diplomatic ties was deliberately spread by the mainland Chinese embassy in Vanuatu. The report was incorrect, Lu added.
Kau said Vohor had to keep his Taipei trip secret to avoid pressure from mainland China.

"Twice before, Vanuatu has had the intention of establishing diplomatic relations with the ROC, but because Beijing exerted pressure, the relationship did not completely come to fruition, " Kau noted.
About 200,000 people live in Vanuatu, a group of around 80 islands located between Australia and Fiji.
