DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Surge of Violence Kills 50 Iraqis. At least 50 people,most of them Iraqi police- men ,were killed in a wave of explosions and gunfire north west of Baghdad, as insurgents sent a message that efforts by the U.S.military to quash them last month had fallen short.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Iraqi rebels face assault, kill 30
Facing a major assault in Fallujah, insurgents struck back with suicide car bombs, mortars, and rockets across a wide swath of central Iraq, killing over 30 people and wounding more than 60 others, including nearly 24 Americans.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Filipino still hostage in Iraq
HOPES FELL yesterday for Filipino accountant Robert Tarongoy, held hostage in Iraq, but rose for compatriot and diplomat Angelito Nayan, held captive in Afghanistan.
The Philippine Star: Janjalani eludes gov't troops
Abu Sayyaf leader Khaddafy Janjalani remains slippery as ever after escaping a military dragnet in Sultan Kudarat last month and sneaking back to Basilan, a military official said yesterday.
The Manila Times: Tarongoy still captive
DOHA -- The fate of the Filipino accountant Roberto Tarongoy, taken hostage by militants in Iraq, remains unknown, al-Jazeera TV said Sunday, retracting a report that Tarongoy had been freed.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times:Sing$ may rise further against US$ next year.
The Singapore dollar has been rising steadily against the United States dollar in recent months, prompting analysts to predict that the local currency will rise to a high of $1.62 against the greenback in the second half of next year.
The Lianhe Zaobao:MM Lee:Singapore will keep the growth and bright in next 10 years at least.
The election results in the United States and the Asian region augur well for Singapore and it faces a future as bright for next decade as it enjoyed in the past 30 years,said Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO MAJOR CHANGES EXPECTED IN BUSH ADMINISTRATION'S TAIWAN POLICY: MOFA

TEXT.P: A senior ROC foreign affairs official predicted Monday that there won't be any major changes in the Bush administration's policy towards Taiwan and the Taiwan Strait over the coming four years.
Kau Ying-mao, vice minister of foreign affairs, made the comments in a report which he gave at the Legislative Yuan regarding "Taiwan-U.S. relations after the U.S. presidential election."

The vice minister also promised that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will continue communicating with the United States and the international community. He also expressed the hope that Washington will understand the goodwill Taiwan has shown in dealing with cross-strait affairs and its wish to jointly maintain cross-strait peace with mainland China and to resume cross-strait dialogue without any preconditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY FORECAST TO GROW 4.62% FOR 2005: TIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is forecast to grow by 4.62 percent for 2005, down slightly from the projected growth rate for this year, the private think-tank Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) reported Monday.

At a seminar on the Taiwan economy's prospects for 2005, TIER President Wu Rong-i also forecast private consumption growth of 2.61 percent for next year, and growth in exports and imports of goods and services of 8.07 percent and 6.75 percent, respectively.

Economic growth for 2005 will be down slightly due to a variety of factors, including skyrocketing oil prices, worldwide inflation and mainland China's measures to cool its overheated economy, Wu analyzed.

Worldwide, many leading economic forecasters have estimated that the growth rate for 2005 will be down slightly from that for 2004, with some agencies already having readjusted downward their forecasts for next year, Wu noted.

Negative factors, including rising interest rates, surging oil prices and mainland China's restraint measures, have already begun impacting the world's economic growth over the third quarter of this year, he added.

However, Wu pointed out that the "downturn" is not expected to throw the global economy off its current track and consequently, global economic growth for 2005 will still be higher than the "historical average."
For 2004, Wu forecast that Taiwan's economic growth will hit 5.93 percent, mainly due to the brisk export trade and expanding investment at home.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, VANUATU EXPECTED TO SWAP AMBASSADORS IN TWO WEEKS: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Vanuatu have established formal diplomatic relations after detailed assessments and the two allies are expected to swap ambassadors in two weeks, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau said Monday.

Fielding a question raised by Legislator Yen Ching-fu from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party at the Legislative Yuan Foreign and Overseas Affairs Committee about the validity of the diplomatic ties with the South Pacific country, Kau said the ties "should be no problem" and the two countries will exchange envoys soon.

Answering questions raised by Legislator John Chang from the opposition Kuomintang on the veracity of the report that the government of Taiwan will provide some US$27 million grant money to Vanuatu next year, Kau said that Taiwan has so far not promised any specific amount of cash aid to Vanuatu, with which Taiwan established formal diplomatic relations on Nov. 3.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has only promised that Taiwan will talk with the Vanuatuan government about financial aid after the two countries forge full-fledged diplomatic ties, Kau added.
Kau denied categorically that the government has promised to give Vanuatu a grant of US$27 million as reported by a wire service.

The legislators said that since Nov. 3 there has been much noise that Vanuatuan Prime Minister Serge Vohor's signing of the joint communique with ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen in Taipei was a "personal act" without the prior approval of the Vanuatuan government, and asked Kau to explain.

Kau responded by saying that Taiwan and Vanuatu did indeed sign a joint communique establishing formal diplomatic ties and that Taiwan will establish its embassy in Vanuatu's capital of Port-Vila shortly. He added that Prime Minister Vohor has given his word to the foreign ministry that the Vanuatuan Parliament will support his move.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOTELS, SPAS MAY BE ASKED TO PROVIDE FREE CONDOMS TO PATRONS

TEXT.P: Hotels, spas and saunas must offer free condoms to customers under a draft amendment of an AIDS prevention law, the Department of Health (DOH) said Monday.

The Health, Environment and Social Welfare Committee of the Legislative Yuan was scheduled to review the amended draft law Monday morning in a meeting, and DOH Minister Chen Chien-jen was to give a report, but the meeting was canceled because not enough legislators were present.
The amended draft law stipulates that hotel, spa and sauna operators will have to provide condoms in their places of business, and sets out disciplinary regulations for violators.
Another amendment, albeit vague in its application, states that the two parties caught engaging in sex for money must take compulsory courses on AIDS and other venereal disease prevention.

Taking a cue from classes for traffic regulation violators, the DOH believes such a compulsory course for prostitutes and their patrons will be able to cut the risk of mass transmissions of sexually transmitted diseases among four million people.

Yet another amendment asks people from mainland China, Hong Kong or Macau who will stay in Taiwan for more than three months to have AIDs tests, or submit related test reports, to monitor the number of AIDS patients entering Taiwan.
For those AIDS patients from foreign countries, they can apply for short-term stays in view of human rights considerations, but they will not be able to extend their stays in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MAY USE TAIPEI MODEL FOR PUBLIC TRANSPORT DURING OLYMPICS
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Nov. 8 (CNA) (By Peng Si-chou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Beijing may use lessons learned in Taipei's public transportation systems to help alleviate potential traffic jams during the 2008 Olympic Games in China's capital, Zhang Mao, a vice mayor of Beijing, said Monday.

Talking to a group of visiting members from the Taipei Journalists Association, Zhang said that Beijing will develop and overhaul the city's mass rapid transportation system to avoid a traffic nightmare from occurring during the Games.
Beijing City authorities may borrow Taipei's experiences in streamlining its traffic conditions, including opening exclusive traffic lanes for buses, Zhang told the media from Taipei.
Beijing could also learn a lot from Taipei's MRT system, Zhang added.

Answering a reporter's question whether Beijing will consider inviting Taipei to jointly host some events of the 2008 Olympic Games, Zhang said that some people have suggested that Beijing move the equestrian competition to Hong Kong, taking advantage of the special administrative region's long history of horse racing, but the decision is up to the International Olympic Committee.

The Taiwan media group, led by Broadcasting Corporation of China President Lee Ching-ping and Eastern Multimedia Group Vice Chairman Chao Yi, arrived in Beijing Sunday for a three-day visit. Group members will also visit Nanjing and Shanghai before returning to Taiwan Nov. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RAILWAY DENIES REPORT ABOUT PRICE HIKE AFTER ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) categorically denied a media report Monday that it will raise its ticket prices after the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

TRA Director Hsu Ta-wen said that with gasoline prices rising steadily, many motorists have opted for public transport to save money. As a result, Hsu said, the TRA's ticket sales have increased substantially in recent months.
"Against this backdrop, how could we raise train ticket prices at the moment?" Hsu asked, adding that the TRA has no plan to raise its ticket prices before or after the legislative elections.

According to media reports, the TRA has drawn up a comprehensive ticket price adjustment plan to be put into force after the upcoming legislative elections. Under the plan, the reports said, ticket prices for the "Tzu Chiang" express trains will go up by 11.7 percent; those for the "Chu kuang" express trains will rise 8.8 percent and a steep 38.1 percent price hike will be imposed on the "Fu Hsing" and various commuter train services.
Hsu said the reported plan was recommended by a consulting firm that is helping the TRA transform its train services in urban areas into mass rapid transit (MRT)-style commuting services.

"Transforming our urban railways into MRT-style commuting services is our present priority. We'll not consider any price adjustment plans until that priority goal is accomplished. With a view to competing with the high-speed railway scheduled to be inaugurated next October, we may even lower our ticket prices, " Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Fighting Around Fallujah Intensifies.
U.S. ground forces fought insurgents on the outskirts of Fallujah early Monday, and U.S. warplanes pounded the insurgent-held city, as a full military assault appeared increasingly imminent. On Sunday, Iraq's interim government had announced a state of emergency for most of the country. U.S. commanders have not said when the major offensive to retake Fallujah will start.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN MEETS BEIJING OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Nov. 8 (CNA) (By Chiao Hsing-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang, at the head of a Taiwan group championing agricultural exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, met with Beijing's top official in charge of Taiwan affairs Chen Yunlin for talks at the Diaoyutai Guest House Monday.

During the meeting with Hsu's 21-member group, Chen, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of mainland China's State Council, said that agricultural sectors from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should further bolster their exchanges and cooperation given that the two sides have many complementary characteristics and share common interests in many aspects.
Hsu, who served as DPP chairman before the party came to power more than four years ago, then engaged in a closed-door meeting afterward with Chen.

Hsu, who had a falling-out with the DPP after the party failed to nominate him to run in the 2000 presidential election, has recently co-founded a new political group in Taiwan, the Taiwan Democratic School. He registered to run in the Dec. 11 legislative elections as an independent.

Hsu and the Taiwan group is scheduled to meet with Hui Liangyu, a State Council vice premier in charge of agricultural affairs, Monday afternoon for talks on the feasibility of stepped-up agricultural ties across the Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 6.15 points to close at 5,937.46.
The bourse opened at 5,937.16 and fluctuated between 5,942.86 and 5,894.98 during the trading. A total of 2.93 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.57 billion (US$1.93 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.3 percent.

Three other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 0.4 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.2 percent and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
Construction issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 364 to 295, with 126 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for November moved down 11 points to close at 5,909, with 17,358 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December dropped seven points to finish at 5,920, with 303 contract transactions, while March futures decreased nine points to close at 5,880, with seven contracts traded. June futures moved up 30 points to finish at 5,880, with six contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for September.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,920 points for November, 5,927 points for December, 5,889 points for March, 5,850 points for June and 5,862 points for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

November TE futures dropped 1.25 points to close at 217.75, with 3,736 contracts changing hands, while December TE futures moved down 1.65 points to finish at 217.35, with 88 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

November TF futures decreased 0.8 points to finish at 1,054.2, with 6,047 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures gained 0.8 points to close at 1,052.8, with 268 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, dropping NT$0.185 to close at NT$32.890.
A total of US$860 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.075 and hit a low of NT$32.870.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO INVEST NT$6.8 BILLION TO NARROW DIGITAL GAP

TEXT.P: The government has set the narrowing of the digital gap as a major policy of the nation, and will invest NT$6.8 billion (US$206.68 million) over the next four years to achieve this goal, the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) said Monday.
RDEC Chairman Yeh Chun-jung made the remarks as the commission held a seminar on the promotion of information services in remote areas in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan.
On the same occasion, the commission also donated computers that have been phased out by government agencies to poor students in Yunlin and Nantou to take care of minority groups in remote areas.

The commission has since 2003 helped local governments establish footholds for residents in remote areas to use the Internet. In 2004, it has worked with local governments and civic groups to establish information service Web sites and promote information education to create a more convenient information service environment for residents in remote areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN RED CROSS DELEGATION SETS OFF FOR VISIT TO FUJIAN

TEXT.P: A 30-member delegation of the Kinmen chapter of Taiwan's Red Cross Society sailed from Kinmen Monday to Xiamen in Fujian, mainland China, to pay a five-day visit to the province.

Wang Shui-chang, president of the charitable organization, who headed the group for the visit, said ahead of setting off that they will preside over the inauguration of a liaison office in Xiamen, as well as visit Red Cross organizations in Fujian to exchange views on humanitarian aid cooperation.

Wang said their services need to be expanded since more and more problems are emerging from the increasing contacts between people of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait after the government opened Kinmen and another outlying island, Matsu, for direct trade, mail and shipping links with the mainland -- better known as the "mini three links" -- in 2001.

According to the delegation's itinerary in Fujian, the group will travel to several major cities including the provincial capital Fuzhou, and are scheduled to inaugurate the Xiamen liaison office on Thursday before returning to Kinmen Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CURRENCY APPRECIATION HAS NOT YET 'FATALLY AFFECTED' TRADE: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Monday that the recent appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar has not yet brought about a "fatal impact" on Taiwan's foreign trade.
Nevertheless, Ho said local exporters should prudently manage their hard currency holdings lest they incur unnecessary losses from exchange rate fluctuations.
The local currency has appreciated against the U.S. greenback significantly in recent weeks, closing at NT$32.89 to the dollar Monday.
In her view, Ho said the NT dollar's current appreciation rate is still not expected to "fatally" affect Taiwan's external trade for the moment.

"With the NT dollar appreciating, local exporters' competitiveness will certainly be dampened. But the extent of the impact will depend on how much the currency of a specific competing country has appreciated. If its currency appreciation range is similar to our currency's appreciation range against the greenback, the impact will be limited," Ho said. The currencies of Japan, South Korea and Singapore have all appreciated substantially against the U.S. dollar in recent days.

Ho said the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will closely monitor the currency fluctuation trends and work out feasible measures to help the hardest-hit exporting industries tide over challenges arising from the currency exchange rate fluctuations.
Meanwhile, Ho reiterated that the MOEA has no timetable for adjustments of public utilities fees.
Ho made the reaffirmation in response to media inquiries about whether the government is likely to raise water and electricity rates before next February.
Ho didn't give a direct response. Instead, she said the government will handle the issue prudently because any price adjustment could have a strong impact on people's livelihood.
"We have no timetable regarding utility fee hikes. The MOEA will address the issue in a broader perspective based on the nation's overall economic situation," Ho said.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan interpellation session late last month, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said there will be no tax, water and electricity rate hikes before his tenure expires Feb. 1. According to Taiwan's constitutional practices, the Cabinet should resign en masse before a new legislature is inaugurated on Feb. 1. It remains unclear if Yu will stay on as premier after his current term expires next February.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION WANTS CABINET TO WITHDRAW ARMS PROCUREMENT BUDGET BILL

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Monday demanded that the Executive Yuan withdraw its NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) special arms procurement budget bill before the Legislative Yuan passes a law to authorize the procurement.

The KMT-led "pan-blue alliance" had blocked nine attempts by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to put the "major arms procurements bill" on the legislature's agenda. The KMT made the request ahead of the DPP's 10th attempt expected on Tuesday -- the final day the legislature is in session prior to a month-long recess called in preparation for the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Huang Te-fu, whip of the KMT legislative caucus, argued that the law should come before the budget and that it is unlawful for the Executive Yuan to bind the legislative bill together with the budget bill.
Also, Huang said he suspected the cost of the procurement has been "bloated" to profit the United States, asking that the Executive Yuan plan the budget anew and halve the amount to NT$300 billion.
Huang said the arms procurement should not be funded in the form of a special budget but should be included in the government's annual budget.
The KMT caucus will continue to bar the legislative bill from being included in the legislature's agenda unless the Executive Yuan responds positively to its demands, Huang said.

Holding a tougher stance on the issue, People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said his party opposes the government's plan to spend such a huge sum of money on some "useless" weapons and thus is also against the DPP's bid to push the "major arms procurements bill" through the legislature.

Soong doubted the accuracy of the anti-missile Patriot-III systems that the government plans to buy from the United States and called the anti-submarine planes also on the shopping list "antiquated" items that are unhelpful to upgrading Taiwan's defense capabilities.

In response, Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai said the Cabinet will never retract the budget bill, which he said has been proposed for the purpose of defending homeland security and maintain peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.
Being "uncivilized" does not mean the opposition has the right to "boycott national security," Chen said.

Chen said the Executive Yuan has drafted the legislative and budget bills following relevant procedures and laws and then submitted them to the legislature accordingly, dismissing the KMT's allegation that the two bills were "bound together" as totally unfounded.
He pointed out that the special budget bill for the government's expanded infrastructure projects, which was passed in August, had been handed to the Legislative Yuan using a similar model.

Unless the "major arms procurements bill" is placed on the legislature's agenda on Tuesday, there will not be enough time to allow the arms procurement budget bill to pass before the current legislature ends in late January, according to Chen.
The government has aimed to have the NT$610.8 billion budget run over a 15-year period starting in 2005.
The procurement covers six batteries of Patriot-III anti-missile systems, eight diesel-fueled submarines and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 TAIWAN BUSINESS ALLIANCE FORUM OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh promoted Taiwan's investment environment at the 2004 Taiwan Business Alliance Forum, which began at the Taipei World Trade Center Monday.

Speaking at the opening ceremony, Ho said the theme of the forum, which will last until Wednesday, was IT service, biotechnology and IC design, adding that more than 500 domestic and foreign companies have joined the forum, far more than expected.
Ho noted that Taiwan is the 15th-largest economy in the world and it is estimated that its exports and imports could reach US$300 billion this year.

Taiwan also ranked fourth in a global competitiveness report by the World Economic Forum, and its business environment was rated the third in Asia over the next five years by the London-based Economic Intelligence Unit, Ho said, adding that this has shown that Taiwan has an excellent business investment environment.

She also said that domestic high-tech manufacturers have been able to use integration or division of labor to produce and deliver products to their customers quickly. Traditional industry has greatly added value through technological innovation, noting that Taiwan used to export bicycles at around US$50 each a decade ago, but the price has now risen for some models to US$1,000 each, showing that the bicycles have become high-tech products, receiving large orders from big companies.
She said that Taiwan will now target information-intensive service industries, IT services, biotechnology and IC design as priorities for development.
Taiwan welcomes foreign and domestic investment to promote technology transfer, and expressed the hope that the forum can serve as a platform for exchanges between foreign and domestic manufacturers.

MiTAC-Synnex Group Chairman Matthew F. C. Miau and IBM Asia-Pacific President Frank Kern gave a keynote presentation on "Innovation and Differentiation: Vital for Success In Global Markets" Monday, which was followed by panel discussions.
There will be fact-finding tours to see Taiwan's biotechnology, semiconductor industry and e-government Tuesday. Arrangements will be made for individuals Wednesday to meet with Taiwan manufacturers.
The 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance conference attracted nearly 2,000 domestic and foreign companies and resulted in NT$138.3 billion in investments.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun has instructed that there will be a business alliance conference every three years and a business alliance forum every year to show the government's determination to solicit business opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Suicide train crash prompts safety review.
Rail experts and passenger groups are demanding urgent new safeguards after a suicidal motorist derailed all eight carriages of an inter-city high-speed train, killing seven people. An eight-year-old girl and the train driver were among those who died along with the motorist, who was seen to stop his car in the middle of the tracks at a level crossing near the Berkshire village of Ufton Nervet. Seventeen passengers are still in hospital.
Financial Times: Emergency law in Iraq ahead of planned attack.
Iyad Allawi, Iraq's interim prime minister, declared a state of emergency yesterday as military preparations continued for an offensive by US and Iraqi forces into the rebel-held town of Falluja.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET MAPS OUT TIMETABLE TO PROMOTE DIGITAL TV

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan unveiled Monday its timetable for the full digitalization of television in Taiwan by 2008.

According to the timetable mapped out by a financial and economic panel of the Cabinet, all 29-inch TV sets and larger sold in Taiwan must be embedded with a digital receiver starting 2006, and the policy will be expanded to cover all 21-inch TV sets and larger starting 2007.
All TV sets sold in the market will be digital products starting from 2008.

Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Lin Chia-lung said the promotion of digital TV must be carried out simultaneously at the production, reception and programming ends in order to be successful.

The government will halve the commodity tax for digital TV sets before the end of 2010 to lower the prices of digital TV sets and offer an incentive for the people to replace their old TV sets with a digital product, Lin said.
Lin said the analogue channels currently owned by local cable TV networks will be recalled in 2010.
In addition, he said, the government will subsidize the purchase of add-on digital TV receivers by low-and-medium income families that cannot afford to buy brand-new digital TV sets.

As far as digital programming is concerned, the GIO is planning to guide the five wireless TV networks to form a joint transmission company and to cooperate with high-quality overseas networks to enhance the quality of domestic TV programs, Lin said.
While there are some nine million TV sets around Taiwan, the new policy is expected to bring enormous business opportunities to TV-related industries, Ministry of Economic Affairs officials said.
The prices of digital TV sets will be comparable to those for traditional analogue TV sets following the mass production of digital TV sets, the officials predicted.
The prices for an add-on digital TV receiver should range between NT$2,000 (US$60) and NT$2,900, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RENMINBI MAY UNDERGO DRAMATIC APPRECIATION: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: The appreciation of mainland China's currency, the renminbi, is only a matter of time, and when it occurs, the scale will be major, the head of a think tank predicted Monday.
Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, made the remarks in a seminar on Taiwan's economic prospects for 2005.

Wu said the renminbi's appreciation will also trigger appreciation of the new Taiwan dollar, he said. The only difference between the two is that Beijing has suppressed its currency appreciation for so long that once it does appreciate, it will be on a large scale, while in Taiwan, the currency may undergo only gradual, moderate appreciation.
He noted that the United States has long been impatient with the mainland's undervalued currency and has urged Beijing to gradually ease the fluctuation range of its currency.

On Beijing's raising of interest rates in late October for the first time in nine years in a bid to slow the country's breakneck economic growth and control inflation, Wu said the move has fueled speculation that the renminbi will appreciate, resulting in "hot money" flowing into Asian countries, which has also triggered recent appreciation of Asian currencies.

According to Wu, Beijing is very likely to adjust its currency upward in one swoop, because if the appreciation scale is too small, it will fail to solve the problem of the mainland's overheated economy.

The appreciation will also pressure Taiwan's currency, Wu said, but he added that as Taiwan has an open market, it will have to maintain export competitiveness. In addition, it has recently raised its key interest rates.
He predicted that the Central Bank of China, Taiwan's central bank, will adopt its consistent stance of maintaining a stable currency and allowing only gradual, moderate appreciation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFERS MORE AID FOR JAPANESE QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government donated a further 8 million yen (US$75,902) Monday to help Japanese people affected by the recent earthquakes in the northeastern Japanese prefecture of Niigata.

ROC Representative to Japan Ko Se-kai presented the donation to Masa ji Takahashi, president of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA) , a quasi-official body authorized to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
Major Japanese news media, including NHK and Mainichi Shimbun, sent reporters to cover the donation ceremony.
The JIA will forward the fund to the relevant Japanese authorities for various post-earthquake relief programs.

Shortly after Niigata Prefecture was shaken by a magnitude 6.8 earthquake and a series of strong aftershocks Oct. 30, Chen Hung-chi, Taiwan's deputy representative to Japan, donated 2 million yen in relief aid to the Niigata prefecture government on behalf of the ROC government.

In the company of Kazuo Okazawa, president of a pro-Taiwan Japanese parliamentarian association, Chen also traveled to the disaster zone to convey President Chen Shui-bian's and Premier Yu Shyi-kun's concern for the earthquake victims.

According to the ROC representative office in Japan, there are about 146 Taiwan expatriates and students in the Niigata area. However, only the home of a Taiwanese physician in the region was partially damaged, while no other expatriates or students incurred any losses in the disaster.

As Japan offered various kinds of assistance to Taiwan when its central mountainous region was rattled by a magnitude 7.6 earthquake Sept. 21, 1999, the ROC government also invited major private Taiwan groups, including the Chinese National Association of Commerce and Industry, the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, Christian churches and other charitable organizations, to donate relief goods to be sent to the Niigata disaster zone.
Meanwhile, the Foundation of Medical Professionals Alliance in Taiwan (FMPAT) has launched a fund-raising campaign to help the Japanese earthquake victims.

FMPAT Chairman Wu Shu-min, who is also a national policy adviser to the president, said the fund-raising campaign is aimed at expressing the Taiwan people's concern for the earthquake victims and gratitude for Japan's past assistance to Taiwan.
"We look forward to raising at least NT$5 million in the next week or two to help with Japan's post-disaster relief work," Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: G.I.'s Open Attack to Take Falluja From Iraq Rebels.
U.S. troops seized control of two strategic bridges and a hospital in Falluja in the start of a long-expected invasion of the city.
The Wall Stree Journal: Surging Imports Of Food Threaten Wider Trade Gap.
The U.S. inproted more agricultural goods than it exported in June and August, marking the first monthly trade deficits for the farm sector since 1986, in a development that could worsen the nation's already significant trade imbalance.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN STOCK MARKET UP

TEXT.P: The net volume of foreign investment in the Taiwan Stock Exchange for last week was NT$97.11 billion (US$2.95 billion) , with selling registered at NT$50.33 billion, leaving net buying of NT$46.78 billion, Taiwan Stock Exchange Corporation (TSEC) officials said Monday.

From the beginning of this year until Nov. 5, net buying snowballed to NT$198.84 billion, according to statistics released by the TSEC. Foreign investors purchased a total of more than NT$3 trillion-worth of shares listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, accounting for 22.52 percent of the total market turnover, up NT$185.35 billion from Oct. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE FOREIGN HIKERS 'FOUND' HOURS AFTER BEING REPORTED MISSING

TEXT.P: A French national and two Britons turned up safe late Monday, hours after they were reported missing during a recent trek in the southern stretch of the Central Mountain Range, according to police.
The trio walked out of the mountains by themselves at around 7 p.m., one day later than their original schedule, police said.
According to the police, the French citizen, 47-year-old Philippe Desgran, and the 63-year-old British man Colin Snow work for the Taiwan High Speed Rail Co. (THSRC).
The third man is their friend Tim Boyle, 46.
The trio started their trek from Hsiang Yang Shan last Thursday and were scheduled to finish their journey at the foot of Hsiao Kuan Shan in eastern Taitung County Sunday, police said.
As the two THSRC workers did not show up for work Monday, the company filed a report with the police that afternoon.
The three men turned up just as the police were ready to start a search for them.

DOC.HEADLINE: CURRENCY APPRECIATION NOT FATAL TO EXPORTERS: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: The ramifications of the appreciation of the new Taiwan dollar have not yet sunk in, but it is certainly not fatal for local exporters, Minister of the Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Monday.

The hike in the value of the new Taiwan dollar, which had risen against the U.S. dollar from NT$33.460 Nov. 1 to NT$32.890 as of close of trade Monday, will blunt the competitive edge of Taiwan products by inflating cost, but the seriousness of the situation depends on the value of the currencies of Taiwan's competitors, Ho said.
She recommended that local traders hedge against foreign exchange risk by converting their U.S. dollars into stronger currencies.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Finance said the value of Taiwan's exports were posted at US$15.39 billion in October, which is the second-highest on record for any single month, against imports worth US$15.05 billion, also a single-month high.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIST SAYS TAIWAN AND JAPAN SHOULD COOPERATE IN IT INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: A private economist said Monday that Taiwan and Japan ought to cooperate in the information industry because it will benefit both sides.

Chen Tain-Jy, president of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, told a seminar on the comparative study of IT industry in Taiwan and northern Kyushu, Japan, that the technology know-how accumulated by Japan coupled with Taiwan's marketing strategy will create a team unrivaled in the worldwide IT industry.

Chen said Taiwan used to depend on Japan for capital and technology in industrial development, but the situation is changing. Taiwan's IT industry is shifting from manufacturing products for others to the development of new materials on its own and the division of labor between Japan and Taiwan in the IT industry has changed from a vertical one to a horizontal one.

There are many cooperation opportunities between Japan and Taiwan in light of the Japanese technological experience and Taiwan's skill in marketing, and their proximity to each other geographically Chen went on.
The one-day workshop was jointly organized by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, the Association of East Asian Relations and the National Science Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CPI TO INCREASE BY 1.89% IN 2005: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: A think tank predicted Monday that Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) in 2005 will rise by 1.89 percent from this year' level.
Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, made the remarks when he presided over a seminar on Taiwan's economic prospects for 2005.

He noted that the global price of raw materials is high, resulting in high prices for imported goods. With the rising costs of imports, prices of low-end daily necessities will be affected, although domestic manufacturers will have little room to pass on the rising costs to the consumer because of steep competition.

Based on the premise of international crude oil dropping in price to around US$40 per barrel, the institute predicted that the CPI will rise by 1.89 percent, while the wholesale price index will rise by 3.97 percent in 2005.

He also described Taiwan's economic performance as "brilliant" in the first quarter, noting that exports were brisk thanks to the global economic recovery. Domestic demand expanded, the job market improved and stock and real estate markets were brisk.

In the second quarter, the chaotic political scene following the March 20 presidential election disputes had a short-term effect on overall economic development, but with the political factors gradually fading away and the exports and stock markets continuing to build momentum, coupled with the government's active pushing of financial reforms, the economic growth in the first half reached 7.17 percent, and it is estimated that growth will be 5.93 percent for the whole year.

He predicted that in 2005, affected by the still too-high price of crude oil, as well as mainland China's policy of trying to cool down its overheated economy, export-oriented Taiwan will be affected and he forecast a lower economic growth of 4.62 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE FM FORESEES CROSS-STRAIT TENSION, BUT NO WAR

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau said Monday he foresees tension between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait from time to time, but no cross-strait war.
Kau made the remarks while delivering a report on developments in Taiwan-U.S. relations in the wake of the Nov. 2 U.S. presidential election in which President George W. Bush won re-election.

Asked by opposition People First Party Legislator Lee Tung-hao which country can serve as a mediator between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Kau said only the United States is qualified for that job.

Kau further said there should be no fundamental changes in U.S. policy toward Taiwan during Bush's second four-year term because continuity and consistency have been important elements in U.S. policy formulation.

As U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell made unusually harsh remarks about Taiwan during his recent visit to Beijing, many lawmakers expressed their concern about the possibility of Bush saying something harmful to Taiwan during a meeting with mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao on the sidelines of the upcoming informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in the Chilean capital of Santiago.
In response, Kau said the MOFA has expressed its hope to the U.S. authorities via proper channels that Bush will refrain from making any negative or unconstructive remarks during his meeting with Hu.

Kau said the MOFA has been endeavoring to fortify high-level dialogue channels with the United States in order to avoid misunderstandings. He acknowledged that there is no high-level hotline for the top leaders of Taiwan and the United States to communicate directly. Nevertheless, he went on, the MOFA has crafted an early warning mechanism to detect any developments in Taiwan-U.S. relations.

Kau further said the MOFA has also been working on improving high-level dialogue and communication with the United States. "We must be very articulate in communicating with the U.S. authorities to avoid misunderstandings. We should refrain from using negative or ambiguous terms," he added.

As to the possible agenda of the forthcoming Bush-Hu talks, Kau speculated that issues regarding Taiwan independence and U.S. arms sales to Taiwan will be addressed. "We are hopeful that Bush can adhere to the basic U.S. stance toward cross-strait relations, particularly an insistence on abiding by the Taiwan Relations Act, " he added.

Meanwhile, Kau said, the MOFA has prepared many reference materials and data for Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, a Nobel laureate who will represent President Chen Shui-bian at the upcoming APEC summit meeting.

If Lee has an opportunity to talk with Hu on the sidelines of the APEC meeting, Kau said, the MOFA hopes he will convey the government's desire to forge a regular dialogue mechanism with Beijing in order to safeguard peace, stability and security in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE AIRLINES ORDERED TO COMPENSATE TAIWAN AVIATION AUTHORITY

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines (SIA) was ordered by a local court Monday to pay NT$1.33 million (US$40,462) in damages to the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) for crashing an airplane on the runway of the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in 2000.
In light of the damage caused by the crash to the airport's tarmac and lighting system, the Taipei District Court granted the compensation request from the CAA, which runs the airport.

However, the a request by the CAA for an additional NT$1.68 million (US$51,110) for losses in rent of airport land used to keep the debris of the crashed airplane and the cost of the body bags and blankets used to cover the bodies of the victims was denied by the court on the grounds this should be shouldered by the aviation authority.

The crash took place Oct. 31, 2000 when an SIA Boeing 747-400 mistakenly took off on a runway closed for repairs and crashed after hitting construction equipment. A total of 83 people were killed and 71 were injured.
The court's judgment is subject to appeal.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECTED SUNKEN VESSEL 40 METERS DOWN NEAR TUNGSHA ISLANDS

TEXT.P: National Sun Yat-sen University in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, has reported a suspected sunken vessel in 40 meters of water near the Tungsha (Pratas) islands in the South China Sea.
Liu Chin-yuan, director of the university's Institute of Undersea Technology, unveiled the results of his research of the waters around the islands over the past year in a seminar held in Kaohsiung.

Liu said that his team has been collecting information and carrying out inspections since last year, and that in May and June this year, it detected via sonar what the team suspects is a sunken ship. Possible salvage operations, however, will have to wait for further confirmation, he said.
Hsieh Hsin-tsi, president of the Chinese Underwater Archaeology Society, said that the average depth of the water around Taiwan is 70 meters and that the suspected vessel is at 40 meters.
He said the possibility of finding sunken ships in the waters around the Pratas islands is high based on historical records and various inspections.
National Sun Yat-sen University conducted the survey at the commission of the Marine Bureau of the Kaohsiung city government, which administers the islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL PEOPLE HAVE CONSENSUS ON TAIWAN'S SOVEREIGN STATUS: POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of local people have a consensus on Taiwan's sovereign status or statehood, a spokesman for Taiwan Thinktank said Monday.

Quoting the results of an opinion survey conducted by the private think tank in the wake of the Nov. 2 U.S. presidential election, the spokesman said 70.6 percent of the respondents think Taiwan is an independent sovereign state.

The survey also found that 62.5 percent said they agree with President Chen Shui-bian's declaration in his Oct. 10 National Day speech that "Taiwan is the Republic of China and the Republic of China is Taiwan."

Moreover, 57.2 percent of the respondents said they agree that "Taiwan is the Republic of China" is a description of Taiwan's status quo, and only 18.7 percent said they think the statement is a trick to promote Taiwan independence.

The figures indicate that local people have a stable consensus on Taiwan's sovereign status, Hsu Yung-ming, an assistant researcher at Academia Sinica's Institute of Sociology, said at a news conference at which the survey results were unveiled.
"The survey results show that the idea that Taiwan is an independent sovereign state is a consensus conclusion, " according to Hsu.
The telephone survey of 1,076 adult residents selected from around the nation was conducted between Nov. 4-5, with a margin of error of 3.04 percent.

The survey also found that 61 percent of the respondents want to hold a referendum to safeguard Taiwan's sovereign status if the international community continues to refuse to recognize Taiwan's sovereignty or statehood.

Asked which domestic political party is most capable of protecting Taiwan's sovereignty, 28 percent cited the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, 13 percent mentioned the main opposition Kuomintang, which ruled Taiwan for more than 50 years until 2000, 1.7 percent cited the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union and only 0.9 percent mentioned the People First Party. Most noteworthy was that 56.1 percent said they had no idea.

Hsu said the large number of those who failed to answer the question reflects three possibilities -- local people are not confident of the political parties' capability; or they feel the issue is a matter of international concern and that Taiwan does not have much say; or many people want to resolve the issue by referendum.

As to expectations for Taiwan-U.S. relations during President George W. Bush's second term, 89 percent said they look forward to seeing normalization of Taiwan-U.S. relations under the principles of equality and reciprocity, 70 percent said the United States should review its "one China" policy and 42 percent said they are worried that the United States is likely to sacrifice Taiwan's rights for the sake of boosting cooperation with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ELECTRONIC PARTS, COMPONENTS INDUSTRY EXPANDING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's electronic parts and components industry continues to expand in terms of output, according to statistics released Monday by the Industrial Technology Intelligence Service (ITIS) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The tallies show that the industry's production amounted to NT$392 billion (US$11.87 billion) in the first three quarters of this year, up 18 percent year on year.
The ITIS predicted that the industry's output for the whole year will reach NT$545.8 billion, an increase of 16 percent from the previous year's level.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND FORMS SPECIAL TASK FORCE TO INVESTIGATE DEPOT EXPLOSION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has formed a special task force to investigate the cause of an explosion at an ammunition depot in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung over the weekend, a senior official said Monday.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Vice Defense Minister Hou Shou-yeh said the investigative team is composed of ammunition experts at the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology and various firearm production facilities.
Hou said the team will conduct thorough investigations into possible cause of the explosion that killed three soldiers last Saturday.
"The investigative team will publish its findings after investigations are completed," Hou said.

According to military regulations, soldiers usually do not conduct ammunition repair or disposal work at weekends or on holidays. Hou said the three soldiers were cleaning up the depot, not handling ammunition when the explosion occurred.
The deceased soldiers were 2nd Lt. Hung Tuan-lung, Sgt. Huang Chien-che and PFC Yang Wu-chang. Huang and Yang were killed instantly while Hung died en route to a hospital.
Hou said the MND will offer the best possible compensations for their families and will present them with posthumous honors.

The depot is located in a remote mountainous region between Kaohsiung County's Kouping village and Chishan township. As the depot covers a large area and is far from civilian houses, the explosion did not affect residents in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG, MAINLAND CHINA MAJOR MARKETS FOR TAIWAN EXPORTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports grew by 23.5 percent in the first 10 months of this year, with Hong Kong and mainland China still the major export markets, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Monday.

Taiwan's exports totaled US$143.67 billion for the 10-month period, up 23.5 percent from the same period of last year, while imports totaled US$136.95 billion, up 34.7 percent from the year-earlier level. Taiwan enjoyed a trade surplus of US$6.72 billion, down 54.3 percent from the same period of last year.

As Hong Kong and mainland China have continued to be the major markets for Taiwan's exports, accounting for 36.8 percent of the country's total exports in the first 10 months, BOFT officials said that they will continue to push for a project to promote global exporting by helping domestic manufacturers diversify their overseas markets so as to cut the risk of over-reliance on the mainland market.

BOFT officials also said that foreign trade in October totaled US$30.44 billion, up 26.9 percent from the same month of last year, with exports totaling US$15.39 billion and imports totaling US$15.05 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY CHIEF ELECTED TO CHAIR REGIONAL FORUM

TEXT.P: The president of the National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in Tainan, southern Taiwan, was elected chairman of a proposed forum for presidents of Southeast Asia universities on Monday, according to sources from the NCKU.

During the first preparation conference for the Presidents Forum of Southeast Asia Universities, Kao Chiang was chosen as the chairman by representatives from eight Southeast Asian universities, while NCKU Vice President Ou Shan-Hwei was named general-secretary of the forum.

Kao said the forum, the brainchild of the first Presidents Conference of Southeast Asia Universities last year, is aimed at promoting exchanges and cooperation between universities in Southeast Asia with an eye to upgrading their academic levels.
No date was set for the first forum during Monday's conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE MISSION TO VISIT NORTH AFRICAN NATIONS

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-lung will lead a trade mission on a visit to north African nations late this month to explore business opportunities there, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials said Monday.
The mission will leave Taipei Nov. 22 for Egypt, Morocco and Nigeria, where there is ample room for promoting Taiwan's products, the officials said.

According to statistics compiled by the MOEA, the officials noted, Taiwan-Egypt trade amounted to only US$237.46 million in 2003, while Taiwan-Morocco trade totaled US$96.9 million, with a surplus of US$15.3 million in Taiwan's favor.
At the same time, Taiwan exported US$177.62 million-worth of goods to Nigeria and imported US$282.83 million-worth from the African nation, leaving a trade deficit of US$105.21 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAVORABLE LOAN PROGRAM FOR CONVENTIONAL INDUSTRY RENEWED FOR ONE YEAR

TEXT.P: A favorable loan program for the country's conventional industries that do not employ high technology will be renewed for another year, an economics official said Monday.

Yeh Min-feng, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that during a meeting earlier in the day, Premier Yu Shyi-kun asked for a one-year renewal of the program, which expired at the end of October.

A total of NT$450 billion (US$13.67 billion) will be set aside for the renewed program, which will bring the total credit line to be extended under the program to NT$2 trillion (US$60.77 billion), Yeh said.

Taiwan's conventional industries have been plunged into difficulties because of the high cost of local labor and the government launched the favorable loan program in October, 2000, to provide them with soft loans.
Yeh said the premier decided to extend the program in anticipation of a slowdown in the global economy next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Nov. 9, or the 27th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1799: Napoleon Bonaparte seizes power in France, making himself one of three consuls.
1818: Jean Monnet, French president of the European Coal and Steel Community, the precursor to the European Union, is born.
1906: President Theodore Roosevelt goes on a tour of Puerto Rico and Panama, becoming the first U.S. president to go abroad for an official visit.
1918: The German Empire comes to an end. A German republic would be established the following year.
1937: Japanese troops capture Shanghai.
1938: Germany's Nazi thugs go on a nighttime rampage and attack the Jewish community. Thirty-six people are killed and 20,000 are arrested during the "night of terror."
1940: Former British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain dies at the age of 71. He followed a policy of appeasement regarding Nazi Germany in the years before World War Two, negotiating the Munich agreement with Adolf Hitler in 1938.
1962: During India's border war with mainland China, the United States completes an emergency airlift of arms and ammunition to India.
1962: The Republic of China Army test-fires its homemade T-2 rocket.
1963: A gas explosion at a coal mine in Omuta, Japan, kills 448 and injures 470 others.
1964: Eisaku Sato is sworn in as Japan's new prime minister.
1965: A major blackout in New York City causes losses of nearly US$100 million.
1970: Former French President Charles de Gaulle dies at the age of 79.
1971: The Communist Chinese make their first appearance at the United Nations for a conference on problems facing its main delegation on its way from Beijing.
1982: Some 2,700 Soviet soldiers in a convoy and civilians are killed after a fiery collision in an Afghanistan mountain tunnel jammed with buses and trucks.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan and his wife arrive in Japan for a visit.
1989: East Germans on foot and in cars start arriving in West Germany and West Berlin to experience long-forbidden freedoms after the East German government threw open its border to the West. East German border guards watch helplessly as jubilant Germans dance on the Berlin Wall, which divided people living in East and West Berlin for decades.
1989: The fifth plenary meeting of the Chinese Communist Party's 13th Central Committee concludes. Deng Xiaoping resigned from the post of chairman of the party's Central Military Commission, with Jiang Zemin succeeding him.
1990: Nepal's King Birendra proclaims a new constitution which restores multi-party democracy to the Himalayan kingdom.
1995: In his first visit to Israel, Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, calls on Leah, the widow of assassinated Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin in Tel Aviv.
1999: Dr. Jih-chu Lee, chairperson of the Youth Affairs Commission of the Republic of China, receives an award from the Junior Chamber International for her contributions to and achievement in political and legal affairs.
1999: Dr. Jane Goodall, British primatologist known as the "mother of chimpanzees" for her years of research on chimpanzees in Africa, arrives in Taiwan for her fourth visit to the island since 1996.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui presides over the opening ceremony of the 1999 Taiwan Johnnie Walker Classic Golf Charity Tournament at the Ta Shee Golf and Country Club.
2000: An Israeli combat helicopter fires rockets on a car carrying Palestinian militia commanders, killing one and wounding another critically.
2001: English zoologist Jane Goodall arrives in Taiwan for a 13-day visit. Goodall, who has visited the island five times, is known for her work with chimpanzees and her efforts to ensure their survival in the wild.
2001: Dozens of Tibetans and Falun Gong practitioners gather in front of the mainland Chinese embassy in Berlin to protest against Beijing's persecutions of Tibetans and Falun Gong practitioners in mainland China.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The object of learning is nothing else but to seek for the lost mind."
