DOC.HEADLINE: YU URGES 'PAN-BLUE' TO SUPPORT QUICK PASSAGE OF ARMS PURCHASE BILL

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) Tuesday to support quick passage of the arms procurement bill and budget for the sake of national security.
The premier made the appeal in response to media questions at the Legislative Yuan.

The Legislative Yuan's Procedure Committee is set to review for the tenth time at its meeting scheduled for noon Tuesday whether to place the draft bill related to the NT$610.8 billion arms procurement package from the United States on the agenda of the legislature's plenary session and then submit it to the committee for examination after next month's legislative elections.
The Bush administration agreed in April 2001 to sell Taiwan eight diesel-electric submarines, twelve P-3C Orion anti-submarine warfare aircraft, six sets of PAC-3 launchers and 388 Patriot missiles.
However, the "pan-blue alliance" has said that it prefers to see a re-evaluation of the NT$610.8 billion budget before the bill is passed by the legislature.

Yu said that although competition among political parties during election campaigns is normal in a democracy, this should not be at the expense of the nation's security. He therefore urged the alliance to support passage of the bill as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TO CONTINUE TO ACT IN ACCORDANCE WITH 'ONE CHINA' POLICY: BUSH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 8 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush on Tuesday reiterated that his administration will continue to act in accordance with its "one China" policy in dealing with cross-Taiwan Strait affairs.
Bush made the comment while speaking to mainland Chinese President Hu Jingtao on the phone, according to a White House official.

The official also pointed out that both leaders said during their conversation that they are looking forward to meeting with each other at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Forum (APEC) set to be held in Chile Nov. 20-21.

In response to questions raised by Hu regarding Taiwan issues after he congratulated Bush on his re-election, the U.S. president said that Washington will continue to follow its "one China" policy based on the three communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) , according to the official.

Noting that the United States does not support Taiwan independence and opposes any unilateral change to the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, Bush said that the United States will also provide Taiwan with defensive weapons in accordance with the TRA.
Bush also expressed the hope that Washington and Beijing will continue to cooperate in various fields in the future, including in efforts to establish a nuclear-free zone in the Korean Peninsula.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT FILES SUIT AGAINST PREMIER OVER 'PLUNDERED' ASSETS REMARK

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) filed a lawsuit Tuesday against Premier Yu Shyi-kun for slander and public humiliation, while the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) responded by saying that it is the highest honor for the premier to be the defendant in the case.
Three lawyers representing the KMT elaborated on the reasons for filing the suit at a news conference presided over by Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Cultural and Communications Commission.

The KMT said in the suit that as premier, Yu should know that the KMT assets are a legacy of history as well as the accumulation of years of efforts, and they have by no means been obtained by illegal means.

The suit charges that the premier said in an Oct. 5 general interpolation session of the Legislative Yuan that the KMT assets were " plundered booty," a statement which was slander and an attempt to publicly humiliate the KMT.

The premier also said on Oct. 21 that when the KMT administration relocated to Taiwan from mainland China in 1949 after its defeat in the civil war, "they only arrived with their two feet, " the suit said.

The DPP has put the retrieval of the assets of the KMT, once one of the richest political parties in the world, as one of its major campaign themes of the year-end legislative elections. The suit also claims that the DPP has said in its campaign literature that the KMT assets were looted, plundered or obtained illicitly, and that these allegations have smeared the KMT's reputation.
Meanwhile, Tsai Huang-liang, DPP whip in the legislative caucus, defended the premier by saying that he only wanted to "protect national assets as well as justice."

"It is the highest honor in the premier's entire political career [to be the defendant in the case], " Tsai said, adding that the DPP caucus and the public should support the premier to retrieve the ill-gotten assets.

Tsai lashed out at the KMT for "shamelessly plundering from the nation and the public, " adding that statistics provided by the National Property Bureau of the Ministry of Finance have shown that the KMT has only returned 1.12 percent of its ill-gotten assets since 2002, but he suspected the real amount looted by the KMT is far greater than the figure provided by the bureau.

Despite the fact that the KMT has repeatedly said that it will return the ill-gotten assets, Tsai said that it has used its slim majority in the legislature to block the review of a bill on the handling of assets of political parties in the legislature's Procedure Committee 68 times.
"The KMT will not reflect upon itself and knows no shame, and it will eat bitter fruit come the Dec. 11 legislative elections, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 7.74 points to close at 5,945.2.
The bourse opened at 5,944.6 and fluctuated between 5,947.51 and 5,900.03 during the trading. A total of 2.4 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$53.17 billion (US$1.61 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 1.1 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent and construction issues at 0.1 percent.

Four other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks and textile stocks both moving down the most at 0.5 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, plastics and chemicals shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 350 to 256, with 179 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER MULLING POSSIBLE COUNTERSUIT AGAINST KMT

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday that he welcomes a slander lawsuit filed by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and is not ruling out the possibility of filing a countersuit.
Premier Yu was responding to a lawsuit filed by the KMT earlier in the day against him for calling the KMT assets "plundered booty."
The premier said that the KMT assets were obtained illicitly, and he urged third parties with good intentions not to purchase them.

"When the KMT retreated to Taiwan after its defeat in the civil war on the mainland, it came empty-handed, " the premier said, adding that all the assets should belong to the 23 million people, and that all parties want to see the KMT return its ill-gotten gains.

His words came after recent controversy surrounding former President Lee Teng-hui's remarks during stumping trips where he said not to think Taiwan's present prosperity hinges on 9.6 million taels of gold brought by the KMT -- widely credited with stabilizing the economy of the island at the time -- because the ship transporting the gold sank on its way to Taiwan. A tael is a Chinese unit of weight. One tael is equivalent to 1.2 oz or 37.4 grams. Tael bars are widely traded in Chinese-speaking countries, mainly Hong Kong and Taiwan.
That amount of gold on today's market would be worth about US$5 billion.
Yu said that KMT Chairman Lien Chan said as early as 2000 that the KMT would return its ill-gotten assets, but he has so far not matched his words with deeds.
Chen Chi-mai, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, also reaffirmed Tuesday the government's determination to retrieve the KMT's ill-gotten assets.

Chen said that an investigation report by the Control Yuan, the highest watchdog body of the nation, has shown that the KMT has in the past taken over assets left by the Japanese colonial rulers in Taiwan, or used its power as the only political party on the island to obtain national assets through cheap purchases, or through "donations" by local governments.

"The Executive Yuan, based on the protection of national and public interests, demands that the KMT return to the public the booty it looted from the nation," he said, adding that "the premier made an appropriate comment on the issue that is subject to public judgment."

Since the KMT has now filed a lawsuit over the issue, the Executive Yuan will use the window of opportunity to compel KMT Chairman Lien to reveal in court the workings of the party's income and distribution of funds, Chen said.

The Executive Yuan has recently targeted eight pieces of land in Panchiao, Taipei County that are currently under the name of the KMT-owned Broadcasting Cooperation of China (BCC), Chen said, adding that it will file another suit to challenge the BCC's land in Pali, Taipei County, next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Williams Claims Votes for Stadium. Council Showdown Scheduled Today.
Mayor Anthony A. Williams said yesterday he believes he has lined up the seven crucial votes on the D.C. Council to pass his plan to build a baseball stadium on the Anacostia River in Southeast Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGNITUDE OF OVERNIGHT QUAKE REVISED TO 6.7 ON RICHTER SCALE

TEXT.P: The Seismology Center of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) Tuesday corrected the magnitude of an overnight earthquake to 6.7 from 5.7 on the Richter scale.
Seismologists said a smaller quake coming a few seconds before the strong quake had disrupted the reading and caused the rare mistake.

The 6.7 magnitude earthquake occurred at 11:54 p.m. Monday night, with the epicenter located 96.6 kilometers east of the eastern city of Hualien and 10 kilometers under the seabed, according to the center.
The tremor was felt in most parts of the island. No casualties or damage was reported.

It was first mistakenly reported by the center as measuring 5.7 on the Richter scale and occurring at 11: 55 p.m. from an epicenter one kilometer northwest of Nanao, Ilan County, and 19 kilometers underground.

CWB Deputy Director-General Hsin Tsai-chin said because there was asmaller quake which came just four seconds before that, the computer-aided automatic locating system confused the shockwaves of the two quakes and misread its magnitude.
The bureau discovered the mistake and immediately released a correction about one hour later after a manual analysis of the recorded data, Hsin said.
Hsin said earthquakes occurring off Taiwan's eastern coast usually carry a larger margin of error because they are recorded merely by an observation post located in the sea.
However, Hsin admitted that it is rare for the computer system to produce a mistake with an error margin as wide as this one.
He promised that the bureau will work to improve its earthquake measuring mechanism to reduce the chances of misjudgment in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN MINISTER TO VISIT TAIWAN TO DISCUSS LABORERS EXPORT ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Jakarta, Nov. 9 (CNA) (By K.C. Yu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Indonesian Minister of Manpower and Trans- immigration Affairs Falmi Idris announced Tuesday that he will visit Taiwan at the end of November to discuss the resumption of Indonesian laborers export to Taiwan with Taiwan officials.

The minister made the announcement while meeting with several representatives from local labor employment agencies, non-governmental organizations and those who are concerned about labor groups' interest.
"I decide to visit Taiwan at the end of this month to discuss with officials of the Taiwan government matters regarding its reintroduction of Indonesian laborers to the island, " the minister said.
Idris also revealed that Taiwan will soon resume importing laborers from Indonesia, allowing about 60,000 to 100,000 Indonesian workers to work on Taiwan.

Idris, who became a Cabinet member of the new Indonesian government formed Oct. 20 of this year, will be the first ministerial-level Indonesian minister to visit Taiwan after the inauguration of former Indonesian President Megawati Sukarnopurri in July 2001.

Taiwan's Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) decided in August 2002 to impose a ban on the import of Indonesian laborers in retaliation for the high rate of illegal work and absconding of Indonesian workers in Taiwan, as well as unreasonable brokerage fees charged by the Indonesian side.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DENIES REPORT ABOUT FINANCIAL AID TO VANUATU

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday the government did not promise a large aid package to the South Pacific island nation of Vanuatu in exchange for diplomatic recognition of Taiwan.

Yu made the remarks during a Legislative Yuan interpellation session where opposition Kuomintang Legislator Sun Guo-hua asked the premier whether foreign wire service reports about Taiwan's large aid offer to Vanuatu were correct.

"Previous foreign wire service reports said Taiwan pledged to offer a grant of US$28 million (NT$950 million) to Vanuatu but later reports said the aid amount could reach US$6 billion. Were those reports correct?" Sun asked.

In response, Yu said the Republic of China government, while establishing diplomatic relations with a specific country, is likely to pledge aid, nevertheless, the government has never pledged an extremely large special offer to a single diplomatic ally.

Even though he has not yet read the joint communique signed by Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen and Vanuatu Prime Minister Serge Vohor in Taipei last Thursday on the establishment of full diplomatic ties between the two countries, Yu said he is convinced that the ROC government did not offer Vanuatu money.

Asked whether the reported US$6 billion aid offer could be paid out of the confidential budgets of the Presidential Office or the national security units, Yu ruled out that possibility, saying that all of the nation's foreign aid has consistently been listed in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' (MOFA's) "secret budget" section.

Vanuatu forged full-fledged diplomatic ties with the ROC last Thursday after Vohor signed a joint communique with Minister Chen to that effect. With a population of about 200,000, Vanuatu is the ROC's 27th diplomatic ally.
Despite confusing reports about Taiwan's aid offer to Vanuatu, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau said Monday the ROC has not made any firm commitment yet on aid.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting a day earlier, Kau also said Taiwan and Vanuatu will exchange ambassadors in two weeks to facilitate promotion of bilateral exchanges and cooperation in various fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Soldiers' Mothers Form a Party.
After 15 years of assisting conscripts who suffer from hazing or wish to avoid compulsory military service, the respected Union of Soldiers' Mothers Committees is going into politics with the creation last weekend of the United People's Party of Soldiers' Mothers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2.5 KILOS OF HEROIN SEIZED IN CONTAINER FULL OF FURNITURE

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard on Tuesday uncovered 2.5 kilograms of pure-grade heroin in a cargo container delivered from mainland China and arrested a key suspect.

The container, full of wooden furniture, was discovered at a container terminal in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung, a coast guard official said, adding that the heroin was hidden in the inner layers of several wooden cabinets.
Initial investigations showed that the drug originated in mainland China, the official said, adding that drug traffickers delivered the heroin to Taiwan by pretending to deliver furniture.
The arrested suspect was identified only by his family name of Yao. The Coast Guard official said law enforcement authorities will continue investigating the case and bring other suspects to justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November gained 34 points to close at 5,943, with 27,268 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December moved up 20 points to finish at 5,940, with 807 contracts traded, while March futures lost four points to finish at 5,888, with seven contracts traded.
June futures gained 22 points to finish at 5,890, with one contract traded, while September futures moved up 19 points to close at 5,870, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,909 for November, 5,920 for December, 5,892 for March, 5,868 for June and 5,851 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
November TE futures moved up 1.55 points to close at 219.3, with 3,793 contracts traded, while December TE futures gained 1.65 points to finish at 219, with 206 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
November TF futures lost 1.2 points to finish at 1,053, with 6,476 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved down 1.6 points to end at 1,051.2, with 425 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC EXPERIENCE IS UNPARALLELED GLOBALLY: CIER CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The economic and trade experience of Taiwan is unparalleled in the world with 18 Taiwanese products or technologies ranking first globally, even though the nation's population accounts for only 0.4 percent of the world, Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) Chairman Vincent Siew said Tuesday.
Siew made the remarks in his opening address to a seminar on international economic cooperation and development organized by the CIER in Taipei.
Siew said Taiwan has emerged from its past agriculture-based economy to become one of the world's manufacturing giants today over a period of 50 years.
In 2002, Taiwan was the world's 15th-largest trading country, with its export and import volumes ranking 14th and 16th largest, respectively, in the world, Siew pointed out.
While a total of 16 products or technologies from Taiwan ranked first in the world in 2002, the number has increased to 18 this year, Siew said.
For instance, he said, Taiwan supplies to the world 50 percent of the key parts and components for such products as notebook computers, silicon chips, motherboards, digital cameras and glass fibers.
These achievements are marvelous to a country with a small population of 23 million, which accounts for merely 0.4 percent of that of the entire world, Siew said.

He said Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) was a milestone for the island's efforts to take part in international organizations and has enabled Taiwan to play a part in promoting global economic and social development.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.084 to close at NT$32.974.
A total of US$694 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.910 and fluctuated between NT$32.850 and NT$32.974.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP'S BID TO PUT ARMS PROCUREMENT BILL ON AGENDA FAILS AGAIN

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, making use of its majority in the Legislative Yuan, for the 10th time blocked putting a bill for arms purchases from the United States on the agenda Tuesday.

The "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), made one last effort to have the NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement bill brought to the floor in the Procedure Committee in the legislature.

Since the legislature is scheduled to go into a one-month recess Wednesday in preparation for the Dec. 11 legislative elections, Tuesday was the last chance for the "pan-green camp" to have the high-profile bill put on the agenda.
But the outnumbered DPP and TSU legislators withdrew from the meeting en masse in protest, shouting that the "pan-blue alliance" has neglected national security.
Meanwhile, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said it was wrong for the "pan-blue alliance" to block the arms procurement bill with procedural issues.
He said that the bill could have been discussed rationally, either in the committee or in its review or in public hearings.

He said the "pan-blue alliance" shouldn't block the bill by making use of its majority, stressing again that this is why the "pan-greens" should command over half the seats in the 225-member legislature in the year-end elections.

The Executive Yuan has said that unless the arms procurement bill is placed on the legislature's agenda Tuesday, there will not be enough time to allow the arms procurement special budget bill to pass before the current legislature ends in late January.

The Executive Yuan proposed in June to buy six batteries of Patriot-III anti-missile systems, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft from the United States with NT$610.8 billion special budget to be paid for over a 15-year period starting in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUP ELATED OVER REJECTED ARMS PROCUREMENT BILL

TEXT.P: Members of a civic group opposed to the NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) special budget for an arms procurement from the United States were elated Tuesday after learning that the issue failed for the 10th time to be put to the legislature for discussion.

Members of the Democracy Action Alliance (DAA), which has staged a sit-in outside the Legislative Yuan since Monday afternoon to protest the sale, cheered loudly after hearing that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party (PFP) had again blocked the bill.
The members sang songs and threw gloves painted with anti-arms purchase slogans into the air. PFP Legislators Pang Chien-kuo and Lee Yung-ping also were on hand to lend support.

Huang Kuang-kuo, a professor and DAA convener, said that political parties have had election strategies in mind when deliberating on the arms procurement package, but the DAA has ideals beyond electioneering.
The DAA thinks that the NT$610.8 billion special budget for arms procurement is closely linked to cross-strait tensions, Huang said.
For this reason, the next step will be for the DAA to promote a "European Union model" as a framework for cross-strait peace.

He said that the EU model is a "supra-country organization, " and during the process to form a community, no one country will be "unified" by others, adding that both sides of the Taiwan Strait could start from establishing direct cross-strait trade, postal and transportation links.

Huang said that the EU model is the only possible way to resolve cross-strait confrontations, adding that if a community concept can serve as a cross-strait peace framework, then Taiwan will have no need to spend astronomical sums on special budgets to buy arms from the United States and engage in an arms race with the other side of the Taiwan Strait.
Taiwan society will also no longer have to suffer from ethnic divisions, Huang added.

The Executive Yuan proposed the NT$610.8 billion special budget to buy six Patriot-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft, which will be paid for over a 15-year period starting in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: LCCIEB TO HOST JOINT CONFERRING CEREMONY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The London Chamber of Commerce and Industry Examinations Board (LCCIEB) is set to hold a joint qualifications conferring ceremony in Taipei Wednesday for training programs provided at 10 of its affiliates around Taiwan, officials said Tuesday.

The LCCIEB-affiliated institutions that will take part in the ceremony include the Portal of University Resources Ltd. under the National Taiwan University Innovation Incubation Center, National Yunlin University of Science and Technology, Feng Chia University, Aletheia University, Lunghwa University of Science and Technology, Shu-Te University, Overseas Chinese Institute of Technology, and Yu Da High School of Commerce and Home Economics.
The ceremony will be hosted by Sean Leslie, the LCCIEB's representative in Asia.

The LCCIEB, which was established in 1887, is a leading global provider of vocational, business-related qualifications that enjoy international recognition from employers, universities and professional bodies.

It has more than 8,000 training centers and 5,000 qualification examination centers in 125 countries around the world, and there are over 80,000 people taking part in LCCIEB-hosted examinations worldwide every year.

The LCCIEB first established its representative office in Taiwan in July this year and has since provided a wide range of programs in marketing, customer service, secretarial and administration as well as business English at its affiliated institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO LIFT BAN ON INDONESIAN WORKERS AFTER SIGNING MOU

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Tuesday it would lift the ban on importing Indonesian workers after Indonesia signs a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Taiwan on labor management cooperation.

The Cabinet-level council made the remarks after Falmi Idris, minister of manpower and trans-immigration affairs of Indonesia, announced earlier in the day that he will visit Taiwan late this month to discuss resumption of Indonesian labor export to Taiwan.

CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu said now that the Indonesian government has shown goodwill toward cooperation with Taiwan in resolving labor management problems, the CLA will handle the issue in a reciprocal manner.

Noting that the CLA has signed MOUs with countries supplying laborers to facilitate cooperation in introducing foreign blue-collar workers, housemaids and caregivers into Taiwan, Chen said negotiations with Indonesia will follow the principles set forth in those accords.
If all goes smoothly, Chen said, imports of Indonesian workers will resume before long.

The CLA has imposed an across-the-board ban on the import of Indonesian workers since Aug. 1, 2002 in retaliation for Indonesia's failure to cooperate with Taiwan in fixing the high absconding rate of Indonesian workers in Taiwan as well as unreasonable brokerage fees charged by the Indonesian side.

CLA Chairwoman Chen made a visit to Jakarta earlier this year to discuss a labor management cooperative agreement. The CLA originally expected to sign an MOU soon after Chen's Jakarta visit. However, the signing was delayed by Indonesia's presidential election. Now that the new Indonesian administration has been inaugurated, Chen said she expects to finalize the MOU signing soon.

According to reports from Jakarta, Idris said during a meeting with representatives from several local-level Indonesian labor employment agencies, non-governmental organizations and those who are concerned about labor groups' interest that he has decided to visit Taiwan at the end of November to discuss a bilateral labor management cooperative agreement.
Idris also disclosed that Taiwan may soon resume importing laborers from Indonesia, allowing about 60,000 to 100,000 Indonesian workers to work in Taiwan.
Idris, who became a Cabinet member of the new Indonesian government formed Oct. 20 of this year, will be the first ministerial-level Indonesian official to visit Taiwan since 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TAP WATER AVAILABILITY RATIO OVER 90 PERCENT IN 2003: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The availability of tap water in Taiwan was 90.9 percent at the end of 2003, up 4.7 percentage points from 86.2 percent at the end of 1993, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Tuesday.

DGBAS officials said that in terms of counties and cities, the availability was below 50 percent in Pingtung County, while the ratio was between 70 percent and 80 percent in the four counties of Nantou, Taitung, Hsinchu and Miaoli, and between 80 percent and 90 percent in five other cities and counties. But the remaining 15 cities and counties all registered an availability ratio of over 90 percent.

To improve the living environment of urban areas and prevent water pollution, the government has stepped up the construction of sewage systems, the officials said, noting that the government invested NT$46.44 billion (US$1.41 billion ) between 2001 and 2003 for sewage construction.
Taipei County (US$23.15 billion) , Taipei City (NT$9.88 billion) and Kaohsiung City (NT$3.78 billion) accounted for nearly 80 percent of the total investment.

Statistics show that Taiwan's availability ratio of sewage systems was 10.9 percent at the end of 2003, up 7.8 percentage points from the previous year. The ratio is the highest in Lienchiang County (the Matsu islands) at 67.1 percent, followed by Taipei City at 63.3 percent, and 30.2 percent in Kaohsiung.

The officials said that the infrastructure couldn't be complete in one leap because of limited resources, but Taiwan's sewage ratio was quite low compared with Japan (62 percent) and South Korea (68.4 percent), showing that there is an ample room for improvement.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUYERS OF EARTHQUAKE INSURANCE INCREASE SIGNIFICANTLY IN 2003: DGBAS

TEXT.P: A total of 122.5 of every 1,000 insurance policies issued in 2003 included coverage against earthquake damage, compared with only 1.7 out of every 1,000 in the previous year, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Tuesday.
While 934,000 household insurance policies contained an earthquake insurance clause in 2003, 99,000 fire insurance policies had supplementary earthquake coverage, according to the DGBAS.
Meanwhile, 53,000 fire insurance policies carried supplementary typhoon insurance, the DGBAS report shows.

Usually there is no separate insurance policy that provides coverage solely against natural disasters such as earthquakes, floods and typhoons. These risks are usually covered in fire insurance policies.
Since April 2002, housing fire insurance policies in Taiwan have automatically included one-year coverage against earthquake, known as the basic housing earthquake insurance.
The new measure was introduced after the disastrous earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999, which killed more than 2,000 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE FOREIGN LIQUOR DEALER EYES KINMEN MARKET

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese dealer of foreign drinks visited the outlying island of Kinmen Tuesday, looking for potential trade opportunities after mainland China announced it would allow Fujian people to come to the Taiwan-controlled island for sightseeing.

Lee Chi-ying, chairman of Diageo Taiwan, Inc., a Taiwan branch of Diageo that trades a broad collection of world-recognized drinks like Johnnie Walker, Smirnoff, Smirnoff Ice, Baileys and Guinness, visited the Kinmen County Government Tuesday, and held talks with Magistrate Lee Chu-feng and Lee's deputy Yang Chung-chuan to inquire about the possibility for business cooperation.

Lee said during the meeting that mainland Chinese authorities are expected to open the door for Fujian people to travel to Kinmen and Matsu before the end of the year, and he believes if Kinmen opens duty free sales of foreign drinks, it will attract more tourists from the mainland Chinese province.

Yang said that Kinmen's Shuitou Wharf has been permitted to set up duty free shops. However, the official said, work to construct dock facilities, including a building for travelers to clear customs, is behind schedule, meaning the planned facilities can only be inaugurated by the end of next year.
Not until then, pubic bidding for the rights to sell duty free goods, including foreign drinks at the wharf, will not be offered, Yang noted.

During the talks, Lee also expressed his interest in forging a cooperative relationship with the county-run Kinmen Liquor Co. to set up outlets in three major Fujian cities, which are the provincial capital Fuzhou, Qienzhou and Xiamen, in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO SUPPORT HIGH-PERFORMANCE DEVELOPMENT OF TEXTILE SECTOR

TEXT.P: The government will continue to support the high-performance development of Taiwan's textile industry to maintain its status as the country's largest earner of foreign exchange, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Tuesday.
Ho pointed out that Taiwan is currently the world's second- and third-largest supplier of polyester and nylon fibers, respectively, with the world's largest output of nylon fibers for clothing.
The textile sector is expected to contribute US$10 billion toward the trade surplus this year, and the total output of chemical fibers is expected to amount to 3.16 million metric tons, she said.

Ho made the remarks at the celebration of the 45th anniversary of the Taiwan Textile Research Institute at which the past, present and future of the textile industry was presented to visitors in the form of street dances.
There was also an exhibition of various newly developed fabrics.

The institute will in the near future establish cooperation alliances with various foreign research institutions and companies including Germany's Hohensteiner Institutes, Coatema and Dow Chemical to enhance the application of fabrics in medical, sports and technological fields, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU LAWMAKERS CALL FOR TAIWAN-CENTRIC HISTORY TEXTBOOKS

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers, legislative candidates and supporters of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) staged a demonstration at the Ministry of Education (MOE) Tuesday, urging the ministry to compile Taiwan-centric history and geography textbooks for school children as part of a desinicization campaign.

The group, led by TSU legislators Lin Chih-long and Huang Chung-yuan, said Taiwan has had a hard time forging a national consensus on its separate national identity due in part to the sinicized education system imposed by the Kuomintang (KMT) during its 55-year rule of Taiwan until 2000.

The MOE must overhaul its education policy in line with four principles -- National history must refer to Taiwan history; national geography must refer to Taiwan's geography; national literature must refer to Taiwan's literature; and Taiwan's various mother tongues must enjoy equal status to Mandarin, Huang said.

Noting that desinicizing teaching materials is critical to his party's localization and Taiwanization campaign, Huang said the MOE should play an active role in making Taiwan-centric curricula the mainstream in school education.
"I believe Taiwan-centric curricula will contribute to enhancing local people's awareness of Taiwan's separate national identity and thus boosting national unity," Huang said.
He further said current sinicized history and geography textbooks for local elementary and junior high school students are unrealistic and do not cultivate a Taiwan-conscious citizenry.

"In the past, Taiwan's history and geography has accounted for only 5 percent of textbooks used in junior high schools. Since 1998, the ratio has been increased to 20 percent, but this ratio remains unacceptable and should be greatly improved," Huang said, adding that the MOE should do more to establish a Taiwan-centric education and cultural system.
After reading out their petition, Huang and several demonstrators entered the MOE office, where they were greeted by Wu Tsai-shun, director of the MOE's Elementary Education Department.
Wu told the demonstrators that the MOE has been reforming compulsory education curricula to increase Taiwan-related subjects in textbooks.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCTU SIGNS TECHNOLOGY COOPERATION AGREEMENT WITH JAPAN'S TIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Chiao Tung University (NCTU) signed an agreement on technology cooperation with the Tokyo Institute of Technology (TIT) at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan Tuesday.
NCTU President Chang Chun-yen and TIT President Masuo Aizawa were on hand to ink the documents, with Taiwan Representative to Japan Koh Se-kai witnessing.

Koh said at the signing ceremony that it is a good thing that the two schools, renowned for technological achievements, have an opportunity to build up a systemized cooperation channel. The two schools' close cooperation, he added, is sure to contribute to both countries' technological industries.

A 20-year friendship between NCTU and TIT spurred the two schools to map out areas of exchange including semiconductor technology, nanotechnology, optoelectronics, online telecommunications, physical materials and liberal arts, Chang said.
NCTU is one of Taiwan's best universities featuring science and engineering, Aizawa said, adding that its research in nanotechnology plays a leading role in the world.
For the short-term cooperation programs, TIT will send a delegation of around 10 professors to NCTU for detailed discussions next January.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Assault on Falluja Sets Off Street Fighting.
Thousands of American troops are advancing across the deadly streets and alleyways of the rebel- held city.
The Wall Stree Journal: As Growth Returns To Pakistan, Hopes Rise on Terror Front.
Pakistan's economic renaissance -- largely obscured by the flow of news about al Qaeda fugitives and terrorist plots -- is an experiment on whether Western economic orthodoxy can build stability in countries fighting Islamic extremism.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FREE SOFTWARE INDUSTRY GROWING RAPIDLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's free software, or freeware, industry is growing rapidly, with an annual output of NT$13.5 billion (US$409 million) registered in 2003, an official of the Networks and Multimedia Institute (NMI) under the Institute for Information Industry said Tuesday.
The industry's annual production is estimated to reach NT$29 billion this year and to top the NT$100 billion mark in 2007, according to NMI Director Tung Chien-cheng.

The freeware industry is a key indicator for the information service industry's development, is one of the driving forces for relevant industries and is one of the basic platforms for increasing Taiwan's overall industrial competitiveness, Tung said.

A total of 25 companies in Taiwan are involved in the research and development of freeware so far, Tung went on, adding that the ratio of network servers using freeware increased to 16 percent in 2003 from the 10 percent of the previous year.
The number of companies dedicated to freeware R&D is expected to increase to 50, when the industry's annual output will top NT$100 billion, he predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF CALLS FOR MAINTAINING CROSS-STRAIT STATUS QUO

TEXT.P: Taiwan and mainland China should shelve their dispute over who owns Taiwan, maintain the status quo in terms of their relations and cooperate in developing the economy to improve the wellbeing of people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said Tuesday.

Receiving members from the Taiwan Kiwanis Club, Lien said his party has never wavered in its support for the Republic of China and will neither accept Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula for unification with the mainland nor changing the name of the country.

Noting that some politicians are calling for a new constitution by 2008, or claiming that "China is not our country, " Lien said they are pushing the country on a collision course with the People's Republic of China, which is a very dangerous move.
Both Beijing and Taiwan should set aside their territory dispute about Taiwan for the time being and cooperate on the economy, which will benefit both sides, Lien said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST TAKE CARE TO AVOID PROVOKING MAINLAND CHINA: MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan must make every possible effort to avoid giving any excuse for mainland China to attack the island, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu cautioned Tuesday.
The nation's top mainland policy planner also urged local people to be more patient in expecting any improvement in relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Wu said the Beijing leadership has felt the challenge to the rule of the Chinese Communist Party after more than 58,000 public demonstrations occurred on the mainland last year.

The recent series of large-scale riots there further betrays the instability of the mainland society, Wu said, adding that Taiwan must be watchful of the possibility of the mainland resorting to nationalism to try to distract domestic attention from the ongoing social disorder.

"We should exercise prudence to avoid giving any excuse for Beijing to launch an attack on Taiwan as a way to distract the mainland people's attention from their discontent over their domestic plight," Wu said.

Stressing that peace and development remain the gist of the government's mainland policy, Wu said he hopes the mainland can respond to Taiwan's goodwill and cooperate to improve cross-strait relations.

"As the improvement of cross-strait ties cannot rely solely on Taiwan's efforts, local people should have greater patience in waiting for a thaw in the current cross-strait impasse, " Wu said, adding that the mainland's complicated domestic politics and social forces could easily affect its policy toward Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Wu acknowledged that Beijing has no intention of negotiating any opening of direct cross-strait charter flight services during the Chinese New Year holiday before Taiwan's Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Wu said he is still hopeful that Beijing's leaders will change their minds and name an appropriate person to discuss opening such services for the convenience of the large number of Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland and who intend to return for family reunions during the Chinese New Year holiday, which will begin Feb. 6, 2005 and run through Feb. 13.

With Beijing's consent, Taiwan carriers operated special charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during the 2003 Chinese New Year period. The services were not offered during the 2004 Chinese New Year holiday because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers be allowed to also provide the same flight services while declining to negotiate the necessary technical details with Taiwan.
The ROC government said that as the opening of two-way, non-stop cross-strait charter flight services involve the exercise of public authority, prior negotiations are necessary.
In related news, MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said the mainland is not expected to escalate tension in the Taiwan Strait simply because of the result of Taiwan's upcoming legislative elections.

Chiu was commenting on opposition politicians' claims that if the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union wins a clear majority in the Dec. 11 elections, Taiwan could face a "war threat" from the mainland.
Chiu said the mainland has become more aware of the direction of Taiwan's mainstream public opinion.

"The mainland leaders are not expected to heighten cross-strait tension simply because of the election results. Instead, they will base their evaluation on the development of specific events, " he predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS TAIWAN'S DYNAMIC VENTURE BUSINESS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday Taiwan boasts one of the world's most dynamic venture business thanks to the government's support.
Addressing the opening ceremony for the 2004 Taiwan Venture Forum, Chen said Taiwan has more than 200 venture firms with a combined paid-in capital of NT$170 billion.
Since the government promulgated regulations governing venture business in 1983, Chen said venture business has contributed much to Taiwan's high-tech industry development.

The government-owned Development Fund is a successful venture business, Chen said. The Development Fund has invested in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., United Microelectronic Corp., Acer Inc. and ASUSTek Computer, Chen said, adding that all of those companies have emerged as forerunners in various high-tech fields.

Noting that venture business has helped boost Taiwan's industrial upgrading and transformation, Chen said his administration has further eased restrictions on venture business in order to help accelerate corporate restructuring, reform and industrial integration.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PREMIER HONORED FOR STARTING VENTURE FUNDS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Venture Capital Association (TVCA) awarded a "Lifetime Achievement" prize to former Premier Sun Yun-hsuan Tuesday for his introduction of venture funds into Taiwan in 1984 during his term at the helm of the Executive Yuan.

In a ceremony marking the 20th funding anniversary of the country's first venture fund, Wang Poh-yuan, president of the TVCA, said Sun's far-sighted policy laid the groundwork for the thriving venture fund sector, which has swelled to 227 funds with a combined capital of NT$170 billion (US$5.32 billion) in 2004.
However, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh put paid to the association's hope that the government will reinstate tax credit to investors who pump their money into venture funds.
In a speech on the same occasion, Ho said the venture funds should attract capital through their profit-earning capacity rather than through the tax credit offered by the government to investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-NUCLEAR GROUP CALLS FOR DISCIPLINING FOR NUCLEAR CHIEF

TEXT.P: An anti-nuclear group demanded Tuesday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) discipline Atomic Energy Council Chairman Ouyang Min-sheng for remarks he made defending nuclear power.

The Nuke-4 Referendum Initiative Association said Ouyang's claims at the Legislative Yuan that it is impossible to do away with nuclear power unless the country wants to go back to a primitive stage without air conditioners or electric bulbs run counter to the DPP's vision for nuclear-free country.
The association also urged the ruling party to follow through on its campaign promise to hold a referendum on whether to go ahead with the construction of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant.

DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, who received the association's representatives, reiterated his party's policy of a nuclear-free country and promised to relay the association's request for Ouyang's disciplining to the Executive Yuan, which has the authority to reprimand Cabinet members.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO ORGANIZE LARGE-SCALE LEGISLATIVE ELECTION CAMPAIGN RALLY

TEXT.P: The Legislative Election Campaign Committee of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) decided Tuesday to organize a large-scale rally in Taipei Dec. 4 to solicit support for the party's candidates, a DPP official said.
DPP Deputy Secretary-General Chung Jia-ping said the decision was made at a committee meeting presided over by Premier Yu Shyi-kun in his capacity as the committee chairman.

The rally, which is expected to attract 100,000 DPP supporters, will be held at the Chungshan Soccer Stadium in Taipei, Chung said, adding that President Chen Shui-bian will be also present at the gathering.
Chung said that it will be the last large-scale campaign rally organized by the ruling party in the run-up to the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
The DPP is seeking to gain control of the 225-member legislature after the elections by winning a majority of seats along with its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

A total of 387 candidates have registered to vie for 168 regional and eight aboriginal legislative seats in the elections, of whom 92 are recommended by the DPP and 30 by the TSU, while the opposition Kuomintang is fielding 74 hopefuls, the People First Party has named 41 and the newly formed Non-Partisan Solidarity Union has nominated 26.
The 225 legislative seats will include 168 regional seats and eight aboriginal seats, as well as eight overseas Chinese seats and 41 at-large seats.
The overseas Chinese and at-large legislators will be allocated based on a proportional representation of the ballots that each party garners in the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR PROMISES TO CRACK DOWN ON ILLEGAL FOREIGN TEACHERS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou promised Tuesday to crack down on foreigners who work in the city as language teachers without relevant work permits.

Ma told the city council that foreigners who receive work permits to work as professionals in Taipei are not necessarily allowed to serve as language teachers, who should meet criteria laid down by the education authorities.
He urged the relevant city agencies to crack down on such illegal foreign teachers.

Ma made the promise at the request of city councilman Wang Hao, who claimed that many language cram schools, especially those which teach English and Japanese, hire native speakers as teachers even though they do not have permits to teach.
Wang claimed that those foreigners cost local university graduates who major in English or Japanese at least 2,000 jobs in Taipei alone. He provided no statistics to back his claims.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S EDGE LIES IN COMBINING MANUFACTURING, SERVICE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: In order to keep its competitive edge, Taiwan manufacturers should develop their own brands and market access, as well as combining manufacturing with service, Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research Chairman Vincent Siew said Tuesday.

Speaking at the 2004 Taiwan Venture Forum, Siew, a former premier, said Taiwan has enjoyed an economic growth rate of 6.28 percent in the first quarter of this year and is anticipating a growth of 6.40 percent in the second quarter.

However, Siew said the rise in interest rates in the United States and the curb imposed on economic growth in mainland China will inevitably take a toll on Taiwan's economy in the second half of this year.

Furthermore, Siew said, the economic significance of Taiwan is eclipsed by the emergence of the mainland, which is attracting foreign technology and getting a say in laying down technology specifications for certain products via the weight of its huge market.
Taiwan therefore is under pressure to upgrade its industries to hold its own against the mainland competition, Siew said.
In order to tide over the crisis, Siew said Taiwan industries should shift their emphasis from development and design to marketing and the development of their own brands.
Only by combining manufacturing and service can domestic industries keep their competitiveness, Siew said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Nov. 10, or the 28th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1483: Martin Luther, German theologian and leader of the Reformation, is born. He confirmed the Augsburg Confession in 1530, effectively establishing the Lutheran Church.
1925: Richard Burton, British actor, is born.
1928: Japan's Emperor Hirohito ascends the throne at the age of 27.
1934: The Tai Yang Fine Arts Association, Taiwan's largest private fine arts association, is established in Taipei.
1938: Mustapha Kemal Ataturk, Turkish national leader and founder of modern Turkey, dies at the age of 57. He became the first president of Turkey in 1923.
1942: Buoyant after the desert victory at El Alamin, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill warns that "this is not the end. It is not even the beginning of the end. But it is, perhaps, the end of the beginning."
1944: The International Committee of the Red Cross wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1944: Wang Ching-wei, chairman of the puppet "Nanking government" during the Sino-Japanese War, dies in Nagoya, Japan, at the age of 62.
1952: Albert Schweitzer, doctor and philosopher, is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in recognition of his humanitarian work in Africa.
1964: Yu Yu-jen, president of the Republic of China's Control Yuan, the country's top watchdog body charged with taking disciplinary action against government officials' irregularities, dies at the age of 86.
1967: The ROC Ministry of Education forms the Bureau of Culture. Wang Hung-chun is invited to serve as the first head of the bureau.
1968: The Republic of China's first eye bank is established.
1971: The U.S. Senate approves the treaty to return Ryukyu to Japan, ending 27 years of U.S. rule of the island.
1975: Angola gains independence from Portugal.
1982: Leonid I. Brezhnev, general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, dies at the age of 75.
1989: Todor Zhikov, Bulgaria's Communist Party chief and head of state, resigns after 35 years in power.
1990: Chandra Shekhar, a veteran socialist leader, becomes prime minister of India.
1994: Iraq formally recognizes Kuwait as a sovereign state.
1994: Prime Minister Kumaratunga wins the presidential election in Sri Lanka.
1995: The Pugwash Conference on Science and World Affairs, Britain and Joseph Rotblat are awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1997: Jiang Zemin of mainland China and Boris Yeltsin of Russia sign a declaration ending a long-running border dispute between them.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui, in his capacity as the chairman of the Kuomintang (KMT), orders an across-the-board mobilization of KMT legislators to drum up support for Vice President Lien Chan, the party's candidate in the 2000 presidential election.
2000: President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines denies new corruption allegations that he pocketed a kickback of US$20 million from the sale of a telephone company and received more than US$16 million from a controversial stock sale.
2001: The opposition Kuomintang stages a large-scale demonstration to highlight the serious problem of unemployment in Taiwan.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The people are the most important element of a country; the spirits of the land and grain are the next; the ruler is the least important."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TAIWAN STRAIT POLICY EXPECTED TO REMAIN UNCHANGED: KELLY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 9 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The United States' Taiwan Strait policy is expected to remain unchanged in U.S. President George W. Bush's second term, a State Department official said Tuesday.

Answering questions after a speech delivered at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, James A. Kelly, assistant secretary of state for East Asia and Pacific Affairs, said that because the Taiwan Strait issue is tremendously complex, it would not be conducive to a peaceful resolution for the United States to change its policy rashly.
Based on this, Kelly asserted that he does not expect the U.S. policy on relations across the Taiwan Strait to change in Bush's second four-year term as president.

Kelly said he believes that the people on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have the wisdom and ability to solve their differences, adding that he expects these differences to be resolved peacefully.
On mainland China's stepped-up militarization, Kelly said that it could cause a military imbalance across the Taiwan Strait, which could in turn bring about increased cross-strait tensions.

He pointed in particular to China's deployed missiles aimed at Taiwan, saying that they could be weapons of mass destruction and serve nobody's interests. He added that the United States is aware of this situation and that it has expressed its concerns to Beijing and will continue to do so.

Kelly also told his audience that he reiterated Washington's Taiwan Strait policy at a hearing on the 25th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act at the House International Relations Committee on April 21, and that his testimony at the hearing was crafted after full-range consultations among all related agencies of the administration.

Kelly noted that at the hearing, he made known once again the United States' stance that it opposes any unilateral action by either side of the Taiwan Strait to change the status quo. Kelly also encouraged Beijing and Taipei to engage in direct trade, postal and transportation links, as this would create a win-win situation for both sides in stepping up economic exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: A savage dance of death in the alleys of Fallujah.
The green video screen in the back of a Bradley fighting vehicle is the ultimate in reality television, and that is how we watched the battle of Fallujah unfold as our 30-tonne steel beast advanced into the district of Jolan, the rebels' bastion, in the small hours of yesterday morning.
Outside, in the bomb-blasted streets, up to 5,000 die-hard insurgents were out to kill. Inside, on a screen accurate enough to show rats scavenging on the rubbish piles, the battle between luminous green tanks and luminous green gunmen seemed almost abstract.
Only the shock of the explosions and the occasional back blast of dust when a gunner opened fire reminded us we were in the midst of the most desperate urban battle since the fall of Baghdad. That, and the shrapnel which went right through my arm later in the morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT POLICY PROPOSALS CAN'T WORK WITHOUT COMMON GROUND: KMT

TEXT.P: An official of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Wednesday that with no common ground between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, it will be impossible to carry out any cross-strait policy proposals.

Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Culture and Communications Committee, made the remarks amid news reports that President Chen Shui-bian will make a major announcement on cross-strait relations based on his Double Ten National Day speech.

"The two sides of the Taiwan Strait in fact have no common ground on the issue of maintaining cross-strait peace, " Chang claimed, adding that cross-strait dialogue has not been able to be resumed, which he said worries the United States.

He urged the government not to fool the Taiwan people, adding that President Chen said before the March 20 presidential election that if he is elected, mainland China will forgo its "one China" formula, which it has still not done.

Chang noted that the president also said that if the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, can win more than half of the seats in the 225-member Legislative Yuan in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can resume talks next year. Chang said that "this is just rhetoric to woo voters."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN EXHORTS APEC DELEGATES TO LET TAIWAN'S VOICE BE HEARD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday exhorted members of the Taiwan delegation to the 2004 informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to grasp every opportunity to let Taiwan's voice be heard.

During a meeting at the Presidential Office with Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, who will head the Taiwan delegation, and other delegates to the APEC ministerial meetings, Chen said he wants them to take every opportunity, private or public, to make known Taiwan's sincerity in bolstering cooperation among all APEC economies and its concrete plans towards that goal.

The Taiwan delegates should actively seize every opportunity to talk with their counterparts, particularly those from the United States, mainland China, Japan and Russia, to make known Taiwan's stances, Chen noted.

Lee, president of Taiwan's top research institute and a Nobel Prize winner in chemistry in 1986, has been assigned by President Chen to attend the 2004 APEC informal leadership meeting scheduled to take place in the Chilean capital of Santiago Nov. 20-21 on his behalf.

Chen said he is confident that Lee would achieve these tasks to win international support and respect for Taiwan again this year. Lee also attended the APEC informal leadership meeting on President Chen's behalf in 2002 and in 2003.

Noting that APEC is one of the few international groupings that has both Taiwan and mainland China as members, Chen said that although he cannot attend the leadership meeting in person due to Beijing's obstruction, this does not mean that Taiwan's resolve in contributing to APEC efforts as a member would be lessened.

Chen said that Taiwan is not only resolved to support the implementation of various APEC projects and plans, it also keenly expects that other APEC economies will throw their support behind the projects that Taiwan plans to field this year, including an avian flu prevention project and regional cooperation in vaccine research and development.

He added that Taiwan cannot afford to restrict itself under the current difficult circumstances that Taiwan faces due to Beijing's ubiquitous diplomatic suppression and the international community's reluctance to offend Beijing.

"We must take the initiative in creating opportunities for ourselves and make as many friends as possible in the international community, particularly in important dialogue platforms such as APEC," Chen asserted.

As security will be one of the main themes to be discussed at this year's APEC conferences, Chen said, the Taiwan delegation should express Taiwan's desire to play an active role in cultivating a safe living environment and its past contributions in this regard, Chen added.

President Chen received a formal invitation from Chilean President Ricardo Lagos Escobar in October to attend the 2004 APEC informal leadership meeting but decided to let Lee attend on his behalf to spare the host country any unnecessary trouble.

APEC groups 21 Asia-Pacific economies -- Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND PUSHES FOR SMOKE-FREE MILITARY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) is promoting a no-smoking directive in the military in an effort to help implement a government no-smoking policy as well as optimize the public health and environment, a military spokesman said Wednesday.

MND spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said at a press conference that under the no-smoking military project, smoking will gradually be wiped out from the armed forces, including barracks, military organizations and military academies, eventually making the entire military smoke-free.

Also speaking at the press conference, Lu Li-chun, a division director with the MND Medical Affairs Bureau, said that to facilitate the no-smoking policy, the MND will enact regulations on smoking prevention and will establish "smoking prevention committees" in military units at various levels.

According to Huang, the MND is also sponsoring classes and workshops to help personnel in uniform to quit smoking and opening outpatient services at military hospitals and clinics for the same purpose.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PEACE FOR TAIWAN' POSTER DISPLAYED OUTSIDE U.N. HEADQUARTERS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Nov. 9 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Members of an anti-war alliance from Taiwan displayed a poster bearing the slogan "Peace for Taiwan" in front of the United Nations headquarters in New York City Wednesday in a bid to raise global concern over peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.
The poster was pieced together from more than 20 separate paintings completed by a group of Taiwanese children and parents Oct. 31 to depict their desire for peace.

Alliance leader Chou Sheng-hsin said the poster represents the call for peace of the Taiwanese people, who are facing the imminent threat of more than 600 missiles and the strong military power of mainland China.

By organizing the event, the alliance was trying to call global attention to the issue of peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, to call for more positive participation by the U.N. in cross-strait peace and stability, and to promote closer connections between Taiwan's peace movement and those of other parts of the world, Chou said.
Chou said the alliance is also promoting the launch of a referendum aimed at pressing Taipei and Beijing to sign a 50-year peace accord under the principle of maintaining the cross-strait status quo.
The alliance was founded by a group of academics in June after the Executive Yuan proposed a NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement package from the United States.
In addition to staging a June 19 demonstration against the arms procurement, the alliance has started a signature campaign in an attempt to initiate a public referendum on the arms procurement.

The bourse opened at 5,948.38 and fluctuated between 5,957.58 and 5,899.25 during trading. A total of 3.01 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$67.08 billion (US$2.01 billion).
