DOC.HEADLINE: EPA TO SET UP NATIONWIDE GROUNDWATER EARLY WARNING NETWORK

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will establish a nationwide early warning network to monitor groundwater quality to ensure early detection of pollution, officials said Wednesday.
Under the program, the EPA will drill an additional 180 monitoring wells in four years in the vicinity of pollution-prone areas such as industrial zones, the officials said.

After the network is completed, the EPA will sample the water in the monitoring wells on a regular basis to check for contamination to make sure the water is safe for public consumption, the officials added.
The EPA has set up 431 monitoring wells in major groundwater areas, but they are mostly located in areas upstream of potential sources of pollution and have limited early warning functions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MAINLAND CHINESE OFFICIALS ARRIVE IN TAIPEI FOR LOW-PROFILE VISIT

TEXT.P: Two mainland Chinese officials arrived in Taipei Wednesday for a low-profile visit.

Li Xiaoyun, director of the Cross-Strait Economic and Technological Exchange Center under mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office, and Feng Chuozhe, president of Beijing's state-run Cross-Strait Travel Service, were greeted by an anonymous official upon their arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway.
Li and Feng became grim-faced when they saw a crowd of journalists and cameramen at the airport and they refused to answer specific press inquiries.

Reporters had speculated Li and Feng are visiting Taiwan to discuss issues regarding the opening of direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday, as well as the opening of Taiwan to mainland Chinese tourists.

Li and Feng, however, said they were invited to make a sightseeing trip. "We will travel around the island for sightseeing, " Li said, adding that he and Feng received the invitation a long time ago but postponed the trip until now for a variety of reasons.
This is Li's first trip to Taiwan, while Feng has visited on several previous occasions.

Senior Taiwan officials in charge of mainland affairs, including Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu, have on many occasions urged Beijing's leaders to name an appropriate person to discuss cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday for the convenience of the large number of Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland, commonly known as Taishang.

With Beijing's consent, Taiwan carriers operated special charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during the 2003 Chinese New Year period. The services were not offered during the 2004 Chinese New Year holiday because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers be allowed to also provide the same flight services while declining to negotiate the necessary technical details with Taiwan.

The ROC government said that as the opening of two-way, non-stop cross-strait charter flight services involves the exercise of public authority, prior negotiations are necessary. The upcoming lunar New Year holiday falls between Feb. 6, 2005 and Feb. 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUPPORTS ESTABLISHMENT OF ASIA-PACIFIC FREE TRADE ZONE

TEXT.P: Taiwan supports the establishment of a Free Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific to help achieve the Bogor Goals of accelerating regional free trade and investment reforms, Taiwan's delegates to a sub Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum business grouping said Wednesday.

The establishment of the Free Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific (FTAAP) -- a resolution reached during an APEC Business Advisory Council (ABAC) meeting held in Taipei in May -- will help accelerate the implementation of plans that were hammered out during the Bogor-round meetings of APEC leaders and ministers, said the delegates.

Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Taiwan-based Chinatrust Financial Holding Corporation, TECO Group Chairman Huang Mao-hsiung and I-Mei Foods Vice Chairman Kao Chih-shang, who will take part in the 2004 ABAC meeting to be held in Chile Nov. 16-18, made the remarks during an audience at the Presidential Office with President Chen Shui-bian.

The trio presented Chen with a copy of an ABAC proposal letter to the APEC informal leadership meeting scheduled to take place in the Chilean capital of Santiago Nov. 20-21 urging the APEC leaders to help facilitate the establishment of the FTAAP.

The ABAC proposal letter also suggests that leaders of the APEC economies discuss the feasibility of implementing a Trans-Pacific Business Agenda -- a resolution reached in another ABAC meeting held last month in Auckland, New Zealand -- to further optimize APEC's free trade spirit and obligations, the three delegates said.

They argued that although the Bogor Goals is the bedrock of APEC visions for trade and investment liberalization, and although APEC leaders have constantly vowed to help achieve the goals, it is difficult to imagine some of the APEC economies, particularly industrially-advanced countries, fully opening their trade and investment regimes before 2010 as stipulated in the Bogor Goals.
The ABAC proposal letter also expects that the APEC will move to improve the security and supervision system of banking and financing institutions in the Asia-Pacific region, they said.
ABAC members also issued an Anti-Corruption Statement during their last meeting, calling for APEC leaders to help foster efforts to fight against corruption in the region.

They said that private business sectors have been the prime movers behind economic development in the Asia-Pacific region and that all governments in the region need close cooperation with private businesses, making groupings like the ABAC important bridges for communication between APEC political leaders and the private sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DEFENDS EDUCATION MINISTRY OVER TEXTBOOK CONTROVERSY

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday that it supports a plan by the Ministry of Education (MOE) to revise history textbooks for high school students, but the opposition accused the DPP of ruling on "ideology" and "an acceleration toward Taiwan independence."
The DPP legislative caucus was referring to an MOE plan for the next academic year, a draft summary of which was put on its Web site a day earlier.

Tsai Huang-liang, DPP whip in the legislature, said that the Cairo Declaration -- referring to a meeting of the leaders from the three major powers, Britain, the United States and China in Cairo regarding Japan in 1943 -- and the San Francisco Peace Treaty, in which Japan officially renounced its rights to Taiwan -- are two major documents on which Taiwan bases its legal status.

In the past, the textbooks were the subjective interpretation of the rulers and are not necessarily correct, he said, adding that interpretations of history can vary because of different backgrounds and stances.
"The Ministry of Education has the responsibility to clarify the legal status of Taiwan's sovereignty so that the next generation will clearly understand Taiwan history," he added.

He noted that Taiwan students are taught about the rise and fall of every dynasty in China but know little about their own country, citing the example that only a few know that Wu Sha was the pioneering hero that helped develop Ilan.
He expressed regret that the opposition have "overinterpreted" Taiwan history and link everything to ideology, adding that they should not try to "reap political gains from high school textbooks,"
DPP Legislator Chen Chin-chun said that Taiwan and China are "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait, " and that China's history should not be included in Taiwan's history.

On the other hand, Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, said that recent remarks by President Chen Shui-bian and the DPP that China is not part of "our country" might come from the DPP's attempts to cement its pro-independence core supporters or could be the result of the party's own ideology.

He said that ideology is only the belief of a few, but history will remain unchanged. "Those who try to replace history with ideology will forego their origins, " he said, adding that doing so will only bring "disaster" to Taiwan under the present circumstances.

Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Culture and Communications Committee, noted that the DPP's plan to put the establishment of the Republic of China in 1912 into the category of Chinese history and that President Chen recently said that China is not part of "our country."

Under such logic, the ROC will also become "not part of our country" in the future, he said, adding that the government's approach to integrating "Taiwan independence" into education and its acceleration of a tilt toward Taiwan independence will only force mainland China to quicken its pace of seeking unification.
The KMT legislative caucus said that the revision of the history textbooks is an attempt by the DPP to push Taiwan's status into "uncertainty."

Legislator Huang Teh-fu, KMT whip in the legislature, said that the MOE's plan to make 1945 -- when the KMT administration took over Taiwan -- the dividing point between Taiwan and China history is a "questionable mentality."
Huang said that the ROC ruled China in 1912 and that between 1945 and the present, its jurisdiction has only covered Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu.
He also said that history has continuity, otherwise banknotes in Taiwan would not bear the image of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founding father of the ROC.

Legislator Lee Ching-an of the opposition People First Party, an ally of the Kuomintang, lashed out at what she called the ideology-based rule of the DPP, and claimed the party is moving toward de facto independence through education and national examinations.

Taiwan history currently accounts for only 21 percent of the history textbooks for high schools, but under the new plan, the ratio of Taiwan will be raised to be the same as that of China history and world history, so that each will account for one-third.

The establishment of the ROC will be placed in the China history section, while in the post-World War II Taiwan, a lot of space will cover the KMT's authoritarian rule, which encroached on human rights and suppressed political discontent, and the tragic 2-28 incident, a KMT massacre that has left an indelible mark on many Taiwanese people.

The new textbooks will also elaborate on the Cairo Declaration, the San Francisco Peace Treaty and an ROC-Japan Peace Treaty that basically acknowledged the terms of the San Francisco Peace Treaty, and their "uncertain relationship to Taiwan's sovereignty."

It is believed that the history textbook issue is a U-turn, as supporters of Taiwan independence have used the San Francisco Peace Treaty to justify Taiwan's right to self-determination because the treaty does not explicitly state Taiwan's sovereignty. Over the past five decades, history textbooks have stated that the ROC, based on the Cairo Declaration, legally took over Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD VISION TAIWAN RECRUITING INTERPRETERS

TEXT.P: In view of the rising number of foreign spouses in Taiwan, World Vision Taiwan's central office is recruiting interpreters of various Southeast Asian languages.

World Vision officials said that with the number of abused foreign spouses in Taiwan rising steadily, the group needs interpreters who can speak Southeast Asian languages to upgrade the organization's ability to handle domestic violence cases.
They will recruit 70 interpreters, including those versed in Indonesian, Thai, Cambodian, Vietnamese and English, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON URGED TO BE CAREFUL ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT SITUATION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 9 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A senior member of the U.S. House of Representatives called on Washington Tuesday to handle the situation across the Taiwan Strait carefully.

James Leach, chairman of the Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific of the House Committee on International Relations, said Americans must be aware of the sensitivity of the Taiwan question, namely that mainland China will start a war if Taiwan moves toward independence.
Although the concepts of independence and self-determination are usually synonymous in most parts of the world, this does not include Taiwan, Leach said.

While Taiwan will enjoy a high degree of self-determination as long as it does not declare independence, a tragic war implicating many countries will break out immediately if Taiwan declares independence, Leach predicted.
Therefore, he said, the United States must be very careful about the situation, which he said could jeopardize millions of lives if it is allowed to spiral out of control.

According to the terms of the Taiwan Relations Act, the United States is committed to preventing the status of Taiwan from being changed by force and allowing Taiwan to enjoy self-determination, but this does not include independence, Leach said.
He said a recent statement by U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell that Taiwan "does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation" only reflects the long-standing position of the United States.
Leach made the remarks at a seminar on the Asian relations of the George W. Bush administration, which was organized by the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIAN POLITICIANS TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Two high-ranking Indian politicians will arrive in Taiwan Thursday for a three-day visit at the invitation of the Taiwan Thinktank, a source from the think tank said Wednesday.

The anonymous source said Shri George Fernandes, chairman of the Janta Dal, United and Jaya Jaitly, former chairman of the Samata Party, will attend a Friday seminar organized by the Taiwan Thinktank on the prospects for democratic cooperation among Taiwan, India and Japan.

Fernandes, a nine-term member of the Lok Sabha, or People's Assembly, left his post as defense minister in May after the coalition lead by the Gharatiya Janata Party (BJP) lost the general election. He had been touted as a favorite for prime minister should the BJP have won the election.

During his term as defense minister, Fernandes was the first Indian minister who sees Taiwan officials posted to New Delhi in his office and was praised for his handling of India's dispute with Pakistan.
Jaitly is well-known in India as a feminist and writer, and has campaigned for better lives for India's women.
The two will exchange views with other seminar participants on cooperation among Taiwan, India and Japan in economics, science and democracy, the source said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND MONITORS SUSPICIOUS MAINLAND CHINESE NUCLEAR-POWERED SUBMARINES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Wednesday that the ministry is monitoring the movements of a suspected mainland Chinese nuclear-powered submarine in Japanese territorial waters.

The MND officials made the remarks in the wake of an Agence France Presse report that Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi had expressed regret over the vessel entering Japan's territorial waters.

The submarine was detected in Japanese waters near islands disputed with China about 300 kilometers southwest of Okinawa, a southern Japanese island home to a major U.S. military base, according to the report.
The officials said that through information swapping, they are keeping abreast of the vessel's movements.
Based on various pieces of information received, the officials said that while they have initially concluded that the vessel is on a deep-sea training trip, they will continue to monitor it closely.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOWS NOT TO DEVELOP WEAPONS OF MASS DESTRUCTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday the Republic of China government would never develop weapons of mass destruction.
He also urged mainland China to make a similar public pledge and renounce the use and development of weapons of mass destruction.

Chen made the remarks at a high-level national security meeting to discuss measures to cope with the delicate triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations in the wake of the U.S. presidential election as well as how to kick-start the long-stalled dialogue across the Taiwan Strait and promote cross-strait engagements on an equal and reciprocal basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: VANUATU YET TO CONFIRM DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH ROC

TEXT.P: Vanuatu Prime Minister Serge Vohor has yet to convene a Cabinet meeting to confirm the establishment of diplomatic relations between the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the South Pacific island nation, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Wednesday.
Michel Lu said the Cabinet meeting, originally scheduled for Wednesday afternoon, was postponed because Vohor has yet to return to Port-Vila, the capital of Vanuatu, due to local elections.
But Lu also quoted a spokesman for Vohor as saying that the Cabinet meeting is only a formality, and Cabinet members will not oppose the establishment of diplomatic relations with the ROC.

ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen and Vohor signed a joint communique in Taipei Nov. 3 on the establishment of full diplomatic ties between the two countries. Vanuatu has a population of about 200,000 and will be the ROC's 27th diplomatic ally.

Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau said recently the ROC and Vanuatu would exchange ambassadors in two weeks, and the establishment of diplomatic ties will have to wait for the confirmation of its Cabinet meeting.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun on Tuesday denied that the government has promised a large aid package to Vanuatu in exchange for diplomatic recognition of Taiwan. Vohor has said repeatedly that his country wants to make friends with both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 70% OF PEOPLE IN FAVOR OF ARMS PROCUREMENT BILL: POLL

TEXT.P: Just over 70 percent of the pubic supports the Executive Yuan's move to submit the "major arms procurement bill" to the Legislative Yuan before lawmakers start reviewing its NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) budget, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.
While 16 percent of the respondents do not support the move, the rest said they have no opinion, the survey showed.
The survey was conducted by the TVBS Poll Center at the Ministry of National Defense's commission. It was carried out Nov. 2-3 on 1,073 Taiwan adults, with a margin of error of three percent.
The survey found that 46.2 percent of the respondents are for the arms procurement, compared with 40.5 percent who are against.
If the cost of the procurement was cut to NT$500 billion, the people in favor of the package rose to 54.1 percent, and those opposing it fell to 30.6 percent.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's bid to put the "major arms procurement bill" on the legislative agenda was blocked by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party for the 10th time on Tuesday.

As the Legislative Yuan went into a one-month recess starting Wednesday in preparation for the Dec. 11 legislative elections, any hope that the legislature would discuss the bill before the elections was killed.
The Ministry of National Defense released a statement Wednesday to deplore what it called political tussles at the expense of national security.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PRAISES KERRY'S POISE IN DEFEAT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian praised U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Sen. John Kerry Wednesday for his democratic poise and graciousness in conceding defeat at the end of the bitterly fought race a week ago.

Chen offered his commendation while meeting with three core members of the U.S. Congressional Hispanic Caucus. The three House of Representatives members, including Rep. Ciro Rodriguez (D-Texas), are all Hispanic Democrats.

After a long, tense night of vote counting, Kerry telephoned incumbent President George W. Bush Nov. 3 to concede defeat and congratulate Bush on his re-election. Kerry then delivered a gracious and heartfelt concession speech in which he said the outcome of the election should be decided by voters, not a protracted legal process and that he would not be giving up the fight if there was a chance that he would prevail.

Kerry further said that in an American election there are no losers because, "Whether or not our candidates are successful, the next morning we all wake up as Americans." He also called for unity, saying that America is in need of unity and longs for a larger measure of compassion and that he will do his part to try to bridge the partisan divide.
Chen said he admires Kerry's magnanimous sportsmanship and democratic manners.

The situation in Taiwan is completely different, Chen lamented. When he won his first presidential term in 2000, Chen said he didn't receive phone calls from any of the defeated candidates. "Instead I telephoned them to express my gratitude for their participation in the race."
This time around, Chen said he won re-election by a slim margin. But his challenger has so far declined to concede defeat, not to mention to offer him congratulations.

Without referring to him by name, Chen said he feels regret that his sole challenger in the 2004 presidential race, KMT Chairman Lien Chan, would not respect the Taiwan High Court's Nov. 4 ruling that upheld Chen's re-election.

"Kerry said those who were defeated in political elections should not feel anger or rancor. In Taiwan, nearly eight months have passed since the March 20 presidential election. I don't understand why the defeated challenger still harbors rancor and hatred. I think we have much to learn from Kerry and from the U.S. founding spirit, " Chen said.

He further said that although the Democratic Party failed to win the presidency this time, it has won the hearts and respect of American people for its performance throughout the race. "You should be proud of it," Chen said.

Chen also took advantage of the meeting to express his gratitude for the U.S. Congressional Hispanic Caucus' long-term support for Taiwan's cause. For years, the caucus has consistently thrown its full support behind pro-Taiwan resolutions and bills in the U.S. Congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULES ON ENTRY OF MAINLAND PROFESSIONALS TO BE FURTHER EASED

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese athletics experts who are employed to assist in training Taiwan's national sports teams will be allowed to stay for up to six years, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Wednesday.
Moreover, mainland Chinese high-tech experts employed to conduct research or manufacturing activities in Taiwan can also stay for up to six years.

The new regulations are part of a package of revisions to the existing rules governing the entry of mainland Chinese professionals to conduct professional activities in Taiwan, MOI officials said, adding that the proposed amendments are aimed at facilitating exchanges of skilled individuals across the Taiwan Strait.

The MOI-drafted amendment package will be referred to the Mainland Affairs Council for further discussions and then be sent to the Cabinet for final approval. The new package will be put into practice with the Cabinet's consent.

According to the new package, mainland high-tech personnel who are allowed to stay for four months or longer can bring their spouses and underage children. They can also apply for multiple entry/exit permits valid for six years.

Last week, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) also announced that Taiwan will offer permanent residency rights to mainland Chinese high-tech professionals with a view to enriching the island's technological talent pool.

According to the MOEA-drafted rules, mainland citizens with outstanding achievements in technologies that are helpful to upgrading Taiwan's industrial sector are eligible to apply for permanent residence here.

Also eligible are those who are professionally trained in skills related to rising industries, key technology or key components or products that are needed by Taiwan or difficult to acquire in a short period of time, according to the regulations.

By sector, the technologies considered useful to Taiwan include digital content, image display, optoelectronics, semiconductors, electronics, information, communications, industrial automation, material application, biotechnology, nanotechnology, pharmaceuticals, medical equipment, special chemicals, health food, resources development and utilities, and alternative energy resources development.
Eligible mainland residents can file their applications along with documents proving their credentials after they have legally resided in Taiwan for two years.

After the applications have passed screening by the MOEA, they will need to undergo final review by the Ministry of the Interior, which will ensure that the number of mainland residents in Taiwan does not exceed the quota set by the government, MOEA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN TRAVEL SERVICE DELEGATION VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A delegation of tour operators in the Taiwan-held frontline island of Kinmen traveled to the southeast mainland Chinese province of Fujian Wednesday to attract mainland tourists to the island.
The delegation, headed by opposition New Party Legislator Wu Cheng-tien, will discuss with Fujian authorities on technical details regarding opening of Kinmen to tourists from Fujian.
The Fujian provincial government has promised to allow its residents to make sightseeing trips to Kinmen, which lies closer to Fujian than to Taiwan, via the direct "mini three links" route soon.

Wu said the delegation will push the Fujian government to honor its promise as early as possible to help boost cross-Taiwan Strait civilian exchanges and Kinmen's tourist industry. The delegation is composed of representatives of travel agencies, hotels, tour bus companies and restaurants.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST PART OF 1,000-MEMBER JAPANESE TOUR GROUP ARRIVES IN PINGTUNG

TEXT.P: A group of 158 Japanese tourists, the first part of a 1,000-member tour group, arrived in Pingtung Wednesday, via Hsiaokang International Airport in Kaohsiung, for four days of sightseeing in southern Taiwan.

The Japanese tourists, boarding a Taiwan-based China Airlines (CAL) charter flight, were warmly greeted by officials of the Executive Yuan's Southern Taiwan Joint Service Center and representatives of local governments upon their arrival at the airport.

After a welcoming ceremony at the airport, the Japanese visitors, guided by police vehicles sent by the Pingtung County Government, traveled to Kenting National Park in Pintung, the first stop of their trip.
During their stay in Taiwan, the Japanese tourists will visit scenic spots and cultural establishments in Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Tainan cities and counties.
Yu Hung, executive director of the Executive Yuan's Southern Taiwan Joint Service Center, said that it will be the largest Japanese tourist group to ever have visited southern Taiwan in 30 years.

The other members of the Japanese tourist group, composed of executives of Japan's Asahi Breweries Group, are scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Nov. 13, 20, 23, 26 and 29 on CAL charter flights and regular flights, Yu noted.
Most of the Japanese visitors are from Kyushu and Hiroshima and are between 40 and 60 years old, he added.
The program is part of efforts by the government to promote tourism under the "2004 Visit Taiwan Year" program.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SUGGESTS BUFFER ZONE, SAFETY CONSULTING MECHANISM WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that Beijing and Taipei should agree on a military buffer zone in the Taiwan Strait and establish a failsafe communications channel to avoid military miscalculations from either side.

After a meeting with his senior national security advisors, the president said the proposed buffer zone should be off-limits to warships and aircraft from both sides of the Strait unless the other side has been informed beforehand.

He also suggested that mainland China establish a consultation mechanism with Taiwan to ensure stable relations. This could be patterned on the 1972 US-Soviet Maritime Event Consultative Agreement and the 1998 US-China Military Maritime Consultative Agreement.
The president said such a mechanism would help both sides develop a standard of conduct in and across the Taiwan Strait.

In line with the international norms, Chen said his country has pledged to renounce the development and use of weapons of mass destruction, including nuclear, biological and chemical. He urged Beijing to follow suit.

For the sake of easing the strain across the Taiwan Strait, Chen said compulsory military service for the country's draftees will be cut from one year and eight months to one year and six months, beginning July next year, and to one year by 2008. At the same time, the number of armed forces will be cut by 100,000.

The president reiterated a suggestion he made in his Double Ten National Day address that Taipei and Beijing should resume talks on the basis of their 1992 meetings, and negotiate the opening of direct charter cargo flights across the Strait as well as charter passenger flights during the upcoming Chinese New Year.
Different from the charter flights in 2003, Chen said this time the flights would be operated by carriers from both Taiwan and China and would not stop at an intermediate destination.

Noting that the next two years will be crucial for the reopening of dialogue between Taipei and Beijing, and for the development of stability and peace across the Strait, Chen urged the leaders in Beijing to take advantage of the window of opportunity to improve the wellbeing of the people on both sides.

He promised not to change the policy he spelled out toward mainland China in his second inaugural address on May 20, and the Double Ten National Day address. In those speeches, Chen promised not to change the name or flag of the nation, which would be tantamount to an alternation to the country's political status quo.
The president said he would wait for Beijing to reciprocate his gesture with patience and determination.

To underline his great desire to promote peace across the Strait, the president promised to form a commission to promote peace with mainland China after the year-end legislative elections and might invite an opposition leader to head the commission, which will work out guidelines for peaceful development with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC REPRESENTATIVES WILL NOT MEET WITH VISITING CHINESE OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-shan said his office has no plan for a meeting with two mainland Chinese officials who arrived in Taiwan for a visit Wednesday.

Chiu said Li Xiaoyun, director of the Cross-Strait Economic and Technological Exchange Center under mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office, and Feng Chuozhe, president of Beijing's state-run Cross-Strait Travel Service, were invited to visit Taiwan by a private group in Taipei.

Chiu said he has no knowledge whether the two were authorized by Beijing to negotiate with Taiwan on possible charter flights between Shanghai and Taoyuan during the Chinese New Year and no meeting with the two has been scheduled.
Beijing has refrained this year from negotiating with Taipei on charter flights similar to the ones in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTIES REACT ALONG PARTY LINES TO CHEN'S OFFER TO BEIJING

TEXT.P: Political parties reacted along party lines Wednesday to President Chen Shui-bian's latest offer to Beijing.

Hours after Chen called for a military buffer zone across the Taiwan Strait and urged China to reopen dialogue with Taiwan, Legislator Tsai Huang-liang, the whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) at the Legislative Yuan said the president has offered another olive branch to China.

Tsai said it is also an olive branch to the opposition parties in Taiwan, because the president promised to form a commission for peaceful development with China with an opposition leader as its head.
The opposition parties, or the so-called "pan-blue alliance, " should embrace the president's proposal by working together with Chen in promoting peace with China, Tsai said.

Legislator Lin Chih-chia from the Taiwan Solidarity Union, a DPP political ally in the Legislative Yuan, said the president's appeal will fall on deaf ears unless Chen's party wins a majority in the legislature in the year-end elections.

He confirmed Chen's efforts to maintain peace with China, saying that the president has done whatever he can, but without backup from the legislature, the president's appeal won't be taken seriously by China.
Meanwhile, Chang Jung-kung, a spokesman for the opposition Kuomintang, said Chen's appeal for peace betrays the seriousness of the strain across the Strait.
Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung from the oppositon People First Party dismissed Chen's statement as a campaign gambit aimed at winning over voters in the year-end legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Nov. 11, or the 29th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1821: Russian novelist Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoyevsky is born in Moscow.
1855: Danish philosopher Soren Kierkegaard dies. He greatly influenced 20th century existentialism.
1909: The U.S. Navy builds the world's largest naval base at Pearl Harbor.
1918: World War I comes to an end.
1918: The independent republic of Poland is proclaimed.
1921: The British Legion holds its first Poppy Day to raise funds for those wounded in World War I.
1923: Adolf Hitler is arrested in a village in suburban Munich after a failed coup attempt.
1937: Kuomintang troops evacuate Shanghai during the Sino-Japanese War.
1945: Jerome Kern, the U.S. composer who wrote musicals such as "Show Boat," dies.
1947: The Republic of China celebrates its first Industrial Day.
1961: The Soviet city of Stalingrad is renamed Volgograd.
1965: Three Communist Chinese airmen defect to Taiwan in a Russian-made IL-28 jet bomber.
1965: Rhodesia unilaterally announces independence from Britain.
1971: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Lebanon.
1971: The United States Senate ratifies a treaty returning the island of Okinawa to Japan.
1974: The National Council of the Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement holds its 7th annual plenary session.
1975: Angola announces independence from Portugal.
1981: The Republic of China's Executive Yuan establishes the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs. Chen Chi-lu would serve as the first head of the council.
1987: Van Gogh's painting "Irises" is sold at Sotheby's in New York for US$53.9 million.
1987: Boris Yeltsin is removed as Moscow Communist Party chief.
1999: The Hsintien line of Taipei's Mass Rapid Transit system, the third line to be competed, is inaugurated.
1999: Former Taiwan Governor James Soong, set to run as an independent in the year 2000 presidential race, names Chang Gung University President Chang Chao-hsiung as his running mate.
1999: The Cabinet approves an infrastructure assistance agreement between the Republic of China and the Balkan nation of Macedonia.
2000: Jacques Chaban-Delmas, French prime minister under President George Pompidou from 1969 to 1972, dies. He was a French resistance hero during World War II, becoming Gen. Charles de Gaulle's personal representative in occupied France in 1944.
2001: The World Trade Organization (WTO) at its ministerial meeting in Doha, Qatar unanimously approves Taiwan's applications for membership, ending its 12 years of efforts to be integrated into the world trade system.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The men of the present day cultivate their nobility of Heaven in order to seek for the nobility of man, and when they have obtained this, they throw away the other; their delusion is extreme. The issue is simply this: that they must lose that nobility of man as well."

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WELCOMES CHEN'S STATEMENT AT NSC MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 10(CNA) (By W.C. Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department on Wednesday welcomed the statement made by President Chen Shui-bian at an expanded National Security Council meeting in which he urged Beijing to resume cross-strait dialogue and proposed the establishment of a cross-strait military security consultation mechanism.
Chen said the mechanism could gradually become a cross-strait "code of conduct. He also suggested that Taipei and Beijing mark out a buffer zone in order to reduce tensions between the two sides.

The State Department said in a statement released Wednesday evening that Chen's statement lays foundations for progress and offers some creative ideas for reducing tensions and resuming cross-strait dialogue.
"We urge both sides to take this opportunity to engage in dialogue in order to resolve their differences peacefully, " the department said.

Saying that the United States will not change its cross-strait policies, the department reiterated that Washington is firmly committed to its "one China" policy, the three joint communiques and its responsibilities under the Taiwan Relations Act, and that it does not support Taiwan independence and opposes any move by either side of the Taiwan Strait to unilaterally change the status quo.

"We have long maintained that differences between China and Taiwan are matters to be resolved peacefully by the people on both sides of the strait, absent of the threat or use of force, and should be accepted by the people on both sides, " it also said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ROCKED BY QUAKE AGAIN

TEXT.P: A magnitude 6.0 earthquake rocked eastern Taiwan at 10: 16 a.m. Thursday, about 12 hours after a magnitude 5.5 temblor hit in an adjacent area, the Seismology Center of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported.

The epicenter of Thursday's quake was located 46.8 kilometers southeast of the eastern township of Suao, Ilan County, at a depth of 13.9 kilometers beneath the surface of the sea, CWB seismologists said.

It was the largest aftershock so far of the magnitude 6.7 earthquake that occurred at 11: 54 p.m. Monday night. The epicenter of that quake was located 96.6 kilometers east of the eastern city of Hualien and 10 kilometers under the seabed, according to the center.

Thursday's quake, the third major temblor in three days in the Taiwan area, was felt in most parts of the island. It had an intensity of 4 in Ilan and Hualien counties; 3 in Ilan City and the north-central county of Yunlin; 2 in Taipei City in the north, Chiayi City in the south and Taitung City in the east, the seismologists reported.
No casualties or damage had been reported anywhere around the country as of noon.

On Monday night, the seismology center's computers misread the magnitude 6.7 earthquake due to two quakes occurring four seconds apart, marking a rare computer reading mistake. The center initially reported that the quake had a magnitude of 5.7, but then corrected its mistake about an hour later.

A magnitude 7.0 earthquake rattled eastern Taiwan on Oct. 15. It was the strongest to shake Taiwan since the deadly magnitude 7.6 earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999. However, the quake didn't cause any major injuries or damage because its epicenter was located well below sea level and far out to sea.

The 921 earthquake, the deadliest in five decades in Taiwan, killed 2,415 people and injured more than 10,000 others. Some 100,000 residents were displaced in the quake, and damage to property was immeasurable.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU OPPOSES COMPENSATION FOR DROWNED ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) caucus in the Legislative Yuan on Thursday said that it opposes the decision to provide compensation to the families of drowned illegal mainland immigrants, saying that there is no need to do so.

The TSU, an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), was responding to a Taichung High Administrative Court ruling Tuesday that the Miaoli Prosecutor's Office should provide compensation to the families of eight illegal mainland citizens who were thrown overboard by "snakeheads" off the shore of Tunghsiao, Miaoli, in August 2003, after the snakeheads spotted a coast guard cutter approaching.
Huang Chung-yuan, TSU whip in the legislature, said the party regrets the court's "unreasonable" ruling.

Noting that illegal mainland immigrants are given good treatment in Taiwan's detention centers if they are caught, Huang said providing compensation for those who drown while attempting to enter Taiwan is tantamount to encouraging illegal immigration.
TSU Legislator Chen Chien-ming said that it is unreasonable for illegal mainland immigrants to receive the protection of the crime victims.

Chen noted that Taiwan people have been killed in mainland China and that their families have never received compensation from the mainland Chinese government, saying that the Taiwan government has no obligation to provide compensation to the drowned illegal mainland immigrants.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HELP TRAIN MONGOLIAN BUSINESS ELITE

TEXT.P: Fifteen members of Mongolia's business elite are coming to Taiwan shortly to receive two weeks of intensive training under the joint auspices of Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), MOFA sources reported Thursday.

The 15 Mongolians, all owners or executive managers of small or medium-sized enterprises in Mongolia, will be in Taipei from Nov. 24 to Dec. 6 to receive training to be sponsored by the International Cooperation and Development Fund run by the MOFA, according to Lin Chin-chung, deputy director of the MOFA's Department of West Asian Affairs.

They will attend lectures on business management, financial management, business creativity, as well as business research and development. They are also scheduled to take field trips to several small and medium-sized enterprises and factories around Taiwan, Lin said.

This will mark the first program that Taiwan carries out in collaboration with the London-based EBRD in terms of benefiting Mongolia and other needy nations since the MOFA signed two pacts with the European banking conglomerate in May 2003.

Tien Hung-mao, Taiwan's representative to the United Kingdom, and Jean Lemierre, president of the EBRD, inked the agreement in Tashkent, capital of Uzbekistan, on the eve of the EBRD's annual meeting held May 4-5, 2003, to provide more funds as a long-term donor to EBRD operations that help 28 countries in Central and Eastern Europe and Central Asia to develop free market economies.

Under the Replenishment Agreement, Taiwan pledges to donate an extra US$1 million to the EBRD's technical cooperation programs. Taiwan is the largest non-member donor to the EBRD's technical cooperation funds.
The second agreement commits Taiwan to contribute 1 million euros (US$1.29 million) to a Mongolia Cooperation Fund that will be used solely to help Mongolia develop private enterprises.

Taiwan, officially known as "Taipei China" to the bank, then formed a supervisory board with three other donors -- Japan, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. The board will meet twice a year to review past performance and determine new project priorities.

In an interview with a CNA correspondent in London in May 2003, EBRD President Lemierre said that his bank has enjoyed significant support from Taiwan for both technical cooperation and official co-financing over the past 12 years.
"We are pleased to see this support continuing, especially as our work moves into countries in Central Asia," he said.

Lemierre also said that Taiwanese companies interested in increasing their investments in Central and Eastern Europe are encouraged to discuss their needs in the areas of trade facilitation and project financing with the EBRD.

Meanwhile, Tien told CNA that Taiwan and Mongolia set up representative offices in each other's capital in early 2003, and that the contribution of 1 million euros to the Mongolia Cooperation Fund demonstrates that Taiwan attaches great importance to its relationship with Mongolia.

According to Tien, since Taiwan made its initial contribution of US$10 million to the EBRD in 1991, followed by subsequent donations, the funds have been used to help many countries in Central and Eastern Europe as well as those of the Commonwealth of Independent States in their transition to market economies. A small portion of the funds has been set aside to allow the EBRD to recruit Taiwanese experts to assist in its operations.

The EBRD is owned by 62 shareholders -- 60 countries plus the European Investment Bank and the European Community. The bank was founded after the collapse of Communist regimes in Central and Eastern European countries in 1991 to help these countries to change from centrally planned economies to market economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO LAUNCH PUBLICITY CAMPAIGN AT APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan will launch a series of publicity campaigns at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum summit in Santiago, Chile later this month, the head of the Government Information Office (GIO) said Thursday.
GIO Director-General Lin Chia-lung made the remarks when he presided over a presentation ceremony of local and foreign audio and video works to promote Taiwan.
The series of publicity campaigns will have "Taiwan Stands Tall" as its theme, with an aim of projecting the image of Taiwan progress to the participants of the APEC summit, Lin said.

He noted that the Taipei 101 skyscraper -- currently the tallest building in the world -- will also be included in the publicity campaign, with the hope of underscoring the ambition of Taiwan and its relentless efforts toward new peaks.
The ads will be placed in subway stations and local newspapers in Santiago, Lin said.

During the ceremony, a 14-minute film to introduce the nation, titled "Taiwan -- Where Mountains Meet the Sea, " made its debut, which Lin said would serve as the forerunner of the nation's drive to promote high-definition digital TV with "completely digital by 2010" as the ultimate goal.

He also announced the kicking off of an international publicity drive to promote Taiwan strategically, including the unveiling of the CIS (corporate identity system), slogan, and the launching of a national image Web page at the end of the year. In addition, there will be six advertisements published in international newspapers and magazines between February and June 2005, he said.

The GIO will also prepare four commercials to be aired on CNN, ABC and BBC, as well as conduct public surveys in the United States, Europe, Japan and Southeast Asia and promote Taiwan according to the survey results in the various regions, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS SUPPORT TO JOIN SUB-GROUP OF WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Nov. 10 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's bid to enter the World Health Organization's International Health Regulations (IHR) has the support of several of its diplomatic allies, the United States and other countries, although mainland China still opposes the island's inclusion.

WHO member states are currently in a two-week inter-governmental session that began Nov. 1 to revise the IHR. The hope is to bring the regulations up to date and increase controls on the international spread of infectious diseases.

During the first few days of the meetings, both Taiwan's allies and the United States voiced "implied support" for Taiwan's inclusion in the world health community and in the IHR after revisions to the regulations.

A health source in Geneva has said that Nicaragua delegates to the meetings proposed to revise Article 65 of the current IHR regulations related to the participation of non-members of the WHO, saying that the article should include those territories that have the ability to add to the knowledge pool in health-related matters and that can take on IHR affairs in the same manner as official WHO members.

The proposal was supported by 16 of the Republic of China on Taiwan's diplomatic allies. The United States also sided with Taiwan. The 25-member European Union and Canada emphasized the principle of universality, although they did not make public their stance on the proposal.

However, mainland China and its supporters strongly opposed Nicaragua's proposal at the meetings, pointing out that the territory's concept does not have the proper legal status to join since the WHO is an inter-governmental organization and the IHR is a convention among nations.

The differences between the two camps on the proposal could not be resolved during the meetings, so the chairman of the panel discussions decided Wednesday to shelve the issue pending future discussions.

Shen Lyu-shun, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Geneva, said that the development at the meetings is encouraging and that many countries have paid heed to the principle of universality, which Taiwan has always emphasized.

Analyzing views expressed by WHO members at the meetings, he said that 42 members voiced their support for Taiwan's bid to be included in the IHR, while only 16 members backed mainland China's stance, demonstrating that "the justification and necessity" of the bid cannot be denied.

Shen also said that there is room for Taiwan to make further efforts to push for its inclusion in the IHR, adding that no WHO member can unilaterally deny Taiwan's bid to be included in the IHR because the issue has drawn attention from many WHO members.
Taiwan has failed to become an observer of the WHA, the WHO's highest decision-making body, despite years of efforts.
It is expected that WHO members will hold additional meetings next year to further discuss the IHR revisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TAPS DPP SECRETARY-GENERAL AS NEXT LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian addressed ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung as "the next speaker of the Legislative Yuan" Thursday at a campaign event and appealed for the nation's support to make the DPP the majority party after the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

On the first stop of a tour to promote candidates in his capacity as DPP chairman, President Chen said that only when the DPP becomes the majority in the legislature and the Legislative Yuan speaker is a DPP member can the administration have a free hand to answer its calling.
Chen began the DPP campaigning at Taipei's Lungshan Temple by offering incense to call for a landslide victory for the ruling DPP in the upcoming legislative elections.
Chen said that he will attend all 50 campaign events scheduled during the next 30 days to back the DPP's candidates.
The DPP is fielding 10 candidates in Taipei City, an area of intense competition.
Chang Chun-hsiung, formerly a premier after serving as a DPP legislator for six terms, has been tapped to be a DPP legislator-at-large candidate. He is ranked first on a list of at-large candidates.
In a brief interview with the Central News Agency, Chang disclosed that President Chen talked to him in July about the feasibility of his being elected speaker of the next legislature.

Chang said he has taken up the task with honor and will try his utmost to enable the DPP to win up to 100 seats in the 225-seat legislature, and along with its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union, hold over 50 percent of the seats.

Once he is elected speaker, Chang said, he will first work to have the Legislative Yuan's notorious "black-gold" (violence and corruption) umbrella removed to restore the dignity and image of the nation's legislative system.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT URGES SECOND WAVE OF 'MOVING EASTWARD' POLICY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged Taiwan's industrial sector to embark on a "second-wave of moving eastward, " and this time eyeing the whole world.
Lu made the remarks when she addressed the 58th Industry Day celebrations sponsored by the Chinese National Federation of Industries.

The vice president said that thanks to the efforts of the industry, Taiwan has weathered economic sluggishness and created economic growth again in a few years, showing that though "Taiwan is small geographically, it can still shine globally."
She said that between the 1970s and the 1990s, Taiwan was promoting an "eastward" policy, seeking development in Europe and the United States.

But since the 1990s, cross-strait relations have become too close with Taiwan investors flocking westwards toward mainland China, she said. Though both sides share the same language and same culture, the exchanges are actually bad for Taiwan, citing the example of the hollowing-out of Taiwan industrial sector.

Also, though there are advantages in investing on the mainland, there are potential problems such as the unstable society, Beijing's animosity toward Taiwan and missiles targeting the island, Lu said.

She urged people to think twice before jumping on the investment wagon on the mainland, saying that at a time of globalization, Taiwan needs to embark on a second wave of moving eastward -- targeting the world this time.
The vice president, who is scheduled to visit Latin America next February, also took the opportunity to invite industrial leaders to go with her to inspect the investment environment there.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 73.97 points to close at 5,874.52.

The bourse opened at 5,919.77 and fluctuated between 5,931.37 and 5,873.28 during the day's trading. A total of 2.24 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$45.81 billion (US$1.38 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 1.7 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.5 percent, construction issues and banking and financial shares both at 1.4 percent, cement stocks at 0.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.4 percent, textile stocks at 0.3 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 512 to 132, with 132 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LUKEWARM OVER PRESIDENT'S LATEST CROSS-STRAIT OVERTURE

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) gave a cool reception to President Chen Shui-bian's latest peace overture to mainland China.

President Chen elaborated on 10 points at a meeting Wednesday with his senior advisors, which included the call for the creation of a cross-strait military buffer zone, the promise of not developing weapons of mass destruction, and establishing a military consultation mechanism that would lead to the creation of a cross-strait "code of conduct."
Huang Teh-fu, KMT whip in the Legislative Yuan called the 10 points "just another of many election gambits" of the president.
Huang noted that since the president invariably extends an olive branch to China before elections, but acts differently afterward, the KMT "will now listen to his words and observe his deeds."

He noted that President Chen has advocated "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait, " writing a new constitution, and joining hands with the opposition to form a committee for cross-strait peace and development, but at the same time has lashed out at the opposition for buying into mainland China's rhetoric.
"President Chen is playing a double-handed strategy to win votes in the Dec. 11 legislative elections," Huang said.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said that President Chen's advocacy of establishing a cross-strait military consultation mechanism is "not a bad idea."

However, to resolve cross-strait disputes, the president shouldn't be in a rush to take action before the year-end elections, but should display a persistent sincerity in striving for an improvement in cross-strait relations.

The president's idea "might not be very feasible" at the moment, the mayor said, adding that President Chen should first display enough sincerity over a longer period of time, and then extend his goodwill in a gradual manner.

Meanwhile, James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP), commenting on President Chen's proposal that he would organize a cross-strait peace and development committee after the legislative elections and could invite an opposition leader to head the committee, said that this statement was made due to pressure from the United States.

Soong criticized President Chen for "wavering" and for doing differently from what he said earlier, pointing out that President Chen advocated writing a new constitution only recently, and is now advocating a cross-strait peace and development committee.
If the president is indeed sincere, he should support a cross-strait peaceful development bill proposed by the PFP, Soong said.

The Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the ruling DPP, said that cross-strait relations should be based on equality, reciprocity, security and dignity, especially the establishment of a military buffer zone, which must be based on mutual trust. If the development of cross-strait relations violates these four principles, the TSU will vehemently oppose it.

TSU Legislator Chen Chien-ming also said that the TSU will not oppose the idea of an opposition leader serving as the head of the proposed cross-strait peace committee, but the premise must be that the "pan- green camp" of the DPP and the TSU will hold over half of the 225 seats in the new legislature after the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: GENOME-BASED RESEARCH TO SPUR FRESH TECHNO REVOLUTION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Genome-based biotechnological research will be the prime mover for a fresh round of technological innovation and economic development for Taiwan in the 21st century, President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday.

Addressing the opening of the Genomics Research Center (GRC) building of the Academia Sinica, Chen pointed out that the booming semiconductor, IT and imaging industries in Taiwan have boosted the island's technological development and economic growth over the past two decades.
"In the 21st century, genome-based biotechnological research will play a crucial role in motivating the next technological revolution and economic growth in Taiwan," Chen said.
Chen said the opening of the GRC building symbolizes a major advance for Taiwan in the field of life science research.

The GRC and the top-end research team of the Academia Sinica will become the "bullet train" of Taiwan's biotechnology sector, which will fuel the momentum of Taiwan's development and steer the country's biotechnology sector toward the leading position in the world, Chen said.

The GRC is one of the core projects in the "national-level genomic medicine program" launched by the government in 2002 and will provide a technological platform for Taiwan's biotechnology industry, Chen noted.

The establishment of the GRC will also help the government achieve the goals of attracting investment worth NT$150 billion (US$4.54 billion) in the sector in five years, seeing the founding of at least 500 biotech firms in 10 years, and developing Taiwan into the Asia-Pacific hub for bio-tech venture investment, research and development and operations, he added.
The GRC was founded in January 2003 and comprises such research areas as functional genomics, chemical biology, cellular and molecular medicine, and bioinformatics.
