DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF EXPOUNDS ON 'HK FORMULA' FOR CHARTER FLIGHT TALKS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu expounded on the formula used in signing the Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation agreement in June 2002 in preparation for negotiations on the opening of direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter cargo flights and Chinese New Year charter passenger flights.

Wu said the formula implies three basic principles -- shelving disputes without imposing any premises or prerequisites; resolving issues with mutual respect and pragmatism; being guided by the governments while enlisting private-sector assistance.

Wu's explanations came a day after President Chen Shui-bian directed relevant government agencies to actively promote the resumption of dialogue with Beijing on the basis of the bilateral meetings in Hong Kong in 1992. At the beginning, Chen went on, the two sides can negotiate the opening of two-way, non-stop cross-strait charter cargo flights and Chinese New Year charter passenger flights in line with the formula set forth in the 2002 Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation pact negotiations.

Under the formula, the Republic of China government authorized a non-governmental airline association to negotiate the aviation pact with Hong Kong, with officials from the MAC and the Civil Aeronautics Administration joining the talks as advisers to the association.

Wu said the MAC and other government agencies will follow the above-mentioned principles in pushing for opening of two-way, non-stop cross-strait charter cargo flights and charter passenger flights for the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday, which will run from Fe. 6, 2005 through Feb. 13.

The nation's top mainland policy planner further said the MAC will organize a seminar on cross-strait charter flight issues Friday, with the participation of government officials and industry executives.

"The seminar will serve as a platform for the government to exchange views with relevant industry representatives on direct cross-strait charter flight issues, " Wu said, adding that MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san will brief the press on technical details after the seminar.

Two mainland Chinese officials -- Li Xiaoyun, director of the Cross-Strait Economic and Technological Exchange Center under mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office, and Feng Chuozhe, president of Beijing's state-run Cross-Strait Travel Service, arrived in Taipei Wednesday for a private visit.

Reporters had speculated that Li and Feng are visiting Taiwan to discuss issues regarding the opening of direct cross-strait charter passenger flights during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday, as well as the opening of Taiwan to mainland Chinese tourists.
However, MAC officials said they have no plan for a meeting with the two mainland officials.

"We have no knowledge whether the two were authorized by Beijing to negotiate with Taiwan on possible cross-strait charter flights during the forthcoming Chinese New Year holiday and no meeting with the two has been scheduled, " MAC Vice Chairman Chiu said.

With Beijing's consent, Taiwan carriers operated special charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during the 2003 Chinese New Year period. The services were not offered during the 2004 Chinese New Year holiday because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers be allowed to also provide the same flight services while declining to negotiate the necessary technical details with Taiwan.
The ROC government said that as the opening of two-way, non-stop cross-strait charter flight services involves the exercise of public authority, prior negotiations are necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE OUT OF EVERY 3.7 PERSONS IN TAIWAN IS HAKKA: POLL

TEXT.P: One out of every 3.7 people in Taiwan is Hakka or of Hakka origin, constituting 26.9 percent of the entire Taiwan population, the Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs quoted a recent survey as indicating Thursday.

At a press conference publicizing the results of the latest census survey that the Council for Hakka Affairs has consigned a private poll company to conduct in recent months, council Chairman Lo Wen-chia said that the power of Hakka people in Taiwan is too big to be ignored.
Also speaking at the same occasion, Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan, herself a Hakka, said that the Hakka people are full of hope.
Lo said that there had not been a precise census of the number of the Hakka population in Taiwan before this survey.

Formerly, Lo said, it was reported by authorities that Taiwan had about 2.86 million Hakka people. But after conducting the survey this year of residents from 368 cities, counties and townships nationwide, it was found that the number of Hakka people and people of Hakka origin in Taiwan totals 6.08 million, representing 26.9 percent of the country's entire population, he added.
According to the survey, about 1.66 million people in Taiwan who have Hakka origin had not been considered as Hakkas. Of these people, many cannot speak any Hakka dialect.
Some 42.5 percent of the respondents said that only those people who are of Hakka origin and can speak Hakka dialect can be considered as Hakkas.

In addition, 85 percent of the Hakka people think that their mother tongue has increasingly lost ground in Taiwan due to a variety of reasons. About 72 percent of the Hakka people said they are proud to be Hakkas, although 46 percent of the Hakka people said that they would not take the initiative to tell their ethnical origin without prompting.

Hakka people, whose ancestors originated from central China more than 1,000 years ago, have been scattering around the world since the early 19th century due to their trademark characteristics of hard-work and perseverance.
Last year, three top political leaders in Taiwan discovered that they all have Hakka ancestors from the same area in today's Zhaoan County in the mainland Chinese province of Fujian.
After a series of activities heralding Hakka culture, President Chen Shui-bian had his ancestry traced back to the village of Baiye in Taiping Township, Zhaoan County.

According to the Chen clan family tree records, President Chen is a descendant of the first official dispatched by the Tang emperor to explore the southern lands during the Tang Dynasty (618-907 A.D.).
President Chen is the ninth generation offspring of Chen Wu (1739-1796) , the first Chen ancestor to cross the Taiwan Strait and settle in Taiwan, according to the Chen family tree.

Meanwhile, Vice President Annette Lu said in January 2003 that she is half Hakka as her ancestors on her mother's side came from Zhaoan, which is a well-known Hakka area. "Hakka" means "the guest people" in Mandarin Chinese.
The Hakka people were so defined during the Yuan Dynasty (1277-1367) when residents from central and north-central China fled to the south to escape famine and calamity.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun's ancestors have been traced to a village only some 12 kilometers from where the president's ancestors resided.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH LIKELY TO TOP 6% IN 2004: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan is likely to post economic growth of more than 6 percent this year as the economy continues to recover vigorously, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh predicted Thursday.
Ho made the forecast while delivering a keynote speech on "environmental trends and challenges faced by Taiwan's economy" during a seminar for small- and medium-sized businesses held in Taichung.
With the global economy revitalizing noticeably, the volume of global trade is expanding and sustaining the strong economic growth in the United States, Europe and Japan, Ho pointed out.
The economic recovery in Japan has also motivated regional growth in Asia including Taiwan, Ho said.

While the latest economic forecast released by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research shows that the country's economic growth could reach 5.9 percent this year, it is likely that the economy could perform even better and see a growth rate of over 6 percent, Ho said.
Export volume, meanwhile, is expected to hit a new high and amount to more than US$160 billion this year, she said.
Exports in the first 10 months to October have reached US$143.67 billion, which is close to the record high of US$148 billion registered in 2000, Ho noted.
She said small- and medium-sized businesses have always been an uplifting force in the development of Taiwan's economy and are now pushing Taiwan's industries toward higher performance.

To cope with the advent of the digital and knowledge-based segments of the economy, small- and medium-sized businesses need to adjust their marketing and operational models and enhance their research and development and innovation capabilities to break through the bottleneck of industrial development, Ho said.

The minister said Taiwan must continue to boost the development of such sectors as biomedics, wireless broadband networking, energy recycling, automobile parts and components, nanotechnology and knowledge-intensive services to maintain its international competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DECLINE ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market lost ground Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November declined 92 points to close at 5,868, with 29,323 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December dropped 82 points to finish at 5,870, with 2,309 contracts traded, while March futures fell 80 points to finish at 5,850, with eight contracts traded.
June futures gave up 51 points to close at 5,839 points, with two contracts traded, while September futures dropped 53 points to finish at 5,835, with only one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,960 for November, 5,952 for December, 5,930 for March, 5,890 for June and 5,888 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

November TE futures moved down 3.55 points to close at 216.3, with 4,561 contracts traded, while December TE futures fell 3.8 points to finish at 216.1, with 762 contract transactions and September TE futures lost 12 points to finish at 202.05, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

November TF futures lost 12.4 points to end at 1,036.8, with 6,027 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures gave up 10.8 points to close at 1,035.2, with 1,031 contracts traded and March TF futures dropped 12.6 points to close at 1,028.2, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION HEAD ENLISTS HELP IN SPREADING PLURALISTIC CULTURES

TEXT.P: Minister of the Education Tu Cheng-sheng on Thursday enlisted the assistance of foreign representative offices in Taiwan so that the thinking of pluralistic cultures can take root in Taiwan.
Tu made the appeal when he met with more than a score of representatives from foreign missions in Taiwan at a seminar on the establishment of a pluralistic culture society.

The education minister, himself an historian, noted that Taiwan was originally a pluralistic society, but under the rule of China since the Qing dynasty, it has formed a "single culture mentality, " in believing that only Chinese culture is "the orthodox one, " and didn't respect people from other cultures.
"I want to point out in sadness that there are a lot of laborers and foreign brides from Southeast Asian countries, and they have yet to receive sufficient respect in Taiwan society," Tu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY OF PEOPLE THINK ARMS PROCUREMENT TOO EXPENSIVE: KMT POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of people in Taiwan think the government's NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement from the United States is too expensive, and nearly 50 percent of the people believe the amount should be cut at least by half, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).
The survey was conducted by a private poll company at the KMT's commission from Nov. 5-6 on 1,073 people. It has a margin of error of 2.99 percent.

The results showed that 54.2 percent of the respondents think the amount of the procurement is too high, compared with 1.6 percent who think it is too low and 19.2 percent who think it is moderate. The remaining 25.1 percent said they have no opinion.
While 44.8 percent of the respondents agreed to the KMT's proposal to cut the amount by at least NT$300 billion, 29.7 percent disagreed, and 25.5 percent did not express any opinion.

Those who believe the amount should be slashed by more than NT$300 billion account for 36.1 percent, and 10.3 percent believe it should be reduced by less than NT$300 billion. The rest had no opinion.
Meanwhile, 23.5 percent of the respondents said the procurement budget should be removed completely, but 65.1 percent disagreed and 11.5 percent expressed no opinion.

Also, 35.6 percent of the respondents said the Legislative Yuan should start reviewing the "major arms procurement bill" before the Dec. 11 legislative elections, compared with 36 percent who said it should start after the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIALOGUE NEEDED TO SOLVE CROSS-STRAIT DISPUTES: INDIAN EX-MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taipei, Nov. 11 (CAN) Former Indian Defense Minister George Fernandes sees cross-Taiwan Straits disputes basically as political issues that need to be solved through dialogue. He added that India has no role to play in this process.

Fernandes, who arrived in Taipei Thursday for a three-day visit, said in an interview with CNA that any discussion of military cooperation between India and Taiwan is "not on the agenda, " dispelling Beijing's fears that his visit will lead to some sort of strategic cooperation between the island and his country.

There are three feasible areas of cooperation, though, among India, Taiwan and Japan, he said. He noted the three countries can form a "strategic alliance" in technological development, in addition to economic and cultural exchanges.

Fernandes, in his capacity as India's defense minister, visited China during the SARS outbreak last year. After meeting with top Chinese leaders, including Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, he found that economic development was China's top interest.
"They have a mission -- to become the No. 1 economy of the world by the year 2020, " he said, and the Chinese are "working in a very organized manner in that direction."

After stepping down from his Cabinet post in May, Fernandes, 74, has remained as the leader of the Janta Dal (United) Party. He is in Taipei to attend the India-Japan-Taiwan Trialogue Conference organized by Taiwan Thinktank. The conference will be held Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGE HAUL OF KETAMINE HIDDEN IN DVD PLAYERS SEIZED

TEXT.P: A man was arrested Thursday on charges of smuggling 10 kg of ketamine into Taiwan from Malaysia by concealing the drug in DVD players.

The man, identified as Hsieh Chung, was intercepted by law enforcement officers near the Tucheng intersection on the second freeway in northern Taiwan after he claimed the drugs from customs authorities at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport early in the morning.
The ketamine, which was wrapped in aluminum foil or carbon paper and then hidden in five "hollowed-out" DVD players, was delivered to CKS the previous evening.
Law enforcement officers uncovered the drug, worth an estimated NT$25 million in street value, and the five DVD players on Hsieh's car.
Aviation police said it marked the first time that contraband drugs have been delivered in such a way in an attempt to foil the airport inspection instruments.

Acting on a tipoff from intelligence sources, police said they had formed a surveillance team prior to the arrival of the drug. They added that they will track down Hsieh's accomplices, who were still at large.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVERAGE MONTHLY SALARY DOWN 5% FROM LAST YEAR: SURVEY

TEXT.P: People in Taiwan with five years of work experience receive an average salary of NT$30,207 (US$915) per month, down 5 percent from the same period last year, according to a survey unveiled Thursday.
The survey was conducted by www.1111.com.tw, an online human resources company via e-mail questionnaires, which gathered 5,217 effective samples with a margin of error of 1.3 percent.

The survey targeted those who have worked for five years and aged around 30, with the result showing that they receive a monthly payment of NT$30,207 on average, compared with a similar survey last year that showed NT$31,802 on average.
Yet, over half of those surveyed said that they could accept their current salary level, the poll found.
Although the average salary fell slightly, some sectors showed differing results, the survey said.

Average payments for those in industry and business counseling increased to NT$34,498 from NT$28,897 last year. Those who are in the tourism service sector, which the government has actively promoted in recent years, also have higher pay, with those in the restaurant, tourism and entertainment sectors receiving an average payment of NT$27,120 per month, an increase from NT$26,291 last year.

Officials from the online company said that lower unemployment rates have to do with job opportunities released by the government in the public service sector, which does not necessarily mean that the economy is recovering.

From the perspective of the business operators, even if the economy has rebounded, they are adopting a more conservative approach, the officials said, adding that overall, the wage structure is showing a downward adjustment trend.

Meanwhile, the survey also found that wages for men are about 1.3 times those for women, with men receiving average monthly pay of NT$34,544, compared with the average monthly pay of NT$26,517 for women.
With more people pursuing advanced studies, the survey also found that those who have higher degrees do receive higher pay.

The average monthly pay for those with college degrees is NT$30,389, while those who have masters degrees get NT$46,576 per month, and those who have doctoral degrees receive NT$78,931 on average, or 2.6 times the salary of college graduates. Comparatively, those who have only a high school education can only manage NT$25,865 per month.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON TAIWAN-JAPAN-INDIA COOPERATION TO OPEN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Experts from Taiwan, Japan and India will take part in a seminar Friday in Taipei on trade and economics, technology and democratic cooperation among the three nations, the sponsor of the event said Thursday.

Officials from the Taiwan Thinktank said that through the discussions at the seminar, to be presided over by Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng, it is hoped that Taiwan can explore the possibility of forging democratic alliances with Asian countries.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun will give a speech at the seminar's opening ceremony.

Notable among the participants is the head of the Indian delegation, Shri George Fernandes, a former Indian defense minister and a nine-term member of the Lok Sabha, or People's Assembly. Fernandes left his post in May after the coalition led by the Charatiya Janata Party lost a general election.
The Japanese delegation to the meeting will be headed by Yoshitomi Masaru, president and CRO of the Research Institute of Economy, Trade and Industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Yasir Arafat Dies at 75; No Successor Is Set.
Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, died early Thursday morning in a Paris hospital, a French military spokesman announced.
The Wall Stree Journal: Yasser Arafat Is Dead at 75.
Arafat died at 75 at a Paris hospital, ending a life embodying a dream of Palestinian statehood that is still distant. Parliament speaker Rauhi Fattouh was sworn in as temporary president until expected elections in 60 days. Egypt will host the funeral, and burial will be in Ramallah.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES MAINLAND CHINA INTERFERED WITH PRESIDENTIAL FLIGHT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) denied a newspaper report Thursday that mainland Chinese jet fighters locked their radar on a plane carrying President Chen Shui-bian during a flight over the Taiwan Strait in late September.
"The report is not factual, " the Office of Military Spokesman said in a press statement.

The report in a Chinese-language daily claimed that Chen's flight from Taipei to the outlying island of Penghu Sept. 27 was temporarily diverted because 28 mainland jet fighters were spotted in the area.

According to the report, the mainland warplanes, including Russian-made Sukhoi-27s and Sukhoi-30s, approached the sensitive center line of the 160 km-wide Taiwan Strait that separates Taiwan from mainland China. Chen's "Air Force One" pilots then altered their flight path to avoid the mainland jets, delaying Chen's arrival on Penghu by 15 minutes.
A similar incident occurred Oct. 2 when Vice President Annette Lu was flying to Penghu, according to the report.

The MND press statement said that mainland warplanes conducted training drills in airspace 11 nautical miles west of the center line of the Taiwan Strait on the morning of Sept. 27. By the time Chen flew to Penghu for an inspection tour that afternoon, the statement said, no mainland warplanes were spotted throughout the flight.

The statement also denied that mainland jet fighters were spotted during Lu's Oct. 2 flight to Penghu, saying that no mainland warplanes conducted training exercises or patrol missions near the demarcation line that day.
The statement further said the MND has consistently kept close tabs on mainland military activities.
The air force has also worked out comprehensive regulations to protect the top government leaders' flight safety, the press statement stressed.

The report came a day after Chen urged Beijing to agree to the creation of a military buffer zone -- an area that military aircraft and warships from both sides of the Taiwan Strait would not be allowed to enter. Chen also called for the formulation of a code of conduct so that their militaries can avoid incidents that could trigger a conflict as well as the establishment of a failsafe communications channel to avoid military miscalculations from either side.

Chen made the appeals at the end of a high-level national security meeting to discuss measures to cope with the delicate triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations in the wake of the U.S. presidential election as well as how to kick-start the long-stalled dialogue across the Taiwan Strait and promote cross-strait engagements on an equal and reciprocal basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S ADVANCE TOWARD 'SECOND ISLAND CHAIN' INEVITABLE: LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: It is an "inevitable trend" that the mainland Chinese navy might advance toward the "second island chain" after breaking through the first, as it is developing itself into a pelagic force from a coastal one, legislators said Thursday.

They were commenting on reports that a suspected mainland nuclear submarine entered Japan's territorial waters Wednesday near Okinawa's Sakishima island chain, which lies close to the disputed Tiaoyutai islands.
Some analysts say the move, if true, would mean the mainland's breakthrough of the "first island chain, " which refers to the defense line made up of Japan, Okinawa, Taiwan and the Philippines.
The "second island chain" refers to the defense line linking Japan and Guam.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lee Wen-chung, who heads the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee, said it is a long-term strategic goal of the mainland to continue to attempt to break through the "second island chain" while it modernizes its navy in the direction of building up its pelagic defense capabilities.
As an outpost of the defense lines formed by the United States-Japan military alliance, the Taiwan Strait is also one of the main points the mainland is trying to break through, according to Lee.
He claimed that Taiwan and the United States now maintain what he called a "quasi-military alliance" relationship and will work more closely in the future.
This is the reason why the Taiwan Strait has been included in the U.S.-Japan security treaty and why the United States has supplied defensive weapons to Taiwan, Lee said.

Opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang, another member of the committee, said it is difficult to determine if the submarine belongs to the mainland because a number of countries have sent submarines to the area.
Lin said it is an unavoidable development for the mainland to become a superpower, but he said this does not necessarily mean the mainland will attack Taiwan.

By claiming to be a member of the U.S.-Japan military alliance and even engaging in an arms race with the mainland, Taiwan is likely to provoke Beijing and accelerate the outbreak of a war across the Taiwan Strait, Lin warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CHANGE IN ROC-VANUATU DIPLOMATIC TIES: MOFA

TEXT.P: Diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and the South Pacific island nation of Vanuatu remain unchanged, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks after mainland Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Zhang Qiyue claimed at a news conference earlier in the day that Vanuatu's Cabinet "has made the decision to revoke the so-called communique on the establishment of diplomatic relations between Vanuatu and Taiwan."

Zhang's claim does not represent the Vanuatu government's stance, Lu said, adding that Vanuatu Prime Minister Serge Vohor sent a message to the MOFA Tuesday reaffirming the validity of the joint communique he signed with Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen in Taipei Nov. 3 on the establishment of full-fledged diplomatic ties between the two countries.
"Vohor assured us in his letter that he had singed the communique on behalf of the Vanuatu government and people," Lu said.
Through MOFA's verification, Lu said, the mainland spokeswoman's claim was not based on any announcement issued by the Vanuatu government.

Lu said Vohor did not attend Wednesday's Cabinet meeting because he is not in Vanuatu's capital. "He is staying in his home town on an outlying island, and Wednesday's meeting was chaired by Vanuatu's deputy prime minister," Lu said.

According to Lu, Vohor telephoned the MOFA earlier in the day to say that some members of his Cabinet have differing opinions on his decision to switch diplomatic recognition from Beijing to Taipei. "But Vohor assured us that he will continue to communicate with them in order to win their support for his decision," Lu explained.

He further said the Vanuatu Cabinet mainly discussed budget issues at Wednesday's meeting. "Although the Vanuatu Cabinet did discuss issues regarding the establishment of diplomatic ties with the ROC, it remained unclear whether any conclusion had been reached at the meeting. The MOFA is still trying to get a better understanding of relevant developments," he added.
Meanwhile, Chen said he understands that Beijing will try every possible means to force Vanuatu to revoke its diplomatic ties with the ROC.
"Nevertheless, we are confident that our ties with Vanuatu will not change. Vohor has repeatedly assured us that his government will uphold its commitment to Taiwan," Chen said.
With a population of about 200,000, Vanuatu lies 2,250 km northeast of Sydney, Australia. It is the ROC's 27th diplomatic ally.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. STATE DEPARTMENT REAFFIRMS NO CHANGE IN 'SIX ASSURANCES'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 10 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department reaffirmed Wednesday that its policy and "Six Assurances" toward Taiwan remain unchanged.

State Department Spokesman Richard Boucher was asked during a daily news briefing about the U.S. position on the status of the 1982 "Six Assurances" on Taiwan policy. "Specifically, is the one pertaining to sovereignty still valid?" a reporter asked Boucher.
Boucher did not answer the question immediately, but written answers were posted on the State Department Web site that evening.
The answer reads: "There is no change in U.S. policy, including regarding the Six Assurances.

"The United States remains firmly committed to our 'one China' policy, the three joint communiques, and our responsibilities under the Taiwan Relations Act. We oppose attempts by either side to unilaterally alter the status quo. We do not support Taiwan independence.

"We have long maintained that differences between the People's Republic of China and Taiwan are matters to be resolved peacefully, absent the threat or use of force, and should be acceptable to the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait."

The Reagan administration offered the "Six Assurances" to Taiwan after it signed a joint communique Aug. 17, 1982 with mainland China over issues concerning arms sales to Taiwan. The "Six Assurances" were conveyed by James Lilley, then-director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan, to then-ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo in verbal form.

The "Six Assurances" include that the United States will not set a date for ending arms sales to Taiwan, will not hold prior consultations with Beijing on arms sales to Taiwan, will not play any mediation role between Taiwan and Beijing, will not revise the Taiwan Relations Act, will not alter its position regarding sovereignty over Taiwan, and will not exert pressure on Taiwan to enter into negotiations with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN SPOUSES SHOULD BE WARNED ABOUT HEPATITIS B: HEPATOLOGIST

TEXT.P: Foreign spouses of Taiwan citizens should be taught about the dangers of hepatitis B and how to avoid infection, a hepatologist warned Thursday.

Chang Mei-hui, president of the Taiwanese Association for the Study of Liver Disease, said Taiwan has cut down the prevalence of Hepatitis B to 1 percent thanks to a program of screening pregnant women for the disease and a program to inoculate all infants.

However, Chang said, most Taiwanese spouses, especially those from Southeast Asia, where hepatitis B is not as common as in Taiwan, are ignorant of the disease. They have neither been tested for the disease nor have they been taught about ways to protect themselves and their offspring from the disease.
Chang urged the government to start a program to raise the awareness of foreign spouses of hepatitis B.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ UNVEILS NEW TV COMMERCIAL AGAINST VOTE-BUYING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) unveiled a new TV commercial Thursday to warn against vote-buying in the run-up to the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

At a ceremony to launch the commercial, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan dressed up as Pao Ching-tien, a legendary judge in ancient China known for his integrity and competence in bringing criminals to justice, to signify his determination to fight vote-buying.
He warned grassroots campaign workers not to bribe voters on behalf of any candidate, saying the government has formed a special investigative team to crack down on any vote-buying deals.
The minister also called on the general public to reject bribery and to cooperate with the government to root out the corrupt practice.
"Whoever manages to provide useful leads or clues that result in conviction of any vote-buying case will be offered lucrative rewards," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATIVE CAMPAIGN FOCUSES ON THREE ISSUES

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) legislative campaign will focus on the issues of finance, defense and surveillance of the government, KMT Vice Chairman Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday.
The KMT candidates will raise the three issues simultaneously about two or three weeks before election day and will spell out the party's position on them.

One day after President Chen Shui-bian unveiled a plan to cut down the period of compulsory military service and build trust between Taiwan and mainland China, Wang said his party will respond with a new defense policy, the contents of which are still being studied.
Wang said the KMT will train its attack of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on finance, which the opposition claims is worsening under the DPP.

Claiming that the DPP has dried up the country's coffers, sold stocks in state enterprises at a loss and left them in the hands of unqualified managers, Wang said these have eluded public scrutiny and should be addressed.

Citing a decision made by the Ministry of Education Wednesday to separate the history of Taiwan from that of mainland China in textbooks, Wang said it is yet more evidence of the Executive Yuan's attempt to get around the Legislative Yuan and drives home the importance of having the legislature controlled by the opposition when the four other branches of government are controlled by the DPP.
Wang said the KMT will come up with a comprehensive position paper on the three issues in the leadup to the Dec. 11 election.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER: DPP WILL NOT IMPOSE OWN THOUGHTS ON EDUCATION POLICY

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday the ruling Democratic Progressive Party will not impose its own thoughts on education policy, in an attempt to calm down a dispute prompted by a draft guideline prepared by the Ministry of Education (MOE) to separate the history of Taiwan from that of China in hight school textbooks.

Quoting President Chen Shui-bian as saying that the Republic of China is Taiwan and Taiwan is the Republic of China, the premier said there is no question about the fact that the ROC is a sovereign state.
As premier, Yu said, he will do his utmost to defend the sovereignty of the ROC.

As to the MOE's draft guideline, the premier said it is only a set of proposals for the compilation of history textbooks and is subject to change after public discussion. He added that the DPP will not meddle with the preparation of the guidelines.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INVITES ARATS CHAIRMAN TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian invited Friday mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Wang Daohan to visit Taiwan.

According to a press release issued by the Presidential Office, Chen extended the invitation when he visited Koo Cheng-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , at the Cheng Hsin Medical Center in Taipei.
Chen said that he hopes Koo and Wang will meet again based on their meeting in Singapore in 1993 to make more contribution to the promotion of the cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Nov. 12, or the first day of the tenth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1847: James Simpson, professor of midwifery at the University of Edinburgh, gives the first public demonstration of his new anesthetic.
1866: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founding father of the Republic of China, is born in mainland China's Kuangtung (Guangdong) Province.
1920: The first and second volumes of the "General History of Taiwan," authored by Lien Heng, are published.
1921: A nine-nation disarmament conference is held in Washington among the Republic of China, the United States, Britain, France, Japan, Italy, Holland, Portugal and Belgium.
1927: Josef Stalin becomes undisputed ruler in Russia after Leon trotsky is expelled from the Communist Party.
1944: The Tirpitz, sister ship of the Bismarck and the last of the major German battleships, is sunk by British bombers at Tromso Fjord in northern Norway.
1948: Seven Japanese war criminals, including Hideki Tojo, Japan's wartime prime minister, are sentenced to death by an international court martial.
1964: The African nation of Dahomey forges diplomatic ties with Beijing.
1965: President Philibert Tsiranana of Malagasy (now called Madagascar) visits the Republic of China.
1966: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek dedicates the newly completed Chinese Cultural Hall of the Chung Shan Building at Yangmingshan on the 100th birthday of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, and designates Nov. 12 "Chinese Cultural Renaissance Day."
1968: The United Nations General Assembly vots against admission of Communist China.
1969: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with the African nation of Gambia.
1969: Former mainland Chinese president Liu Shaoqi dies at the age of 71.
1970: A cyclone and tidal wave hits East Pakistan, killing more than 200,000 people.
1972: The 27th Junior Chamber International World Congress opens its eight-day meeting in Taipei with 2,000 delegates from 47 countries and areas participating.
1972: The ROC wins the World Cup Golf Championship in Melbourne.
1973: China Shipbuilding Corp. of the ROC signs a contract with Gatx-Oswego Corp. of the United States to build four 450,000-ton oil tankers.
1984: Taiwan's public security authorities launch the first stage of an all-out crackdown on underworld figures.
1990: Akihito ascends the throne to become Japan's emperor.
1993: Two mainland Chinese hijack a Northern Airlines MD-82 jetliner to Taiwan.
1996: An Indian passenger plane collides with a cargo plane, killing 349 people.
1997: A federal jury convicts Ramzi Ahmed Yousef of masterminding the 1993 World Trade Center bombinh in New York.
1999: Four members of the banned Falun Gong are convicted and sentenced to prison terms of up to 12 years, the first of what is expected to be a series of prosecutions against the exercise and meditation group termed by Beijing as an "evil cult."
1999: Braving drizzling rain, some 3,961 pairs of twins gather in front of Taipei City Hall to break the world record for group of twins gather together at one time.
1999: The Republic of China and Guatemala sign an agreement to promote economic cooperation between the two nations.
2000: The Tu-154, a Russian airliner with 58 passengers and crew, is seized by "armed terrorists" and demanded that it fly to Israel.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian meets with renowned British primatologist Jane Goodall and at her urging pledges to refrain from releasing balloons at future celebratory events out of respect for other living things.
2001: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung approves the nomination of Wang Chen-chih, known in Japan as Sadaharu Oh, as the Republic of China Ambassador-at-large for sports, as had been proposed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
Mencius' lesson of the day: "To desire to be what is considered honorable is the common mind of men. And all men have what is (truly) honorable in themselves; only they do not think of it."

The death of Yasser Arafat, symbol of the Palestinian people's four-decade struggle for statehood, has plunged the Middle East into a new era of uncertainty.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Arafat dies of illness.
The announcement of the 75-year-old Palestinian President Yasser Arafat's passing yesterday ended days of confusion over his fate as he lay comatose under a shroud of secrecy in a Paris hospital. Doctors would not reveal the cause of death.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ENVOY IN HONG KONG CALLS FOR INCREASED EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Nov. 12 (CNA) (By Lo Kin-fai and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative in Hong Kong on Friday called for the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government to let its staff members visit Taiwan more often to optimize private exchanges between the two sides.

Pao Cheng-kang, who assumed his Hong Kong post Oct. 18, said in an exclusive interview with the Sing Pao daily that Hong Kong and Taiwan can foster closer bilateral ties beginning in less-sensitive areas like the private sector.

Visits by lower-ranking Hong Kong civil servants to Taiwan could be a good start to better mutual understanding between the two sides and to pave the way for closer ties, said Pao, whose official title is managing director of the Chung Hwa Travel Service in Hong Kong.
Pao reiterated that the mutual trust and genuine desire for better ties fostered by Hong Kong and Taiwan would lay the groundwork for closer exchanges between the two sides.

In fact, Pao said, Hong Kong and Taiwan benefited from medical exchanges during the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome in early 2003, adding that the fact that it took a shorter period of time for him to get a work visa from the Hong Kong authorities than it took his predecessor is an indication that bilateral ties are improving.
Having Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa visit Taiwan is of course a distant wish, Pao said, adding that he will nevertheless work relentlessly toward that goal.

Pao was chief secretary of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) before being appointed Taiwan's representative in Hong Kong earlier this year. The MAC is the direct supervisory agency in charge of Chung Hwa Travel Service in Hong Kong.
MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san has recently called for the Hong Kong government to seriously consider setting up offices in Taiwan to promote bilateral ties.
A Hong Kong office in Taiwan would help provide better services to the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, Chiu said.

Noting that more than 230,000 Hong Kong visitors arrived in Taiwan in the first nine months of this year for sightseeing and business purposes, Chiu said that the number is nearly equal to that for the whole of last year, which he said demonstrates that exchanges between the two sides are increasing rapidly.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.K. PARLIAMENT PRO-TAIWAN GROUP BIDS FAREWELL TO OUTGOING ROC REP
DOC.DATELINE: London, Nov. 11 (CNA) (By N.K Han and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Members of the British-Taiwanese All-Party Parliamentary Group on Thursday bid farewell to outgoing Republic of China Representative to Britain Tien Hung-mao at a reception held at the House of Commons.
This is the first time that members of the British Parliament have held a farewell reception at the Parliament for an ROC envoy.

In addition to 18 members of Parliament, some 100 dignitaries, including members of diplomatic corps and international organizations, local business leaders, think tank experts, scholars, and leaders from the local Taiwanese community also attended the gathering.

The reception was jointly hosted by the group's co-chairmen, Thomas Cox and Sir Nicholas Winterton. Martin O'Neill, chairman of the House of Commons Trade and Industry Committee; Lord Faulkner of Worcester, vice chairman of the group; and two officials from the Foreign and Commonwealth Office, Denis Keefe and Rod Wye, also attended.

Praising Tien as an outstanding diplomat, Cox said during the reception that he and many of his colleagues in Parliament have always used "ambassador" as a title of respect to address the outgoing representative.

Tien's efforts have further strengthened relations between Taiwan and Britain, and Taiwan businesspeople's investment in Britain and the increasing trade exchanges between the two countries have also created employment opportunities for local people, Cox said, adding that they will always remember Tien's achievements during his tenure in London.

Sir Winterton also highly lauded Tien as "the most outstanding ROC representative to Britain" and said that although Taiwan has not obtained recognition, which he said it deserves to get, Tien has made the British people better understand that the ROC is a very important country in the international community and that the island's democratic development can be regarded as a model for many other Asian countries.

In order to express their respect to Tien, Winterton, on behalf five leading members of the group, presented a jointly-signed letter to him, in which they affirmed the representative as "the most respectable diplomat".

In response, Tien expressed his gratitude for the group's longstanding friendship with Taiwan, saying that the House of Commons has raised several motions over the past two-and-half years to voice its support for Taiwan, including affirming Taiwan's democratic achievements, supporting the island's bid to join the World Health Organization, and opposing a lifting of the European Union ban on arms sales to mainland China.

Meanwhile, Cox has already raised a motion in the House of Commons to request that it cite Tien's outstanding performance in enhancing the relationship between the two countries. The motion has so far been signed by 54 members of Parliament.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Palestinian leader Arafat dies at 75; former prtmier Mahmoud Abbas appointed new head of PLO.
Yasser Arafat, the guerrilla chieftain who juggled armed resistance and political diplomacy, died at age 75 Thursday in Paris, leaving a dual impression on the world. The iconic symbol of the Palestinian struggle for nationhood, and the embodiment of a revolutionary who could not make the transition to governance.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI DIABETES DEATHS QUADRUPLE IN 20 YEARS: HEALTH DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: Thirty-six out of every 100,000 residents in Taipei City died of diabetes mellitus last year, a ratio about four times higher than that recorded 22 years ago, when the ratio was nine out of every 100,000, the Taipei Department of Health (TDOH) reported Friday.
Diabetes ranked ninth among the 10 leading causes of death in Taipei City in 1981, but it has surged to fourth place since 1999, TDOH officials said.

According to TDOH tallies, a total of 946 people died of diabetes in Taipei city in 2003. Of the total, 84 percent were chronic diabetes patients aged over 65, and 14 percent were people aged between 45 and 64.
Although diabetes affects mainly older people, it is also a "lifestyle disease, " which can occur due to long-term rich diets and lack of exercise, the TDOH officials said.

Nationwide, a total of 10,013 people died of diabetes last year, marking a fatality rate of 44.38 out of every 100,000, or about 1.2 times higher than that of Taipei City. The figure would be 1.5 times if calculated under an age parity structure, in which Taipei City's diabetes fatality rate was 22.5 out of every 100,000, the officials said.
The ratio is the sixth lowest in the 21 cities and counties nationwide, only higher than that in Matsu, Kinmen, Taichung City, Chiayi City and Hsinchu City, in that order.
By comparison, Taipei City's diabetes fatality rate of 22.5 out of every 100,000 is still relatively much higher than Japan's 3.8, Hong Kong's 8.3 and Singapore's 10, the TDOH officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP UNVEILS 10-POINT CAMPAIGN PLATFORM FOR LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Friday unveiled a 10-point campaign guidelines for the year-end legislative elections in a bid to win support for its call of a clear majority for the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) in the new legislature.

DPP heavyweights, including Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, Vice Secretary-General Chung Chia-pin, Department of Culture and Information Director Tseng Wen-tsang, as well as Liang Wen-chieh, chief vice executive director of the Policy Research and Coordinating Committee, held a press conference to unveil the campaign outline.

In the outline, the DPP stresses that if the "pan-green camp" can obtain half of the seats in the Legislative Yuan in the Dec. 11 elections, then the opposition Kuomintang will not dare to disperse its "ill-gotten assets, " the umbrella to protect the corrupt "black gold" politics will be removed, the opposition will not dare to propose "money-pit" bills, referring to the scores of social welfare bills totaling NT$1.6 trillion (US$48.48 billion) , the compulsory military service period will be cut in half, and national security will be taken care of well.

Also, the number of elections in Taiwan as well as the number of major and minor public functionaries will be cut in half, the minefield of bad loans will be handled, the financial burden to families will be cut in half, and there will be no abuse in the development of national land.

DPP Secretary-General Chang noted that 2000 marked the first ever power transfer between different political parties at the national level in Taiwan's history. However, he added the transfer has yet to be completed after five years, mainly because the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party still holds a slight majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.

"This is why the DPP will make winning more than half of the seats in the legislature the main theme in its campaigning so as to have a complete transfer of power, " Chang said, adding that the DPP "will then take full responsibility for governing."

He noted that since the power transfer in 2000, the opposition has set its mind on boycotting instead of monitoring, which he said has resulted in low efficiency in the legislature and difficulties for the administration.

Tsai Huang-liang, DPP caucus whip in the legislature, speaking on the same occasion, said that the campaign outline is self-explanatory. In contrast, the opposition has only two focuses in its campaign, namely the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and opposing President Chen, he added.

"They are still in the quagmire of their March 20 presidential election loss, and they have yet to propose any substantial platform or outlook for the benefit of the nation and the people," Tsai added.

He also expressed worries that if the "pan-green camp" is unable to win a legislative majority, "it will be the end of Taiwan, " because "the 'pan-blue alliance' will pass its 'money-pit' bills which will lead to a collapse of the nation's finances.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S. Tries To Corner Fallujah Insurgents; Evidence of Guerrilla Atrocities Is Found.
U.S. forces pushed toward a corner of Fallujah where commanders said insurgents may be preparing to make a last stand, as soldiers and civilians uncovered evidence of atrocities committed by the foreign and Iraqi guerrillas who controlled the city for nearly seven months, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-GREEN' POLITICIANS FORM PRO-INDEPENDENCE UNITED FRONT

TEXT.P: A group of 66 legislative candidates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) have joined a "legislative united front" to promote a new constitution and a new name for the country, organizers said Friday.

Peter Wang, leader of the pro-independence Alliance to Campaign for Rectifying the Name of Taiwan, which initiated the drive, said the alliance will send a "Taiwan Republic" campaign mission to tour the island starting next week to drum up support for the politicians.
Former President Lee Teng-hui will also attend a rally promoting the foundation of the "Taiwan Republic, " which is set for Nov. 28 in Panchiao, Taipei County, Wang said.
Also Friday, the alliance released a "theme lamp" and the theme song "Beautiful Formosa" for yet another mass rally planned for the cause Feb. 28, 2005.
The lighting-up rally is expected to attract 1 million people around Taiwan, Wang said.

The alliance held a similar rally Feb. 28 this year in which more than 1 million people held hands to form a chain stretching from the northern tip to the southern tip of Taiwan, in a demonstration against the missile threat from mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP VOWS IMPARTIALITY IN OMBUDSMEN RECOMMENDATION

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday she will see to it that the new ombudsmen recommendation panel abides by the principles of openness, impartiality and fairness in recommending candidates for the Control Yuan seats.

Lu, who concurrently serves as convener of the new ombudsmen recommendation panel, made the remarks during a luncheon with incumbent Control Yuan members. Also present were other members of the recommendation panel.

The tenure of the current third-term Control Yuan members will expire Jan. 31, 2005. President Chen Shui-bian is expected to nominate 29 fourth-term Control Yuan members later this year. According to the present version of the Additional Articles of the Constitution, nominations for the Control Yuan require the consent of the Legislative Yuan.

In addition to appointing Lu as convener of the new ombudsmen recommendation panel, Chen also named five panelists to screen the qualifications of hopefuls recommended by various social or academic groups and come up with a list of qualified aspirants.

Noting that times have changed and that the political vision and ideology of the Democratic Progressive Party administration differs from the previous Kuomintang (KMT) administration, Lu said the recommendation panel will take into account "timing factors" in qualification screening.
Equally important is constitutional provisions, Lu said, adding that the screening panel will faithfully respect the Constitution in screening and recommending qualified candidates.

"We'll make every possible effort to ensure openness, transparency, impartiality and fairness in the procedure, " Lu said, adding that the panel's ultimate goal is to recommend those most qualified and suitable to serve in the Control Yuan, the nation's supreme watchdog body.

Lu further said she hopes the luncheon will provide a forum for her panelists to exchange views with incumbent Control Yuan members and thus gain a better understanding of the watchdog body's functions and its operating rules.

"As ombudsmen are responsible for correcting government officials at all levels and generally monitoring the government, they are often involved in investigating scandals and graft cases. I think all incumbent members are fully aware of the social changes, national evolution and personal traits needed to be a competent and outstanding ombudsman, " Lu said, adding that she welcomes the advice and opinions of the incumbent ombudsmen for the panel's reference.
As to how many incumbents will be recommended for another term, Lu said the panel has yet to consider this issue.

During the KMT era, a certain percentage of incumbents were retained for a second six-year term. The incumbent ombudsmen took office Feb. 1, 1999 when the KMT was still in power. With the DPP winning the presidency in 2000 and again in 2004, Lu said, the nation has entered a new era. "We could use a broader perspective in mulling the issue," she added.

Members of the panel include incumbent Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien and Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang, as well as Chang Chien-pang, a senior adviser to the president, Hsiao Hsin-huang, a national policy adviser to the president, and Nita Ing, chairwoman of Taiwan High-Speed Railway, who is also an adviser to the president. Chien has made clear that he will retire from public service after his current tenure expires.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 42.64 points to close at 5,917.16.
The bourse opened at 5,901.79 and fluctuated between 5,952.45 and 5,894.39 during trading. A total of 3.19 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$67.74 billion (US$2.05 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 1.6 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1 percent, machinery and electronics shares and foodstuff issues both at 0.8 percent, cement stocks at 0.5 percent, construction issues at 0.3 percent and paper and pulp issues at 0.1 percent.
Plastics and chemical shares moved down 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 364 to 216, with 200 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CORAL SOCIETY APPEALS FOR REMOVAL OF SHIP WRECKAGE

TEXT.P: Members of the Taiwanese Coral Reef Society environmental group appealed yet again Friday to government agencies not to let the "Amorgos" pollution case go any further and see to it that the undersea wreckage is removed at the earliest possible date.

Wreckage of the Amorgos, a Greek freighter that ran aground and sank off the coast of Kenting at the southernmost tip of Taiwan Jan. 14, 2001, is now "a slaughter hell" for coral in an area of Lungkeng off Kenting, said Cheng Ming-hsiu, Society chairman and a researcher with Academia Sinica's Institute of Zoology.
Since the freighter's sinking, its wreckage has continued to impair the growth of coral because of the sharp metal edges of the wreck, turning the area into a coral graveyard, Cheng claimed.
He added that after a series of observations, it has been found that in a 2 km by 500 meter coral reef area near Lungkeng, Kenting, coral coverage rate has continued to drop.

Contrary to previous speculation that the freighter's wreckage could become an undersea artificial fishery reef, he said, the ship has disintegrated in the strong currents and its debris has continued to spread, posing increasing threats to the coral.

The harmful debris will not disappear by itself and it cannot be "digested" by the sea, Cheng argued, adding that the only option is to have it removed before more coral, the ecological system and Taiwan's tourism resources are further compromised.
A similar situation has been found in an undersea area to the east of Green Island, where the freighter Picasso sank 12 years ago, Cheng said.
By comparison, he said, coral reefs near Penghu Island are found to be the most healthy, with coral coverage rate totaling nearly 100 percent.

The Amorgos, carrying 60,000 tons of iron ore, was heading for Nantong in mainland China from Singapore when it developed mechanical problems and began to drift. It ran aground 1.6 km off the coast of Oluanpi, Taiwan's southernmost tip, before sinking.
All 25 crew members were rescued, but the ship later broke in two and an estimated 1,150 tons of fuel oil gushed out of the vessel and blanketed coral reefs in the Oluanpi area.
The oil spill has blanketed coral reefs in the Oluanpi area, causing an ecological disaster that will take the sensitive ecosystem years from which to recover.
At least three officials were disciplined due to aftermath of that incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMPLE ROOM FOR TAIWAN, INDIA TO IMPROVE POLITICAL TIES

TEXT.P: There is ample room for Taiwan and India to bolster their political relations from a long-term perspective, a former Indian government adviser said in Taipei Friday.

Dr. Jagdish Shettigar, a leading economics and finance adviser to India's former BJP coalition government, suggested at a seminar that the authorities from the two countries begin with economic exchanges to eventually draw themselves together politically.

Noting that two-way trade between Taiwan and India totaled around US$1 billion in 2003, Shettigar said trade is expected to top US$2 billion this year, with the two countries' exchanges in information technology industry increasing by leaps and bounds.
He analyzed that high technology, the IT industry and food processing industry are the three most promising areas for Taiwan and India to further expand their cooperation in years to come.
Shettigar also expressed his hope that when thinking about relocating investment or business operations overseas, Taiwan investors should give India and Indian business partners more consideration.

He further pointed out that as both Taiwan and India are members of the World Trade Organization (WTO), the two countries should make the most of the WTO platform to optimize their partnership in trade and investment.
"After establishing solid ties and understanding in economy, the two countries will naturally become closer in political relations, " Shettigar claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' MARKS SUN YAT-SEN'S BIRTHDAY

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) paid tribute to Dr. Sun Yat-sen Friday to mark 139th anniversary of his birth, while a pro-independence party wanted to draw a line between Taiwan and the founding father of the Republic of China.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan said it is a historical fact that Sun led the 1911 uprising in Wuchang, leading to the collapse of the Ching dynasty and the inception of the Republic of China. This historical fact should not be distorted by the ideology of a few, he said.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who concurrently serves as a KMT Vice Chairman, led six KMT legislative candidates to Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei to bow before a bronze statue of the founding father.
Ma, who holds a doctorate in law from Harvard University, then delivered a speech on recent controversy about the legal status of Taiwan from a historical perspective.
The mayor said that Ching dynasty ceded Taiwan to Japan in the 1895 Treaty of Shimonoseke, but the world recognized that the Nationalist administration inherited the Ching dynasty.

The Shimonoseke treaty was rendered void because in a peace treaty signed between the Republic of China and Japan in Taipei in 1952, one year after signing of the San Francisco Peace Treaty, Japan promised that from Dec. 9, 1941, all treaties signed between the two countries were void, which included the Treaty of Shimonoseke, which Ma said clearly shows Taiwan's return to the Republic of China.

The 1943 Cairo Declaration -- in which leaders of the three Great Powers of Great Britain, the United States and China met regarding Japan -- also stipulated clearly that Japan must return the lands it had stolen, including Manchuria, Taiwan and Penghu, and that they must return to the Republic of China.

The KMT also sponsored an artifact exhibition of Dr. Sun Yat-sen at its party headquarters in Taipei. A pair of Sun's shoes were among the items on display, with the aim of conveying the message "tread the right path and Taiwan will find its way."
The KMT also planned the first ever Sun Yat-sen memorial library.
PFP Chairman James Soong also led party officials to the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall to pay tribute.

Soong criticised the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for ruling on "ideology, " which leads to a "crisis of the collapse of values in Taiwan." According to Soong, the DPP's claim that China is an enemy country has made Sun Yat-sen and the goddess Matsu "foreigners or enemies."

He was referring to recent controversy over Sun Yat-sen, whose relations with the ROC or Taiwan seem tenuous after a proposed change to the senior high school history curriculum, in which 1945, when the KMT administration took over Taiwan, will serve as a watershed point separating Taiwanese history and Chinese history, and the remarks of "multiple founding fathers" by some DPP officials who say all the martyrs who contributed to the birth of the ROC are the founding fathers.
After the ceremony, several PFP legislators took banners and trumpets to the Presidential Office to express their discontent over the recent controversy.

PFP legislators Pang Chien-kuo, Lee Hung-chun and Chou Hsi-wei wielded ROC flags and shouted slogans. The brief protest ended peacefully after reading a statement urging President Chen Shui-bian not to waver and to express his stance clearly on the status of the nation.

The Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the ruling party, said that Taiwanese under the education of the KMT administration called Sun Yat-sen the founding father, but his relationship with Taiwan is tenuous.
In addition, Taiwan did not take part in the creation of the ROC, so Taiwan's founding father is not Sun Yat-sen, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November gained 67 points to close at 5,935, with 29,339 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December moved up 78 points to finish at 5,948, with 4,736 contracts traded, while March futures gained 70 points to end at 5,920, with four contracts traded.
June futures gained 48 points to finish at 5,900, while September futures moved up 39 points to close at 5,874, with eight contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,868 for November, 5,870 for December, 5,850 for March, 5,852 for June and 5,835 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
November TE futures moved up 2.9 points to close at 219.2, with 4,327 contracts traded, while December TE futures gained 2.9 points to finish at 219, with 1,495 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
November TF futures gained 17.4 points to finish at 1,054.2, with 8,805 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved up 17.6 points to end at 1,052.8, with 3,204 contracts traded.
March TF futures moved up 17 points to finish at 1,045.2, with three contracts changing hands, while June TF futures gained 28.4 points to end at 1,050, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MIGHT VISIT PALAU NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday he should be able to arrange a state visit to the West Pacific island nation of Palau in the first half of next year.
Chen made the remarks during a meeting with visiting Palau President Tommy Remengesau and former Palau President Kuniwo Nakamura.
The president told his guests that he is busy at present with national affairs and with stumping for his Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) candidates in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

"After the elections, I think I will have a good opportunity to arrange a state visit to Palau in the first half of 2005," Chen said, adding that if possible, he hopes his planned visit can be timed to allow him to attend the inauguration of a Taiwan-invested tourist hotel under construction in Palau. The hotel is scheduled for completion in May or June next year.

Noting that Taiwan tourists account for nearly half of the annual tourist arrivals in Palau, Chen said Taiwan business groups have already built several tourist hotels in the scenic Pacific island nation.
"I believe that the completion of the new hotel next year will further boost Taiwan's contribution to Palau's tourism development, " Chen said.
He also took advantage of the meeting to express his gratitude for Palau's consistent support for Taiwan's bid to joint the United Nations and other major international organizations.
Remengesau arrived in Taipei Thursday for a ofrmal visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTHERN LINK HIGHWAY WIDENING PROJECT PASSES FEASIBILITY ASSESSMENT

TEXT.P: A project to widen the southern link highway has passed a feasibility assessment, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said in Taitung County Friday.

Making the announcement during a meeting with Taitung County Magistrate Hsu Ching-yuan, Lin said the travel time from Taitung to Kaohsiung is expected to be cut by one hour after the NT$16.8 billion (US$509.09 million) project is completed in 2012.
The project is set to start in 2006 after it undergoes an environmental impact assessment next year, Lin said.
According to the feasibility assessment, the section between Hsianglan and Tawu will be widened to a three- or four-lane thoroughfare.

While tunnels will be drilled through the mountains in the section between Anshuo and Tsaopu to reroute and straighten the highway, passing lanes will be constructed in the section between Tsaopu and Hsinlu to facilitate faster traffic flow, the report says.
The project will involve a total of 51 km of the highway, and the tunneling project will run 4.5 km.

Lin said the feasibility assessment has taken into account concerns about environmental protection and ecological conservation, and that the ministry will avoid ecological and water resource reserves while carrying out the tunneling project.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.101 to close at NT$32.990.
A total of US$839 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.091 and fluctuated between NT$32.956 and NT$33.100.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI HOLDS LANGUAGE, CULTURAL ACTIVITIES FOR PRESCHOOL CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government has set November as a month of language and cultural education for preschool children and has prepared a number of activities to allow young citizens to know the different languages and diverse cultures of the world.

City Education Department Director Wu Ching-ji, wearing a wizard outfit, played a game with some children Friday at a news conference at City Hall to kick off the "Preschool Language and Cultural Education Month" activities.

During the news conference, kindergarten students sang local folk songs and English Mother Goose rhymes, as well as playing games. The performance was a warm-up for the upcoming activities, which include an award ceremony for the best "children's talk" creators Saturday, a native language and cultural talent performance and a multi-language fair Nov. 20, as well as a dance show featuring traditional and unique dances of other countries Nov. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE MARKS SUN YAT-SEN'S BIRTHDAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over a ceremony Friday to mark the 139th anniversary of Dr. Sun Yat-sen's birth and to celebrate Chinese Cultural Renaissance Day, which falls on the same day.

Vice President Annette Lu, Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien, Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen and representatives of the military attended the ceremony. But Sun Chi-ping, adviser to the president and the grandson of Sun, was not present as he was in Hong Kong.
Chen sang the national anthem and bowed three times before a portrait of Sun during the ceremony.

Several newly appointed officials -- Vice Justice Minister Shih Mau-lin, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng, Vice Health Minister Wang Hsiu-hung and Vice Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Lu Tung-ying -- were sworn in prior to the ceremony.

Architect Chen Po-sheng then delivered a report on "history, culture and architecture," in which he called for efforts to look for the historical identity of the land in the process of pursuing a better economy.
Meanwhile, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party distanced the party from remarks by various DPP members with regard to Sun, the Republic of China's founding father.

Tsai Huang-liang, DPP whip in the legislature, said that Examination Yuan President Yao and Examination Yuan member Lin Yu-ti's words that Sun was a "foreigner" represent the view of the individuals and not the stance or policy of the DPP.
Tsai said that the DPP respects history and will look at the 94 years of the ROC in a positive light.

DOC.HEADLINE: TALKS HELP TAIWAN BREAK BEIJING'S DIPLOMATIC BLOCKADE: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: With the opening of a conference on trade, economics, technology and democratic cooperation among Taiwan, Japan and India in Taipei, the chairman of the Taiwan Thinktank, which sponsored the event, said Friday that the seminar has helped Taiwan breaking the diplomatic blockade by mainland China.

Chen Po-chih told the Central News Agency on the sidelines of the "India-Japan-Taiwan Trialogue" conference that "our goal is to promote regional and world peace " and that Taiwan will benefit when the world is more peaceful and the people of the world and East Asia enjoy "more correct" ideas about democracy.

He said he is happy to have former Indian Defense Minister Shri George Fernandes attending the conference, a fact that shows there are still people in the international community who care about Taiwan and are willing to have cooperative ties with the country.
Besides Fernandes, another notable participant in the conference was Yoshitomi Masaru, who is president of Japan's Research Institute of Economy, Trade and Industry.

Members of the Indian delegation at the conference also included Jagdish Shettingar, chief economic policy advisor of the former ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (Indian People's Party) ; Y.S. Rajan, principal advisor of the Confederation of Indian Industry; Shyam Sunder, a professor of accounting, economics and finance at Yale School of Management; M.D. Nalapat, a professor of Geopolitics and UNESCO peace chair at the Manipal Academy of Higher Education; and Jaya Jaitly, former president of the Samata Socialist Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAOYUAN HOLIDAY HOTEL DESIGNATED NEW TRANSIT HOTEL

TEXT.P: The Taoyuan Holiday Hotel is to become the contract hotel for transit passengers after the government-run Chiang Kai-shek Airport Hotel stops operating Nov. 15, officials said Friday.
Under a contract signed between the hotel and China Airlines, passengers will be put up at the hotel in the event of a contingency that prevents them making their flight as scheduled.
The 9th to 11th floors of the hotel will be reserved for transit passengers and up to 400 rooms will be available.

Wang Jung-hui, the hotel's general manager, said the hotel will serve passengers whose planes are delayed and those in transit, and will also provide accommodation for police officers carrying out a deportation mission.
The C.K.S. Airport Hotel has been operating at a loss ever since it opened in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Kozak Defuses Cherkessk Crisis.
Protesters left the Karachayevo-Cherkessia government building early Thursday after overnight negotiations with Kremlin envoy Dmitry Kozak, but tensions continued to simmer over seven slayings linked to the son-in-law of the republic's president, Mustafa Batdyev.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EXPECTS TAIWAN TO JOIN WHO IN TWO YEARS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed hope Friday that Taiwan will be allowed to participate in the World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer in two years.
Chen pointed out that Taiwan has tried to join the World Health Organization (WHO) but has failed on each occasion over the past eight years.

He urged politicians across party lines to continue to work together with the government to help Taiwan succeed in his goal of membership in two years, saying that for the health and well-being of the Taiwan people, the country must not be left out of the world body.
Chen made the remarks at a Doctor's Day celebration organized by the Taiwan Medical Association.
He also promised that the government will gather the opinions of different sectors and work out plans to reform and improve the National Health Insurance program.
Reminding the public that the program is not supposed to be a kind of social welfare, Chen urged the public to cherish medical resources to sustain the operation of the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOTEBOOK MAKERS JOCKEYING IN GREATER SHANGHAI AREA

TEXT.P: The monthly production volume of Taiwan notebook computer makers based in the greater Shanghai area of mainland China is expected to top 5 million units and hit 6 million next year, almost double the present level, industry sources said Friday.

Currently, Taiwan notebook makers operating in the Kunshan, Sungjiang and Pudung areas near Shanghai put out nearly 3 million units per month, making the greater Shanghai area the world's most important area for notebooks.

As most of Taiwan's major notebook contractors have relocated to the greater Shanghai area, their profit margins are falling fast -- to less than 5 percent -- and a fierce war to grab customers is set to rage amid expanded production capacities, the sources said.

So far, some 90 percent of Taiwan's notebook manufacturers have set up at least a production plant in the three cities, with Kunshan luring the largest number and registering the highest level of output volume.

Quanta Corp., Taiwan's largest notebook company, enjoys a leadership role in Sungjiang with an output of 1.35 million units in October, accounting for 45 percent of the Taiwan makers' total production volume and effectively widening the gap between it and other competitors.
Quanta is planning to build eight more plants in Sungjiang, six of which are completed and five of which have been designated for component assembly.
At the same time, Compal Electronics Co. forecast that its notebook export value contributed by its Kunshan division will reach around US$6 billion for this year.

A Compal executive was upbeat that the company will be able to put out 10 million notebooks for the whole of next year on the back of an increased monthly capacity of 1.2 million units. It is constructing a third manufacturing facility in Kunshan.
Inventec Corp. led other companies in opening its first facility in Pudung 10 years ago due to its convenient location close to Shanghai's new airport.
Inventec has plans to erect eight plants in Pudung, three of which are completed to boost its present notebook production level of 500,000 units to 1 million.
Following in Inventec's footsteps, ASUSTek Computer Inc. has also shown a strong ambition to explore Pudung, having purchased 2,500 acres of land there.

Should ASUSTek -- Taiwan's No. 1 motherboard manufacturer -- also use its Pudung land for notebook production, the city stands a very real chance of rivaling Kunshan and Sungjiang in terms of production volume.

In the face of the expanded capacities of notebook makers in the Shanghai area, none of them have shown signs of wanting to retreat from the race, business sources pointed out, adding that their main strategy now is to further squeeze their earnings to seize more business opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL JUDICIAL OFFICES GEAR UP FOR ANTI-BRIBERY CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: With the government's declaration of war against vote-buying prior to the Dec. 11 legislative elections, local prosecutor's offices are gearing up to deal with illegal practices in the crucial elections.

Chen Shou-huang, chief state prosecutor in Taichung, central Taiwan, sent letters to all legislative candidates wishing them success but at the same time warning them to eschew illegal means, stressing that the Taichung Prosecutor's Office will be relentless in its crackdown on bribery and violence.

Chen noted that the election of the best and the most able is a lofty ideal, as well as the main purpose of the election, but if vote-buying and violence is involved, it will become just a pipe dream.

Liu Wei-chung, chief state prosecutor in Tainan, southern Taiwan, called on 12 legislative candidates in the Tainan County to express the hope that they will monitor any corrupt practice and work together to root out vote-buying.
Lin also asked all the candidates to take part in an awareness drive on anti-vote buying in Tainan County later this month.
Cheng Wen-kuei, chief state prosecutor in Liangchiang County on the outlying islands of Matsu, urged "phantom" voters not to challenge his determination to safeguard a fair election.
According to Cheng, past information shows that bribery is rare in Matsu compared with Taiwan proper, but the problem of "phantom" voters is serious.

He said that if people move their household registration to Matsu for the election but do not actually live there, it will interfere with the fairness of the elections and he warned such people that doing so is illegal.
