DOC.HEADLINE: 18TH ASIAN STAMP FAIR SLATED FOR AUGUST 2005 IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition is slated to be held Aug. 19-24 next year at the Taipei World Trade Center, a spokesman for the Chunghwa Post Co., Ltd. said Friday.

More than 20 countries, including Japan, Singapore and South Korea will take part in the show -- the first international event of its kind organized by Chunghwa Post since 1996 under the patronage of the Federation of Inter-Asian Philately (FIAP), the spokesman said.
The major purpose of the exhibition is to expand and develop friendly ties and close cooperation among the FIAP members and to promote every aspect of philately in the FIAP region, he said.
The Chinese Taipei Philatelic Federation and Taiwan External Trade Development Council will jointly organize the exhibition, which will have around 150 booths to display stamps and coins.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE TO CONVEY CHEN'S GOODWILL TO BEIJING LEADER AT APEC

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said Friday he will convey President Chen Shui-bian's goodwill to mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao at the upcoming informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Lee, who will represent President Chen at the 2004 APEC summit scheduled to open in the Chilean capital of Santiago Nov. 20, made the remarks at a pre-departure news conference.

The soft-spoken scholar, who won the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1986 along with two other men, said he is not a mediator between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. Nevertheless, he said if opportunity presents itself, he would convey President Chen's goodwill and determination to maintain cross-strait peace and stability.

APEC is one of the few international organizations that admit both Taiwan and mainland China. Because of Beijing's diplomatic suppression, Taiwan's president has been barred from attending the annual APEC summit meeting in person and has to name a proxy to attend the gathering on his behalf. This will be the third time that Lee will serve as Chen's representative at the APEC summit.

Lee said he will take advantage of this year's meeting to let other APEC leaders understand that Taiwan can make positive contributions to the world and will never be a troublemaker or a flashpoint that might become the theater of a Third World War.

Over the past year, Lee said, Taiwan has sent personnel to six other APEC member states, including Chile, Vietnam, Peru, Indonesia, the Philippines and Papua New Guinea, to assist in their digitization programs.
"The assistance is part of our concrete actions to help narrow the digital gap among APEC members," Lee said.

Asked whether President Chen has asked him to forward personal letters to top leaders of other APEC countries, such as Chinese President Hu, U.S. President George W. Bush and Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, Lee said: "No. President Chen has not asked me to convey letters to any foreign leader."

Lee stressed that Chen has repeatedly made peace initiatives to mainland China in recent days. After unveiling 10 innovative policy initiatives for forging rapprochement with mainland China two days ago, Chen said Thursday mainland China's top negotiator, Wang Daohan, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, is welcome to visit Taiwan to meet with his Taiwan counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu.
"All these appeals signify President Chen's efforts to honor his commitment to ease cross-strait tensions and safeguard peace, stability and security in the Taiwan Strait," Lee said.

During last year's APEC summit, Lee recalled that he had a brief courtesy chat with Hu. "I felt he was a person easy to talk with. Now that Hu has taken command of the mainland military, I think he has even greater clout in the mainland leadership hierarchy. I hope mainland China's reform programs can continue moving forward under his leadership," Lee added.

Asked what he will say to President Bush, Lee said he will congratulate him on his re-election as well as express Taiwan's gratitude for U.S. support for Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization as an observer. In addition, Lee said he will ask Bush to accelerate free trade agreement negotiations with Taiwan.
As to talks with the Japanese prime minister, Lee said he will ask Koizumi to begin free trade pact talks with Taiwan and to offer visa-free privileges to Taiwan students.

APEC groups 21 economies; they are: Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

Besides Lee, the Taiwan delegation to this year's APEC meeting will also include Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, Department of Health Minister Chen Chien-jen and Vice Minister of Finance Chen Shu.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAN-SEPT CROSS-STRAIT COMMUNICATIONS RISE SIGNIFICANTLY: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The communications volume between Taiwan and mainland China increased significantly in the first nine months of this year, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) on Friday.
A total of 370 million phone calls were made across the Taiwan Strait between January and September, up 16.1 percent from the same period last year, the DGBAS report showed.
Looking at the calls in terms of time spent talking, 1.37 billion minutes were used, up 25.4 percent year-on-year.
Of these phone calls, 920 million minutes were made from Taiwan to the mainland and 440 million minutes vice versa, a rise of 31.8 percent and 13.8 percent, respectively, over last year.

On postal correspondence, the number of cross-strait letters and parcels fell 5.5 percent year-on-year to 11.61 million during the same period because of the fast development of telecommunications and e-mail services, the DGBAS report said.

Meanwhile, shipping and travel across the Strait has also increased over the years since direct ferry services between Kinmen and Matsu and the mainland's Xiamen and Fuzhou -- known as the "mini three links" -- were launched in 2001.
A total of 2,412 ferry trips were operated in the 10 months to October this year, which is almost double the 1,418 trips registered during the same period last year.
Passengers traveling across the Strait via the "mini three links" also jumped 1.8 fold to 175,000 during that period, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: EMPLOYERS DISCRIMINATING AGAINST FOREIGN SPOUSES TO BE FINED

TEXT.P: Employers who discriminate against foreign spouses with legal working rights in Taiwan could face a fine ranging between NT$300,000 and NT$1.5 million, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Friday.

The current Employment Law protects equal working opportunities for every Taiwan citizen and thus prohibits employers from discriminating against any employee or job seeker due to class, language, ethnic origin or birth place.

Based on the principle of human rights protection, CLA officials said the council has decided to extend the same protection to foreign spouses of local citizens who have obtained the legal right to work in Taiwan but have yet to obtain Republic of China citizenship.

DOC.HEADLINE: 55 COUNTRIES TO PARTICIPATE IN TAIPEI TRAVEL FAIR

TEXT.P: More than 500 organizations and companies from 55 countries and regions around the world will participate in the 2004 Taipei International Travel Fair slated for Nov. 18-21, organizers said Friday.

The exhibition, organized by the Taiwan Visitors Association, is considered to be one of the most important travel fairs in Asia. A total of 720 booths will be set up in the exhibition venue, an increase of 200 over the previous year.

Japan will be the largest foreign participating country in terms of the number of booths with 69, organizers said, adding that Egypt, Slovakia, Mexico and Argentina will make their debuts at the exhibition.

The exhibition will be divided into the Taiwan area, the Asia-Pacific area, the Europe-America-Middle East and African area, the youth and student travel area, hotels and recreational centers area and a travel-related area.
In the Taiwan area, central and local government agencies will display their best to attract domestic and foreign tourists in line with the government's tourism expansion plan.

Su Cheng-tien, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, said that the Taipei International Travel Fair's focus is on entrepreneurs, buyers and consumers.
A similar fair held last year at the Taipei World Trade Center attracted 88,000 visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN READY TO NEGOTIATE WITH BEIJING ON CHARTER FLIGHTS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has assigned an intermediary to begin talks on cross-strait charter flights for the upcoming Chinese Lunar New Year holidays and is only waiting for a positive response from Beijing, MAC spokesman Chiu Tai-san said Friday.

Two days after President Chen Shui-bian said negotiations with Beijing on direct cargo flights and charter passenger flights during the Chinese New Year holiday could begin, Chiu said his council is ready to authorize the Taipei Air Carrier Association to negotiate with its mainland counterpart on this issue as soon as Beijing is ready.

Noting that a spokesman for the Taiwan Affairs Office under the Chinese State Council said on Oct. 27 that charter flight negotiations could be patterned on the aviation negotiations between Taiwan and Hong Kong, Chiu said the opinions of both sides are converging.
Chiu said Taiwan's experience in opening charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei in 2002 will serve as a useful guide in Taiwan's possible negotiations with Beijing.
President Chen said Wednesday that charter flights this year may be operated by carriers of both Taiwan and the mainland and do not need to stop at any third place as did charter flights in 2002.
If the charter flights do in fact get off the ground, they might open door for regular direct flights between Taiwan and the mainland in the future, according to the president.

Chiu said his office had a conference with several government agencies and six major business and industrial groups earlier in the day to exchange views over the charter flights and all agreed that talks on the issue could start immediately if Beijing responds positively.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR PUBLIC BANKS SHOW DROPS IN OVERDUE LOAN RATIO: FSC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's seven major public banks continued posting improved overdue loan ratios in October, the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) reported Friday.

Except for the Taiwan Cooperative Bank, the remaining six -- Bank of Taiwan, Land Bank of Taiwan, First Commercial Bank, Hua Nan Bank, Chang Hwa Bank and the Medium Business Bank of Taiwan -- all registered declined overdue loan rations last month as compared to their September levels, according to statistics compiled by the FSC.

Bank of Taiwan, the country's most representative state-run bank, recorded an overdue loan ratio of 1.58 percent for October, valued at NT$18.94 billion (US$574 million) , a drop from September's 1.64 percent.

The Land Bank of Taiwan marked an improvement from 3.72 percent to 3.62 percent worth NT$46.23 billion, while the Taiwan Cooperative Bank posted a turnabout from 3.75 percent to 3.79 percent but with a reduced value from NT$47.26 billion to NT$46.89 billion.
The rest of the banks also showed declines ranging from 0.18 percentage points to 0.03 percentage points, according to the FSC tallies.
Since President Chen Shui-bian came to power for the first time in May 2000, financial reform has been one of the priorities on the government's agenda.

The FSC was set up to oversee the domestic banking insurance, securities and futures industries, which were exercised in the past by the Ministry of Finance, the Central Bank of China and the Central Depository Insurance Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR CLOSER TAIWAN-JAPAN-INDIA COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday Taiwan, Japan and India should strengthen cooperation in various fields as they have shared values in freedom, democracy and human rights protection.
Yu made the appeal while addressing a seminar on the promotion of Taiwan-Japan-India cooperation, organized by the private Taiwan Thinktank.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, Yu said Taiwan has consistently maintained close substantive ties with Japan, including booming bilateral trade and brisk cultural and educational exchanges. Two-way trade reached US$40 billion in 2003, making Taiwan Japan's fourth largest trading partner. The people of the two countries made more than 1.5 million visits to each other's country last year, indicating close civilian exchanges, Yu added.

With the end of the Cold War, Yu said, Taiwan-India relations have also been growing steadily in recent years. The two countries exchanged representative offices in 1995 and the opening of direct flights from Taipei to New Delhi by China Airlines in 2002 has further facilitate bilateral personnel exchanges.

Two-way trade between Taiwan and India increased to US$1.5 billion last year and the two countries have forged close cooperation in information-technology industries in recent years, Yu said, adding that there is still ample room for Taiwan-India commercial exchanges and cooperation to grow in the years ahead.
Noting that Taiwan is a new democracy in Asia, India the world's largest democracy and Japan an advanced democracy, Yu said all the three countries rank among the top five Asian economic powerhouses.
Yu said he intensely looks forward to seeing the three countries reinforce cooperation in promoting freedom, democracy, human rights and economic prosperity in Asia and the entire world.
The premier also said Taiwan fully supports Japan's and India's bid to become permanent members of the United Nations Security council.
Taiwan Thinktank Chairman Chen Po-chih said the think tank has organized the "India-Japan-Taiwan Trialogue" seminar with a view to promoting regional cooperation and world peace.
In his view, Chen said, Taiwan will benefit when the world is more peaceful and the people of the world and East Asia all enjoy freedom, democracy and prosperity.

"We hope the seminar can work out feasible measures to promote Taiwan-Japan and Taiwan-India relations as well as the triangular Taiwan-Japan-India cooperation, " Chen said, adding that by forging partnerships and strategic alliances with Japan and India, Taiwan can break the Beijing-imposed diplomatic embargo and gradually form alliances with even more Asian democracies.

The Indian delegation to the seminar is headed by former Indian Defense Minister Shri George Fernandes, while the Japanese mission is led by Yoshitomi Masaru, president of Japan's Research Institute of Economy, Trade and Industry.

Members of the Indian delegation also included Jagdish Shettingar, chief economic policy advisor of the former ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (Indian People's Party); Y.S. Rajan, principal advisor of the Confederation of Indian Industry; Shyam Sunder, a professor of accounting, economics and finance at Yale School of Management; M.D. Nalapat, a professor of Geopolitics and UNESCO peace chair at the Manipal Academy of Higher Education; and Jaya Jaitly, former president of the Samata Socialist Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES BEIJING TO RESPOND AFFIRMATIVELY TO CHEN'S OFFER FOR TALKS

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) urged Beijing authorities Friday to respond affirmatively to President Chen Shui-bian's offer for another meeting between Beijing's chief negotiator with Taiwan, Wang Daohan, and his Taiwan counterpart, Koo Chen-fu.

MAC spokesman Chiu Tai-san told a news conference that Chen's suggestion is a follow-up to his Double Ten National Day address wherein he urged Beijing to resume talks with Taiwan on the basis of discussions that were held between the two sides in 1992 in Hong Kong.

Chen offered Wednesday to invite Wang, who is the head of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, to visit Taiwan and meet with Koo, who is the chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation.
The president extended the invitation after visiting Koo at a local hospital where Koo was admitted for poor health.

Koo and Wang met for the first time in 1993 in Singapore, which was the first talks between Taiwan and mainland China since the two separated in 1949 after a civil war, but their discussions were not continued because of a statement by then-President Lee Teng-hui in 1999 that the relationship between the two sides was "state to state" in nature. China was angered and did not return to the discussions.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMOUS SONGWRITER REMEMBERED IN GRAND FUNERAL

TEXT.P: Famous songwriter Liang Hung-chih, who died of pancreatic cancer at Tri-Service General Hospital Oct. 30 at the age of 44, was remembered in a grand funeral Friday.
The funeral took place at Holy Family Catholic Church in Taipei, with Cardinal Paul Shan presiding over a requiem mass, which was then followed by a music-filled memorial service.

Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai presented a posthumous citation to Liang on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian at the funeral in recognition of his music career achievements and his assistance in helping design the annual Presidential Education Awards a few years ago.

Liang had composed many popular lyric songs during his music career that spanned more than two decades. Many Mandarin pop singers, including Tsai Chin, Su Jui, Wang Chi-lei, Cheng Yi, Yu Tai-yen, Chiang Yu-heng and Tseng Ching-yu, came to fame after singing his songs. They took turns singing Liang's songs at the memorial service.
Liang was already in the terminal stage of pancreatic cancer when his disease was discovered by Tri-Service General Hospital doctors early this year.

Doctors said pancreatic cancer is one of the most virulent forms of cancer because it shows no special symptoms in the early stages. Doctors said Liang had undergone chemotherapy and radiotherapy, but the treatment was not effective.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL ELECTION COMMISSION DISQUALIFIES THREE FROM LEGISLATIVE RACE

TEXT.P: Three out of 496 hopefuls who registered last month to run in the Dec. 11 legislative election failed to pass the qualification screening by the Central Election Commission (CEC), a spokesman said Friday.

According to the CEC official, one registered to run in the first constituency of Taipei City and the other two fielded by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) for overseas Chinese representation were verified by the CEC as unqualified to take part in the elections for the sixth 225-member Legislative Yuan.
This brings the number of eligible candidates to 493, who will be entitled to draw their designation numbers slated for Nov. 17 at local CEC units, he said.

The 493 candidates, including 386 for both regional and aboriginal seats, will contest 168 regional seats and eight aboriginal seats, as well as eight overseas Chinese and 41 at-large seats to be produced based on a proportional representation system according to the ballots that each party garners in the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CASUALTIES REPORTED IN EXPLOSION NEAR MINISTRY OF EDUCATION

TEXT.P: A homemade bomb exploded Friday night near the Ministry of Education but no casualties or damage was reported, police said.
The explosion occurred at about 8: 08 p.m. near an outer wall of the ministry, the police said.

The police are investigating the incident which is suspected to have links with the controversy over a recent draft guidelines proposed by the ministry for the compilation of history textbooks for senior high school students.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL RELIGIOUS CONFERENCE CONCLUDES

TEXT.P: An international religious conference jointly organized by the Goldin Institute for International Partnership and Peace in the United States and the Museum of World Religions in Taipei concluded in Taipei Friday.
After six days of discussions, more than 60 religious representatives from overseas and 40 local religious leaders and experts agreed on the importance of water conservation.
The Goldin Institute also announced at the closing ceremony that the next conference will be held in India next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CANVASSES FOR VOTES FOR DPP IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian appealed to voters in Tainan City Friday night to help his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) win a majority in the Legislative Yuan by voting DPP in the Dec. 11 elections.
The president told his supporters that he will be a lame duck if his party doesn't control the legislature.

Chen said the priorities of his second term are to make Taiwan a great country -- and this requires a constitution suitable for the nation -- to normalize relations with mainland China and keep the economy strong.
This will be impossible without the support of the legislature, the president said.
He urged his followers to support his party as well as the four DPP candidates for legislators in Tainan City.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Nov. 13, or the second day of the tenth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1851: Telegraphic services between London and Paris come into operation.
1907: French engineer Paul Cornu successfully test-flies the world's first human-carrying helicopter.
1913: Greece signs a peace treaty with Turkey.
1914: A patent is taken out for an item of women's underwear to be known as the "backless brassiere."
1918: The Republic of Austria is proclaimed.
1923: Italy's Benito Mussolini introduces a bill granting women voting rights in national elections.
1925: The South African government calls for further segregation between whites and blacks.
1935: Sun Chuan-fang, a warlord of the Peiyang army, a regional military regime in the early republic of China, is assassinated.
1941: The Ark Royal, Britain's aircraft carrier, is torpedoed by a German submarine, sinking the next day off Gibraltar.
1945: Charles de Gaulle is elected president of the French Provisional Government.
1948: Chen Pu-lei, a senior member of the Kuomintang, commits suicide in Nanking (Nanjing).
1950: Tibet appeals to the United Nations against Communist Chinese aggression.
1970: Hafez al-Assad seizes power in Syria after a military coup.
1974: Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO), gives a speech at the United Nations for the first time.
1975: A Boeing 747-SP passenger plane successfully completes a non-stop flight from New York to Tokyo.
1975: The World Health Organization announces that Asia is free of smallpox for the first time in history.
1985: The U.S. spacecraft Voyager I sends back the first close-up pictures of the planet Saturn.
1985: The volcano Nevado del Ruiz in Colombia erupts, killing about 25,000 people.
1993: A mainland Chinese passenger plane crashes and bursts into flames while landing in the western city of Urumqi, causing an undetermined number of casualties.
1994: Swedes in a referendum vote 52.2 percent in favor of approving European Union membership.
1995: Israel starts pulling troops out of the West Bank city of Jenin to end 28 years of occupation.
1995: A bomb rips through a building filled with American and Saudi military personnel in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, killing seven people, including five Americans.
1999: Chile and Peru sign an agreement, ending a 120-year territorial dispute over borders.
1999: Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara, heading a three-member delegation, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit at the invitation of President Lee Teng-hui.
2000: President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines is impeached on corruption charges.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian sends his condolences over the crash of an American Airlines Airbus A-300 passenger jet in New York City, killing more than 260 aboard. His condolences are sent to U.S. President George W. Bush, Dominican President Hipolito Mejia and New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "When men have what they will not do, they are prepared to act in what they do do with effect."

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HARBOR KEEPS GROWING IN OPERATION

TEXT.P: The operating volume of Kaohsiung Harbor grew considerably in the first 10 months of this year, with the loading and unloading volume of containers expanding the most at 10.4 percent over the same period from last year, according to statistics released by harbor authorities Saturday.

The statistics show that 32,685 vessels entered or left the harbor over the past 10 months, with a total displacement of 585,632,500 tons, which is 2.25 percent more than the corresponding period of the previous year.
A total of 390,335,000 tons of cargo was loaded and unloaded during the same period of time, representing a growth of 9.8 percent, in addition to 8,083,870 containers.

Kaohsiung's proportion of the country's total is 74.5 percent in terms of loading and unloading volume of containers, 68 percent in terms of loading and unloading volume of cargo, and 48.8 percent in terms of the number of vessels entering and leaving, and 61.8 percent in terms of combined displacement of vessels entering and leaving.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 50 PERCENT OF WORKERS WILL TAKE HIGH-RISK JOBS FOR MONEY: POLL

TEXT.P: Nearly 53 percent of workers in Taiwan will accept high-risk jobs if the price is right, according to the results of a survey released by the 1111 Job Bank Saturday.
The survey was conducted between Oct. 28 and Nov. 12 on 1,300 workers, with a margin of error of 2.7 percent.

As to why a person would take a high-risk job, 42.38 percent of the respondents said these jobs usually offer high pay, 39.92 percent said they would earn big money in a short period of time, 30 percent said this would help them through the hard times of unemployment, and 24.23 percent said these jobs would enrich their life experience.

The top-10 high-risk professions named by the respondents were high-voltage electricity engineering, chemical manufacturing, high-rise window cleaning, quarry blasting, fire-fighting, oil and propane delivery, policeman, stunt performing, medical waste disposal, and mining.
As to the degree of risk involving their present jobs, the respondents graded an average of 3.84 on a 10-point scale.

Those respondents from the medical and biochemical sectors consider their professions the most dangerous (4.7 points), followed by those working in the traditional manufacturing sector (4.3 points) and dining, tourism and entertainment sectors (4.1 points).

The survey found that less than 20 percent of the workers will take workplace safety into consideration in picking their jobs, with 61 percent citing career development as their priority consideration.

Also, more than 50 percent of the respondents are unaware of the fact that workers in some high-risk professions are not entitled to insurance because of rejection by insurance companies, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Leaders Filling Arafat Vacuum.
Palestinian officials moved swiftly to install an interim leadership, convey a sense of calm and make plans to bury their leader, as debate swirled over whether the death of Yasser Arafat would provide an opening for renewed Middle East peacemaking efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: U.S. Troops Set for Final Attack on Falluja Force.
U.S. forces moved into position for a decisive battle with the insurgents, pounding some of their last strongholds with airstrikes.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVEN MORE KINDS OF TAIWAN FRUITS TO ENTER MAINLAND MARKET

TEXT.P: Mainland China has agreed to open its markets to seven more kinds of Taiwan fruits, an agricultural delegation said Saturday upon its return from the mainland.

Legislative candidate Hsu Hsin-liang, who led a score of representatives from farmers' associations last Sunday to the mainland, said the delegation met with mainland Vice Premier Hui Liangyu, Director of Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council Chen Yunlin, and Minister of Agriculture Du Qinglin during the weeklong visit.

Hsu, a former chairman of the now-ruling Democratic Progressive Party, noted that the World Trade Organization will expand agricultural product trade in 2006 and that up to 134 agricultural products might flock into Taiwan by then.
The visit aims to find outlets for Taiwan farmers and ease cross-strait tensions to avoid unnecessary confrontations, Hsu said.

Ku Yuan-chun, president of Taiwan Province Farmers' Association, said that Hui and other mainland officials have agreed to allow seven more kinds of fruits -- guavas, dates, oranges, papayas, lychees, bananas, and pineapples -- from Taiwan to the mainland in addition to the original five kinds -- pomelos, betel nuts, mangoes, starfruits, and wax apples -- starting Dec. 1.

Beijing also agreed that it will not dump rice, vegetables and fruits in Taiwan after the expansion of agricultural trade under the WTO framework in 2006, and that Taiwan will import corn, soybean and wheat it does not produce from the mainland to cut production costs, Ku added.

Both sides also agreed to set up counterpart offices, with Taiwan's farmers' associations dealing with the agriculture product transactions, which will provide 62 percent of the profits back to farmers.

Hsieh Yung-huei, president of Yunlin County Farmers's Association, said that the delegation has repeatedly asked for tariff-free treatment and simplified quarantine procedures for imported Taiwan agricultural products, and Beijing has agreed to do as much as it could.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S APEC MISSION TO DEPART FOR CHILE SUNDAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's mission will leave Sunday for Santiago, Chile to take part in this year's ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum slated to open Nov. 17, Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) officials said Saturday.

Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh and Minister of Finance Lin Chuan will head the delegation composed of officials of relevant agencies, including BOFT Director-General Huang Chi-peng and Directorate General of Customs Director-General Yu Shao-wu, the officials said.

In the meeting, Ho and Lin will express Taiwan's willingness to promote multi-lateral trade mechanisms, free trade agreements and the establishment of a Free Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific (FTAAP) and the so-called TPBA -- a state-of-the-art enterprise solution to enhance any successful data management strategy among the APEC's 21 member economies, they said.

The delegation will do its best to display Taiwan's keen interest in contributing to the international community and to seek the maximum benefits for the country during the meeting, they said, adding that Hu and Lin will also hold two-way talks with their counterparts from Australia, Canada, Chile, Japan, Russia and South Korea to exchange views and ideas on issues of mutual concern.
The two ministers are slated to host a banquet Nov. 16 in Santiago with Taiwan businessmen residing there and invite them to invest at home, they said.

THe APEC informal leaders' summit will open on Nov. 20, in which Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh will participate on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian. It will be the third time Lee has represented Chen.

The APEC's 21 member countries are Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, mainland China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: NICARAGUAN AMBASSADOR TO U.S. GIVES PARTY FOR ROC REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 12 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Nicaragua's Ambassador to the United States Salvador Stadthagen held a party to welcome David Ta-wei Lee, Republic of China's new representative to the U.S., Friday at the Nicaraguan embassy.

Stadthagen, who formerly served as ambassador to the ROC, said that during his time in Taiwan, Lee was the director-general of the Government Information Office before he was promoted to the vice foreign affairs minister.
Stadthagen noted that he had just come across Lee and learned of his new posting during a recent event in Washington, D.C. and he wanted to host the party to welcome him.
Stadthagen said the two countries have solid friendship, adding that Nicaragua and other allies of Taiwan supported its bid to join the World Health Organization recently.
He also said that his son, who lived with him in Taiwan for five years, likes Taiwan very much and will soon return to study.
Lee expressed his appreciation for Stadthagen's hospitality and his country's support of Taiwan. Also, he was happy that the two old friends could meet again in Washington, D.C.

Ambassadors to the U.S. from Burkina Faso, Chad, Swaziland and Costa Rica, and ambassadors from Honduras, Panama, Nicaragua and Paraguay to the Organization of American States were also on hand in the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'GREEN' VICTORY WILL ENSURE FULFILLMENT OF ADMINISTRATION POLICIES: YU

TEXT.P: Giving the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, a majority in the legislature will ensure that key administration policies are implemented, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday.

The premier made the remarks while stumping for DPP Legislator Duan Yi-kang, who is bidding for re-election in the Dec. 11 elections. Also on hand were Chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs Chen Chu, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san, as well as Minister Without Portfolio Lin Yi-fu, and Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long.
Yu stressed that only when the "pan-green camp" commands more than half of the 225-seat legislature, can the DPP have a free hand in pushing through its ideals of governance.
The legislature will then be able to pass a bill for a national seniors' subsidy plan, statutes on the alleged ill-gotten assets of political parties and a political party law, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION CALLS FOR SACKING OF OFFICIALS WHO DENY ROC EXISTS

TEXT.P: Lawmakers from the opposition People First Party (PFP) Saturday called for the dismissal of two officials from the Examination Yuan who have denied the existence of the Republic of China (ROC).

Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung, convener of the PFP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said President Chen Shui-bian, who was sworn in as ROC president should honor his official oath by firing Yao Chia-wen, president of the Examination Yuan and Lin Yu-ti, a member of the yuan, who claimed that the ROC is not their country and Sun Yat-sen, the founder of the ROC, was a foreigner.
Leaving the two at their posts would make Chen a hypocrite since he said that he is the president of the ROC, an entity that Yao and Lin deny even exists.

Another PFP lawmaker, Hsu Yuan-kuo, called on Yao and Lin to quit their posts on their own to show that they meant what they said instead of hanging on shamelessly to jobs in a country they don't acknowledge.

Yao and Lin drew fire from the PFP and the Kuomintang (KMT) by claiming earlier this week that Taiwan is not the Republic of China, and that the Examination Yuan's history test for government employees should exclude the history of the ROC.

In a related development Saturday, KMT lawmaker Huang Teh-fu said President Chen and his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have created the controversy over the identity of the country as a campaign strategy for the year-end legislative elections.
Huang said Chen and the DPP should be blamed for splitting the country for their own political gains.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU TO CONFER HONORARY DOCTORATE DEGREE TO CHINESE NOBEL WINNER

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) will confer an honorary doctorate degree on the 2000 Nobel Prize for literature winner Gao Xingjian during the university's 76th anniversary celebrations on Nov. 15, officials said Saturday.
The Chinese-French writer, however, will not be able to come to Taiwan for the ceremony because his health does not allow him to fly long distances, the NTU officials said.
Gao will instead address the event through a 10-minute pre-recorded video that will be shown at the event, they said.
Also, they said, Gao has promised to offer lectures at NTU during the second half of next year or the year after that if his health improves.
The theme of the lectures might focus on "literature and life" and "literature and art."

As an alternative arrangement in the case of his failure to make the trip, the NTU could send a literature professor to Paris and have their dialogue recorded as a video for teaching purposes, according to the officials.
Gao, who was born in mainland China's Jiangxi province in 1940, left the mainland in 1987 and settled down a year later in France as a political refugee.
During this year's anniversary celebrations, NTU will also confer an honorary doctorate degree on Henry T. Yang, chancellor of the University of California, Santa Barbara, NTU officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Deputy Chief Resigns From CIA.
CIA Deputy chief resigns after clashes with agency chief of staff; officials say other senior officers are threatening to leave.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUN YET-SEN FATHER OF COUNTRY, ROC FLAG NATIONAL SYMBOL: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian confirmed in Taipei Saturday that Dr. Sun Yat-sen is the founding father of "our country" and the flag of the Republic of China is "the flag of our country."

In an attempt to quell the controversy stemming from the denial of the existence of the ROC by two senior officials from Chen's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Chen said as "the 11th-term president of the ROC," he will do his part to defend the sovereignty, safety and dignity of "Taiwan."
The president used the terms "ROC" and "Taiwan" alternatively in his statement to draw a parallel between them.

The two DPP officials, Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen and a member of the yuan, Lin Yu-ti, caused an uproar among opposition politicians by denying that the ROC is the name of their country earlier this week, which gave Chen's political critics a field day to lambaste the president.
Chen made the statement while visiting a temple in Neihu, Taipei City. He was accompanied by five DPP candidates in the year-end legislative elections.

While being treated by the temple to dumplings, a Chinese snack which is supposed to bring safety to those who consume them, Chen ascribed his failure to win re-election as mayor of Taipei City in 1998 to his failure to visit the temple and eat its dumplings that year.

Now that the god to which the temple was dedicated has helped him win re-election as president, Chen said he hopes the god of the temple will also help the five DPP candidates who accompanied him on the visit to win in the year-end elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES US$2 MILLION TO PARAGUAY
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Paraguay, Nov. 12 (CNA) (By Lee Pai-chen and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China (ROC) donated US$2 million to Paraguay Friday to help with its economic development.

The money was presented by ROC Ambassador Yen Bing-fan to Paraguay President Nicanor Duarte Frutos in a ceremony in the presence of Paraguay's Minister of Foreign Affairs Leila Rachid de Cowles, Minister of Industry and Commerce Ernst Bergen as well as 30 business leaders.
Speaking at the ceremony, Duarte thanked Taiwan for its generous grant and praised the long way his country has come in attracting foreign investment and developing its economy.
For his part, Yen praised Paraguay as one of Taiwan's firm allies in politics and economics and added that bilateral ties have kept improving since the two concluded diplomatic ties in 1957.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE OUT OF THREE TAIWAN PEOPLE WILL MAKE AN OUTBOUND TRIP THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: One out of three Taiwan people is predicted to travel outside the country this year, a ratio well higher than Japan's one out of seven, according to government tallies.
During the first 10 months of this year, more than 6.63 million Taiwan people went abroad, statistics compiled by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications showed.
Bureau officials forecast that the figure will rise to 7.8 million for the whole of this year, equalling one trip for every three Taiwan people.
The full 2004 figure will represent a noticeable increase over the 2003 level of 5.92 million and over the 2002 level of 7.32 million.
Hong Kong and Macau are the most popular destinations for Taiwan people who go abroad for the first time, as more than 40 percent of the total make their first overseas trips there, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN JOINS MUSEUM COMPUTER NETWORK

TEXT.P: Taiwan has obtained membership in the Canada-headquartered Museum Computer Network (MCN) , becoming the organization's third regional member outside North America, Academia Sinica officials said Saturday.

Academia Sinica Vice President Ovid Tzeng signed a memorandum of understanding to join the MCN in his capacity as leader of the Executive Yuan's "national-level technological program for digital archiving," during the MCN's 32nd annual meeting being held Nov. 10-13 in Minneapolis, Minnesota, the officials said.
They said admission to the MCN is a major step forward and will be of great help to the government's efforts in promoting the use of computer technologies among domestic museums.
The MCN is a non-profit organization that serves individuals and institutions wishing to improve their means of developing, managing and conveying museum information through the use of automation.
The theme of its 32nd annual meeting is "Great Technology for Collections, Confluence and Community."
In addition to exhibiting Taiwan's progress in the field of digital archiving, members of the Taiwan delegation led by Tzeng also presented several reports at the meeting.
The MCN maintains special interest groups on intellectual property, digital media, information technology as well as standards and controlled vocabulary.
Besides Taiwan, the other two international special interest groups of the organization are Japan and Ireland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SENIOR ECONOMIC PLANNER VISITING U.S.

TEXT.P: The nation's senior economic planner left for the United States at the head of a delegation Saturday.

Yeh Ming-feng, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that the delegation will observe software and hardware facilities and measures related to the "Customs-Trade Partnership Against Terrorism" (C-TPAT) -- a joint initiative between U.S. Customs and businesses -- in the wake of the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in the U.S.
The 11-day visit aims to learn more about the U.S. policy concerning its trade, harbors, cargo inspection, customs and border monitoring policies and to promote Taiwan-U.S. trade relations, Yeh said.

Accompanying him were Liao Chien-shun, vice director-general of the Directorate General of Customs under the Ministry of Finance, and Lin Chih-ming, director of the Department of Navigation and Aviation under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

The delegation is scheduled to call on the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, the Customs Bureau and the Trade Representative Office, the Department of Commerce as well as visit San Francisco and other harbors.

The delegation will observe the U.S. land security strategy, custom clearance, cargo security, transportation management and control procedures, as well as the U.S. "Container Security Initiative" before returning to Taiwan Nov. 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: 244 MEDICAL PROFESSIONALS HONORED FOR 50 YEARS OF DEVOTION

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) held a ceremony Saturday to honor 244 medical professionals who have devoted half a century of their lives to helping patients.

President Chen Shui-bian was invited to present them -- including Western and Chinese medical doctors, dentists, medical examiners and mid-wives -- with citations to express the DOH's highest regards and gratitude.
DOH Minister Chen Chien-jen lauded the unselfish devotion of the medical personnel, saying that have conveyed "warmth and a shining light" in facing the "darkest moment of life."
Hsu Yuo-chuan, 93, one of the physicians honored, said he has worked in internal medicine since finishing his studies in Japan.
Hsu and his wife, a gynecologist and obstetrician, opened a general hospital in Chingshui, Taichung County. He only gave up his practice at age 88.

Hsu said that he made up his mind to become a doctor after his mother died giving birth to him. During his medical practice over 50 years, he never thought of making big money, saying that he derives his greatest joy from seeing a patient healed.
Asked about his feelings about practicing medicine all his life, he said that he must thank the blessing of god for letting him never have a major malpractice problem.

Su Chi-mou, a 92-year-old ophthalmologist, has devoted all his life to Likang, Pingtung County. He continued to perform surgery on patients with cataracts until he was 60, and did not charge patients who were poor, adding that his house was always filled with fresh vegetables or fish from his patients to show their gratitude.
Su said that his son is now stepping into his shoes, and he is gratified for a happy and easygoing life.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT MAKES PITCH FOR NEW CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui, who has been an ardent advocate of Taiwan independence after leaving office in 2000, made a pitch for a new constitution for the country in Tainan, southern Taiwan, Saturday, claiming the country's Constitution has been reduced to a "ragged mosquito net" after being tinkered with six times during his term in office.

Stumping for candidates of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), Lee said he dared not take the euphemism of "Taiwan's founding father" offered to him by some of his supporters, but he would spare no efforts to press for a new constitution for the country.
As a Taiwanese, he said, it was a pity that he had to serve as the "false" president of the "Republic of China" between 1996 and 2000, although the ROC had perished long ago.

Lee disputed as nonsense the claims that a new constitution for Taiwan will invoke a military attack from Beijing, saying that China is incapable of doing that militarily and because of the disastrous political fallout that would ensue.
He urged voters to support TSU candidates because in that way they will be helping the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to win a majority in the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 19 ASIAN TEAMS ATTEND TAIWAN-HOSTED TUG-OF-WAR CONTEST

TEXT.P: The fifth Asian Tug-of-War Championship began Saturday in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan, and will run until Sunday, with a total of 19 teams from Japan, India, Hong Kong, Mongolia, Macau, South Korea and Taiwan attending.

Among the local and foreign groups, the "Sagawa" team from Japan is widely regarded as the most powerful. It recently defeated the Japanese national team that won the men's 600kg contest at the World Tug-of-War Championship in Scotland in February.
The Indian team and the muscular Mongolians, who are attending the Taiwan-hosted competition for the first time, are also seen as strong groups that may pull down the well-trained Japanese athletes.
In informal contests on Saturday, the Chinese Taipei team lost to Japan, while Hong Kong was defeated by India, and Mongolia beat Macau. The formal competitions will be held on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR WILL KEEP RISING AGAINST U. S. DOLLAR: DEALERS

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar will maintain its rising streak against the U.S. dollar in the future despite its recent gains in value against the greenback, market dealers said Saturday.

With the recent re-election of U.S. President George W. Bush and rampant speculation on an appreciation of mainland China's renminbi, the local currency has gotten a boost to firmer ground against the U.S. unit, they said.

Bush's re-election coupled with the United States' long-term huge trade and fiscal deficits have been indicative that the United States will tolerate a weaker greenback, market watchers said, pointing out that this widely held assumption has been prompting foreign capital to flow into Asia.
Asian currencies, including the Japanese yen, the Korean won, the Singapore dollar and the new Taiwan dollar all went up markedly in value against the U.S. dollar in recent days, they noted.
The new Taiwan dollar appreciated by a combined NT$0.127 against the U.S. dollar Thursday and Friday, finishing at NT$32.990.

They forecast that the local currency will further gain steam against the U.S. dollar on the grounds that the renminbi will eventually loosen its peg to the greenback and that the local unit will get an extra boost provided by the Morgan Stanley Capital International's move to increase the inclusion weight of its Taiwan Index from 75 percent in late November to 100 percent in May 2005.
Yeh Yin-hua, a professor at Fu Jen Catholic University, predicted a weak course for the U.S. dollar, pointing to the United States' serious trade deficits as the main factor.
An analyst in charge of operations in Northeast Asia at Standard Chartered Bank claimed that Asian currencies will further strengthen against the U.S. dollar by at least 5 percent next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONTHLY SUBSIDY FOR ELDERLY COULD BE RAISED TO NT$7,500: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that if the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), wins a majority in the year-end legislative elections, the monthly subsidy for seniors over 65 will be raised to NT$7,500 (US$227).

President Chen made the remarks when he led a large contingent of officials to stump for three DPP candidates in Yunlin, central Taiwan for the Dec. 11 legislative elections. Accompanying him were Vice President Annette Lu, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, DPP Vice Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan, Vice Minister of the Interior Lee Chin-yung, and Council of Agriculture Vice Chairman Tai Cheng-yao.

The president noted that if the "pan-green camp" wins more than half of the 225 seats in the legislature, then after the new legislature is inaugurated in February next year, a proposed national subsidy bill for the elderly can be passed.
"In the future, those seniors over 65 will be able to receive NT$7,500 a month, not the present NT$3,000 or NT$4,000," he said.
In addition, the president said that a financial restructuring fund should be increased to help write off bad loans and attract more foreign investment in Taiwan.

The president also took the opportunity to express his appreciation to Yunlin County, saying that he garnered only 47 percent of the vote from the county in 2000 presidential election, but the number topped 60 percent in the March 20, 2004 election.

The increase of 50,000 votes shows that Yunlin people want him to better the economy and embark on major reforms, the president said. But he said that he was hand-tied over the past four years because the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party still enjoy a slight majority in the legislature.
The president asked the people of Yunlin to give him and his administration a continued mandate in the legislature by allowing all three DPP candidates to be elected.

Vice President Lu also said that the Taiwan fish called tilapia is being raised commercially in ponds, some of which are damaging the environment. Although the fish is popular on dinner tables around Taiwan and as an export item, the problems with the ponds must be addressed. She said she would convene a seminar to discuss the issues soon.

Next February, she will also invite those in the industrial, agricultural and fishery sectors to go with her to Latin American for a visit, saying that she hopes to spread Taiwan's superb agricultural and fishery technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HARBOR WELCOMES RENEWED CONTRACT BY MAERSK

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau on Saturday welcomes Maersk's decision to renew the rental contract with the port over two wharves in the port's fifth container center.

Harbor officials said Saturday that Maersk's decision to renew its lease of the 76th and 77th wharves until 2010 is significant, because they said it will help Kaohsiung Harbor develop into a leading shipping center for the Asia-Pacific region.

They noted that with ports in mainland China and Southeast Asia emerging in recent years, and the continued delay of direct cross-strait shipping links, Kaoshiung has faced steep competition and challenges in its operations, especially because Hong Kong and Macau have used fairly low rates to woo shipping companies.

Maersk currently rents the 118th and the 119th wharves in the fourth container center of the harbor as well as the 76th and 77th wharves in the fifth container center, the contract for the latter would have expired next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WORKS TO IMPROVE TRADE DEFICIT WITH SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: The government has launched a sales-promotion program targeting South Korea to continue its efforts to improve Taiwan's huge deficit with that country, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials said Saturday.

Taiwan has an unfavorable trade balance toward South Korea that started in 1989, with the amount standing at US$4.32 billion in the nine months to September this year and becoming the second-largest source of Taiwan's trade deficit, according to MOEA statistics.
The ministry started a program to "strengthen trade toward South Korea" early this year by organizing a series of fact-finding and trade-show missions to South Korea.
Major industrial associations in Taiwan also jointly established a Taiwan-South Korea trade and economic friendship club in October to try to strengthen bilateral exchanges.
MOEA officials said this program has produced preliminary results, with Taiwan's exports to South Korea posting an average monthly growth of 30 percent from April to September this year.

In order to keep up with these efforts, the ministry has worked out the sales-promotion program, which will cover measures such as setting up a "Korean task force" and "Korean desk" at the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) to assist South Korean buyers, they said.
TAITRA staff will visit the Taiwan offices of major South Korean manufacturers such as Samsung and LG to facilitate their procurements in Taiwan, the officials said.

They said the ministry will also organize trade-promotion tours to South Korea, which will join members of the automobile and mobile phone parts and components, communications, digital content, sports equipment and bicycle sectors.
In addition, the ministry will host a series of activities to help domestic manufacturers promote their corporate images and assist them with setting up more sales outlets, they said.
South Korea is the fifth-largest trading partner of Taiwan. It is also Taiwan's fourth-largest source of imports and six-largest out-bound market.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT PAINTS NEW HORIZONS FOR FARMERS, FISHERMEN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu vowed Saturday to make Taiwan's farmers and fishermen the world's happiest people in their line of work, encouraging them to have new ideas and reach out to explore new horizons.
Lu made the remarks while stumping at a campaign stop in central Yunlin County for three candidates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Stressing that Taiwan's agricultural and fishery industries must aim to produce the world's top-level goods, Lu urged local farmers and fishermen to develop new thinking in the face of severe challenges from across the world.
Lu said that she is planning to lead a mission of fishermen, farmers and businessmen to visit various countries in Central and South America in February.
According to the vice president, what she hopes to achieve with the trip is to help open a new window for young farmers and fishermen from Taiwan.

But before that, she said, she will host a seminar with township and village chiefs from nationwide coastal regions to discuss and find solutions to problems related to land sinkage and aquaculture -- all issues of grave concern to their livelihood.
She also warned Taiwan's farmers not to fall into mainland China's trap, which has been offering free land to lure Taiwan people to settle there.

Pointing out that local farmers's poverty is usually the main reason behind the numerous riots and unrest in the mainland's rural areas, she urged Taiwan people to open wide their eyes and never buy the story.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN HIGHER EDUCATION FAIR OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2004 European Higher Education Fair opened Saturday in Taipei with some 50 institutions from France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Spain, Switzerland and United Kingdom participating.
The fair is aimed at presenting the advantages of a European education to attract more Taiwanese students and to promote bilateral academic exchanges, the organizers said.

The participants of the fair are to introduce higher education institutions to Taiwanese students and their parents, helping them get a better understanding of schools, the education system and life in Europe, they added.
The fair, jointly organized by Agence EduFrance, Germany Academic Exchange Service, French Institute, and Netherlands Trade and Investment Office in Taipei, will run through Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: IAEE ANNUAL MEETING TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI NEXT JUNE

TEXT.P: The 2005 annual meeting of the International Association for Energy Economics (IAEE) will be held in Taipei next June, officials of the Chinese Association for Energy Economics (CAEE) said Saturday.
The meeting will be presided over by CAEE honorary President Vincent Siew, with more than 600 energy experts from home and abroad participating.

With the arrival of the era of high energy prices, CAEE has expected to bring together specialists from around the world by organizing the meeting to discuss energy issues, which include the raising of Taiwan's energy economics research standard and the promotion of international energy economics cooperation, CAEE officials said.

The topic of the annual event will revolve around energy globalization examined in the light of marketing and technology. Participants will discuss the topic from dimensions including the pan-Pacific region's energy policy, the Middle East region's energy safety, the control of the energy market, re-deliberation on nuclear power generation, outlook on new energy techniques and economy in energy use.
Currently, the CAEE organizing committee is soliciting dissertations on energy for discussions next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES E.U. TO ABANDON 'ONE CHINA' POLICY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the European Union Saturday to abandon the "one China" policy, according to a press release issued by the Presidential Office.
Chen made the appeal in a pre-recorded video address to the inauguration of the Marco Polo Club formed by pro-Taiwan lawmakers of 25 E.U. member nations and of the European Parliament in London.

Chen said in his speech that the "one China" policy adopted by the E.U. prevents him from visiting the E.U. member nations, which, he criticized, is not only an unreasonable restriction against a president elected directly by the people of Taiwan but also ignores their basic rights.
It is also ironic to the concept of freedom, democracy and human rights upheld for long by the European nations, Chen stressed.

It was harmful to the spirit of freedom when he was forced to abandon a trip to Denmark in 2001 to receive the "Prize for Freedom" granted by the Liberal International and to commission his wheelchair-bound wife Wu Shu-jen to travel to Strasbourg, France to collect the award on his behalf, Chen went on.

The Republic of China has persistently supported the universal values of freedom, democracy and human rights and hopes that the international community can fairly treat Taiwan with the status it deserves, Chen appealed.
The president also thanked the European lawmakers for the support they have extended to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Nov. 14, or the third day of the tenth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1889: Jawaharlal Nehru, Indian statesman, is born. He was the first prime minister of independent India.
1907: The Kuang Hsu emperor dies, and his aunt, the Empress Dowager Tzu-hsi, orders Henry Pu Yi to be crowned as the Hsuan Tung emperor, the last Ching ruler.
1908: Foul play is suspected in the death of Tzu-hsi, dowager empress of the Ching dynasty.
1908: Joseph McCarthy, U.S. senator who led the Senate inquiries into the backgrounds of alleged communists in the 1950s, is born.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces, resigns to try to bring solidarity to the Nanking-Hankow factions of the Kuomintang.
1935: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt proclaims the Philippine Islands a commonwealth and pledges to grant it independence by 1946.
1940: German aircraft bomb the English city of Coventry, killing more than 1,000 people.
1945: Trials of important Nazi leaders begin to take place in Nuremberg.
1948: Charles Philip Arthur George, the first child of Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh, is born. He is now the Prince of Wales.
1954: The ROC Navy ship "Taiping" is sunk by Communist Chinese torpedoes near Cheking Province.
1954: Gamal Abdel Nasser comes to power in Egypt after Muhammad Naguib lost the presidency.
1963: An entirely new island, formed by the eruption of an underwater volcano, appears about eight kilometers off Iceland's southern coast and is named Surtsey.
1973: Princess Anne of Britain marries Captain Mark Philips at Westminster Abbey.
1974: The Executive Yuan lifts the ban on the construction of buildings over four stories high.
1975: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs reiterates the Republic of China's firm stand against any agreements between the U.S. government and the Communist Chinese regime.
1975: The world's tallest Buddha (132 feet) is dedicated at Fukuangshan in southern Taiwan.
1983: Another Communist Chinese pilot flies his MiG-17 to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to start a new life in the Republic of China. The pilot, identified as Wang Hsueh-cheng, 28, from Henan, lands at the airport at 10:15 a.m.
1983: King Khalid International, the world's largest airport, opens near Riyadh.
1985: Wellington Koo, veteran ROC diplomat and former Chinese ambassador to France, dies at the age of 98.
1986: The Legislative Yuan passes a bill governing the handling of toxic chemicals. Under the new law, any death caused by illegal pollution-causing operations is punishable by a maximum penalty of life imprisonment.
1988: Chien Yi, daughter of Chien Moo, a noted scholar of Chinese national classics, arrives in Taipei, becoming the first mainland compatriot to visit Taiwan in nearly 40 years.
1991: Prince Norodom Sihanouk returns to Cambodia after 13 years in exile.
1991: F.W. de Klerk, president of South Africa, arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1999: The United Nations imposes sanctions against Afghanistan for Kabul's failure to hand over suspected terrorist Osama bin Laden, alleged by the United States to have masterminded the bombings of U.S. embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou meets with visiting Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara to exchange views and experiences on city administration and earthquake prevention.
2000: Israel imposes a siege on Palestinian communities, paralyzing life in the West Bank and Gaza Strip in retaliation for deadly shooting ambushes.
2001: The Taipei-based China Textile Institute (CTI), the Central American Trade Office (CATO) and the Ministry of Economic Affairs jointly sponsor a Central American Night party aimed at encouraging domestic textile companies to invest in that region.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The people turn to benevolent rule as water flows downwards, and as wild beasts run to the wilds."
