DOC.HEADLINE: LEE TO EXPRESS TAIWAN'S GOODWILL AT APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh departed for Santiago, Chile Sunday to participate on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian in the 2004 informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum slated to open Nov. 20.
This will be the third time that the Nobel laureate represents President Chen at an APEC informal leadership summit.

Answering reporters' questions at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Lee said that he will "of course say hello" to mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao during the summit and express Taiwan's and President Chen's goodwill to him.
Lee was accompanied on the flight Sunday by a Taiwan delegation which will take part in this year's APEC ministerial meeting scheduled to open Nov. 17.

The Taiwan delegation, headed by Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh and Finance Minister Lin Chuan, will express Taiwan's willingness to promote multilateral trade mechanisms, free trade agreements, and the establishment of a Free Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific (FTAAP) and the so-called TPBA -- a state-of-the-art enterprise solution to enhance successful data management strategies among the APEC's 21 member economies, according to Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) officials.
Ho and Lin will also hold bilateral talks with their counterparts from Australia, Canada, Chile, Japan, Russia and South Korea to exchange views and ideas on issues of mutual concern.
Other members of the Taiwan delegation include BOFT Director-General Huang Chi-peng and Directorate General of Customs Director-General Yu Shao-wu, the officials said.

The APEC groups 21 countries in the Asia-Pacific region, namely Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, mainland China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN FIRE CHIEFS TO MEET IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The International Fire Chief's Association of Asia (IFCAA) will hold its annual general conference in Taipei next week, organizers said Sunday.

The IFCAA conference will open Wednesday for a three-day run, with new global disaster prevention and relief trends as its main theme, the National Fire Administration (NFA) under the Ministry of the Interior said.
More than 2,000 delegates from 23 IFCAA member states or areas will attend the meeting, NFA officials said.

In addition to a regular IFCAA board meeting, a working-level meeting and a plenary session, a series of lectures and seminars on disaster prevention/relief mechanisms, management systems and relevant technological development will also be held during the three-day period, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL TO EXPLAIN CHEN'S CROSS-STRAIT POLICY AT ICG MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Nov. 13 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior Presidential Office official said Saturday that he will explain President Chen Shui-bian's ideas and policies on cross-Taiwan Strait relations to leading members of the International Crisis Group (ICG).

The ICG, an independent non-profit organization working to prevent conflict via field-based analysis and high-level advocacy, is holding a three-day meeting of its board in Geneva Nov. 13-15. Huang is a Taiwan member of the ICG board.

Huang Chih-fang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, arrived in Geneva Saturday from London, where he attended the inauguration of a pro-Taiwan pan-European organization supported by legislators from various member states of the European Union.

Huang said upon his arrival in Geneva that although he is not sure whether the meeting will discuss cross-strait issues, he will certainly take the opportunity to explain the president's ideas and policies on cross-strait relations as well as the current state of cross-strait relations.

Noting that Chen has formulated since February of this year a set of rational concepts regarding cross-strait relations, the deputy secretary-general said that Taiwan should make the international community better understand these concepts.

The president said in February that he hopes to establish a peaceful and stable interactive framework between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. He also expressed his goodwill in wanting to develop better relations with mainland China in his May 20 inaugural speech and his Double-Tenth National Day speech.

At an expanded meeting of the National Security Council held Nov. 10, Chen also urged Beijing to resume cross-strait dialogue and proposed the establishment of a cross-strait military security consultation mechanism.

The ICG board includes prominent political, diplomatic, business and media figures from countries around the world, including former U.S. National Security Advisor Zbigniew Brzezinski, former U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills, former European Parliament President Pat Cox and former Swiss President Ruth Dreifuss.
The organization is currently chaired by former Finnish President Martti Ahtisaari, while former Australian Foreign Minister Gareth Evans has served as its president since January 2000.
With more than 100 staff members on five continents, the Brussels-based ICG produces regular analytical reports containing practical recommendations targeted at key international decision-makers.
The organization also publishes a monthly bulletin, Crisis Watch, to provide a regular update on the current state of the most significant conflicts and potential conflicts around the globe.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TOUGHENS STANCE AGAINST TAIWAN'S IHR INCLUSION
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Nov.13 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Mainland China has promised to do whatever it can to oppose the inclusion of Taiwan in the International Health Regulations (IHR) after the revisions of the regulations.

WHO member states engaged in a two-week session of inter-governmental working group meetings which began Nov. 1 on revisions of the organization's IHR, with the goal of bringing the regulations up to date and increasing controls on the international spread of infectious disease.

Despite the fact that a proposal made by Nicaraguan delegates to the meetings that could indirectly help Taiwan's participation in the IHR was supported by 16 of the island's diplomatic allies, the United States and other countries, Beijing continued to oppose Taiwan's inclusion in the regulations.

Nicaragua proposed revising Article 65 of the current IHR rules related to the participation of non-members of the WHO, saying that the article should include those territories that have the ability to add to the knowledge pool in health-related matters and that can take on IHR affairs in the same manner as WHO members.

But mainland China and its backers strongly opposed the proposal at the meetings, claiming that the territories do not have the proper legal status to join since the WHO is an intergovernmental organization and the IHR is a convention among nations.

As the differences between the two camps on the proposal could not be resolved during the meetings, the chairman of the meetings decided during the panel discussions Wednesday to shelve the issue pending future discussions.

Nevertheless, Beijing toughened its stance at the last plenary session of the meetings held Nov. 12, and its chief delegate to the meetings, Sha Zukang, said that since the WHO is a special sub-institution of the United Nations, it can only discuss health issues, and not political issues.

Although health issues are important, Sha said, national sovereignty is more important, and the IHR should respect national sovereignty and territorial integrity. "China will never compromise and will do whatever it can to protect (the sovereignty and territorial integrity)," he said.

In order to oppose the "principle of universality" supported by many WHO member states, including the United States, the European Union countries and Canada, Sha even set a precondition at the meeting, claiming that there will be no agreements unless agreement can be reached on all the issues regarding the IHR revisions.

In response to Sha's remarks, the U.S. delegates reiterated their firm stance in support of Taiwan's inclusion in the global health system, saying that nobody can be neglected by the IHR and that the principle of universality is unquestionable.

Due to the lack of consensus being reached on various IHR revision issues at the meetings, the WHO member states decided at the plenary session that they will hold additional working party meetings next February to discuss the IHR revisions proposals.

Analyzing views voiced by WHO members at the meetings, Shen Lyu-shun, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Geneva, has expressed that there is room for Taiwan to make further efforts to push for its inclusion in the IHR, noting that no WHO member can unilaterally deny Taiwan's bid to be included in the regulations because the issues have drawn attention from many WHO members.
Taiwan has so far failed to become a member of the World Health Assembly, the WHO's highest decision-making body, despite years of efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREST FIRE BROUGHT UNDER CONTROL

TEXT.P: A forest fire in the Lishan and Tayuling areas in mountainous central Taiwan has been brought under temporary control, sources from the Tungshih Forestry Management Department reported Sunday afternoon.
The fire, which broke out simultaneously in four places late Saturday afternoon, had engulfed nearly nine hectares of state forest as of noon Sunday, the sources said.
Police, who are continuing their investigations into the cause of the fire, have not ruled out the possibility of arson.

The area ravaged by fire contains mainly Taiwan red pine and yellow cedar, which are both systematically cultivated around Taiwan's mountainous areas, said Chen Yi-huang, director of the Tungshih Forestry Management Department.

Department officials were alerted about the fire at about 7 p.m. Saturday and immediately mobilized 57 firefighters to try to contain the fire in the woods located about 2,400 meters above sea level, Chen said.

About 100 more firefighters were rushed to the scene during Sunday morning, while a firefighting helicopter was also dispatched, with the fire being brought under control by about noon Sunday, according to Chen.

Department officials said they strongly suspect that the fire was started by farmers who had been informed by the National Forestry Bureau in recent months that if they failed to plant 600 trees per hectare under a forestation project, their leased lands would be taken back by the government and all orchards and crops on any leased land taken back by the government are to be destroyed.
A group of farmers staged a protest in front of the Tungshi Forestry Management Department Nov. 11 and appealed to the government for more lenient measures and a longer grace period.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHILDREN HELP WITH NO-SMOKING CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: A group of elementary school children were invited Sunday to help in the campaign to eradicate smoking in Taiwan, officials from the John Tung Foundation said.

After having tried many schemes to bolster the anti-smoking campaign, the John Tung Foundation's Taichung Office in central Taiwan invited the Peitun Elementary School students to pitch in, hoping that adults will be moved by the children's innocence and quit smoking.
The school children, numbering about 30, distributed anti-smoking brochures to adults on the streets and picked up cigarette butts in a park to help clean up the environment.
The John Tung Foundation, a major driving force in Taiwan society devoted to raising public awareness of the hazards of smoking, celebrated its 20th anniversary in May of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND HAS FILES ON TAIWAN RESIDENTS' PERSONAL DATA: DPP LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese intelligence authorities have files on almost all the personal data of Taiwan residents, Legislator Trong Chai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed Sunday.

Chai, together with two other DPP lawmakers, submitted an emergency inquiry to the Executive Yuan, telling the administration about the seriousness of the problem and calling for a quick resolution to the "crisis."

Chai quoted unidentified Taiwan businesspeople in mainland China and intelligence sources as saying recently that mainland Chinese intelligence officials have files on the personal data of almost every resident in Taiwan.

Mainland Chinese intelligence authorities' computers contain data on Taiwan residents' household registration, military service records, vehicle registration and even national health insurance records, Chai claimed.
Mainland authorities also keep files on Taiwan's political parties, military hierarchy line-ups, and high technology research and development sector personnel, Chai asserted.
The data could be smuggled from Taiwan and sold to mainland authorities by unworthy Taiwan officials or stolen by criminal rings who trade the information for certain purposes, Chai claimed.

Chai said that mainland intelligence authorities have established atask force to exclusively focus on Taiwan's upcoming legislative elections, including gathering personal data on the candidates. The task force is even dedicated to trying to influence the elections by having Taiwan businesspeople on the mainland return to Taiwan to vote or to drum up support for candidates that are more to Beijing's liking, he added.
He said this is a pressing issue that the Taiwan people should be concerned with and that should be tackled.

Meanwhile, DPP Legislators Lin Chin-hsing and Chiang Chao-yi said they want the government to "clean up" all possible channels through which important personal data could be smuggled to the mainland and to establish a special task force to find out whether certain government officials have been bribed by Beijing for intelligence information.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATIVE VICTORY NEEDED TO GET BEIJING TO THE TABLE: CHANG

TEXT.P: Mainland China will be willing to resume talks with Taiwan only if the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) gains a clear majority in the Legislative Yuan in the Dec. 11 elections, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said Sunday.
Chang made the remarks while stumping for DPP Legislator Lee Chun-yi who is seeking another three-year term in the southern Tainan County constituency.
Chang said that although the DPP managed to win the presidency in 2000, it has yet to control a clear majority in the legislature.
As a result, Chang said, many aspects of the DPP's political reform agenda and its policy initiatives have been blocked by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan over the past four years.

Chang said he intensely hopes that the "pan-green" camp of the DPP and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- can jointly win a majority in the 225-seat legislature in the upcoming elections. If this goal is accomplished, he said, the DPP will then become a full-fledged ruling party and be able to implement its core agenda.

"Moreover, Beijing would be more willing to resume dialogue with Taiwan to forge cross-strait rapprochement, " Chang said, claiming that the DPP's inability to control a majority in the legislature has been a factor discouraging mainland China from negotiating with the DPP administration.

"If we manage to gain control of the legislature, we'll have an even stronger mandate to negotiate with Beijing, and mainland leaders will no longer be able to ignore the DPP administration's call for peaceful dialogue and engagement," Chang claimed.

Beijing unilaterally suspended dialogue with Taiwan in July 1999 after then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined relations across the Taiwan Strait as a special state-to-state relationship, which Beijing viewed as a move promoting Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN TO GRANT VISA-FREE ENTRY TO ROC CITIZENS FROM NEXT MARCH: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Nov. 14 (CNA) (By Perry Hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Japanese government has tentatively decided to grant visa-free privilege to Taiwan citizens from March 2005, the Japanese Sankei Shimbun daily reported Sunday.

According to the Japanese business newspaper, the Japanese government will come up with a draft revision to its existing exit and entry law to that effect early next year for the Japanese parliament to approve.
Under the current Japanese exit and entry law, the Japanese government can only offer visa-free privilege to citizens of countries with which Japan maintains diplomatic relations.

As Japan switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972, offering visa-free privilege to Republic of China citizens requires an amendment to its existing exit and entry law. The Japanese government has decided to add a clause to the law allowing citizens from "officially designated areas" to enjoy the same visa-free privilege, the Sankei Shimbun said.
The paper further said that once the proposed revision clears the Japanese legislative floor, former ROC President Lee Teng-hui will be able to visit Japan easily.
For fear of offending Beijing, the Japanese government has been reluctant to issue a visa to Lee for a private visit.

The Sankei Shimbun said Japan's decision to grant visa-free privilege to Taiwan citizens is part of its efforts to attract more foreign visitors to an eco-friendly world exposition to be held in the Japanese prefecture Aichi next year. The EXPO 2005 Aichi, Japan will be held March 25-Sept. 25, with the participation of 122 countries and many international organizations, including the United Nations and its affiliates.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO WAR EXPECTED TO BREAK OUT IN TAIWAN STRAIT: EXPERT

TEXT.P: No war is expected to break out between Taiwan and mainland China, although a tense stand-off across the Taiwan Strait is likely to occur, an adviser to the Taipei City Government said in Kuala Lumpur Sunday.

Cheng An-kuo made the remarks while delivering a speech on cross-strait relations at a celebration activity organized by the Alumni Association of the Taipei-based National Chengchi University in Malaysia.

Noting that maintaining stability and peace across the Taiwan Strait serves the interests of the United States, Cheng said that the U.S. government will do its utmost to prevent either of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait from taking any provocative actions that might trigger a war.

U.S. President George W. Bush is expected to push for a resumption in cross-strait dialogue in the year to come following his recent re-election, while ROC President Chen Shui-bian will seek to improve relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Cheng pointed out.

He further said that relations between the United States and mainland China are becoming closer, with the two nations becoming cordial trade and investment partners. In addition, he noted, the Washington and Beijing authorities have also reached a consensus on the anti-terror issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 KILLED, 23 INJURED IN CRASH

TEXT.P: The drivers of a tour bus and a pre-mixed concrete truck were killed and 23 bus passengers were injured when the two vehicles crashed in Taipei County's Juifang township early Sunday morning, police said.
The wounded were rushed to Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Keelung and the Keelung Hospital under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, a police spokesman said.
The bus driver and truck driver were identified as Lin Chin-yi and Huang Ting-li, respectively, he added.
The spokesman further said that police are still investigating the cause of the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR PUBLIC COOPERATION TO WIPE OUT VOTE-BUYING

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged the public Sunday to cooperate with the government to wipe out vote-buying in the run-up to the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
Yu made the appeal at a rally in Taipei, organized by the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) to signify the government's determination to get rid of election bribery.
Noting that 387 hopefuls will vie for 176 regional and aboriginal legislative seats, Yu said the competition in nearly all constituencies is tense and ferocious.
With a view to establishing clean politics, Yu said, law enforcement authorities will gear up to fight against vote-buying.

"We should not let money pollute our politics. We want democracy, not moneyed politics. We should work together to eradicate the corrupt vote-buying practices which used to be rampant in the past, " the premier said.

To upgrade the efficiency of the anti-vote-buying campaign, Yu said, prosecutors and MOJ investigators will begin to work at police offices in cities and counties around the nation 10 days before voting day to facilitate monitoring and investigations into vote-buying charges or suspicious deals.
Yu said ordinary citizens are welcome to provide any information on any suspected vote-buying acts.
"Whoever manages to provide useful leads or clues that result in conviction of any vote-buying case will be offered lucrative cash rewards of up to NT$10 million," Yu added.
Several popular professional baseball stars were invited to join with the premier in striking bats at the rally to symbolize striking at vote-buying acts.
Meanwhile, the Panchiao Prosecutor's Office in Taipei County's Panchiao City also organized a carnival-style street parade Sunday as part of its anti-vote-buying publicity campaign.

During the parade, judicial police officers dressed up as Pao Ching-tien, a legendary judge in ancient China known for his integrity and competence in bringing criminals to justice, to signify their determination to fight vote-buying.

Before the parade, acting Taipei County Magistrate Lin Hsi-yao and several senior prosecutors shot arrows on balloons bearing the words "black-gold politics, " "violence, " and "vote-buying" to reaffirm commitment to ensuring clean elections and clean politics. Marching bands from several high schools in the county and private dancing troupes also joined the parade.

The MOJ has unveiled two TV commercials to warn grassroots campaign workers not to offer bribes to voters on behalf of any candidate and to raise public awareness of the ongoing anti-election bribery campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTH CAMPS TRY TO WOO VOTERS WITH NATIONAL PENSION PLAN ISSUE

TEXT.P: A legislator from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called on voters Sunday to support the party's candidates in the year-end legislative elections in order to see the establishment of a national pension system as soon as possible.

Tsai Huang-liang, whip of the DPP's legislative caucus, said that the Legislative Yuan has failed to deliberate a draft bill on the establishment of a national pension program submitted by the Executive Yuan because the legislature is controlled by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party.

Tsai said that if the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union can win a majority in the Legislative Yuan in the Dec. 11 elections, he is convinced that senior citizens will stand a good chance of receiving a monthly pension of NT$7,500 (US$228).

It is an established policy of the DPP-led government to establish a national pension system, Tsai stressed, adding that the Executive Yuan had brought forward a related draft bill to the legislature for approval as early as in 2002.

Tsai's remarks came one day after President Chen Shui-bian reiterated at a Saturday campaign rally for DPP legislative candidates in central Taiwan the determination of his administration to push for early legislation of a national pension system.
President Chen said that if the "pan-green camp" wins a majority in the legislature, then the monthly subsidy for citizens aged 65 and older will be raised to NT$7,500 (US$227).

In reply to the president's remarks, Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT Central Policy Committee, said it is the DPP legislative caucus that has not worked actively to push for the draft bill because they are worried the clause that citizens below the age of 65 must pay NT$600 monthly into the pension system will have a negative impact on the DPP candidates' chances in the Dec. 11 elections.

Pointing out that the only session to review the bill was convened by KMT Legislator Hsu Chung-hsiung in 2003 after the bill was submitted by the Executive Yuan in 2002, Tseng said the president's words are just a campaign ploy to trick voters into casting their ballots for DPP candidates.

Noting that the KMT legislative caucus has brought forward its own version of a national pension plan, under which citizens will only have to pay monthly fees of NT$480 and will be entitled to NT$10,000 per month after they reach the age of 65, Tseng urged voters to support "pan-blue alliance" legislative candidates in the year-end elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS BUDGET SHOULD BE SLASHED TO IMPROVE SOCIAL WELFARE: KMT CHIEF

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan on Sunday blasted the Democratic Progressive Party administration's NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement special budget plan, saying defense spending should be cut to provide more funds for the welfare of disadvantaged groups.

While stumping for a KMT candidate for the year-end legislative elections in Hsintien City, Taipei County, Lien noted that Taiwan must procure adequate arms systems to build up the nation's defense capabilities, but added that arms procurement will be in vain if the government fails to effectively deal with political, economic and diplomatic affairs.

Lien noted that the special budget for arms procurement from the United States should be slashed to help those who cannot afford to pay lunch fees for their school children or national insurance premiums. He added that since the DPP came to power in May 2000, the nation's debt has risen to NT$4.2 trillion from less than NT$2 trillion when the KMT was in power.

Huang Chih-hsiung, a KMT candidate for an at-large legislative seat and taekwondo silver medalist at the 2004 Athens Olympic Games, was also present at the mass rally to mark the inauguration of KMT candidate Lo Ming-tsai's campaign headquarters.
The KMT chairman called on voters to support Lo and Huang, who he described as being "professional, vital, enthusiastic and efficient" young men, in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
Meanwhile, Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT Central Policy Committee, also said that the proposed NT$610.8 billion special budget should be halved to subsidize social welfare budgets.

Stressing that the KMT supports an arms procurement plan to be carried out under the principles of transparency, rationality and serviceability, Tseng noted that the proposed special budget completely runs counter to the three principles.

Tseng noted that Premier Yu had said during a visit to Panama in 2002 that the arms procurement plan would cost only NT$280 billion, but that after the March 20 presidential election, the budget for the procurement plan skyrocketed to NT$610.8 billion.
He added that the KMT legislative caucus insists that the budget be reduced by NT$300 billion, with the funds saved to be used to help low-income families.

Tseng's remarks came one day after President Chen Shui-bian condemned the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party for boycotting the inclusion of the special arms procurement budget bill on the agenda of the Legislative Yuan before the legislature went into a one-month recess last Wednesday in preparation for the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

The Executive Yuan proposed in June to buy six batteries of Patriot-III anti-missile systems, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft from the United States with a NT$610.8 billion special budget to be paid for over a 15-year period starting in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE REPRESENTATIVE VISITS KINMEN

TEXT.P: Singapore's Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew is welcome to visit the Republic of China-held frontline island of Kinmen again, Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng said Sunday.

Lee Chu-feng extended his invitation to the influential former Singaporean prime minister while meeting with Ker Sin Tze, Singapore's resident representative to Taiwan, who was on a two-day visit to Kinmen.
Lee Chu-feng recalled that Lee Kuan Yew made a visit to Kinmen on Feb. 28, 1981 in the company of then-ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo.

"We welcome him to visit Kinmen again," Lee Chu-feng said, adding that Lee Kuan Yew may be able to travel to Xiamen in mainland China's Fujian Province from Kinmen via the direct "mini three links" shipping route.
Ker said he will convey Lee Chu-feng's invitation to Lee Kuan Yew.
Singapore has some 100,000 residents of Kinmen origin, Ker said, adding that many of them have outstanding career achievements.

Lee Chu-feng told Ker that mainland Chinese authorities have agreed to allow Fujian residents to make sightseeing trips to Kinmen via direct voyage before the end of this year. The move will help boost Kinmen's tourist and economic development, Lee Chu-feng said.

In addition to exchanging views with Lee on the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait, Ker also toured major tourist attractions and war relics in Kinmen, which lies closer to Fujian than to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY ZOO SIGNS COOPERATIVE PACT WITH JAPANESE ZOO

TEXT.P: Taipei City Zoo formed cooperative ties with Tama Zoological Park in Tokyo, Japan Sunday to promote bilateral animal exchanges and cooperation in conservation technology development.

Taipei City Zoo Director Chen Pao-chung and Tama Zoological Park Director Yuuji Seki signed the cooperative agreement in Taipei on behalf of the two sides. The Japanese zoo presented a pair of lesser pandas to the Taipei zoo to mark the establishment of cooperative ties.

Chen said the Taipei City Zoo hopes to learn from the Japanese zoological park in animal conservation, breeding and feeding. The recent death of a koala provided by Australia has caused much concern among local animal fans, Chen said, adding that Tama Zoological Park has more than 20 years of experience in raising koala and that the Taipei zoo can learn from Japan's experience in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP NOT TO RECOMMEND CONTROL YUAN CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will not recommend any hopeful for the Control Yuan seats, a senior party official said Sunday.

As Control Yuan members must transcend partisan stances and maintain neutrality and impartiality in supervising government operations in line with constitutional provisions, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said the DPP will refrain from recommending any aspirant for Control Yuan seats.
"We'll give the new ombudsmen recommendation panel the greatest possible room to select qualified hopefuls for President Chen Shui-bian to nominate," Chang said.
Chang's announcement is part of the DPP's efforts to defuse opposition parties' concern about the ruling party's possible dominance of the selection of new ombudsmen.

The tenure of the current third-term Control Yuan members will expire Jan. 31, 2005. President Chen Shui-bian is expected to nominate 29 fourth-term Control Yuan members later this year. According to the present version of the Additional Articles of the Constitution, nominations for the Control Yuan require the consent of the Legislative Yuan.

President Chen has named Vice President Annette Lu to serve as convener of a special panel to screen the qualifications of hopefuls recommended by various social or academic groups and come up with a list of qualified aspirants for his reference.

In addition to Lu, the panel has five other members -- incumbent Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien and Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang, as well as Chang Chien-pang, a senior adviser to the president, Hsiao Hsin-huang, a national policy adviser to the president, and Nita Ing, chairwoman of Taiwan High-Speed Railway, who is also an adviser to the president. Chien has made clear that he will retire from public service after his current tenure expires.

During a luncheon with other panelists and incumbent Control Yuan members Friday, Lu said she will see to it that the recommendation panel abides by the principles of openness, transparency, impartiality and fairness in recommending candidates for the Control Yuan seats.

Lu further said the panel's ultimate goal is to recommend those most qualified and suitable to serve in the Control Yuan -- the nation's supreme watchdog body responsible for correcting officials at all levels and generally monitoring the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: LONG-TERM STABILITY REQUIRES EFFORTS FROM BOTH SIDES: ROC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Nov. 14 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior Presidential Office official said Sunday in Geneva that maintaining a durable stability in the Taiwan Strait requires efforts from both sides of the strait, rather than just unilateral actions by Taiwan.

Hung Chih-fang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, made the comments while explaining the current state of cross-Taiwan Strait relations to foreign affairs experts attending the International Crisis Group's (ICG's) meeting of its board being held in Geneva Nov. 13-15. Huang is a Taiwan member of the ICG board.

The Brussels-based group, an independent non-profit organization working to prevent conflict via field-based analysis and high level advocacy, includes prominent political, diplomatic, business and media figures from countries around the world, and is currently chaired by former Finish President Martti Ahtisaari.

Despite the fact that the ICG has not officially discussed cross-strait issues at the meeting as it considers that there is currently no crisis in the Taiwan Strait, Hung still took the opportunity to urge the international community to pay heed to the cross-strait problems.

Pointing out that cross-strait relations have basically not deteriorated over the past four years, Hung said that this is because Taiwan has demonstrated goodwill in wanting to have better relations with mainland China and has not provoked the mainland nor attempted to change the status quo.

However, he also pointed out that there hasn't been an improvement in cross-strait relations during this period, stressing that long-term stability in the Taiwan Strait requires joint efforts by Taipei and Beijing.
Without mainland China's cooperation, it is impossible for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to engage in dialogue, Huang emphasized.
Huang is scheduled to leave Monday for London en route back to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Nov. 15, or the fourth day of the tenth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1777: The U.S. Congress adopts the "Articles of Confederation of Perpetual Union of the United States of America."
1891: Erwin Rommel, the German general who commanded the Afrika Corps in North Africa during World War II, is born.
1920: The League of Nations holds its first plenary session in Geneva.
1930: The fourth plenary session of the Third Central Committee of the Republic of China's nationalist Kuomintang resolves to hold a National People's Convention on May 5, 1931.
1935: The Commonwealth of the Philippines is established, with Manuel Quezon as its first president.
1942: Japanese forces suffer heavy losses at Guadalcanal after three days of sea battles with U.S. forces around the Solomon Islands.
1945: Taipei Imperial University is reorganized and renamed National Taiwan University.
1946: The National Assembly of the Republic of China officially opens in Nanking, attended by 1,355 representatives. Chiang Kai-shek announces the termination of Kuomintang tutelage.
1969: Taipei voters go to the polls to elect city council members for the first time since Taipei became a special municipality July 1, 1967.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan receives Sheikh Mahdi, director-general of the Saudi Arabian Civic Aviation Bureau, who arrives for a three-day visit.
1976: The 11th National Congress of the Kuomintang resolves to carry out the Last Will and Testament of late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1978: An Icelandic Airlines DC-8 passenger plane carrying Indonesian Muslims home from Mecca crashes in Sri Lanka, killing 175 passengers and eight crew members.
1984: Law enforcement officials carry out an anti-crime drive, dubbed "Operation Clean-Sweep," and round up key members of ROC crime syndicates.
1985: British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Irish leader Garrett Fitzgerald sign the Anglo-Irish Agreement, which gives the Republic of Ireland a consultative role in the running of Northern Ireland.
1988: Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO), announces the PLO's recognition of Israel's right to exist alongside a Palestinian state.
1990: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces an ROC-Canadian agreement to exchange aviation rights and establish Taipei economic and cultural offices in major Canadian cities.
1991: South African President Frederik Willem de Klerk signs a joint communique with ROC President Lee Teng-hui for closer relations between the two countries.
1991: Two trains collide head-on near Chaochiao Village in Miaoli County, killing 30 people and injuring more than 100 others.
1991: Li Huang, chairman of the Young China Party, dies at the age of 96.
1995: ROC independent presidential hopeful Lin Yang-kang names former Premier Hau Pei-tsun as his running mate.
1997: Noted mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng is released from a 14-year prison term and leaves for the United States the next day.
1999: Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan and Corpus Christi in southern Texas clinch an agreement on sisterhood ties.
1999: Presidential Secretary-General Huang Kun-huei is named as the new secretary-general of the Kuomintang, switching positions with John Chang, the current KMT secretary-general.
1999: The 42nd annual meeting of the International Association of Judges opens in Taipei with about 300 judges from around the world participating.
2000: A Russian-built Antonov enroute to Namibe, southern Angola, crashes near Luanda, killing all 39 aboard.
2001: The former Taipei home of late President Yen Chia-kan is designated a national historical site by a panel of experts under the Ministry of the Interior.
2001: Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, Koo Chen-fu, is awarded an honorary doctorate in law by the prestigious National Taiwan University (NTU) in recognition of his extraordinary contributions to the nation.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "In good years, most of the children of the people are good, and in bad years, most of them are evil. It is not owing to their natural endowments conferred by heaven that they are thus different. It is owing to the circumstances in which they appear so."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES VANUATU CABINET'S APPROVAL OF FORMAL TIES WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed welcome Monday to the Vanuatuan Cabinet's approval of the joint communique that Vanuatuan Prime Minister Serge Vohor and ROC Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen signed in Taipei Nov. 3 on the establishment of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.
The Vanuatu Council of Ministers' approval Monday reaffirmed the validity of the formal diplomatic ties between Taiwan and the South Pacific island country, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said.

Currently, Taiwan diplomatic personnel in Vanuatu are exchanging views with Prime Minister Vohor on substantive and technical matters surrounding the newly-established diplomatic relations, including the establishment of embassies in each other's country, Lu said.

Sources from the Vanuatu capital of Port-Vila said Monday that the Vanuatuan Council of Ministers gave its consent to the communique recognizing Taiwan as a formal diplomatic ally, although several ministers had expressed concerns that switching diplomatic recognition from Beijing to Taipei may affect Vanuatu's relations with mainland China.

It was also learned that Prime Minister Vohor will make a television address to the nation later Monday to formally announce the government's decision on establishing formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

Beijing has been working since Nov. 3 to get Vanuatu to drop its decision to establish formal diplomatic ties with the ROC. It has claimed that Vohor's signing of the joint communique with Foreign Minister Chen in Taipei was a"personal act" without the prior approval of the Vanuatuan government.

Mainland Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Zhang Qiyue also claimed at a news conference last week that Vanuatu's Cabinet "has decided to revoke the so-called communique on the establishment of diplomatic relations between Vanuatu and Taiwan."

According to MOFA officials, it is believed that People's Republic of China Ambassador to Vanuatu Bao Shusheng will continue to negotiate with the Vanuatuan government to try to get it to drop its decision, and that Beijing may choose to sever formal ties with Vanuatu shortly based on its "one China" policy if Bao is not given a satisfactory answer.
With a population of about 210,000, Vanuatu lies 2,250 kilometers northeast of Sydney, Australia. It is the ROC's 27th diplomatic ally.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS BETTER CRISIS MANAGEMENT ON WATER RESOURCES

TEXT.P: Taiwan must improve its water resources crisis management in the face of frequent natural disasters and accidents, participants at a seminar said Monday.

Speaking at a seminar attended by experts and specialists from Taiwan and the United States on business, engineering and technology, Yang Wei-pu, chief engineer with the Cabinet-level Water Resources Agency, said a spate of typhoons and accidents over the past year has shown the need for crisis management involving dams, reservoirs and catchments.

Yang mentioned some of the problems: pipelines connecting the Nanhua Reservoir in southern Taiwan ruptured; a reservoir in the outlying island of Kinmen was contaminated with rat poison in June; a floodgate failed at the Liyutan Reservoir in central Taiwan during a typhoon in early July; and the turbidity of the water in the Shihmen Reservoir in Taoyuan County became unprecedentedly high after Typhoon Aere pounded northern Taiwan with record rainfall in August.

Also speaking at the seminar -- formally known as the 2004 Biannual ROC-USA Business Conference and the Modern Engineering and Technology Seminar 2004 -- Dr. Chein-chi Chang from the United States said that Taiwan and America are different in terms of water resources crisis management.

While the U. S. government has striven to protect the security of dams around the United States from terrorist attacks, Taiwan authorities should pay closer attention to reservoir safety, mainly against damage caused by natural disasters, Chang noted.

Dr. Junn-ling Chao, also from the United States, has 40 years of experience in tap water engineering and sewage systems. He took tap water as an example to explain that every junction, ranging from catchments to water tanks, of a running water system is crucial in terms of water safety and security since errors or accidents could happen anywhere along the line.

As to the issue of water pipeline ruptures, Chao said that water companies should have their own information, detection and monitoring systems, plus maintenance personnel in addition to guards and firefighting and medical units to maintain safe and efficient water supplies.
Chao suggested that Taiwan reservoir authorities use computers to monitor areas susceptible to ruptures and work out crisis management policies by simulating failures in computer models.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ENJOYS SUPERB ADVANTAGES IN CHINESE DIGITAL CONTENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan has unique advantages when it comes to Chinese digital content, an information official pointed out Monday.

Huang Kuo-chun, executive vice president of the semi-official Institute for Information Technology, made the remarks during the opening of the two-day, 27th biennial ROC-USA conference and the 20th modern engineering and technology seminar 2004.

Huang said that it is estimated that by 2006, digital content market will have a production value of NT$370 billion (US$11.2 billion) and Taiwan has the opportunity to become the design, development and integration center of Chinese digital content.

He noted that Taiwan has considerable advantages in leading the Chinese digital content market, citing as an example that Taiwan has accumulated considerable capital, talented workers and technology in the information industry over the years, and has established an industry chain that has combined the IT upper- and lower-stream sectors.
"This experience can be transplanted to the digital content industry, " he said, saying that it will be a great help to Taiwan's entry into the digital content market.

In addition, he noted that Taiwan culture is a fertile breeding ground for nurturing the digital content industry, noting that with Taiwan's unique experience and geography, it has integrated Chinese culture, the ocean culture of the aboriginal people, the colonial culture of the Dutch, and the Western culture it has been exposed to over the long term. These various cultures have converged in Taiwan, he said.

Moreover, compared with Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaysia, and Shanghai, Taiwan has the most democratic politics, open society and pluralistic culture in the world, which are the main ingredients to develop into a society centered on digital content, he said.
He said that he believes Chinese around the world need a digital content center, and Taiwan enjoys a unique edge in terms of industrial, social and cultural conditions.

Since Taiwan has the edge in being of the same race and having the same language as those on mainland China, he said that whether it is European or American companies wanting to make inroads into the Chinese market, or Chinese manufacturers wanting to enter the world market, Taiwan can provide assistance and service closer to market needs.
He concluded by saying that by 2006, Taiwan's digital content industry will create a production value of N$370 billion, with 3,000 companies and 70,000 workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME CHILDREN OF CROSS-CULTURAL MARRIAGES HAVE DEVELOPMENT PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: About 90 percent of the children of foreign brides of Taiwan citizens suffer slowness in cognition and language development, the Chiayi Christian Hospital (CCH) reported Monday.

CCH specialists called for the overseas spouses and their Taiwanese families not to let these young children, the so-called "new Taiwanese," miss the most crucial time of their treatment due to the adults' ignorance or the language barrier.
About 300,000 foreign brides have arrived in Taiwan and their number is increasing, mostly as a result of marriages arranged by venal cross-border marriage brokers, CCH specialists said.

Under this system, overseas young women, mostly from poor families in Southeast Asian countries, can fly into Taiwan within two weeks or one month and become Taiwan citizens' wives in a very short time, soon changing their roles from a young woman to a stranger's wife, and a mother and daughter-in-law in a Taiwanese family.

Language barriers may be the root of many problems for foreign brides in Taiwan -- ranging from intense husband-wife relations, confrontations between them and their mothers-in-law, and adverse impact on the education of their children -- but other factors, including too short a time for the foreign brides to develop mutual understanding with their Taiwanese families; big cultural differences; and lack of social support, have also contributed to the mothers of the "new Taiwanese" finding themselves in difficult situations without satisfactory help, the specialists said.

Chiayi Christian Hospital, which grouped with 12 other social groups and medical institutions to form the Around Taiwan Health Care Alliance this year, recently conducted a poll of therapists of early-stage treatment, psychologists, and social work specialists around the island to further investigate the plight of foreign brides and their "new Taiwanese" children.
The poll found that 62 percent of the respondents believe that social psychological factors are the prime reason causing the "new Taiwanese" to suffer in their development.
Some 37 percent of the respondents pointed to congenital diseases and genetic abnormalities as reasons behind the cognitive and language slowness.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS ALASKA GOVERNOR

Chen said Taiwan has appointed representatives of various sectors to a committee aimed at promoting the cooperation program.

He thanked the Alaska Legislature for passing resolutions in support of Taiwan's participation in the World Health Assembly as an observer and of the signing of a free trade agreement between Taiwan and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MISSION ATTENDS IACP CONFAB TO BOOST JUDICIAL COOPERATION
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Nov. 14 (CNA) (By Lu-sheng Chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A large Taiwan delegation composed of 10-plus senior law enforcement officers is currently attending an annual conference of the International Association of Chief of Police (IACP) being held in Los Angeles.

Members of the delegation include Chang Chi, director of the foreign affairs department of the National Police Administration under the Ministry of the Interior, Yeh Mao-sheng, director of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau, and Central Police University Vice President Lo Yi-an.

IACP Chairman Joseph Polisar extended a warm welcome to the Taiwan delegation at the opening ceremony, saying that engagements between Taiwan and U.S. police and judicial authorities have become ever closer in recent years. There have been many successful cases in crime-fighting through Taiwan-U.S. cooperation in the past few years, Polisar said, adding he believes that bilateral cooperation will further strengthen in the years ahead.

Polisar, who has been to Taiwan on many occasions, pointed out that anti-terrorist operations have become ever more important in the wake of the 911 terrorist attacks and that judicial and police authorities of major countries around the world should increase contacts and forge information exchange mechanisms to enhance operational efficiency.
More than 10,000 law enforcement officers from 113 countries around the world are attending the four-day IACP annual conference whose themes include crime-fighting and the war on terrorism.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WILL NOT ASSIGN BLAME FOR 'SOFT COUP': TOP AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has no intention of assigning culpability for what he alleges was a "soft coup" attempt after the presidential election and only seeks to put an end to the chaos of the nation via the ballot box in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, the president's top aide said Monday.

Su Tseng-chang, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, was referring to President Chen's remarks Sunday when he was stumping for legislative candidates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who will compete in the Dec. 11 elections in Taipei County.

The president first attacked the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) for being unwilling to concede defeat in the March 20 presidential election. He then proceeded to say that after the election, there was a reported "seven-day coup" wherein several retired ranking generals advised active generals to resign or go on sick leave.
This, the president said, was not a military coup, but a "soft coup."
Chen said that if they had been successful, the consequences would have been unthinkable.

Su agreed that after the presidential election, some in the opposition camp tried to lobby active generals to resign to create a social disturbance. "This was by no means just a rumor, as such an atmosphere did in fact exist," Su added.

"This shows that Taiwan's drive to separate political affiliation with military effectiveness has been successful. Taiwan's military and generals now pledge their allegiance to the nation, and democratic development has solidly taken root," he said.

He said that compared with the "pan-blue alliance" who mobilized supporters to demonstrate in front of the Presidential Office and who have distributed "bulletgate" pamphlets over the election-eve shooting of President Chen in an attempt to smear the president, the military generals have more democratic training.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun also said that since the presidential election, the KMT and the PFP have "used every means" to fight the result, including the relatively little-used attempt of a "soft coup."

Regarding any evidence to support the president's theory of a "soft coup, " or whether the government has a list of the retired generals who were alleged to have been pulling the strings behind the "coup attempt, " the premier said only that he has kept abreast of the matter and he has been in close contact with the president since that time, adding, "Some parts are not appropriate to make public now."
Meanwhile, the KMT lashed out at the president's remarks as "despicable," urging him to publish evidence to back up his claim.
Huang Teh-fu, KMT whip in the Legislative Yuan, said that if the president has evidence to substantiate his words, he should produce it, instead of wantonly smearing opposition parties.
He wondered how the Ministry of National Defense could put up with remarks so damaging to its image, saying that the ministry should get tough and fight against such slander.
Liu Wen-hsiung, PFP whip in the legislature, called President Chen's "coup" wording is his own "fantasy," and said if Chen knew the truth behind the coup, why hasn't he arrested those responsible?

President Chen said in his speech at the anniversary celebration of a senior high school in Chiayi, southern Taiwan April 25 that with god's blessing of the nation, he was able to pass three major hurdles: surviving the March 19 shooting, winning the March 20 presidential election by a narrow margin, and surviving the "seven-day coup" after March 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT BUSH RECOGNIZES TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC ACHIEVEMENTS

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush has recognized Taiwan's role in the global trade and economic system, saying the island's financial reforms and high-tech industrial development have created abundant business opportunities for business people from both countries.

Bush made the commendation in a congratulatory message read at the opening of an ROC-USA economic conference and modern engineering and technology seminar being held at the Taipei International Convention Center.

In his written message, Bush lauded Taiwan for its relentless efforts to promote industrial upgrading and international trade. Nowadays, Bush said, Taiwan plays an important role in global trade and economics. Bush also praised Taiwan's achievements in democratic development and its continued efforts in financial reforms and high-tech industrial development.

President Chen Shui-bian also issued a written message marking the opening of the two-day conference which brought together many high-tech industry executives, crisis management experts and trade promoters from Taiwan and the United States to discuss a range of relevant topics.

At a time when the global economy faces challenges from rising oil prices and terrorist attacks, Chen said he hopes the conference participants can offer valuable advice and initiatives to help Taiwan break bottlenecks in high-tech development and further boost Taiwan-U.S. trade and economic cooperation.

Douglas Paal, director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, delivered a speech at the opening ceremony.

Paal said the United States has long been one of Taiwan's most important trading partners. Although the United States is no longer Taiwan's top export outlet, it remains Taiwan's second-largest market and bilateral economic ties have gotten even closer through technology transfers and the formation of joint-venture partnerships.

Wang Chung-yu, president of the ROC-USA Economic Council, which organized the ongoing conference, said Taiwan is at a critical juncture of industrial upgrading. He said he hopes the conference can help formulate feasible strategies and measures to contribute to Taiwan's high-tech industrial development and corporate restructuring and crisis management.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, US HELD BILATERAL TALKS ON COMPETITION LAW

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the United States held their annual bilateral talks on competition law Monday in Taipei, officials from the Fair Trade Commission (FTC) said Monday.

FTC Vice Chairman Chen Chi-yuan and Makan Delrahim, vice director of the Anti-trust Division under the US Department of Justice, exchanged experiences on their handling of anti-trust cases at the conference, according to an anonymous FTC official.

The FTC official said Taiwan and the U.S. exchanges views on the implementation of competition law regularly because the globalization of trade has made the contents and enforcement of an individual country's competition law a cause of concern of other countries.
As close trade partners, the bilateral conference is the fourth of its kind, and FTC Chairman Huang Tsung-lo went to Washington, D.C. for the conference last year.
Meanwhile, the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association and the US-Taiwan Business Council will jointly organize an Anti-trust Seminar in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Tuesday.
Both Taiwan and U.S. officials in charge with the enforcement of competition law will take part in the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP EXPECTS HI-TECH SECTOR TO BUILD UP 'SOFT POWER' FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called on the hi-tech sector to help Taiwan build up "soft power" Monday.
Addressing the 10th anniversary celebration of the Powerchip Semiconductor Corp., Lu said her so-called "soft power" means "cooperation" and "sharing."
Lu said the 21st Century is an era for cooperation and sharing, which she said are the characteristics of technological industries.
Lu urged the hi-tech sector to help the country expand its foreign relations and integrate with the cultural and creative sectors to face "the era of knowledge warfare."

She pointed out that the World Economic Forum has rated Taiwan as the fourth most competitive country in the world, with its technology and innovation indexes rated in second and third place, respectively, which she said shows that the development of Taiwan's hi-tech industries has won international recognition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOMBS FOR TWO LATE PRESIDENTS SET FOR COMPLETION NEXT JUNE

TEXT.P: Tombs for the late President Chiang Kai-shek and his son and successor Chiang Ching-kuo in Taipei County are scheduled to be completed by late June, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Monday.
The MND's Bureau of Armament and Acquisition (BAA) said that after many twists and turns, the process of bidding and contract operations for the tombs have finally been completed.
Geographical surveys will next have to be carried out to ensure soil conservation, while at the same time, design work will be done and approval obtained from the families of the two late presidents.

The widow of Chiang Ching-kuo sent a letter to the MND early this year asking it to help with the relocation of the two Chiangs -- who are embalmed in interim mausoleums in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan -- to the Wutzushan military cemetery in Hsichih, Taipei County, for permanent interment.

After the approval of President Chen Shui-bian, the MND, the Ministry of the Interior and various other government agencies began to plan for the relocation and burial in line with the state funeral law. The BAA was in charge of the bidding and contracting operations.
These failed several times, and there were also heated debates on whether to have state funerals for the two Chiangs before the issue was hammered out.

It is understood that the MND's Combined Logistics Command, which is in charge of the Wutzushan military cemetery, known for its serene and beautiful views, offered three sites, sized 950, 1,200 and 250 pings (one ping is equal to 3.3 square meters) . The two larger plots are on hilly terrain and pose difficulties in construction, while the smaller one is on flatter ground, which is the one chosen by the families.

Chiang Kai-shek fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing the Chinese mainland to the Mao Zedong-led communist party in a bloody civil war. He died in 1975 and his remains were embalmed in a temporary mausoleum at Tzuhu in Taoyuan, awaiting a proper burial on the mainland.

Chiang ruled Taiwan with an iron fist, using martial law to suppress democracy. However, some view him as a hero for keeping the island out of reach of the Chinese communists and claim that it was he who fostered Taiwan's freewheeling market economy.

Chiang Ching-kuo is respected for ending martial law in 1987, shortly before his death, thus unleashing the democratic forces that broke his family's firm grip on power and eventually ended the Kuomintang's half-century of rule over Taiwan.
Chiang died in 1988 and his remains also lie embalmed in an interim mausoleum at Touliao in Taoyuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Brown to launch attack on Europe over the failure of single market.
BRITISH firms are losing out in the battle for the 1,000 billion European public works market because other governments are unfairly discriminating against them and rigging the rules to help their own companies, a report will disclose today. Gordon Brown will tomorrow call on Europe to reform its single market rules after a year-long review commissioned by him found that huge obstacles stand in the way of fair competition in European markets, harming British and other EU businesse.
Financial Times: Blair stands by Bush alliance.
Europe must unite with the US under the banner of democracy to defeat the scourge of terrorism around the world, Tony Blair will urge on Monday. The prime minister will defy leftwing critics of the war in Iraq to mount an impassioned defence of Britain's "special relationship" with the US.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI FORMS A GOODWILL TROUPE TO GREET FOREIGN FUSAL PLAYERS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou mobilized a "goodwill ambassador" troupe Monday to welcome futsal teams from 16 countries, including Spain, Italy and the United States, who will compete in the upcoming Chinese Taipei 2004 tournament of the FIFA Futsal World Championship Nov. 21-Dec 5.

The troupe is made up of students from 16 senior and junior high schools and elementary schools in the capital city in the hope that they will present the Taiwanese people's hospitality and kindness to the foreign athletes, according to the city's Education Department, which organized the group.

The young goodwill ambassadors will welcome the arrival of the teams and see them off at the airport afterward, and will also cheer them on at the stadiums where the five-a-side games will be staged, Taipei officials said, noting that they have even learned greetings and folk songs in different languages for the mission.

Meanwhile, the mayor and Taipei Education Director Wu Ching-ji jointly inaugurated a Web site for the Futsal tournament to offer information and knowledge on the indoor soccer game, as well as the history, geography and folk customs of the competing countries.
There is also an on-line vote on the national learning Web site http://futsal.tp.edu.tw for soccer fans to predict the champions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS BRIGHT STAR IN ECONOMIC SHOWING: WEF ECONOMIST

TEXT.P: With the world's fourth-most competitive economy and the first in Asia, Taiwan is a bright star in terms of its economic achievements, a World Economic Forum (WEF) economist said Monday.

Augusto Lopez-Claros, chief economist and director of the WEF's Global Competitiveness Programme, made the remarks in a speech in Taipei, citing the latest Global Competitiveness Report released by the WEF in October.
Lopez-Claros said that according to the report, Taiwan's performance has been brilliant, especially in the field of technological development.

While Taiwan's technological development has expedited the country's economic development over the past two decades, the island's technology index now ranks second in the world after the United States, Lopez-Claros pointed out.
Despite the small size of the country, Taiwan has a thriving IT industry, with some products taking up to 60-percent shares of the global market, he said.
However, he said there is still room for improvement in Taiwan's government sector, suggesting that Taiwan work to solve the problems of deficit and emigration of businesses.
Taiwan moved up a notch to fourth place this year in terms of the WEF's Growth Competitiveness Index, according to the WEF report.

The nation scored second in technology competitiveness, an advance of one notch from last year, and it grabbed ninth spot in terms of its macro-economic situation, an improvement from 18th place last year.
But it lost ground in terms of the quality of public institutions, falling to 27th from 21st.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER CZECH PRESIDENT TO ARRIVE FRIDAY FOR SIX-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: Former Czech Republic President Vaclav Havel and his wife will arrive in Taipei Friday for a six-day visit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Monday.
The Havels are coming to Taiwan at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian and the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, MOFA officials said.

During his stay, Havel will meet with Chen, Vice President Annette Lu, academics and literary figures. Chen will decorate him with a medal in recognition of his contribution to the promotion of Taiwan-Czech Republic ties and his versatile career achievements, particularly his courage in keeping alive the "flame of democracy" when his country was under communist rule.
Havel will also deliver a speech and receive an honorary doctorate from National Chengchi University. His itinerary also includes meetings with local academics, artists and literary celebrities.
A resourceful man, Havel has had multifaceted roles throughout his career -- a poet, playwright, dissident, thinker and politician. He formally ended his 12-year presidency in February 2003.

After his retirement, MOFA officials said, Havel immediately planned to visit Taiwan. But he later chose to stay in his country to help stabilize the domestic political situation following the transfer of power. Early this year, Havel planned to visit Taiwan and several other Asian countries to promote his new book. However, his Asian tour stopped in India and he canceled the remaining itinerary due to health reasons.

Havel played a pivotal role in his country's "velvet revolution" of 1989. He used his literary and theatrical creations to kindle and keep the flame of democracy burning amidst a storm of repression and autocracy during communist rule. He eventually led his country to break the shackles of communist suppression and move toward democracy. During his presidency, he continued working hard to consolidate the Czech Republic's democratic system as well as promote human rights and social justice, earning wide respect and admiration from his fellow countrymen.
MOFA officials said Havel has been very friendly toward Taiwan because of his conviction in democracy and courage in standing up to mainland China's pressure.

During his presidency, Havel invited then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui to attend an international forum in Prague. Incumbent ROC first lady Wu Shu-chen and former Vice President Lien Chan have also visited the Czech Republic. In 1995, Havel spoke for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations at an annual U.N. General Assembly plenary session. He is one of the few world leaders willing to publicly throw support behind Taiwan without fearing Beijing's backlash.

To welcome Havel's visit, Taipei National University of the Arts has designated November as its "Month of Vaclav Havel Art." In addition to performing Havel's plays, the university has also organized many other activities during the period of Nov. 5-24, including a Havel book fair and a series of seminars on Havel's artistic and political achievements, as well as a Czech film festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: DECISION ON WHETHER TO SUSPEND TRUTH COMMISSION TO BE MADE DEC. 15

TEXT.P: The Council of Grand Justices decided Monday to hand down its decision Dec. 15 on whether to suspend the Truth Investigation Commission as requested by lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The commission, formed under a statute crafted and railroaded through the Legislative Yuan by the opposition parties, has been branded unconstitutional by the DPP, whose lawmakers asked the Council of Grand Justices to rule on its constitutionality and to suspend its operations until a final ruling on its constitutionality has been made.

DPP lawmakers claim that the commission, set up to investigate the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian, infringes on the constitutional power of other government agencies and should be suspended immediately.

The council, which is responsible for interpreting the Constitution, has never been asked to suspend the operation of any commission with such urgency and have sought opinions from the attorneys of the DPP lawmakers about its authority to do so.
The council decided after a meeting earlier the day to come up with a decision on whether to suspend the commission Dec. 15 and to rule on whether the statute is invalid by Dec. 30.

Meanwhile, Shih Chi-yang, the convener of the Truth Investigation Commission, shrugged off the news, saying he will press on with the investigation regardless of the Council of the Grand Justices' decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60% OF PARENTS UNSURE OF GLOBAL COMPETITIVE EDGE OF THEIR CHILDREN

TEXT.P: More and more parents are having their children learn English at an early age, hoping to foster their competitive edge in the world, although over 60 percent said they are not confident they will achieve their goal, according to the results of a survey released Monday.

The prestigious Commonwealth Magazine conducted the survey in mid-October to try to learn about the global perspective of Taiwan residents and parents' attitude toward English learning for their children. The monthly sampled residents over the age of 18 on the first question, collecting 1,079 effective replies, while asking parents with children under 12 on the second, obtaining 763 effective samples.

On English learning, parents with higher academic background tend to have their children learn English earlier, with 54.3 percent of parents with masters degrees sending their children to study English at nursery school or even earlier.
Sixty-one percent of the parents also think it is better to study English at an early age, while 78 percent said good English is important for a child's future.

The survey also found that over 60 percent of Taiwan people have been overseas, with 90 percent of the respondents having been elsewhere in Asia and 29 percent having been to North America. Only 2 percent had been to the Middle East.
Nearly 90 percent go abroad for travel, 16 percent for work, 6 percent to visit family members and only 2 percent for studying.
Sixty-two percent of those polled cited the best part of their foreign experience as broadening their horizons, followed by 44 percent who cited enhancement of their understanding of other cultures.

The survey also found that nearly 80 percent did not know the location of the United Nations headquarters, 60 percent did not know Athens is in Europe, and over half were unaware that the mainland Chinese President is Hu Jintao.

The international events Taiwan people are familiar with are mostly related to wars, with 80 percent of the respondents aware that the U.S. led an attack on Iraq last year and 77 percent aware that the United States dropped atomic bombs in Japan near the end of the Second World War.
Knowledge of wars was followed by economic issues, with nearly 50 percent aware of the World Trade Organization and 42 percent aware that Germany now uses the euro as its currency.
Overall, the survey found that 73 percent of the respondents believe their global competitive capability is insufficient.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTED ORTHOPEDIC PHYSICIAN TAPPED AS DOH VICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Hou Sheng-mao, director of the department of medicine of National Taiwan University (NTU) , has been tapped to serve as vice minister of the Department of Health (DOH) , Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Monday.
According to Chen Chi-mai, DOH Minister Chen Chien-jen will soon complete the formalities regarding the appointment of Hou as his deputy.
Hou, a noted orthopedic physician, will fill the position left vacant by Chang Hung-jen who resigned last month amid controversy over national health insurance-related reform measures.

Media reports said Hou is a mentor of President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, who is now an orthopedic physician at NTU Hospital. The reports further speculated that Hou will be promoted to the position of DOH minister at the end of this year, when Chen Chien-jen returns to his NTU teaching position.

Chen Chi-mai dismissed the reports, pointing out that as the Cabinet will resign en masse before the Feb. 1 inauguration of the new Legislative Yuan to be elected Dec. 11, it is meaningless to speculate as to who will be the next DOH minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Shooting Breaks Out in Gaza Around Likely Arafat Successor.
A group of Palestinians unleashed deadly bursts of gunfire as Mahmoud Abbas arrived at a service for Yasir Arafat.
The Wall Stree Journal: Dow Jones Buy CBS MarketWatch For $519 Million.
Hoping to expand its online presence, Dow Jones & Co. said late Sunday it has reached an agreement to pay $519 million to buy MarketWatch Inc., parent of the financial news Web site CBS MarketWatch.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA PRESIDENT TO SERVE AS PTS PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Central News Agency President Hu Yuan-hui has been selected as the president of the Public Television Service (PTS), PTS officials announced at a press conference Monday.
In the first joint conference of the directors and supervisors of PTS, a vote passed unanimously 12-0 to appoint Hu, who was nominated by PTS Chairman Chen Chun-shan, to serve as the new president.

Hu said his new post will be "significant and challenging work, " adding that PTS has passed the ground-laying stage and is entering a development period. He said he is committed to promoting PTS as "world-class public television."
Hu expressed regret at leaving CNA, saying that during his more than two years in the news agency, he has learned a lot.
"CNA has significance in its existence and values of development," he said, "but I have to take up new challenges ahead."

CNA Chairman Su Tzen-ping noted that Hu has contributed a great deal to the transformation and progress of CNA over the past two years and expressed hope that PTS can cooperate with CNA in other fields in the future.

Hu, 46, holds a masters degree in politics from National Chengchi University and has served as reporter and editor-in-chief for various news media. Before he came to CNA in July 2002, he was president of the Taiwan Television Enterprise.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO PROMOTE YOUNG CIVIL SERVANTS IN RESTRUCTURING DRIVE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Monday the government will select high-caliber young civil servants with broad perspective and forward vision for special training in preparation for sweeping restructuring of the administrative framework.
Yu made the remarks in a speech delivered at the opening of a meeting of the personnel chiefs of various government agencies.
Yu said the ultimate goal of the ambitious government restructuring plan is not just to reduce the number of government departments or adjust the structure.
"The most important goal is to upgrade the government's operational efficiency and improve the nation's overall competitiveness," Yu said.

He outlined several policy goals for personnel chiefs to follow in their day-to-day operations, including strengthening strategic manpower resources management, focusing on core missions, streamlining government structure and upgrading quality of public services.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVITIES PLANNED TO MARK 1ST ENCOUNTER BETWEEN TAIWAN, HOLLAND

TEXT.P: A series of activities will be held on the outlying island of Penghu this Saturday to relive the first encounter between Holland and Taiwan 400 years ago, the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) said Monday.
Council officials noted that the first Dutch ship sailed into Makung, Penghu, in 1604, marking the beginning of Taiwan's interaction with foreign powers.
To mark the significant event, the CCA, the Netherlands Trade and Investment Office in Taiwan, as well as the Penghu county government, have co-sponsored the 400th anniversary of the first encounter.

On Saturday, President Chen Shui-bian and representatives from various Matsu temples around Taiwan will first pray for blessing in the first Matsu temple of Taiwan proper and Penghu. This will be followed by recreations of historical scenes.
Netherlands Trade and Investment Office Representative Menno Goedhart will lead Dutch businessmen in a re-enactment of the first encounter.

The representatives and the businessmen will meet with President Chen in asquare before the temple to exchange souvenirs and bear witness to the business friendship between Taiwan and the Netherlands over the past four centuries.
An exhibition to show the Dutch activity in Taiwan and Penghu waters in the 17th Century will be held between Nov. 20 and Dec. 19 at the Heaven's Goddess temple on Penhgu.
Goedhart has expressed the hope that the exhibition will also make rounds in Taiwan proper as well as in the Netherlands.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR NOV. 16 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, Nov. 16:
09: 00, The 27th Joint Conference of ROC-USA and U.S.-Taiwan Business Councils and the 19th Modern Engineering and Technology Seminar will open at the Taipei International Convention Center.
09: 30, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will chair an anti-terrorism conference at the Executive Yuan.
10: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive representatives of Chinese communities in the western United States and Canada at the Presidential Office.
10: 00, The Ministry of National Defense will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
10: 30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
11: 00, Australia's minister of natural resources and mines of Queensland will visit the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
13: 30, The ruling Democratic Progressive Party will hold its Central Standing Committee meeting at the party's headquarters.
13: 30, The organizers of the 2004 Taiwan International Documentary Festival will hold a news conference at the Taipei Spot.
