16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5TH ASIA NGO FORUM OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The fifth Taipei Asia Non-Governmental Organization (NGO) Forum opened Monday at the Taipei city government's NGO Hall.
Ho Hung-jung, director of the city's Bureau of Civil Affairs, joined the Taipei-based Nook Drama Troupe in performing African drum dances to mark the opening of the event.
More than 50 NGO workers from Canada, the Philippines, Vietnam, Japan and Hong Kong have traveled to Taipei to meet with their local counterparts, Ho said.

In a variety of programs over the next two weeks, Ho said, local and foreign NGO workers will interact with local citizens in various ways, including colloquiums, workshops, evening parties and documentary discussions.
Noting that the vitality of NGOs is an important index to gauge the extent of a nation's democratization, Ho said local citizens are welcome to take part in these programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABORIGINAL PROTESTERS CLASH WITH POLICE IN FRONT OF EXECUTIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: About 1,000 aborigines clashed with police in a demonstration in front of the Executive Yuan Monday in which several police officers, including one draftee serving alternative military service in the police force, suffered bruising.

The protesters, led by an aboriginal lawmaker, were demonstrating to protest against what they claim is the Executive Yuan's failure to provide enough funds for the rebuilding of roads in mountainous areas that were ravaged by flooding earlier this year.
The clashes occurred when the protesters tried to enter the Executive Yuan and were prevented from doing so by about 300 police officers and draftees. None of the reported injuries were serious.

Chen Chih-mai, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, denied the protesters' claims, claiming that the Executive Yuan has shouldered the cost of rebuilding any road used by more than 30 farming households in mountainous areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S NATIONAL SCIENCE ADVISOR CALLS FOR COOPERATION WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Canada-Taiwan technology and trade cooperation should be enhanced to create mutually beneficial opportunities, Canada's National Science Advisor Arthur Carty suggested Monday.

Addressing a luncheon jointly hosted by the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei and the Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association, Carty said Canada has been vigorously promoting technological development by setting national strategies in emerging areas -- nanotechnology, quantum information technology, biotechnology and alternative energy technologies -- which he said are also priorities listed by Taiwan.
He introduced Canada as a dynamic and comprehensive economy and said that it is open for global business, while praising Taiwan for its performance in trade and technology development.
"I am very pleased that the collaboration between Canada and Taiwan in science and technology has created economic growth, high quality of life and opportunities for our citizens," Carty said.

Carty, a frequent visitor to Taiwan, arrived in Taiwan a day earlier for a three-day visit. He is a leader in the development of research collaboration involving Canada's National Research Council (NRC) and Taiwan's National Science Council.
Before being appointed National Advisor on Science and Technology to the Prime Minister in April 2004, Carty was the NRC president.

The purpose of his present visit to Taiwan is to share information about the state of scientific and technological development in Canada, to recognize the thriving science and technology relationship between Canada and Taiwan, to further explain the global reach of Canada's international collaboration initiatives involving prominent research organizations, agencies and institutions worldwide, and to promote two-way investment, as well as other commercial partnerships between Canada and Taiwan, according to the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 600 BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS ARRIVE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: More than 600 black-faced spoonbills have flown from the Korean peninsula to the Chiku wetlands in the southern county of Tainan to overwinter, local wildlife conservationists said Monday.

As of Monday, 617 of the highly endangered wading birds had arrived at the wetlands at the estuary of the Tsengwen river in Tainan County, conservationists said, adding that the number accounts for more than half of the total surviving population of the species.
According to the result of a global survey conducted in January this year, only 1,206 black-faced spoonbills still survive in the world.
The birds usually begin arriving in Taiwan to spend the winter after the Mid-Autumn Festival and will make the return migration for breeding between March and April the following year.
A record 750 black-faced spoonbills were recorded at the Chiku wetlands Dec. 3, 2003 and birdwatchers said they believe more birds will arrive as the temperature drops in the coming weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2ND ROUND OF TALKS WITH NICARAGUA ON FREE TRADE PACT TO BEGIN

TEXT.P: A second round of talks between Taiwan and Nicaragua on a free trade pact is slated to take place Nov. 29-Dec. 3 in Los Angeles, an economic official said Monday.
Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long will serve as Taiwan's chief negotiator at the talks, the official said.
The first round of talks finished in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: VANUATU PREMIER CONFIRMS DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Vanuatu Prime Minister Serge Vohor has confirmed his country's diplomatic ties with Taiwan in a letter to Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Monday.
Lu said Vohor told Chen that Vanuatu finished the legal process of recognizing Taiwan and the prime minister announced his government's decision in a televised address earlier that day.
As for Vanuatu's relations with mainland China, Lu said Taiwan will respect whatever decision is made by Vanuatu.

In light of the fact that there are about 20 mainland diplomats who have not yet left the South Pacific island nation, Lu said it is understandable that those people will try to destroy the ties between Vanuatu and Taiwan and that the foreign ministry is guarding against this.
Now that diplomatic ties with Vanuatu are confirmed, Lu said Taiwan diplomats there will find a location for an embassy in the hope of raising Taiwan's flag as soon as possible.

Vohor signed an agreement to recognize Taiwan Nov. 3 while in Taipei, but his Cabinet denied any knowledge of it and there were conflicting reports about whether Vohor was empowered by his government to recognize Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Nov. 16, or the fifth day of the tenth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1813: A mixed force of various ships belonging to Britain's Royal Navy under the general command of Adm. Warren takes up positions in a blockade of Long Island Sound.
1907: Oklahoma becomes the 46th state of the United States.
1917: Bolshevik troops capture Moscow.
1920: The Bolsheviks defeat the White Russians in the Crimea, ending Russia's civil war.
1922: Benito Mussolini threatens the Italian Chamber of Deputies with dissolution if his wishes are not obeyed.
1933: The United States establishes diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.
1940: Marshal Henri Philippe Petain takes over the French government and asks Hitler for an armistice.
1952: The Atomic Energy Commission (AEC), a U.S. government agency to direct the development and use of atomic energy, announces the successful testing of the first H-bomb.
1956: An engineering agency for the construction of the East-West Cross Island Highway in Central Taiwan is formally established.
1960: Clark Gable, known the world over as "The King of Hollywood," dies at the age of 59. He received an Academy Award for his performance in "It Happened One Night" in 1934.
1965: The World Health Organization declares that malaria has been eradicated in Taiwan.
1966: The Republic of China becomes the 54th member of the International Chamber of Commerce.
1971: The Republic of China withdraws from the International Labor Organization.
1972: Luxembourg establishes diplomatic ties with Communist China.
1973: The United States launches Skylab 4, carrying three astronauts on a 84-day mission.
1976: More than 1,300 delegates attend the Kuomintang's 11th national congress at the Chungshan Building at Yangmingshan. They elect Chiang Ching-kuo as chairman of the ruling party.
1977: The Republic of China's first nuclear power plant formally begins operations.
1979: The ROC and the United States conclude 40 days of talks on the revision of their air transportation agreement. In the memorandum initiated by the two parties, the ROC will be able to open its civil air services to the United States by obtaining four new service stops, namely Guam, Seattle, New York and Dallas-Fort Worth.
1986: Twelve people are killed, one goes missing, and 41 are injured in a violent earthquake in Taiwan.
1988: The Estonian Supreme Soviet rejects President Gorbachev's plans for reform of the Soviet constitution and adopts its own, although it stopped short of demanding outright independence from Moscow.
1992: Lithuania's Democratic Labor Party of ex-communists wins a victory in the country's first post-Soviet elections.
1995: Roh Tae Woo, former president of the Republic of Korea, is arrested on charges of taking bribes.
1999: Jose Antonio Dominguez, new Panamanian ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew says that Taiwan is pleased to see the signing of a World Trade Organization deal between Washington and Beijing, a development seen as perhaps reducing "political pressure" on Taipei's accession to the trade body.
2001: The Republic China Legislative Yuan ratifies Taiwan's World Trade Organization (WTO) accession accord which was approved at the Nov. 11 WTO meeting in Doha, Qatar.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "All things which are the same in kind are like to one another -- why should we doubt in regard to man, as if he were a solitary exception to this? The sage and we are the same in kind."

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP URGES THAT AIR FARES NOT BE RAISED RASHLY

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) on Tuesday urged air carriers to make public their cost structures for air fares and to not rashly raise ticket prices during the current Legislative Yuan recess.

PFP Legislator Hsu Yuan-kuo noted that the legislature is currently in a one-month recess in preparation for the Dec. 11 legislative elections and that the price of crude oil in the world market has dropped to around US$45 per barrel from a recent peak of more than US$50 per barrel.
"This is not an appropriate time to raise air fares, especially because the air carriers have not yet made public the cost structure of air tickets," Hsu said.

He noted that raising air fares will lead to a series of price hikes in the transportation sector. As global oil prices go down, the price of air tickets should not be raised, and should instead be lowered, he added.

Hsu's words came one day after the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications convened a review meeting on a proposal by air carriers to raise air fares.

CAA Director General Chang Kuo-cheng noted that fuel price is only one of the 14 items that air carriers use in calculating the cost of air fares. With the continued rise in world crude oil prices, the air carriers have complained that they have lost the profits they earned in the first 10 months of this year, and have therefore asked to hike air fares.

But review meeting members still had questions concerning the relation between the rising oil prices and the level of air fare hikes. They demanded that the air carriers provide them with more detailed calculations before they discuss air fare hikes further.

PFP Legislator Lee Hung-chun noted that not only has there been an upward price trend in air fares, water, electricity and gas, there has been in an upward trend in the consumer price index, which rose 2.36 percent in October.

Directorate General of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics tallies show that wholesale prices increased by 12 percent in October over the same month a year earlier, or the biggest jump in over 23 years, which Lee said shows that inflationary pressures still exist.
Lee Tung-hao, acting director of the PFP Policy Center, said that the party suspects the government will have to raise taxes in the next three years because of financial difficulties.

He said Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai's recent comment that "the government currently has no plan to raise taxes" was only a way of avoiding the question of whether the government could raise taxes in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 6TH IN NUMBER OF STUDENTS IN U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 15 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan students registered in schools in the United States between 2003-2004 was 6.6 percent lower than the previous year, making Taiwan the sixth largest source of foreign students in the United States, the Institute of International Education (IIE) reported Monday.
The IIE's latest statistics showed that Indian students ranked first in terms of numbers, followed by mainland Chinese students.

Among 26,178 Taiwan students registered in U.S. schools, 57.4 percent are studying in graduate schools, while 32.4 percent are studying in undergraduate programs at universities, and the remaining 10.2 percent are studying at other institutions.

The report showed that the number of Taiwan students going to the United States has been on the decline in recent years. Between 1993 and 1994, the number of Taiwan students peaked at 37,581. Between 1987 and 1988, Taiwan students topped all foreign students in the United States in terms of numbers. Mainland Chinese students topped the list between 1988 and 1989.

The report analyzed that the number of foreign students studying in the Unites States recorded negative growth for the first time in between 2003-2004 mainly because it has become more difficult to obtain student visas following the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks on the United States, especially for those students in the science and technology fields.

The active recruiting campaign to woo foreign students by other English-speaking countries such as the Australia and Britain has also cut the number of students going to the United States, according to the report.
In addition, the tuition fees of U.S. universities have been rising, the report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA THANKS POWELL FOR EFFORTS AT BOOSTING TAIWAN-U.S. TIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Tuesday extended Taiwan's recognition and appreciation to outgoing U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell for his efforts at enhancing Taiwan-U.S. relations during his four years in office.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu pointed out that Powell has praised the democratic development of Taiwan on various occasions and has reaffirmed Washington's commitment to defending Taiwan according to the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).
Powell has also praised Taiwan as a success story and has supported Taiwan's bid to participate in international organizations, including the World Health Organization, Lu added.

The ministry believes Powell's departure will not affect the development of relations between the two countries, which share identical values in terms of freedom, democracy and human rights, and which maintain close cooperation in economics and trade as well as in anti-terrorism efforts, Lu said.
Lu, however, would not comment on Powell's possible successor on the grounds that this is an internal affair of the United States.
Lu said the ministry believes that relations between Taipei and Washington will continue to develop under the framework of the TRA regardless of who is appointed as the next secretary of state.
The White House confirmed Monday that Powell had tendered his resignation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HAILS HU JINTAO'S REMARKS AS 'SIGNALING GOODWILL'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday hailed mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao's recent remarks as containing signs of goodwill that give weight to Taiwan's expectations of a thaw in relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Chen made the statement while meeting at the Presidential Office with a group of overseas Chinese community leaders from western Canada and the United States.

Hu is currently in Brazil on the first leg of his official visit to several South American countries that will also take him to Argentina and Chile. He was quoted as having told mainland Chinese community leaders in Rio de Janeiro Monday that mainland China's development comes ahead of cross-Taiwan Strait unification issues on his government's agenda.
President Chen said he felt that Hu's remarks signalled "some goodwill toward the expectation of a gradual thaw in the lingering cross-strait stalemate."
Chen added that he noticed that Beijing had refrained from using some of its stock rhetorical phases regarding Taiwan in a news release issued the previous day.

"In the latest Beijing news release, we found some signs of goodwill that we are paying close attention to, " Chen said, adding that he takes this as mainland China's initial response to the 10-point conclusion reached at a National Security Council (NSC) meeting chaired by him last Wednesday.
Since his re-election, Chen said he has repeatedly extended olive branches to Beijing in the hopes of resuming regular cross-strait dialogue and normalizing bilateral relations.

Noting that he unequivocally expounded on the aspirations of his administration and of the Taiwan people for cross-strait rapprochement in his May 20 inauguration speech for a second term and in his Double Ten National Day address as well as in last Wednesday's 10-point NSC meeting conclusion, Chen said he intensely hopes Beijing can make a goodwill response to open up a "window of opportunity" for the future.
Chen assured the overseas Chinese community leaders that his administration will continue to pursue normalization of cross-strait relations with maximum goodwill, sincerity and patience.

"My administration will adopt effective measures to create an environment favorable for cross-strait interaction and peaceful development for the sake of regional stability and the people's well-being," Chen said.
As a popularly elected president, Chen said, he is obligated to safeguard the nation's sovereignty, dignity and security as well as the 23 million Taiwan people's well-being.
In an attempt to defuse controversy over national identity issues, Chen also took advantage of the occasion to call for support for the Republic of China.

"The Republic of China's continued existence since 1911 is beyond question. As the ROC's 11th-term president, I cannot tolerate any questioning of the ROC's existence. During my tenure, I will not allow any person to make the claim that the ROC no longer exists. I'll dedicated myself to defending its sovereign status, dignity and security," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMMENT ON TAIWAN LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS FROM WHITE HOUSE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 15 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government's policy toward mainland China and Taiwan remains unchanged regardless of changes in the U.S. administration and possible shifts of power in the legislature in Taiwan, White House spokesman Scott McClellan said Monday.

McClellan made the remarks at a routine news briefing while answering a question on reports suggesting that if the "pan-green camp" won a majority in Taiwan's legislature following the Dec. 11 legislative elections, it could bring the island closer to a military confrontation with the mainland.
The press secretary also said that changes in the U.S. administration after President George W. Bush's re-election will be done smoothly and will not impact any U.S. policies.
"In terms of our policy on China and Taiwan, it remains unchanged and there's nothing really to update beyond that at this point, " the U.S. official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-AIDED ORPHANAGE OPENS IN BURKINA FASO

TEXT.P: An orphanage built with support from Taiwanese churches has been completed and opened earlier this month in Burkina Faso, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

A 20-member delegation formed by the Glory Star Church in Taipei and the Bread of Life Christian Church in Pingtung went to Burkina Faso on Nov. 3 to attend the opening ceremony and established sisterhood ties with churches in the African nation, according to Patrick Chang, director of MOFA's Department of African Affairs.

Lien Chia-en, who is a medical school graduate and a member of the Glory Star Church, started a fundraising campaign in Taiwan for the construction of the orphanage a few years ago when he was serving in Taiwan's medical mission in Burkina Faso as an alternative to military service.
On finishing his service last year, he was hired to become a staff physician at the mission and continued to work on the orphanage project.
Chang said the completion of the orphanage shows that foreign service as an alternative service has been a success.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 4.16 points to close at 5,910.85.
The bourse opened at 5,917.42 and fluctuated between 5,937.62 and 5,894.98 during trading. A total of 2.52 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$55.9 billion (US$1.7 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 0.6 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.3 percent and paper and pulp issues and banking and financial shares both at 0.1 percent.
Three other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 1.2 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 0.5 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.2 percent.
Cement stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 384 to 214, with 182 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA INSTRUCTS PROTECTION OF TAIWAN NATIONALS IN IVORY COAST

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has instructed its missions overseas to establish an urgent communication network with 25 Taiwan nationals currently residing in the Ivory Coast since military conflicts have broken out in the West African country.
Chang Pei-chi, director of MOFA's Department of African Affairs, noted that European and American countries have since Nov. 11 started to evacuate their nationals.

He said that there are currently 25 Taiwan expatriates living in the Ivory Coast, and that the ministry has asked an ROC office in the Ivory Coast to establish an urgent communication network to execute an evacuation if the situation deteriorates.

Chang noted that the office has urgently communicated with the U.S. embassy in the Ivory Coast and secured their consent to help evacuate Taiwan expatriates should such need arise, but Taiwan expatriates are currently unwilling to leave because they want to safeguard their investments in the country.
Chang also urged Taiwan people to refrain from traveling to the Ivory Coast for the time being.

The Ivory Coast's government reopened the nation's civil war on Nov. 4 with air strikes on the rebel-held north. Two days later, Ivory Coast war planes bombed a French peacekeeping post, killing nine French troops and an American aid worker and plunging the country into chaos.
This new round of bloodshed has raised fears for the future of what was once one of African's most stable and prosperous countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HOUSING PROJECT WELL UNDERWAY IN PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: Houses being built for low-income families in Paraguay with the Republic of China donated funds are almost 50 percent complete, the Paraguay National Housing Committee said Tuesday.
A committee official said the program was now in its second phase with 557 houses completed. The construction of an additional 640 units started earlier this month.
Each unit is estimated to be worth about US$4,423, or just under the annual income of an average citizen of Paraguay, the official said.
ROC Ambassador in Paraguay Yan Ping-fan donated US$3 million on behalf of the ROC government last month to be used for housing projects in Paraguay.
Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Frutos said everyone in Paraguay hopes to own a home and thanked the ROC government for the donation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STEEL EXPORTS RISING: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's steel export value has been growing every year and has topped its import value since 1996 to account for 6.5 percent of the country's total outbound shipments last year, according to government tallies.

The statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that with rapid development in the domestic steel industry in 1987, the sector's outbound shipment value began to surpass its inbound shipment every year since 1996 through 2003 at a double-digit rate, except for 2001, when the United States was attacked by terrorists.

DGBAS officials attributed the domestic industry's boom in recent years to strong demand from mainland China and the whole world. It made the third-largest contribution in terms of output value to the manufacturing sector only after those registered by the electronics and the petroleum industries.

Nevertheless, more and more domestic steel makers are considering relocating to the mainland in the face of higher labor costs and tighter restrictions on greenhouse emissions, they said, adding that mainland-bound investment by Taiwan companies approved by the government for 2002 and 2003 totaled US$630 million and US$720 million, respectively.

In a related development, the recent strong appreciation of the new Taiwan dollar has kept fierce pressure on domestic downstream steel makers but is benefiting their upstream counterparts, industry sources said.

Taking China Steel Corp. (CSC) , Taiwan's largest steel maker, which heavily relies on imported materials, as an example, a stronger new Taiwan dollar has helped it rack up a greater profit after having gained in imports, they said, adding that an appreciating local currency is definitely beneficial to upstream suppliers.
Like CSC, Tung Ho Steel, Feng Hsin Iron and Steel and others are now awash in cash, they added.

On the other hand, downstream companies will have greater difficulties in acquiring materials and will have to absorb price gaps without being able to fully pass on the costs to customers, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVOLVED OFFICERS CONFIRM 'SOFT COUP' ATTEMPT: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday defended his claim concerning an opposition-backed "soft coup" attempt after the March 20 presidential election, saying the military officers contacted to join the operation had confirmed its existence.

Chen gave a detailed account of his claim at a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Central Standing Committee meeting after the allegation, which he made over the weekend, drew strong protest from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP).

"After March 20, several retired generals tried to persuade active generals to fake sickness or tender their resignations in an attempt to upset the morale of the military and worsen social disorder after the election," Chen said.
"This is not a made-up story. I have checked out the who, when and where of the incident and the persons involved have also admitted to it," Chen added.

Chen said the purpose of his raising the issue again was to let the public understand how the "pan-blue alliance" had intended to overturn the result of the election -- not only by instigating a mob in front of the Presidential Office but also by fomenting a plot to destabilize the government and the military.
The failure of the operation is also an example of the success of the DPP government's efforts to nationalize the armed forces and institutionalize the intelligence service since 2000, Chen said.

"In the past, the KMT always considered the military one of its possessions.... Regrettably, the 'pan-blue alliance' and some retired generals still retain this erroneous belief after the 2004 presidential election," Chen said.
It was a victory of democracy and the people that none of the generals in service had been moved to take part in the plot, Chen said.
Trying to justify his use of the term "soft coup, " Chen said the expression is not an exaggeration in light of the critical situation the country was facing in March.

In addition to inciting supporters to ram a district court in Kaohsiung and occupy the boulevard in front of the Presidential Office for an entire week after the election, "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidates Lien Chan and James Soong hosted a series of news conferences in which they urged foreign governments to intervene in the election results, Chen said.

Chen said that while the "pan-blue alliance" called on the military to join an "uprising" on Web sites and posters, it also incited its supporters to storm the Central Election Commission building March 26 to try to prevent the commission from proclaiming his re-election.
This chain of events prompted the mainland Chinese authorities to issue a statement saying that Beijing would not "sit idly" if the situation in Taiwan spiralled out of control, Chen noted.
"If this is not a 'soft coup,' what is it? A 'coup' does not mean only a 'coup d'etat' or a successful operation in toppling the government. An 'abortive, soft coup' is also a 'coup,'" he argued.
Also Tuesday, Ministry of National Defense spokesman Huang Suey-sheng said the military always abides by the Constitution and that it is impossible that the military would start a coup.
Huang said the military, which pledges allegiance to the country and is politically neutral, will never become a tool for political struggle by any party.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. COURT RESCINDS DISGRACED TYCOON'S SUIT AGAINST ROC REP OFFICE
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Nov. 15 (CNA) (By Lu-sheng Chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A U.S. federal court in Los Angeles has rescinded a disgraced Taiwan business tycoon's lawsuit against the Republic of China's representative office in Los Angeles, a lawyer said Monday.

Lin Ying-lang, a U.S.-based Taiwan lawyer who has been retained by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Los Angeles to handle the case, said the federal court had rescinded former Tuntex Group Chairman Chen You-hao's suit earlier in the day without bothering to hold any debate session, on the grounds that the U.S. court does not have jurisdiction over the case.
Lin said the U.S. court ruling has not only given a fair and impartial judgment but also indicates that the U.S. judicial authorities recognize Taiwan as a sovereign state.

According to Lin, Chen filed the suit in March, demanding that the U.S. court revoke an ROC government move to put him on the list of Taiwan's 10 most-wanted fugitives and "other political persecutions." Chen claimed that Taiwan's move impinged upon his basic human rights and privacy as well as restricted his business activities. The listing resulted in his being detained on two occasions by customs authorities when he was entering the United States, Chen claimed in his suit.

TECO filed an application with the U.S. federal court Aug. 17, asking the court to rescind Chen's suit. The court then informed the plaintiff of TECO's application. On Nov. 5, Chen refused to withdraw the suit.
Lin said the court was originally scheduled to hold a hearing on the case Monday but the presiding judge later decided to cancel it and directly handed down his ruling rescinding Chen's suit.

The judge said in a written verdict that in accordance with the foreign sovereign immunity law, Taiwan is a foreign state to the United States and also a sovereign state. As TECO represents the Taiwan government, he said, the U.S. government has no jurisdiction over the case.

According to U.S. law, Chen can appeal his case to a higher court, but cannot use the same reason. As a result, Lin said, the case is closed as far as TECO is concerned and the office is immune from any further legal action on Chen's part.

Chen was an influential businessman during the tenure of former President Lee Teng-hui. His Tuntex Group was involved in a number of businesses, including textiles, cement, construction, petrochemicals, travel and telecommunications. His business empire failed in the late 1990s due in part to a botched land development project. He has been indicted on charges of breach of trust and corporate funds embezzlement. He fled Taiwan in late 2001 and has since lived either in the United States or in mainland China as one of Taiwan's most-wanted fugitives.

He caused a stir before Taiwan's March 20 presidential election by claiming in San Francisco that he had twice offered huge political contributions to President Chen Shui-bian's wife -- the first time during the run-up to the Taipei mayoral election in 1994 and the second time during the lead-up to the 2000 presidential election. His allegations were seen at the time as a tactic to undermine President Chen's re-election bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-INTELLIGENCE OFFICER INDICTED ON CHARGES OF SPYING FOR BEIJING

TEXT.P: A former staff member of the Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB) under the Ministry of National Defense was indicted Tuesday on charges of spying for mainland China.

Liao Hsien-ping, 59, was accused of having collected information about activities of Taiwan's major political parties and Taiwan's 2004 presidential elections, as well as visits to Taiwan by pro-Taiwan members of the Hong Kong Legislative Council, for the reference of mainland Chinese authorities.

According to the indictment, Liao was fired from his position as an MIB intelligence officer in 1994 for dereliction of duty. He then went to live in the Philippines. In late 1999, he returned to Taiwan under the arrangement of a pro-Beijing overseas Chinese businessman in Manila to collect intelligence for mainland China.

Liao worked as a taxi driver to cover up his intelligence-gathering operations. He regularly sent intelligence reports to designated people in Hong Kong and Macau for which he received at least NT$1.7 million since 2000, the indictment said. Prosecutors demanded a three-year prison term for Liao for infractions of the National Security Law, document forgery and leaking of non-military national secrets.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WTO ENVOY HOPES FOR SPEEDY TALKS ON TRADE FACILITATION
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Nov. 15 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's permanent representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO) called Monday for speeded up negotiation on trade facilitation, one of the issues contained in the Singapore issues, among WTO members.
Yen Ching-chang issued the call after a WTO negotiation panel opened its first meeting to discuss the trade facilitation issue earlier the same day at the organization's Geneva headquarters.

Saying that WTO member states should step up their pace to complete the talks as soon as possible, Yen suggested that the panel hold more meetings in order to settle the issue prior to a ministerial meeting scheduled for December 2005 in Hong Kong.

Currently, the panel has slated only five formal meetings on trade facilitation from February to July for the whole of next year. Prior to that, the panel will conduct this year's second and final meeting Nov. 22-23.

According to Yen, the panel's top priority is to accelerate the discussion pace to catch up with those on the other two Singapore issues -- investment and transparency in government procurement and competition policy.

Taiwan has rich experience in promoting trade facilitation and is keen to advocate the issue under the WTO framework, he noted, adding that the country is willing to provide its assistance in helping the world trade regulatory body to forge a sound climate for the talks among member states.
The Singapore issues form a key segment of the so-called July Package, which was agreed upon in August by all WTO member countries to include in the next round of the Doha Talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: CTV SHARE PRICE PLUNGES AFTER SEIZURE OF BUILDINGS

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT)-owned China Television Co. (CTV) issued a statement Tuesday after the Shihlin District Court seized property owned by the station, saying that it was as much a victim as the bankrupt company whose downfall precipitated the seizure.
The two buildings were seized because the TV station is the supervisory body of the failed company, Procom, and is responsible for any legal actions taken against it.
The buildings are in the Nankang district of Taipei and include CTV's headquarters.

CTV's share price went into freefall after investors heard the news of the property seizure. The price fell the maximum daily limit of 7 percent to NT$10.6 (US$0.32) per share, or close to its face value -- a value assigned all Taiwan stocks to be NT$10 per share -- after the opening of the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday.
CTV, which formed a crisis team in the wake of the provisional seizure, has mapped out emergency measures to try to mitigate the impact and to keep the company operating normally.

Reports say that the real estate involved in the CTV seizure exceeds NT$2.5 billion, and CTV Chairwoman Cheng Su-ming's assets, including all her bank deposits and one-third of her monthly salary were also temporarily frozen by the court.

CTV and its legal representative, who is also Cheng, have served as one of the supervisors of Procom, Co. since August 2002. A series of fraudulent practices involving the company's operations came to light early this year.

The Shihlin Prosecutor's Office recently indicted Yeh Su-fei, chairwoman of Procom, and 30 other defendants for various violations including securities transactions infractions, breach of trust and money laundering. The prosecutor asked for a maximum 20-year term for Yeh and a fine of NT$500 million (US$15.15 million).

The non-profit Securities and Futures Investors Protection Center, which is handling complaints from 7,500 Procom investors who are asking NT$3.3 billion in compensation, have already acted on behalf of the investors in obtaining compensation from 19 people, including the chairwoman, other members of the Board of directors and the supervisors of Procom and accountants from two prestigious accounting firms that audited and certified the financial reports of Procom.

But since CTV borrowed NT$1.65 billion from a bank using the two buildings in question as mortgage earlier this month, the protection center asked that the Shihlin District Court provisionally seize the two properties to ensure the rights of the creditors.
In a six-point statement issued Tuesday, CTV implored the Protection Center to give the same consideration to the shareholders of the TV station as it has to the investors in Procom.

CTV also stressed that the borrowed NT$1.65 billion was mainly used when it returned a NT$1.1 billion deposit made by a Buddhist TV station for renting facilities in the buildings, and digitization work of the CTV. The TV station stressed that it has no intention of selling or transferring its assets.

The seizure of the buildings comes at a politically sensitive time as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -- currently campaigning to try to capture a majority in the legislature -- has made the return of assets owned by opposition parties alleged to have been obtained illegally a key plank in its electioneering strategy.
A KMT spokesman said Tuesday that a "political hand" was pulling the strings behind the seizure of CTV's buildings.

Chang Jung-kung said that the court over-extended its scope by taking control of property that far exceeds the amount in compensation money at the center of the court action. Taking just one of the two buildings would have been sufficient, he said.
Chang said that the seizure was politically motivated and was designed to undermine the financial operations of the TV station, and hence deal a blow to the KMT.
However, the DPP flatly denied the allegation, saying that the protection center was only acting in accordance with the law to protect investors.
Lee Ying-yuan, a DPP vice secretary-general, said that the matter has nothing to do with the government, and that the KMT should not politicize everything.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DISASTER PREVENTION, RELIEF SYSTEM TO BE STRENGTHENED

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of the Interior Lee Chin-yung said Tuesday that the ministry will strengthen the nation's national disaster prevention and relief system.

Lee made the remarks when he received Yuji Hakuya, president of the International Fire Chiefs' Association of Asia (IFCAA) and other Japanese officials, who are here to attend the 23rd general ce of the IFCAA that will open in Taipei Wednesday.
The three-day meeting will have new global disaster prevention and relief trends as its main theme.

Lee said that the central disaster prevention and relief center will be made into a permanent body, instead of a contingency body for individual disasters, so as to strengthen the national disaster prevention and relief system.

Lee noted that Japan was battered by several earthquakes and typhoons this year, resulting in casualties and property damage, and said the government wants to express sympathy as well as its appreciation for the firefighters' efforts.
The visiting Japanese official also inquired about the situation regarding recent earthquakes and typhoons in Taiwan.
More than 2,000 delegates from 23 IFCAA member states or areas will take part in the Taipei meeting.

In addition to a regular IFCAA board meeting, a working-level meeting and a plenary session, a series of lectures and seminars on disaster prevention/relief mechanisms, management systems and relevant technological developments will also be held.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA SEEKING INVESTORS IN ENVIRONMENTAL TECHNOLOGY INDUSTRIAL PARKS

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Tuesday offered preferential packages to try to attract investors to set up operations in four environmental technology industrial parks.

While the Penchou Industrial Park in Kaohsiung County was completed and opened in February, construction of the other three -- located in Hualien, Taoyuan and Tainan counties -- is set to be completed by March 2005, EPA officials said.

The EPA has worked out a number of preferential measures as incentives for investors, including a 50 percent subsidy for land rental, a NT$25 million (US$761,754) production subsidy and a NT$10 million fund to finance research projects on trial and mass production, the officials said.

Seven domestic companies specializing in the recycling of lead-acid batteries, metal-impregnated mud and waste lubricant have established operations in the industrial park in Kaohsiung County, they said.
With a combined output of more than NT$1.3 billion per annum, these companies are expected to create over 200 jobs, they said.
In addition, the U.S.-based World Resources Company (WRC) has also decided to set up a treatment plant in the park, the officials said.
Interested investors are urged to contact the EPA at (02)23117722 ext. 2643.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO SET UP ANTI-TERRORISM COMMAND OFFICE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun has ordered the formation of an anti-terrorism command office within a week to step up response measures, Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Tuesday.
Yu issued the directive at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Chen said, adding that the planned office will comprise seven divisions to cope with different types of terrorist attacks.

According to Chen, the seven divisions will deal with violent attacks, biological attacks, toxic attacks, radioactive attacks, attacks on major public facilities, attacks on information and communication systems and other forms of terrorist attacks, respectively.
During the Cabinet meeting, Yu also directed that the new command office must organize at least one full-range anti-terrorist training exercise within three months.

Noting that national security strategies have changed significantly since the 911 terrorist attacks, Chen said major countries around the world have all stepped up preparations against terrorist assault.
In line with the general world trend, Chen said, the Cabinet referred a draft anti-terrorist action bill to the Legislative Yuan for approval in November 2003.
"Much to our regret, the opposition-controlled legislature has so far failed to screen the bill," Chen said.
The draft bill has designed a three-color warning system to signal the risks of a possible terrorist attack -- green, yellow and red -- in a progressive measurement system, Chen went on.

Quoting a report prepared by the National Police Administration (NPA), Chen said, there are 75 mature terrorist organizations around the world, with Europe, the Middle East and Asia as their main hubs.

According to the NPA report, bombings, armed surprise attacks and kidnappings are the most common forms of terrorist attack. In the first 10 months of this year, 1,381 terrorist attacks were reported around the world, resulting in 3,097 deaths and 7,041 injuries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INTERNATIONAL DOCUMENTARY FESTIVAL TO OPEN IN MID-DECEMBER

TEXT.P: The 2004 Taiwan International Documentary Festival will be held Dec. 11-17 in Taipei, organizers of the festival announced Tuesday.

Officials of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA), which is sponsoring the film and video competition, said that a total of 122 documentaries from more than 40 countries around the world will be screened in the week-long event.

Speaking at a news conference to introduce the festival, CCA Chairman Chen Chi-nan thanked foreign missions in Taipei for their support and assistance with the festival, as well as their contributions to cultural exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEADERS SUE PRESIDENT OVER 'SOFT COUP' ALLEGATION

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong lodged a civil lawsuit Tuesday against President Chen Shui-bian for defamation over Chen's allegation about an aborted "soft coup" after the March 20 presidential election.

Commissioned by Lien and Soong, who formed the "pan-blue alliance" ticket against the ticket of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) of Chen and Vice President Annette Lu in the election, lawyer Li Fuldien brought the suit to the Taipei District Court against Chen over his rhetoric about a "soft coup" plotted by Lien and Soong in the wake of their failed election bid.
According to Li, both Lien and Soong believe that Chen has seriously damaged their reputations and the two men decided to seek justice and symbolic compensation through legal means.

They are demanding that Chen compensate a token NT$1 dollar for his allegation and that he run a half-page advertisement on the front page of seven major daily newspapers at home and abroad, such as Taiwan's Liberty Times, United Daily News and China Times, as well as Japan's Yomiuri Shimbun, the United States' New York Times, Le Figaro of France and Britain's Times, Li said.

Liao Feng-te, a KMT legislator, and Liu Wen-hsiung, a PFP lawmaker, who accompanied Li in bringing the case to the court, asked Chen to make public the hard evidence that he claims to have in hand as soon as possible. "Only so doing will help clarify the truth, " they argued.
Chen claimed Sunday while stumping for a DPP candidate in the Dec. 11 legislative poll in southern Taiwan that he has hard evidence of who attempted the so-called "soft coup," when and where.

According to Chen, various retired generals sought to persuade about a dozen generals in active service to offer their resignations or take sick leave in an attempt to undermine the military's morale and order in the wake of his March 20 election victory.

However, Chen said, their plot failed thanks to Taiwan's success in turning the military into a national force that has allegiance to the country rather than to a political party, as was the case during the KMT's five decades in power.

He also asked the public to end what he called "Lien-Soong" unrest in the coming legislative polls by giving the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union a majority in the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTED JOURNAL PUBLISHES ARTICLE ON TAIWAN'S SARS-FIGHTING DRIVE

TEXT.P: The world-renowned medical journal Lancet carries an article on Taiwan's fight against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in its latest issue, marking world recognition of Taiwan's efforts in this regard, a medical expert said Tuesday.

Su Ih-jen, director of the clinical research division at the National Health Research Institute, who co-authored the article with Ho Mei-hsiang, an Academia Sinica research fellow, said the article is mainly aimed at sharing Taiwan's experience in SARS prevention and control with other countries.

"It marks the first time that we have offered a comprehensive review of our SARS-fighting experience, " Su said, adding that he was pleased to see the article published in the authoritative medical journal.
Another purpose of the article is to introduce Taiwan's experience in fighting influenza, Su said.
In his view, Su said, influenza poses an even greater challenge than SARS in quarantine and containment of its transmission.

"By now, we have become fully aware of the path of SARS transmission and can effectively treat the disease. A SARS-infected person usually cannot transmit the virus to other people until he or she develops fever. In contrast, a flu-infected person can pass the virus onto other people two or three days before he or she develops fever," Su explained.
Noting that Tamiflu, an anti-virus drug, is the most effective way to contain the spread of influenza, Su said the drug can break a fever, thus containing transmission of the disease.

Su said Taiwan is the first country whose government has purchased the drug to treat flu patients. In the face of the ever-increasing flu threat, the drug is now in short supply. "Our neighbors, such as Japan, Singapore and South Korea, have expressed admiration for our government's foresight," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTHERN SCIENCE PARK SEES JUMP IN REVENUE

TEXT.P: The Southern Taiwan Science Park in Tainan County has seen a jump in revenue, with 50 companies based there as of the end of last year, according to government statistics published Tuesday.

The tallies complied by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that the park recorded an average 75.9 percent growth rate in its annual revenue in the last three years, a ratio far higher than the 13.8 percent posted by the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in the north, the most representative establishment of its kind in Taiwan.
The Southern Taiwan Science Park was set up in 1996, with 50 hi-tech companies operating there, which have fueled in actual capital worth NT$42.9 billion (US$1.3 billion).

The park chalked up combined business of NT$155.3 billion for the whole of last year, with the opto-electronics industry as its mainstay, generating NT$89.7 billion in business, or 57.8 percent of the total, according to the same tallies. The IC industry ranked second, contributing NT$60.9 billion. The two industries made up 97 percent of the park's overall business.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION ARRIVES FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: A five-member French parliamentary delegation, headed by National Assembly Deputy Bernard Schreiner, arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a four-day visit.

He is accompanied by four other French National Assembly deputies, including Alain Cousin, Jean-Marie Geveaux, Jean-Pierre Kucheida and Andre Schneider.
During their stay, the lawmakers will meet with senior officials and visit major economic and cultural institutions.

The main topic of the meeting will be the global vision for disaster preparedness and response, and the activities will include keynote speeches, fire chiefs' presentations, technical seminars and technical visits, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Nov. 17, or the sixth day of the tenth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1869: The Suez Canal, linking the Red Sea and the Mediterranean Sea, is opened to navigation after more than 10 years of construction.
1887: Bernard Montgomery, British field marshal , is born. His many victories in battle include the defeat of Rommel in North Africa.
1903: The Ching court establishes a translation school to train its diplomats.
1917: Auguste Rodin, noted French sculptor, dies at the age of 77. Through his works, the most famous of which are perhaps "The Kiss" and "The Thinker," Rodin opened an innovative new chapter in the history of sculpture.
1922: Siberia votes for union with the USSR.
1941: Japanese Prime Minister Gen. Tojo outlines a three-point plan he says is aimed at peace in East Asia just less than a month before Pearl Harbor.
1959: Many overseas Chinese are forced to move out of Indonesia as anti-Chinese riots worsen.
1961: Diosdado Macapagal is elected president of the Philippines.
1969: The United States and the Soviet Union hold their first Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALK) in Helsinki.
1970: The unmanned Soviet spacecraft Luna 17 lands an eight-wheeled lunar vehicle on the moon.
1971: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Mexico.
1971: Vemij Thanom Kittikachorn seizes power in Thailand, suspending the nation's constitution, abolishing parliament and dismissing the Cabinet.
1972: Juan D. Peron, former president of Argentina, returns to his homeland, ending 17 years in exile.
1973: Mr. Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez, Costa Rican speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1976: Communist China sets off its largest nuclear explosion in the atmosphere.
1980: Yeh Tao-lei is arrested by the Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters and is prosecuted for insurrection.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives city and county chiefs of Taiwan Province, encouraging them to develop infrastructure to serve the people as best they can.
1986: The third ROC-France Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Taipei.
1988: Benazir Bhutto becomes the first woman leader of an Islamic country in the first democratic elections in Pakistan in 11 years.
1988: The Executive Yuan approves the private installation of small satellite dish antennas, which will allow viewers to tune into the KU-band and receive television programming from Japan's NHK station.
1990 The Soviet government agrees to change the country's constitution.
1995: Koo Chen-fu, a senior adviser to the ROC president, arrives in Osaka, Japan, to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum summit in place of President Lee Teng-hui.
1999: The southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung and the northern German port city of Hamburg sign an agreement on sisterhood ties in a move expected to boost bilateral trade and cooperation.
1999: The ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee approves the expulsion from the party of former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, who is running a renegade presidential campaign as an independent.
2000: A huge earthquake shakes the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Papua New Guinea, triggering a tidal wave that would crash ashore and damage many buildings.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "I like fish, and I also like bears' paws. If I cannot get both together, I will let the fish go, and take the bears' paws. So I like life, and I also like righteousness. If I cannot keep the two together, I will let life go and choose righteousness."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., TAIWAN CONTINUE TO WORK ON TRADE ISSUES: USTR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 16 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A U.S. Trade Representative Office (USTR) spokesman said Tuesday that the United States has continued to work with Taiwan on a number of trade issues.

Richard Mills made the remarks during a regular press conference when he was asked whether the USTR, in its annual review next March or April, will remove Taiwan from its priority watch list compiled according to the special 301 provisions of the 1989 U.S. Omnibus Trade Acts regarding intellectual property rights protection.

Taiwan has been placed on the priority watch list for the last three straight years because the United States considers that the island has not made sufficient efforts in the protection of intellectual property rights.

"Taiwan is an important trading partner of the United States, and we will continue to work with them on a number of issues related to intellectual property rights and other areas to make sure that Americans are treated fairly," he said.

On questions about Taiwan-U.S. talks on lifting the island's ban on U.S. beef imports imposed after the appearance of a case of mad cow disease in Washington State in December 2003, and on whether the United States will re-open to Taiwan chicken imports, Mills didn't give a specific timetable, saying only that both sides have continued to communicate on these issues.
The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) recently said that Taiwan has agreed in principle to resume imports of U.S. beef and beef products.

Taiwan health and agriculture officials are currently in the United States to inspect the major features and implementation of U.S. safeguards against mad cow disease, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE).
Taiwan purchased US$325 million worth of U.S. beef and beef products in 2003, making it the sixth largest importer of U.S. beef prior to imposing the ban, according to the USDA.
