Powell, who often struggled for influence as the lone moderate in an administration dominated by foreign policy hawks, resigned. National security advisor Condoleezza Rice will replace him, with an official announcement coming as early as today, senior officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CROSS-STRAIT POLICY NOT EXPECTED TO CHANGE WHEN RICE TAKES OVER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 16 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: U.S. policy on cross-Taiwan Strait relations is expected to remain unchanged after Condoleezza Rice takes over from Colin Powell as secretary of state, a group of U.S.-based academics opined Tuesday.

The U.S. policies toward Taiwan and mainland China are expected to remain basically the same after National Security Advisor Rice assumes her new post, including the "one China" policy, and the position that cross-strait differences should be solved peacefully and that no unilateral changes should be made to the current cross-strait status quo by either side, said Vincent W.C. Wang, associate professor of political science at the University of Richmond, Virginia.

Noting that Rice, who is particularly familiar with Russian affairs, is an expert at power politics, Wang predicted that Rice will probably rely heavily on the opinions of the assistant secretary of state and the deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs when formulating policies on Taiwan and mainland China.

June Teufel Dreyer, professor of political science at the University of Miami at Coral Gables, also said that Washington's China policy is not expected to change after Rice assumes the post of secretary of state.

Dreyer said that the Iraq war and Iraqi affairs will remain the top U.S. foreign policy concern, followed by Afghanistan and North Korea. She added that she does not agree with speculation in the State Department that mainland China will assist Washington in these efforts.

As to mainland China, Dreyer said two developments deserve the Bush administration's close attention, namely that members of Congress have become increasingly displeased with the United States' ever-widening trade deficit with mainland China, and that Beijing authorities are taking high-handed measures in an attempt to suppress social unrest that has surfaced in many provinces around the country.
Meanwhile, Bonnie Glaser, a fellow researcher with the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies think tank, said that she foresees continuity in U.S. cross-strait policies.

Rice is expected to follow the policy of continuing to foster bilateral ties with both Taiwan and mainland China, while the three communiques that Washington signed with Beijing, the Taiwan Relations Act, and opposition to any unilateral moves to change the cross-strait status quo will remain the bedrock of Washington's policies, Glaser noted.

She added that Rice has maintained good interactions with the Beijing leadership and has visited Beijing twice in her current post. Like President Bush, Rice is very much concerned with China's escalating military build-up and with the possibility of Taiwan taking actions to change the status quo.

Larry Diamond, a senior fellow at Stanford University's Hoover Institution, also forecast that the current U.S. policy on cross-strait relations will remain basically unchanged. He pointed out that this also means that Washington will continue to pressure Taiwan to adopt a more reconcilable stance on the development of cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE LAUNCH CRACKDOWN ON ORGANIZED CRIME

TEXT.P: Police launched a crackdown operation on organized crime and gangsterism Wednesday in an effort to beef up social order in the run-up to the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
A total of 5,400 police officers have been mobilized for the operation code-named "Leiting No. 40, " according to the Criminal Investigation Bureau.

Police said that they have targeted nearly 100 gang leaders and hoodlums and that they plan to raid some 1,200 underworld hangouts, such as gang headquarters, underground credit unions and gambling dens.
Six gang leaders and 20 hoodlums had already been arrested as of noon Wednesday, police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTERS ARRIVES IN CHILE FOR APEC MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Santiago, Chile, Nov. 16 (CNA) (By Kuan Chung-wei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh and Minister of Finance Lin Chuan arrived in the Chilean capital of Santiago Tuesday to attend an annual ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
The 2004 APEC ministerial-level meeting will open Wednesday for a two-day run.

Ho said Taiwan's participation in APEC activities are mainly aimed at making positive contributions to trade liberalization championed by the regional economic cooperation forum as well as to the Doha round global trade talks launched by the World Trade Organization in 2001.

On the sidelines of the multilateral APEC meeting, Ho said she is scheduled to hold bilateral talks with her counterparts from at least six other APEC member economies, including Chile -- the host country of all 2004 APEC activities.
Ho said the formation of an Asia-Pacific free trade area is one of the topics to be addressed at this year's APEC ministerial meeting.

According to Ho, the issue has been discussed at the annual APEC senior ministers meeting held in Santiago earlier this week. While some member countries gave a thumbs-up to the proposal, several other members were opposed to it. Ho said the issue will be further weighed at the ministerial meeting.

As to Taiwan's plan to sign bilateral free trade agreements (FTAs) with its major trading partners, Ho said Taiwan faces difficulties negotiating FTAs with countries with which it doesn't maintain formal diplomatic ties.
"We must overcome those difficulties step-by-step. We should start from forging close cooperative ties," Ho explained, adding that the government will tackle the issue with maximum patience.

For his part, Finance Minister Lin said he hopes to hold bilateral talks with his counterparts from other APEC member economies on customs cooperation and signing of taxation agreements to facilitate mutual investment.
Meanwhile, Yu Shao-wu, director-general of customs, who attended the APEC senior officials meeting, said Taiwan will realize the goal of "paperless" customs clearance by 2005.

Trade liberalization, automation and economic cooperation are three major topics of this year's APEC conference. Yu said Taiwan has been actively promoting automated customs clearance systems in recent years and has achieved remarkable progress in the field.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER IN HAWAII FOR ASIA-PACIFIC HOMELAND SECURITY SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan is currently in Hawaii taking part in the 2004 Asia-Pacific Homeland Security Summit and Exposition, sources from the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Wednesday.

Su, who has kept his Hawaii visit low key to avoid interference from Beijing, arrived in Honolulu Monday to participate in the second Asia-Pacific Homeland Security Summit, which is being held Nov. 14-17.
Soon after his arrival, Su met with Hawaii Governor Linda Lingle for talks on a wide range of topics, according to MOI officials.

During the meeting, Lingle, who visited Taiwan in 2001, told Su that she came away from her trip to Taiwan with a distinct impression of Taiwanese hospitality and strong cultural and educational development there.

For his part, according to the MOI officials, Su conveyed Premier Yu Shyi-kun's greetings to Lingle and the regional homeland summit meeting, which is being sponsored by the state government of Hawaii.

Su told Lingle that Taiwan has been enthusiastically supportive of the U.S.-led war on terror and that it will continue to cooperate with all countries in the Asia-Pacific region to ward off global terrorism.

Su also told Lingle that Taiwan can learn a lot from Hawaii in the area of tourism and related development. Taiwan would also like to exchange views with Hawaii in efforts seeking balanced development between tourism and counter-terrorist programs, Su added.
At the dinner party Monday marking the opening of the summit, Su met with Tom Ridge, secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, for a brief chat, the MOI officials said.
Ridge told Su that he is welcome to visit Washington anytime for talks on counter-terrorism efforts, according to the officials.

The development of innovative response strategies to the threat of terrorism is at the core of the four-day conference, which has been divided into three tracks, namely leadership and policy, law enforcement, and counter-terrorism regional outreach.
Su is scheduled to return to Taipei Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVIATION SAFETY COUNCIL CHAIRMAN HONORED

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Aviation Safety Council (ASC) under the Executive Yuan, has been honored with an award for his achievements, ASC officials said Wednesday.

Upon the recommendation of the U.S.-based Flight Safety Foundation, Kay Yong received the Laura Taber Barbour Air Safety Award in Shanghai, where the foundation is holding its annual international air safety seminar Nov. 15-18.

The officials noted that award was established in 1956 by the late Clifford E. Barbour and his son, Clifford E. Barbour Jr., in memory of the elder Barbour's wife, a passenger on a DC-3 that struck a mountain in West Virginia in 1945.

The award recognizes notable achievements in the field of aviation safety in method, design, invention, study or other improvements. Over the past 48 years, most of the recipients of the award have been Americans.
The Flight Safety Foundation recommended Yong because under his leadership, the ASC has become an independent and professional body, projecting an image of fairness, integrity and professionalism.
Yong was the Aviation Weekly and Space Technology 2002 laureate and also holds the Sir Barnes Wallis Medal, awarded by the Guild of Air Pilots and Air Navigators of Great Britain.
Yong, 63, served as adjunct professor of National Cheng Kung University and director of the Aerospace Science and Technology Research Center before he became the ASC managing director and chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS POSITIVE ON EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT MEMBERS

TEXT.P: An official of the pro-independence Taiwan Association of University Professors (TAUP) expressed welcome Wednesday that members of the European Parliament Committee on Foreign Affairs have opposed the lifting of a ban on arms sales to mainland China.

TAUP Secretary-General Hsiao Chih-ju made the remarks in the wake of a discussion on arms sales in the Committee on Foreign Affairs that day, when several members spoke out against the lifting of the arms embargo that was imposed after the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989.

Commissioner for External Relations Chris Pattern also said that if China had made more substantial progress in human rights, then it could have persuaded the Europeans that a lifting of the ban would be appropriate.

Hsiao welcomed the views, but he also cautioned that some major European countries are still promoting a lifting of the embargo and that the European Union could very possibly announce a lifting by mid-2005.
"The government should address the issue squarely, and block any possible move in that direction," he said.
He also urged the EU to demand that China forego the use of force against Taiwan if it wants to lift the ban, so as to safeguard Taiwan's safety.

Hsiao said that the association is joining forces with European non-governmental organizations to lobby members of the European Parliament to support Taiwan's position, hoping to build momentum within Europe to oppose a lifting of the arms embargo, adding that the efforts have borne initial results.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN'S GROUP RECOMMENDS PRO-GENDER EQUALITY CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: The Awakening Foundation released Wednesday a list of recommended candidates for the Dec. 11 legislative elections that the group considers faithful advocates of gender equality.
Fan Yun, a board director of the foundation, said the candidates were selected based on their long-time devotion to the promotion of gender equality and not based on partisan considerations.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidates on the list include Chou Ching-yu, Yeh Yi-chin, Chou Ya-shu, Hsiao Bi-khim, Tang Pi-o, Tuan Yi-kang, Shen Fu-hsiung, Chen Chin-jun and Lai Ching-te.
The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidates recommended by the group are Tina Pan, Wang Yu-ting, Yang Li-huan, Tsai Ling-lan, Hung Hsiu-chu, Chen Shei-saint and Shyu Jong-shyong.
The opposition People First Party (PFP) candidates on the list are Li Yung-ping, Chao Liang-yen, Chin Huei-chu and Shen Chih-hwei.
While Chien Lin Hui-chun is the only Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) candidate on the list, the independent candidates recommended by the group include Su Ying-kui, Wang Fang-ping and Lin Cheng-hsiu.
The at-large legislative candidates of the DPP recommended by the group are Chen Hsiu-hui, Huang Shu-ying, Yang Fang-wan and Lu Tzu-yen. Those from the KMT are Huang Chao-shun and Huang Te-fu.
On the percentage of female candidates fielded by each party, the DPP stands at 20 percent, the KMT at 26 percent, the PFP at 23 percent and the TSU at 10 percent, according to Fan.
She pointed out that all the figures have failed to reach the 30-percent target set by the parties.
Also Wednesday, a draw was conducted in each county and city to decide the order of the candidates on the ballots.
In Taipei City, meanwhile, the DPP unveiled a vote-allocation plan aimed at scoring all five seats it is vying for in the Taipei-south district.

According to the plan, DPP supporters whose identification card numbers end with the Arabic numerals "1" and "2" are asked to vote for Lan Mei-chin; those ending with "3" and "4" are urged to vote for Julian Kuo; those ending with "5" and "6" are asked to vote for Tuan Yi-kang; those ending with "7" and "8" are urged to vote for Shen Fu-hsiung; and those ending with "9" and "0" are asked to vote for Wang Shih-chien.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 117.83 points to close at 6,028.68.
The bourse opened at 5,916.12 and fluctuated between 6,028.68 and 5,904.61 during trading. A total of 4.47 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$106.98 billion (US$3.26 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 2.7 percent, followed by textile stocks at 2.1 percent, construction issues at 1.7 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.2 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.9 percent and paper and pulp issues and cement stocks both at 0.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 579 to 90, with 113 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO WITNESS REINTRODUCTION OF HISTORICAL TABLET IN PENGHU

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to fly to Penghu Saturday to officiate at a ceremony marking the reintroduction of an ancient stone tablet that carries the history of the first encounter between Chinese and Dutch officials in the early 17th Century, which had a profound influence on Taiwan's development.

The ancient stone tablet -- with a Chinese inscription saying that Ming dynasty official Shen Yourong rejects Dutch Captain Wijbrand van Waerwijck here -- was carved in the Penghu Islands (Pescadores) in December 1604 after van Waerwijick, an official and captain of the Dutch East India Company, was rejected by Shen, a Ming Dynasty official from Fujian, over a request to exchange in commerce.
The stone tablet was first unearthed from under the floor of an altar in the Tienhou Matsu temple in Makung, Penghu's capital city, in 1919 when the temple was being rebuilt.

The tablet was stored in a corner of the temple until 1985 when the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) refurbished the temple and designated it a national historical site. The stone tablet was at that time moved to a library on the second floor of the temple.
Although the stone tablet remains intact, the characters engraved upon it have long since become blurred.
Van Waerwijck led a Dutch East India Company fleet to today's Macau in early 1604 in an attempt to take it as a colonial bastion.

But he was defeated by the Ming troops there and consequently led the remaining fleet in a retreat. Pounded by a typhoon, van Waerwijck and his fleet arrived in the Penghu islands, also then Ming territory, in summer of that year.
The Dutch East India Company forces landed on Penghu and started settling there. Van Waerwijck, meanwhile, sent his men to Fujian to request to exchange in commerce with the Chinese.

Before long, Shen Yourong, under the authority of the Ming government, led 20 ships to Penghu to expel the Dutch invaders. Shen rebuked van Waerwijck for offering a bribe of 30,000 gold nuggets and told him that a Chinese traitor, Pan Xiu, who guided the Dutch to Penghu, would be executed. On Dec. 15, 1604, van Waerwijck left Penghu.
After departing Penghu, van Waerwijck headed to Taiwan, then not yet part of Ming territory, to begin another page of the Dutch colonization of the island.
History would have been different should van Waerwijick have succeeded in capturing Macau or if the Ming forces did not expel the Dutch from Penghu, CCA officials said.
The stone tablet reintroduction is part of a series of activities that the CCA is sponsoring to mark the 400th anniversary of the first encounter between Chinese and Dutch officials.

Among the activities will be an exhibition at the Tienhou Matsu Temple of photos, historical artifacts and documents that witness the Dutch activities in the area including the Chinese mainland, the Penghu islands and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: BASIC LANGUAGE ABILITY TO BE PREREQUISITE FOR NATURALIZATION

TEXT.P: Foreigners intending to naturalize as Republic of China citizens must possess basic language ability and knowledge about ROC citizens' rights and obligations, according to a draft package of revisions to the existing Nationality Law.
The Cabinet passed the draft package at its weekly meeting Wednesday and it will soon be referred to the Legislative Yuan for approval, a Cabinet official said.

With the number of foreign spouses increasing rapidly in Taiwan, the official said, the government has attached great importance to their life and work in local society, as well as the education of their children.

Against this backdrop, the official said, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has come up with the draft revisions to the Nationality Law to add basic language and civic knowledge requirements to those who intend to naturalize as ROC citizens.

To facilitate implementation of the revisions, the official said that Premier Yu Shyi-kun has directed the MOI to join forces with the Ministry of Education, the Ministry of Justice and the Ministry of Economic Affairs to work out required language and civic knowledge measurement standards and complementary testing rules.

Under the existing law, foreigners intending to naturalize must meet requirements regarding abode, duration of residence, financial status, professional skills, sobriety and having no criminal record.
"We hope to add language ability and civic knowledge requirements in the future so that naturalized foreign spouses can adapt to the local lifestyle more easily," the official said.

Official tallies show that Taiwan now has more than 320,000 foreign spouses, most of whom are young women from Southeast Asian countries. Because of the language barrier, many of them have a hard time adapting to daily life here and educating their children.
Yu has recently directed the MOI to strengthen care and assistance for foreign spouses, including pushing them to receive literacy and supplementary education, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S DIGITAL CAMERA OUTPUT ON RISE: III

TEXT.P: Taiwan's output of digital cameras continued to grow for the third quarter of this year, with models of four and five megapixels dominating production, according to the results of a recent investigation by the semi-official Institute for Information Industry (III).

The investigation carried out by the III's Market Information Center (MIC) showed that Taiwan manufactured 5.94 million digital cameras in the third quarter, up by 12.4 percent compared to the second quarter level and a 19.2 percent growth over the previous year's level.
The sector's Q3 production value hit US$549 million, a rise of 25.1 percent year-on-year, but the average price quotation dropped to US$92.4 per unit, according to the investigation.
It also discovered that four and five megapixel models have replaced three megapixel models as the mainstay of production, enjoying a stake of more than 50 percent.

MIC researchers said that market demand for high resolution and value-added products will remain strong but forecast that the domestic industry's output volume will reach around 5.65 million for the fourth quarter, a slight fall of 5 percent from the Q3 level, as a result of eroded consumer confidence due to higher oil prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November gained 111 points to close at 6,040, with 18,339 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December moved up 132 points to finish at 6,063 with 40,468 contracts traded, while March futures gained 128 points to finish at 6,060, with 30 contracts traded.
June futures gained 139 points to finish at 6,045, with 43 contracts traded, while September futures moved up 122 points to close at 6,010, with 47 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,929 for November, 5,931 for December, 5,932 for March, 5,906 for June and 5,888 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
November TE futures moved up 6.7 points to close at 227.7, with 4,517 contracts traded, while December TE futures gained 7.75 points to finish at 228.45, with 8,402 contract transactions.
March TE futures gained 6.95 points to close at 227, with three contracts traded, while September TE futures moved down 0.25 points to finish at 219.55, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.
November TF futures gained 9.4 points to finish at 1,058.4, with 4,500 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved up 12.4 points to end at 1,060.4, with 10,462 contracts traded.

March TF futures gained 14.6 points to finish at 1,057.6, with five contracts changing hands, while June TF futures moved up 15.8 points to close at 1,055, with one contract traded. September TF futures gained 6 points to end at 1,041.8, with two contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, dropping NT$0.16 to close at NT$32.659.
A total of US$702 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.829 and hit a low of NT$32.620.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC TAIWANESE NAMED TO SERVE IN CALIFORNIA STATE GOVERNMENT
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Nov. 16 (CNA) (By Chiang Ying & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: An Taiwanese American was recently named by movie star-turned-California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger as a member of the state's Labor and Workforce Development Agency.

Forty-seven-year-old Liou Shenq-chern, also known as Sean Liou, is the only Asian American among five people appointed by Schwarzenegger Nov. 15 to deal with his administration's policies on workforce and economic investment. He told the Central News Agency on Tuesday that his new assignment is without stipend.

Liou said that he will focus on the work of helping new immigrants with vocational training assistance, providing opportunities for private enterprises to forge cooperation ties with state-run departments, and ensuring that the state's workforce reflects a multi-ethnic population structure.

Liou is an active Republican who has served as a member of the White House's Advisory Commission on Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders, and helped Schwarzenegger to win the governorship. He was also named to take care of handover affairs for the new governor.

Liou was born in Chiayi, southern Taiwan, and graduated from Changhua's National Taiwan College of Education. He obtained a masters degree in mathematics and computers from the University of Massachusetts 20 years ago, since which time he has been working in the sector of insurance and real estate investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG URGED AGAIN TO INCREASE EXCHANGES WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Nov. 17 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong authorities were once again called upon Wednesday to establish a representative office in Taiwan and increase exchanges with Taiwan liaison officials stationed there.

Taiwan's representative in Hong Kong, Pao Cheng-kang, urged the Hong Kong authorities to adopt an open and pragmatic approach to handling Taiwan-Hong Kong affairs, including opening a counterpart liaison office in Taiwan.

Pao, who assumed his Hong Kong post Oct. 18, said that Hong Kong and Taiwan can cooperate to bolster bilateral ties, beginning with a swap of representative offices and stepped-up bilateral exchanges in tourism and high technology industry and business.

Pao has still had no opportunity to meet with Hong Kong's Secretary for Constitutional Affairs Stephen Lam for a talk even after being in Hong Kong for a month, and said that the Hong Kong authorities are too reserved with regard to Taiwan-Hong Kong affairs.
He reiterated that the Hong Kong authorities could have done better and added that Hong Kong is the best platform for communication between Taiwan and mainland China.
It was the second time in a week that Pao had made a call for efforts to facilitate bilateral exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong.
In a similar appeal Nov. 12, he called for the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government to let its staff members visit Taiwan more often to optimize private exchanges between the two sides.
Pao said in an interview with the Sing Pao daily newspaper that Hong Kong and Taiwan can foster closer bilateral ties beginning in less-sensitive areas like the private sector.

Visits by lower-ranking Hong Kong civil servants to Taiwan could be a good start to better mutual understanding between the two sides and to pave the way for closer ties, said Pao, whose official title is managing director of the Chung Hwa Travel Service in Hong Kong.
He reiterated that mutual trust and a genuine desire for better ties fostered by Hong Kong and Taiwan would lay the groundwork for closer exchanges between the two sides.

In fact, Pao said, Hong Kong and Taiwan benefited from medical exchanges during the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome in early 2003, adding that the fact that it took a shorter period of time for him to get a work visa from the Hong Kong authorities than it took his predecessor is an indication that bilateral ties are improving.
Having Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa visit Taiwan is of course a distant wish, Pao said, adding that he will nevertheless work relentlessly toward that goal.

Pao was chief secretary of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) before being appointed Taiwan's representative in Hong Kong earlier this year. The MAC is the direct supervisory agency in charge of the Chung Hwa Travel Service.
MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san recently called for the Hong Kong government to seriously consider setting up offices in Taiwan to promote bilateral ties.

Noting that more than 230,000 Hong Kong visitors arrived in Taiwan in the first nine months of this year for sightseeing and business purposes, Chiu said that the number is nearly equal to that for the whole of last year, which he said demonstrates that exchanges between the two sides are increasing rapidly.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: LUKoil Eyes Deliveries to China, Japan.
Top oil producer LUKoil said Tuesday it is preparing to ship crude directly to China and Japan by rail and ship, opening up vast new markets for the energy giant. LUKoil deputy CEO Leonid Fedun said deliveries could start as soon as the government and national rail monopoly Russian Railways, or RZD, agrees to reduce transport tariffs to make the new export routes economically viable.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE TAIWANESE FIRMS SET UP OPERATIONS IN PHILIPPINES
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Nov. 16 (CNA) (By Emerson T. Lim and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Three Taiwanese enterprises have opted to establish operations in the Philippines' Subic Bay Industrial Park in support of the Taiwan government's "go south" policy, Republic of China Representative to the Philippines Wu Hsin-hsing said Wednesday.
The Coin Chemical, Taiwan Pao An Industrial Co. and Asia Wooden Articles Industrial Co. signed contracts with the park on the investment projects last Saturday, Wu said.
The three enterprises are expected to invest a total of US$50 million in the park and create 2,700 jobs, Wu said.

Wu, who attended the contract-signing ceremony, said he also visited the Subic Bay Metropolitan Authority (SBMA) and discussed with Filipino officials the operational problems faced by Taiwanese investors.

During the meeting, SBMA head Alfredo Antonio promised to help work out solutions to problems such as high water, electricity and land rental costs, about which Taiwanese investors there have complained, Wu said.
Wu, meanwhile, told Antonio that Taiwan will continue to promote the "go south" policy and encourage businesses to set up operations in Subic Bay, a freeport located about 80 km from Manila.
He also urged the SBMA to improve the investment environment of Subic Bay to enhance its competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD STRESS STRATEGIC LOCATION WHEN DEALING WITH U.S.

TEXT.P: A former Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Wednesday that Taiwan should stress its "strategic location" when dealing with the United States.

Lin Chong-pin, who is now a professor at the Graduate Institute of International Affairs and Strategic Studies of Tamkang University, said that for incoming U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, democracy and freedom are not the highest paradigms of the United States when dealing with other countries and that in the next four years of Bush's second term, the government should play its "strategic location" card, instead of appealing for democracy.

The former MAC vice chairman noted that several of the core members of the Bush administration, including Rice herself, submitted a policy report on American national interests in July 2000 that first and foremost spoke of the establishment of favorable relations between mainland China and the United States in a seven-point focus, with peace in the Taiwan Strait placed third and democratic issues placed fifth.
Lin said that Rice and other U.S. high-ranking officials regard the mainland as the major potential rival in Asia and feel that good relations with Beijing must be established.

He said that with Taiwan jammed between the two superpowers, it should stress its strategic location rather than continuing to trumpet its democracy, for to Rice, strength is mightier than everything else.

In addition, Lin said that from the experience of the past four years, Taiwan's administration has to inform the United States in advance concerning its major policies on cross-strait relations and foreign affairs to save time and energy later in elaborating on the policies.
He stressed that this is not a sign of weakness but a principle of engagement between mature countries.
Meanwhile, an opposition Kuomintang expert on mainland affairs said that U.S. foreign policy is not expected to undergo any major adjustment after U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell steps down.
KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung made the remarks after U.S. President George W. Bush nominated Rice to replace Powell.

Chang said that the Bush administration has continued to adjust its cross-Taiwan Strait policy over the past two years and that the general view of the international community is that the policy is gradually tilting in favor of mainland China.

He predicted that although U.S. foreign policy will not see any major adjustments after Rice assumes the top U.S. diplomatic post, the trend is a tilt toward the mainland, which he claimed is due to Beijing's rising influence but is also a problem of Taiwan's own making.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO HELP REVIVE DOMESTIC FILM INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The government is dedicated to the creation of an environment conducive to the development of the movie industry, in the hope that Taiwan's film industry will shine once again, the head of the Government Information Office (GIO) said Wednesday.

GIO Director-General Lin Chia-lung made the remarks when he presided over the first of four presentations on incentives for film investors in Taipei. The three other presentations will be held in Taipei and Kaohsiung.
According to Lin, Taiwan culture is the most dynamic and creative in Asia, but Taiwan people seem to have lost interest in Taiwan films in recent years.

Describing the film industry as a high-return, high-risk business, he said the government will shoulder up to 20 percent of the investment risk to help encourage enterprises to put money into domestic filmmaking, he said.

He said that in the first stage of reviving Taiwan's film industry, the government will offer incentives to investors, nurture film talent and increase import taxes on foreign films. In the mid- and long-term, it will oversee a convergence of the movie, television and digital industries, and will encourage the cultural and creative industry, multi-national production of films, and coordination with related government agencies, so as to create an excellent environment for the development of Taiwan's movie industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OPENS DOOR WIDER TO MAINLAND CHINESE BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: Taiwan will open its doors much wider to mainland Chinese people intending to visit the island for business activities, Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Wednesday.
Chen made the remarks after the Cabinet passed a package of regulations governing visits by mainland people for business at its weekly meeting earlier in the day.
With the implementation of the new regulations, Chen said, the number of mainland business visitors can reach 140,000 or more annually, marking a 10-fold increase from the present figure.

Quoting statistics compiled by the Mainland Affairs Council and the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Chen said the government approves an average of 1,500 applications by prospective mainland business visitors per month and that about 70 percent of the applicants actually come to Taiwan, as the mainland authorities impose even stricter standards in screening such applications.
To date, Chen said, none of the mainland business visitors have ever absconded or overstayed their visas nor have they been found to have been involved in any illegal activities.

In the past, Chen said, the government has not formulated a special set of rules to regulate the entry of mainland business visitors. Screening of those applications were based on regulations governing mainland professionals' visits as well as regulations governing multinational corporations' business activities.

As many local business executives have complained of the stringency of the existing regulations, Chen said, the Cabinet decided to compile a new set of rules to govern the entry of mainland business visitors.

"The new rules largely ease restrictions on the qualifications of local companies or institutions intending to host mainland business people's visits to Taiwan, the number of mainland business people they are eligible to invite and the duration of mainland visitors' stay, " Chen said, adding that the new regulations will be able to meet the local business community's general demands and are expected to help attract more multinational business groups to invest in Taiwan to facilitate their inroads into the mainland market.

Under the new regulations, prospective local hosts are no longer confined to those who have invested more than US$300,000 in mainland China. Prospective mainland business visitors will no longer be restricted to those who have worked for a certain period of time at their current posts and more mainland business managers and professionals can be allowed to visit Taiwan for business activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: A life devoted to Iraq ends with a single bullet.
She devoted 30 years to helping Iraq -- opposing sanctions, campaigning against the war and working for the survival of the country's neediest when all other foreign aid workers had fled. But neither her dedication to her adopted country, nor even her conversion to Islam and marriage to an Iraqi, could save Margaret Hassan from the killer's bullet. She was, however, spared the decapitation meted out to many victims.
Financial Times: Company reporting proposals relaxed.
New corporate reporting requirements will be more business-friendly and less legally threatening, after the government gave way to intense lobbying from business groups over the proposals.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGING PROBLEM TO CAUSE SHORTAGE IN HI-TECH WORKFORCE: TIER

TEXT.P: Low fertility and an aging population are expected to worsen workforce shortages in Taiwan, especially in the hi-tech sector, according to a report released Wednesday by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER).

While the number of people 65 years old and older accounted for over 7 percent of Taiwan's population in 1993, the figure has risen to 9.24 percent with nearly 2.09 million people by 2003, Ministry of the Interior statistics show.
The fertility rate in Taiwan, meanwhile, has dropped to one child per woman today from four children per woman decades ago, and every 7.6 working persons need to support one elderly person now.
It is estimated that every 2.7 working people will need to support one elderly person 20 years from now, and 50 years from now, it will become every 1.6 working people supporting one elderly person.

According to the report authored by TIER associate research fellow Chen Miao, the aging of Taiwan's population will lead to a decline in productivity and lay a heavy burden on future generations as they will have to support the senior population.

As young people nowadays tend to spend longer in education, which delays their entry into the job market, the low fertility and aging of the workforce will further worsen manpower shortages, Chen said.
Chen said the shortages will also affect the hi-tech sector and threaten its competitiveness.
To solve the problem, he suggested that the government push back the standard retirement age, which now stands at 65 years old.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES MORE MONEY FOR GRENADA'S POST-DISASTER RECONSTRUCTION
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Nov. 17 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China donated an additional US$2 million to Grenada Tuesday to help with the Caribbean nation's post-disaster reconstruction projects.
ROC Ambassador Jiang Li-shang presented the check to Grenadian Prime Minister Keith Claudius Mitchell on behalf of the ROC government in a ceremony held at Mitchell's office.
Jiang said the money will be used for construction of housing units and public facilities as well as for education programs.

Since Grenada was hit by Hurricane Ivan in September this year, Taiwan has so far donated US$4.75 million to help with the nation's post-disaster rehabilitation. In addition to the latest donation, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen presented a US$1.5 million check to the Grenadian government when he visited the country Sept. 18.

On Oct. 14, the ROC donated an additional US$1 million in relief aid. Shortly after the disaster, the ROC donated US$200,000 worth of relief goods and the ROC Embassy donated US$5,000, which was originally earmarked for a cocktail reception to mark the ROC's Oct. 10 National Day. The embassy didn't hold any National Day celebration so that the money could be used to help with Grenada's rehabilitation projects.
In addition, the ROC government has promised to assist Grenada in building a stadium for the country to host the 2007 World Cup cricket championship.
The ROC's agricultural mission stationed in Grenada has also donated a large quantity of vegetable seedlings and fruit seeds.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPZA APPROVES INVESTMENT PROJECTS WORTH US$69.56 MILLION IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: The Economic Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs approved five investment plans worth a combined NT$2.28 billion (US$69.56 million) for November, EPZA officials said Wednesday.

The investment projects will be launched by five companies dedicated mainly to the manufacture of high-tech products, including digital and optoelectronic products and are expected to create more than 1,100 job opportunities, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: U.S. Troops Move to Rein in Rebels in North of Iraq.
The U.S. military raced into the streets of Mosul to root out bands of rebels. Also, a kidnapped aid worker was feared dead.
The Wall Stree Journal: Kmart, Sears to Merge In $11 Billion Deal.
Kmart Holding Corp. and Sears, Roebuck & Co. agreed to merge in an $11 billion transaction.

DOC.HEADLINE: MSCI'S WEIGHTING INCREASE MEANS PRAISE FOR TAIWAN: CEPD OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Morgan Stanley Capital International's (MSCI's) announcement of its prospective weighting increase later this month for Taiwan is an affirmation of the country's progress and growth, a government official said Wednesday.

Hu Chung-ying, director of the Economic Research Department under the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , made the remarks after the MSCI issued the announcement earlier the same day.

Saying that the MSCI's move is an indication of its recognition of Taiwan's efforts in financial and entrepreneurial reform, Hu said that the famous investment consulting company's further weighting increase planned for May next year is set to provide fresh leads for the domestic stock market.

Effective following the Nov. 30 trading, the MSCI will raise its inclusion weight of the MSCI Taiwan Index to 75 percent from the current 55 percent. It will fully increase the ratio to 100 precent in late May 2005. By that time, Taiwan will surpass South Korea to become the Far East's largest country outside Japan in terms of the MSCI's weight capitalization.

Fueled by the lead, the weighted index in the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose by 117.83 points to close at 6,028.68 the same day. All eight major share categories rose, particularly the flat-panel and other hi-tech shares. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. finished at a six-month high of NT$49.5 per share.
Foreign institutional buyers have overpurchased Taiwan stocks for 15 trading days in a row.

An executive at the Taipei-based Jin Sun Futures Co., Ltd. said that he is looking forward to a new wave of surges following the Dec. 11 legislative elections and that buying by foreign investors will be the key engine that will push the market up, especially in the fourth quarter, according to past experience.

Market analysts predicted that the MSCI's first stage movement will help bring in foreign capital worth about US$7.3 billion for the domestic bourse on strong speculation that the weighted index will continue climbing to 6,800 points in the coming month.

At present, local investors have remained more conservative in the face of bullish sentiments, market watchers pointed out, claiming that they will soon join ranks with foreign investors in search of handsome profits.

Meanwhile, the new Taiwan dollar has come under robust pressure to appreciate in view of the persistent influx of foreign capital despite its rapid gains in value against the greenback over the past month.

Chou Ar-ting, director-general of the Foreign Exchange Department of Taiwan's Central Bank of China, said that the central bank will leave the value of the local currency to be decided by market forces.

For the time being, the impact of a strengthening new Taiwan dollar has been limited in the domestic export sector, as other currencies, such as the Japanese yen and the euro, also rose against the U.S. dollar, he noted.
The new Taiwan dollar further firmed against the greenback by NT$0.16, finishing at 32.659 Wednesday in the Taipei foreign exchange market -- a new high in three years and eight months.
Local consumption and asset shares, including construction and financial stocks, will be helped the most by a stronger new Taiwan dollar, market watcher said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN ASKS HEAD OF LIONS CLUBS INT'L TO USE 'TAIWAN'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday he sincerely hopes that Taiwan's designation in the Lions Clubs International can be changed to "Taiwan" instead the current "China Taiwan."
Chen made the remarks while meeting with Clement F. Kusiak, president of the Lions Clubs International, who is currently on a visit to Taipei.
Without the consent of Taiwan's Lions Clubs, Lions Clubs International changed Taiwan's designation in the organization from the Republic of China to "China Taiwan" two years ago.
The change was regrettable, Chen said, adding that all of the 30,000-plus members of the Taiwan Lions Clubs unanimously demanded that the designation in the organization be changed to "Taiwan."
Since the first Lions Club was established in Taiwan in 1953, Chen said, the number of Lions Clubs has grown to exceed 100, with more than 32,000 members.

Over the past 10 years, Chen said, local Lions Clubs have donated more than US$10 million to the Foundation of the Lions Clubs International. The donations have contributed much to the enhancement of people's well-being, Chen said, adding that he hopes Kusiak can help realize local Lions Clubs members' common wish of having Taiwan's present designation rectified.
The Lions Clubs International is the world's largest volunteer service organization, with 1.4 million members in 46,000 clubs in 193 countries and geographical areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REJECTS CHINESE 'CENSORSHIP' OF TV COMMERCIAL BANNED IN CHILE

TEXT.P: The government Wednesday refused to revise a TV commercial that was to be shown in Chile during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum meeting, which was banned owing to protests from mainland China.

Calling the mainland's move a form of "censorship, " Government Information Office Director-General Lin Chia-lung said for the sake of national dignity, Taiwan will not change the content of the TV commercial just to meet China's expectations.
Also, Lin said, Taiwan will not pay for the air-time for the commercial because Chile has breached the contract with Taiwan by ordering the ban.

The two-minute commercial showcasing Taiwan's natural beauty, economic and technological developments, delicious foods and achievements in sports was launched on Nov. 14 in Chile and was originally set to run through Nov. 21.
However, it was stopped Nov. 16 after China protested to Chilean authorities over a line in the narration, which says "building a nation one day at a time."
China argued that the word "nation" had violated the "one China" policy of APEC.
Lin said the line is meant to emphasize the energy and vitality of Taiwan and that China's emotional reaction has exposed its ignorance and cowardice.
He said Taiwan has no intention of stirring up controversy at the APEC meeting but will not yield to any attempt by China to degrade its status.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FLAG RAISED IN VANUATU: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China flag was finally raised Wednesday in Port-Vila, the capital of Vanuatu, heralding the start of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, according to Michel Lu, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Lu made the remarks at a news conference where he confirmed that the ministry had received written notice of the matter from the Vanuatu government earlier the same day.

ROC diplomats in Vanuatu immediately raised the national flag at a makeshift embassy in a local hotel after having gained approval from the Vanuatuan government, Lu said, quoting the officials as adding that no boycott or protests from mainland China surfaced in the process.
Lu was reserved when asked by reporters about who might be appointed ambassador to the new ally, saying only that the ministry is looking for a qualified career diplomat.

Vanuatu Prime Minister Serge Vohor signed a document Nov. 3 in Taipei with Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen to set up diplomatic relations with the ROC. However, the matter was later shelved by the country's Cabinet due to Beijing's protests.
The South Pacific country finally recognized its ties with Taiwan Monday, becoming the ROC's 27th diplomatic ally in a diplomatic tug-of-war with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD CONSUMER PROTECTION FORUM TO OPEN IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The International Conference of Consumption Safety and Protection and the World Consumer Protection Forum will open Thursday in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, the organizers said Wednesday.

Representatives of 12 consumer protection groups from 11 countries, including the United States, Canada, Sweden, South Korea and Japan, will attend the meeting, which is jointly organized by the Kaohsiung Municipal Government and the Consumers Foundation of the Republic of China.
The main purpose of the two-day meeting, which will be held at National Sun Yat-sen University, is to share the practical experiences and progress of consumer protection, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET SPOKESMAN, DPP DEFEND FUNDRAISING PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai defended the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) requirement that its members holding high-ranking posts in the government and state-owned enterprises donate funds to the party.

Chen, a DPP member who had served as a legislator for three terms before assuming his current post, said it is a normal practice in democratic countries for party members to raise funds within the law, which in Taiwan is the Political Contributions Law.

"Since the DPP doesn't have any party assets, it can only rely on membership fees and funds raised or donated by its public office-holding members," Chen said, adding that the practice has been used since the DPP's establishment 18 years ago.

Chen said the DPP headquarters has opened a special account to receive voluntary political contributions from rank and file members as well as supporters and always issues receipts for each political donation.

Chen was responding to media reports that the DPP headquarters has recently sent letters to its members holding high-ranking posts in the government and state-run enterprises to raise funds for the party.

According to DPP regulations, an ROC president who is from DPP must donate or raise NT$10 million annually; the vice president NT$3 million; the premier NT$2.5 million and the vice premier NT$1.5 million; chairmen of state-owned enterprises who are DPP members must raise or donate NT$1 million annually.

"All of our fundraising activities have been transparent and have strictly abided by the law, " Chen stressed, adding that the DPP headquarters has enclosed copies of the Political Contributions Law provisions in its letter to its members holding high-ranking posts in the government and state-owned enterprises to remind them not to violate the law in their fundraising activities.
DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan said political parties can receive donations under the Political Contribution Law.

"Our public office-holders can either raise funds from their supporters or make donations out of their own pockets. Our fundraising activities are legal and transparent. There will absolutely not be any cases of funneling government funds or state-run enterprises' funds into our party coffers, " Cheng insisted.

Government Information Office Director-General Lin Chia-lung, a DPP member who is required to raise NT$500,000 for the party this year, said he will donate the sum out of his own pocket and would not solicit donations from supporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: RISING LOCAL UNIT NOT TO HINDER TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: A stronger new Taiwan dollar is not expected to affect Taiwan's economic growth rate this year, scholars said Wednesday.

Hsu Chen-ming, an economics professor at National Taiwan University, said that the new Taiwan dollar's recent gains in value against the U.S. dollar have been moderate compared to other Asian currencies' appreciation.
The Japanese yen and the South Korea won have appreciated against the U.S. dollar more sharply, a development which Hsu said will bail out Taiwan's export-oriented economy.

Lai Feng-hsiung, dean of the College of Business at Tamkang University, contended that an appreciation of mainland China's renminbi will have a greater impact on the domestic economy on the grounds that most of Taiwan's exports are bound for the mainland.

Should the mainland currency remain stable this year, Taiwan's economic growth rate will also stay on track, Lai said, pointing out that market forces are very likely to stop the greenback further depreciating out of public concern about a serious shrinkage in their assets in U.S. dollars.

The two men's comments came after the new Taiwan dollar closed at 32.659 against the U.S. dollar -- a new high in three years and eight months -- on the same day in the Taipei foreign exchange market.

Although a strengthening local currency is good for bringing down import product prices and quell growing inflation at home, some people are worried about whether it will make Taiwan's exports less competitive overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO INCREASE COMMUNICATIONS WITH U.S. ADMINISTRATION: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan will increase communications with the United States administration, particularly on trade and economic relations, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday.

Receiving Rupert Hammond-Chambers, chairman of the US-Taiwan Business Council, at the Executive Yuan, Yu said that Taiwan hopes to sign a free trade agreement with the U.S. as soon as possible because it is the most important trading partner for Taiwan.
Taiwan has paid a great deal of importance to the protection of intellectual property, which will continue to be a priority of his Cabinet's administration, the premier assured.

Yu thanked Hammond-Chambers for his council's assistance and support for the signing of a Taiwan-U.S. free trade agreement and for removing Taiwan from the priority watch list of the special 301 provisions of the 1989 U.S. Omnibus Trade Acts.
Taiwan will continue to enhance communications with the U.S. administrative branch to further promote bilateral trade and economic cooperation, Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAPERLESS CUSTOMS-CLEARING TO BE READY IN TAIWAN BY 2005: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The chief of Taiwan's Customs Service, Yu Shao-wu, said in Santiago Tuesday that Taiwan will begin automatic customs-clearing services by 2005, which means that written documentation will no longer be required.

Yu, who is attending the senior official's meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, said his office is introducing electronic clearing facilities and Taiwan's experience has aroused the interest of other APEC members at the meeting, which was held Nov. 14-15.
An electronic customs-clearing system will speed up the process and save both time and money, Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE CANDIDATES DRAW NUMBERS AND JOCKEY FOR LIMELIGHT

TEXT.P: All 493 legislative candidates drew their designation numbers in 25 counties and cities around Taiwan Wednesday.
The candidates each drew their number in the order in which they had registered for the race, and the number they drew will determine the order in which their names will appear on the ballots.

Most of the candidates were escorted to the occasion by large numbers of their supporters, in addition to bands of drums and gongs to boost their campaign. Some, however, sent others to pick up the number for them.
Some of the candidates tried to grab the limelight with stunts, turning the event into a circus-like atmosphere.
In Taichung City, central Taiwan, four candidates nominated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, showed up in military camouflage to show their solidarity.
Ho Ming-hau, a candidate for the Taiwan Solidarity Union waved a baseball bat before picking up his number to highlight his determination to hit a "home run" in the race.
Kuomintang candidate Lu Hsiou-yen appeared with four men who dressed as women and bared their pot bellies on which Lu's name was written.
A New Party candidate arrived in a truck converted into a tank.

In Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, all candidates showed up in person and brought with them their supporters who carried their campaign flags and painted their numbers on their flags once the numbers were determined.
An independent candidate in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan, called in a singer and a dozen campaign workers who danced in swimming suits at the number-drawing occasion.

Legislator Liao Feng-teh, director of the Kuomintang Department of Organizational Affairs, predicted that his party will win 79 seats and the party's ally, the People First Party, about 40 seats, which means 119 seats in the 225-seat legislature.
Meanwhile, Legislator Tsai Hao, the convener of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union, predicted that his union will win about 20 seats and garner more than five percent of the total ballots cast.
Any party that receives more than five percent will be eligible for government financing for its campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Nov. 18, or the seventh day of the 10th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1886: Chester Alan Arthur, the 21st president of the United States, dies at the age of 57. He supported the 1883 Pendleton Act, which created the Civil Service Commission to regulate federal appointments.
1903: Panama signs a treaty with the United States granting the United States the rights to build the Panama Canal.
1905: Japan declares Korea to be a Japanese protectorate.
1909: Liao Tien-ting, a legendary hero in Taiwan, dies at the age of 27.
1926: George Bernard Shaw, Irish-born British playwright who won the 1925 Nobel Prize for literature, refuses to accept the prize money.
1931: Republic of China Gen. Ma Chan-shan and his troops put up a strong fight against the Japanese in Heilungkiang.
1936: Germany and Italy both issue proclamations recognizing the Falangist administration of Gen. Franco as the legitimate government of Spain.
1940: Winston Churchill confirms a lend-lease deal to allow the United States to establish military bases in St. Lucia, Guyana, Trinidad, Antigua, the Bahamas, Jamaica and Bermuda. In return, Britain receives 50 destroyers.
1963: Pu Hsin-yu, a noted Chinese painter, dies in Taipei at the age of 68.
1970: Beijing names an ambassador to Moscow, restoring top-level diplomatic relations for the first time in four years.
1972: The Fourth Asian Women's Cup Basketball Tournament opens in Taipei, with teams from the Republic of China, South Korea, Thailand, Hong Kong and Indonesia taking part.
1973: The First Asian Track and Field Meet opens in Manila.
1974: President Gerald Ford arrives in Tokyo, becoming the first U.S. president to visit Japan.
1975: The China Shipbuilding Corporation lays a 360-meter long, six-meter wide keel for its first 445,000-ton tanker.
1977: President Anwar Sadat becomes the first Egyptian leader to visit Israel.
1978: More than 900 members of a cult led by American pastor Jim Jones commit suicide in Jonestown, Guyana, by drinking a cyanide-laced fruit drink.
1987: Up to 34 people are killed as a fire sweeps through King's Cross underground station, one of London's busiest interchanges.
1991: Gustav Husak, former president and Communist Party leader of Czechoslovakia, dies in Prague at the age of 78. He crushed the Prague Spring in 1968.
1992: German Vice Chancellor Jurgen Mollemann and Economics Minister Vincent C. Siew reach an agreement on the establishment of direct air links and channels of communication on trade between the ROC and Germany.
1992: The French government approves the selling of 60 Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters to the Republic of China.
1995: Alexandra Manley, a businesswoman from Hong Kong, becomes Princess of Denmark in a wedding to Prince Joachim, second in line to the Danish throne.
1997: Some 60 tourists are killed by Islamic militants outside and ancient temple in Egypt.
1999: The 23rd joint meeting of the ROC-USA and US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Councils opens in San Antonio, Texas, with the participation of more than 600 senior business executives from both sides.
1999: The Republic of China and Guatemala sign an agreement on investment guarantees which will protect the business interests of both sides.
2000: Leaders of Japan's ruling party reach a compromise to avert the removal of Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori in a no-confidence vote to ward off a protracted internal power struggle.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "I like life indeed, but there is that which I like more than life; and therefore I will not seek to hold it by any improper ways. I dislike death indeed, but there is that which I dislike more than death, and therefore there are occasion when I will not avoid calamity (that may occasion death)."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REITERATES STRONG WILLINGNESS TO PARTAKE IN APEC ACTIVITIES
DOC.DATELINE: Santiago, Chile, Nov. 17 (CNA) (By Kuan Chung-wei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh and Finance Minister Lin Chuan met with their counterparts from Chile, Canada and South Korea Wednesday for bilateral talks on the first day of the ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
During the talks, Ho and Lin reiterated Taiwan's strong willingness to participate in all formal activities of the APEC.

In their talks with South Korean Trade Minister Kim Hyun-chong, Ho and Lin stressed that Taiwan has actively taken part in various APEC activities since 1991 and that it will also participate in all formal APEC activities to be held next year.
Ho and Lin expressed their admiration for South Korea's success in staving off a financial crisis while optimizing the development of its innovative and high-technology industries in recent years.
Also on Wednesday, Ho and Lin met with their counterparts from the host country of Chile, mainly for talks on bilateral cooperation on APEC-related issues.
Trade exchanges between Taiwan and Chile have gradually increased in recent years, thanks to the cooperative platform that the APEC has provided, Ho and Lin said.

Chile's exports to Taiwan for the first ten months of this year registered growth of 80 percent over the level for the previous year, while Chile's trade surplus with the island for the same period grew by 135 percent over the year-earlier figure.
The two ROC ministers also held similar talks with their counterparts from Canada during the day.

Ho, who arrived in the Chilean capital of Santiago Tuesday to attend the annual APEC ministerial-level meeting, said Taiwan's participation in APEC activities is mainly aimed at making positive contributions to trade liberalization championed by the regional economic cooperation forum as well as to the Doha round of global trade talks launched by the World Trade Organization in 2001.
Ho said the formation of an Asia-Pacific free trade area is one of the topics to be addressed at this year's APEC ministerial meeting.

As to Taiwan's plan to sign bilateral free trade agreements (FTAs) with its major trading partners, Ho said Taiwan faces difficulties negotiating FTAs with countries with which it doesn't maintain formal diplomatic ties.
"We must overcome these difficulties step-by-step. We should start by forging close cooperative ties, " Ho explained, adding that the government will tackle the issue with maximum patience.

For his part, Lin said he hopes to hold bilateral talks with his counterparts from other APEC member economies on customs cooperation and the signing of taxation agreements to facilitate mutual investment.

On the sidelines of the multilateral APEC ministers meeting, Ho and Lin are expected to hold bilateral talks with their counterparts from at least six other APEC member economies during the two-day run of the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER IN U.S. TO ATTRACT INVESTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Nov. 17 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Shih Yen-hsiang said in New York CIty Wednesday that Taiwan's high value-added products are a major attraction to American investors.

Shih, at the head of a 13-member delegation visiting the United States to solicit investment, made the remarks in a presentation in Manhattan during which he introduced Taiwan's investment environment, incentives for foreign investors, and the island's export processing zones.

He pointed out that Taiwan's industry has undergone major changes in recent years, adding that it is now more appropriate to invest in Taiwan's information technology, communications, and biomedicine sectors.

On whether the flow of Taiwan businesspeople to mainland China will hollow out Taiwan's industry, he said that it is normal for Taiwan businesses to invest on the mainland or in Southeast Asia, adding that they are mostly low-value businesses.

He invited the more than 40 U.S. enterprises in the biomedicine, communications and imaging sectors taking part in the presentation to invest in Taiwan. The enterprises showed interest but also expressed concerns about a shortage of skilled workers in Taiwan.

Shih's delegation arrived in New York City from Taipei Dec. 14. The delegation will also visit Minneapolis, Minn., and San Francisco, Calif., to give similar presentations before returning to Taipei Dec. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Top schools will be forced to admit unruly pupils.
Leading schools, including selective grammars, will have to accept disruptive pupils under government plans to confront classroom indiscipline, Charles Clarke told The Times last night.
The Education Secretary will tell head teachers today that they must all accept a fair share of expelled pupils rather than allow disruptive youngsters to be concentrated in "sink schools" shunned by parents.
Financial Times: Blair vows to target sabotage by animal rights extremists.
Tony Blair on Wednesday promised to introduce an unprecedented criminal offence that targets "economic sabotage" by animal rights activists as part of a drive to make Britain a global magnet for life science companies.
The new offence is designed to tackle the small band of anti-vivisectionists who attack companies by focusing on their suppliers, financial backers, investors and customers, as well as their employees and directors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 21ST IN THE WORLD IN LIVING ENVIRONMENT: ECONOMIST
DOC.DATELINE: London, Nov. 18 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks 21st among 111 countries around the world in terms of quality of living environment, according to a survey carried in a publication by the Economist released recently.
Taiwan scored a 7.26 out of a possible 10 in the survey in "The World in 2005" publication.
Ireland topped the list with a score of 8.33, followed by Switzerland, Norway, Luxemburg, and Sweden, in that order. Australia, Iceland, Italy, Denmark and Spain rounded out the top ten.
The United States and Canada ranked 13th and 14th, respectively, behind Singapore and Finland.
Hong Kong ranked 18th, compared with mainland China, which placed 60th on the list.
Zimbabwe finished dead last on the list, with a score of 3.89, according to the survey.
