DOC.HEADLINE: CHILD CARE CONCEPTS POLL RELEASED

TEXT.P: Nearly 50 percent of Taiwan parents believe children are obliged to repay any debts left by their parents, and parents in this group are at greater risk of committing murder-suicides involving their children, according to the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families.

The organization based its conclusions on a child care concepts survey it conducted on parents of elementary school children around Taiwan. The results of the survey, in which a total of 1,590 valid samples were collected, were unveiled Thursday.
In the survey, parents scored an average 70.22 points out of a possible 100 on child care, and 41 percent of the parents received scores of less than 70 points.

Nearly half of the parents surveyed said they believe children are responsible for any debts left behind by their parents, and nearly 20 percent said they would consider ending their children's lives in order to avoid them having to pay back their debts.
The organization urged society to pay attention to this group of parents as they potentially present a serious danger to their children.

The survey also found that 80 percent of the parents surveyed agree with the notion that children cannot have a normal life growing up without proper parental care, while 57 percent said that no one can take the place of parents. The organization interpreted these results as indicating that there is widespread distrust in the ability of the government or private care institutions to provide proper care for children.

On the question of disciplining children, nearly 30 percent of the respondents said that corporal punishment is unavoidable. The fund therefore reminded parents to try to avoid direct or cruel punishment in order not to inadvertently endanger the lives of their children.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATE HONG KONG TYCOON PROPOSED FEDERATION BETWEEN CHINA AND TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Nov. 18 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The late Hong Kong-based shipping magnate C.Y. Tung once proposed a federation formula for Taiwan and mainland China to bypass the thorny issue of "two Chinas, " according to a report in an English daily in Hong Kong Thursday.

In his diary, C.Y. Tung, who once owned the largest container fleet in the world, wrote that he suggested during a talk with former U.S. President Richard Nixon that Washington instigate the formation of a federation, similar to that of the United States of America, between Taiwan and mainland China to solve the "one China" or "two Chinas" problem and see the two rivals unify peacefully, according to the report carried in Thursday's South China Morning Post.
The innovative suggestion, however, was not received favorably by the then Beijing leadership, the report said.

According to the "Diary of C.Y. Tung, " which has just been published and is scheduled to hit Hong Kong's bookstores Saturday, Tung met with Nixon in Los Angeles in October 1979 for talks, during which he made the suggestion to the U.S. president who had normalized diplomatic relations between the United States and mainland China.

In his diary, Tung said that the Republic of China on Taiwan was forced out of the United Nations in 1971, but the notion of "two Chinas" was not recognized by either mainland China or the United States.
Gravely concerned with the situation, Tung, who had maintained close ties with Taiwan, made the "bold" proposal to Nixon.

In a diary entry dated May 1973, Tung, founder of Orient Overseas International Ltd. and Orient Overseas Container Lines (OOCL), wrote that he had striven to "try to pave the way for the Chinese Communist Party and the Kuomintang to talk for a peaceful resolution of the divisions between the two sides."
The Shanghai-born C.Y. Tung was the father of Tung Chee-hwa, who is currently the chief executive of the Special Administrative Region of Hong Kong. C.Y. Tung died at the age of 70 in 1982.
The diary also revealed that Tung, despite being a billionaire, led a simple life, traveling around by MRT and sometimes even washing his own clothes.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 TO BE 'YEAR OF HEALTH': VICE PRESIDENT LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday the government will designate 2005 as the year of health.

Lu made the remarks at a panel discussion of basic medical rights and the universal health insurance program. The meeting was attended by members of the Presidential Office human rights advisory panel, government officials and medical community representatives.

Noting that medical service and health care are basic human rights, Lu said the universal health insurance program is aimed at granting low-income people access to basic medical services and health care.

Lu said even though disputes over the universal health insurance program have arisen from time to time since its inception some 10 years ago, all relevant quarters are obliged to cooperate in resolving them so that the program can continue.

With a view to encouraging local people to lead a healthy lifestyle, Lu said the government will designate 2005 as "healthy life year" and will launch a series of activities to raise public health awareness.

In addition, Lu said the government will coordinate with travel service operators in issuing "healthy life tourist passports" to encourage local people to engage in health-oriented tours and leisure activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT ANNOUNCES RISING NUMBER OF SUCCESSFUL STUDENT VISA APPLICATIONS

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) announced Thursday that student visas issued to Taiwan students in the first 10 months of this year have surpassed the number during all of 2003.
AIT has issued 12,654 students visas to Taiwan applicants in Jan.-Oct. 2004, compared to 11,277 for all of 2003, AIT officials said.
The officials also said that the AIT acceptance rate for Taiwan student visa applications has continued to rise over the past several years.
Over 97 percent of visa applications have successfully resulted in the issuance of a student visa. This compares with issuance rates of approximately 90 percent in 2002 and 91 percent in 2003.
"We welcome and want to encourage international students to come to the U.S. to study," AIT Director Douglas Paal said.

"Although we have implemented new measures to make our borders and the traveling public more secure, we have not changed the basic criteria for visa eligibility to visit or study in the United States," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE PERSON SUFFERS FROM CANCER EVERY 8.5 MINUTES IN TAIWAN: REPORT

TEXT.P: One person was being diagnosed with cancer every 8.5 minutes in Taiwan in 2001, compared with 9 minutes the previous year, according to a report released Thursday by the Department of Health (DOH).
The statistics were compiled based on the number of cancer cases at 194 hospitals around the island with at least 50 beds in 2001.
There were 261.13 cancer patients out of every 100,000 people in Taiwan in 2001, with liver cancer and cervical cancer being the most common, the report showed.

It was found that the 10 most common kinds of cancer among men were liver cancer, lung cancer, colon cancer, oral cancer, stomach cancer, prostate cancer, bladder cancer, esophagus cancer, skin cancer and pharyngeal cancer.

Among women, the 10 most common kinds of cancer were cervical cancer, breast cancer, colon cancer, liver cancer, lung cancer, stomach cancer, thyroid cancer, skin cancer, ovary cancer and uterine cancer.
Chao Kun-yu, deputy director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion, said a total of 61,607 new cancer cases were reported in 2001, up 2,491 compared with 2000.
While there were 278.02 cancer patients out of every 100,000 men, there were 243.41 cancer patients for every 100,000 women, Chao said.

With cervical cancer and breast cancer usually diagnosed earlier than lung cancer and liver cancer, 57.84 percent of women cancer patients survive after five years, compared with only 32.35 percent of men, Chao said.
Chao attributed the increase of cancer cases in Taiwan to unhealthy living and dietary habits, in addition to the aging of the population.
He pointed out that people who smoke, drink alcohol and chew betel nuts are 123 fold more likely to suffer from cancer than those who do not.
For example, he said, the number of oral cancer cases among men in 2001 was 29.4 percent higher than the 1997 level, and the number of uterine cancer cases among women was 26.86 percent higher.
While the increase in oral cancer cases is related to the habit of betel nut chewing, the rise of uterine cancer is related to the consumption of a high-fat diet as well as hormonal changes, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PART OF GLOBAL ANTI-TERRORISM ACTIONS: INTERIOR MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not absent itself from international counter-terrorist actions and efforts, Republic of China Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan said in a speech made in Hawaii recently, sources from the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Thursday.

Su, who completed his attendance at the 2004 Asia-Pacific Homeland Security Summit and Exposition in Honolulu Nov. 14-17, delivered a speech during the summit to make known concrete measures taken by Taiwan against global terrorism, according to an MOI news release.

Su said that Taiwan has been active in taking part in global anti-terrorism efforts since the 9/11 terrorist attacks on the United States. Concrete measures taken in this regard included new plans and execution of the plans in Taiwan by the administration, MOI officials said in the news report released Thursday.
The interior minister is scheduled to return to Taipei Saturday.

Su related in his speech that Taiwan's Executive Yuan established a national counter-terrorism action task force in early 2002 in accordance with a resolution reached by the United Nations Security Council in the wake of the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

He stressed that although not a UN member, Taiwan considers itself a member of the global village and spares no efforts to contribute in efforts maintaining international peace and regional stability.
Taiwan is more than willing to cooperate with all members of the global village to optimize security of the world and bolster bilateral ties as well, Su added.

Su also introduced Taiwan, once known as Formosa, a beautiful island in the eyes of the Dutch navy and traders who first visited Taiwan more than 400 years ago, to his summit fellow participants. He received a big round of applause from the audience, the news release indicated.
During the summit, Su gave an exclusive interview with American Broadcast Corporation (ABC) , in which he urged the United States to include Taiwan in a U.S.-led global counter-terrorism system.
He also expressed Taiwan's eagerness to join the U.S.-led Proliferation Security Initiative (PSI) to contribute the island's wisdom and energy to help make the world a better place to live in.
Su, who kept his Hawaii visit low profile to avoid interference from Beijing, arrived in Honolulu Monday to participate in the second annual Asia-Pacific Homeland Security Summit since November 2003.

Su met with Hawaii Governor Linda Lingle for talks on a wide range of topics. During the meeting, Lingle, who visited Taiwan in 2001, told Su that she came away from her trip to Taiwan with a distinct impression of Taiwanese hospitality and strong cultural and educational development there.
For his part, according to the MOI officials, Su conveyed Premier Yu Shyi-kun's greetings to Lingle and the regional homeland summit meeting, which was sponsored by the state government of Hawaii.

Su told Lingle that with Pingtung County and Hawaii's Maui County being sister counties, Taiwan should learn from Hawaii's success in promoting tourism, adding that Taiwan should also exchange ideas about finding a balance between tourism and preventing terrorism.
At the dinner party Monday marking the opening of the summit, Su met with Tom Ridge, secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, for a brief chat, the MOI officials said.
Ridge told Su that he is welcome to visit Washington anytime for talks on counter-terrorism efforts, according to the officials.

The development of innovative response strategies to the threat of terrorism was at the core of the four-day conference, which had been divided into three tracks, namely leadership and policy, law enforcement, and counter-terrorism regional outreach.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE URGED TO SEEK CULTURAL ROOTS
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Nov. 17 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: All the people from Taiwan must work together to retrieve their cultural roots, better understand Taiwan and let Taiwan shine like a diamond internationally, national policy adviser and ambassador-at-large Tchen Yu-chiou said Wednesday.

The former chairwoman of the Council for Cultural Affairs made the remarks while delivering a speech on the metamorphosis of Taiwan to Taiwanese expatriates in Los Angeles. The event was organized by the Taiwanese United Fund (TUF).

Comparing Taiwan to a diamond, Tchen said it is time Taiwan displayed its new identity to the world as a "cultural Taiwan" after decades of swift changes, and the assimilation of various ethnic groups.
Los Angeles is one of Tchen's stops in her on-going tour around Europe and the United States in her capacity as an envoy promoting the culture of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 20.81 points to close at 6,049.49.
The bourse opened at 6,063.56 and fluctuated between 6,088.12 and 6,035.36 during trading. A total of 4.27 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$102.94 billion (US$3.16 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 0.6 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.3 percent and construction issues at 0.2 percent.
Three other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down at 0.8 percent and textile stocks and banking and financial shares both at 0.3 percent.
Foodstuff issues and plastics and chemicals shares both remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 418 to 219, with 141 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE THAI WORKER DIES, ANOTHER INJURED IN KAOHSIUNG MRT ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: One Thai worker was killed and another injured in an accident at a construction site of Kaohsiung's mass rapid transit (MRT) project on Thursday, police said
The two workers fell from an elevated track 10 meters above the ground in Chiaotou township, Kaohsiung County when they were installing a steel mold, according to police.
The injured man was reported in stable condition.
The Council of Labor Affairs has ordered that work at the construction site be suspended for a safety inspection.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December gained 9 points to close at 6,072 with 29,707 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January moved up 37 points to finish at 6,080, with 45 contracts traded, while March futures gained 12 points to finish at 6,072 with 10 contracts traded.
June futures gained 20 points to finish at 6,065 with five contracts traded, while September futures moved down one point to close at 6,009 with 36 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,063 for December, 6,043 for January, 6,060 for March, 6,045 for June and 6,010 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

December TE futures moved up 0.4 points to close at 228.85, with 7,013 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 2.2 points to finish at 229.2, with 13 contract transactions. March TE futures lost 0.65 points to close at 228.2, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months

December TF futures gained 0.2 points to finish at 1,060.6, with 7,303 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 0.2 points to end at 1,060.4, with 29 contracts traded. March TF future gained 4.2 points to finish at 1,060, with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT QUESTIONS DPP LEGISLATIVE CANDIDATE'S FITNESS TO RUN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Thursday a former official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should be thrown out of the Dec. 11 legislative elections because he was convicted for disseminating unfounded information.
But Cheng Yun-peng, a former director of the DPP's Department of Culture and Information, retorted by saying that he is currently in "not guilty" status.

Cheng said that he was acquitted in the first trial, but the plaintiffs appealed and he was subsequently sentenced to six months in jail. He then appealed to the Supreme Court, which returned the case to the Tainan branch of the high court for review.
"The case will be re-tried in Tainan Nov. 25, and I will continue to fight for justice," Cheng said.

A trio of KMT officials -- Liao Feng-teh, director of the KMT's Organization and Development Committee, Huang Teh-fu, KMT whip in the Legislative Yuan, and KMT Legislator Tsai Cheng-yuan -- asked Cheng to bow out at a news conference.
Liao noted that Cheng helped produced a party campaign ad three years ago in the previous legislative elections to smear opposition parties.

The ad, called "No matter how barbaric [you are], " which was believed to have dealt a heavy blow to the opposition, impressed voters with the message that no matter how barbaric the opposition parties are, they should not cut budgets that concern the general public. The ad linked a series of bills that failed to clear the legislature with the faces of opposition legislators to insinuate that they were to blame.

Liao said that Taiwan High Court's Tainan branch recently sentenced Cheng to six months in jail and stripped him of his civil rights for three years for disseminating unfounded information which was deemed defamatory.
"But Cheng, instead of being remorseful, has produced a sequel to the ad to try to smear the opposition parties," Liao said.

He further said that Cheng was most likely the fall guy for those higher up in the DPP. The Taipei Prosecutor's Office dismissed suits against then-DPP chairman Frank Hsieh and then-DPP secretary-general Wu Nai-jen over the same ad.
Liao also claimed that since the case had been dragged out over three years, there was room to suspect that a political force was involved.
KMT Legislator Huang Teh-fu said that the smear campaign has seriously undermined Taiwan's democracy, and the court's verdict is overdue justice for his party.
Tsai Cheng-yuan also said the KMT has stipulated clearly it will not nominate anyone who has been convicted, and he questioned the DPP's approach of nominating Cheng.
"Which political party has higher quality or standards is very self-evident here," Tsai said.

He said that mudslinging is the worst example of democracy, adding that all political parties have to establish a "code of conduct for political parties and candidates" to help upgrade campaigning in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Powell Says Iran Is Pursuing Bomb.
The United States has intelligence that Iran is working to adapt missiles to deliver a nuclear weapon, further evidence that the Islamic republic is determined to acquire a nuclear bomb, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OPTIMISTIC ABOUT JOINING APEC ENGINEERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Examination said Thursday that it is cautiously optimistic that Taiwan can join the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Engineers next year.
Ministry officials said that the body of APEC Engineers was established in 1995, with the purposes of recognizing "substantial equivalence " of professional competence in engineering.
The body currently has 11 member economies -- Australia, Canada, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, the United States and Thailand.

APEC countries can apply to become members of the agreement by demonstrating that they have in place systems that allow the competence of engineers to be assessed to the agreed international standard set by the APEC Engineers agreement.

Ministry officials noted that to bid for membership in the APEC Engineers, the Executive Yuan has since last year instructed the Ministries of Examination, Foreign Affairs and Education to send officials to form a promotion committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, dropping NT$0.239 to close at NT$32.420.
A total of US$1.13 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.560 and hit a low of NT$32.405.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ISSUE TO BE ON BUSH-HU TALKS AGENDA: WHITE HOUSE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 17 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Issues regarding cross-Taiwan Strait relations will be on the agenda of talks between U.S. President George W. Bush and mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao on the sidelines of an upcoming informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, senior White House officials said Wednesday.

Three White House officials gave a background briefing to foreign journalists stationed in Washington, D.C. ahead of Bush's departure for the Chilean capital of Santiago to attend the 2004 APEC summit meeting scheduled for Nov. 20-21. The three officials spoke on condition of anonymity.

The three officials said Bush will hold bilateral talks with Hu on the sidelines of the multilateral APEC summit meeting and that the topics to be addressed are expected to include the North Korea issue as well as the Taiwan Strait issue.
As far as the Taiwan Strait issue is concerned, the officials said, the United States will adhere to its "one China" policy.

The officials further said the Bush administration has noticed a "new element" in the recent development of cross-strait relations, namely, President Chen Shui-bian's proposal in his Oct. 10 National Day speech that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait resume dialogue based on their "1992 talks" in Hong Kong.

According to the U.S. officials, the United States has consistently encouraged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to conduct regular dialogue in order to defuse cross-strait tension and forge constructive interactions.

Asked whether the United States is likely to change its arms sales to Taiwan under Beijing's pressure, the three officials said the U.S. government will provide Taiwan with adequate defensive weapons to safeguard its security in line with the Taiwan Relations Act and will not waver on this stance simply because of Beijing's opposition.

As to whether Bush would hold bilateral talks with Lee Yuan-tseh, Taiwan's representative to the APEC summit, the officials said Bush doesn't have such a plan for the moment. Because of Beijing's opposition, Taiwan's president has been barred from attending the annual APEC leadership meeting in person and has to name a proxy to attend on his behalf.
Asked whether Bush would likely ask Lee to pass any message to President Chen, the U.S. officials didn't give a direct response. They instead said Lee can fully represent Chen at the APEC summit.

APEC groups 21 Asia-Pacific economies -- Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD TO STEP UP PROTECTION OF FISHERMEN IN KINMEN

TEXT.P: Coast Guard Administration (CGA) officials vowed Thursday to step up protection of fishermen in Kinmen.
CGA officials made the remarks when they met with Kinmen fishermen at a seminar held in the outlying island to learn more about their needs.

The fishermen complained that mainland Chinese fishermen often trespass into Kinmen waters, affecting their fish haul and their livelihood. They asked the CGA to step up operations to chase the trespassers away.
Kuo Hsien-wu, head of CGA's Kinmen branch, said that six rubber rafts have been in use since last year while seven advanced radar monitoring systems were installed early this year to monitor the sea.

He noted that the rubber rafts sailed out 132 times this year to disperse mainland fishing vessels in coastal waters, evicting 214 mainland fishing ships, arresting 47 suspects, seizing 9,872 kg of agricultural or fishery products and five kg of drugs. There were also six cases of illegal electrocution of f0ish.

The coast guard cutters also made 902 sorties at sea this year, seizing 167 smuggling suspects, nearly 50,000 kg of agricultural and fishery products, 26.655 kg of drugs and 16 illegal mainland immigrants.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL POLICE AGENCY UNVEILS COUNTER-TERRORISM STRATEGY

TEXT.P: The government has adopted a strategy of deterrence in its counter-terrorism work, according to a report released by the National Police Agency (NPA) Thursday.
The report was presented by NPA Deputy Director-General Liu Shih-lin at the 2004 Asia-Pacific Homeland Security Summit and Exposition held Nov. 14-17 in Honolulu.

Liu said that among the efforts to thwart terrorism, the top priority is setting up a comprehensive anti-terrorism law and organization, gaining access to early-warning intelligence, establishing an anti-terrorism deterrent and building up international anti-terrorism partnerships.

In terms of beefing up an anti-terrorism deterrent, Taiwan is enhancing its "capability, credibility and communication" to thwart any intent or attempt by terrorists to launch an attack in Taiwan, Liu said.
He said the government has earmarked a budget to establish a center for the training of anti-terrorism forces and has worked out contingency plans to prepare for any possible terror attack.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURIST ARRIVALS TO BREAK 3 MILLION-MARK THIS YEAR: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Tourist arrivals will break the 3 million mark this year thanks to the concerted promotional efforts of the government and the private sector, Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan said Thursday.
Addressing the opening ceremony of the 2004 Taipei International Travel Fair, Yeh said the government has listed tourism as one of Taiwan's most important industries, subject to intensive promotion.
In an attempt to attract foreign tourists, Yeh said, the government has made strenuous efforts in recent years to create a tourist-friendly environment and simplify visa processing.

"Our efforts have gradually paid off. We set a goal of attracting 3 million foreign tourists this year. So far, tourist arrivals have already exceeded 2.9 million. We believe that the number will reach or exceed 3 million by year's end," Yeh said.
The travel fair is organized by the Taiwan Visitors Association (TVA) with the assistance of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
Nearly 500 institutions from 55 countries and areas around the world are participating in the fair, manning 720 exhibition booths at the Taipei World Trade Center.

"The number of booths is an increase of 200 from the year-earlier level. The exhibition space has also been expanded by 30 percent and is fully occupied, " said Stanley Yen, chairman of the travel fair organizing committee.
Hong Kong and Singapore have sent large delegations, while Egypt, Italy, Slovakia, Mexico and Argentina are taking part for the first time.

Many countries offer attractive tour packages to entice prospective Taiwan tourists. The travel show will open to the general public from Friday, with an admission fee of NT$200 per person and NT$150 for the elderly and the physically challenged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WANTS CLOSER INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION IN DISASTER RELIEF

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday he hopes Asian countries can strengthen exchanges and cooperation in disaster prevention and post-disaster relief for the benefit of all parties concerned.
Chen made the appeal in a speech delivered at the opening of the 23rd annual conference of the International Fire Chief's Association of Asia (IFCAA).
Noting that disaster knows no borders, Chen said international cooperation in meteorological and seismological studies is needed in disaster prevention and control.

"In view of our geographical proximity, we Asian countries should increase exchanges in experience of fire-fighting and battling various natural disasters. We should also enhance relevant technological and resources exchanges so that we can create a better and safer living environment for our peoples," Chen said.
In the modern world, Chen said, a natural disaster can often evolve into a regional crisis.

"Against this backdrop, we should have new concepts about security, cooperation and disaster prevention measures, " Chen said, adding that he believes cooperation in disaster prevention and post-disaster rehabilitation can eventually contribute to regional integration.

More than 2,000 delegates from 23 IFCAA member states or areas are taking part in the organization's three-day annual conference, with new global disaster prevention and relief trends as its main theme.

In addition to a regular IFCAA board meeting, a working-level meeting and a plenary session, a series of lectures and seminars on disaster prevention/relief mechanisms, management systems and relevant technological development will also be held during the conference, organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Trying to Get Big Enough to Battle Wal-Mart.
Some people may be wondering just how well Kmart and Sears will compete against Wal-Mart as part of the same company.
The Wall Stree Journal: Kmart to Buy Sears for $11.5 Billion.
After slipping from their perch as America's top two retailers, the much-diminished Kmart and Sears chains are merging in an $11.5 billion deal that will propel them back into the No. 3 position.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRONGER RENMINBI WILL HURT TAIWAN IT SECTOR: ANALYSTS

TEXT.P: An appreciating renminbi will hurt Taiwan's information-related business more than a stronger new Taiwan dollar, industry analysts said Thursday.

Despite the fact that the local currency has surged to a high in almost four years against the U.S. dollar, the analysts said that a stronger renminbi will do greater damage to Taiwan computer companies based in mainland China, as a vast majority of them are contract makers for big multinationals.
Mainland-based Taiwan computer companies will face a fierce war to defend their gross earnings should the mainland currency go up in value as expected next year, they pointed out.
Many leading international economic forecasting agencies have predicted that the renminbi will appreciate against the greenback in 2005, ranging from 3 percent to 7 percent.

The United States and Japan have repeatedly asked Beijing to allow its currency to float freely by dropping the renminbi's peg to the U.S. dollar, which stands at about 8.277 against the greenback at present.

According to a recent survey carried out by the Professional Management Association in Taipei, some 60 percent of the Taiwan businessmen working on the mainland believe that the renminbi will rise in value next year, with nearly 50 percent of the opinion that such a development will hurt their profits.
Most of them have turned from "optimistic" to "cautiously optimistic" in terms of their business prospects in the coming three years, the survey found.
Chen Miao, a researcher at the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, said that the mainland currency is now enjoying a strong advantage in exports due to its close peg to a sliding U.S. dollar.

But he added that the mainland has been confronting mounting pressure to allow the renminbi to pick up amid growing inflationary pressure and efforts to cool its overheated economy. The mainland's recent interest rate hikes form part of its bid to stifle the increased appreciation pressure on its currency, he noted.

A senior researcher at the semi-official Institute for Information Industry pointed out that compared to the local currency's gains in recent days, a much-anticipated appreciation of the renminbi will create a heavier burden on Taiwan computer makers on the mainland.

As about 80 percent of Taiwan's computer firms have relocated their production lines to the mainland in search of cheaper costs, a strong new Taiwan dollar will only have a limited impact on their knowledge-based research and development centers at home, he said.

However, a strong renminbi will levy a robust operating cost on export-oriented Taiwan contractors operating on the mainland, making their efforts to seek cheaper production in vain, according to an analyst with the Taipei-based Topology Research Institute.
In particular, makers of cell phones and wireless LAN facilities will be affected the most, as well as producers of notebooks and personal computers, he said.

If the mainland allows the renminbi to appreciate, as is widely expected, Taiwan manufacturers will have to absorb currency exchange rate losses on their own in a war against multinational big names, which usually hold effective bargaining chips on back of their global presence, he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: 57% OF TAIWAN WORKERS FEAR DEATH FROM OVERWORK: POLL

TEXT.P: Fifty-seven percent of workers in Taiwan are worried that they might die from overwork and 40 percent think they are in poor health, according to the results of a survey released Thursday.
The survey was conducted by the 9999 Pan Asia Job Bank among 6,391 workers between Oct. 11 and Nov. 9. It had a margin of error of 1.25 percent.

Among the respondents who complained of poor health, the most common illnesses were those involving the neck and shoulders, waist and back, intestines and stomach, and liver, as well as obesity and headache.

On the causes leading to their health problems, 51.15 percent attributed their problems to a stressful life and work, 44.3 percent to long work hours, 41.53 percent to a lack of exercise, 37.11 percent to nutritional imbalance, and 27.87 percent to irregular mealtimes.
Because of these health problems, 56.53 percent of the respondents said they fear death from overwork, compared with 14.29 percent who said they do not.
While 61.18 percent of the workers said their jobs are likely to cause their death through overwork, 20.31 percent were not so sure, and 18.51 percent said it is unlikely.

The top five role models for a "healthy worker" selected by the respondents were Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, supermodel Lin Chih-ling, designer Chiang Yu-po, singer Wang Lee-hom and baseball player Tsao Chin-hui.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SEND DELEGATION TO ATTEND BUSH INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: The government will follow past practice by sending a delegation to attend U.S. President George W. Bush's inauguration next January, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.
Chin Jih-hsin, director of the MOFA's North American Affairs Department, said the delegation will be composed of representatives of major political parties, legislators and academics.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties with the United States, Taiwan has consistently sent non-governmental delegations to attend U.S. presidential inaugurations to convey the congratulations of the ROC government and people.

Meanwhile, Chin said he is convinced that Taiwan-U.S. relations will continue to grow on the solid existing basis after incumbent National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice takes over from Colin Powell as U.S. secretary of state.
Chin said Rice came up with many diplomatic policy initiatives during Bush's first term, contributing a great deal to the U.S. foreign policy enforcement and earning Bush's trust.
As for Powell, Chin said, the outgoing U.S. secretary of state has on various occasions recognized Taiwan's democratic development and has contributed greatly to the global war on terrorism.

According to a CNA report from Washington, D.C., John J. Tkacik, a U.S. Heritage Foundation fellow familiar with cross-Taiwan Strait affairs, said Wednesday that Rice is a mature strategic thinker and capable of formulating foreign policy.
Tkacik further said Rice has a clear understanding of the gist of the United States' "one China" policy.

Noting that Rice once wrote in an article that the "one China" policy also demands that Beijing, with a stronger military strength, should renounce the option of using force, Tkacik said he believes Rice will adopt a pragmatic and realistic approach in implementing the U.S. policy toward China after assuming her new post.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIAN PASSENGER DETAINED IN TAIWAN FOR DRUG TRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: A Malaysian passenger was arrested at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan Thursday for trafficking nearly four kilograms of heroin, according to police reports.
Samuel Yee Chuen Tak, 28, attempted to bring into Taiwan a total of 3.824 kg of heroin packed in four bags tied to his legs, the police said.
Tak raised the suspicion of police officers and customs officials at the airport due to his curious gait after getting off an Eva Airways flight from Phnom Penh.
The drugs have a street value of about NT$38 million (US$1.16 million) , the police estimated, adding that the law enforcement authorities are conducting further investigation into the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO ARRESTED FOR CROSS-STRAIT DRUG TRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: Two men were arrested Thursday in Changhua City and Chiayi City, respectively, for allegedly smuggling high-grade heroin into Taiwan from mainland China, law enforcement authorities said.

The two men were identified only by their family names of Yeh and Cheng. Investigators from the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) uncovered a total of 8.5 kg of powdered heroin at the two men's hideouts, worth an estimated NT$100 million in street value.

Initial investigation results show that the drug was first shipped to mainland China for processing into powder and divided into 12 packages that were disguised in cans of brand-name nutritional supplement before being delivered to Taiwan.
"This marks the first time traffickers have disguised contraband drugs as foodstuffs to evade customs investigations, " an MJIB investigator said.
Saying there is probably a cross-strait criminal ring behind the operation, the investigator added that the MJIB has formed a special team to further investigate the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT: EMBRACING CHINESE CULTURE NOT BEING ASSIMILATED BY CHINA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian drew a fine line between politics and culture Thursday, saying that Taiwan should accept Chinese culture, which is not the same as "being assimilated by China."

Speaking at a conference of the National Cultural Association, Chen said Taiwan should keep spreading excellent Chinese culture, enrich its own culture and foster self-confidence and cultural tolerance in tune with its democracy."

Noting that the virtues that he said are treasured by Chinese culture, such as benevolent government, kindheartedness, peace, honor, harmony and friendliness are also vital to a modern country and society, Chen said they are valuable assets of all Chinese and there is no question of discarding them because of their Chinese origin.

"We do not accept China's military threat against the 23 million people of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu, but political rivalry should not necessarily drive us to get rid of anything reminiscent of China," Chen said.

As to the controversy surrounding guidelines came up by the Ministry of Education for history textbooks used in senior high schools, Chen said Taiwan is an island that has been exposed to various cultures. However, the Kuomintang suppressed the development of local culture and interpreted history in its own view. Now, he went on, it is time to review history in perspective.

Chen said his administration respects different historical aspects and will leave the controversy in the hands of historians, but will not agree with those who cast doubt on the sovereignty of the Republic of China.

Noting that the guidelines are still being worked on and that public opinion will be consulted before they are finalized, Chen said he regrets that some politicians have picked them apart as "good for nothing, " consider them part of his administration's efforts to "distance itself from China" and have even "blamed me for them."

In a democracy, Chen said, everybody is entitled to his or her own opinion, but no one should force his own views on others. The same rule should apply to the controversy caused by the history textbook guidelines, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROWTH CONTINUES AT KAOHSIUNG PORT OFFSHORE TRANSSHIPMENT HUB

TEXT.P: Business of the cross-Taiwan Strait offshore transshipment center at the Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan continues to increase, with the number of containers handled by the hub showing substantive growth, according to tallies released Thursday by the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau.

In October alone, the center dealt with more than 53,500 containers, up by 2.7 percent over the previous year's number, the tallies show. It handled a combined 553,100 containers for the January-October period, an increase of 6.5 percent over the year-earlier level.

Bureau officials forecast that the center will deal with as many as 670,000 containers for the whole of this year. Meanwhile, Kaohsiung Port, Taiwan's largest, is estimated to handle more than 9.4 million containers for the whole of 2004.

At present, there are 10 shipping companies -- four from Taiwan and six from mainland China -- plying the Kaohsiung-Fuzhou and Kaohsiung-Xiamen routes between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the officials said, adding that they provide a total of 20 crossings per week.

The cross-strait offshore transshipment center at Kaohsiung Port was opened in 1997 to allow vessels from the mainland to load and unload containers there, as their personnel and cargoes are restricted from entering Taiwan.

The purpose of the establishment was to boost cross-strait economic exchanges in the face of the lack of trade, transport and postal links between Taiwan and the mainland due to their long-term political disputes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPS KEEN ON CLOSER COOPERATION WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Philips Taiwan is keen on setting up closer cooperative ties with local companies on a wide range of product lines, Philips Taiwan President Chuang Chun-yuan said Thursday.

In addition to increasing purchases in Taiwan, the Dutch multinational group is willing to enhance cooperation with local companies, mainly in the fields of wireless telecommunications, electronic medical treatment equipment, cathode ray tubes and personal digital entertainment facilities, Chuang said.

According to the new company president, the world trends focusing on creating multifunctional devices with a mix of audio, visual and telecommunications effects have sharply increased the chance of bilateral cooperation between the Philips group and Taiwan firms.

Philips will further expand its cooperation with Taiwan and buy more here, he promised, adding that future purchases will center on five areas, including telecommunications goods and digital televisions.
Taiwan companies seeking to create their own brands specializing in digital home appliances will have a better chance and more opportunities to set up cooperative ventures with the group, he noted.
Last year, Philips bought a total of NT$15 billion (US$461.5 million) worth of Taiwan products, which he said is only a small portion compared to the group's entire revenue of NT$1.2 trillion.
Taiwan ranks as the group's 13th-largest purchase source, mainly providing liquid crystal displays, memory chips and power-generating facilities.
Philips Taiwan posted a business turnover of NT$120 billion for the whole of 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM DENIES REPORT ABOUT VANUATU'S RENEGING ON TIES WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs denied a report Thursday that Vanuatu's Cabinet has reneged on its newly forged diplomatic ties with Taiwan, calling it a lie put into circulation by Beijing.

Michel Lu, a spokesman for the foreign ministry, dismissed as "groundless" a report broadcast by a radio station in Australia that Vanuatu's Cabinet reaffirmed Thursday its commitment to the "one China policy," which recognizes the People's Republic of China as the sole legitimate government of China, and opposes ties with Taiwan.

The spokesman said his ministry checked the report with the country's diplomats in Port Vila, Vanuatu, and was told that Vanuatu's new foreign minister has denied the report, saying that Thursday's Cabinet meeting did not even discuss the issue in depth, let alone oppose the diplomatic ties.
Lu said mainland China's diplomats in Port Vila are putting out lies through several Vanuatu Cabinet members, although the Republic of China flag is flying at its temporary embassy in Port Vila.
Vanuatu Prime Minister Serge Vohor concluded an agreement with Taiwan Nov. 3 in Taipei, extending diplomatic recognition to the country.

However, Vohor's Cabinet had since given out conflicting messages as to whether it would approve Vohor's agreement with Taiwan until Monday, when Vohor announced the government's recognition of Taiwan on television.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG CHILDREN REPORTEDLY INFECTED WITH PIV

TEXT.P: A disease spreading among Hong Kong children in the last two days is believed to be para-influenza virus (PIV), the official Radio Hong Kong reported Thursday.
Initial test results at the Caritas Medical Centre have shown positive results for the relatively common virus.
The official Centre for Health Protection (CHP) said that three out of the seven specimens taken from patients yielded positive results.
A CHP spokesman was quoted as saying that PIV is common among small children and is transmitted through sneezing and contact with contaminated objects.
Results on other specimens are still pending, with a total of 32 children so far stricken by the outbreak, the report said.
The infected children are all from the Caritas' unit for severely handicapped children.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, RUSSIA INK PACT FOR BASIC SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Russia concluded a cooperation accord on basic scientific research early this month in Moscow, a scientific official said Thursday.

Wang Wei-chung of the National Science Council (NSC) said the accord was signed by NSC Vice Chairman Hsieh Ching-chih when he visited Moscow at the head of a Taiwan scientific delegation. His counterpart is the chief of the Moscow-based Russian Basic Research Foundation.

Under the terms of the agreement, Wang said, both Taiwan and Russia will spend US$2 million a year to finance 10 basic research projects conducted jointly by scientists from Taiwan and Russia, as well as to host three academic conferences.
This is the first scientific cooperation pact between the two countries, Wang said.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: MA DENIES PLANNING TO RUN FOR KMT CHAIR

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Friday categorically denied that he has been planning to run for the chairmanship of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

Ma dismissed a local daily report that he has been planning to run for the post currently occupied by KMT Chairman Lien Chan as a "patched-up" and "groundless" report since the reporter did not even interview him before writing it.

Ma said he has absolutely not thought about the chairmanship, particularly at a time when he has been busy with stumping for KMT legislative candidates in his capacity as a KMT vice chairman and busy with running the city as the mayor.

As a vice chairman of the KMT, Ma said that the most critical work for him at the moment is helping to bolster KMT legislative candidates' support base and helping to retain the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" majority in the Legislative Yuan. Things besides this and his work as mayor are beyond his considerations at the present time, he added.

Meanwhile, KMT Chairman Lien Chan ducked reporters' questions about the veracity of Ma's "increasingly evident" intention to run for the KMT chairmanship in party elections slated for next March, responding only by saying that "all of the KMT candidates in the Dec. 11 legislative elections will be elected."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES E.U. DECISION TO CONTINUE BAN ON ARMS SALES TO CHINA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Friday welcomed a decision by the European Parliament to maintain its arms sales embargo against mainland China.
MOFA spokesman Michel Lu was referring to a vote by the European Parliament Wednesday to continue the ban on arms sales to China which was imposed shortly after the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.
Lu said the decision shows that the E.U. still thinks that China has not done enough in improving its human rights protection, and that it is concerned about the Asian-Pacific region.
"The ministry hopes the international community will attach more importance to the issue," he urged.

The European Parliament said the arms embargo should continue until the European Union has adopted a code of conduct providing legal restraints on arms exports, and until China takes concrete measures to improve its human rights situation. The arms ban issue is expected to come up again during an E.U. summit in Brussels in December.

Lu noted that the E.U. imposed the ban in the first place because the human rights situation in mainland China was poor. There has still not been sufficient improvement in this respect to meet the E.U.'s conditions for lifting the ban, he said.
Lu added that if the E.U. lifts the arms ban, it will affect the peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS NAME CHANGE OF KIWANIS TAIWAN CHAPTER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday he is pleased with the successful change in the official designation of the Taiwan chapter of Kiwanis International.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with Kiwanis International President Case Van Kleef at the Presidential Office.

The local Kiwanis club was originally named the "Republic of China District of Kiwanis International." With a view to signifying Taiwan's identity, the club applied last year to have its official designation changed to "Taiwan District of Kiwanis International." It has received approval from the Kiwanis International headquarters in the United States.

Chen said the Kiwanis Taiwan chapter has contributed a great deal to the local community and charitable services over the years. During the Kiwanis International general conference held this June, Kiwanis Taiwan received a citation as one of the most outstanding district Kiwanis chapters.

In compliance with the Kiwanis International's 2004 theme of promoting children's welfare, Chen said the Kiwanis Taiwan chapter has set up a children's welfare fund to help improve welfare services for children from impoverished families.
Kleef is currently in Taipei to inspect progress in preparations for the Kiwanis International's 2006 Asia-Pacific conference to be held in Taiwan.
Chen told Kleef that his administration will give necessary assistance to the Taiwan Kiwanis chapter in organizing the conference.
Kiwanis International is an association of men and women committed to volunteer service and charity in their local communities.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER CZECH PRESIDENT IN TAIWAN FOR SIX-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: Former Czech Republic President Vaclav Havel and his wife arrived in Taipei Friday for a six-day visit, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said.

A multi-talented and resourceful man, Havel, who has been a poet, playwright, dissident, thinker and politician, and his wife are in Taiwan at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian and the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, the MOFA officials said.

During his stay, Havel will meet with Chen and Vice President Annette Lu. He will be decorated by Chen with a medal in recognition of his contribution to the promotion of Taiwan-Czech Republic ties and his career achievements, particularly his courage in keeping alive the "flame of democracy" when his country was under communist rule.
Havel is scheduled to deliver a speech and receive an honorary doctorate from National Chengchi University.
Also included in Havel's itinerary are meetings with local academics, artists and literary celebrities.

Havel formally ended his 12-year presidency in February 2003. During his presidency, he continued working hard to consolidate the Czech Republic's democratic system as well as to promote human rights and social justice, earning wide respect and admiration from his compatriots.
MOFA officials said Havel has been very friendly toward Taiwan because of his democratic convictions and his courage in standing up to mainland China's pressure.

During his presidency, Havel invited then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui to attend an international forum in Prague. Incumbent ROC first lady Wu Shu-chen and former Vice President Lien Chan have also visited the Czech Republic. In 1995, Havel spoke in support of Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations at an annual U.N. General Assembly plenary session. He is one of the few world leaders willing to publicly throw his support behind Taiwan without fearing a backlash from Beijing.

After his retirement, MOFA officials said, Havel had planned to visit Taiwan immediately. But he later chose to stay in his country to help stabilize the domestic political situation following the transfer of power. Early this year, Havel again had planned to visit Taiwan and several other Asian countries to promote his new book. However, his Asian tour was cut short in India due to health reasons.

Havel played a pivotal role in his country's "velvet revolution" of 1989. He used his literary and theatrical creations to kindle and keep the flame of democracy burning amidst a storm of repression and autocracy during communist rule. He eventually led his country to break the shackles of communist suppression and move toward democracy.

To welcome Havel's visit, Taipei National University of the Arts has designated November as its "Month of Vaclav Havel Art." In addition to performing Havel's plays, the university has also organized many other activities during the period of Nov. 5-24, including a Havel book fair and a series of seminars on Havel's artistic and political achievements, as well as a Czech film festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFERS INTELLIGENCE ABOUT CHINESE SUB INTRUSION INTO JAPAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian confirmed for the first time Friday a report that Taiwan had provided Japan and the United States with intelligence about the intrusion of a mainland Chinese nuclear-powered submarine into Japanese waters earlier this month.

Chen made the confirmation while meeting with Reijiro Hattori, president of the Japanese Interchange Association, a quasi-official organization authorized to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties. Hattori is currently on a visit to Taipei.
A mainland nuclear-powered submarine intruded into Japanese territorial waters Nov. 10, for which the mainland authorities apologized to Japan Nov. 16.

Chen said he was pleased with Taiwan's ability to take the lead in detecting the mainland submarine's intrusion. Taiwan alerted Japan and the United States to the intrusion and the intelligence was later verified, he added.
In the face of the mainland's military threat, Chen said, Taiwan, Japan and the United States have a shared interest in maintaining peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.

Chen said he has noticed that many Japanese people look forward to having the post-war Japanese Constitution revised to make Japan a "normal" country. Taiwan faces a similar situation, he went on, adding that although Taiwan is an independent sovereign state, it has yet to become a fully "normal and complete" country. Chen said his administration must redouble its efforts to complete many unfinished tasks.

Touching on Taiwan-Japan ties, Chen said the successive opening of regular flights between Taiwan and three more Japanese cities -- Sapporo, Hiroshima and Sendai -- in recent years has further facilitated exchanges between the two countries. Taiwan and Japanese people exchanged 1.4 million visits in 2003, Chen said, adding that the number will continue to increase in the years ahead.

He also expressed a warm welcome to Japan's decision to offer visa-free entry for Taiwan people during the World Exposition in Aichi from March 25 through Sept. 25, 2005. Chen said he hopes Japan will offer full-fledged visa-free entry to tourists from Taiwan on a reciprocal basis in the not-too-distant future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LIKELY TO POSTPONE RESUMPTION OF U.S. BEEF IMPORTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is likely to postpone a resumption of imports of U.S. beef and beef products upon reports of possible new cases of mad-cow disease in the United States, sources from the Department of Health (DOH) said Friday.

While Taiwan has continued to dispatch quarantine personnel to the United States for on-site inspections of the implementation of U.S. safeguards against bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), also known as mad cow disease, before giving a green light to a resumption of U.S. beef imports, new cases of the disease reported Thursday, although not yet confirmed, may cause the DOH to postpone the schedule of the resumption.

Taiwan suspended imports in December 2003 following the discovery in Washington State of a single BSE-infected cow, but the two sides have been working in last two months to facilitate a resumption of imports.

According to Hsieh Ting-hung, a senior engineer with the DOH Bureau of Food Sanitation, Taiwan is still assessing the possibility of reopening its market to beef products from the United States and Canada, and related personnel have continuously been dispatched to the two countries for on-site inspections.
If the Taiwan inspectors are satisfied with their findings, Taiwan may reopen its doors to U.S. and Canadian beef and beef products before the end of 2004, Hsieh said.
The reopening, however, will be feasible only on the premise that no new cases of mad-cow disease are reported, Hsieh noted.
He added that even if Taiwan agrees to re-introduce U.S. beef in the near future, such imports will all be beef and meat products, and brain and spine parts will not be considered.
Taiwan purchased $325 million-worth of U.S. beef and beef products in 2003.
U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) officials reported Oct. 26 that Taiwan had agreed in principle to resume such imports.
Dr. J.B. Penn, undersecretary for Farm and Foreign Agricultural Services, met with Taiwan health and agriculture officials early in October for talks on the matter, USDA officials said.

The Taiwan officials have indicated that they are close to completing the reviews necessary for resuming the beef trade, with on-site inspections as the final step in the process, according to the USDA news release.

"We are very pleased with this progress in yet another important beef market, " Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman said. "We are continuing our market opening efforts in the remaining key countries. Our goal is a return to normal beef trade as quickly as possible."
According to Penn, the United States and Japan concluded an agreement in Tokyo Oct. 23 that paves the way for a partial resumption of the beef trade between the two countries.

Japan was the largest importer of U.S. beef before it imposed a ban last year, with annual beef imports from the United States amounting to more than US$1.4 billion, or more than 30 percent of total U.S. beef exports.

Taiwan was the sixth-largest importer of U.S. beef before it imposed the ban. Only Mexico continued to import U.S. beef and beef products after the discovery of the case of mad cow, according to USDA.
Meanwhile, Hsieh said, Taiwan is not planning to reopen its doors to Japanese beef and related products, which were banned in March 2000 after mad cow disease was reported in that country.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROUTE ALLOCATION COMPLETED FOR TAIWAN-SOUTH KOREA AIR SERVICES

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) completed Friday the route allocation among six Taiwanese airlines that are interested in operating Taiwan-South Korea passenger services.
According to the plan, the Taipei-Seoul route was assigned to China Airlines and EVA Airways, and the Kaohsiung-Seoul line was designated to UNI Airways and Mandarin Airlines.
The Taipei-Jeju line was designated to Far East Air Transport and TransAsia Airways, the Kaohsiung-Jeju line was appointed to UNI Airways and Far East Air Transport.
The Taipei-Busan line was designated to TransAsia Airways and UNI Airways.
CAA officials said the six airlines are required to file an application for an air route certificate within a month and to launch services within four months of the certificate being issued.
It is estimated that scheduled passenger services will start in April 2005 at the latest.

Taiwan and South Korea struck an aviation agreement Sept. 1 authorizing the formal resumption of air links between both sides after the links had been broken off for 12 years since the severance of diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, RUSSIA TO SIGN AGREEMENT ON RUSSIA'S WTO MEMBERSHIP
DOC.DATELINE: Santiago, Chile, Nov. 19 (CNA) (By Kuang Chung-wei and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh said Thursday that Taiwan will sign an agreement with Russia to agree on the latter's terms for joining the World Trade Organization.

Ho, who is attending the ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum along with Finance Minister Lin Chuan, said that Taiwan will hold bilateral talks with Russia Friday.
She said that the WTO consultations are ministerial-level and that Lee Yuan-tseh, leader of Taiwan's APEC delegation, will not attend the consultations.
She also said that Taiwan had already held bilateral talks with Chile, South Korea, Canada, Japan, Australia, Vietnam and Indonesia on the sidelines of the APEC meet.

Meanwhile, both Ho and Lin said they had not yet had a chance to have formal talks with delegates from mainland China, as the seating arrangements of the two delegations are too far apart, and they had only exchanged handshakes or toasts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC HAS NO RIGHT TO CENSURE TAIWAN AD: GIO
DOC.DATELINE: Satiago, Chile, Nov. 18 (CNA) (By Kuan Chung-wei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The People's Republic of China has no right to censure advertisements run by Taiwan, which is another economic entity and a formal member of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, a Government Information Office (GIO) official said here Thursday.

Yi Rong-tsung, deputy director-general of the GIO, who is incumbent spokesman for the Taiwan APEC delegation, said Taiwan agreed to scrap a promotional commercial, which had absolutely no political content or implication, in order not to cause inconvenience for the host country, Chile.

Yi said that the two-minute, four-segment commercial -- dubbed into English and describing how Taiwan has struggled "from humble beginnings, laboring in the fields, but gradually worked toward building a nation one day at a time" -- was not meant to provoke anyone or any APEC economy.

The people of Taiwan have realized the dream of a better tomorrow and have succeeded in creating a prosperous modern society. At the dawn of the 21st Century, Taiwan has already walked toward an even brighter future, the commercial said.

Beijing lodged two written protests with the APEC Secretariat several days ago against the TV commercial, produced by the GIO and screened at the APEC International Media Center, demanding that it be removed immediately.

Beijing claimed that the use of the word "nation" in the ad went against the "consensus" and "normal practice" of the annual conference. It also charged that the wording of the ad was clearly "inappropriate" and "politically oriented."
Responding to the protests, the APEC Secretariat requested that Taiwan edit the ad's content.

Yi said that Taiwan agreed to scrap the ad but refused to edit the content on the grounds that each member economy of the APEC should be on an equal footing when promoting their own country. "The request was a humiliation of our national dignity and a heinous move to belittle our international status," Yi said.

Meanwhile, the furor over the ad raised concern in the Chilean media. Ultimas Noticias (Latest News) , a major, mass-circulation daily, contributed an entire page Thursday to the matter, including an interview with David Lee, director of the GIO International Information Services Department, who flew into Santiago from Taipei particularly to smooth out the controversy surrounding the ad.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange ended lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 22.94 points to close at 6,026.55.
The bourse opened at 6,053.20 and fluctuated between 6,065.68 and 6,018.19 during trading. A total of 3.27 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$72.52 billion (US$2.23 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 1.0 percent, followed by textile stocks at 0.7 percent, cement stocks and banking and financial shares both at 0.5 percent, and machinery and electronics shares and plastics and chemicals shares both at 0.3 percent.
The two other major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up 0.4 percent and construction issues increasing 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 339 to 263, with 174 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market ended lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 16 points to close at 6,056, with 22,611 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January dropped 14 points to finish at 6,066, with 29 contracts traded, while March futures fell 42 points to finish at 6,030, with 92 contracts traded.
June futures gave up 13 points to close at 6,030 points, with seven contracts traded, while September futures lost 58 points to finish at 5,962, with 65 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,072 for December, 6,080 for January, 6,072 for March, 6,043 for June and 6,020 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.
December TE futures moved down 0.4 points to close at 228.45, with 3,925 contracts traded, while January TE futures fell 1.2 points to finish at 228, with 16 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

December TF futures lost 7.6 points to end at 1,053, with 11,818 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures gave up 9.8 points to close at 1,050.2, with 67 contracts traded and June TF futures surged 17.4 points to close at 1,069, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.134 to close at NT$32.554.
A total of US$1.078 billion changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$32.520 and was traded between NT$32.352 and NT$32.570.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RADIO PROGRAM RATED ONE OF WORLD'S BEST

TEXT.P: A radio program produced and aired by the Central Broadcasting System of the ROC (CBSROC) was once again rated as one of the top 10 English-language radio programs in the world recently by Passport to World Band Radio (PWBR).

"The Beauty of Traditional Chinese Music, " also known as "The Ensemble of Traditional Stringed and Woodwind Instruments, " a musical program mainly to introduce traditional Chinese music, was rated as a top 10 English-language radio program in 2004 by PWBR, an international short wave broadcasting magazine.

CBSROC Chairman Lin Feng-cheng said the rating is encouraging as well as welcomed and vowed that his radio station will continue to produce quality programs to live up the station's principles of making itself "the Voice of Taiwan."

According to the show's presenter, Huang Chia-shan, the program has been aired for six years, mainly to introduce traditional Taiwanese and Chinese music, including music from various ethnic groups such as Mongolian, Tibetan, Hakka and aboriginal people.
The program was first selected as a top 10 show in 2001 and this is the second time it has been awarded, Huang said.
The Ensemble of Traditional Stringed and Woodwind Instruments is the second Asian radio program to have been given a top 10 rating by PWBR after Japan's NHK, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Nuclear Disclosures On Iran Unverified.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell shared information with reporters Wednesday about Iran's nuclear program that was classified and based on an unvetted, single source who provided information that two U.S. officials said yesterday was highly significant if true but has not yet been verified.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO MAJOR CHANGES LIKELY IN ROC LEGISLATIVE STRUCTURE: U.S. SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 18 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: An American scholar said Thursday that Taiwan's year-end legislative elections are not expected to give an absolute majority to any political camp, which she said will help avert a crisis resulting from possible major changes to the Constitution.

Shelley Rigger, brown associate professor of political science at Davidson College, made the remarks during a seminar on Taiwan's Dec. 11 legislative elections, which was presided over by Richard Bush, former American Institute in Taiwan chairman and currently a director of the Brookings Center for Northeast Asian Policy Studies (CNAPS) in Washington, D.C.

Rigger speculated that the results of the legislative elections will not lead to major changes in terms of the number of seats held by each party and that the structure of the legislature will basically remain intact.

President Chen Shui-bian won his second four-year term by a narrow margin in the March 20 presidential election, but according to Rigger, his hope of translating this into a major victory in the Dec. 11 elections may prove to be limited.

She said that most of the candidates in the Dec. 11 elections are incumbent legislators seeking re-election. The current multiple-seat election system, which often sees several candidates from a political party vying for seats from their comrades of the same party in the constituency, also means that personal attributes of individual candidates take precedence over their party affiliation.

For this reason, she predicted, even if the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union can garner more seats in the new legislature, the changes will not be too big and the main structure of the legislature will not undergo dramatic change. Currently, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party enjoy a slim majority in the legislature.

She noted that even if the "pan-green camp" garners between 105 and 109 seats, as it has estimated before, it will still be a relative majority and not an absolute majority in the 225-seat legislature.
For this reason, she said, the "pan-green camp" will still be short of the absolute majority needed to make major changes to the Constitution as advocated by the DPP.
Such changes would undoubtedly raise the ire of Beijing and could precipitate a crisis in the Taiwan Strait, she added.

However, Liu Shih-fang, former Executive Yuan secretary-general and currently a visiting fellow at the Bookings Institute, said on the same occasion that while the "pan-green camp" can garner about 110 seats, still short of an outright majority, it will have no major difficulties in soliciting the support of independent legislators when reviewing bills.

An official from the U.S. State Department also asked about a major issue in the Dec. 11 elections -- the Executive Yuan's proposal for a NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) special budget for a major military procurement from the United States -- mainly for six Patriot PAC-3 missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.
W. Michael Meserve noted that Taiwan's defense spending has gone
down every year and asked if the island can surpass partisan politics to make possible an increased defense spending.

His question went unanswered. But John J. Tkacik, Jr. a research fellow on China policy at the Heritage Foundation, said that judging from recent remarks by Richard P. Lawless, deputy under secretary of defense for Asia-Pacific affairs, when he exhorted Taiwan to stop dallying and buy U.S. arms, the result of the year-end legislative elections could well be a touchstone for U.S-Taiwan relations in years ahead.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONDURAS TRADE WEEK OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2004 Honduras Trade Week and Product Fair opened Friday at the Taipei World Trade Center, one of a series of activities organized by Honduran Ambassador Marlene Villela to boost bilateral ties.

High-ranking Honduran government officials, including the presidential secretary-general and the trade and industry minister, delivered congratulations via video, in which they voiced their firm willingness to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with Taiwan.

Vice President Annette Lu, who presided over the opening of the fair, echoed their sentiments by reiterating her plan to lead a delegation to visit the Republic of China Central American diplomatic ally next year to further increase two-way relations.

Lu said that she is looking forward to sustainable development in Taiwan-Honduran exchanges on a broad range of fronts and she thanked the Honduran government and people for their long-term support and friendship of Taiwan.
The Honduran trade show will also be staged in central Taichung City and southern Tainan City.

Under the arrangement of Villela, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the Taiwan External Trade and Development Council, a Honduran trade-promotion mission is currently visiting Taiwan, where it has conducted more than 60 meetings with Taiwan businessmen.

According to Economic Affairs Vice Minister Chen Ruey-long, Honduras is Taiwan's leading coffee supplier in Central America and from June this year, it began to provide Taiwan consumers with high-grade beef at competitive prices.
Chen said that the MOEA has invited the Honduran trade and industry minister to visit Taiwan next year to start bilateral FTA talks.

Taiwan enjoys a long-term surplus in its trade with Honduras, but imports from the Central American country have been increasing in recent years. For the first 10 months of this year, Taiwan imports from Honduras totaled US$2.7 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC ENVOY CONFIDENT BUSH WILL KEEP WORKING ON TRIANGULAR TIES

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush is expected to continue to try to stabilize the triangular relations between Taipei, Washington and Beijing, given the long-term Taiwan-U.S. friendship, Taiwan's envoy to the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum (APEC) summit said Thursday.
Lee Yuan-tseh said the ongoing Cabinet reshuffle in the Bush administration should not cause any change in U.S. policy toward Taiwan.
He made the remarks upon arrival in the Chilean capital to attend the APEC leader's conference, set for Nov. 20-21, on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.
Bush and mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao will hold talks on the sidelines of the summit, with issues concerning Taiwan expected to take center stage.

Pointing out that Chen has displayed willingness to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations on many occasions since his second inauguration in May, Lee said he will pass on Chen's resolve to pursue cross-strait stability to Hu if he sees him during the summit.
On the agenda of the summit, Lee proposed that APEC leaders put their heads together for measures to prevent inflation as the global economy recovers.

Lee said he hopes APEC member nations will learn from the Asian financial crisis, the 911 terror attacks and the severe acute respiratory syndrome outbreaks, and will work together to stabilize the Asia-Pacific trade and investment environment and strive for security, regional peace and economic prosperity.
Taiwan will share its economic and technological achievements with other members to narrow development gaps for the goal of common prosperity, he said.
Also, he said, the development of energy recycling technologies is becoming a crucial issue on the APEC agenda in the face of the challenge of a possible imbalance between oil supply and demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALES OF TAIWAN MANUFACTURING SECTOR UP 18.22% IN 3RD QUARTER

TEXT.P: Sales in Taiwan's manufacturing sector totaled NT$2.472 trillion (US$76.06 billion) in the third quarter of this year, up 18.22 percent from the same period of last year, officials of the Statistics Department of the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Friday.

The officials said that among the sales, NT$1.3247 trillion (accounting for 53.59 percent) were local sales, up 18.34 percent from the year-earlier level, while NT$1.1473 trillion (46.41 percent was for exports, up 18.07 percent from the same period of last year.

Sales in the manufacturing sector in the first nine months of this year totaled NT$7.1574 trillion, up 20.27 percent from the same period of last year. Among them, domestic sales totaled NT$3.8533 trillion, up 20.22 percent from the previous year's level, while direct exports totaled NT$3.3040 trillion, up 20.33 percent from the previous year's level.

In terms of sector, sales of electronic parts and components were NT$564 billion in the third quarter, up 27.18 percent from the previous year, mainly because of strong demand from mainland China and Europe and the phasing out of the high-end cell phone panel.

Sales of the chemical material industry totaled NT$268 billion in the third quarter, up 38.09 percent from the previous year, thanks to the high international crude oil price and the accidents of naphtha cracker plants.

In the textile industry, sales grew by 7.13 percent to NT$72.3 billion after manufacturers adjusted their operation strategies, strengthened research and development and adjusted prices following price increases for upstream raw materials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MEETS YOUNG POLITICAL LEADERS FROM U.S.

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou shared his achievements in administering the capital city Friday with a group of visiting young political leaders from the United States.
