Ma pointed out that he has put a great deal of effort into developing Taipei as a "cyber city" by implementing measures such as providing free e-mail boxes and computer courses for residents.
While 90 percent of residents are familiar with computer use, 84 percent know how to use the Internet, Ma noted.
Also, Internet networking equipment is available now in every classroom in primary schools and the city government is working to establish a wireless Internet infrastructure in the city, Ma said.

Showing off the city government's achievements in garbage classification and recycling, Ma said each resident used to produce an average of 1.1 kg of garbage per day in the past, an amount that has been cut by half after the city government started to charge garbage collection fees on a per-bag basis.

The mayor said the "garbage revolution" has been a success and is the pride of the city government, adding that the city will continue to try to attain the goal of "zero garbage output, full resource recycling."
The 11-member delegation of the American Council of Young Political Leaders (ACYPL) is led by New Jersey's Hamilton Township Council President Daniel Benson.
In addition to observing the Dec. 11 legislative elections, the group will visit the Legislative Yuan, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and major technological firms around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITUNG CHIEF WITHDRAWS FROM PFP IN ORDER TO STUMP FOR DPP CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Taitung County Magistrate Hsu Ching-yuan quit the opposition People First Party (PFP) Friday to pave the way for his stumping for the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) sole candidate in his county for the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

While announcing his decision to renounce his PFP membership, Hsu also confirmed that he will deliver on his promise to stump for Hsu Jui-kuei, the DPP's sole candidate in the eastern county, in a campaign rally Saturday together with President Chen Shui-bian, who doubles as DPP chairman.
"It's a painful decision for me to withdraw from the PFP, " Hsu said, adding that he made the decision mainly because he intends to seek maximum benefits for Taitung voters.

"By endorsing the DPP candidate, I hope to cooperate closely with the DPP administration in carrying out two critical infrastructure construction projects to accelerate the county's economic development," he said.

Noting that the expansion of the southlink highway -- which connects Taitung County with the booming western part of the island -- and the construction of the Fukang fishing port are crucial to Taitung's long-term development, Hsu said he hopes the two projects can be completed as early as possible.
"Putting aside politics and giving the top priority to local construction are my primary concerns in deciding to endorse the DPP candidate," he stressed.

As the PFP's ally -- the Kuomintang (KMT) -- has fielded a candidate in the Taitung constituency, Hsu said he must renounce his PFP membership before stumping for the DPP candidate, in order to spare PFP Chairman James Soong a headache.

He further said he supports a merger of the PFP and the KMT. Nevertheless, he went on, he has no intention of joining such a merged party. If the two parties fail to merge, he continued, he is also unlikely to return to the PFP ranks, nor will he join the DPP. "I'll keep my status as a non-partisan independent in the future," he added.

It is believed his support will give DPP candidate Hsu Jui-kuei's legislative bid a big boost. The DPP has never been able to win a legislative seat in the eastern rural county, which has long been a KMT stronghold.

DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said the DPP appreciates Hsu's endorsement of its legislative candidate and will respect his decision to maintain his independent status instead of joining the DPP ranks.

Meanwhile, the PFP issued a statement expressing its regret over Hsu's decision and condemning the DPP for dangling a "carrot" in front of him, which has given him no choice but to comply with the DPP's wishes if he hopes to realize his campaign promise of accelerating Taitung's development.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCHER CONFIDENT OF TAIWAN'S BIOMEDICAL INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan is strong in the biochemistry, semiconductor and display industries, an advantage which will help the country become a front-runner in developing a competitive biomedical industry, a well-known researcher said Friday.

Wong Chi-huey, director of the Gene Research Center at the Institute of Botany under Academia Sinica, made the remarks while giving a speech at the 2004 International Symposium for Chinese Medicinal Chemists held at National Taiwan University.

Claiming that Taiwan stands a good chance of creating a competitive biomedical industry due to its abundant hi-tech manpower and rich know-how as well as full government support and a sound environment, Wong said that the country should also use its advantages to develop new technologies and devices for disease examination.
But he suggested that Taiwan set its sights on making new medicines, although it is a time consuming task that warrants visionary moves over the long term.

For instance, he said, Taiwan is suitable to study the virus of the potentially deadly severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and make effective drugs to tackle it amid public concern that SARS might stage a comeback as peak winter season approaches.

Despite the fact that mainland researchers have been keen on producing new medications by mixing traditional Chinese medicines and Western drugs, he pointed out that they have not developed any new drugs that have been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

He said that he is confident that Taiwan will be able to produce new medicines that can pass the FDA's strict requirements. "Only by surpassing the FDA's thresholds can drugs made by Taiwan make inroads into the global market and that is the correct path for the domestic biomedical industry to walk, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5,000 CHINESE ATTACKS MADE ON TAIWAN WEB SITES IN LAST TWO MONTHS

TEXT.P: The government has detected 5,088 attacks allegedly launched by a mainland Chinese "cyber army" on its official Web sites in September and October, according to a report released Friday by the National Information and Communications Security Taskforce (ICST).

Following a massive, organized cyber attack against Taiwan near the March 20 presidential election, Chinese hackers again started large-scale attacks against the island in September and October, the report said.

The hackers first invaded the Web systems of private companies and civil organizations with weak security as a "springboard" for them to gain access to the Web systems of government agencies, it said.
After they succeeded in doing this, they would change the information posted on the Web sites and even steal some other information stored in the government's computer systems, the report said.
To protect itself from these attacks, the government has enhanced its monitoring of suspicious e-mails and stepped up firewalling and the detection of spyware, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT UNIVERSITY PRESIDENTS FORUM TO OPEN NOV. 22 IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: A cross-strait forum for university presidents will be held Nov. 22-23 at National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in Tainan City, officials said Friday.

The presidents or their representatives of 49 research-oriented universities in Taiwan and mainland China are expected to attend the event to share their views on ways to make their universities world-class, the NCKU officials said.
In addition to NCKU, the universities from Taiwan will include National Taiwan University, National Tsing Hua University and National Central University.

Those from the mainland will include Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Tsinghua University, Tongji University, Southeast University, Wuhan University, Zhejiang University, Fudan University, and University of Science and Technology of China.

NCKU President Kao Chiang said higher education in Taiwan and the mainland, like other institutions, is facing challenges from international competition following their entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Therefore, it has become a priority issue for universities to upgrade their quality and develop their unique characteristics to strengthen their competitiveness, Kao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER CZECH REPUBLIC PRESIDENT HAVEL HAPPY TO BE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Former Czech Republic President Vaclav Havel said Friday he takes great pleasure in coming to Taiwan for a visit.
Havel made the remarks after his arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport for his first-ever visit to Taiwan.

"From file photos, I come to know that Taiwan is a beautiful island. I'm very delighted to be able to visit your country, " Havel told ROC Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Ouyang Jui-hsiung, who greeted Havel at the airport.
Havel is being accompanied by his wife, doctors and close aides on his six-day visit to Taiwan at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian and the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD).
In consideration of his health, TFD officials said Havel's itinerary is not a busy one so that he can have enough time to rest. Smoking resulted in Havel having to have a lung removed.
As Havel has keen interest in Taiwan's arts, culture and customs, his itinerary includes visits to the National Palace Museum and several aboriginal cultural museums.

During his stay, Havel will receive a decoration from President Chen for his contribution to the promotion of Taiwan-Czech Republic ties and his versatile career achievements, particularly his courage in keeping alive the "flame of democracy" when his country was under communist rule.

Havel will deliver a speech on the future of globalization and democracy as well as receive an honorary doctorate from National Chengchi University. His itinerary also includes meetings with local academics, artists and literary celebrities.

A resourceful man, Havel has had multifaceted roles throughout his career -- a poet, playwright, dissident, democracy activist, thinker and politician. He formally ended his 12-year presidency in February 2003.

After his retirement, diplomatic officials said, Havel immediately planned to visit Taiwan. But he later chose to stay in his country to help stabilize the domestic political situation following the transfer of power. Early this year, Havel planned to visit Taiwan and several other Asian countries to promote his new book. However, his Asian tour stopped in India and he canceled the remaining itinerary due to health reasons.

Havel played a pivotal role in his country's "velvet revolution" of 1989. He used his literary and theatrical creations to kindle and keep the flame of democracy burning amidst a storm of repression and autocracy during communist rule. He eventually led his country to break the shackles of communist suppression and move toward democracy. During his presidency, he continued working hard to consolidate the Czech Republic's democratic system as well as promote human rights and social justice, earning wide respect and admiration from his fellow countrymen.
Havel has been very friendly toward Taiwan because of his dedication to democracy and courage in standing up to mainland China's pressure.

During his presidency, Havel invited then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui to attend an international forum in Prague. Incumbent ROC first lady Wu Shu-jen and former Vice President Lien Chan have also visited the Czech Republic. In 1995, Havel spoke for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations at an annual U.N. General Assembly plenary session. He is one of the few world leaders willing to publicly throw support behind Taiwan without fearing Beijing's backlash.

To welcome Havel's visit, Taipei National University of the Arts has designated November as its "Month of Vaclav Havel Art." In addition to performing Havel's plays, the university has also organized many other activities during the period of Nov. 5-24, including a Havel book fair and a series of seminars on Havel's artistic and political achievements, as well as a Czech film festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS INVESTMENT AT HOME OVER US$300 MILLION FOR OCTOBER: MOEA

TEXT.P: A total of 86 investment plans made by overseas Chinese and foreigners in Taiwan were approved in October by the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), a commission spokesman reported Friday.

According to the official, the approved capital reached US$338.73 million, bringing the total investment capital from overseas Chinese and foreigners for the first 10 months to US$2.925 billion, up by 19 percent over the previous year's level.

During the January-October period, a total of 932 investment projects by overseas Chinese and foreigners were given the green light by the commission, up by 7.75 percent year-on-year, the official said.
In outbound investment (those in mainland China excluded) , 54 projects launched by Taiwan companies were approved last month by the commission, with a value of US$134.58 million.

In the same 10-month period, 550 outbound investment projects worth a combined value of US$2.878 billion were given the go-ahead, marking a drop of 6.3 percent in number and an increase of 7.2 percent in value, respectively, compared to their levels a year ago.
In October alone, the commission approved 113 investment cases bound for mainland China, with approved capital amounting to US$635.78 million.

The commission let go a total of 1,724 mainland-bound investment plans valued at more than US$5.425 billion for the first 10 months, up by about 17 percent in number and 53 percent in value, respectively, over their 2003 levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Judiciary panel backing Specter as its chairman.
Senator Arlen Specter, the Pennsylvania Republican under attack by some conservatives as too liberal to lead the Senate Judiciary Committee, won the unanimous backing of the panel's Republicans on Thursday, a move that appears to guarantee that he will become chairman when the new Congress convenes in January. The committee will not take a formal vote until January, when it is reconstituted with new members, and the entire Republican caucus must ratify the appointment.
Wall Street Journal: The deregulator, a less-visible role for the Fed chief: freeing up markets.
As Alan Greenspan approaches his last year as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, he continues to draw praise for his most visible job: steering the economy by raising and lowering interest rates. But behind the scenes, the 78-year-old economist has had a big impact on American life in an entirely different role: pushing the government to stay out of financial markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO LOCAL STEAKHOUSES SELLING JAPANESE BEEF: HEALTH DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: The Department of Health said Friday it has not found any local steakhouses selling Japanese beef.

The department was responding to a newspaper report that said many local steakhouses were still selling Japanese beef even though the government had banned imports of the meat in March 2000 over concerns of foot-and-mouth and mad cow diseases.

Health department officials said they conducted 1,810 spot-checks on domestic steakhouses last year, including 14 stores that publicly advertised that they were selling premium brand-name Japanese beef, such as Kobe and Matsusaka beef.
"None of the stores inspected were selling Japanese beef," said Hsieh Ting- hung, a health department official in charge of food sanitation.

Hsieh said the health department will intensify inspection of steakhouses that boast of having Kobe or Matsusaka beef. If they decline to produce documents proving the origins or sources of their beef, Hsieh said they will face a fine ranging between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000 and their names will be published as part of the penalty.
So-called Kobe beef or Matsusaka beef refers to cattle breeding methods rather than cattle origins.
If any steakhouse is found to have imported beef from Japan, Hsieh said, it will be slapped a fine ranging between NT$60,000 and NT$1.5 million, in addition to having all its beef destroyed.
According to customs authorities, no Japanese beef was imported into Taiwan in the first nine months of this year. The main sources of imported beef have been Australia, Panama and New Zealand.

Restaurants, tourist hotels and supermarkets that were mentioned by local media as selling Kobe or Matsusaka beef also rushed to clarify that their beef came from cattle raised in Australia with Japanese breeding methods.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN FIRE CHIEFS PLEDGE TO INCREASE COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Asian fire chiefs pledged to increase cooperation in disaster prevention and relief Friday after concluding the 23rd general conference of the International Fire Chiefs' Association of Asia (IFCAA) and the 2004 International Fire and Safety Exhibition that opened in Taipei Wednesday.

In two joint declarations signed by 15 IFCAA directors at the conference, the Asian fire chiefs agreed to further promote cooperation in disaster prevention and relief, to enhance exchanges of experiences and technologies, to increase visits by experts and scholars and to improve the granting mechanisms employed in humanitarian assistance.
More than 2,000 delegates from 23 IFCAA member nations and areas took part in the three-day meeting with "a global vision for disaster preparedness and response" as its main topic.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUPS FOUNDED BY VICE PRESIDENT TO SHARE SINGLE OFFICE

TEXT.P: Several private groups founded by Vice President Annette Lu will pool their resources and move into the same office from Saturday, one of Lu's aides named to head the joint office said Friday.
Chen Ming-ying said Lu will preside over the opening ceremony of the office, titled Go Go Go Union, and deliver a speech.
The groups, which will share their resources as well as office space, include Formosa Heart, National Prospects Foundation and Democratic Pacific Union.
Since all the groups were founded by Lu and share similar causes, it will be more efficient if they work together, Chen said.
Since the country's politicians are busy with the upcoming legislative elections, Chen said, no government leaders were invited to the opening ceremony.

Meanwhile, Premier Yu Shyi-kun, who is considered a possible successor to President Chen Shui-bian in the 2008 presidential election, dismissed in Kaohsiung reports that Lu's move is aimed at boosting her chances of being named the DPP candidate for the 2008 presidential election, saying it is simply a reorganization of Lu's groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: VANUATU PRIME MINISTER REAFFIRMS TIES WITH TAIWAN: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Vanuatu Prime Minister Serge Vohor has reaffirmed that there is no change in his country's diplomatic relations with Taiwan, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said Friday.
Vohor made the reaffirmation during a meeting with MOFA staff members stationed in the Vanuatu capital of Port-Vila earlier in the day, Lu said.

"Vohor assured our officials that ties between the two countries remain unchanged. Nevertheless, he said he needs a bit more time to confer with a few members of his Cabinet who have different opinions about forging diplomatic ties with Taiwan," Lu said.

He further said Vohor will deliver an administrative report at his country's parliament. Vohor is expected to report on the establishment of diplomatic relations between Vanuatu and Taiwan in his report, Lu added.

According to Lu, the Republic of China's provisional Embassy has begun operations at Le Meridien Hotel in Port-Vila. "Relations between our two countries are proceeding normally, " he said, adding that the Embassy hoists the ROC national flag from 8 a.m. through 5 p.m. each day.

Noting that Vohor is Vanuatu's top government leader, Lu said the joint communique signed by Vohor and ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen in Taipei Nov. 3 on establishing bilateral formal diplomatic ties is fully valid. The confirmation of Vanuatu's Cabinet is only a formality and will by no means affect the validity of Taiwan-Vanuatu ties, Lu added.
He further said a media report about Vanuatu reneging on its newly forged diplomatic ties with Taiwan was groundless. He dismissed it as "a lie" put into circulation by Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR PROSECUTED FOR BUYING VOTES THREE YEARS AGO

TEXT.P: Independent Legislator Tsai Hau from Pingtung, southern Taiwan was prosecuted in his hometown Friday for buying votes in the 2001 legislative elections, and the prosecutor from the Pingtung Prosecutor's Office is seeking a six-year jail term.
Also prosecuted were Tsai's wife, Soong Li-hua, and 34 of his former campaign workers; each was recommended by the prosecutor to jail terms of three years and six months.
Another 722 were prosecuted for going on overseas tours financed partially by Tsai. The prosecutor is seeking six months in jail for each of them.

According to the prosecutor, Tsai gave handouts varying from NT$3,000 to NT$5,000 to each of the 722 voters under the pretext that anyone who subscribed to the Commons Daily for one year would get money to go toward an overseas tour.

The prosecutor said in his statement of charges that the 722 voters visited Japan or Thailand between February and October, 2001 in 22 groups, fully aware that part of their fare was coming from Tsai. Tsai, his wife or his campaign workers accompanied these groups on the tours.
Tsai, whose three-year term runs out next February, is running for re-election, and could not be reached for comment.

Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan was reported to be angry with the fact that the prosecutor took three years to finish the investigation and filed the charges only weeks before the Dec. 11 legislative elections. He said that this has left the impression that the release of the indictment was timed to block Tsai's chance of winning re-election.
Chung Rung-sung, a chief prosecutor at the Pingtung Prosecutor's Office said too many people were involved in the case and it took time to question each of them.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIEF OF TAIPEI EUROPEAN CHAMBER LEAVES FOR REPORT TO EU

TEXT.P: Dirk Sanger, chairman of the European Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (ECCT) left recently for Brussels to give his chamber's annual report about Taiwan's business climate to the European Commission under the European Union (EU).

Before embarking on his trip, Sanger said he would urge the EU to support Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization and facilitate the normalization of business exchanges between Taiwan and the mainland.

Sanger said that most European companies have relocated part of their manufacturing operations to the mainland, and Taiwan's restrictions on imports of Chinese-made products have virtually shut these European companies' goods out of Taiwan, not to mention the absence of direct transportation links between Taiwan and the mainland, which has damaged European companies' competitiveness in Taiwan.
Sanger's complaints were included in the ECCT's annual report and have already been made known to Taiwan authorities.

Taiwan officials defended the island's policy of restricting imports from the mainland, arguing that it has already opened its markets to mainland Chinese goods wide enough and shifted the blame for the lack of direct transportation links to the mainland and the Beijing authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX-YEAR HIGH ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE ESTIMATED FOR 2004 AT 5.93 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The government raised its forecast for Taiwan's economic growth rate Friday for the whole of 2004 to a six-year high of 5.93 percent, up from 5.87 percent predicted in August.
The Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) renewed its estimate following a screening meeting involving the country's newest figures and data.
The DGBAS also reported that the Taiwan economy expanded by 5.27 percent in this year's third quarter and it predicted that it will grow by 4.11 percent in the fourth quarter.

DGBAS Director-General Hsu Chang-yao attributed the upward adjustment of the full-year economic growth rate to a sound domestic economy well underpinned by a global economic recovery since the beginning of this year, which peaked in the middle of the year.

According to Hsu, the performance of the domestic economy this year will be better than the world's average of 4.2 percent, the United States' 4.4 percent, South Korea's 4.3 percent and Japan's 4.1 percent.

The country's outbound and inbound shipments also increased by 23.5 percent and 34.7 percent, respectively, during the January-October period year-on-year, he said, adding that per capita income will hit US$13,995 for 2004.
However, he pointed out that Taiwan's economic growth rate for 2005 will be around 4.56 percent as a result of an anticipated slower economic upturn across the world.

But he forecast that per capital income will increase to an all-time high of US$14,961 next year, thanks to the government's drive to improve the country's infrastructure and boost local consumption and investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES BEIJING TO EXPRESS CLEAR STANCE ON CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun urged mainland China Friday to make clear its attitude toward the opening of direct two-way charter passenger flights across the Taiwan Strait during the upcoming Chinese Lunar New Year holiday.
Liu said the MAC has unveiled a comprehensive package of measures for the proposed charter flight services.

"We hope Beijing will speak up as to what it wants to do regarding the proposal and start negotiations with Taiwan over the issue to facilitate the return of Taiwan business people operating in mainland China for family reunions during the lunar new year holiday," Liu said.
The MAC has authorized the Taipei Airlines Association to negotiate with its mainland counterpart.

With Beijing's consent, Taiwan carriers operated special charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during the 2003 Chinese New Year period. The services were not offered during the 2004 Chinese New Year holiday because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers be also allowed to provide the same flight services while declining to negotiate the necessary technical details with Taiwan.

The ROC government said that as the opening of two-way, non-stop cross-strait charter flight services involves the exercise of public authority, prior negotiations are necessary. The upcoming lunar new year holiday falls between Feb. 6-13, 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SIGNS DOCUMENT SUPPORTING RUSSIA'S WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Russia inked an agreement in Santiago, Chile Friday, wherein Taiwan gave its consent to Russia's admission to the World Trade Organization.

The pact was signed by Taiwan's Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh and his Russian counterpart, German Grefa, on the sidelines of the annual ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, which was held Nov. 17-18.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR NOV. 20 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Nov. 20:
09: 10, President Chen Shui-bian will attend the first sports games of Hua Nan Financial Holding Co. at the Taipei County Stadium in Panchiao.
10:00, Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan will attend the opening ceremony of the "Challenge 2008" national development programs exhibition in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan.
10: 00, The 2004 United Nations NGO International Cultural Conference will open at National Taiwan University of Science and Technology in Taipei.
10: 10, The Sixth Asia-Pacific Children's Urology Symposium will open at the Taipei International Convention Center.
10:40, Vice President Annette Lu will attend the inauguration of the "Go Go Go Union" office at the 12th fl. West wing, No. 51, Heng Yang Rd., Taipei.
10: 45, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will attend the celebrations marking Marriage Day at the Civil Service Development Institute in Taipei.
11:00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend the opening ceremony of celebrations marking the 400th anniversary of the Taiwan-Netherlands first encounter in Penghu.
11: 00, The 2004 Taiwan Design Expo will open at the Ilan Sports Park in Ilan City, northeastern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT: LEGISLATIVE PRESIDENT SHOULD HEAD CONTROL YUAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday he will name Wang Jin-pyng, currently president of the Legislative Yuan, to head the Control Yuan.

Stumping in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan for a legislative candidate of his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , the president said the chief of the Legislative Yuan should be one detached from politics; therefore, Wang, who is a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), is not suitable for the post.
Chen said he would name Wang to head the Control Yuan, and would wait until after the Dec. 11 legislative elections to nominate candidates, including Wang, for members of the Control Yuan.
The president's nominees for Control Yuan members have to be approved by the Legislative Yuan.

Earlier in the day, DPP convener at the Legislative Yuan, Legislator Ker Chien-ming, said his party recommended Wang to President Chen as head of the Control Yuan to rescue Wang who, Ker claimed, has been held political hostage by KMT Chairman Lien Chan and Lien's political ally, People First Party Chairman James Soong in the elections.
Wang, who was named as the KMT's first choice for lawmakers-at -large, and who was campaigning for KMT candidates in the race, passed over DPP's proposal as a joke.

KMT spokesmen Chang Rung-kung decried Chen's statement as a political trick to alienate Wang from the KMT, noting that Chen has claimed that he would name another KMT vice chairman, Wu Poh-hsiung, as head of the Control Yuan sometime before.

As a response to Chen's statement, Legislator Huang Teh-fu, KMT secretary at the Legislative Yuan, said facetiously that his party suggested Chen name Vice President Annette Lu as the head of the Control Yuan and she would probably find out the truth behind the March 19 shooting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Nov. 20, or the ninth day of the tenth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1910: Leo Tolstoy, one of the greatest novelists in world literature and an important moral and religious thinker, dies at the age of 82.
1937: The Nationalist government of the Republic of China announces the move of the capital to Chungching to prepare for the long-term war against Japan.
1947: Princess Elizabeth marries Philip Mountbatten at Westminster Abbey. She later became the queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.
1962: The United States announces lifting the blockade to Cuba.
1969: A large scale anti-Vietnam war demonstration is staged in Washington, D.C. with some 250,000 people participating.
1975: Spanish dictator Francisco Franco dies in Madrid at the age of 82.
1980: Chinese Communists begin the public trial of the "Gang of Four."
1981: George Yeh, senior adviser to the president, dies at the age of 78.
1996: Gambian President Yahya Jammeh visits the Republic of China.
1998: The Republic of China and the Marshall Islands sign a joint communique to formalize diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times: Legislator Tsai Hau and 755 others prosecuted for election-fixing.
The United Daily News: President charges former defense minister with trying to stage a quasi-coup.
The Liberty Times: President: Two retired generals tried to stage a quasi-coup.
The Taiwan Daily: Chen accused retired general Hsu Li-nung of trying to stage quasi-coup.
The Central Daily News: Former defense minister rebuts Chen's accusation of coup.
The China Post: China hackers molest Taiwan gov't Web sites.
The Taiwan News: GDP growth hits 5.27%, slowest record in a year.
The Taipei Times: Heavyweight quits PFP to support DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Taipei tipped off Tokyo on China sub.
President Chen Shui-bian yesterday said Taiwan had tipped off Japan and the United States about the intrusion of a Chinese nuclear- powered submarine into Japanese waters last week.
'Information provided by Taiwan to the United States and Japan in advance has led to the confirmation and discovery' of the submarine intrusion in Japanese waters, he said, without elaborating.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Almost half of the old person in Singapore doesn't help to look after their grandchild.
The Lianhe Zaoboa's investigation shows there are 70% of the person above 55 years old have grandchild in Singapore, but only 53% of them help to look after thier grandchild.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: GMA flies on to Chile for APEC
BURLINGAME, California (Via PLDT) -- President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo ended her visit to California and flew direct to Santiago, Chile yesterday to attend the 12th Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Summit.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Solons feasting on pork
IGNORING mounting clamor for a drastic cut, if not the outright abolition, of their "pork barrel" funds, members of the House of Representatives have opted to retain the entire Priority Development Assistance Fund (PDAF) , also known as pork barrel, in the proposed P907.6 billion national budget for 2005.
The Philippine Star: 10 senators give up P1.3-B 'pork'
If congressmen are clinging to billions in pork barrel, 10 senators led by Senate President Franklin Drilon are committed to give up a total of P1.3 billion in "pork" allocations for next year to bring down the budget deficit.
The Manila Times: Customs man fired for lavish spending
For a Customs official drawing an annual salary of P275,820, Ma-nuel Valencia's credit-card expenses were remarkably extravagant. In 2003 Valencia, a chief Customs officer, charged P300,000 worth of items to his Bank of the Philippine Islands Master Card.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE WOULD BE PLEASED TO SEE PRESIDENT AT APEC: ENVOY

TEXT.P: Taiwanese would be pleased to see President Chen Shui-bian attend the the 2004 Economic Leaders' Meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic (APEC) forum set to begin here Saturday, Chen's envoy to the meeting, Lee Yuan-tseh, said Friday.

The APEC leaders' meeting has been off-limits to Taiwan's president ever since it began in 1993 because of Beijing's opposition, and Lee has been named by Chen as his envoy to the meeting for the last two years.
In a veiled attempt to air Taiwan's grievance, Lee told a news conference that the Taiwanese would like to see their president speak for them in international conferences.

He touted Taiwan's contributions to APEC, saying that his country has followed up on its call last year for narrowing the gap among members in digital technology by sending six teams of experts to help 13 member economies.

Predicting an outbreak of avian flu next year, Lee said his country will suggest that APEC come up with a prevention program, adding that Taiwan will funnel US$20 million into developing a vaccine against the disease, which will be enough to meet Taiwan's own needs with some left over for other countries.

Lee, who is president of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest research body, expressed his concerns that many countries are pursuing economic development on the wrong assumption that natural resources are inexhaustible.
Instead of exploiting nature for endless economic development, the winner of the 1986 Nobel prize in chemistry said mankind should try to balance development with the preservation of nature.

Lee, who arrived in Santiago Thursday, told a dinner party in his honor the following evening that many people he has had contact with here are worried about Taiwan's strained ties with mainland China. "We hope peace will prevail in the Taiwan Strait for ever and we will do our best to achieve that goal," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Troops Invade Baghdad Mosque; Raid on Sunni Site Leaves Two Dead.
Iraqi troops backed by U.S. soldiers raided the most revered Sunni mosque in Baghdad, setting off stun grenades, arresting dozens and leaving at least two people dead, according to witnesses and a hospital official, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO INK FTA WITH CHILE: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Santiago, Chile, Nov. 19 (CNA) (By C.W. Kuan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes to ink a free trade agreement (FTA) with Chile to enhance bilateral trade relations, Taiwan's envoy to the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit in the Chilean capital of Santiago said Friday.

Lee Yuan-tseh, who attended the summit on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, made the remarks in response to questions on how to enhance bilateral trade relations between Taiwan and Chile when he was interviewed by Chilean TV channels TVN and UCV, as well as by United Press International.
Lee also said Chilean President Ricardo Lagos' idea of an Asia-Pacific FTA is worth studying.

During a separate interview with the Associated Press, Lee said that Taiwan, in addition to developing its own economy, is willing to cooperate with other APEC members to promote regional economic prosperity.

He noted that APEC consists of developed countries, such as the United States, Japan and Canada, and developing countries, with Taiwan in between, which will enable it to play a major role in contributing to the regional organization.
Taiwan is capable and determined to contribute to APEC, the Nobel laureate said.

He also said that Taiwan has rich experience in its development of small- and medium-sized enterprises, as well as having excellent information technology and an e-government that can be of reference to other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 WHOLESALE, CONSUMER PRICES TO RISE: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's wholesale price index (WPI) and consumer price index (CPI) are expected to rise 7.2 percent and 1.8 percent, respectively, in 2004, according to a forecast by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) released Saturday.

With the costs of imports having jumped significantly this year due to soaring oil and raw material prices, the WPI stood at 10.4 percent in the third quarter and is expected to amount to 9.4 percent in the fourth quarter, the report says.
The CPI, on the other hand, saw a less vigorous increase of 2.9 percent in the third quarter and is expected to register a 2.6 percent rise in the fourth quarter.

While prices for foodstuffs soared as a result of typhoon damage, commodity prices mostly remained stable because of market competition, and the fall in housing rentals also helped even up service prices, according to the report.
On the outlook for 2005, the DGBAS predicted that pressure on prices will become more moderate as the appreciation of the new Taiwan dollar is expected to lower import costs.
Next year's WPI and CPI are expected to rise 2 percent and 1.9 percent, respectively, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. NGO INTERNATIONAL CULTURAL CONFERENCE OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A United Nations-affiliated Non-Governmental Organization International Cultural Conference opened Saturday in Taipei.

Scholars from home and abroad, including Holland, Hong Kong, India, Japan and the United States, will give speeches and take part in discussions centering on cultural differences between the East and the West during the two-day meeting at National Taiwan University of Science and Technology.

Recent surveys show that more than 80 percent of Taiwan's parents and teachers are worried about a rapid deterioration in social morals and ethics in recent years, a development that is also taking place in the West, organizers said, adding that the main purpose of the conference is to find ways to promote morals, culture and education.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA TO LURE BUSINESS VISITORS FOR TAIWAN TOURISM

TEXT.P: The head of the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said he and a delegation from a South Korean company will climb Yushan, the highest mountain in northeast Asia, Sunday, as part of an effort to promote tourism for business visitors.

TAITRA Chairman Hsu Chih-jen noted that foreigners made 2.24 million visits to Taiwan last year, with those naming business as their main purpose for visiting accounting for the most at 698,000, or 31.08 percent, showing that this is an area worth development.

He said that TAITRA has been working with local travel agents to choose a score of attractive tour routes that will hopefully prompt business visitors to come to Taiwan or extend their stays in Taiwan when they visit for exhibitions, conferences and other trade activities in Taiwan.
Hsu said he invited Yoon Young Dal, president of Crown Confectionery Co., to climb Yushan when he visited South Korea last June. The South Korean company then organized a 19-member team for the trip.
Hsu said that he hopes to share the beauty of Taiwan's mountains with the South Korean visitors and help promote tourism for business visitors.
The group will include officials from TAITRA and the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, as well as from Taiwan's Imei Foods Co.

Crown Confectionary and Imei Foods signed a strategic cooperation agreement last year under which Imei will supply cookies and pastries for sale in South Korea, while Crown will produce various cookies and pastries for sale in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Early Vioxx Alarms Alleged.
Federal regulators and the drug maker Merck & Co.were aware of risks that the company's Vioxx painkiller could cause serious heart problems before the drug was approved in 1999, government and expert witnesses told a Senate committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTHERN TAIWAN SCIENCE PARK BOOSTS JOBS: POLL

TEXT.P: The jobs available in southern Taiwan now are nine-fold the level of three years ago following the establishment of the Southern Taiwan Science Park, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.
The survey was conducted by the 104 Job Bank from Nov. 4-8 among 3,818 job seekers and 222 enterprises.
Statistics of the job bank show that 54,982 jobs in southern Taiwan have been advertised on its Web site so far in November, compared with 5,796 in the same month of 2001.

While openings in the fields of finance, securities and insurance have increased by 5,056, those in the electronic manufacturing sector rose by 4,193, and those in the business management and industrial and commercial consulting sectors increased by 2,688.

Positions related to sales and trading were most common, with 15,237 openings available, followed by those related to production and manufacturing, with 12,139 openings and those related to engineering and research and development, with 11,470 openings.
However, the survey found a wide gap between demand and supply.

For example, jobs in the finance, securities and insurance sectors accounted for 9.9 percent of all the jobs in southern Taiwan, but only 6.6 percent of the people in that region were interested in them.
The electronic manufacturing sector offered only 8.3 percent of the openings, but 23.9 percent of people were seeking to enter the popular sector.
Sales personnel positions comprised 30 percent of all openings, but only 8.7 percent of the survey respondents were willing to take such jobs.

Meanwhile, 61 percent of the enterprises and 58 percent of the job seekers surveyed said the scale of the Southern Taiwan Science Park will catch up with that of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in three to five years.

On the benefits of working in southern Taiwan, 79.7 percent of the enterprise respondents named the low cost of living, 53.2 percent named the relaxed tempo of life, 40 percent named the low housing costs, and 30.2 percent named the pleasant living environment.

On the problems they face in personnel recruitment in the south, 65.3 percent of the respondents said talent is scant, 26.6 percent cited the high personnel turnover rate and 25.7 percent said their enterprises are not attractive for new talent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPANIES FEEL THREATENED BY RISING CURRENCY

TEXT.P: In the face of rapid surges of the new Taiwan dollar, local companies are worried about a decrease in their competitiveness overseas, spokesmen for trade groups and industry associations said Saturday.

Out of grave concern over losing their competitive edge in foreign markets, Taiwan businessmen are asking the central bank to intervene to stem the local currency from further strengthening pushed up by global hot money on a dwindling U.S. dollar and rampant speculation over an appreciated mainland China currency early next year, they said.

Lo Hai-chia, an executive of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association, said that this recent wave of appreciation of the domestic currency has been much fiercer than public expectations, seriously affecting many companies that failed to hedge in advance.

The new Taiwan dollar dropped by NT$0.134 Friday to end at 32.554 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market. It finished at 32.42 a day earlier, marking an almost-four-year high. In the first four days of the week, it picked up NT$0.57 in value.

A spokesman for the Chinese National Federation of Industries said that the rising new Taiwan dollar has greatly eroded the competitiveness of home-based export-oriented textile makers and he pointed out that they have asked the central bank to take measures to curb any further strengthening.
He said that domestic textile makers will be in big trouble should the local unit continue rising and he urged the central bank to do something quickly to help them tackle their difficulties.

Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$6.7 billion for the first 10 months of this year, down by a whopping US$7.9 billion from the previous year's level, a situation he said indicates that Taiwan companies are much less capable of creating foreign exchange reserves.
If the situation persists, it will deal a heavy blow to the domestic export sector and lead to many business closures, he warned.

Officials of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development admitted earlier this week that the new Taiwan dollar has surged too fast recently and that it will cause some negative effects on domestic businesses. But the impact has yet to be assessed, as most of the companies would have made efforts to hedge against such an eventuality.
However, they acknowledged that a continuously appreciating local currency will have a profound impact on export businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN URGED TO ENHANCE SECURITY COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Japan should maintain closer security cooperation and exchanges to fend off potential political and security risks between the two countries and mainland China, the leader of an Asian studies group from Japan said Saturday.

Kunihiko Takano said there are many uncertainties in Asia and these include the Asia policy in the second term of U.S. President George W. Bush, as well as the mainland's political, economic and military movements.

Takano said the mainland's economic development has faced challenges such as a shortage of raw materials, food production reaching the limit for exporting countries, a large amount of non-performing loans and a severe imbalance in the distribution of wealth.

He said that anti-Japan riots on the mainland, the dispute over the Tiaoyutai islands, a mainland intrusion into Japan's territorial waters and Beijing's ignoring of President Chen Shui-bian's peace overtures show that there are potential political and security risks between Taiwan, Japan and the mainland.
Takano made the remarks during a forum on "China's peaceful rise" organized by the Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS MIGHT FACE NEW CHALLENGES NEXT YEAR: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: London, Nov. 20 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's outgoing representative to Britain said Friday that cross-Taiwan Strait relations might face new challenges next year because of President Chen Shui-bian's determination to push through constitutional reforms.
Tien Hung-mao made the remarks when he spoke at a farewell dinner given in his honor by Taiwan businessmen residing in Britain.
Tien said Beijing could respond to Chen's insistence on promoting constitutional reforms, which might cause tension across the strait and result in a complex and contradictory situation.

He noted that since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States three years ago, the U.S. has viewed mainland China as a cooperation partner in its anti-terrorism campaign. The attack changed the situation, which cannot be unilaterally reversed by Taiwan, he added.
The seasoned diplomat also said that U.S. President George W. George is not expected to change his anti-terrorism campaign as priority policy after winning his second four-year term.
But although the United States needs cooperation from the mainland, it will not be mean to Taiwan, as the core members of the Bush administration will continue to support the country, he said.

The situation in the Taiwan Strait is currently stable, he went on, adding that this has to do with the attitude of the United States. On one hand, the U.S. has decided to rein in Taiwan from taking too-provocative actions against the mainland, while Beijing on the other hand has shown restraint by not involving the United States into a possible eruption of conflict in the Taiwan Strait.
As the only military superpower in the world, the United States will continue to play a decisive role in the Taiwan Strait, he said.

On cross-strait relations, Tien said that after years of development, both sides of the strait have formed interdependent relations. He noted that Taiwan businessmen flock to the mainland to find outlets for their labor-intensive industries, attracted by the rich human resources and huge potential mainland market.
In addition, the coastal areas of the mainland have good infrastructure and both sides of the Taiwan Strait also share the same language, culture and eating habits, he said.

He noted that Taiwan businessmen traveling to the mainland do not necessarily support cross-strait unification and that they only go to the mainland because they have no choice because of the world trend of division of labor.

A conservative estimate puts Taiwan's investment in the mainland at at least US$100 billion. The number of Taiwan businessmen, employees and their dependents who have to live there for over six months a year is between 600,000 and 700,000, while about 300,000 Taiwanese in the mainland marry mainlanders.

With continued investment by Taiwan businessmen, cross-strait trade has risen rapidly and the mainland has replaced the United States as Taiwan's largest market. Two-way trade between Taiwan and the mainland is expected to reach US$60 billion this year, with Taiwan enjoying a trade surplus of US$40 billion.

Tien also predicted that in the next five or 10 years, Beijing will avoid taking drastic action against Taiwan because of these closer trade relations, which could be favorable to the unification of the two sides.
He said the Beijing authorities currently have adopted three strategies with regard to Taiwan: either woo the Taiwan people, warn them of risky consequences, or use verbal or military intimidation.
Basically, he added, the mainland leaders are all hardliners, though they may employ different methods.

Tien predicted that in the end, Beijing will not resort to a destructive approach for handling cross-strait issues and that Taipei will also not bet on the lives and property of the 23 million people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH FIREFIGHTING SCHOOL VISIT HELPS BILATERAL COOPERATION

TEXT.P: The National Fire Administration under the Ministry of the Interior said Saturday that a visit by the faculty of a French national firefighting school will help enhance bilateral cooperation.

The 34-member group arrived Nov. 14 for a weeklong visit during which they visited fire departments in various cities and counties, including Taipei City and Taipei, Nantou, Pingtung, Taitung and Hualien counties. The group will wind up its visit Sunday.
Fire administration officials said that the French group mainly observed fire prevention work in high-rising buildings, as well as rescue and evacuation operations for people in such buildings.

The officials also said that a student of the school was the main catalyst behind the visit, noting that the student was one of the members of a French rescue team who came to Taiwan for rescue operations in the wake of the devastating earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999, which caused heavy casualties and tremendous property losses in Taiwan, especially central areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Negotiators add abortion clause to spending bill.
U.S. House and Senate negotiators have added anti-abortion provision into a US$388 billion must-pass spending bill, complicating plans for Congress to wrap up its business and adjourn for the year. The provision may be an early indication of the growing political muscle of social conservatives who provided crucial support for Republican candidates, including President Bush, in the election.
Wall Street Journal: Oracle receives mandate from PeopleSoft shareholders.
Oracle Corp. won the backing of 60.8 percent of PeopleSoft Inc. shares Friday in a crucial tender vote that could decide whether PeopleSoft remains an independent company. The substantial mar gin of victory suggests that PeopleSoft's shareholders are solidly behind the Oracle merger, though some have urged the database maker to raise its US$24-a-share price.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP OPENS JOINT OFFICE FOR HER CIVIC GROUPS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu opened a joint office Saturday in Taipei for several civic groups she has founded.

Lu denied news reports that the "Go Go Go Union" office is "her" office or that she will use it to launch her ambition to run for the presidency in 2008, saying instead that the office was opened to pool the resources of the several private groups that share the cause of stressing Taiwan's status as a country.
The groups using the office are the National Prospects Foundation, Formosa Heart, Democratic Pacific Union and various others.
Lu said the groups share the office and pool their resources to save money because it is expensive to keep an individual office for each of them.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LAUDS FIRST ENCOUNTER BETWEEN TAIWAN, HOLLAND 400 YEARS AGO

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over a ceremony in Makung, Penghu County, Saturday, to mark the arrival of Dutch sailors in Penghu 400 years ago, describing it as the first encounter between Taiwan and the outside world.

Citing a story inscribed on a stone tablet unearthed in 1919 at the site of the Tienhou Temple in Makung, Chen said Dutch sailors arrived in Penghu in 1604, bringing Taiwan into contact with the world and opening a new chapter in the country's history.
Chen said the arrival of the Dutch in Taiwan put the island onto the international stage and gave Taiwan an important role to play in exchanges between the West and the East.
According to Chen, the role Taiwan has played in the West-East exchanges is the same role Penghu plays in the current exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China.
He hailed the significance of Saturday's ceremony, the first of its kind in Taiwan, claiming that it underlines the fact that Taiwan is an island of the world.
The president said he has a map of Taiwan drawn by Dutch in 1726 hanging in his office to remind him of the Netherlands' contributions to Taiwan.
The tablet found in the Tienhou Temple describes an official of China's Ming Dynasty who succeeded in expelling a group of Dutch sailors who landed on Penghu and tried to settle there in 1604.

Menno Goedhart, the representative of the Netherlands' Trade and Investment Office in Taipei, attended Saturday's ceremony, during which he presented Chen with a bottle of jenever, a traditional Dutch liquor.
Chen also promised to set up a science and technology university in Penghu by August next year and to start another ferry service between Kaohsiung and Penghu before the end of this year.
After his speech, the president opened an exhibition of Dutch artifacts at the Tienhou Temple.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HONORS MODEL MARRIAGES

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun honored 10 couples who have forged successful marriages Saturday in a celebration marking the fourth Marriage Day, during which he urged the public to "find love," which he said is the key to family happiness.

The premier attended the event, organized by the Taiwan Blissful Marriage Promotion Association and held at the Civil Service Development Institute in Taipei, in the company of his wife. Yu said his administration has implemented many plans aimed at strengthening a support network for local families.
He said the network is part of the government's efforts to encourage singles to get married, to reduce singles' fear of carrying a family burden and to encourage young couples to start families.
During the Marriage Day celebration, Yu awarded 10 local couples who have maintained their marriages for over 50 years, as well as a model foreign couple living on the island.

According to an August survey conducted by the association, 10.9 percent of citizens nationwide who responded to the poll said they were not satisfied with their marriage, a figure that represents some 1.09 million married people.
Taiwan had 10.01 million married people at the time the survey was carried out, according to official tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT PLAN EXHIBITION OPENS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: An exhibition for the national development plan "Challenge 2008" opened Saturday at the National Science and Technology Museum in the southern city of Kaohsiung, officials of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported that day.

The event, called "Taiwan Goes Far, " is organized by the CEPD, with several officials including Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan, CEPD Vice Chairman Chang Jing-sen, National Science Council Vice Chairman Shieh Ching-jyh, Executive Yuan Southern Office CEO Yu Hung and Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Yao Kao-chiao on hand to witness the opening ceremony.

Yeh said that the national development plan has been well-formed at that it is time to put the plan into practice in order to make Taiwan a "green silicon island" and boost the country's global competitiveness.
The exhibition features a show of the results to date of the national development plan, a "Go Far Bus" that is designed to be a totem to embody the plan and various folk art performances.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR 'PAN BLUE' MAJORITY IN NEXT LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan reiterated his call Saturday for a majority of legislators from the opposition "pan blue alliance" in the next legislature, in order to safeguard the future course of the Republic of China.

Lien issued the call in southern Kaohsiung City while stumping for various "pan blue alliance" candidates, including Chiang Yi-wen and Lo Shih-hsiung of the KMT and Chiu Yi and Chang Hsien-yao of the People First Party (PFP) in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Stressing that the outcome of the elections will be of maximum importance to the country's future, Lien claimed that it is vital to have more than half of the 225-seat Legislative Yuan held by "pan blue" lawmakers to defend the country's current system, including its title and territory, freedom and democracy.
The KMT chairman was also critical of the plans for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for ruling the country over the long term, calling it a reflection of an "authoritarian mindset."

"100 percent power will lead to 100 percent corruption, " he said. He also accused the DPP of creating hatred and conflict among Taiwan's various ethnic groups that has led to social disorder under its rule.

According to Lien, the misery index of the Taiwan people has peaked at a 20-year high of 7.2 points, as the country's jobless rate and living costs have remained high without showing signs of cooling.
Taiwan does not need to provoke war against mainland China and the two sides should seek to maintain the status quo in their best interests by putting aside sovereignty disputes, he said.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng also claimed in Kaohsiung that same day that it would be a "major crisis" in Taiwan's democratic development should the "pan blue alliance" fail to secure its current majority in the next legislative.

Wang, who is also a vice chairman of the KMT, said that Taiwan is now facing serious problems arising from the dangers of war, poverty, marginalization and a twin-peak society under the leadership of President Chen Shui-bian.

Commenting on Chen's repeated vows to write a new constitution by 2006, Wang said that it will further worsen the sharp divide in Taiwan society, engulfing the country in a risky situation with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER CALLS FOR INVESTIGATION INTO 'SOFT COUP' ALLEGATION

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator demanded Saturday that prosecutors start an investigation into the "soft coup" allegation made by President Chen Shui-bian.
Wang Sing-nan said anyone found to have engaged in such an activity can be charged with sedition or attempted sedition according to the Criminal Code.

Chen first claimed last week that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) incited a "soft coup" by asking some retired generals to attempt to persuade active service generals to fake sickness or resign after KMT candidate Lien Chan lost the March 20 presidential election.

Following up on his allegation, Chen said Friday that a former defense minister and Hsu Li-nung, former director of the General Political Warfare Department under the Ministry of National Defense, were involved in the plot.

Also Saturday, KMT Vice Chairman and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou agreed that prosecutors must probe the case immediately, saying that the head of state must not be allowed to "speak with indiscretion without having to take responsibility" for his words.
Holding a similar view, Lien said it is irresponsible of Chen to make the allegation "based only on information gathered from the Internet."
Huang Te-fu, the KMT's legislative caucus whip, accused Chen of trying to mislead the people by making groundless remarks just so that his party wins the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
Meanwhile, former Premier and Defense Minister Hau Pei-tsun said Chen's allegation is "naive and ignorant" and is a humiliation for the military.

Hau said the nationalization of the military was already completed during the term of former President Lee Teng-hui and that the military abides by the Constitution and obeys the command of the president.
If the military had intended to start a coup, it would have done so as soon as Chen was elected to his first term in 2000, according to Hau.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF TO STEP UP PROMOTION OF E-DISBURSING OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) is stepping up the promotion of e-disbursing operations in line with the e-government goal set by the Executive Yuan.

The MOF's National Treasury Agency said Saturday that since the ministry's Taipei Regional Disbursing Office started e-disbursing operations in July 2003, 347 out of 829 central government disbursing agencies have practiced one-way e-disbursing, while 317 have practiced two-way e-disbursing.

The office is hopeful that all central government agencies, when paying a certain amount -- currently under NT$100,000 (US$3,077) -- or documents to certify a transfer -- can be changed to e-disbursing so as to upgrade the e-disbursing efficiency of the national coffers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARKET VALUE OF LISTED COMPANIES UP NT$296.7 BILLION

TEXT.P: In anticipation of a proposed weighting increase of Taiwan shares by Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) by the end of the month, foreign institutional investors have continued to increase their purchases of Taiwan stocks, which has boosted the market value of Taiwan listed companies by NT$296.705 billion (US$9.12 billion) this week.
Taiwan Stock Exchange statistics show that the combined market value of listed companies in Taiwan reached NT$13.71 trillion this week due to the MSCI effect, up 2.21 percent from the previous week.

The statistics also show that gainers outnumbered losers in the 20 top major industries this week, with the market value of the listed companies in the electronics industry gaining the most at 3.99 percent, while the market value of the listed companies in the tourism, rubber, finance and plastic industries also showed an increase of 1 percent. The market values of the logistics, steel and iron, and automobile industries showed a decline, and the decline ratio was more than 1 percent.
The weighted index, the key barometer of the Taiwan Stock Exchange, ended at 6,026.55 Friday, a surge of 109.39 points from last week.
There have been 220 trading days on the Taiwan Stock Exchange so far this year, with a daily average turnover of NT$100.08 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRONG NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR AFFECTS EXPORTS TO U.S., EUROPE: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: A strong new Taiwan dollar will affect Taiwan's exports to the United States and Europe, but its impact will be limited on outbound shipments to mainland China, scholars said Saturday.

Lin Chu-chia, an economics professor at National Chengchi University, said that the recent appreciation of the new Taiwan dollar should have had some effects on the country's exports, in particular those to the United States and Europe.

However, exporters doing business with mainland China are being less influenced, he said. Currently, Taiwan's trade with the mainland accounts for one-third of the country's total foreign trade, he noted.

Since late September, the new Taiwan dollar has strengthened against the U.S. dollar by about 4 percent, a ratio Lin described as "reasonable." Should the local unit gain in value by more than 10 percent, its impact on the domestic export sector will have to be reassessed, he added.

The new Taiwan dollar closed at 32.554 against the greenback Friday in the Taipei foreign exchange market, a drop of NT$0.134 from Thursday's finish. It had gained NT$0.57 in value for the first four days of the week on back of an influx of international hot money taking advantage of the weak U.S. dollar.

Despite wide speculation over a mainland China's renminbi appreciation of between 5 percent and 10 percent early next year, however, the professor was reserved about the likelihood of the mainland authorities making such a move, pointing to the mainland's relatively low per-capita income of about US$1,000.
As many mainland economists are opposed to a renminbi appreciation at this time, he said it is hard to predict precisely when such a move will actually be implemented.

Chen Ruey-long, vice minister of economic affairs, also said that the impact of a rising local unit must be evaluated compared to the gains made by other currencies, such as the Euro, the Japanese yen, the renminbi and the South Korean won.
In essence, a more expensive local currency has both positive and negative effects on different lines of businesses in various regions, he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 300 TAIWAN EXPORT ITEMS TO RUSSIA TO ENJOY 30% TARIFF CUT

TEXT.P: More than 300 Taiwan export items to Russia will enjoy an average 30 percent deduction in customs duties after Russia is admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO), Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Friday.

Ho was referring to the content of an agreement she signed in the Chilean capital of Santiago with her Russian counterpart, German Grefa, wherein Taiwan gives its consent to Russia's admission to the world trade regulatory body.
The document was signed on the sidelines of the annual ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, which was held Nov. 17-18 in the Chilean capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Nov. 21, or the 10th day of the tenth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1937: Kao Chih-hang, a Republic of China "814 Air Action" hero, is killed at Chouchiakou airport by a Japanese fighter plane bombing before his fighter plane takes off to strike head-on.
1947: The first National Assembly elections in the Republic of China are held.
1969: The United States and Japan issue a joint statement that the United States hands over Okinawa to Japan in 1972.
1972: The Central American country Jamaica establishes diplomatic relations with mainland China.
1990: The Straits Exchange Foundation, a Taiwan quasi-official organization dealing with cross-Taiwan Strait technical affairs, is established.
1995: The Republic of China and Australia sign a memorandum of understanding to permit temporary duty-free entry of certain goods as a means of increasing the two-way trade.
1996: Taoyuan County Magistrate Liu Pang-yu is shot to death at his residence.

Foreigners will eventually sour on U.S. bonds and the dollar because of America's bulging trade and budget deficits,posing significant risks to the nation's economy,Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspansaid in remarks that rattled financial markets.
