Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, during talks with U.S. President George W. Bush, suggested Saturday that Japan will extended the deployment of the Ground Self-Defense Forces in Iraq beyond the end of their current mission, Japanese officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN APEC ENVOY MEETS WORLD LEADERS
DOC.DATELINE: Santiago, Chile, Nov. 20 (CNA) (By Kuan Chung-wei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Lee Yuan-tseh, Taiwan's envoy to the informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, attended the opening of the summit held in the Chilean capital of Santiago Saturday.

Lee, who attended the summit on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, met and talked with leaders from several APEC economies, including U.S. President George W. Bush, Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi and Russian President Vladimir Putin.
Lee, president of Academia Sinica and a Nobel laureate, said he has not had the opportunity to meet with mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao yet.

Pointing out that President Chen has displayed willingness to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations on many occasions since his second inauguration in May, Lee said he will pass on Chen's resolve to pursue cross-strait stability to Hu if he sees the mainland president during the summit.

During interviews a day before with international media, including the Associated Press, UPI, Chilean TVN, and Chilean UCV, Lee said that it is the hope of the 23 million Taiwan people that President Chen will be able to take part in future APEC leadership summits in person.
Lee said that Taiwan, in addition to developing its own economy, is willing to cooperate with other APEC members to promote regional economic prosperity.

Taiwan, having rich experiences in its development of small- and medium-sized enterprises, as well as having excellent information technology and an e-government, is capable and determined to contribute to APEC efforts, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD EXPLAINED TAIWAN'S MAINLAND POLICY IN EUROPE
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Nov. 20 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top official for mainland affairs said that the goal of his tour of Europe was to explain Taiwan's mainland policy to various countries to counter Beijing's attempts to marginalize the island.
Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), spoke on the eve of his departure in Berlin. Wu returned to Taipei Saturday.

Pointing out that many European heads of state have side with mainland China against Taiwan to further their business interests, Wu said that Beijing has never relented in its campaign to belittle Taiwan, labeling it a "troublemaker."
"This greatly harms Taiwan and my current tour in Europe has been to explain clearly to European countries the Taiwan government's consistent and transparent cross-Taiwan Strait policy," he said.
His tour of Europe was a sensitive matter and he was not welcomed by all European countries. France, for instance, is still pro-China, Wu said.
However, Germany seems to better accept Taiwan, Wu said, adding that German think tanks have a good understanding of cross-strait affairs, as do pro- Taiwan members in the German Parliament.

Touching on Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization as an observer, Wu said that Berlin has stressed that it has to discuss the matter with other members of the European Union and cannot take unilateral action because the EU has a common foreign policy.

Wu said that he had personally thanked German parliamentarians for their support. He emphasized that in a pro-Taiwan resolution, many voiced their concerns about Taiwan's security, showing that the military threat from China has drawn attention from the German people.

The resolution, which was raised by German ruling parties, requested that the arms embargo against mainland China be maintained. It also asked Beijing to resolve cross-strait disputes peacefully, to improve its human rights record and to oppose the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.

The resolution, along with a similar one passed recently by the European Parliament, shows the strong international support for Taiwan, Wu said, adding that he hopes that these resolutions can serve as a foundation for other European countries to discuss Taiwan and to keep the arms embargo in place.

He reiterated that if the EU agrees to lift the export ban, it would mean that Europe does not care about Beijing's military threat toward Taiwan and accepts its threat of the use of force in the Taiwan Strait. Some EU members, including France, have been requesting that the EU lift the ban.

During his visit, Wu met with Guido Westerwelle, president of the opposition German Free Democratic Party, scholars and representatives from think tanks. He also gave interviews with some leading German newspapers, including Frankfurt's Allgemeine Zeitung, Berlin's Zeitung and Germany's Financial Times.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CULTURE RECEIVES INCREASING WORLD ATTENTION: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Nov. 20 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's multi-ethnic culture is receiving ever-increasing world attention, a visiting Republic of China official said in Los Angeles Saturday.
Wu Chin-fa, vice chairman of the Council for Cultural Affairs, made the remarks in a speech delivered to a group of Taiwanese expatriates residing in California.

Wu said the University of California at Santa Barbara sponsored an international seminar on Taiwan culture recently, with the participation of academics from the United States, Canada, Japan and South Korea.

A total of 27 papers on Taiwan's history and culture were discussed at the seminar, Wu said, adding that it marked the first time that a U.S. university has ever organized a symposium exclusively on Taiwan's cultural development.
In the past, Wu said, international seminars or studies on Taiwan usually focused on political and economic issues.
Wu, himself a poet and essayist, said Taiwan culture's greatest features lie in its receptivity and inclusiveness.

"Although Taiwan is a small island, it has a great ability to assimilate foreign cultures. It has managed to integrate many alien cultural elements into its own culture, adding to Taiwan culture's diversity, uniqueness and vitality, " Wu said, adding that the cultural receptivity can explain why Taiwan can far more easily accept democratic political systems than mainland China.

Wu further said the government and people of Taiwan should let the world understand that Taiwan is a very special place and that values demonstrate in its arts, music and dances form the core of Taiwan culture.

In the future, Wu said, the Council for Cultural Affairs will endeavor to have Taiwan's literary works translated into English for distribution to English-speaking countries and to introduce Taiwan's diverse musical and artistic creations to the world.

In another news development, an exhibition of photos featuring Taiwan's beautiful natural scenery and folk customs and culture opened Saturday at the Los Angeles culture center for a four-day run. The show is being organized by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Los Angeles.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSOU FISH FESTIVAL BEGINS IN ALISHAN

TEXT.P: The Tsou Fish Festival began Sunday in Shanmei rural township of Chiayi County to mark the successful conservation of the carp-like fish that is endemic to Taiwan.

The aboriginal Tsou people, who have traditionally made the Sun Moon Lake and Mount Ali (Alishan) regions their home, celebrated the opening of this year's Tsou Fish Festival at a ceremony held at Danayi Valley in Shanmei Sunday.

The Tsou people first offered millet wine to worship the river god of Shamichi Creek, which is upstream from Tsengwen Creek, one of the major waterways in Taiwan, followed with other traditional Tsou celebrations, including Tsou-style wrestling, an archery competition and glutinous rice grinding by stone mortar.

The Tsou people began the conservation project in 1988 to protect the endangered fish that is endemic to Taiwan's mountainous areas, in hopes that the fish, known as Yosku Aulu in the Tsou dialect -- meaning "the genuine fish" -- will not be threatened with extinction due to poaching.
Since then, the Tsou people have organized their own patrols to guard the Yosku Aulu from illegal fishing.
The Danayi Valley of Shanmei rural township is home to many of the fish.

Yosku Aulu, commonly known in Taiwanese as Kohuei, has been coveted by both aboriginal and Han people since ancient times because it has been regarded as a great delicacy. The Japanese colonial settlers during the 1920s called it Oshima.
The fish, with yellowish green glittering scales and pale yellow or white belly, is found in mountainous streams with strong currents where the water is clear and cold.
President Chen Shui-bian attended a similar ceremony held at Danayi Valley in April 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH-HU TALKS ON TAIWAN ISSUE WENT AS EXPECTED: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: The head of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Sunday that the talks between U.S. and mainland Chinese leaders on Taiwan issues on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Santiago went as expected.

MAC Chairman Joseph Wu made the comments when he attended a friendly baseball game between teams from his council and the Presidential Office at the opening of the 2005 Presidential Cup Baseball Championship, which began the same day.

According to wire services reports, mainland Chinese President Hu Jingtao said after he met with U.S. President George W. Bush on the summit sidelines that he appreciated Bush's commitment to the "one China" policy, the "three communiques" and his opposition to Taiwan independence.

Wu, who just returned from Europe where he explained the ROC government's cross-strait policies to various European countries, said that the Bush-Hu talks on Taiwan issues showed that Washington's cross-strait policy is consistent, noting that aside from the "one China" policy, there is the Taiwan Relations Act and the "three communiques" and that the U.S. also opposes Beijing's use of force against Taiwan.

Considering that Washington's existing cross-strait policy will remain unchanged in the foreseeable future, and that the United States will explain the contents of the Bush-Hu talks to Taiwan through appropriate channels, the official said that the authorities in Taipei will then give further explanations to the public.

Wu also predicted that Washington's cross-strait policy will not change after Condoleezza Rice assuming the post of U.S. Secretary of State because she was already aware of the issues as national security advisor. (By P.C. Tang) Endtiem/mw .

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD ADMINISTRATION STEPS UP PATROL AGAINST MAINLAND POACHERS

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) has begun a sweeping patrol operation in waters to the west of Taiwan to expel mainland Chinese poachers.

The operation, dubbed "Clear Seas, " began in waters outside Taichung, central Taiwan to the areas surrounding Penghu Islands Friday night after local fishermen complained that a large number of mainland fishing boats have converged in the areas in recent days to fish illegally, CGA officials said.
Under the "Clear Seas" operation, four CGA cruiser frigates, flanked by several patrol boats, began to patrol the Taichung-Penghu area in the Taiwan Strait Friday night for three days.

During the patrol, most of the mainland Chinese fishing boats fled while some stubborn ones who refused to leave the ROC economic territory were cornered by the CGA coast guard forces, having their catch and fishing gear confiscated before being driven away.

CGA authorities said that patrolling will continue in three-day stints because this time of the year, the northeast trade winds bring in big schools of fish to the Taiwan Strait, which attracts mainland Chinese fishing boats to Taiwan waters.

CGA authorities also called for Taiwan fishing boats or anybody who spots mainland Chinese boats conducting illegal fishing in Taiwan waters to call 118 -- the Taiwan Fishermen's Broadcasting Station -- which will in turn notify the CGA.

DOC.HEADLINE: RETIRED GENERALS DENY PRESIDENT'S 'SOFT COUP' ALLEGATION

TEXT.P: Former Minister of National Defense Chiang Chung-ling on Sunday denied President Chen Shui-bian's allegations that he cooperated with several other retired generals to stage a "soft coup" after the March 20 presidential election.

Chiang made the denial at a news conference held at the headquarters of the major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) after Chen said Friday that a former defense minister who also served as a KMT deputy chairman and Hsu Li-nung, former director of the General Political Warfare Department under the Ministry of National Defense were involved in the "plot."

Chiang said that the former defense minister and former KMT deputy chairman mentioned by the president should refer to him, and stressed that he absolutely did not persuade generals on active service to fake sickness or resign in an attempt to launch a "soft coup" after KMT candidate Lien Chan lost the presidential election.

"If President Chen has concrete evidence for the who, when and where of the incident and the persons involved, he should immediately give it to the justice authorities for investigation, and I would be subject to legal punishment if I were found having violated the law," Chiang told reporters.

Chiang also voiced the hope that former Defense Minister Tang Yiau-min and incumbent Defense Minister Lee Jye will engage in a public cross-debate with him about the alleged "soft coup" in order to find out the truth.

Speaking on the same occasion, Yok Mu-ming, chairman of the opposition New Party, denied the president's accusation on behalf of Hsu Li-nung, who is currently receiving medical treatment in mainland China, saying that Chen's charges were aimed at defaming the opposition camp in the lead-up to the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Meanwhile, Ku Chung-lien, a legislator of the opposition People First Party (PFP) , who served as commander-in-chief of the Republic of China Navy, also rejected the president's accusation that he was involved in the plot, through his proxy at the press conference as he was stumping for PFP candidates in southern Taiwan.

Chen first claimed last week that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and PFP incited a "soft coup" by asking some retired generals to attempt to persuade active service generals to fake sickness or resign after the March 20 presidential election to cause social unrest.

Following up on his allegation, Chen said Friday that a former defense minister and Hsu Li-nung, former director of the General Political Warfare Department under the Ministry of National Defense, were involved in the "plot."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. BRIEFED TAIWAN ON BASIC STANCE BEFORE BUSH-HU TALKS: MOFA

TEXT.P: The U.S. government had assured Taiwan that there would be no changes in its policy toward cross-Taiwan Strait relations before President George W. Bush held talks with mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao in Chile Saturday, a diplomatic official said Sunday.

"U.S. authorities had briefed us on their basic policy line ahead of the Bush-Hu talks on the sidelines of the ongoing informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Santiago the previous day, " Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said.

Lu was responding to foreign wire service reports saying that Hu had praised Bush after their one-hour talk for his reaffirmation of the U.S. commitment to the "one China" policy, the three Washington-Beijing joint communiques and opposition to Taiwan independence. The reports further said Bush didn't mention any Taiwan-related subjects after his talks with Hu.
Commenting on the reports, Lu said the reported content of the Bush-Hu talks didn't go beyond what Taiwan had expected.

"From the pre-summit U.S. briefings, we already knew that the U.S. policy toward cross-strait relations would not be changed, " Lu said, adding that MOFA will continue to maintain close interactions with the United States and make every possible effort to boost bilateral substantive relations.

Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said the latest Bush-Hu talks indicates that the U.S. government will uphold consistency in its basic policy line toward Taiwan and mainland China and is unlikely to waver on this stance in the foreseeable future.

Wu, who just returned from a European tour to expound on the nature of Taiwan's cross-strait policy, further said he didn't find any unexpected elements in the latest Bush-Hu face-to-face talks on the sidelines of the APEC summit in the Chilean capital.
According to foreign wire service reports, Hu said after his meeting with Bush that he was pleased with the result of the talks.

The two "exchanged views on the issue of Taiwan and I expressed my high appreciation to President Bush for his position on the 'One China' policy and his opposition to Taiwan's independence," Hu said after the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PRESIDES OVER FREEWAY OFF-RAMP OPENING IN CHANGHUA COUNTY

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun officiated at the inauguration ceremony for an off-ramp of the North-South Freeway near the Peidou exit in the central county of Changhua on Sunday morning.
Yu commended the Changhua County Government for its efficiency in completing the construction, affirming that its inauguration will boost the development of the local tourist industry.
The premier said that the central government is planning to build the Changpin Industrial Park into a free trade harbor zone to speed up the transformation of the county's agricultural industry.

Also present at the ceremony were Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san, Council of Agriculture Chairman Lee Chin-lung and Changhua Magistrate Weng Chin-chu as well as Legislators Wei Ming-kun and Chou Ching-yu.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANUFACTURERS URGED TO GLOBALIZE OPERATIONS DUE TO WEAKER GREENBACK

TEXT.P: Taiwanese manufacturers should speed up the globalization of their business operations as a way to reduce the negative impact that a weaker U.S. dollar will have on their exports, a government official said Sunday.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said that the continued appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar against the greenback shows the importance of globalizing business operations, adding that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is not worried that this will accelerate domestic manufacturers' "go west" policy.

Noting that it is the MOEA's duty to create a favorable environment for Taiwanese manufacturers to globalize their business operations, Chen said that the government will actively participate in various trade talks within the framework of the World Trade Organization and seek to sign with more foreign countries agreements aimed at avoiding double taxation to facilitate domestic manufacturers' business operation globalization.

The local currency has appreciated against the U.S. dollar by about 3 percent over the past two weeks, an amount that Chen described as "acceptable." Although it has an impact on export prices, import prices for semi-finished products, raw materials and key spare parts and components required for export product manufacturing are also lowered at the same time, he explained.

Chen said that the Japanese yen and the South Korea won have appreciated against the U.S. dollar more sharply over the past two weeks while the appreciation range of the local unit against the greenback has been relatively lower.

Although mainland China's renminbi is also facing growing appreciation pressure, it is still pegged to the greenback, thus leaving Taiwan in a more advantageous position than Japan and South Korea, Chen noted, adding that domestic manufacturers with operations on the mainland can export those items which are prone to be affected by the foreign exchange fluctuations directly from the mainland.

However, domestic entrepreneurs are worried about losing their competitive edge in foreign markets in the face of a continuously appreciating N.T. dollar. Executives from several business and industrial organizations, including the Chinese National Federation of Industries, said that the recent appreciation range of the local unit is higher than expected and asked the central bank to take measures to curb any further strengthening of the New Taiwan dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT CALLS ON VOTERS TO SUPPORT 'PAN-GREEN' CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui called on voters Sunday to support candidates of the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) in the year-end legislative elections.

"Only when the 'pan-green camp' win a majority in the Legislative Yuan in the Dec. 11 elections, can Taiwan enjoy a stable political situation, " Lee said, adding that the number of seats to be garnered by the TSU will be decisive for the camp to control the legislature.
Lee, also the spiritual leader of the TSU, made the remarks while stumping for the party's candidate Chang Chin-hu who inaugurated his campaign headquarters in Taiping City, Taichung County.

It has been more than eight months since the March 20 presidential election, but the domestic political situation is still unstable because the legislature is controlled by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, Lee pointed out.
He went on to say that if the "pan-green camp" can win more than half of the legislative seats in the Dec. 11 elections, the government will be able to carry out various sweeping reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA DEFENDS QUALITY OF LOCALLY PRODUCED FRESH MILK

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) defended the quality of locally produced fresh milk Sunday, saying the product is hygienic and nutritious.

The Cabinet-level council was responding to a study by a National Chiao Tung University (NCTU) research team that claimed that 80 percent of locally produced fresh milk, including most popular brands, were not very nutritious because their beta-lactoglobulin contents were almost completely lost in the process of ultra-high-temperature (UTH) flash sterilization.

The NCTU report further said the quality of locally produced fresh milk lagged far behind that of U.S.-originated fresh milk and even fell below that of imported powdered milk. The beta-lactoglobulin is the main component of proteins in fresh milk that can enhance immunity, lower cholesterol and help vitamin digestion.

In response, Chen Hsing-hao, a COA department chief in charge of husbandry affairs, and Chen Pao-chi, chairman of National Taiwan University's livestock husbandry department, jointly held a news conference to defend the quality of locally produced fresh milk.
Chen Hsing-hao said local dairy farms have consistently followed the standard sterilization procedures widely used in the international community in keeping their products free of bacteria.
"Flash sterilization under a temperature of 130 degrees Celsius is not expected to seriously affect nutrients in fresh milk, " Chen Hsing-hao said.

Chen Pao-chi echoed Chen Hsing-hao's statement, saying that although flash, ultra-high-temperature sterilization may slightly affect some temperature-sensitive nutrients in fresh milk, such as beta-lactoglobulin and some kinds of vitamins, most other proteins, calcium and nutrients in fresh milk remain intact.

Both of them insisted that the UTH sterilization method used in Taiwan has been widely certified in the international community and adopted by many Western countries. They further stressed that locally produced fresh milk still contains beta-lactoglobulin and many other proteins, including whey protein, casin and gamma-lactalbumin.
"Our fresh milk is nutritious and safe for consumers to drink, " Chen Hsing-hao stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: EGYPT BEATS TAIWAN IN OPENING GAME OF WORLD FUTSAL CHAMPIONSHIPS

TEXT.P: Egypt blanked Taiwan 12-0 in the opening game of the Chinese Taipei 2004 Tournament of the FIFA Futsal World Championships held in Taipei Sunday.
This is the first time that the FIFA Futsal championship is being held in Taiwan, in which teams from 16 countries are taking part.
President Chen Shui-bian attended the opening ceremony of the championship held earlier in the day at National Taiwan University stadium.

Addressing the opening, Chen said that it is a great honor for Taiwan to play host to the world indoor football championship. Taiwan will gain much visibility on the world stage after hosting this tournament, he said, adding that via this tournament, the sport will also gain much more popularity in Taiwan as well.

Chen said he believes that the Taiwan team, also known as Chinese Taipei, will "kick well" in the world championship and he offered his appreciation for the Federation International of the Football Association (FIFA) for authorizing the 16-nation tournament.
Chen also thanked the Taipei City Government and Chinese Taipei Football Association, co-sponsors of the tournament.

Also addressing the opening, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said that it is not the first time for Taipei City to host international sport competitions, but it is the first time that Taipei City has a world championship televised around the world via satellite.

Ma said it is hoped that by hosting the Futsal competition, enthusiasm for soccer will be rekindled in Taiwan and local players will be able to pick up experience and expertise from top players from around the world.
He added that it has been a struggle for Taipei City to win the opportunity to host the tournament due to strong competition from rival countries.
The 2004 FIFA Futsal World Championship Chinese Taipei is one of the activities devoted to marking the 100th anniversary of the founding of FIFA, Ma said.
Altogether, 16 teams from six regions are scheduled to come to Taipei for the five-a-side indoor championship.
Four games are scheduled for Monday, the second day of the world championship, with two games being played in Taipei and the other two at Linko Stadium in Taoyuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMING DECADE CRITICAL TO TAIWAN-U.S.-CHINA TIES: EX-MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: The coming decade will be a crucial period for the development of Taiwan-U.S.-China relations, former Mainland Affairs council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Sunday.

Tsai, who is a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate for at-large legislative seat in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, made the remarks during a campaign rally in the southern city of Tainan.

Tsai, one of the most articulate women politicians in Taiwan, said that with U.S. President George W. Bush winning re-election and mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao taking full control of China, the coming 10 years will be a crucial period for the development of the delicate triangular Taiwan-U.S.-China relations and possible changes in Taiwan's international status.
In her view, Tsai said, President Chen Shui-bian's re-election has helped strengthen Taiwan identity and consolidate the "one country on either side" of the Taiwan Strait framework.
Tsai said the government has made tremendous efforts to insist on Taiwan's basic political stance in its interactions with mainland China.
Tsai urged local voters to support candidates fielded by the "pan-green" camp of the DPP and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- in the upcoming legislative elections.
"By controlling a clear majority in the Legislative Yuan, President Chen will have an even stronger mandate to safeguard our national sovereignty," Tsai said.

Over the past four-plus years, the DPP administration has had a hard time implementing its policy initiatives and political reform agenda due to its failure to control a majority in the legislature, Tsai said.

Meanwhile, Tsai said Taiwan badly needs to inject new blood into its legislative, diplomatic, economic and social welfare systems in order to accelerate national development and upgrade overall national competitiveness.
"We need a new generation of lawmakers, formulate new Legislative Yuan operational rules and establish a new mechanism for substantive policy debates," Tsai said.
The nation also needs a new generation of diplomatic and trade officials, Tsai said.

"In the past, most of our diplomats and foreign trade planning personnel were civil servants. In the future, we should recruit high-caliber young professionals to assume leading diplomatic and trade posts to open up new frontiers for our diplomatic work and economic development," Tsai said.
She also criticized the efficiency of existing social welfare mechanisms, saying the current systems are unfair and must undergo modernization reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOY KRATHONG DAY MARKED IN TAIPEI TO HONOR THAI WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government organized a series of activities Sunday to mark Loy Krathong Day, one of the most beautiful and popular festivals in Thailand, to honor the 3,700-plus Thai workers in the city.

Taipei City Deputy Mayor Yeh Chin-chuan said at an evening party at the 228 Peace Park that the celebration activities are aimed at helping Taipei citizens get a taste of the beauty of Thai culture and let nostalgic Thai workers reminisce about their joys and cultural life in their home country.

Yeh said the city government is grateful for the contribution of Thai workers to major municipal infrastructure construction projects, including the Neihu and Nankang lines of the mass rapid transit systems.
"We hope the Loy Krathong Day celebrations will bring joys and happiness to all Thai laborers in Taipei," Yeh said.
The celebration activities included a ball game, making of Krathongs which mean lotus-shaped vessels made of banana leaves, and performances of traditional Thai dances.
During the evening party, Yeh presented gifts and a trophy to the top winner of a beauty queen contest, an important part of the Loy Krathong festival celebrations.

Loy Krathong Day celebrates annually on the 15th day of 12th month on the Thai calenda. It takes place at a time when the weather is fine as the rainy season is over and there is a high water level all over Thailand.
"Loy" means "to float" and a "Krathong" is a lotus-shaped vessel made of banana leaves. The Krathong usually contains a candle, three joss-sticks, some flowers and coins.

On the day, people offer thanks to the goddess of the water. By moonlight, people light the candles and jos-sticks, make a wish and launch Krathongs on canals, rivers or small ponds. It is believed that the Krathongs carry away sins and bad luck, and the wishes that have been made for the new year due to start.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TRAVEL FAIR ATTRACTS RECORD NUMBER OF VISITORS

TEXT.P: A record number of 114,456 people visited the 2004 Taipei International Travel Fair which ended its four-day exhibition Sunday, organizers said.

The number of visitors marked a nearly 30 percent increase from the year-earlier level, said the Taiwan Visitors Association (TVA), which organized the annual fair with the assistance of the Tourism Bureau.

Many local tourist hotels and recreational parks managed to sell a large amount of tour packages and overseas tour packages, particularly Hong Kong- and Southeast Asia-bound tours, also enjoyed brisk sales, TVA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO PASS DRAFT BILL ON AMENDMENTS TO REFERENDUM LAW

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will pass a draft package of amendments to the Referendum Law at its weekly meeting Wednesday, Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Sunday.

Chen said that as the present Referendum Law, passed by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan, contains many flaws, Premier Yu Shyi-kun directed Minister-without-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung to come up with draft revisions to the law.
"The draft amendments are aimed at formulating a referendum law that complies with the democratic concepts and meet Taiwan's practical demands," Chen said.
The draft package had passed initial screening by officials from the Judicial Yuan, the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of Justice, the Central Election Commission and other relevant agencies.
"The Cabinet is scheduled to pass the package at Wednesday's meeting after further discussions," Chen said, adding that the package will then be referred to the Legislative Yuan for approval.

If the "pan-green" camp of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union can win a clear majority in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, Chen said, the draft revisions to the Referendum Law will be able to clear the legislative floor soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Nov. 22, or the 11th day of the tenth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1497: Vasco Da Gama, Portuguese explorer and colonial administrator, becomes the first navigator to sail around the Cape of Good Hope in his search for a sea route to India. He opened the rich lands of the East to Portuguese trade and colonization.
1842: Mount St. Helens in the U.S. state of Washington erupts.
1890: Charles de Gaulle, French general and politician, is born. During World War II, he gained enormous popularity as the leader of the Free French forces in exile. He was elected president in 1958, 1965 and 1968.
1899: Wiley Post, American aviator who made the first solo flights around the world, is born.
1935: Taiwan holds its first elections for members of city and county councils.
1943: China's Chiang Kai-shek, U.S. president Franklin D. Roosevelt, and British Prime Minister Winston Churchill agree in Cairo, Egypt, on measures to defeat Japan in World War Two.
1946: A revolutionary new pen, invented by Hungarian journalist Ladislaw Biro, goes on sale in Britain at 2.75 pounds (US$5). The pen will write 200,000 words without blotting, smudging or needing to be refilled.
1950: The Executive Yuan approves the "37.5 percent Farm Rental Reduction Act" at its meeting.
1956: The Taiwan Provincial Government moves its office from Taipei to Chunghsing Village, Nantou County in central Taiwan.
1963: President John F. Kennedy is assassinated in Dallas, Texas, at the age of 46.
1963: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Kuwait.
1972: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon lifts the 22-year-old ban on American travel to mainland China.
1975: King Juan Carlos is sworn in as King of Spain following the death of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, who had ruled Spain since 1939.
1975: More than 5,000 members from nine countries and territories open the 14th Orient and Southeast Asian Lions Forum in Taipei.
1976: Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan presides over a two-day conference of ambassadors in Taipei. Participants include 10 ambassadors, a consul general and a minister.
1976: The first Pacific Dental Congress on pain control is held at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.
1977: The Anglo-French Concorde, the world's first supersonic passenger plane, finally enters service on the New York- London-Paris run, eight years after its first flight.
1982: The mainland Chinese government today decides to lift import bans on 689 Japanese consumer products to show its sincerity in improving its trade relations with Japan.
1986: The awesome punching power of Mike Tyson, 20, makes him the youngest heavyweight boxing champion ever as he takes the World Boxing Council heavyweight crown after knocking out Trevor Berbick in less than two rounds in Las Vegas.
1989: Rene Moawad, the newly elected president of Lebanon, and 23 others are killed by a 250-kg remote-control bomb while passing through Beirut in a motorcade to celebrate Independence Day.
1990: Margaret Thatcher, British prime minister, resigns after 11 years in office.
1990: Twenty thousand protesters march in Bulgaria to demand the resignation of the communist government.
1991: Boutros Boutros Ghali, Egyptian deputy prime minister, becomes U.N. secretary-general, succeeding Javier Perez de Cuellar.
1999: Presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian calls for a reduction in the number of armed forces regular personnel from the current level of 430,000 to about 300,000.
1999: Lee Chia-tung, rector of National Chi-Nan University, formally renders his resignation.
2000: President Vladimir Putin inaugurates Russia's new State Council.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian signs documents formally approving Taiwan's ratification of World Trade Organization agreements and thereby completing the last step of the country's 12-year pursuit of WTO membership.
2001: Taiwan's World Trade Organization (WTO) information center, jointly set up by technical personnel from Taiwan and the WTO, is opened to the public.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "A man who (only) eats and drinks is counted mean by others; because he nourishes what is little to the neglect of what is great."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR HEADS FOR JAKARTA TO ATTEND ASIAN CITIES CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou left for Jakarta, Indonesia Monday to attend an Asian Network of Major Cities (ANMC) conference aimed at promoting resources exchanges among major Asian cities.
This will be the first time that Ma attends the annual conference in person.
Ma will take part in a forum on inter-city resources exchanges to boost Asian development. He will also meet with Taiwan businesspeople operating in Indonesia.
On Tuesday, Ma will sign a joint declaration at the conclusion of the ANMC conference with his counterparts from other member cities. He is scheduled to return to Taipei Wednesday.
Japan took the initiative to form the Asian Network of Major Cities in 2000, and the organization held its first plenary session in 2001.
The network groups 12 Asian capitals, namely Tokyo, Taipei, Seoul, Beijing, Hanoi, Manila, Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur, Singapore, Jakarta, New Dehli and Yangon.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP TO U.K. DEPARTS LONDON WITH HIGH PRAISE
DOC.DATELINE: London, Nov.21 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Outgoing Republic of China Representative to Britain Tien Hung-mao departed London with his wife Sunday for home, concluding a stint of two years and seven months as Taiwan's top envoy in the United Kingdom.
Tien departed with praise from Taiwan expatriate community members in Britain and with a high degree of recognition from political and diplomatic circles in both the United Kingdom and Europe.
Over 50 Taiwanese and British friends saw the Tiens off at the the airport.

During his time in office, Tien scored several "record" achievements in his efforts at strengthening Taiwan's friendship with the United Kingdom and Europe and at broadening Taiwan's diplomatic horizons.

Tien's most recent achievement was inviting 26 parliamentarians from 20 European countries who have been friendly toward Taiwan to establish the "Marco Polo Club" and convening the club's first general meeting on Taiwan-related issues, including how to facilitate Taiwan's participation in important international organizations.

Last week, members of the British-Taiwanese All-Party Parliamentary Group bid farewell to Tien and his wife at a reception held at the House of Commons. It marked the first time that members of the British Parliament had held a farewell reception at the Parliament for an ROC envoy.

Thomas Cox, one of the co-chairmen of the parliamentary group, raised a motion in the House of Commons to request that it cite Tien's outstanding performance in enhancing relations between the two countries. The motion was signed by over 60 members of Parliament.

Altogether, the House of Commons raised eight motions during Tien's tenure in London to show support for Taiwan. The motions featured efforts ranging from supporting Taiwan's accession to the World Health Organization and recognizing Taiwan's democratization, to raising concerns about China's military intimidation of Taiwan and calling for the European Union not to lift its arms embargo against mainland China.

During his stint, Tien also signed an agreement with Jean Lemierre, president of the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) , to jointly initiate two programs to help 28 countries in Central and Eastern Europe and Central Asia in their transition to free market economies.

Under the Replenishment Agreement, Taiwan pledges to donate an extra US$1 million to the EBRD's technical cooperation programs. Taiwan is the largest non-member donor to the EBRD's technical cooperation funds.
The second agreement commits Taiwan to contribute 1 million euros (US$1.29 million) to a Mongolia Cooperation Fund that will be used solely to help Mongolia develop private enterprises.

After signing the agreements, Taiwan, officially known as "Taipei China" to the bank, then formed a supervisory board with three other donors -- Japan, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. The board will meet twice a year to review past performance and determine new project priorities.
Tien is going to be succeeded by Lin Chun-yi, currently ROC ambassador to Gambia.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS ARRIVE IN TAIWAN TO WINTER

TEXT.P: Strong northeast trade winds have brought another flock of black-faced spoonbills from the northern Korean Peninsula to the Chiku wetlands in southern Taiwan to overwinter, local wild bird fans said Monday.

As of Monday, 682 of the endangered wading birds had arrived at the wetlands located at the estuary of the Tsengwen River in Tainan County, said a spokesman for the Happy Family, which groups wild bird fans to promote wildlife conservation.

"The number is already close to the record set Dec. 3, 2003, when 705 black-faced spoonbills were counted wintering at the Chiku sanctuary, " the spokesman said, adding that more of the rare bird species are expected to arrive in the coming weeks as the weather gets colder.
According to a global survey conducted in January of this year, only 1,206 black-faced spoonbills remain in the world.

The wading birds usually begin arriving in Taiwan to spend the winter after the Mid-Autumn Festival. They then start heading back north to their breeding grounds between March and April the following year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WHIP WANTS 'HAPPIER' NATIONAL ANTHEM

TEXT.P: The party whip of the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday that he would like to see a "happier and lighter" Republic of China national anthem.

Lee Chun-yi said that the current national anthem -- which was in fact also the party anthem of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -- was composed nearly 80 years ago, and that it is "heavy" both in terms of tune and lyrics.

Even James Soong, former KMT secretary-general and current chairman of the KMT-allied opposition People First Party, has on at least one occasion criticized the national anthem as confusing, saying that the first and second lines mix the nation and the KMT, according to Lee.

The anthem first declares the "Three Principles of the People" to be the foundation of the party and the nation, and then calls upon the party members to be brave, earnest and unrelenting in striving to fulfill the nation's goals.

Since there is no law yet to regulate the national anthem at the moment, Lee said he would be very pleased to see all the parties from across Taiwan's political spectrum come together to consult one another on whether and how to revise the national anthem to make it more cheerful and light-hearted.

The words of the ROC national anthem were first delivered as an exhortation at the opening of the Whampoa Military Academy on June 16, 1924, by Dr. Sun Yat-sen. This exhortation was designated as the KMT's party song in 1928, after which the KMT then solicited contributions from the public for a tune to fit the words. The melody submitted by Cheng Mao-yun was chosen from among 139 contenders.

The tune, with the Whampoa exhortation, was temporarily adopted as the ROC national anthem in the late 1920s before being officially announced as the national anthem in 1937. The piece was honored as the world's best national anthem at the 1936 Berlin Olympics.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LOGO SHOULD CHANGE, NOT SYMBOL OF THE ROC: CABINET SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The government has no plans to change the nation's official national emblem, Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Monday.

Chen Chi-mai confirmed, however, that the Executive Yuan will soon start working to have the National Emblem Law revised in response to President Chen Shui-bian's recent remarks that the party emblem of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is "too close" to the national emblem on the ROC national flag and that he would like to have the KMT change its party emblem to avoid confusion.

Clarifying President Chen's position, Chen Chi-mai stressed that the government is not going to change the national emblem. Instead, the government will see to it that the National Emblem Law is amended in three months to pave the way for the government to legally require the KMT to change its party emblem.
Chen Chi-mai added that the revised National Emblem Law will be much clearer than the existing one and will have exact punishments set out for violators.

According to regulations of the National Emblem Law, the ROC national flag belongs to the government of the Republic of China and it should not be used "commercially" by any other groups, Chen Chi-mai said.

He also pointed to the Trademark Law as stipulating that the national flag, national emblem or any pattern that is closely similar to the two cannot be used as logos or trademarks of any organization. Based on this, he said, the KMT has been using its logo illegally.
Chen Chi-mai said the Executive Yuan is soliciting opinions and suggestions from the public to facilitate the amendment to the National Emblem Law.
