DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT RETORTS KMT HEAD'S CALL FOR REFERENDUM ON INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: Taiwan is already a sovereign, independent country so there is no need to hold a referendum on independence, only on the question unification with China, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Monday.
Chen Chi-mai was responding to a call by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan in a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting Saturday.

Lien said the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has repeatedly advocated "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait, an independent Taiwan and the establishment of a nation" to try to fool the people of Taiwan and he tried to call the DPP's bluff by daring President Chen Shui-bian to propose a referendum on Taiwan independence, which could be held alongside the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

President Chen responded during a stumping trip for DPP legislative candidates that night by saying that he would not fall for Lien's ploy, adding that everyone knows that he sticks to his "five noes" pledge -- which includes no referendum on independence or unification.

Spokesman Chen noted that President Chen has stressed on several occasions that Taiwan is already a sovereign, independent country and its name is the Republic of China. Unless the nation or its status quo is threatened by foreign countries or its sovereignty is at risk of being changed, then the president will invoke Article 17 of the Referendum Law concerning a "defensive referendum."
Chen also reminded Lien that according to the Referendum Law that cleared the opposition-dominated legislature last November, there is no possibility of holding a referendum on Taiwan independence.

He said that Article two of the Referendum Law stipulates that issues concerning changing the name and geographic boundaries of the nation involve constitutional revisions and cannot be included in a referendum.
"Lien doesn't even understand the law he helped clear the legislature, " Spokesman Chen said, adding that he "felt sorry for him."
Another DPP official also criticized Lien for being too reckless as a party chief.

Cheng Wen-tsang, director of the DPP's Department of Culture and Information, said that according to the Referendum Law, the formation of a referendum topic must take at least 102 days, and that Lien's proposal that a referendum be held simultaneously with the legislative elections next month is simply to take national security as "horseplay."

Cheng noted that the DPP passed a resolution on Taiwan's future in 1999, which clearly stated that Taiwan is a sovereign, independent county, and that its name is the Republic of China according to the Constitution, and any changes to the status quo must have the consent of the 23 million people on Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Major creditors in accord to waive 80% of Iraq debt.
The world's leading industrial nations agreed Sunday to cancel 80 percent of the nearly US$39 billion debt owed them by Iraq, a critical step in rebuilding the country's devastated economy and an important precedent for its other creditors to follow. The agreement puts pressure on Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Iraq's other Middle Eastern neighbors to forgive obligations owed them, including billions in reparations Iraq owes from the Persian Gulf war in 1991.
Wall Street Journal: A brutal killing opens Dutch eyes to threat of terror.
On Friday a group of left-wing aldermen from Amsterdam's heavily Muslim western districts met to discuss an issue previously left to the police: how to root out Islamic terrorists in their neighborhoods. The socialist aldermen's resolve follows the murder early this month of Dutch filmmaker Theo van Gogh, who was shot, stabbed and slashed across the throat by a suspected Islamic radical. The killing set off a wave of attacks on mosques. It also triggered a surprising shift in a country where, like elsewhere across much of Western Europe, America's "war on terror" has often been derided as too crude and too brutal.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Yugansk Goes on the Block for $8.6 Bln.
Yukos' main production unit, Yuganskneftegaz, will be sold at auction with a starting price of $8.65 billion, confirming investors' worst fears that the country's biggest oil exporter will be carved up amid massive new tax claims.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market nose-dived Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved down 221 points to close at 5,835, with 44,598 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January dropped 229 points to finish at 5,835, with 127 contract transactions, while March futures decreased 187 points to close at 5,855, with 20 contracts traded. June futures moved down 195 points to finish at 5,835, with 17 contract transactions, while September futures dropped 215 points to close at 5,765, with 19 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,056 points for December, 6,064 points for January, 6,042 points for March, 6,030 points for June and 5,980 points for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

December TE futures dropped 11.45 points to close at 217, with 7,019 contracts changing hands, while January TE futures moved down 10.85 points to finish at 217, with 50 contract transactions. March TE futures decreased 6.75 points to close at 221.5, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

December TF futures moved down 42.4 points to finish at 1,010.6, with 11,911 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures dropped 39.2 points to close at 1,011, with 92 contracts traded. March TF futures decreased 22.8 points to finish at 1,026, with six contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, losing NT$0.075 to close at NT$32.479.
A total of US$837 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$32.453 and was traded between NT$32.355 and NT$32.490.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Affected by hikes in international oil prices, falls in share prices of the U.S. stock market and the continued appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar, shares prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) opened low and closed even lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 188.13 points to close at 5,838.42.

The bourse opened at 5,962.32 points and fluctuated between 5,970.33 and 5,838.42 during trading. A total of 2.99 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$68.13 billion (US$2.12 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most by 3.9 percent, followed by banking and financial issues by 3.5 percent, construction stocks by 2.4 percent, cement and textile issues by 1.6 percent, foodstuff shares by 1.5 percent, plastics and chemicals issues by 1.3 percent, and paper and pulp issues by 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 615 to 73, with 83 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: POOR DIET FOUND TO BE COMMON PROBLEM OF YOUNG STUDENTS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: A new survey of nutrition in Taiwan released Monday has found that elementary school students lack several basics to provide a balanced diet.
The Department of Health commissioned Academia Sinica, the nation's highest research institute, to conduct the survey on the nation's nutrition situation and its changes between 1998 and 2002.
The survey on students aged 6-12 found that boys took in more calories and other nutrients (except for vitamin C) than girls.

About half of the students ate too much fat, while over 60 percent of fourth, fifth and sixth grade girls were deficient in iron as recommended by the Dietary Reference Intakes, and that they took in too much cholesterol and salt.
The health department suggested that parents should choose appropriate snacks and beverages for their children, while avoiding those that have too much fat, sugar or salt.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SHOULD RETURN NATIONAL SYMBOL TO THE NATION: DPP

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official charged the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Monday with being purposefully ambiguous with the KMT party logo and the national symbol of the Republic of China.
Cheng Wen-tsang, top DPP official in charge of publicity, urged the KMT to return the national symbol to the nation and change the opposition party's logo to avoid confusion.

Cheng repeated President Chen Shui-bian's recent remarks that the KMT party logo is "too close" to the national emblem on the ROC national flag and that he would like to have the KMT change its party logo to allow the country to have a clear symbol.

He quoted Chen as urging the KMT Sunday evening to change its party emblem within three months. Otherwise, he said, the government will move to have the National Emblem Law revised to make it illegal for any political party, private organization or business group to use the national symbol commercially. The revision will say that the symbol is national property and only the government has the legal right to its use.

He added that President Chen will never seek to change the ROC's national symbol nor its flag since the president stands behind his May 20, 2000 inaugural speech where he said that so long as mainland China has no intention of using force against Taiwan, his administration will uphold the "five noes" policy.

The "five noes" refers to no declaration of Taiwan independence, no changes to the ROC's national title, no inclusion of the controversial "special state-to-state relationship" concept into the ROC's Constitution, no referendum on the issue of independence or unification, and no abolition of the ROC's existing National Unification Guidelines and National Unification Council.

Some other officials from the DPP headquarters commented Monday that the KMT is now caught in a dilemma, which, they claimed, is a result of a longstanding problem with differentiating between the KMT and the nation.

In response to President Chen's demand that the KMT change its party logo in three months, KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said Monday that the president does not need to wait three months, because "we are not changing anything."

Chang said that the KMT party emblem is a form of property with history and is protected by the Constitution. "Only by showing respects to history, the law and the opposition can the Republic of China prove itself to be a nation of law and order," Chang argued.
Chang called for President Chen not to use the state apparatus to suppress the opposition and stop using destructive rhetoric during the current election campaign.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan dismissed the president's demand as "narrow-minded" and not worth responding to.
Legislative caucus members of the opposition People First Party called on President Chen to stop trying to put blinkers on the nation with such ideological nonsense.

Having failed to build Taiwan into a better nation over the past four years, Chen has no other option to drum up support for the DPP legislative candidates but to play both ends against the middle to deepen the rift between the ruling and opposition parties, including the accusation of a "soft coup," they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN DECORATES HAVEL FOR CONTRIBUTIONS TO BILATERAL TIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian decorated visiting former Czech Republic President Vaclav Havel with the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon Monday in recognition of his contributions to the promotion of relations between the two countries.
Praising Havel as a world-class literary figure, thinker and political leader as well as an important dissident, Chen said he was honored to meet Havel in person.

As Havel accidentally slipped in his hotel room in Taipei and broke his leg two days ago, he sat in a wheelchair during the decoration ceremony. Chen apologized for the accident and asked Havel to take care.

Chen expressed his admiration for Havel's versatile career achievements. Havel played a pivotal role in his country's "velvet revolution" of 1989. He used his literary and theatrical creations to kindle and keep the flame of democracy burning amidst a storm of repression and autocracy during communist rule. He eventually led his country to break the shackles of communist suppression and move toward democracy. During his 12-year presidency, he continued working hard to consolidate the Czech Republic's democratic system as well as promote human rights and social justice, earning wide respect and admiration from his fellow countrymen.

Chen also thanked Havel for his efforts at promoting high-level exchanges between the two countries. During Havel's presidency, his wife visited Taiwan. The wife of the then-Czech Republic prime minister, who is now the country's president, also has been to Taiwan. Meanwhile, former ROC President Lee Teng-hui, former Vice President Lien Chan and incumbent first lady Wu Shu-jen all have visited Prague.

Moreover, Chen said, the 23 million Taiwan people were grateful for Havel's explicit support for Taiwan's participation in the United Nations while addressing a ceremony marking the U.N.'s 50th founding anniversary in 1995.

Chen said he himself almost succeeded in making a visit to the Czech Republic in 2002. Even though he eventually failed, Chen said he still appreciated Havel's and the Czech Republic government's support for Taiwan's cause.

Personally, Chen said he admires many of Havel's convictions and concepts, particularly those regarding human rights, such as that human rights take precedence over national sovereignty and nations are formed by people whom Havel said were created by god.

Havel, accompanied by his wife, doctors and close aides, arrived in Taipei Friday for his first-ever visit to Taiwan at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian and the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD).
In consideration of his health, TFD officials said Havel's itinerary is not a busy one so that he can have enough time to rest. Smoking resulted in Havel having to have a lung removed.
Havel was originally scheduled to visited the National Palace Museum and an aboriginal culture museum Sunday, but the visits were canceled due to his leg problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANCIENT CONGO ARTIFACTS EXHIBITION TO OPEN NOV. 23

TEXT.P: The four-month Ancient Congo Artifacts Exhibition (ACAE) will open simultaneously Tuesday at the National Museum of History in Taipei and the National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts in Taichung, organizers said Monday.

The display will include over 360 Congolese artifacts ranging from the 15th to the 20th Century. Congolese history will also be discussed from the points of view of religion and ritual, social class and the marital system.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S APEC SUMMIT ATTENDANCE HINGES ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Santiago, Nov. 21 (CNA) (By Kuan Chung-wei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's attendance at the annual informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum will hinge on relations across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan's foremost scholar said in Santiago Sunday.

Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, who arrived in the Chilean capital Thursday to attend the 2004 APEC summit on behalf of Chen, made the remarks at a news conference held at the end of the two-day meeting.

Because of Beijing's opposition, Taiwan's top leader has been barred from attending the annual APEC summit in person and has to name a proxy to attend instead. This is the third consecutive year that Lee has attended the event on Chen's behalf.

If cross-strait relations were to improve, Lee said, it would be possible for Chen to attend the annual APEC summit in person. "I still look forward to seeing that scenario happen, " Lee said, adding that if cross-strait ties remain deadlocked, the possibility of Chen attending the APEC event would remain slim.

Lee said he had brief talks with mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao earlier in the day. He described the atmosphere of their talks as amicable, but added that their talks did not touch on cross-strait issues.

"As we had only limited time, we couldn't address any complicated topic. Moreover, cross-strait ties are not an APEC theme, " Lee said, adding that their talks focused on issues related to energy resources and economic development.

Lee said that although he did not convey a goodwill message from Chen to Hu during their face-to-face talks, he passed Chen's message on to the mainland leader indirectly during a news conference held upon his arrival in Santiago. On that occasion, Lee said if he had an opportunity to talk with Hu during the APEC summit, he would convey Chen's goodwill and invite the top mainland cross-strait negotiator, Wang Daohan, to visit Taiwan on the basis of the 1992 cross-strait meetings in Hong Kong and a 1993 meeting in Singapore.
A mainland official issued a statement after the Lee-Hu talks, confirming that Hu had a brief meeting with Lee.

"What happened was that at the APEC meeting, Lee Yuan-tseh, the representative from Taiwan, came to President Hu and they did have a brief conversation, " mainland Foreign Ministry spokesman Kong Quan told journalists.

"The core element of their conversation was that Hu emphasized that the one China principle must be adhered to. So if Lee Yuan-tseh called the meeting cordial, it must be because they discussed the one China principle," Kong claimed.
During Lee's news conference, Lee also said he met with U.S. President George W. Bush on several occasions on the last day of the summit.

Bush was very friendly, Lee said, adding that the American president clearly said he hopes to see peaceful development on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and would not like to see any cross-strait conflict.

Lee said he is convinced that both sides of the Taiwan Strait are oblidged to work together for cross-strait peace and stability. "Both sides should defuse misunderstanding and forge constructive peaceful interactions in order to contribute to world peace and prosperity," he added.

Meanwhile, Lee said he also had conversations with Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, during which Koizumi said Japan has agreed to grant visa-free privileges to visitors from Taiwan. Koizumi was also quoted as having told Lee that Taiwan and Japan should boost cultural and technological exchanges.

Although the curtain has already fallen on the APEC summit, Lee's work has not yet concluded. He has been invited to deliver a speech on the challenges of the 21st Century at the National Science Academy of Chile Monday. After the speech, Lee will depart for home via San Francisco.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL SUPERVISORY COMMISSION HEAD ATTENDS WTO MEETING

TEXT.P: Kung Chao-sheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission is currently attending a World Trade Organization Committee on Trade in Financial Services meeting.

Kung is expected to deliver a speech on financial services at the meeting. He left for Switzerland Nov. 19, keeping a low profile to avoid a protest by mainland China, and will report on the results of the meeting after his return Nov. 28.
Since assuming his post July 1, Kung has advocated a new supervisory culture based on service, as well as internationalization and reaching out to the international community.

He attended a Financial Services Roundtable in Washington in late September and an international seminar on the financial services supervisory mechanism, accounting, auditing and trading systems in New York in late October.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLIANCE CALLS FOR NEW LAW TARGETING SEXUAL HARASSMENT PREVENTION

TEXT.P: An alliance said on Monday that it wants a new law targeting sexual harassment prevention, but the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said that it would create confusion and would overlap current regulations and stretch existing resources.

The alliance is backing the revision of two bills, one on domestic violence, and another on violent serial criminals. A third bill advocated by the alliance is one regarding sexual harassment, which has yet to be passed into law.
The alliance said more work has to be done to revise or pass legislation to protect people from sex crimes, including sexual harassment.

The alliance is comprised of 11 civic groups, including the Taiwan Association for the Treatment of Domestic Violence and Sexual Offence, the Garden of Hope Foundation and the Modern Women's Foundation.

The alliance also unveiled the results of an online survey to show that most victims of sexual harassment tend to be passive or accept the unpleasant feelings of sexual harassment, and that fewer people are actively seeking assistance.

Chi Huei-jung, executive director of the Garden of Hope Foundation, said that 30.03 percent of respondents to the survey said that they would complain to their relatives or colleagues after being sexually harassed, while 24.9 percent would swear at the perpetrators, with about 24 percent saying that they would just ignore the action or "swallow their pride" and do nothing.
Answering for situations that occurred over the past two years, 51 percent received unwanted pornographic e-mails and 45 percent were verbally harassed.

Kao Huei-hsien, a judge and member of the alliance, said that the draft sexual harassment prevention bill has obtained support from half of the members of a legislative committee and discussions have been completed.

But Kao noted that the MOI has said that it lacks the manpower and money and is opposed to the idea of the central and local governments setting up sexual harassment prevention operations and that the MOI is also opposed to a mediation system, and has said that a separate law would overlap with bills concerning equal gender working rights and equal education rights.
But Kao pointed out that the victims of sexual harassment often do not want to fight with their perpetrators in court, and a mediation system could be an alternative.

Kao also said the alliance advocates that all agencies shoulder the responsibility for compensation, saying that the legislation aims to prod the agencies to do their share to prevent and discipline the perpetrators so that the victims will not have to fight alone.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS LEADER SUGGESTS ASIAN BOND MARKET

TEXT.P: Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinatrust Group, suggested Saturday that an Asian bond market should be established. He was speaking at a meeting of business leaders in Santiago, Chile.

Koo told the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Business Advisory Council (ABAC) , which was held between Friday and Saturday, that a joint bond market in Asia would better prepare the countries in the region to prevent or respond to a financial crisis such as the one in 1997.
Koo made his suggestion while delivering a speech on good governance and its challenges.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO BEGINS CAMPAIGN AGAINST PIRACY, PORNOGRAPHY, VIOLENCE

TEXT.P: Pirated video and audio products accounted for 42 percent of all video and audio products sold in Taiwan last year, resulted in a 20 percent decrease per year in the total value of legitimate products, Lin Chia-lung, chief of the Government Information Office claimed Monday.

Speaking at the start of a public campaign against pornography, violence and piracy, Lin said piracy has taken a toll on the country's trade with the United States, while the government's enforcement of the law regarding intellectual property rights has often been raised in Taiwan's trade talks with the United States.
As to violence and pornography, Lin said his office will begin rating publications and videos from Dec. 1, as well as rating Web sites, to prevent children from being exposed to them.
As a gesture to show the government's determination to crack down on pirated audio and video products, Lin set fire to 65,980 pirated discs and 3,412 pirated video tapes.

DOC.HEADLINE: CZECH OFFICIAL PRAISES TAIWAN'S COURAGE TO 'WALK ITS OWN ROAD'

TEXT.P: Former Czech Republic President Vaclav Havel praised Taiwan's courage in "walking its own road" Monday in the first public speech delivered since his arrival in Taipei Friday for a six-day visit.
Havel, a poet and playwright-turned-politician, focused his speech at the National Library on the theme of globalization and democracy.
He told his audience that when he launched a pro-democracy campaign during his country's communist era, he never thought he would one day become president.

"I and my like-minded friends were not even sure whether we could succeed in overthrowing communist rule. We just listened to our consciences and said what we should say. With our efforts and international assistance, we finally made it. Our 'velvet revolution' of 1989 became part of the turbulent international changes of that time and I became the president of my country. This was a 'gift of destiny,'" Havel said.
In his speech, Havel said the fall of the Soviet Union spelled an end to the bi-polar world political landscape. Nowadays, he said, the world has yet to develop a new world order.
During his 12-year presidency until February 2003, Havel said he visited 50 countries around the world.

"During overseas trips, when I woke up in the morning, I often did not know where I was because the decor of hotels around the world was almost the same. But this was just superficial. Beneath the surface, enormous differences exist in cultures, histories, traditions, languages and customs and lifestyles in different countries and areas around the world," Havel said.
In his view, Havel said, people from different civilizations should respect one another.

"World civilization requires all countries around the world to mutually respect their own traditions and lifestyles. All countries should get along peacefully on the basis of democracy and human rights," Havel said.
He further said Taiwan has set a good example in its national development. "Brave Taiwan people have been firm in taking their own road and upholding their own concepts and values," he added.

Asked whether Taiwan should change its military conscription system, Havel said the Czech Republic phased out its mandatory military service system just a year ago. In addition to establishing a democratic society, Havel said, a country must also have the ability to safeguard its security, freedom and human rights.

President Chen Shui-bian decorated Havel with the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon earlier in the day in recognition of his contributions to the promotion of relations between Taiwan and the Czech Republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT THANKS TAIWAN FOR TREATING FILIPINO WORKERS WELL
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Nov. 22 (CNA) (By Emerson T. Lim and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Philippine President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo expressed appreciation to Taiwan during the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Santiago, Chile, for treating the 90,000 Filipino laborers in Taiwan well, a Philippine presidential spokesman said Monday.

Igamacio Bunye said that before the summit began, there were various bilateral meetings between the APEC members in which Macapagal-Arroyo met with Lee Yuan-tseh, president of Academia Sinica and the leader of the Republic of China delegation, for a 15-minute closed-door meeting.
The two did not touch on political issues and did not violate the Philippines' "one China" policy that recognizes Beijing as the sole ruler of China, Bunye said.

He said that Macapagal-Arroyo took the opportunity to thank Taiwan for taking care of the Filipino workers there, while Lee solicited Manila to support Taiwan's proposal to set up a communicable disease prevention center.
They also discussed the establishment of an APEC Digital Opportunities Center, in the hope that all APEC members "will become a digital village like Taiwan," Bunye added.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE DROPS TO 40-MONTH LOW: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's jobless rate dropped to 4.31 percent in October, the lowest since May 2001, when the unemployment rate was 4.22 percent, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Monday.

The October jobless rate was lower than Hong Kong's 6.7 percent and Japan's 4.6 percent, DGBAS officials said, adding that the government's goal of bringing this year's average unemployment rate down to 4.5 percent can be realized smoothly.
Compared with September, the October jobless rate fell 0.19 percent and also marked a 0.61 percent decline from the year-earlier level.

Meanwhile, the jobless rate among those who have received tertiary education dropped to 4.24 percent in October, down 0.14 percent and 0.18 percent from September and the year-earlier level, respectively.
In terms of age, the jobless rate stood at a high of 10.93 percent among those aged between 15 and 24, the highest rate among the various age groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: EMBLEMS OF POLICE, FIREFIGHTERS SHOULD BE `CORRECTED': OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: One day after President Chen Shui-bian pointed out the similarity between the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) emblem and the national emblem, Vice Minister of the Interior Lee Chin-yung said Monday that the police and firefighters who "falsely" incorporated the KMT emblem into their emblems should make "corrections."
Lee said the emblems of police and firefighters have incorporated the national emblem, which has a bigger blue rim but is otherwise similar in figure to the KMT emblem.
Unfortunately, Lee said, the contractors who provided the uniforms to the police and firefighters "mistook" the KMT emblem for the national emblem and used it in the uniforms.
The Ministry of the Interior has urged the National Police Administration and the National Fire Administration to "correct this mistake," Lee said.

Chen raised the issue the previous day while stumping for legislative candidates of his Democratic Progressive Party. He accused the KMT of patterning the national emblem on its party emblem in the belief that the party would control the country forever.
Chen threatened to change the national emblem after the legislative election unless the KMT drops its emblem by itself.
A similar issue applies to the Ministry of National Defense, which also uses the national emblem as the military emblem.
An anonymous defense officer said, however, that the military will change its emblem as long as the national emblem is changed, which falls under the authority of the MOI.

DOC.HEADLINE: VANUATU PRIME MINISTER REAFFIRMS RELATIONS WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Vanuatu Prime Minister Serge Vohor issued a statement Monday to reaffirm that the diplomatic relations established between the South Pacific island state and the Republic of China earlier this month remain intact, according to a report from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Vohor said in the statement that the Union of Moderate Parties (UMP) he leads won a Nov. 9 provincial election, showing that most of the Vanuatu people support the establishment of diplomatic relations with Taiwan in the interest of enhancing their own welfare and the long-term economic development of the nation.
Vohor also called attention to the fact that there is no law in Vanuatu that says the establishment of diplomatic relations must receive the consent of the Cabinet.

MOFA officials said Vohor will take the opportunity of a special session of Vanuatu's parliament to urge political leaders to work for the rapid and sustainable development of the nation's economy. To reach that goal, Vanuatu must fully carry out the establishment of diplomatic relations with the ROC, the statement says.
MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said the Vanuatu parliament opened that day but did not discuss Vanuatu's ties with Taiwan.
He said that Vohor's UMP controls 36 of the 52 seats in the parliament and that the prime minister is confident that the establishment of diplomatic ties will be passed by the parliament.

Vohor and ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen signed a joint communique to establish diplomatic relations Nov. 3, making the South Pacific island state the 27th ally of the ROC, despite reports that mainland China has continued to try to woo the country away from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG WELCOMES KIWANIS INTERNATIONAL'S ASIA-PACIFIC CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung welcomes the Kiwanis International's 2006 Asia-Pacific Conference and will give necessary assistance to the organizers of the meeting, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said Monday.
In a meeting with Kiwanis International President Case van Kleef at Kaohsiung City Hall, Hsieh praised the international charity organization for its dedication to social welfare and services.
He also announced that the city will earmark NT$2 million (US$61,500) to help finance the gathering.

Kaohsiung will become a "wireless e-city" next year, when all its citizens will be able to enjoy the convenience of wireless Internet access, while an integrated monitoring system for social order, traffic and fire will be set up, Hsieh went on.
He assured his guest that the participants of the Kiwanis International's 2006 Asia-Pacific Conference will experience a friendly, convenient and safe visit to the southern port city.
Van Kleef is in Taiwan to inspect progress in preparations for the conference. He was received by President Chen Shui-bian last Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MATSU AIRPORT TO BE INCLUDED IN CROSS-STRAIT DIRECT LINKS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Monday that after the completion of a new terminal building at Peikan Airport on the island of Matsu, it will be included in direct transportation links with mainland China.
Yu made the remarks when he inspected the construction of the new terminal building on the outlying island.
He said that once the airport is included in the direct shipping links with the mainland, it will help the diversification of the island's development.
Currently, only one harbor on Kinmen and Fuao Harbor in Matsu are used as direct shipping points with the mainland's Fujian Province.

The premier noted that the government has already provided subsidies of nearly NT$3 billion (US$92.3 million) for the Nankan airport, which was inaugurated in January 2003, while the construction at Peikan airport further shows that the government attaches great importance to Matsu's development.

President Chen Shui-bian garnered more than 200 ballots on Matsu in this year's presidential election, or almost three times the number he got in the previous election in 2000, although the premier said the government's attention to local development is not weighed by ballots.

The premier said that due to the efforts and cooperation of the Civil Aeronautics Administration and Matsu county government, the new terminal will be completed by the end of the year as scheduled and is scheduled to be inaugurated at the Chinese New Year.
It is expected to greatly benefit Matsu's outbound traffic and tourism, the premier added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR NOV. 23 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, Nov. 23:
10: 00, The Ministry of National Defense will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
10: 00, The New Party will hold a news conference at the party's headquarters.
10: 30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
11: 00, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will be interviewed by the Voice of Germany at the Executive Yuan.
13: 00, The Industrial Development Bureau, the Institute for Information Industry and Macromedia will sign a memorandum of understanding on cooperation at the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
13: 30, The ruling Democratic Progressive Party will hold its Central Standing Committee meeting at the party's headquarters.
16: 00, The Ministry of Economic Affairs will issue a report on export orders received in October at the ministry's headquarters.
16: 00, The Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.
16: 00, The Institute of Transportation will hold a news conference at the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
16:30, The Department of Customs Administration will hold a news conference at the Ministry of Finance.
19:00, The 2004 Golden Bell Awards ceremony will open at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG EXPORT PROCESSING ZONE APPROVES 5 INVESTMENT PROJECTS

TEXT.P: The Economic Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs approved five new investment and capital-added projects in October for the Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone, EPZA officials said Monday.

The projects, which are worth about NT$255 million (US$7.84 million) , are focused on the technological industries that have become the main sector of the export-oriented industrial complex, the officials noted.
The investment projects also show foreign and domestic investor confidence in Taiwan's economic prospects, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAN-SEPT. SALARY DECREASES BY 0.46%

TEXT.P: The average salary in real-terms in the first nine months of this year has decreased by 0.46 percent to NT$34,929 (US$1,073) because the inflation rate has grown much more quickly than the increase of salaries, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan.

In September alone, the average salary was NT$40,439 (US$1,243), which is 2.35 percent less than the previous month and 1.14 percent less than the corresponding period of last year, according to statistics released by the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT SPELLS OUT CRITERIA FOR TOP-LEVEL UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: Universities have to shift their focus from teaching to research and step up exchanges with foreign universities if they want to upgrade their ranks to the top level in the world, National Cheng Kung University President Kao Chiang said in Tainan City Monday.

Presiding over the opening of a two-day forum of university heads in Taiwan and the mainland China, Kao said the function of universities has tipped from teaching toward research, witnessed by the emergence of many research-oriented universities around the world.

Taiwan, he said, is moving in this direction, with the Ministry of Education setting aside NT$50 billion (US$1.53 billion) over five years to merge several research-oriented universities into one in the hope that can become one of the world's top universities, Kao said.
A top-level university should also be able to commercialize the results of its research and attract foreign students, which is vital for a good university.

The publication of articles about new discoveries, new knowledge and new technology in well-known periodicals, and the winning of international prizes such as the Nobel Prize are also vital indications of a top level university, Kao said.
The forum has attracted 48 university chiefs from Taiwan and the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TIES NOT RAISED IN TALKS WITH HU: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Santiago, Nov. 22 (CNA) (By Kuan Chung-wei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh reiterated in Santiago, Chile Monday that his talks with mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao a day earlier did not touch on cross-Taiwan Strait issues.

Lee, who attended the just-concluded informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum on behalf of ROC President Chen Shui-bian, was responding to a mainland official's remarks that Hu had mentioned Beijing's cherished "one China" principle in his brief talks with Lee on the sidelines of the APEC summit.
Lee stressed that he didn't bring up any issues regarding cross-strait relations in his short meeting with Hu because Taiwan-mainland China ties were not one of the APEC themes.
"My conversation with Hu mainly focused on the APEC's core agenda, including energy supply and regional economic development, " Lee said.

This was the third consecutive year that Lee represented President Chen at the annual APEC summit. Lee recalled that when he encountered former mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin on the sidelines of the APEC summit three years ago, Jiang immediately talked about Beijing's "one China" principle as a prerequisite for resumption of cross-strait dialogue.
"It was not unexpected that Beijing would seize every opportunity to mention the 'one China' principle, " Lee said, adding that "the mainland official's statement came as no surprise to me."
Beijing's "one China" principle downgrades Taiwan to a province under the its jurisdiction -- a stance unacceptable to the Republic of China on Taiwan.
Because of Beijing's opposition, Taiwan's head of state has been barred from attending the annual APEC summit in person and has had to name a proxy to attend instead.

APEC groups 21 Asia-Pacific economies -- Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.
Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, delivered a speech on "The Challenges of the 21st Century" at the National Science Academy of Chile Monday.

In his speech, Lee said excessive consumption of fossil fuels has resulted in serious damage to the natural environment. In the new century, Lee said, humankind should develop new approaches that can ensure the co-existence of Mother Nature and sustainable economic development.

On globalization, Lee said differences among different cultures and nations should be respected in the process of globalization. "We should educate a new generation of responsible Global Village citizens," he added.
Dealing with the continued growth in the global population and the widening gap between developed and underdeveloped countries are also major challenges for the 21st century.
Lee is scheduled to depart Chile for home via San Francisco Monday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PLAN TO ANNOUNCE MERGER AT KMT ANNIVERSARY CANCELED

TEXT.P: Opposition "pan-blue alliance" plans to announce a merger of the Kuomintang (KMT) and its two splinter parties at the KMT's 110th founding anniversary celebrations on Wednesday in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan have been canceled, party sources said Tuesday.

The sources said that it was originally arranged to have KMT Chairman Lien Chan, New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong announce the merger of the three parties at the anniversary celebrations so as to boost the chances of the "pan-blue alliance's" legislative candidates in the run-up to the Dec. 11 elections.
A PFP spokesman has confirmed that Soong will not be present at the anniversary celebrations.

KMT Chairman Lien, Vice Chairmen Wu Po-hsiung, Wang Jin-pyng and Ma Ying-jeou, as well as KMT mayors and magistrates in northern Taiwan will all take part in the activity with the party's legislative candidates to celebrate the party's anniversary and to drum up support ahead of the elections.
Lien will deliver a speech titled "Taiwan Will Find its Way by Following the Right Path" at the end of the celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA DISMISSES REPORT ABOUT MISAPPROPRIATION OF ROC AID TO PALAU

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Tuesday dismissed a media report claiming that the Republic of China's aid to the West Pacific island nation of Palau has been misappropriated.
Lee Chuan-tung, deputy director of the MOFA's East Asian and Pacific Affairs Department, said the report by a local weekly was groundless and incorrect.
According to the report, Taiwan companies were barred from bidding for Taiwan-financed infrastructure construction projects in Palau, and the quality of those construction projects were worrisome.

Lee said tenders for all Taiwan-donated infrastructure construction projects in Palau have been carried out with the consent of the Palauan government and in compliance with the country's legal procedures.
"The report about excluding prospective Taiwan contractors' participation in bidding and the poor quality of the construction projects was not true," Lee stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CONFIRMS FORMER MINISTER'S INSTRUCTIONS ON NATIONAL EMBLEM ISSUE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) confirmed Tuesday that the ministry did instruct its overseas missions four years ago about the principle to be used in displaying the national emblem.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said that according to the principle, the Republic of China flag and emblem are to be used in countries with which the ROC maintains diplomatic relations, while pragmatism is to be pursued in countries with which the ROC does not maintain formal ties. He said the principle is based on pragmatic needs and to avoid any unnecessary confusion.

Lu made the remarks amid media reports that former Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao sent a message in November 2000 to overseas missions instructing them to drop the use of the national emblem as the official logo and to replace it with the ROC flag on official invitations, menus, name cards, seating cards, and letter paper in countries with which the ROC maintains formal diplomatic ties, and to use the plum blossom -- the national flower of the ROC -- in other countries.
Lu confirmed that the MOFA did send such a message.

Lo Chih-cheng, former director of the MOFA's Research and Planning Board, said at the time that the change in policy was made mainly because the national emblem is too similar to the opposition Kuomintang's emblem and could create unnecessary misunderstanding.

Meanwhile, a military spokesman noted that the emblem on the uniforms of servicemen is the national emblem, adding that the question of whether this should be changed is for the Ministry of the Interior to decide.

Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng, spokesman of the Ministry of National Defense (MND) , said that the use of the national emblem on military uniforms is in accordance with the National Emblem Law. He said he would not comment on the current debate over the national emblem, saying that it is not an issue for the MND to decide.

Debate on the national emblem issue has intensified following President Chen Shui-bian's comments Sunday while stumping for Democratic Progressive Party candidates in the Dec. 11 elections. Chen pointed to the similarity between the national emblem and the KMT emblem and demanded that the party change its emblem within three months, or else he'll push for a revision to the National Emblem Law after the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE GROUP RELEASES 'CALENDAR FOR TAIWANESE'

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Union of Taiwanese Teachers (UTT) released a "2005 calendar for the Taiwanese" Tuesday that marks dates that are considered significant to Taiwan's history and omits a number of traditional national holidays.
The calendar features 13 works of art by local painter Chen Lai-hsing to display the various facets of Taiwan, according to the UTT.
UTT President Huang Jui-chiang said the calendar has done away with national holidays that have no relevance to Taiwan.
These include Youth Day, the Republic of China's National Day, the birth and death anniversaries of ROC founding father Sun Yat-sen and late President Chiang Kai-shek, Huang said.

Instead, the calendar highlights dates such as those commemorating Taiwanese men of letters such as Lai Ho and Yang Kuei, the 228 Peace Memorial Day and the death anniversary of Chen Nan-zon, a martyr for freedom of speech in Taiwan, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 12.68 points to close at 5,851.1.
The bourse opened at 5,856.71 and fluctuated between 5,872.88 and 5,790.27 during trading. A total of 2.59 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$59.64 billion (US$1.83 billion).
Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up at 0.4 percent and textile stocks and machinery and electronics shares both at 0.3 percent.

Three other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.4 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNCERTAIN IF E.U. WILL LIFT CHINA ARMS EMBARGO: ROC DIPLOMAT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 22 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: It is still too soon to tell if the European Union will lift its arms embargo against mainland China in view of the opposition from the majority of its member nations, Republic of China deputy representative to the United States Stanley Kao said Monday.

Kao was commenting on reports that Bernard Bot, minister of foreign affairs of the Netherlands, who presides over the Council of the European Union, had hinted that the E.U. might remove the 15-year-old ban on arms sales to China.
According to Kao, the majority of East European nations do not support lifting the embargo, and the Netherlands is also inclined to oppose the plan.
While Great Britain is not opposed to lifting the embargo under certain conditions, France and Germany are the two prime movers pressing the E.U. to end the ban, Kao pointed out.

By doing so, France is trying to expand the market for its ammunition industry and to curry favor with Beijing in an effort to create more business opportunities for French investors in China, Kao said.
The United States, on the other hand, is objecting to the proposal to lift the embargo and has recently sent officials to Europe to express its opposition, Kao noted.
Kao said the U.S. may use its influence to lobby European countries including Great Britain to block the plan, making it uncertain as to whether the bid by France and Germany will be successful.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December gained seven points to close at 5,842 with 33,263 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January moved down one point to finish at 5,834, with 35 contracts traded, while March futures gained eight points to finish at 5,842 with 67 contracts traded.
June futures lost two points to finish at 5,833 with 35 contracts traded, while September futures moved down six points to close at 5,759 with 35 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,835 for December, 5,835 for January, 5,834 for March, 5,835 for June and 5,765 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

December TE futures moved up 1.3 points to close at 218.3, with 4,259 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained one point to finish at 218, with 15 contract transactions. March TE futures lost 5.5 points to close at 216, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

December TF futures gained 4.4 points to finish at 1,015, with 5,818 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up three points to end at 1,014, with 34 contracts traded. September TF future gained one point to finish at 998.8, with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA FACTOR BEHIND CONFLICTING REPORTS ON VANUATU: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The "China factor" is to blame for sometimes contradictory reports about relations between the Republic of China and its latest diplomatic ally, Vanuatu, according to the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs Tuesday.
Foreign ministry spokesman Michel Lu was responding to reports that Taiwan's relations with Vanuatu are on the rocks and that the South Pacific island nation is being fickle in dealing with Taiwan.

"The foreign ministry is doing everything possible to solicit more maneuvering space for the nation, " Lu said, noting that the nation's diplomatic situation is very difficult because of mainland China's unceasing efforts to isolate Taiwan. "If there was no 'China factor' involved, people in Taiwan would most likely not have to be subjected to the twists and turns in the drama with Vanuatu, " Lu said.
Lu noted that the establishment of diplomatic relations between the two countries is based on common interests.

Vanuatu can support Taiwan's bid to participate in international organizations, while Taiwan's experience in manpower resource investment, the fishery industry, public health and training for high-tech jobs will be useful to Vanuatu.

He noted that between 1960 and 1975 the ROC received an average of US$100 million a year in aid from the United States, and that the achievements of Taiwan can be attributed to the concerted efforts of the people as well as the aid of the international community to the island.
The establishment of bilateral relations will enable Vanuatu to share Taiwan's experiences, and help bring Taiwan businessmen to Vanuatu, creating a win-win situation for both countries.

Lu said that since Vanuatu Prime Minister Serge Vohor and ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen signed a joint communique on the establishment of diplomatic relations in Taipei on Nov. 3, mainland China has tried its best to scuttle the relationship. The foreign ministry will continue to fight this diplomatic battle, Lu said.

Although there are differing stances within the Vanuatu government on the establishment of relations with Taiwan, Lu said that the foreign ministry will respect the wishes of the people of Vanuatu and will continue to help form a consensus.

Reports have said that Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kau Ying-mao and Lin Sung-huan, director of the ministry's department of East Asian and Pacific affairs, traveled to Vanuatu Nov. 20 to try to cement bilateral relations, but the foreign ministry has only said that it would not comment.

Lee Chuan-tung, vice director of the foreign ministry's department of East Asia and Pacific affairs, said Vanuatu's parliament called a special session Tuesday during which Vohor explained the nature of the Taiwan-Vanuatu diplomatic relations to the 46 members present to solicit their support.

New York Times: Premier Victor in Ukraine vote; abuses are seen.
Ukraine approached a political stalemate on Monday, as vote counts of the presidential runoff election indicated that Prime Minister Viktor F. With more than 99 percent of ballots counted, the government tally gave Mr. Yanukovich 49.42 percent of the vote to 46.7 percent for Viktor A.
