What happened at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq eight months after the United States 372nd Military Police Company of Army reservists shipped out to Iraq in March 2003 is now well known as a low point in U.S. military history. Naked detainees were stacked in pyramids, raped with phosphorescent light sticks and forced to masturbate in groups. While all that and more happened, American soldiers smiled for the cameras and signaled their approval with broad grins and hoisted thumbs.

DOC.HEADLINE: 21 ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS JOINTLY CELEBRATE 100TH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education held a joint celebration Tuesday for the 100th anniversary of 21 elementary schools founded between 1904 and July 1905 around Taiwan.
An exhibition of some of the old artifacts used by the schools was held at the ministry Tuesday, and they will also be on display at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall from Dec. 11-19.
The exhibit items included school flags of 100 years ago, students' manuscripts, school diaries, school bells, old photos and documents.

Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng said while schools used to celebrate their 100th anniversary individually, the ministry will hold joint celebrations every year starting this year to show its concern for the schools' precious historical heritage.
According to Tu, modern education was introduced by the Japanese colonial government into Taiwan in 1895, when two schools for the purpose were established on the island.
While seven more schools were built in 1896, 56 schools were set up in 1898, and 166 more were founded in 1904, Tu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI VOWS TO FOSTER ENVIRONMENT CONDUCIVE TO HAVING CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The government will do its utmost to foster an environment conducive to having children, Vice Minister of the Interior Chien Tai-lang said Tuesday.
Chien made the pledge at a public hearing in Taipei on how to encourage childbirth among young couples.
Quoting academic studies, Chien said the number of people aged 65 or older is likely to reach 39 percent of Taiwan's total population by 2051.
By then, Chien said, Taiwan's streets could be filled with silver-haired elderly people. Against this backdrop, he said, encouraging people to have children is the government's established policy.

Noting that having children is not only a personal duty but also agovernment responsibility, Chien said the government will cultivate an environment in which young couples are willing to have children.

According to statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) , Taiwan's childbirth rate ranked among the world's lowest in 2003, with 1.24 births per 1,000 persons. During the same year, the birth rate was 1.2 births per 1,000 persons in Italy, 1.5 in Sweden, 1.9 in France, and 2 in the United States.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development once estimated that Taiwan's population could begin to show negative growth after registering zero growth in 2022. Some scholars said if the government fails to adopt effective measures to encourage childbirth, Taiwan's future would be doomed.

In response, Chien said the MOI has been organizing public hearings in various parts of the island to collect opinions on how to address low childbirth rate issues. All the opinions expressed in the hearings will be included in the government's population policy white paper to be published next March, he added.

During Tuesday's hearing, some conference-goers said the present general social situation is too stressful to encourage young couples to raise children. They said the government should work to lower the unemployment rate first and resolve various social problems to reduce stress in people's daily lives. Only when the general social atmosphere is less stressful will young couples have a greater interest in having children, they added.

Some infertile couples suggested that the government offer financial subsidies or health insurance coverage for infertile couples' first child delivered by expensive artificial reproduction technology.

At the moment, the success rate of artificial insemination is only 12.39 percent and would-be mothers have to endure great pain in the process. Some attendees said they hope the government can invest more in upgrading artificial insemination technology as an alternate way to enhance the childbirth rate.

Some other participants said the government should beef up child care systems by providing better daycare services. Moreover, they said, the government should develop multifacted, well-rounded education systems for young children. In addition to academic study, they said, physical and aesthetic education should be given equal emphasis.

Meanwhile, many representatives complained that private corporate bosses fail to offer women employees child-rearing leave and flexible work schemes for monthers with young kids. The present workplace gender equality law stipulates that companies with 250 employees or more should allow their employees to enjoy child-rearing leave, but the law doesn't contain any penalties for violators. The present Labor Standards Law also doesn't require employers to allow young mothers to work more flexible schedules.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WILL HAVE PRIORITY RIGHT TO HOST 2006 ASIAN CITIES CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Taiwan will have priority right to host the annual conference of the Asian Network of Major Cities (ANMC) in 2006, according to a joint declaration issued at the conclusion of the Asian cities organization's conference Tuesday.

Participants in the conference, which was held in Jakarta, issued a six-point declaration that includes Taipei's priority right to host the annual conference in 2006. a Taipei city government spokesman said.
Yu Tze-hsiang said that all the ANMC members except Beijing signed the Jakarta declaration. The Beijing delegation did not sign because it is opposed to Taipei's hosting of the conference.
Yu noted that Taipei wanted to solicit the hosting right in 2005, but Beijing won the right "through its barbaric manner."

He said that due to the efforts of the Taipei delegation, 10 members of the ANMC issued an open letter at the end of the conference saying that they will not vie for the right to host the 2006 conference, which Yu said is "tantamount" to saying that Taipei has won the right.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who attended the conference for the first time in person, expressed regret at Beijing's attitude and expressed appreciation for the support of the other members, Yu said.
Yu said the ANMC is mainly a forum for the capitals of Asian countries to exchange views on issues relating to city development such as medical care, traffic and technology.
Political issues are not relevant at the meeting, but Beijing brought its dispute with Taiwan to the ANMC meeting by blocking Taipei's bid to win the hosting right, he said.
"This attitude has hurt the feelings of Taiwan and is unacceptable to the Taipei city government," Yu added.
He noted that in order to solicit the right to host the ANMC conference in 2005, Taipei made the application in July this year.

According to practice, those who apply earlier will enjoy the priority in hosting the conference the following year, and although Beijing only applied earlier this month, it launched massive diplomatic lobbying and the member states voted to grant Beijing the right to host the 2005 meeting.
Tokyo formed the ANMC in 2000 and the organization held its first plenary session in 2001.
The network groups 12 Asian capitals -- Tokyo, Taipei, Seoul, Beijing, Hanoi, Manila, Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur, Singapore, Jakarta, New Delhi and Yangon.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO REFERENDUM ON ANY ISSUE OTHER THAN UNITING WITH CHINA: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will not call for a referendum on any issue other than the possibility of uniting with mainland China, a DPP lawmaker said Tuesday.

Tsai Huang-liang, the secretary of the DPP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, made the statement to rebut the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) allegations that the DPP is trying to change the country's national emblem via a referendum, which would be tantamount to a referendum on whether to keep the national flag or whether to seek permanent separation from China.

Before there is consensus among the people on changing the country's name, flag, emblem and anthem, Tsai said a referendum on these issues would only fracture the country and the DPP knows better than to do such a thing.
The only question that could be put to a referendum is whether the country should change its political status quo, uniting with China being one such option, Tsai said.
The KMT's allegations are meant to scare voters away from the ruling party in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, Tsai said.

The country's emblem became an issue in the upcoming legislative elections after President Chen Shui-bian said the KMT had to change its party logo, which is very similar to the nation's insignia, within three months, or face possible legislation that would force them to change it.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TO MAINTAIN GENERAL COMBAT READINESS FOR LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Taipei, Nov. 23 (CAN) The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Tuesday that the military will maintain general combat readiness and regular leave for the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
MND spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng made the remarks during a regular press conference.

Huang said the military only goes on heightened alert during such days as presidential election days, Chinese New Year and Double Ten National Day, but will maintain combat readiness as usual during legislative elections, which means there is no special planning to have additional men on duty.

He stressed that the decision is based on the principles of the nationalization of the army, administrative neutrality and non-interference in politics, adding that all military personnel will be able to exercise their voting rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO OFFER SUBSIDIES TO HELP FOREIGN, MAINLAND SPOUSES LAND JOBS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) unveiled a new program Tuesday to help needy foreign and mainland Chinese spouses of local citizens land jobs.

According to the program, the CLA will offer subsidies for local employers who hire foreign or mainland Chinese spouses for at least six months. The subsidy is NT$5,000 per person per month for a maximum period of 12 months.

Moreover, the CLA will offer a subsidy of NT$95 per hour for low-income local citizens' foreign or mainland spouses who work on an hourly wage scheme. The subsidy will also be offered for a maximum six-month period, with a ceiling of 176 hours per month.

Under the new subsidy program, the CLA hopes to help 5,000 foreign and mainland spouses land jobs per year. If all goes smoothly, CLA officials said, the program will benefit 10,000 underprivileged foreign and mainland spouses by the end of 2006.

According to a Ministry of the Interior report, about 82,000 foreign spouses are now eligible to work in Taiwan and more than 28,000 of them already have jobs. Meanwhile, 32,000-plus mainland spouses are qualified to work in Taiwan, 23,000-plus of whom have landed jobs. Altogether, more than 62,000 mainland and foreign spouses remain unemployed at present.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-KOREA BUSINESS CONFERENCE ENDS IN SEOUL
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Nov. 23 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The 29th joint conference of the Taiwan-Korea Business Council concluded in Seoul Tuesday.

The conference was presided over by Wang Chih-kang, head of the Korea Committee of Taiwan's Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association, and his Korean counterpart, Park Yong-Oh, from the Federation of Korean Industries.
At the end of the meeting, Wang and Park signed a joint statement recording the conclusions reached in the conference and calling for closer economic and trade cooperation between the two countries.

Wang said the absence of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and South Korea has impeded the resolution of problems in bilateral trade and has cost a number of opportunities for economic cooperation and technological exchanges.
He expressed the hope that official channels of communication can be restored soon to enhance the friendship and partnership between the two sides.
While Korean soap operas are very popular in Taiwan, Korean foods and commodities such as mobile phones, electrical appliances, automobiles and clothing also sell very well, Wang pointed out.

After the launch of charter flights between the two sides, more than 4,000 Korean tourists have visited the eastern county of Hualien every month, which is the largest number among all foreign visitors, Wang said.

However, official contact between Taipei and Seoul is confined to the multilateral framework of international organizations such as the World Trade Organization and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, he noted.
He said it is the top priority for both sides to resume bilateral, official interaction by exchanging visits, holding regular economic cooperation conferences and signing a free trade agreement.
Wang said he hopes Tuesday's conference will help upgrade bilateral economic and trade relations.
The 29-member delegation led by Wang is scheduled to return to Taiwan Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET FULLY SUPPORTS TAIPEI'S BID TO HOST ASIAN CITIES CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan said Tuesday that it regrets Beijing's "highhanded political interference" with exchanges between Asian cities and that it supports Taipei's bid to host the annual conference of Asian Network of Major Cities (ANMC).

Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai made the remarks after the ANMC awarded the right to host the 2005 conference of the Asian cities organization to Beijing and gave Taipei the priority right to hold the 2006 meeting.
Chen said that to promote cooperation and exchanges with other major cities in Asia and upgrade the profile of Taiwan cities, the Executive Yuan fully supports Taipei's bid to host the meeting.

But he said that from the process of Taipei's bid to solicit the hosting rights, one can see the relentless squeezing and isolation attempts by mainland China, adding that Taiwan people should also transcend their partisan divisions and unite together when faced with such suppression.
On the other hand, he expressed appreciation for Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara and other members who supported Taipei's bid to host the conference.

Chen noted that the ANMC groups 12 capital cities in Asia -- Tokyo, Taipei, Seoul, Beijing, Hanoi, Manila, Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur, Singapore, Jakarta, New Delhi and Yangon -- with an aim of promoting cooperation between the cities and discussing common issues such as education, traffic, culture and economics. The issues of politics and national sovereignty are irrelevant to such discussions, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MUST WIN 101 LEGISLATIVE SEATS IN UPCOMING ELECTIONS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) must strive to win at least 101 seats in the new Legislative Yuan to be elected Dec. 11.
Chen issued the instruction at a weekly meeting of the DPP's Central Standing Committee in his capacity as DPP chairman.

Noting that he has long outlined three main goals for the DPP for 2004 -- holding the first-ever nationwide referendum, winning the presidency again and winning a clear legislative majority, Chen said the first two goals have already been accomplished.

If the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- fails to win more than half the seats in the upcoming election, Chen said, his re-election will be meaningless because the opposition "pan-blue alliance" will continue to block implementation of his policy initiatives at every turn just as it has done for the past four years.
In his view, Chen said, the "pan-green camp" will be able to win a clear majority in the 225-seat legislature if the DPP can take 101 seats.
Judging from the significant growth in the number of votes he garnered in the 2004 presidential elections, Chen went on, he is confident that the DPP will be able to realize its goal.
"With confidence, sweat and the right strategy, we'll make it," a confident Chen stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT BUREAU SIGNS COOPERATION MOU WITH MACROMEDIA

TEXT.P: The Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on cooperation Tuesday with Macromedia of the United States.

In the signing ceremony held at the Economics Ministry, IDB Director-General Chen Chao-yi and Rob Burgess, chairman and CEO of Macromedia, inked the documents on behalf of their respective parties, witnessed by Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang.

According to the terms of the MOU, the Digital Content Institute established by the Institute for Information Industry under the IDB's commission and Macromedia will cooperate in the applications of technologies in the development of the digital content industry, telecommunications, digital learning and Web site multimedia.

Shih said that the cooperation will help improve the human resources for the development of animation, videogame software, digital learning technology and Web site establishing technologies in Taiwan.
He also expressed hope that Macromedia will establish a research and development center in Taiwan as the hub of its operations in the Asia-Pacific region.

Macromedia Greater China Manager Kenneth Lau said that his company has helped train 16 instructors for Taiwan's digital content industry so far under a master authorized training partner (MATP) accord signed with the Digital Content Institute.
Macromedia will continue to enhance cooperation with its Taiwanese counterpart, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO BAN ON OPINION POLLS IMMEDIATELY BEFORE ELECTION DAY: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: As a revised law prohibiting the release of opinion poll results immediately before a legislative election day has not been enacted, there is no ban on such practices, an official from the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Tuesday.

CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-you said a revision to the public functionary election law intended to introduce a ban on publication of any opinion poll 10 days before the election was still bogged down in the Legislative Yuan.
The prohibition is provided for in the law governing the election of the president and vice president to prevent any candidates from misusing the polls to canvass votes inappropriately.
However, Teng said, the law does prohibit candidates from airing political commercials on television or radio for 10 days prior to an election day.
The country will go to the polls to elect legislators Dec. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. COLLEGE STUDENTS CURIOUS ABOUT TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 22 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A group of students from various U.S. universities paid a visit to the Republic of China's representative office in Washington, D.C. Monday and many of them expressed keen interest in Taiwan's international status and independence issues.
The visit was arranged by the Washington Center for Internships and Academic Seminars.

Kao Shou-tai, deputy ROC representative to the United States, delivered a speech titled "Taiwan: Too Big to Ignore, " to the students in which he explained in detail Taiwan's historical origins and economic performance, its bid to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization (WHO) , the present state of relations across the Taiwan Strait and mainland China's suppression of Taiwan.
Kao told his audience that Taiwan is already an independent sovereign state and does not need to declare independence.
Despite its outstanding economic achievements, Kao said, Taiwan had to spend 12 years realizing its goal of joining the World Trade Organization (WTO) mainly because of Beijing's opposition.
Kao said Taiwan now pays a WTO membership fee equivalent to 2 percent of the WTO's annual budget. This amount is more than the combined payment of the WTO's 48 African member states.
Taiwan is now striving to join the U.N. and the WHO and to sign free trade agreements with the United States and Asian countries, Kao went on.

Given its economic achievements, Kao said, Japan, New Zealand and Australia originally planned to sign free trade agreements with Taiwan. However, he went on, all three countries have shelved their plans due to pressure from Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MAKES CASE FOR SEPARATING PARTY FROM STATE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated his determination to force the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to drop its party logo, which it incorporated as part of the national emblem during its five-decade regime.

Presiding over a weekly conference of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , of which he is concurrently chairman, Chen said he wanted DPP members to understand the urgency of separating the country from any particular political party, saying that is what the 2000 shift of power in Taiwan was meant for.
He accused the KMT, which founded the Republic of China in 1912, of trying to dominate the country forever and of enacting a bill to make the party's emblem part of the national emblem.
The issue was not addressed in the five decades until 2000, when the DPP was swept to power in the general election, Chen said.
The power shift ushered in a period for the country to review its former practices and to address the mistakes committed by the KMT, Chen went on.

Since the KMT has made its party logo part of the national emblem, Chen said, the KMT should be forbidden to use the logo, in order to let the people know the state and the KMT are not synonymous, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCTOBER EXPORT ORDER VALUE HITS SINGLE-MONTH HIGH: MOEA

TEXT.P: Export orders received by Taiwan companies in October amounted to US$20.25 billion, marking a 25.46 percent annual growth and posting the highest single-month level on record, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
The amount brings the combined value of export orders for the January-October period to US$175.54 billion, an increase of US$36.41 billion, or 26.17 percent, over the same period of last year.
MOEA officials attributed the growth to the increase of foreign investment in Taiwan and to a booming demand for consumer electronic products.

In October, orders from the United States reached US$5.78 billion, up by 26.39 percent from a year ago; Hong Kong orders hit US$4.57 billion, an increase of 23.11 percent year-on-year; Japanese orders amounted to US$2.35 billion, posting an annual growth of 33.45 percent; and European orders reached NT$3.33 billion, increased by 24.43 percent from the previous year's level.

In terms of product items, October orders for information technology and communication goods generated US$4.19 billion, an increase of US$770 million over the same period of last year, or an annual growth rate of 22.38 percent, while orders for precision machinery were valued at US$1.1 billion, an increase of US$390 million over the same period last year representing an annual growth rate of 55.43 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT TO CHAIR ROUNDTABLE ON NEW CONSTITUTION FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui will preside over a roundtable on formulating a new constitution for Taiwan this weekend, organizers said Tuesday.
Scores of foreign and local legal scholars will attend the Nov. 27-28 seminar, said a spokesman for the Taiwan Advocates -- a private think tank headed by Lee.
Foreign participants will come from the United States, France, Germany, Japan, the spokesman said.

Topics to be discussed will include the legitimacy of Taiwan's new constitution drive, the new concepts for constitutional democracy and features of Taiwan's new constitution, crisis and predicament of Taiwan's current constitutional system and foreign experiences in formulating new constitutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION INDEX UP MODERATELY IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industrial production index stood at 129.87 for October, a moderate growth of 2.91 percent from the previous year's level, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
During the January-October period, the tallies show, industrial production enjoyed an annual growth rate of 11.48 percent.
At the same time, the output of the manufacturing sector grew by 12.51 percent year-on-year.
However, the manufacturing sector's production in October posted only a moderate growth of 3 percent over that of a year ago.

Chang Yao-chung, the MOEA's statistics department director, attributed the slowdown of the manufacturing sector's production expansion to domestic manufacturers' global deployment, international oil price hikes, mainland China's efforts to cool down its overheated economy and the uncertainty caused by interest rate hikes in the United States.

According to results of a survey conducted by his department, Chang noted, 23.82 percent of domestic manufacturers believe they will receive more export orders in November than they did in October, while 47.07 percent see fair prospects for November and 29.11 percent are pessimistic.

Statistics compiled by the MOEA show that export orders received by Taiwan manufacturers in October amounted to US$20.25 billion, marking a 25.46 percent annual growth and posting the highest single-month level on record.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S `PUSH FOR INDEPENDENCE' DENTS U.S. TRUST: KMT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's so-called "push for Taiwan independence" has dented U.S. trust in the Republic of China and has made Taiwan's dialogue with mainland China virtually impossible, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan claimed Tuesday.

In an interview with Madrid-based newspaper El Pais, Lien said the strained ties between Taiwan and the mainland is of great concern to him because, he claimed, Chen's statements often catch Washington off-guard.

U.S. President George W. Bush's latest reconfirmation of Washington's commitment to its "one China" policy and former Secretary of State Colin Powell's statement that Taiwan is not a sovereign state and that its dispute with the mainland should be solved peacefully all indicate a worrisome tip in Washington's attitude towards China, Lien said.

As to the government trying to "rewrite" the country's history to cover up its Chinese origins, Lien likened this to the attempts of Adolf Hitler, Joseph Stalin and Benito Mussolini, who thought they could change history in whatever way they wished once they had power.
With a government like this, Lien said, the Taiwanese will only see the country reduced to insignificant status in the international community, while the country's industries relocate overseas.
Lien accused Chen of using trickery in order to win his second term and claimed that he "might resort to more innovative tricks" in the upcoming legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HELD TALKS WITH NINE STATES IN SANTIAGO: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan conducted bilateral talks with nine countries on the sidelines of the annual Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Santiago, Chile, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Tuesday.
Ho, who had just returned after attending the APEC joint ministerial meeting Nov. 17-18, said two more states that had disrupted bilateral talks with Taiwan promised to resume the talks next spring.
Ho also said Taiwan signed an agreement with Russia on Moscow's accession to the World Trade Organization and had many meaningful exchanges with trade officials of many countries.

Taiwan's suggestion to APEC for cooperation in developing a vaccine against avian flu was included in the joint statement of the APEC ministerial meeting and has given the economic forum a medical dimension, Ho added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT DINES WITH EX-PRESIDENT OF CZECH REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui dined Tuesday with visiting former Czech Republic President Vaclav Havel.
The content of their lunchtime talk was not disclosed.
Havel also attended a farewell party hosted by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy in which Foreign Minister Tan Sen Chen praised his achievement and invited him to visit Taiwan agains
Havel, who arrived in Taiwan Nov. 18 for a private visit, will leave the country Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Nov. 24, or the 13th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: Zachary Taylor, the 12th U.S. president, who was also known as "Old Rough and Ready," is born. An army officer in the Black Hawk War and the Second Seminole War, he became a national hero during the Mexican War and was elected president in 1848.
1859: Charles Darwin, British naturalist who revolutionized the study of biology with his theory of evolution based on natural selection, publishes his book "The Origin of Species."
1894: Dr. Sun Yat-sen founds his first revolutionary organization, the Hsing-chung-hui (Society for Regenerating China), with a group of overseas Chinese youths in Honolulu. The organization was later reorganized as the Kuomintang (Nationalist Party).
1899: The U.S. Expeditionary Force makes a major advance in its long-running struggle against insurrection leader Emilio Aguinaldo when it gains control of the Philippines' largest island, Luzon.
1924: Egyptian Prime Minister Zaghlol Pasha resigns after refusing to apologize to Britain for the assassination in Cairo of Maj. Gen. Lee Stack, governor-general of Sudan.
1945: The Charter of the United Nations, the draft of which was jointly promulgated by the Republic of China, the United States, the United Kingdom and the Soviet Union on Oct. 9, 1944, before the 51 countries signed it, goes into effect.
1947: A total of 19 members of the National Assembly are elected in the first general elections held in Taiwan Province.
1953: The ROC government protests to the United States against the proposed American transfer to Japan of the Amami Oshima Islands.
1954: National Chengchi University is reopened in Taiwan with Chen Ta-chi as its president.
1963: Lee Harvey Oswald, the man arrested and charged with the assassination of U.S. President John F. Kennedy in Dallas two days earlier, is himself shot and killed by Jack Ruby.
1966: The Asian Development Bank is established in Tokyo, with Takeda Watanabe as its first governor.
1967: The Chinese Economic Development Research Institute is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: A tentative agreement is reached between U.S. President Gerald Ford and Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev at their meeting in Vladivostok.
1975: The Eurasia Trade Organization is established to promote trade between the ROC and European Common Market countries.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks eastern Turkey, killing some 7,000 people and leaving 50,000 others homeless.
1976: Economics Minister Y. S. Sun leaves for a three-week visit to the United States.
1978: President Juan Pereda Asbun of Bolivia is overthrown and succeeded by Gen. David Padilla Aracibia.
1979: Saudi Arabian troops storm the Great Mosque in Mecca to oust Iranian religious fanatics.
1989: Following mass demonstrations in Prague, the entire presidium and secretariat of the Czechoslovak Communist Party, including leader Milos Jakes, resigns.
1992: A mainland Chinese Boeing 737 crashes in southwest China, killing all 141 people on board.
1992: The last batch of U.S. forces is withdrawn from Subic Bay in the Philippines prior to the expiration of the treaty allowing the United States to occupy Subic Bay Naval Station.
1993: South Korea's first representative to the Republic of China, Han Chul Soo, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1997: Afghanistan's Taliban rulers agree to uproot the country's poppy crops.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui appoints Chen Chien-jen, director-general of the Government Information Office, as foreign minister to replace Jason Hu.
2000: Tokyo announces that Peru's ex-president Alberto Fujimori is allowed to live in Japan.
2001: The Kuomintang (KMT), which became the opposition party following its defeat in the presidential election of 2000, celebrates the 107th anniversary of its founding.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "To desire to be what is considered honorable is the common mind of men. And all men have what is (truly) honorable in themselves; only they do not think of it."

DOC.TEXT:
