DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: 100,000 protest in Kiev after disputed election Kiev-A political crisis gripped a bitterly di- vided Ukraine on Tuesday as a about 100,000 peo- ple streamed into Kiev's main square to support pro-Western opposition leader Viktor Yushchen-ko as he appealed to the international community to recognize him as the legitimate winner of the weekend's contested presidential elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Ukraine Election Crisis Erupts. A political crisis erupted at Kiev as official results showed Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovich winning a bitterly contested presidential election, while opposition leader Viktor Yushchenko brought supporters into the streets to press his own claim of victory.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times:Nishimatsu hid key facts,LTA tells inquiry .
In A surprise development in the Nicoll Highway collapse inquiry yesterday, new documents produced by the Land Transport Authority (LTA) suggested that the main contractor knew of problems before the collapse, but kept its concerns from the LTA.
In an often heated court session, Senior Counsel K. Shanmugam, acting for the LTA, produced e-mail messages that he said showed contractor Nishimatsu had suppressed potential problems with its calculations, both in the months before the accident and during the inquiry.
The Lianhe Zaobao:SMEs to get bigger share of government business 10 billon a year.
Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) will soon get a much better shot at winning a slice of the massive $10 billion a year that the Government spends on buying goods and services from the private sector.
In a series of reforms that has won a quick thumbs up from business groups and entrepreneurs ,the Government is knocking down barriers that have effectively barred many SMEs from competing for this vast government shopping list.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Nayan, 2 others freed by captors
Filipino diplomat Angelito Nayan who was kidnapped by militants in Afghanistan has been released to Afghan authorities yesterday morning, the Philippine permanent representative to the United Nations has confirmed.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Nayan freed; 'Best Christmas ever'
EVERY DAY, his captors threatened to kill him and his two women companions. In his darkest moments, he could only find strength in the words from the Bible that he could recall. This was how Angelito Nayan summed up his more than three weeks of captivity in the hands of a shadowy group of gunmen in Afghanistan.
The Philippine Star: Nayan, 2 UN workers freed
A Taliban splinter group claiming to have held three United Nations workers hostage said it freed Filipino diplomat Angelito Nayan and Northern Ireland's Annetta Flanigan yesterday in exchange for 24 Taliban prisoners.
The Manila Times: Kidnappers free Nayan
KABUL, Afghanistan -- Three UN workers kidnapped in Afghanistan have been released unharmed after nearly four weeks in captivity, officials said Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY OPTIMISTIC ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT AIR LINKS TALKS RESUMING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 23 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu, Wennie Chi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative to the United States is optimistic that cross-Taiwan Strait talks on the opening of direct air links will be resumed before long, hopefully sometime next year, the Washington Times reported Tuesday.

David Ta-wei Lee hinted during a luncheon with Washington Times editors and journalists Monday that Beijing is likely to acknowledge President Chen Shui-bian's olive branches by making some favorable responses, increasing the likelihood of a resumption of the cross-strait air link talks, which have been suspended since 1999, the daily reported.

In an interview with the Central News Agency Tuesday, Lee said that the "10-point" directive that President Chen gave during a recent national security meeting has reopened a "window of opportunity" for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume cross-strait air link talks.

In the "10-point" directive, President Chen exhorted relevant government agencies to step up preparations for the opening of direct trade, postal and transportation links with mainland China using the "1992 Hong Kong talks" as the basis, Lee said.

President Chen also said he wants relevant government agencies to start negotiations immediately with their mainland counterparts on the opening of direct charter passenger flights across the Taiwan Strait for the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday and non-stop charter cargo flights based on the Hong Kong-Taiwan formula, Lee noted.
He added that the U.S. government has also on numerous occasions suggested that Beijing grab the golden opportunity to re-start the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue.

Also on Tuesday, Lee said during a press conference at the Twin Oaks Garden that Taiwan has fully grasped the contents of the talks between U.S. President George W. Bush and mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao on the sidelines of the just-concluded informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum held in Santiago, Chile.
From the Hu-Bush talks, Lee said, it was learned that Washington would be pleased to see Taiwan and mainland China resume dialogue and tackle their differences peacefully.
He commented that parts of the Hu-Bush talks concerning the so-called Taiwan or cross-strait issues showed clear "consistency."

Lee also said that he foresees the new U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice sticking closely to President Bush's firm opposition to either side of the Taiwan Strait making potentially destabilizing moves to change the status quo.
Asked about the possibility of meeting with Rice, Lee said that there are currently no such arrangements due to "certain objective constraints."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CELEBRATES PARTY'S 110TH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan celebrated the 110th anniversary of the party Wednesday by first paying tribute to its founder.

Lien went to the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall to pay his respects to Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who founded the party in 1894, and then to Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to honor the party's longest-reigning leader.
The KMT will hold a celebration in a dome stadium in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan later in the day.

Touching on the possible merger of the KMT and its two splinter parties -- the New Party and the People First Party (PFP) -- Lien said that a merger is inevitable and that the KMT will wait patiently.

He also said that the nation is currently facing a daunting situation and that his party will insist on its lofty ideals and follow the right path. He added that the urgent tasks facing the nation include creating a clearer national identity and more harmonious society and strengthening the nation's democracy.

Meanwhile, PFP Chairman James Soong said while stumping for PFP legislative candidates in southern Taiwan that the two parties can talk about the course of a merger and related details next February when the new legislature will be sworn in.

Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang took the opportunity of the KMT's anniversary to extend congratulations to the KMT, expressing the hope that the KMT can play the role of a loyal opposition party to monitor the performance of the administration. He added that he hopes the KMT can "transform" itself to keep in step with Taiwan's democratic progress.
The KMT ruled Taiwan continuously for more than five decades before it was swept out of power by the Democratic Progressive Party in the 2000 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FINANCIAL SUPERVISORY COMMISSION HEAD GIVES REPORT AT WTO
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Nov. 23 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Kung Chao-sheng reported on Taiwan's financial supervisory system to a World Trade Organization (WTO) committee in Geneva Tuesday.

In the 15-minute report to the WTO Committee on Trade in Financial Services, Kung said the ratio of non-performing loans in Taiwan banks has been cut to 3.5 percent from a high of 8 percent. Taiwan's stock market is growing steadily, and its insurance market is the third largest in Asia, he said.
Kung also said that Taiwan's current advantages include a sound financial system, abundant talent and capital, and a strong manufacturing sector.
He said the focus of Taiwan's financial development is on making the island into a center for asset management and for raising funds in the Asia-Pacific region.

Officials from Japan, South Korea, the European Union, Switzerland, Mexico and Malaysia responded positively to Kung's report on Taiwan's financial supervisory system. They also exchanged views with Kung on the financial supervisory system and their own countries' experiences in related matters.

Kung, who is heading a delegation of FSC and Taiwan Securities Association officials on the visit to Switzerland, said the trip has helped upgrade the profile of Taiwan's financial industry in the international community.
Kung is scheduled to visit three major insurance groups in the country before winding up his trip Wednesday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-BASED FORMOSA FOUNDATION TO HOST ACADEMIC CONFAB IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Nov. 23 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Los Angeles-based Formosa Foundation is scheduled to host a conference in Taipei Dec. 13, immediately following Taiwan's legislative elections, on post election U.S.-Taiwan-mainland China relations, a foundation source said Tuesday.

The conference will take place at the Grand Hotel, with the participation of at least six noted "China hands" and academics from the United States and a larger number of political experts and observers from Taiwan, said Donald S. Lee, chairman of the foundation's board of directors.

The conference, titled "The Post-Election Era -- the Impact on U.S., Taiwan and China Relations, " will tackle four related issues: Taiwan in the post-2004 election era; cross-strait relations and Taiwan's economic prospects; political and strategic development of U.S.-Taiwan relations in the post-election era; and retrospective views on the U.S. "one China" policy, according to Lee.

Lee said that holding the conference right after Taiwan's important legislative elections slated for Dec. 11 is aimed mainly at expressing the concerns of U.S. experts and academics on Taiwan's democratization, as well as at enhancing the Taiwan people's resolve in safeguarding freedom and democracy.

The U.S. "China hands" and academics that have confirmed that they will attend the conference are John Thacik, research fellow in China policy with the Heritage Foundation; Jacques deLisle, director of the Asia Program under the Center for East Asia Studies at the University of Pennsylvania; June Dreyer, professor of political science at the University of Miami at Coral Gables; Daniel Lynch, international relations professor at the University of Southern California; and Richard Kagan, professor of history at Hamline University, according to Lee.

The non-profit Formosa Foundation was founded in 2001 in Los Angeles to promote greater understanding between Taiwan, the United States and the People's Republic of China, and to preserve and enhance democracy, liberty and human rights for the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG 'PAN-BLUE' CANDIDATES PITCH 'FIVE-NO' AND 'FIVE-YES' PLATFORM

TEXT.P: Five young legislative candidates from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang, New Party and People First Party jointly spelled out their "five-no" and "five-yes" platform Wednesday to woo supporters.

The five "pan-blue alliance" candidates, including Chou Shou-hsun, who has been a TV anchorman and a KMT spokesman, vowed at a press conference in their "five no" statement to push for peace (no to war), strength (no to violence), professionalism (no to reward for favors) , jobs (no to unemployment) and reconciliation (no to confrontation).
Meanwhile, they also put forward their "five-yes" proposals to stabilize cross-Taiwan Strait relations and to improve relations between the ruling and opposition parties in Taiwan.

The "five-yes" proposals are: pushing to make the Taiwan Strait a no-war zone; requiring that future ROC premiers be technocrats with strong economics backgrounds, instead of political puppets; organizing a Taiwan peace corps to mainland China to optimize peace across the strait; pushing for consultations between the ruling and opposition parties; and seeking to shelve the cross-strait political impasse issue for the next 30 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN'S BOXING TAIWAN INTERNATIONAL TO KICK OFF IN HUALIEN

TEXT.P: Nearly 100 women boxers from 16 countries will take part in the Women's Boxing Taiwan International set to kick off in Hualien, eastern Taiwan Thursday.
Lee Wu-nan, president of the Chinese Taipei Amateur Boxing Association, said that this will be the largest international boxing event in Taiwan in recent years.
Noting that women's boxing could be included in the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Lee said that Taiwan began to promote women's boxing in 1999, or earlier than any other country in Asia.
Taiwan has won the right to host the third Asian Women's Boxing Championship in 2005, and the association wants to stage the Hualien invitational as a warm up for the championship, he added.

The Nov. 25-28 invitational will be divided into international and domestic competitions, with boxers from the United States, Russia, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Japan, mainland China, the Philippines, India, Vietnam, Hong Kong, Macau, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Mongolia and the host Republic of China taking part in the former, and more than 500 boxers from Taiwan's 64 schools taking part in the latter.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPOSITION ON FOREIGN SPOUSE EDUCATION TO OPEN IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: An exposition on the achievements of lifelong learning of foreign spouses will be held in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan Sunday, with the aim of displaying the pluralistic society of a Taiwan rich in different cultures, Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng announced Wednesday.
Tu made the remarks during a press conference held at the ministry to introduce the exposition.
Noting that one out of every seven or eight newborns in Taiwan are the offspring of parents in inter-racial marriages, Tu said that Taiwan has to face the issue squarely.
Education aims to allow foreign spouses to join the fabric of Taiwan society, which in turn helps them educate their children, he said.

With a view to creating a more pluralistic society, Tu said, the Executive Yuan and his ministry don't want the foreign spouses to "become thoroughly Taiwanese" by giving up their own cultures. Tu added that he hopes these spouses from Vietnam, Thailand, Indonesia and other Southeast Asian countries will be proud of their own cultures and that the Taiwan people will try to understand these cultures more.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH ADMINISTRATION MULLING CANDIDATES FOR AIT CHAIRMANSHIP: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 23 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government is scouting a suitable person to serve as its top liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, the Republic of China representative to the United States said Tuesday.

Speaking at a regular news conference, David Ta-wei Lee said that to the best of his understanding, relevant U.S. authorities are weighing a short list of candidates for the top American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) post which has been left vacant since the resignation of former AIT Chairwoman Therese Shaheen in April this year.
Lee said a final decision is expected to be made after the new U.S. secretary of state assumes office next January when U.S. President George W. Bush will be sworn in for a second four-year term.
Meanwhile, Lee said he is delighted at Bush's decision to appoint Stephen J. Hadley, incumbent deputy national security adviser, as the new national security adviser.
Hadley will succeed outgoing National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice who has been designated as the new secretary of state. Rice's appointment requires Senate approval, while Hadley's does not.

Noting that Hadley has a deep understanding of the Taiwan Strait issue, Lee said Taiwan welcomes Hadley's appointment as the new White House national security adviser. Hadley understands every detail in the Taiwan Strait issue, he added.

Touching on cross-strait relations, Lee said the ROC government has a full grasp of the content of the talks between Bush and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Hu Jintao, on the sidelines of the just-concluded informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum held in the Chilean capital of Santiago.

Lee said the latest Bush-Hu talks underscored consistency in the U.S. policy toward Taiwan and cross-strait issues. Lee said he expects to meet in the coming days with U.S. officials who were present at the annual APEC meeting to gain a better understanding of the details regarding the latest Bush-Hu talks.

Asked whether the United States has moved to push the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume the long-stalled dialogue, Lee said the U.S. government would be pleased to see the two sides using peaceful means to resolve their disputes in order to maintain the present status quo across the Taiwan Strait.

Noting that President Chen Shui-bian has on many occasions extended olive branches to Beijing, Lee said he is convinced that there will be good opportunities for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume dialogue in the coming two years.

"President Chen's May 20 inauguration speech, Oct. 10 National Day address and Nov. 10 directives at a National Security Council meeting have opened up a 'window of opportunity' for cross-strait dialogue, "Lee said.
He further said the Bush administration's policies toward Taiwan and China are expected to remain unchanged after Rice takes over from Colin Powell as secretary of state.
"We have come to a full comprehension of the possible directions of U.S. policies toward East Asia and the Taiwan Strait situations after Rice becomes the top U.S. diplomat," Lee added.
With Thanksgiving Day just around the corner, Lee hosted an evening party with Taiwanese dishes and snacks Tuesday in honor of journalists of Chinese-language media stationed in Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, giving up NT$0.1 to close at NT$32.387.
A total of US$862 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.487 and dipped to a low of NT$32.352 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PLEASED WITH NAME 'TAIWAN MEDICAL ASSOCIATION'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed happiness Wednesday to seeing the World Medical Association's (WMA's) recent approval of Taiwan's request for a membership name change from "Chinese Medical Association Taipei" to "Taiwan Medical Association."

While receiving visiting WMA Chairman Yank D. Coble, Jr. and Vice Chairman Dr. Tai Joon Moon at the Presidential Office Wednesday, Chen expressed gratitude for their assistance in the country's successful bid to have the name changed at a WMA general assembly held in Tokyo last month.

Chen also told Coble of Taiwan's desire to join the World Health Organization (WHO), a continuing attempt of which the WMA has been supportive since 2001, that has always failed due to mainland China's opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPATS IN LOS ANGLES TO RETURN FOR LEGISLATIVE STUMPING
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angles, Nov. 23 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: With the approach of the Dec. 11 legislative elections, Taiwan expatriates in Los Angeles are returning to Taiwan to lend support to their favored candidates.

As voters in the legislative elections have to reside in a constituency for six consecutive months to be eligible to vote in the elections, most of the expatriates are unlikely to be able to take part in the voting.
For this reason, the numbers returning are relatively smaller than those who returned for the March 20 presidential elections and most of the returnees are returning to take part in the campaign.

In the case of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the DPP's branch on the west coast of the United States and another group friendly toward President Chen Shui-bian have decided to pool their strength to stump for three DPP candidates -- Trong Chai, Chiang Chao-yi and Hsiao Bi-khim -- who have either studied or worked in the United States and who are considered to be more relevant to Taiwan expatriates.

As of Tuesday, more than 1,000 expatriates had registered to take part in the DPP stumping for the three candidates, while supporters of the opposition Kuomintang, People First Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union have decided that they will provide assistance based on the needs of the individual candidates.

As the number of DPP supporters is very large, the first batch is expected to return to Taiwan Thursday and to join the campaign Saturday, while opposition supporters will return in smaller groups and then travel to various cities and counties to stump for specific candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 60.21 points to close at 5,911.31.
The bourse opened at 5,868.73 and fluctuated between 5,918.7 and 5,862.99 during trading. A total of 3.04 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$71.06 billion (US$2.19 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 2.5 percent, followed by construction issues at 2.3 percent, cement stocks at 1.5 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares and banking and financial shares at 0.8 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.7 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 419 to 208, with 144 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CURRENCY SETTLEMENT SYSTEM UNDER ASSESSMENT: CBC

TEXT.P: Responding to reports that new Taiwan dollars can be directly exchanged for renminbi at some mainland Chinese banks, a key figure said Wednesday that the issue regarding setting up a currency settlement system between Taiwan and the mainland is being assessed by relevant authorities.

Hsu Yi-hsiung, deputy governor of the Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC) , made the remarks following news from Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland that the local currency can be directly exchanged into renminbi at some mainland banks.

On the question of whether the CBC will allow one month in which renminbi can be exchanged for new Taiwan dollars on a trial base on Taiwan's frontline Kinmen and Matsu islands, Hsu said that the CBC and the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) are gauging the possibility of such a move.

He also claimed that it is technically difficult for the CBC to calculate how many new Taiwan dollars have been brought by Taiwan people to the mainland, although there are widespread rumors that more than NT$50 billion worth of domestic currency has been carried to the mainland.

MAC Chairman Joseph Wu told a news conference later the same day that there is no set timetable regarding when such a policy might be implemented and he suggested that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait model any such policy on a settlement pact inked late last year between Hong Kong and the mainland.

MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said on the same occasion that a cross-strait settlement pact must be clinched before the mainland currency can be allowed to be exchanged in Taiwan and on the offshore islands.

Chiu said that the MAC, the CBC and the Financial Supervisory Council have yet to consult local banks on their willingness to start renminbi operations and on their capabilities to take the risks brought about by this operation.

He claimed that the Taiwan authorities are waiting for a positive response from the mainland to the idea of two-way negotiations and ruled out any links between the issue and a mainland plan to permit people from Fujian Province to make pleasure trips to the Kinmen and Matsu islands in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December gained 63 points to close at 5,905, with 31,576 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January moved up 68 points to finish at 5,902, with 72 contracts traded, while March futures gained 13 points to finish at 5,850, with two contracts traded.
June futures gained 37 points to finish at 5,870, with 16 contracts traded, while September futures moved up 71 points to close at 5,830, with 17 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,842 for December, 5,834 for January, 5,837 for March, 5,833 for June and 5,759 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
December TE futures moved up 2.45 points to close at 220.75, with 3,757 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 2.2 points to finish at 220.45, with 17 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

December TF futures gained seven points to finish at 1,022, with 5,909 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 6.4 points to end at 1,021, with 19 contracts traded. March TF future lost 12.4 points to finish at 1,018, with four contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTIES PLAY `ORANGE' CARD AS CITRUS PRICES NOSEDIVE

TEXT.P: All parties across Taiwan's political spectrum have been playing the so-called "orange" card at the height of the legislative election campaign, using the nosediving prices of the fruit as a tool to broaden support base or lash out at rivals.

After the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lambasted the government for failing to safeguard fruit farmers' interests, the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) announced Wednesday that it will buy 20,000 taels (a tael is equivalent to 600 grams) of oranges from fruit farmers to help compensate for over-production of the seasonal fruit.

The wholesale price of domestic oranges has plummeted to NT$1 per fruit over the past several days due to over-production, causing widespread outcry from growers, who are complaining that the income from 5 kg of oranges cannot even buy 1 kg of fertilizer or pesticide, not to mention labor and time costs.

Echoing the DPP legislative caucus' enthusiasm, DPP legislators Chen Mao-nan and Kao Chien-chih also announced that they will each purchase 3,000 taels of oranges from the farmers to help tide them over their difficulties.

Meanwhile, Huang Teh-fu, a KMT party whip at the Legislative Yuan, accompanied officials from the Taiwan Farmers Cooperative and a KMT legislative candidate at a press conference to express the farmers' plight and offer advice to the government on solutions.
Huang criticized the government for being aware of the problem but doing nothing except electioneering.

According to Pai Tien-chih, the KMT candidate, while prices for fertilizers and pesticides continue to rise, the prices of locally produced vegetables and fruit continue to plummet, causing further aggravation for farmers.

Since the DPP took the helm of the central government, Pai said, Taiwan's unemployment rate has continued to surge. With more people unable to find jobs in Taipei returning to rural areas, villagers' and farmers' lives have worsened, he added.
Pai suggested that the government provide subsidies to fruit growers in the same way that it subsidizes the country's rice farmers.

Also blasting the government's inability to offset the orange crisis, opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said his heart goes out to the fruit growers, who are leading bitter lives despite the sweetness of their produce.

Soong claimed that he will send PFP legislative candidate Lee Cheng-ling and Tsai Sheng-chia, chief executive of the Tainan County Farmers Association and a PFP candidate, to mainland China for negotiations to allow the export of locally produced fruit to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT MIGHT ACTIVATE PURCHASE SYSTEM TO HELP PROP UP ORANGE PRICE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday that if necessary, the government will activate a purchase system to help prop up the price of local oranges.
Yu issued the instruction during a floor meeting of the Executive Yuan to hear reports on orange production and distribution by the Council of Agriculture (COA).

The premier said that if all other means of promotion are exhausted and the price of oranges still falls below the production cost, the COA will activate a "95 project, " meaning that the government will purchase oranges in great numbers at a price of 95 percent of the production cost to help bring the price up.

COA officials noted that total production of oranges is expected to reach 230,000 tons this year, up 13 percent from last year. The overproduction has caused the price to slump continuously and the COA has implemented various promotion measures to deal with the situation.
The premier asked the COA to step up these promotion activities in the hope that consumers will buy more of the fruit.

The Ministry of National Defense (MND) should also step up purchases, the premier said. The MND has estimated that it will be able to consume 1,000 tons of oranges between December and next March if it provides the fruit to servicemen.

Also, Yu asked the COA to help growers and farmers groups to embark on a stockpiling program by preserving 10,000 tons of oranges at normal temperature and 5,000 tons at low temperature. The COA will then put them on the market between February and May next year contingent on market needs.

On the processing of orange juice, the premier instructed that the COA and other agencies purchase inferior quality oranges to produce juice starting Nov. 20 at a purchase price of NT$7 (US$0.22) per kilo. The planned purchase amount is 6,000 tons, but this could be increased if necessary.
All agricultural administrative agencies around the island must also step up promotion between now and Feb. 28, with the goal of selling 2,000 tons of oranges.

In the longer term, the premier instructed that the COA should speed up adjustment of the structure of the fruit industry and reform its distribution system, especially international marketing channels, so as to help the nation's farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS UNVEIL LIST OF LAWMAKERS SUPPORTING TAX CUTS FOR THE RICH

TEXT.P: The Pan-Purple Alliance, a private group dedicated to promoting fair and just social welfare services and speaking for the underprivileged, unveiled a list of lawmakers Wednesday who it claims support tax cuts for the rich.

Chien Hsi-chieh, convener of the alliance, joined with the chief executives of several other like-minded social groups in unveiling the list at a news conference dubbed "Beware! Look Who Is Undermining Our National Finances."

Over the past 10 years, Chien said, the nation's financial status has continued to worsen, with the ratio of tax revenues to gross domestic product (GDP) declining from 18.6 percent to 12.3 percent. As the tax revenues have decreased by NT$700 billion over the past decade, Chien said, the government has had to sell its land holdings and stocks, as well as float state bonds, to make ends meet.

Ignoring the government's financial straits, Chien claimed, the Legislative Yuan has passed revisions to three major bills that "would allow business corporations and wealthy families to evade taxes with legal protection."
The three bills refer to packages of revisions to the statute on promoting industrial upgrading, the statute on land value increment tax and the inheritance and gift tax law.

In the run-up to the Dec. 11 legislative elections, Chien said, candidates of different political stripes are gearing up to canvass votes. However, he claimed, few candidates have paid attention to issues related to people's livelihoods, such as government finances and welfare services for the underprivileged.
Chien said the Pan-Purple Alliance has consequently decided to unveil a list of legislators who have initiated the above-mentioned three bills and are seeking re-election in the upcoming vote.
The listed lawmakers come from across the political spectrum, Chien said, adding that the move should serve as a warning to those legislators.

In response to the move, Huang Chung-yuan, legislative whip of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, who was named by the alliance as one of the initiators of the revised statute on promoting industrial upgrading, said the revisions were mainly aimed at creating a better investment climate to boost private investment and increase job openings.
If the tax rate is too high, Huang said, it may result in an exodus of industries and a reduction in job opportunities.

As to the proposed revisions to the inheritance and gift tax law, Huang said the proposals are aimed at enabling the government to actually collect taxes from rich people. Excessively high tax rates, he went on, can only prompt wealthy families to use every possible means to evade taxes.

Norman Yin, an finance professor-turned-lawmaker of the opposition People First Party, who has pushed for a 50 percent cut in land value increment tax, said the tax cut is aimed at making the country's taxation system more reasonable and more just. The "pan-purple alliance, " he claimed, has just paid heed to the land value increment tax rate cut while failing to pay attention to unreasonable clauses in the existing tax laws.

Some lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are also on the list and Tsai Huang-liang, DPP legislative whip, said the party caucus must respect individual lawmaker's rights to initiate legislative bills.

In the future, Tsai said, the DPP caucus will exercise more prudence in screening legislative bills, particularly those regarding tax cuts. "Fairness, justice and the government's financial status will all be weighed carefully in the legislative process, " he said, adding that the DPP will do its utmost to achieve social justice and avoid further widening the domestic wealth gap.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, U.S. TO RESUME TIFA TALKS NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the United States are slated to reopen talks on the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) next week in Washington, D.C., officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long and Josette Sheeran Shiner, U.S. deputy trade representative, will hold the talks next Monday and Tuesday on behalf of their respective governments, the officials said.

Officials from the Council of Agriculture, Department of Health (DOH) , the DOH-affiliated Bureau of National Health Insurance, the MOEA-affiliated Board of Foreign Trade and Intellectual Property Office, and the Directorate General of Telecommunications, will make up the rest of the Taiwan delegation, they added.

The two sides will discuss economic issues of mutual concern, in addition to stalled issues related to the protection of intellectual property rights, Taiwan's market opening to foreign rice imports, telecommunications services and pharmaceutical pricing.

Taiwan and the United States first conducted the TIFA talks in 1995, and the talks were held again in 1997 and 1998. The fourth round of talks in 2002 were postponed until now by the U.S. for what it called lackluster performance on Taiwan's part in resolving key matters related to the stalled issues.
Taiwan has been hoping to rekindle the TIFA talks to further boost bilateral economic and trade relations during the second term of President George W. Bush.
After concluding the TIFA talks, Chen will travel to San Francisco, where he will discuss the signing of a free trade agreement with officials from Nicaragua between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: POPULAR TAIWAN MODEL MEETS WITH JAPANESE MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Nov. 24 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Lin Chih-ling, a popular Taiwan fashion model, paid a courtesy call on Japanese Minister of Land, Infrastructure and Transportation Kazuo Kitagawa Wednesday in her capacity as a goodwill envoy for a tourism promotional campaign to attract tourists from Taiwan, a post she assumed Nov. 17.
Ministry staff members swarmed to Kitagawa's office to get a glimpse of Lin, one of Taiwan's most popular fashion models and TV anchors.

At the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport's (MLIT's) invitation, Lin has traveled to many Japanese sightseeing spots since July this year for location shooting for a television program "Yokoso! Japan (Discovering Japan Again)" featuring Japanese culture, social customs and tourist attractions.

Thanks to Lin's charm, Kitagawa said, the people of Taiwan have become more familiar with Japan's tourism resources. The number of Taiwan tourists to Japan is expected to break the 1 million mark in the next few days, Kitagawa said, adding that he is very grateful for Lin's assistance in helping promote Japan to prospective Taiwan tourists.
As Japan has set a goal of doubling its annual tourist arrivals to 10 million by 2010, Kitagawa said his ministry needs Lin's continued assistance in the future.
For her part, Lin said she is very pleased with the opportunity to travel around Japan to get a better understanding of Japan's natural beauty, cultural heritage, social customs and lifestyle.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER CZECH PRESIDENT ENDS TAIWAN VISIT

TEXT.P: Former Czech Republic President Vaclav Havel concluded his six-day visit to Taiwan Wednesday.

Havel said prior to his departure that he would treasure the memory of his first-ever Taiwan visit very much. The poet and playwright-turned-politician lauded Taiwan as a country that respects freedom and democracy.

As Havel accidentally slipped in his hotel room and broke his leg on the first day of his arrival in Taipei, his itinerary was partially affected and he canceled planned tours of the National Palace Museum and several other cultural institutions. He also canceled a plan to visit Thailand following his Taipei trip.

During his visit, Havel delivered a speech on globalization and the future of democracy at the National Central Library in Taipei, attracting a packed audience. Many fans of his books traveled from al over Taiwan to listen to his speech and obtain his autograph.

On Monday, President Chen Shui-bian decorated Havel with the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon in recognition of his contributions to the promotion of relations between the two countries.
Praising Havel as a world-class literary figure, thinker and political leader, as well as a conscientious political dissident, Chen said he was honored to meet Havel in person.

Havel played a pivotal role in his country's "velvet revolution" of 1989, using his literary and theatrical creations to kindle and keep the flame of democracy burning amidst a storm of repression and autocracy during communist rule. He eventually led his country to break the shackles of communist suppression and move toward democracy. During his 12-year presidency, he continued working hard to consolidate the Czech Republic's democratic system as well as promote human rights and social justice, earning wide respect and admiration.
Havel has been friendly toward Taiwan and has on many occasions explicitly supported Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TALKS LIKELY AFTER DEC. 11 ELECTIONS: MAC

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait are likely to resume long-stalled talks after Taiwan's Dec. 11 legislative elections, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu claimed Wednesday.

Wu said the opportunity for the two sides to talk about the opening of direct cross-strait charter passenger flights during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday after Taiwan's legislative elections still exists.

"The flip-flops in Beijing's attitude toward Taiwan after President Chen Shui-bian extended olive branches on many occasions since his inauguration in May indicate that Beijing has yet to reach a final decision on the charter flight issue," Wu said.

Through cross-strait scholastic exchanges, Wu said, he gets the impression that the mainland Chinese authorities are still weighing Chen's proposal about opening direct cross-strait passenger and cargo charter flights.
According to Wu, some mainland scholars have said Beijing will carefully consider Chen's proposal in the run-up to Taiwan's legislative elections and make a final decision after the elections.

With Beijing's consent, Taiwan carriers operated special charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during the 2003 Chinese New Year period. The services were not offered during the 2004 Chinese New Year holiday because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers be allowed to also provide the same flight services while declining to negotiate the necessary technical details with Taiwan.

The ROC government said that as the opening of two-way, non-stop cross-strait charter flight services involves the exercise of public authority, prior negotiations are necessary. The upcoming lunar New Year holiday falls between Feb. 6, 2005 and Feb. 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN SHOULD BE PREPARED FOR INFLUX OF FUJIAN VISITORS: PROSECUTOR

TEXT.P: In the face of a much-expected influx of tourists from mainland China's Fujian Province, Kinmen Public Prosecutor General Tsai Juei-tsung has urged the Kinmen authorities to take precautions against a possible worsening of social order.
Tsai issued the call Tuesday while making a report during a meeting with local police, prosecution and investigation agents, in which Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng also took part.

Although Tsai admitted that social order on the frontline island has not shown signs of deterioration over the almost four years since the Jan. 1, 2001 opening of the "three mini links" -- direct trade and transportation links between Kinmen and Xiamen and between Matsu and Mawei -- he still called for heightened alert to secure public order on Kinmen with the expected inflow of tourists from Fujian.
Since the inception of the mini links, the Kinmen Prosecutor's Office has received a monthly average of 60 complaints each year, except for 2002, Tsai reported.

The office got an average of 59.9 cases per month in 2001, 64.5 complaints in 2002, and 57.9 in 2003, according to Tsai. For the first 11 months of this year, there was an average of 59.7 complaints per month, he added.

Despite the fact that there have been no serious or violent crimes reported over the past few years on Kinmen, he urged relevant authorities to be wary of possible consequences that might result from an influx of tourists from the Fujian area, in particular, the smuggling of arms and drugs.

He said that he has repeatedly urged the central government in Taipei to legalize petty trade on Kinmen's beaches in order to effectively wipe out the smuggling of arms and narcotics from mainland China via the frontline island that has long been a serious problem without being realized.

According to Lee, Fujian residents might be permitted by the mainland authorities to go sight-seeing on Kinmen by the end of this year. In the initial stage, up to 600 people would be allowed in per day, he said, urging the relevant agencies to pay greater heed to stem any irregularities.
He also echoed Tsai's call by urging the central government to make Kinmen's beach trade legal in order to better manage the long standing practice and stop related illegal activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR: BEIJING OFFENDS MAYORS OF ASIAN CITIES

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that the "rudeness and unreasonableness" of mainland Chinese representatives to the meeting of the Asian Network of Major Cities (ANMC) in Jakarta Nov. 22-23 offended everyone at the meeting.
Ma, who had just returned from the meeting, told journalists that Taipei has won the priority right to host the 2006 ANMC meeting, despite opposition from Beijing.

Ma said Taipei bid to host the 2005 meeting in July, but Beijing entered the race against Taipei for the right only a few days before the 2004 Jakarta meeting, simply because it did not want to see Taipei play any significant role in the meeting.
In a vote to choose between Taipei and Beijing, Beijing won seven out of 12 votes, which was one vote shy of the two-thirds of the vote needed to win the hosting right.

In the ensuing negotiations, all of the meeting-attendants except Beijing Deputy Mayor Zhang Mao, the Beijing representative, agreed that Beijing should host the 2005 meeting, with Taipei getting the priority right to host the 2006 meeting, Ma said.
When the chairman of the meeting announced the results of the negotiations, Beijing's representative walked out in protest.
Ma expressed regret that Beijing representative did his best to scuttle Taipei's chance to play a role on the international stage.

However, Ma did not rule out the possibility of attending the 2005 meeting in Beijing in spite of his unhappy encounter with Zhang, and said he anticipates no difficulty in getting the Executive Yuan's approval to visit Beijing.

Founded in 2001 by Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara, the ANMC is meant to be a forum of mayors of major Asian cities. It groups Bangkok, Beijing, Delhi, Hanoi, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Manila, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Tokyo and Yangon.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Protesters March on President's Office.
Opposition candidate Viktor Yushchenko declared victory and led a march of hundreds of thousands of his supporters to the president's office Tuesday night in an effort to stage a velvet revolution.
Protesters were meters away from the presidential administration building at 11:15 p.m.
Moscow time, and opposition leaders assured riot police that they would not storm the building.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI WORKERS ACCOUNT FOR BULK OF FOREIGN LABORERS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: There were more than 307,000 foreign laborers working in Taiwan as of the end of September, which is 3.4 percent more than at the end of last September and accounted for about 10 percent of the country's total employed workers, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics under the Executive Yuan.
Thai workers, made up the bulk of the foreign laborers, with a total of 103,000, or 33.8 percent, following by Filipinos, at 89,318 and 29 percent and Vietnamese, at 81,000 and 26.3 percent.
The manufacturing industry employed the most foreigner workers, at 168,000 or 54.6 percent, followed by caregiving, at 126,000 and 40.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR NOV. 25 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, Nov. 25:
10: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive Taiwan's delegation to the 2004 leadership meeting of the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation forum at the Presidential Office.
10: 30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a weekly news conference at the ministry's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Nov. 25, or the 14th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1835: Andrew Carnegie, American industrialist and philanthropist who donated over US$129.5 million to charitable causes in the United Kingdom and the United States, is born in Scotland.
1844: Karl Friedrich Benz, German engineer and car manufacturer who built the first car powered by an internal combustion engine, is born.
1884: John Mayenberg of St. Louis, Missouri, patents evaporated milk.
1908: The Christian Science Monitor newspaper publishes its first issue in Boston.
1911: Chinese revolutionaries bomb Nanking.
1913: Police open fire on demonstrators protesting against the imprisonment of Mahatma Gandhi, killing two people and wounding 20 others in Natal.
1921: Emperor Hirohito begins to rule Japan on behalf of his gravely ill father, Emperor Mutsuhito.
1924: Tuan Chi-jui becomes Provisional Chief Executive of the Republic of China.
1936: Japan and Germany sign the Anti-Comintern Pact to collaborate in opposition to the spread of communism.
1954: The remains of Hsuan Tsang (596-664), a Buddhist monk during the Tang dynasty, are shipped from Japan to Taiwan. During his lifetime, he toured India for more than 10 years and brought back over 600 Buddhist scriptures, 25 of which he and his disciples translated into Chinese.
1958: Senegalese vote for independence from France and to become a republic in a referendum.
1963: The first batch of American soldiers, numbering 53, arrives in Taipei from Vietnam for rest and recreation.
1969: President Richard Nixon declares that the United States will not use chemical weapons.
1970: Yokio Mishima, Japan's most widely read author, commits ritual suicide at the age of 45.
1973: The Republic of China team competing at the First Asian Amateur Track and Field Championships in Manila, returns to Taipei. The team won two gold, six silver and seven bronze medals.
1974: On behalf of President Chiang Kai-shek, Vice President C.K. Yen receives the credentials of Guatemalan Ambassador A.D. Kestler.
1974: U Thant, Burmese diplomat and secretary-general of the United Nations from 1961 to 1971, dies at the age of 65.
1975: Surinam gains independence from the Netherlands.
1979: The first Asian-Pacific Conference on Juvenile Delinquency opens in Taipei with the participation of 112 delegates from seven nations.
1986: The new building of the Coordination Council for North American Affairs, USA Office, is opened in Washington, D.C., by Representative Frederick F. Chien (Chien Fu).
1989: Vietnamese boat people riot in Hong Kong's detention camps at the news of forced repatriation.
1993: South Korea opens its Korean Mission in Taipei to replace the embassy which closed after South Korea and the ROC broke off diplomatic relations.
1995: The Republic of China and Poland boost economic ties by initialing an agreement to avoid double taxation and prevent tax evasion by investors.
1999: Newly appointed Malawian Ambassador to the Republic of China Eunice Kazembe presents her credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
1999: Panamanian Foreign Minister Jose Miguel Alemen arrives in Taipei for his first visit to Taiwan since assuming his present post.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "Benevolence subdues its opposite just as water subdues fire. Those, however, who nowadays practice benevolence (do it) as if with a cup of water they could save a whole wagon on fire, and then when the flames were not extinguished were to say that water cannot subdue fire. Such a course is the greatest aid to what is not benevolent."

DOC.HEADLINE: THINK TANK CHIEF DEFINES MAJOR TASKS OF TAIWAN BUSINESSES INVESTING OVERSEAS

TEXT.P: Tapping markets and establishing brands have become the major tasks of Taiwan businesses investing overseas, the head of a local think tank said Thursday.
Vincent Siew, chairman of the Chung-Hwa Institution for Economic Research, made the remarks in a seminar on the experiences of Taiwan businesspeople investing overseas.
Several entrepreneurs -- including Giant Chairman Liu Chin-piao and Johnson Health Tech Chairman Lo Kun-chuan -- were also on hand to share their experiences in investing overseas.

Siew, an expert in economics, said that with the changing world situation, Taiwan businesspeople have flocked overseas, mostly to mainland China and Southeast Asia. However, he added that in order to maintain their competitiveness, Taiwan businesspeople have to continue to expand to other parts of the world.

He noted that years ago, Taiwanese invested overseas mainly for the purpose of cutting their production costs. However, in recent years, their overseas investment has not been confined to the establishment of production bases, but has come to include the tapping of new markets, the establishing of brand names and marketing channels, and the integrating of multinational resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWISS FATHER'S SCHEME LEADS ABORIGINALS TO SAVE
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Nov. 25 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A co-op venture system introduced some thirty years ago in Taitung by the late Swiss Catholic Father Dominik Stener has not only helped foster good savings habits among aboriginal people in the county but also a stronger community spirit over the years.

The Rev. Dominik Stener, a Jesuit missionary who was assigned to eastern Taiwan to sponsor churches there in 1964, introduced the co-op venture system in 1967 as a scheme to encourage aboriginal residents to "save money for a rainy day."
Stener died of an illness in Taitung two years ago. The Yiwan Church, where he had resided and preached, has been turned into a memorial hall in his memory.

Liu Hua-pi, chief of Ningpu village, said that savings in the co-op in the Ningpu-Danman tribal region total about NT$200 million at present, with the figure steadily increasing as villagers enthusiastically put their money into the co-op.

A senior tribe member, who has been a member of the co-op for decades, said that he has enjoyed the convenience of borrowing cash from the co-op. Even if someone wants to borrow money in excess of the amount in their savings deposit, they won't encounter many difficulties so long as they can produce a guarantor, he explained.
An old lady, the only non-aboriginal co-op member, said she joined the group more than 10 years ago and has found it to be much better than any bank.

The co-op, which is managed by a committee manned by representative members, has also been known for its leniency toward its members, never "pressing" debtors to repay loans or interest on the loans, Liu said.

In 1965, two Taiwan-based foreign Jesuit fathers and two local Catholic followers went to Bangkok to attend a regional conference on social and economic development in Asia. During the conference, the four picked up the know-how for establishing saving co-op ventures, an idea invented by German Friedrich Wilhelm Raiffeisen (1818-1888).
Raiffeisen, leader of a cooperative movement, once said that the best way to solve social and economic problems of the people is to let them help themselves.

The Taitung co-op was established in 1967 after Father Stener sent two members of the Amis tribe to Taichung to learn about co-op venture systems in lectures given by the four people who attended the conference in Bangkok.
The Taitung co-op formally registered with the government in August 1982 to become the first legal, public-interest cooperative in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO DEAL WITH RISING CONSUMER PRICES

TEXT.P: Legislators from the opposition People First Party (PFP) on Thursday urged the government to come up with measures to deal with the issue of rising prices of daily necessities.

PFP Legislators Liu Wen-hsiung and Lee Hung-chun said that the government should pay attention to the problem of rising consumer prices while the salary of the average person has not increased accordingly.

Lee cited the first three quarters of this year as an example, saying that the wholesale price index increased 6.5 percent, the consumer price index rose 1.5 percent, while salaries declined by 0.46 percent on average.

He pointed out that the increase in the price of raw materials was 22.6 percent in the third quarter, but the consumer price increase during the same period was only 0.7 percent, showing that consumer price increases have been contained for the time being. However, he expressed concerns that it can no longer be contained, leading to dramatic increases in the price of daily necessities.

Lee also noted that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party recently purchased 20,000 kilograms of oranges after overproduction of the fruit triggered a price slump. However, he added, this will not solve the fruit growers' problem, saying that the government should address the impact on agricultural products of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization Jan. 1, 2002, and map out a comprehensive policy to deal with it.

Legislator Liu also expressed the hope that the government will not place its focus solely on the Dec. 11 legislative elections and will come up with measures to solve the problem of rising prices of daily necessities.

Singapore Parliament yesterday began a debate on the most sweeping changes yet to the teaching of Chinese, aimed at making it a living language.
For nearly five hours, the House discussed the recommendations tabled in a 64-page White Paper report, and will continue again today and likely tomorrow as well.
The Lianhe Zaobao:The revamp in the teaching of Chinese language must carry out in five years.
Singapore Education Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam made a promise yesterday that students learning Chinese in primary and secondary schools will be watched closely to ensure goals are met following a revamp in the teaching of the language.
Minitry Of Education(MOE) will focus the point on the revamp of the Chinese language class and the way teaching,and invest all resoures they need to achieve the goal of White Paper report.

DOC.HEADLINE: NON-PARTISAN CANDIDATE STARTS 16-DAY CAMPAIGN TOUR ON FOOT

TEXT.P: Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) legislative candidate Lin Ming-yi hit the road Thursday for a 16-day walk around the county of Yunlin to drum up support prior to the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Lin, who joined the NPSU in recent months after having a falling out with the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , was accompanied by his mother, NPSU Chairwoman Chang Po-ya, NPSU Secretary-General Chen Chieh-ju and supporters at a ceremony marking the beginning of his trek.
He is scheduled to walk across all the 20 cities, townships and rural townships around Yunlin County over the next 16 days.

Lin said that he will walk around the county to help raise Yunlin residents' political awareness and bring them "out of the darkness and deception" which he claimed has for long clouded politics in the region.
Lin, who had been a KMT legislator for three terms before 2001, is the only candidate that the newly-established NPSU is fielding in Yunlin County in the upcoming legislative elections.
President Chen Shui-bian won some 240,000 votes in Yunlin County in this year's presidential election, or about 80,000 votes more than his challenger, KMT Chairman Lien Chan, garnered.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 TAIPEI TV FESTIVAL OPENS

TEXT.P: The 2004 Taipei TV Festival opened at the Taipei World Trade Center Exhibition Hall on Thursday.
The exhibition features a "TV Mall" section for ordinary visitors, which is being held Nov. 25-28, and a "TV Market" section for professionals, which will run Nov. 28-30.

The "TV Mall" has gathered 38 exhibitors with a total of 271 booths. A variety of themes are being displayed, including frequency platforms, TV shopping, home appliances, digital multi-media, derivate products, audio/video publications, cartoons, and digital content value-added applications.
The "TV Market" will feature 93 exhibitors with a total of 268 booths.
The exhibition has been organized under the guidance of the Government Information Office, which is promoting the government's plan for the digitization of television in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CALL FOR HALVING ARMS PROCUREMENT BUDGET AN 'ELECTION PLOY': DPP

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Thursday criticized a call by the opposition Kuomintang to halve the special budget for arms procurement from the United States as an "election ploy."
Tsai Huang-liang, DPP whip in the Legislative Yuan, was responding to a call by KMT Chairman Lien Chan during a celebration of the party's 110th anniversary party the previous day.

Lien said that if the special budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) for the purchase of six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States can be halved and the extra money used for social welfare programs, the opposition parties are willing to have the proposal put to early screening by legislative committee after the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
Tsai said that Lien's call shows his total disregard for national security by turning arms procurement into "horseplay" to try to win votes.

"Arms procurement and social welfare are two different things, " Tsai said, noting that if the KMT wants to spend more on social welfare programs, this can be achieved through consultation among the parties.

He urged the opposition to respect the judgment of the Ministry of National Defense and pass the budget as soon as possible, adding that if the opposition really loves Taiwan, it should form a team to monitor the use of the budgets.

James Huang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, also said that the point is whether Taiwan can buy arms at a reasonable price, adding that the proposal should be subjected to screening by the legislature and not arbitrarily decided by any single party.

Meanwhile, although the KMT and its ally, the People First Party (PFP), blocked a bill authorizing the special arms procurement budget earlier this month, a KMT party whip in the legislature said the party is not against arms procurement.
"We are only against a bloated budget for such procurement, " Huang Teh-fu said.

Quoting KMT's information, Huang claimed that back in 2002, Premier Yu Shyi-kun and then National Defense Minister Tang Yiau-min said the arms procurement for the Patriot PAC-3 batteries, eight submarines and 12 P-3C aircraft required only about NT$280 billion, but when the Executive Yuan proposed it in June this year, it had ballooned to NT$610.8 billion.

Moreover, Huang claimed that the DPP administration has registered deficits of NT$250 billion a year since coming to power in 2000, accumulating a debt of NT$1.0002 trillion after five years in power. It has also sold state-owned shares and land cheaply, resulting in a squandering of national assets of at least NT$480 billion per year, he added.

Huang said that if the Executive Yuan withdraws its proposal and resubmits it after cutting the amount by half, the KMT will consider putting the arms procurement proposal forward for screening in the legislature.

Meanwhile, PFP Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung said that the PFP also supports arms procurement at a reasonable price, but that it is against squandering money by making the arms purchase at such an inflated price.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO UNVEILS SHORT FILM AIMED AT REVITALIZING SAGGING MOVIE INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) unveiled a short film Thursday as part of its efforts to revive the sagging local movie industry.

In the short film, titled "Taiwan Film Anna, " GIO Director-General Lin Chia-lung plays a "Dragon Brother" trying hard to please "Taiwan Film Anna, " who is played by a fashion model, to symbolize the government's strenuous efforts at revitalizing the sagging movie industry.
Lin said at the presentation that it took six hours for him to shoot the six scenes in the film.
"My acting skills are lousy, but I thought my appearance might be humorous and thus help raise local people's concern for our movie industry," Lin explained.

Since Lin assumed his current post, the GIO has formed a special commission to review the government's policy regarding the local film industry and to work out measures to remove any obstacles to the development of the industry.
Lin said the GIO will publish a pamphlet in the near future outlining its policy and vision for reviving the sagging industry.

The Washington Post: Pro-Russian Candidate Declared Ukraine Winner; Opposition Leader Vows to Fight Results, Calls for Nationwide Strike.
Ukraine's Central Elections Commission declared Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovych the winner of the country's bitterly disputed presidential vote Wednesday, defying strong pressure from the United States and other Western countries. In response, opposition leader Viktor Yushchenko called for a national strike starting Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DENIES REPORT ON SALE OF CENTRAL INVESTMENT HOLDING CO.

TEXT.P: A high-ranking official of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) on Thursday denied reports that the party has sold the Central Investment Holding Co. to the Chinatrust Group at a price of NT$17 billion (US$526.31 million).
Chang Che-shen, chairman of the KMT's Administration and Management Committee, said the party has never contacted the Chinatrust Group about such a deal.

Chang did confirm that a number of buyers had shown interest in taking over the company, but added that no deal was struck with any of them. He said all the potential buyers have been scared away because the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government reportedly has vowed to intervene to bar the KMT from selling off its assets.
He said that it is the KMT's policy to stop operating commercial businesses and that the party is disposing of its assets through lawful means.
Chinatrust Group head Jeffery Koo also denied the report, pointing out that his group has not purchased the KMT-controlled company.
Also on Thursday, Premier Yu Shyi-kun criticized the KMT for attempting to cash in its "ill-gotten" assets to evade its responsibility of returning the assets to the government and the people.
Yu said the move is inconsistent with KMT Chairman Lien Chan's promise to return the assets.
The premier also said the DPP and its ally parties must win a majority of seats in the Legislative Yuan in the Dec. 11 elections in order to push through a law to retrieve the assets from the KMT.

DPP lawmakers, meanwhile, warned buyers interested in any of the KMT's assets of the risk of possible financial loss, saying most of these assets are considered "booty" that will be subject to retrieval by the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 56.07 points to close at 5,855.24.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 5,925.08 and hit a low of 5,855.24 during trading. A total of 2.62 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$57.47 billion (US$1.78 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up at 0.1 percent.

The other seven major stock categories lost ground, with textile shares moving down the most at 1.7 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 1.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, construction issues at 0.5 percent, and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 512 to 127, with 128 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY CANDIDATES PLEDGE WITH BLOOD TO PROTECT ROC

TEXT.P: New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming and the party's eight legislative candidates each drew their own blood and placed it on a Republic of China national flag Thursday to symbolize their vow to protect the ROC.

At a press conference, Yok said that the New Party will emulate the spirit of the martyrs who sacrificed their lives for the building of the Republic of China nearly 100 years ago, adding that the party calls for voters to rise up for the cause of the nation.

Yok said that the New Party will no longer sit idly by and watch the growing independence sentiment in the country, adding that the New Party will ally with all supporters of the ROC in the nation to defend it to the end.

Yok claimed that the Dec. 11 legislative elections provide a crucial opportunity for supporters of the ROC to consolidate among themselves at a time when the Kuomintang, the major opposition party, is still "facing difficulties to free itself from the black hole of being a ruling party for decades, " and at a time when the "pan-blue alliance" supporters are "bogged down in a quagmire with no leadership in sight."

He stressed that the New Party, which split from the KMT 12 years ago, chose to have its eight candidates run under the KMT banner in the upcoming legislative elections in order to manifest the New Party's determination to broaden the "pan-blue alliance's" support base.

Yok claimed that this is also the first step in the integration of the KMT, the People First Party and the New Party, and promised to continue to push toward the ultimate goal of merger of the three parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER WANTS VOTE-BUYING CASES TO BE DEALT WITH MORE QUICKLY

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan on Thursday called for court cases involving vote-buying to be dealt with more quickly, saying that "justice overdue is no justice."

Chen made the remarks after he presented a cash award of NT$5 million (US$153,840) to an informer in a vote-buying suit against legislative candidate Wang Tao-fu in the 1995 legislative elections. In a show of protecting the identity of the informer, Fan Wen-hao, chief prosecutor of Tainan Prosecutor's Office, received the money on behalf of the informer at the presentation ceremony.

According to the Executive Yuan's promulgated regulations concerning awards for informers, an informer will receive half of the award after the first trial in a district court in which a defendant is convicted based on the information provided by the informer, and will receive the other half after a final ruling by a higher court. The cash award for informers in legislative elections graft cases is NT$10 million.

Speaking about the graft case involving legislative candidate Wang, Chen noted that if the case had been concluded eight years ago, the effect would have been much greater, saying that the final ruling handed down after a delay of nine years didn't produce the impact that it was intended to have.
Chen urged the Judicial Yuan to step up the monitoring of graft suits filed by prosecutors so that courts at all levels can carry out speedy trials.

Meanwhile, with only three weeks left before the Dec. 11 legislative elections, prosecutors had handled 3,191 reported graft cases as of Wednesday, the State Public Prosecutor General Wu Ying-chao said Thursday.

Of that total, 615 cases are in Tainan, showing that the prosecutors and other law enforcement units in the southern Taiwan city are working hard in the crackdown on vote-buying, Wu said during an anti-vote-buying meeting with prosecutors and other law enforcement personnel in Tainan.

Cheng Ming-shun, deputy chief of the Investigation Bureau, said on the same occasion that judging from the information collected over the past three weeks, vote-buying methods have shifted from providing free trips or banquets to the distribution of cash, with the latter form of bribery accounting for 52 percent of the reported cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATIN AMERICAN OFFICIALS TO VISIT TAIWAN IN DECEMBER: MOFA

TEXT.P: Representatives from several Latin American countries are expected to visit Taiwan in December, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

Ho Ching-shan, director-general of the MOFA's Central and South American Affairs Department, said Taiwan has invited officials from El Salvador, the Dominican Republic, Guatemala and Paraguay to visit.

The foreign dignitaries who have promised to visit include Salvadoran Economics Minister Yolanda Mayora de Gavidia, Guatemalan Economics Minister Marcio Cuevas, Paraguayan Foreign Minister Marcial Bobadilla Guillen, and Dominican Presidential Office Secretary-General Danilo Medina Sanchez.
Most of the scheduled visits are for the purpose of discussing economic affairs.
