DOC.HEADLINE: APEC ENVOY SAYS MAINLAND PRESIDENT FRIENDLIER THAN TAIWAN REPORTERS

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said Thursday he felt that mainland Chinese President Hu Jiantao was "friendlier than Taiwan reporters" to him during the just-concluded informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Santiago, Chile.

Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, made the remarks at a news conference held after briefing President Chen Shui-bian on the results of the annual APEC summit meeting and his personal feelings about the event.
Lee, who attended the APEC summit on Chen's behalf, said that during the one-and-a-half-day meeting, he held talks with the top leaders of all APEC member economies, including Hu.

As to the content of his conversation with Hu, Lee said he conveyed Chen's goodwill toward promoting rapprochement across the Taiwan Strait and desire to invite Beijing's top cross-strait negotiator, Wang Daohan, to visit Taiwan.
Nevertheless, Lee acknowledged that he did not go into detail in his talks with Hu about cross-strait issues because their meeting was brief.

Prior to his departure for the Chilean capital, Lee said he had repeatedly reminded local journalists that APEC is basically a multilateral economic cooperation forum, not an avenue for political wrangling or diplomatic maneuvering.

"However, since my arrival in Santiago, many Taiwan reporters relentlessly questioned me about my interaction with Hu. Some reporters' attitudes were rude. In the end, I told them that in fact, I felt Hu's attitude toward me was friendlier than theirs, " Lee recalled.
This was the third consecutive year that Lee has served as Chen's proxy at the annual APEC summit meeting.

Lee said he hopes that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can talk after Taiwan's Dec. 11 legislative elections to mend their differences. Cross-strait peace and stability are not only critical to Taiwan and mainland China but also important to the world as a whole, he added.
Moreover, Lee said he looks forward to seeing Chen attend the 2005 APEC summit in person.
"Chen's attendance is of great significance as it will symbolize progress in cross-strait relations," Lee said.
Because of Beijing's opposition, Taiwan's head of state cannot attend the annual APEC summit in person and has to name a proxy to attend on his behalf.

After having attended the annual APEC summit for three years in a row, Lee said he felt many other APEC members have made tremendous progress in various fields. In contrast, he said, the pace of Taiwan's progress is comparatively lagging behind because of domestic political instability and chaos.

The soft-spoken scholar said he sincerely hopes that local political parties can stop their strife after the December legislative elections and work together to accelerate domestic economic development, a cultural renaissance and social stability.

APEC groups 21 Asia-Pacific economies -- Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE RELEASE PICTURE OF ALLEGED 'RICE BOMBER'

TEXT.P: Police released Thursday a picture and filmed image of the so-called "rice bomber, " who is allegedly responsible for more than a dozen bomb threats in Taipei over the past year, and offered a reward of NT$500,000 (US$15,479) for information leading to his arrest.
The portrait was sketched according to descriptions from witnesses and images obtained from surveillance cameras, police said.
The suspect is believed to be aged between 20 and 35 and is about 168 centimeters tall, with short hair, according to police.

Anyone with information on the suspect is urged to call the Taipei City Police Department's criminal investigation unit at (02) 23817409 or 0910222432, or the Criminal Investigation Bureau at (02) 27676676 or 0931770110.

Since November last year, a man claiming to oppose the government's policy of permitting rice imports has placed home-made explosives in public areas such as parks, trains, railway stations and mobile toilets in the greater Taipei area.
One of the devices exploded outside the Legislative Yuan building in June and another outside the Ministry of Education building earlier this month.
Police said they believe the bomber is highly educated and that he has expertise in making explosives.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN EXPERT GIVES SEMINAR ON TAIWAN'S BIOLOGICAL BEAUTY

TEXT.P: A biology professor of the University of Munich held a seminar on the "Natural Beauty of Taiwan" Tuesday in Regensburg, Germany.

Klaus Schoenitzer, who has conducted three field surveys in Taiwan in the past years to discover new species of insects, is one of the most prestigious entomologists in Germany and has discovered many new insect species.
During the 90-minute seminar at the East Bavaria Natural Science Museum, Schoenitzer explained Taiwan's biological resources using slides he took during his field trips.
The entomologist said Taiwan has a unique and diverse biological system and is home to more different kinds of Papilionidae butterfly than Japan or Madagascar, the world's fourth-largest island.
He also introduced Taiwan's historic spots such as Taipei's Lungshan Temple and the National Palace Museum, as well as some modern construction, including Taipei 101, the world's tallest building.
The seminar was sponsored by the Munich office of Taiwan's representative office in Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR SAYS PERFORMANCE IN MEETING HAS NOT LET DOWN CITIZENS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that he did his best to win the priority right to host an Asian cities conference in 2006 and that he "did not let the Taipei citizens down."
Ma made the remarks when he was interviewed by a local radio station after returning from a conference of the Asian Network of Major Cities (ANMC) in Jakarta Nov. 22-24.

The mayor noted that Taipei bid to host the 2005 meeting in July, and should have been awarded the right according to past practice, but Beijing cut into the race simply because it did not want to see Taipei play any significant role in the meeting. Taipei then solicited the support of other members to win the priority right to host the meeting the following year.

Ma pointed out that in contrast with Beijing's "barbaric and irrational" method, Taipei displayed "friendship, cooperation, and an attitude of measurement" to win the sympathy and support of other members.
He noted that the member cities of the organization have always coordinated with each other in their discussions and that "there has never been the need to vote on the hosting issue."

But, he went on, Beijing put on an air of "having veto power" in the meeting, so that many representatives, although having been instructed by their governments to lend support to Beijing, did not support Beijing due to its "overbearing" attitude.

The ANMC was founded in 2001 by Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara. It provides a forum for the mayors of major Asian cities to exchange views on issues concerning city development. It groups Bangkok, Beijing, Delhi, Hanoi, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Manila, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Tokyo and Yangon.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH, TAIWANESE SCIENTISTS TO JOINTLY DETECT QUAKES IN EAST TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Nov. 24 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-shao and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Geophysicists from France and Taiwan agreed in Paris Wednesday to step up cooperation in earthquake and active tectonics research, beginning with the installation of more seismic detectors off Taiwan's east coast next year.

At an award presentation ceremony, Dr. Liu Char-shine, a professor with the Institute of Oceanography at National Taiwan University, who is one of the two recipients of the prestigious French-Taiwan Science Prize of 2004, said that France will help Taiwan in efforts to monitor earthquakes by offering academic expertise as well as undersea earthquake detecting equipment.

It is expected that the number of undersea detectors in Taiwan, currently numbering 18, will be increased to 40 or 50 after French research organizations, including the Institute for Sciences of the Earth, Water and Space under the University of Montpellier II, begin supplying Taiwan with equipment from next year, Liu said.
The beefed up equipment is expected to enhance Taiwan's capability in earthquake detection and even earthquake prediction, Liu added.

Also at the award presentation ceremony, Dr. Serge Lallemand, the other winner of the 2004 French-Taiwan Science Prize, who is director of the Research, Geophysics, Tectonics and Sedimentology Lab under the Montpellier Institute for Sciences of the Earth, Water and Space, said that Taiwan's geographic format is not only extraordinary but also a living classroom for studying active tectonics.

Lallemand, who has been to Taiwan many times for research, said he had discussions with many Taiwanese and French scientists before deciding to choose the offshore area of eastern Taiwan as a spot to intensify earthquake studies.

Onshore and offshore areas of eastern Taiwan have the greatest number of recorded earthquakes around Taiwan, Lallemand said, adding that close detection and recording of tectonic plate friction in the area can possibly one day help seismologists to predict earthquakes.
Lallemand also said that Taiwan's educational level is relatively high, with a good research environment, which is why he encourages French young people to study there.

Wu Mao-kun, chairman of the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) , also attended the award ceremony and delivered a speech in which he exhorted scientists and academics from Taiwan and France to continue cooperating under a program jointly sponsored by the NSC and the Institute of France to make the world a better place.
The annual French-Taiwan Science Prize was established in 1999 by the NSC and the Institute of France, a prestigious research institute supported by French government grants.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRIMINOLOGIST CALLS FOR CLOSER TAIPEI-HK-BEIJING POLICE COOPERATION

TEXT.P: A noted Chinese-American forensic scientist has urged police authorities in Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China to cooperate closely in fighting cross-border crime without consideration of political factors.
Dr. Henry Lee, who is currently attending an international seminar on forensic investigation technology in Beijing, made the appeal in an interview with the Hong Kong-based daily Wen Hui Pao.
Lee said he is happy with the close cooperation between Hong Kong and mainland Chinese police authorities in criminal investigations.

Despite the present political stalemate across the Taiwan Strait, Lee said, it would be very encouraging if the Hong Kong and mainland police authorities could similarly cooperate with their Taiwan counterparts, particularly in the arrest of fugitive criminal suspects and convicts.

Noting that many gangsters have taken advantage of legal loopholes to engage in cross-border criminal activities in the three Chinese societies, Lee said the authorities should not be daunted by political hindrances in developing cooperative ties to upgrade their crime-fighting efficiency.
As the mainland is now in a rapidly changing stage, Lee said, many new types of social problems and crimes have arisen in mainland society.

"My observation is that although the quality of the mainland Chinese police force has improved, it still needs renovation in manpower training, " Lee said, adding that the mainland police authorities should send more technological staff abroad for advanced training.

DOC.HEADLINE: RISING OIL PRICE TO BE DISCUSSED IN TAIPEI AVIATION MEETING

TEXT.P: The high price of crude oil and war risk will be among the issues discussed by the leaders of major airlines in the Asia-Pacific when they meet in Taipei Friday.

China Airlines, sponsor of the Association of Asia-Pacific Airlines (AAPA) 48th Assembly of Presidents, said Thursday that the meeting is sponsored each year by member airlines on a rotation basis, providing a forum for the airline leaders to exchange views on the prospect for the aviation industry.
The last such meeting to be held in Taipei took place in 1989 and CAL was also the host on that occasion.

The agenda this year will include new developments in the aviation policy of the United States, the rising crude oil price, risk hedging strategy, premium and war risk, as well as the emergence of airlines offering low air fares.
President Chen Shui-bian will deliver a speech at the opening ceremony.
The AAPA is the most influential aviation organization in the region, with the passenger volume of its 17 member airlines per year exceeding 85 percent of regional passenger accommodation.

The 17 members are Air New Zealand, EVA Airways, ANA, Garuda Indonesia, Qantas, Royal Brunei, Asiana Airlines, JAL, Singapore Airlines, Cathay Pacific, Korean Air, Thai Airways, China Airlines, Malaysia Airlines, Vietnam Air, Dragonair and Philippine Airlines.

DOC.HEADLINE: RISING NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR HAS LITTLE IMPACT ON EXPORTS: MOEA

TEXT.P: Despite a continued appreciation of the new Taiwan dollar, the government is optimistic about the prospects for the country's exports.

Chang Yaw-tzong, director-general of the Statistics Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), claimed recently that Taiwan, compared to South Korea, one of the country's major export rivals, still enjoys an advantage in exports, as the South Korean won has strengthened more than the new Taiwan dollar.

Chang forecast that Taiwan's outbound shipments, particularly in the information and electronics industries, will continue to grow in November and December and next year after the country's export order value broke the US$20 billion mark to reach a new single-month high of US$20.25 billion in October.
The new Taiwan dollar continued its rise Thursday, gaining NT$0.148 to end at 32.239 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on a weakening greenback.
Amid anticipation that mainland China's renminbi may appreciate early next year, a well-known Taiwan economist forecast that the mainland currency will go up in value in the second half of next year.
Kung Ming-hsin, a division chief at the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER), predicted that the renminbi will strengthen by 10 percent in the second half of 2005.

Kung contended that the timing of late this year or early next year is not yet ripe for a renminbi appreciation, and he suggested that members of the public hoping to take advantage of currency exchange rates should wait a little longer.

He based his argument on the grounds that President George W. Bush will have fully completed his personnel changes by late next year, which will be a better time to discuss the renminbi's exchange rate issue with Beijing.
According to Kung, mainland China has a 35 percent growth rate in exports at present and will still enjoy double-digit expansion even if its currency picks up in value by 10 percent.

Mainland President Hu Jintao revealed in the recent informal leaders' summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Santiago, Chile, that Beijing intends to depeg the renminbi's decade-old peg to the U.S. dollar under stable economic conditions.

Hu's comments have prompted public speculation on a stronger renminbi and many people are planning to convert their holdings in other currencies into the mainland unit to make profits on the exchange rate.

But a stronger renminbi will have a bigger impact on Taiwan-made goods, as the mainland is Taiwan's largest manufacturing base and a majority of Taiwan companies operating there are export-oriented. An appreciating renminbi will make products made by Taiwan companies less competitive in other countries.

Far East Group Chairman Douglas Hsu said that the currency exchange rate issue alone should not affect the export business at the moment, but it is a risk that it should be taken into account for the future.
He said that the mainland authorities are expected to loosen the floating range for the renminbi, but added that a large jump in value might not be very likely in the short term.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OPTIMISTIC ABOUT WINNING MAJORITY IN LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is optimistic about winning a majority in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, which it believes is vital for Taiwan's stability, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said Thursday.

In an interview with the Madrid-based El Paise newspaper, Chang said the ruling party's control of the legislature will improve the government's efficiency, which will in turn serve the best interests of the nation.

As to opposition claims that President Chen Shui-bian won his re-election through trickery, Chang pointed out that the Taiwan High Court, which heard the opposition's complaints, has cleared Chen of the accusation and has confirmed that Chen won the election by a margin of 25,536 votes.

Chang also explained Chen's idea of rewriting a constitution for the country, saying that the existing Constitution was formulated by the Republic of China in Nanjing in 1947, under a political situation quite different from that of Taiwan, and that therefore the president called for a referendum on the creation of a new constitution better suited to today's reality.

The DPP secretary-general also raised the country's bid to enter the United Nations, saying that Taiwan's bid is in tune with the U.N.'s purpose of giving representation to all people around the world.

In another development, Chang rebutted insinuations by opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan that the judicial system, including the court, is controlled by the DPP, saying that the Taiwan High Court's judgment to throw out the opposition parties' claims that the presidential elections were flawed numbers almost 400 pages. "Which court would go into such detail in overthrowing a complaint?" he asked rhetorically.
Lien insulted the judges presiding over the trial by suggesting that they are manipulated by the DPP, he said.

Chang's optimism about a DPP victory in the legislative elections was shared by President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff Su Tseng-chang, who told journalists while canvassing votes for DPP candidates in Chiayi that the DPP is expected to win 101 seats and will command over half of the 225 seats in legislature after combining forces with its political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPENING OF RENMINBI EXCHANGE IN KINMEN, MATSU TO MEET NEEDS: MAC

TEXT.P: A government plan to open renminbi exchange in Kinmen and Matsu on a trial basis is based on the future needs and development of the frontline islands, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Thursday.

Chiu said the government started to study the plan a few months ago in view of the rising needs of mainland Chinese visitors to Kinmen and Matsu after the launch of direct ferry services between the islands and the mainland ports of Fuzhou and Xiamen.
Chiu said the Central Bank of China and the Financial Supervisory Commission are currently assessing the exchange amount to be allowed.

Despite the lack of a currency settlement system between Taiwan and the mainland, several domestic banks with branches on Kinmen and Matsu, including the Bank of Taiwan and the Land Bank, have expressed an interest in operating renminbi exchange services, Chiu pointed out.
Chiu said the Executive Yuan will announce the date for the launch of the trial program after it has finalized all the relevant assessments.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REITERATES SUPPORT FOR TAICHUNG GUGGENHEIM BRANCH PROJECT

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun reiterated Thursday his administration's strong support for a high-profile project of the Taichung city government to build a branch of the Guggenheim Museum.

Yu expressed his support during the opening ceremony for the 2004 Taichung Automation Industry Exhibition held by the Commercial Times. The premier, accompanied by several Cabinet ministers, was invited to cut the ribbon to open the fair and he also delivered an address.
Leading Taichung city government officials including Mayor Jason Hu, attended the event.

The NT$6.4 billion (US$198 million) Guggenheim Taichung branch project would be partly financed by an NT$5 billion central government grant, while the local government would have to pay for the rest of the planned construction, a situation the city council has refused to accept, placing the entire project in jeopardy.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA PROCESSING FOR APPLICANTS FROM 5 ASIAN COUNTRIES SIMPLIFIED

TEXT.P: Visa processing for visitors from the Philippines, Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia and India are to be simplified, a spokesman for the Tourism Bureau said Thursday.

According to the spokesman, the Cabinet's Tourism Promotion Commission (TPC) passed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) -initiated proposal to simplify visa processing for applicants from the five Asian countries at a meeting held earlier in the day.
Hereafter, the spokesman said, visa applications by citizens from those countries will be completed in three days, as long as the applicants meet all the stated requirements.

If those applicants hold visas from the United States, Canada, Japan, Australia or New Zealand, they will be exempt from producing papers proving their financial and employment status. Wealthy ethnic Chinese in those countries or wealthy retirees in those countries will be offered similar treatment.
To encourage citizens from these countries to conduct group tours in Taiwan, the spokesman said, visa fees for groups of eight or more visitors will be halved.

Meanwhile, the MOFA will issue group visas to ethnic Chinese residing in the Bangkok area who hold a "Travel Document For Aliens" issued by the Thai government, so that they can make group visits to Taiwan.
The MOFA will also issue one-year multiple-entry visas for Indian citizens who have been to Taiwan twice.
"These measures are aimed at attracting more foreign tourists to Taiwan to realize the government's goal of doubling the annual number of tourist arrivals to 5 million by 2008," the spokesman said.

Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan presided over Thursday's TPC meeting and urged the Tourism Bureau to take advantage of the imminent resumption of direct air links between Taiwan and South Korea to launch various tourist promotional and publicity programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: AEROSPACE COMPANY GETS ORDER FROM AIRBUS

TEXT.P: Taipei, Nov. 25 (CNA The state-owned Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) has received an order worth US$9.5 million from Airbus in Germany, an AIDC official said Thursday.

The anonymous official said the AIDC will manufacture an adhesive-bonded plywood used for the trailing edge panel on four types of Airbus plane, 1,200 of which are expected to be sold around the world.

The official said the order indicates that the aerospace industry has emerged from the shadow of Sept. 11 terror attacks in the United States and is conducive to AIDC's bid to become a regular parts supplier for Airbus.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 TAIPEI GOLDEN HORSE FILM FESTIVAL OPENS

TEXT.P: The 2004 Taipei Golden Horse Film Festival kicked off Thursday at the Warner Village Cinema complex in Taipei, with the opening screening of the French film Dogora.
The event will run for two weeks through Dec. 5.

More than 100 films will be shown during the festival, covering a wide range of categories, including Masterpiece, Panorama, Asia films, Shorts and Animation, the 5th International Digital Shorts Competition, Nominated films for the 41st Golden Horse Awards, a Tribute to Noboru Shinoda, the Bela Tarr Retrospective, Made in Germany -- A Tragicomic Song of Youth, the Retrospective of Chu Yuan and Ku Lung, and Contemporary Chinese Films.

In addition to Dogora director Patrice Leconte, Japanese film directors Yoichi Higashi and Yuji Nakae are also attending the festival, bringing their new works, the Crying Wind and Shirayuri Clubs Goes to Tokyo, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO PROMOTE MACHINERY INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun vowed Thursday that the government will provide greater assistance to promoting the domestic machinery industry, eyeing its strong potential to yield a trillion dollars worth in production value.
Yu made the pledge while giving a speech at the opening of the 2004 Taichung Automation Industry Exhibition sponsored by the Commercial Times.

Pointing out that Taiwan's machinery industry is expected to expand by an annual growth rate of 25 percent to create an output value of more than NT$600 billion (US$18.6 billion) this year, Yu said the government should grant more extensive help to the traditional industry, which has made impressive efforts to transform.

He also expressed appreciation for the contributions made by machinery makers based in the central Taichung area, a stronghold of the domestic precision machinery industry, claiming that their efforts have made the traditional industry one that is capable of reaching out into the global market.
Taiwan's machinery industry ranked as the world's seventh-largest last year with a production value of NT$500 billion, up from the 2002 level of NT$450 billion.

Its export value totaled NT$352 billion in 2003, the world's fifth-largest highest level and an increase over the previous year's level of NT$326.5 billion. It is estimated that its export value for this year will amount to NT$380 billion.
More than 400 companies based at home and abroad are taking part in the automation industry exhibition in Taichung City, displaying their most advanced products at some 1,200 booths.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC APPROVES CAMPAIGN VIDEOS PRESENTED BY 5 PARTIES

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) approved Thursday promotional videos presented by five political parties to be broadcast nationwide ahead of the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Chi Chen-nan, a CEC commissioner who headed the video screening committee, said that even though the opposition Kuomintang-produced video contains defamatory slogans against the CEC, the commission still agreed to its broadcast on local terrestrial television channels based on the principle of freedom of speech.
Chi said the CEC screened the campaign videos in line with the principles of objectivity, impartiality, neutrality and legality.

Besides the KMT's video, Chi said, the CEC also approved the campaign videos presented by four other parties -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the People First Party, the Taiwan Solidarity Union and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union.

The campaign videos will be broadcast on the nation's five terrestrial television channels -- Taiwan Television Enterprise, China Television Co., Chinese Television System, Public Television Service and Formosa Television -- from Dec. 6.
According to Chi, the KMT video contains slogans such as "the Central Election Commission violates the law, is not impartial and not fair" and "Chen Shui-bian used illegal means to gain power."

As those words do not definitely violate Article 54 of the Public Functionary Election and Recall Law or Articles 21 and 22 of the Radio Broadcasting and Television Law, Chi said, the CEC's screening panel gave the green light to the video.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Two top officials are reported to quit C.I.A.
Two more senior officials of the Central Intelligence Agency's clandestine service are stepping down, intelligence officials said Wednesday, in the latest sign of upheaval in the agency under its new chief, Porter J. Goss. As the chiefs of the Europe and Far East divisions, the two officials have headed spying operations in some of the most important regions of the world and were among a group known as the barons in the highest level of clandestine service, the Directorate of Operations.
World Street Journal: Ukraine opposition prepares for nationwide protest strike.
Backed by thousands of protesters who spent a fourth night outside in the bitter cold, Ukrainian opposition leaders on Thursday prepared for a nationwide strike to protest authorities' decision to declare Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovych winner of a presidential election amid allegations of vote rigging. The West-leaning reformist candidate Viktor Yushchenko and his allies have called for an "all-Ukrainian political strike" after election officials on Wednesday declared the Kremlin- backed Yanukovych the winner of a bitterly disputed runoff ballot denounced by Western observers as fraudulent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TALKS OVER COMPENSATION FOR AMORGOS DAMAGE BREAK DOWN

TEXT.P: Negotiations over compensation for damage to Taiwan's ecology and to the government's tax revenues caused by a Greek-registered cargo ship have broken down, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Thursday.

The EPA was referring to a lawsuit it has filed with a Norwegian court against a Norway-based insurance firm over damage caused the MV Amorgos to coastal areas of the Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan.

The Norwegian court dealt with the case from Nov. 1-18, EPA officials said. In the first four days, lawyers from both sides explained their stances. In the second stage from Nov. 5-16, representatives and expert witnesses further explained these stances and conducted cross-questioning. In the final two days from Nov. 17-18, lawyers conducted final debates.
EPA officials said the defendant disagreed that it should pay any more compensation apart for the US$8.4 million it has already paid to Taiwan.
The EPA demanded total compensation of NT$350 million (about US$10.84 million).
"This means that the two parties failed to come to terms on the compensation amount and negotiations broke down, " said Lu Hung-kuang, an EPA department chief.

The Norwegian court has yet to hand down its judgment, Lu said, adding that this is just the first trial. After the court hands down its verdict, both the defendant and the plaintiff can appeal the case to a higher court.

On Jan. 14, 2001, the Amorgos, on its way from Indonesia to mainland China, ran aground near Kenting National Park in Pingtung County due to bad weather. A large amount of fuel oil aboard the freighter leaked into the surrounding waters and contaminated some 7,000 square meters of the coastal area within the Lungkeng Ecological Reserve.

According to EPA estimates, the Amorgos oil slick caused a total of NT$350 million in financial losses to Taiwan, including NT$90 million in tax revenues and economic losses, NT$240 million in damage to fishery and coral resources and the costs needed for rehabilitation, as well as NT$18 million in ecology monitoring costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S INCREASING MILITARY BUILDUP THREATENS REGIONAL STABILITY

TEXT.P: Beijing's increasing military buildup poses a threat to the stability of the Asia-Pacific region, an aide to President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday.

James Huang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said that countries in the region should pay more attention to the threat created by the expansion of mainland China's military forces to regional balance and stability because it is not a problem for just one country but a common issue affecting the whole region.

Huang made the remarks when commenting on reports that both Japanese Vice Foreign Minister Ichiro Aisawa and Vice Minister of Defense Agency Hiroshi Imazu denied that Taiwan provided the Japanese authorities with information on a recent intrusion of a mainland Chinese submarine into Japan's territorial waters.
Huang said it is regrettable that the Japanese officials issued the denial. However, he added, Taiwan will continue to do its best to maintain the Asia-Pacific region's stability and security.
A mainland nuclear submarine intruded into Japan's territorial waters Nov. 10 for which the Beijing authorities apologized to Japan Nov. 16.

In a meeting with Japan's Interchange Association President Reijiro Hattori last Friday in Taipei, President Chen told his guest that Taiwan provided Japan and the United States with intelligence about the intrusion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TARGETS FOREIGN STUDENTS, INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCES

TEXT.P: A panel under the Executive Yuan decided Thursday to target young foreign students and international conferences in its effort to attract foreign tourists to Taiwan.

In order to do so, the panel for developing and promoting tourism charged Cheng Li-chiun, chairwoman of the National Youth Commission, with soliciting foreign students and Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang with selling Taiwan as an ideal venue for international conferences.
The panel also decided to bid to host the 2006 World Youth and Student Travel Conference.

Su Cheng-tien, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, told the panel that young students accounted for 20 percent of the world's tourists in 2002 and is expected to make up a 25 percent share in 2005.

By hosting the 2006 World Youth and Student Travel Conference, Su said, Taiwan will get the chance to showcase its hospitality to young people around the world and therefore encourage them to visit the nation.
Hosting other international conferences will have a similar effect on local tourism, Su said.

Tourism Bureau statistics show that 2.4 million foreign travelers arrived in Taiwan in the first ten months of this year, which represents a 36.4 percent growth over the same period of 2003 but a minus 1.38 percent growth from 2002.
The bureau ascribed the poorer-than-hoped-for performance to "outbreaks of avian flu in the first and second quarters of this year."

However, the bureau went on, the number of foreign visitors grew by 3.19 percent in October compared to the same period of 2001 and is on track to fulfilling the whole year's goal of having 2.9 million visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL GRADUATE COURSES PLANNED TO PROVIDE HI-TECH WORKERS

TEXT.P: To meet the country's strong demand for hi-tech manpower, the government is planning to launch special graduate courses to help provide domestic industry with skilled hi-tech professionals, a government official said Thursday.

Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh made the announcement at a forum sponsored by the Industrial Technology Research Institute on ways to foster well-trained manpower for Taiwan's key high tech industries. Scores of representatives from government agencies, research institutes and universities took part in the forum.

Stressing that human resources are vital to Taiwan's industrial upgrading, Ho acknowledged that the gap between supply and demand in the domestic job market has been widening. She said that Taiwan industry is keen, in particular, on luring fresh masters degree and doctorate graduates from local post-graduate schools.

In an effort to help Taiwan-based businesses recruit sufficient hi-tech workforce, the government is planning to finance special graduate courses at universities in conjunction with demand from different sectors according to their needs, she said.

Under the terms of the program, cooperating enterprises will have to hire at least 70 percent of the graduates, while the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the companies will jointly raise the funds for the courses, she explained, adding that recruitment of candidates is slated to begin soon.
For the time being, the program aims to train 5,000 qualified workers in three years for the companies involved in the project, she said.

In addition, she went on, the government will offer better scholarships to attract foreigners to study and develop their careers in Taiwan while considering how to provide greater access for immigrants with technology expertise.

The government is poised to do its best to educate and train a hi-tech workforce and keep them at home amid fierce foreign competition, she said, pointing to Singapore as an example, which she said has claimed to lure 3,000 talented professionals from Taiwan.

Speaking on the same occasion, Industrial Technology Research Institute President Johnsee Lee pointed out that Taiwan will face a shortage in experienced hi-tech workforce supply of about 13,900 through the period ending in 2006, mainly in the biotech, nanotech, semiconductor, display, digital-content and telecommunications sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUDGMENT IN PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CASE TO BE HANDED DOWN DEC. 30

TEXT.P: A lawsuit seeking to annul the March 20 presidential election went through its last oral proceeding Thursday and the Taiwan High Court set a date of Dec. 30 to hand down its judgment.

The suit brought by the defeated presidential candidate, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and his running mate, People First Party Chairman James Soong, asked the court to throw out the election on the grounds that it was flawed and unfair.

Attorneys for Lien and Soong argued in Friday's hearing that President Chen Shui-bian, who won the election by a slim margin, held a referendum alongside the election in a move designed to boost his campaign, which skewed the election outcome in his favor.
They also claimed that the Central Election Commission (CEC) failed to carry out the election properly, citing what they described as "mistakes" as evidence.

Attorneys for the CEC defended the validity of the election on the grounds that the errors, committed unwittingly by CEC workers, did not reverse the final results and should not make the election null and void.

The lawsuit is one of two cases brought by Lien and Soong. The other, in which Lien and Soong asked the court to invalidate Chen's election on the same grounds, was turned down by the Taiwan High Court Nov. 4. Lien and Soong have appealed against that ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR NOV. 26 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, Nov. 26:
08: 30, The 48th Assembly of Presidents of the Association of Asia-Pacific Airlines will open at the Grand Hyatt Taipei.
10: 00, The Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) will issue survey reports on Taiwan's economic prospects for November at the TIER headquarters.
10: 30, Vice President Annette Lu will hold a news conference at the Presidential Office on the nomination process of Control Yuan members.
10: 30, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference at the council's headquarters.
10: 30, The organizers of an international conference on cardiovascular disease will hold a news conference at the Taipei International Convention Center.
13: 30, The 2004 Taiwan-Latin America Forum will open at Tamkang University's Taipei campus.
15: 00, The organizers of the 2004 Chinese Taipei Badminton Open will hold a news conference at the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports building.
16: 00, The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) will issue a report on Taiwan's economic situation for October at the CEPD headquarters.
16: 00, The Ministry of Economic Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
16: 15, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will meet the press at Taipei City Hall.
16: 30, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-lung will depart for the United States via the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
18:00, An international seminar on a new constitution for Taiwan will be held at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., ITALY SECURE BERTHS IN SECOND ROUND OF FUTSAL CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: Italy and the United States became the two Group C teams to qualify for the second round of the FIFA Futsal World Championship Thursday.

Italy secured its berth after a 4-2 victory over Paraguay at the Linkou Gymnasium in Taoyuan County, while the United States won its place by drawing 1-1 with Japan in the Taiwan University Gymnasium.
The other four teams which have already qualified for the the second round are Spain, Ukraine of the Group A, and Brazil, Czech Republic of the Group B.
In another game played at the Taiwan University Gymnasium, Chinese Taipei broke its duck by scoring two goals against Ukraine, although it was trounced 7:2.
Chinese Taipei has given its opponents 20 goals in its previous two matches without scoring.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Nov. 26, or the 15th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1688: Louis XIV, king of France also known as "the Sun King," declares war on the Netherlands. His reign, the longest in French history, was characterized by the construction of a magnificent court at Versailles and the expansion of French influence in Europe.
1836: John McAdam, Scottish inventor of the macadam road surface which has done so much to improve the comfort of travel on roads, dies at the age of 80.
1905: The "Min Pao," a newspaper founded by the Revolutionary Alliance, publishes its first issue in Tokyo. Dr. Sun Yat-sen's article introducing his political ideas in a set of doctrines called the Three Principles of the People, appears in the newspaper.
1906: The Southern Manchuria Railway Company is established in Tokyo, through which Japan dominates much of the southern Manchurian economy.
1906: Theodore Roosevelt returns to Washington, D.C. from Central America, becoming the first U.S. president to travel abroad while in office.
1922: Charles Schultz, American cartoonist who created the highly successful "Peanuts" comic strip, is born.
1936: Chungshan Hall (formerly Taipei City Hall) is inaugurated.
1941: Lebanon gains independence from France.
1942: Soviet troops encircle a quarter of a million German troops at Stalingrad, relieving the siege and routing Gen. von Paulus' Sixth Army.
1965: France launches its first satellite into orbit.
1957: The Republic of China Navy sinks six Communist Chinese warships north of Kinmen.
1966: The world's first tidal power station is opened by Gen. de Gaulle on the Rance Estuary near St. Malo in Brittany.
1971: British law bans schools from punishing students with the lash.
1974: Kakuei Tanaka, Japanese prime minister, resigns after allegations of irregularities concerning the Rockheed scandal.
1976: The ROC Cabinet approves a trade agreement with Uruguay.
1976: The Fourth Conference of the Asian Composers' League and the Second Asia-Pacific Music Conference opens in Taipei.
1976: Paraguayan Ambassador Brig. Gen. Timoteo Alvarenga presents his credentials to ROC President Yen Chia-kan.
1979: The International Olympic Committee votes to admit Communist China.
1980: Dr. Shen Chung-han, an expert in agriculture, dies of illness in Taipei at the age of 86.
1982: The "China's Spring" magazine is founded in New York by a group of Chinese democracy movement activists including Wang Pin-chang.
1983: A gang of thieves breaks into the Brinks-Mat security warehouse at Hethrow Airport, neutralizes the alarm system, ties up six guards, and pulls off Britain's biggest ever robbery, getting away with 25 million pounds (US$46 million) worth of gold bullion.
1990: Feng Yu-lan, a noted Chinese philosopher, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 94.
1990: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore resigns after 31 years in office and is succeeded by Goh Chok Tong.
1998: Japan expresses "deep remorse" for its actions in China during World War II in a joint declaration during a visit by Jiang Zemin.
1999: President Rene Harris of the Republic of Nauru reaffirms his support for the Republic of China's bid to participate in international organizations.
2000: Republican presidential candidate George W. Bush is certified the winner of Florida's decisive 25 Electoral College votes.
2001: Republic of China Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Chairperson Chang Fu-mei inspects the Taiwan Science and Technology College of Thailand in the northern province of Parnam.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "Of all seeds, the best are the five kinds of grain, but if they are not ripe, they are not equal to the `ti' and the `pai'. So the value of benevolence lies simply in its being brought to maturity."

Transportation workers led by jeepney drivers held a nationwide strike yesterday to protest, among others, the successive increases in the prices of fuel, but the protest action waned in the afternoon following government assurances of discounts in petroleum products, particularly diesel oil.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Nayan: Incredible journey of faith
"IT'S GOOD to be back home," said a well-scrubbed Angelito Nayan in his opening remarks during his first appearance on Philippine media at Malacanang last night. Nayan, who worked as an election officer for the United Nations in Afghanistan, is back home after a 26-day ordeal as captive of a breakaway Taliban group.
The Philippine Star: Strike strands thousands
After reaching a compromise with the government, transport groups called off their strike midway through it yesterday, but not without stranding thousands of commuters and forcing the cancellation of classes in Metro Manila and other key cities nationwide earlier in the day.
The Manila Times: Strike paralyzes Metro transport
Thousands of commuters were left stranded and school classes were suspended throughout the Philippines Thursday as transport workers struck over rising fuel costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ADDRESSES TAIPEI AVIATION MEETING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said on Friday that Taiwan has adopted a flexible and pragmatic air transportation policy.

The president made the comments while addressing the opening of the 48th Association of Asia Pacific Airlines (AAPA) Assembly of Presidents in Taipei. The assembly is being sponsored by China Airlines, Taiwan's largest civil air carrier.

The president noted that civil aviation is a high-tech transportation industry. Faced with a new situation after joining the World Trade Organization Jan. 1, 2002, Taiwan has actively worked to improve its airport facilities, navigation equipment and outbound traffic connection systems to upgrade service quality, he said.

Taiwan has also made an overall review and adjustment of the ratio of various airport fees, established an airline assessment system, reviewed and revised related regulations, and actively engaged in exchanges with other nations and international organizations, shaping a flexible and pragmatic air transportation policy, the president said.

Chen also affirmed the AAPA's contribution to the regional aviation industry, noting that compared with the performance of airlines in other areas, the AAPA can be proud of itself. He added that at a time when the global aviation industry has been affected by economic slump, the airlines in the Asia-Pacific region have continued to provide high-quality service and to make satisfactory profits.

The AAPA currently groups 17 major airlines, including Taiwan's China Airlines and EVA Airways, in the Asia-Pacific region. The AAPA Assembly of Presidents is sponsored each year by member airlines on a rotational basis, providing a forum for the airline leaders to exchange views on the aviation industry's prospects.
The last such meeting in Taipei took place in 1989, with China Airlines also sponsoring that gathering.

Major topics to be discussed at this year's assembly include new developments in U.S. aviation policy, rising world crude oil prices, risk hedging strategies, premiums and war risk, as well as the emergence of budget airlines.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times:MM relates his personal struggles with language.
The man who started Singapore on the road to bilingualism 40 years ago rose in Parliament yesterday to defend the policy, but also explain why it must now undergo a radical shift.
It is in recognition that the vast majority of people can master only one language, and that parents should have the choice over which master language they want for their children, said Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew.
The Lianhe Zaobao:MM Lee:Students will pay a greater price if learn the easy and simple Chinese language only.
Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew ask students and parents to do their best in learning Chinese language.
If children choice the easy way to learn the low level Chinese language,they will pay a greater price for this in the future,said MM Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO SEEK LAW AMENDMENTS TO DENY MAINLAND SPOUSES CITIZENSHIP

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will push to amend the existing laws governing cross-strait relations in order to deny citizenship to mainland Chinese people married to Taiwan citizens out of national security considerations, the TSU party whip in the Legislative Yuan said Friday.

At a press conference, TSU lawmaker Chen Chien-ming said that according to existing laws, mainland Chinese spouses of Taiwan citizens can serve in government organizations and have the right to vote in Taiwan, which he claimed could eventually allow mainland Chinese authorities to exert influence on Taiwan's politics.
Chen said the TSU will seek amendments to the existing laws so that mainland spouses of Republic of China nationals can only be granted residency, instead of full ROC citizenship.
He said that according to government tallies, the number of mainland Chinese-Taiwan married couples totaled roughly 190,000 as of the end of 2003.

The lawmaker claimed that if all these mainland spouse obtain full ROC citizenship, which entitles them to vote in Taiwan elections and even to run for public office, Beijing could possibly use their political weight to influence Taiwan's domestic affairs.

Noting that many Western countries, including the United States and Canada, have laws explicitly banning the entrance of people from "enemy" or "hostile" countries, Chen claimed that Taiwan's laws allowing mainlanders to enter and work in the country are tantamount to "tossing the nation's sovereignty down the drain."

Considering the fact that Beijing continues to deploy ballistic missiles targeting Taiwan and to refuse to renounce the option of force to settle cross-strait differences, Chen said, Taiwan should only grant mainland spouses residency, which he said allows them access to many privileges, including work permits and national health insurance, instead of granting them full citizenship.

DOC.HEADLINE: 48 PUBLIC OFFICIALS IMPEACHED IN FIRST 10 MONTHS OF YEAR

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan, the nation's supreme watchdog body, said Friday it impeached a total of 48 public officials in the first 10 months of this year, with officials from the Ministry of National Defense (MND) accounting for the lion's share.
Ku Teng-mei, a Control Yuan member, made the remarks during an inspection tour of the Executive Yuan along with her colleagues.

Quoting constitutional provisions, Ku said the Control Yuan is authorized to censure and impeach local and central government-level public officials as well as to rectify administrative agencies under the Executive Yuan.
"We hope the relevant administrative departments can make efforts at resolving these problems once and for all, " Ku said during a meeting with Cabinet members.

"Some of the problems involve different departments, and we hope the Executive Yuan can coordinate and integrate the resources of different agencies to facilitate the solving of relevant problems, " she added.
Among the public officials impeached between January and October, 14 were from the MND, five from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), and four from the Council of Labor Affairs.
During the 10-month period, the Control Yuan decided in a total of 130 cases to ectify various government agencies' administrative measures.

From February 1999 to October 2004, 300 public officials were impeached, with 80 coming from the MND, 38 from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, 24 from the MOTC, 23 from the Ministry of the Interior and 21 from the Ministry of the Justice.
During the same period, the Control Yuan decided in a total of 947 cases to rectify various government agencies' administrative measures.
The six-year tenure of the incumbent Control Yuan members will expire Jan. 31, 2005.

DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Rush to build roads is jamming up the traffic.
Millions of motorists endure daily congestion because the Highways Agency has been too slow to introduce simple measures that would keep traffic flowing smoothly, according to the Government's spending watchdog.

The Inland Revenue on Thursday accused the British film industry of abusing government aid, with every production of recent years deliberately over-claiming tax relief.

Ukraine's Top Court To Review Election; Decision to Hear Fraud Charges Buoys Opposition.
Ukraine's Supreme Court on Thursday blocked the inauguration of Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovych, the declared winner of Sunday's presidential election, and agreed to hear arguments that the vote had been tainted by fraud. The development shifted some momentum to supporters of opposition candidate Viktor Yushchenko.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES DROP

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 76.59 points to close at the day's low of 5,778.65.
The bourse opened at 5,883.59 and fluctuated between 5,935.20 and 5,778.65 during trading. A total of 3.9 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$87.1 billion (US$2.7 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction shares moving down the most at 2.3 precent, followed by banking and financial shares at 2.2 percent, textile stocks at 2.0 percent, foodstuff issues and paper and pulp shares, both at 1.4 percent, machinery and electronics issues at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.5 percent, and cement stocks at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 556 to 110, with 110 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE IDENTIFY 'RICE BOMBER' VIA DNA TESTS

TEXT.P: Police said Friday a man who turned himself in a day earlier is very likely the "rice bomber" responsible for more than a dozen bomb threats in Taipei over the past year.

Hsieh Ing-dan, director-general of the National Police Agency, said test results show that the physical DNA specimens of the suspect, Yang Ju-men, match with most specimens collected from the evidence left at the crime scenes.
However, Hsieh said prosecutors will need to conduct further investigations before the case can be announced as "resolved."

Since Nov. 13 last year, a man claiming to oppose the government's policy of permitting rice imports has placed home-made explosives in public areas such as parks, trains, railway stations and mobile toilets.
One of the devices exploded outside the Legislative Yuan building in June and another outside the Ministry of Education building earlier this month.

Yang turned himself in to police in the company of his brother on Thursday, the same day police released a picture and filmed image of the alleged "rice bomber" and offered a reward of NT$500,000 (US$15,479) for information leading to his arrest.
But Yang later denied he was involved in those cases during questioning by police.
According to Taipei district prosecutor Cheng Ke-sheng, Yang is "highly connected" with 11 of the 16 cases that allegedly were committed by the "rice bomber" as shown by the DNA tests.
Police also found some suspected sketches of threat letters, timers and unidentified powder after a search at his residence.
Yang, 26, sells chickens in Keelung. He received blast training while serving in the marine corps, police said.
According to law, a person can be sentenced to death if convicted of making explosives without permission.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Ukraine court delays results in vote dispute.
Ukraine's Supreme Courton Thursday temporarily blocked the victory of Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich in the disputed presidential election, barring publication of the Central Election Commission's results until the court reviews complaints of widespread fraud and abuse. When the losing candidate, Viktor A. Yushchenko, said to the thousands of demonstrators that complaints of election abuse would be heard in court, the demonstrators erupted in cheers.
Wall Street Journal: Ukraine High Court to Rule on election.
Ukraine's Supreme Court suspended certification of the results of the Presidential Election and said that on Monday it will consider opposition charges that the vote was tainted by massive fraud. The move left the announced winner, Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovych, unable to formally take office at least until the appeal is decided. Yanukovych was declared the winner of Sunday's runoff election by a margin of about three percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY 3% OF KMT'S 'ILL-GOTTEN' ASSETS RETURNED TO NATION: LAWYER

TEXT.P: Only three percent of the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) "ill-gotten" assets acquired over five decades in power have been returned to the nation, while some three-quarters have been transferred to "third party" private individuals, government-hired lawyers said Friday.

Lin Yong-sung, chief attorney of a group of legal counselors that has been enlisted by the Executive Yuan for probes into the KMT's "ill-gotten" assets, said the land that the KMT and its affiliated organizations had owned totaled 254,637 square feet, with a value of over NT$20.9 billion (US$649 million).

Of that total, three percent has been relinquished by the KMT and returned to the national coffers; 18 percent is still under the ownership of the KMT or its affiliates; 75 percent has been transferred to "third party" private individuals; and two percent is state-owned land that has been used by the KMT without payments, Lin noted.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun said last month that the Executive Yuan will retrieve the KMT-held assets which he claimed were "robbed" from the people. "The government cannot tolerate this kind of exploitation and will make every effort to retrieve the 'booty, '" Yu also said at the time.

Lin said that the Executive Yuan will via legal process try to have the KMT make full reimbursement to the nation for the 75 percent of the assets that it has already sold, as well as pay 5 percent in interest charges.

The KMT "booty" includes land and buildings that were used during the Japanese-colonial era, land and buildings that the Taiwan Provincial Government handed out when it was disbanded, and land and buildings that were required by the government for public use when the KMT was still in power, Lin added.

The Kuomintang announced last December that it was relinquishing ownership of two major buildings and seven movie theaters in Taipei City as part of efforts to clear its name in the wake of a spate of criticism of the party for "embezzling" national assets.

Chang Che-sen, director-general of the KMT Administration Management Committee, claimed that most of the party's assets -- many of which are described by party rivals as "ill-gotten assets" -- are "a historical legacy" that have made significant contributions to the country.
However, despite reluctance, the KMT has since last year continued to give up these assets and return property to the original "donors," Chang said.

According to Chang, KMT Chairman Lien Chan announced in September 2002 that the party would undertake a sweeping consignment of party assets back to their former owners in an effort to recuperate some of the former ruling party's image and dignity.

Lien said that a total of 120 land lots and 42 buildings would be returned to their former owners, mostly local governments around the island that gave the property to the KMT as donations in the years when the KMT was in power.
As of August 2003, according to Chang, 120 out of the 165 land lots that the KMT had been using had been returned to their original donors, constituting a completion rate of over 80 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE TRAVEL AGENCY, AIRLINE REPS TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A group of representatives of travel agencies and airlines in the Philippines will visit Taiwan later this month on a promotional campaign sponsored by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Manila, an official of the office said Thursday.
Shih Tzung-Jen said the trip is part of the ROC government's campaign to promote tourism with the goal of doubling the number of visitors to the island by 2008.
TECO will provide free round-trip tickets and tourist information to help the group better understand Taiwan, Shih said.
During the four-day trip beginning Nov. 27, the group will make stops at famous attractions around Taiwan, including the Taipei 101 building, the National Palace Museum, and Kengting National Park.
