DOC.HEADLINE: DENYING M'LAND SPOUSES CITIZENSHIP WOULD VIOLATE HUMAN RIGHTS: KMT

TEXT.P: The idea of denying citizenship to mainland Chinese spouses of local residents runs counter to the notion of human rights protection, a group of legislators from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Friday.

The KMT lawmakers were criticizing an announcement by the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) earlier the same day that it would push to amend the existing laws governing cross-strait relations in order to deny citizenship to mainland Chinese people married to Taiwan citizens out of national security considerations. The KMT legislators called the TSU initiative "an infringement of human rights."
KMT Legislator Chiang Yi-wen asked whether Taiwan could still be considered a democratic country if the legislature were indeed to amend the relevant laws to deny mainland spouses full citizenship.
"If lawmakers harbor hostility toward certain groups of people, then marginalization and hatred will prevail in Taiwan society, " Chiang claimed.
He added that an individual's rights protected by the Republic of China's law or the ROC Constitution should not be infringed upon for political reasons.
Meanwhile, KMT Legislator Chu Fong-chi pointed out that Taiwan must emulate advanced Western countries in the treatment of so-called "new immigrants."

Chu urged legislators as well as government workers to be broad-minded toward the nation's new citizens. "So long as the new immigrants recognize Taiwan as their new home, we should welcome them with open arms," he added.

At a press conference earlier in the day, TSU party whip Chen Chien-ming said that according to existing laws, mainland Chinese spouses of Taiwan citizens can serve in government organizations and have the right to vote in Taiwan, which he claimed could eventually allow mainland Chinese authorities to exert influence on Taiwan's politics.
Chen said the TSU will seek amendments to the existing laws so that mainland spouses of ROC nationals can only be granted residency, instead of full ROC citizenship.
He said that according to government tallies, the number of mainland Chinese-Taiwan married couples totaled roughly 190,000 as of the end of 2003.

The lawmaker claimed that if all these mainland spouse obtain full ROC citizenship, which entitles them to vote in Taiwan elections and even to run for public office, Beijing could possibly use their political weight to influence Taiwan's domestic affairs.

Noting that many Western countries, including the United States and Canada, have laws explicitly banning the entrance of people from "enemy" or "hostile" countries, Chen claimed that Taiwan's laws allowing mainlanders to enter and work in the country are tantamount to "tossing the nation's sovereignty down the drain."

Considering the fact that Beijing continues to deploy ballistic missiles targeting Taiwan and to refuse to renounce the option of force to settle cross-strait differences, Chen said, Taiwan should only grant mainland spouses residency, which he said allows them access to many privileges, including work permits and national health insurance, instead of granting them full citizenship.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO WORK PRAGMATICALLY TOWARD 'TAIWAN UN BID'

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will study and work pragmatically to materialize President Chen Shui-bian's idea of Taiwan seeking to enter the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan," a MOFA spokesman said Friday.
Michel Lu said that Taiwan has tried over the past 12 years to enter the U.N. with the title of "Republic of China, " but this has not been met favorably by the international community.

Lu said that Chen's advocacy is not only an effort to safeguard the interests of Taiwan's people, but also makes known Taiwan's resolve to take part in international organizations and related activities.
Chen said during a campaign rally a day earlier that Taiwan should make its bid to join the U.N. using the name "Taiwan" rather than "Republic of China."

He also promised that he would lead Taiwan to become one of the members of the World Health Assembly (WHA) within two years, saying that Taiwan is a sovereign nation of 23 million people whose rights and interests cannot be excluded from international society.
Lu said MOFA will made further studies of the feasibility of Taiwan's U.N. and WHA bids and will readjust strategies to facilitate the bids at the earliest possible date.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO MONITOR BIGEYE TUNA FISHING IN ATLANTIC

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Friday that next year will be critical to Taiwan's fishing industry because of serious concern in the international community about Taiwan's overfishing of bigeye tuna in the Atlantic.
James Sha, deputy director-general of COA's Fishery Administration, said that the government will adopt clear and effective improvement measures to address the issue.

The measures will include the continuation of a monitoring system for Taiwan fishing boats, random checks at overseas harbors or final destination harbors, rigorous screening of fish hauls, ensuring that long-fin tuna vessels have not fished for bigeye tuna, ensuring that bigeye tuna fishing vessels report their hauls every month to make sure they have not exceeded their quotas and close cooperation with other nations to apprehend poachers.

Sha said that the vessels must also exercise strenuous self-discipline and should not take chances, adding that if violations are detected, the fishery administration will deal with them severely, to the extent of revoking operating licenses.

In the recently concluded International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) meeting, Japan and several other nations accused Taiwan vessels of poaching and the U.S. delegation demanded talks with Taiwan and Japan.

The Taiwan delegation admitted that there could be "isolated cases" of poaching, but claimed the practice is not widespread, saying that the scale of the illegal activity in the Atlantic totaled 4,000 tons at most and not the 20,000 tons claimed by Japan.

Taiwan promised that it will strengthen management and deduct the overfishing quota annually and the ICCAT agreed to give Taiwan one year of probation and continue to give it a quota until a review next year. If there is still no significant improvement in violations, Taiwan's qualification to fish in the Atlantic will be revoked, and it will also face the serious consequences of trade sanctions.
Fishery officials said that the international community has demanded that Taiwan cut its fishing fleet and the government is now mapping out a plan to cut 50 ships within five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ANIMATION SHOULD LEARN FROM JAPAN, KOREA: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's animation industry could learn from Japan and South Korea -- some of whose animation products tell profound and dramatic stories -- to sharpen its competitiveness in the world market, a Taiwan official said Friday.

Huang Kuo-chun, director of the digital content industry promotion office under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and deputy chief executive of the quasi-official Institute for Information Industry, said at a Taipei workshop of Taiwanese and Japanese animation businesses that Taiwan's digital creations, including video games and animation films, display innovatory scenes lack drama.

Forging cooperative relations with Japanese animation creators, whose products have already successfully made inroads into world markets, could be a good way to develop Taiwan's animation industry, he said.

Representatives of well-known animation businesses from Japan, including Shogakukan Inc., Milky Cartoon Co. Ltd., NTT Data Contents Planning Corporation, GONZO and Japan Digital Contents Inc., attended the one-day workshop in Taipei in the hope of forging cooperative ties with Taiwanese companies in the animation sector.

A total of 13 local businesses participated in the activity aimed at promoting exchanges and development of the animation markets in Taiwan and Japan. The workshop was tied in with the upcoming Taipei animation exhibition that will open Nov. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REGRETS JAPAN'S DENIAL OF SUB INTELLIGENCE OFFER

TEXT.P: The government expressed regret Friday that Japan denied Taiwan's claim that it provided Tokyo with intelligence about the intrusion of a mainland Chinese nuclear-powered submarine into Japanese waters earlier this month.
Su Tseng-chang, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said it is regrettable that Japan issued the denial.
Su said Taiwan and Japan should cooperate to maintain regional security in the face of mainland China's military buildup and intrusion into the territorial waters of other countries.
The mainland nuclear-powered submarine intruded into Japanese territorial waters Nov. 10, for which the Beijing authorities apologized to Japan Nov. 16.

During a meeting with Japanese Interchange Association President Reijiro Hattori Nov. 19, President Chen Shui-bian said that Taiwan was the first to detect the intrusion and that it alerted Japan and the United States to the matter.
However, officials from Japan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Defense Agendy denied Thursday that was the case.
Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Japan's handling of the case was understandable yet regrettable and was probably the result of orders from the mainland.

Meanwhile, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman Chang Jung-kung claimed that Japan's denial has done "serious harm" to Taiwan and he asked President Chen to give the people an explanation to protect the national dignity.
Questioning Chen's credibility, Chang also claimed that it was also unlikely that Japan, which is equipped with the latest anti-submarine frigates, would have missed the mainland submarine.

DOC.HEADLINE: 188 CANDIDATES RECOMMENDED FOR CONTROL YUAN SEATS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that a total of 188 hopefuls have been recommended for fourth-term Control Yuan seats.

Among the candidates, 107 were self-recommended, 63 were recommended by professional or social groups and 18 are incumbent ombudsmen who have expressed interest in serving another six-year term in the Control Yuan, the nation's supreme watchdog body, Lu said, adding that the candidates include 170 males and 18 females.
The new ombudsmen recommendation panel, headed by Lu, began to accept reference letters Nov. 5 and stopped accepting referrals Nov. 24.
Judging from the number of recommendation letters received during the period, Lu said, Control Yuan seats are still held in high esteem.

Lu said the recommendation panel will screen all reference letters in two stages. In the preliminary stage, 60 candidates will be selected from among the 188 hopefuls. In the second phase, 40 candidates will be chosen from the 60 short-listed names.

The list of 40 finalists will then be presented to President Chen Shui-bian for his reference in nominating candidates for Control Yuan seats, Lu said, adding that Chen is expected to nominate candidates for 27 Control Yuan seats, as well as for the Control Yuan presidency and vice presidency, by mid-December.

According to the present version of the Additional Articles of the Constitution, nominations for the Control Yuan require the consent of the Legislative Yuan. The present legislature is expected to vote on the nominations before its term expires Jan. 31, 2005.
Lu said the recommendation panel will abide by the principles of openness, impartiality and fairness in choosing the finalists.
Neither the Presidential Office nor the Executive Yuan have recommended anyone, Lu stressed, adding that the president himself has also not made any recommendations.

During the news conference, Lu displayed a recommendation letter from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) legislative caucus suggesting that incumbent Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng be named the next Control Yuan head.
However, Lu said, the recommendation panel will not deal with the DPP recommendation because it is the president's right to decide candidates for the Control Yuan presidency and vice presidency.

Wang, a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, is seeking re-election in the Dec. 11 legislative elections and has publicly dismissed the DPP recommendation as an ill-motivated "joke." He said he has no interest in the top Control Yuan post.

According to Lu, the recommended hopefuls include incumbent and former elected representatives as well as retired officials, private business executives, literary celebrities, artists, accountants, medical doctors and elite members from other professional fields.
"Among the hopefuls are many former officials and elected representatives from the opposition 'pan-blue alliance' of the KMT and the People First Party," Lu added.

Members of the recommendation panel include incumbent Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien and Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang, as well as Chang Chien-pang, a senior adviser to the president, Hsiao Hsin-huang, a national policy adviser to the president, and Nita Ing, chairwoman of the Taiwan High-Speed Railway Co., who is also an adviser to the president. Chien has made clear that he will retire from public service after his current tenure expires.
The new Control Yuan members will assume office Feb. 1, 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVISED DRAFT OF REFERENDUM LAW SEEKS TO LOWER THRESHOLD

TEXT.P: A revised draft of the Referendum Law will dramatically lower the threshold for passing a referendum proposal, an official of the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Friday.

Chuang Kuo-hsiang, a section chief of the MOI's Civil Affairs Department, made the remarks at a seminar convened by several environmental protection groups on the eve of the first anniversary of the passing of the Referendum Law.

The groups claimed that the thresholds for the initiation and establishment of referendum topics are too high, so that except for a "defensive referendum" initiated by President Chen Shui-bian and held alongside the March 20 presidential election, no proposals have yet been established as a referendum topic since the law cleared the opposition-dominated Legislative Yuan Nov. 27 last year.
Chuang said that the revised draft law makes revisions on several controversial points, including lowering the threshold to establish a proposal and the abolishment of a screening committee.

The screening committee, which is composed of members recommended by political parties in proportion to the number of seats they occupy in the legislature, should be abolished, he said, so that representative politics will not supersede those of a direct democracy.

The threshold for initiating a referendum topic would also be lowered from the current over 80,000 votes to just 8,000, while the threshold for petitions to establish a topic will be cut from the current 800,000 to 300,000, according to the revised draft.

Current provisions say the people should not resubmit the same topic within three years if they have withdrawn the topic, abandoned a petition drive or failed to implement a referendum, but Chuang said that the provision would be dropped under the revised draft law.

He said that although over 90 percent of the people who cast ballots in the first nationwide referendum March 20 agreeing with the two questions -- whether to strengthen Taiwan's anti-missile defense capability and whether to negotiate a peace framework with mainland China -- they were considered invalid because fewer than half of the eligible voters took part.

Chuang said that to truly reflect the will of the people, the regulation that half of the voters should take part in the voting would be dropped and that if over 25 percent of registered voters t agree with the topic and outnumber those who are against, then the proposal would be valid.
But on such topics as a change of the national boundaries or constitutional amendments, the approval rate would have to top 50 percent to be considered valid under the revised law draft, Chuang said.

Lin Wen-yin, vice president of the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union, said that there are still flaws in the Referendum Law and he urged a speedy revision by legislators across the party spectrum on the controversial parts after the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Chou Sheng-hsin, convener of the Alliance for a Peaceful Homeland, said that the law stipulates that the initiators of proposals must collect 825,360 signatures within six months to have the proposal established, which she said is too difficult.

She pointed out that the threshold of 825,000 is 3.6 percent of the population, compared to the ratio of 0.8 percent in Italy to have a proposal established, 1.1 percent in Switzerland, and 0.6 percent in California. Taiwan's civil rights are not getting due attention, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60% OF TAIWAN MANUFACTURERS NEUTRAL ON ECONOMIC PROSPECTS

TEXT.P: Taipei, Nov. 26 (CAN) Over 60 percent of Taiwan manufacturers are neutral about their economic prospects in the next six months, according to a survey by a local think tank.

The results of the survey conducted in October by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) show that the ratio of manufacturers optimistic about their economic prospects in the next six months dropped to 12.21 percent from 37.4 percent in September, while those who are pessimistic dropped slightly to 21.3 percent from 22.1 percent.
Those who felt their economic situation would remain the same increased dramatically to 66.4 percent from 40.4 percent the previous month.
TIER Vice President Hung Teh-sheng said that the ratio of those who are optimistic dropped significantly because most manufacturers tend to become more conservative as the year draws to an end.
Meanwhile, the TIER also adjusted its prediction for the average exchange rate of the new Taiwan dollar to the U.S. greenback to NT$32.2 for next year.

The researchers said the world financial community has expected an appreciation of mainland China's renminbi. This, coupled with Taiwan's large foreign exchange reserves and its huge trade surplus, while foreign institutional investors continue to flock into the Taiwan market, are expected to add tremendous pressure for appreciation of the Taiwan dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INVESTIGATION BUREAU CITED BY TOKYO CUSTOMS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Nov. 26 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) was cited by the Tokyo Customs Office Friday for its successful cooperation with Japanese law enforcement authorities in thwarting cross-border drug trafficking.
It marked the first time the MJIB has ever been publicly recognized for contributions to Japan's war on contraband drugs.

Yang Kuang-chuan, director of the MJIB's Narcotics Investigation Center, headed a group of staff members that attended the citation ceremony, which was held in connection with the Tokyo Customs' 51st founding anniversary.

Also cited for their contributions to international cooperation in the fight against drug trafficking were Hong Kong and Canadian customs authorities, Israeli police and the Australian Embassy in Japan.
Keiji Fujiwara, director of Tokyo Customs Office, presented citations to representatives from the MJIB and the other foreign authorities during the award ceremony.
Fujiwara expressed his heartfelt gratitude for the assistance from the foreign authorities in preventing contraband drugs from entering Japan.

By cooperating with the MJIB, Japanese law enforcement officers have managed to uncover two large-scale cross-border drug trafficking cases in the past two years. In one case, Japanese police successfully intercepted 113 kg of amphetamines that were being smuggled into Japan.

Law enforcement officers from Taiwan and Japan have increased exchanges of visits and information in recent years to enhance their efficiency in joint operations against drug trafficking. The MJIB has also posted officers at Taiwan's representative office in Japan to facilitate bilateral crime-fighting cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT, SALES RISE IN TAIWAN EXPORT PROCESSING ZONES IN 2004

TEXT.P: The government approved 41 new investment projects and 72 cases of additional investment worth a total of NT$35.97 billion (US$1.12 billion) in export processing zones (EPZs) around Taiwan from January to November this year, according to official statistics released Friday.
The amount represents a 35.98 percent rise over last year, according to a report by the Export Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Sales amounted to NT$297.8 billion during the 10 months to October, up 22.91 percent compared with the same period of last year, the report shows.
The electrical and machinery equipment manufacturing sector posted the highest sales at NT$231.8 billion, a growth of 22.47 percent from last year's level.
Chou Yen, director of the EPZA, said the structure of EPZs in Taiwan has experienced a fundamental change over the past 30 years.
While foreign investors used to account for 80 percent of the investment in the past, domestic businesses have replaced foreign investors as the major investors, Chou said.
Chou said the EPZA is working to renew plants in the zones to try to attract more investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA TRYING TO SABOTAGE TAIWAN'S TIES WITH VANUATU: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Mainland China is going all-out to sabotage Taiwan's ties with Vanuatu and Taipei is keeping a close eye on the situation, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Friday.

Addressing wire service reports that Australia is cutting down on its aid to Vanuatu, Lu said it is "obviously Beijing" that is twisting Australia's arm to pressure Vanuatu to back down from a Nov. 3 agreement with Taipei to strike diplomatic ties.
Lu said Beijing's former ambassador to Vanuatu has flown to Port Vila to see if he could use his personal influence with Vanuatu leaders to reverse Premier Serge Vohor's decision.
Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kau Ying-mao who is in Port Vila will see to it that the newly forged diplomatic ties are not nipped in the bud, Lu said.
Vanuatu's parliament will meet next week, Lu said, adding that Vohor is confident he can convince the parliament that the diplomatic ties with Taiwan serve the country's best interests.
Vohor, who complained that Beijing's promise of aid has not materialized, extended diplomatic recognition to Taipei Nov. 3 in exchange for a promise of an unspecifed aid.
But his government has since been caught in a diplomatic tug-of-war between Taipei and Beijing, both of whom have gone out of their ways to woo the friendship of the tiny South Pacific island state.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, NICARAGUA TO OPEN 2ND ROUND OF FTA TALKS NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Delegates from Taiwan and Nicaragua are slated to hold a second round of free trade agreement (FTA) talks next week in San Francisco, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials said Friday.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long and his Nicaraguan counterpart Alejandro Arguello will conduct the negotiations on behalf of their respective governments in the meeting, which will open Monday, the officials said.

Officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the MOEA, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Justice, the Department of Health, the Council of Agriculture, the Financial Supervisory Commission and the Directorate General of Telecommunications will make up the bulk of the Taiwan delegation.

The two countries are expected to reach agreement on issues related to plant and animal quarantine, investment and the protection of intellectual property rights during the new round of talks, which will be divided into five panels, the officials said, adding that the MOEA hopes to conclude all the talks and sign an FTA accord by the end of the first half of next year.

According to Chen, Taiwan and Nicaragua exchanged customs tariff reduction lists for agricultural and farm products prior to the San Francisco negotiations, which will help two-way substantive talks conclude sooner.
The two countries finished their first round of FTA talks in late September in Taipei, making Nicaragua a would-be second FTA partner of Taiwan, after Panama.
Two-way trade in the first 10 months of this year totaled US$226 million, up by 117 percent over the previous year's level.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH SPEED RAIL CORP. REACHES SETTLEMENT WITH EUROTRAIN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) reached a settlement Friday with its former partner, Eurotrain, wherein THSRC will pay US$65 million in damages to Eurotrain, THSRC officials said Friday.
Compared with an arbitration ruled by the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) early this year, the new settlement saves THSRC US$24 million, the officials said.
THSRC teamed up with the Eurotrain consortium in 1996 to make a bid to construct Taiwan's first high-speed railway, and won the US$16 billion contract in 1997.
However, THSRC ditched Eurotrain for Japan's Shinkansen consortium in 1999, on the grounds that Eurotrain charged too high a price for its system and refused to become a shareholder of THSRC.
Eurotrain filed for arbitration with the ICC in 2001.
The ICC issued an arbitration award March 15, 2004, wherein THSRC was ordered to pay US$73.04 million in damages and interest to Eurotrain.
The payment, along with the interest payable, had amounted to US$89 million as of Nov. 26, THSRC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE NABBED IN CONNECTION WITH MURDER OF TAIWANESE FAMILY IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Police in the mainland Chinese city of Dongguan in Guangdong Province have arrested a man in connection with the murder of a Taiwanese family of three and their maid, according to news arriving here Friday.
The man arrested is a carpenter who was hired to decorate the family's house, and probably killed the family to steal their money, said Dongguan police.
The Taiwanese, Chang Chien Rung-kun, his pregnant spouse, their daughter and a maid were found murdered in their home early Friday.

However, Deputy Secretary-General of the Straits Exchange Foundation Yen Wang-chin said in Taipei that he is not certain the pregnant woman and child are Chang Chien's wife and child because local newspapers said his wife and their children live in southern Taiwan. He said the SEF is helping Chang Chien's Taiwan family members to visit Dongguan.

Yen said the SEF will urge its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, to prod the Chinese police into investigating the case aggressively and bringing the killer or killers to justice as soon as possible.
Chang Chien operated a factory manufacturing jewelry in Dongguan and was polite to others, according to his Taiwanese friends in Dongguan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TIMETABLE FOR TRIAL RENMINBI EXCHANGE SERVICE ON KINMEN: MAC

TEXT.P: The government has yet to decide on the timing for opening a mainland Chinese currency exchange service on the frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu on a trial basis, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Friday.

Chiu made the remarks in response to a press inquiry as to whether the proposed experimental renminbi exchange service will be implemented simultaneously with the arrival of the first tourists from mainland China's Fujian Province to Kinmen and Matsu for pleasure trips in December.

If the mainland indeed begins to allow its Fujian Province residents to visit the two outlying islands in December, Chiu said the proposed opening of experimental renminbi exchange services will become more urgent.
Nevertheless, he said, the government must still follow established operational procedures in launching the service on the islands, both of which lie closer to Fujian Province than to Taiwan.
Chiu said the MAC began to weigh the feasibility of the new service in July and started preparatory work in August.

"Once the regulation-drafting work is completed, the package must be put up for approval by MAC commissioners before being referred to the Cabinet for final endorsement. The Cabinet will then decide on the exact enforcement timing," Chiu said.

According to media reports, the mainland will allow Fujian residents to make sightseeing trips to Kinmen and Matsu in the first half of December, with the first such tour group headed by Huang Xiaoyen, director of the Fujian Provincial Travel Bureau.

Chiu said the government has long had preparations in place for mainland citizens making sightseeing trips to Kinmen and Matsu and travel agents in the two outlying islands are also well prepared for receiving mainland tourists.
In consideration of hotel and tourism facilities on the two islands, Chiu said the daily mainland tourist ceilings for Kinmen and Matsu are 600 and 100, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TYPE OF FLU TO BE DESIGNATED AS STATUTORY COMMUNICABLE DISEASE

TEXT.P: A new type of influenza will be formally designated as a statutory communicable disease in mid-December, making it subject to stringent controls and preventive measures, the Department of Health (DOH) said Friday.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control (CDC) , made the remarks after the World Health Organization (WHO) warned a day earlier that the world is closer to the next flu pandemic "than we have ever been before" and that it may kill 2 million to 7 million people and infect more than 1.5 billion.
Shih said the DOH made te decision as Taiwan is adjacent to avian flu mutation high-risk areas such as mainland China, Thailand and Vietnam.
Shih said the DOH completed a comprehensive response plan in August in preparation for any possible flu pandemic.

Once the flu is listed as a statutory communicable disease, people who show suspicious flu symptoms and have come into contact with poultry within the previous 10 days or who have traveled to avian flu-affected countries must immediately seek medical treatment and physicians will decide whether to collect blood samples for testing and whether to offer anti-flu drugs.

Shih said the CDC has stockpiled 2.3 million tablets of Tamiflu, a drug for treating flu. Moreover, the CDC has decided to increase Tamiflu stocks to 23 million tablets for the use of 2.3 million people. In addition, the CDC will invest US$10 million in research and development of flu vaccines.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY SLOWS, SIGNALS GREEN LIGHT FOR OCTOBER: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy displayed a green light for October, an indication that domestic economic activity had turned from heating up to steady, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Friday.
The green light was a change from the yellow-red light for September, which signals a booming economy.

The green light for last month was the first for the country's economy since Dec. 2003, as the leading index stood at 106.7, down from 108 in September, while the current index dropped to 110.2 from 110.9. The October composite index showed a fall to 29 points from 32 points a month earlier.
The other colors in the five-color rating system designated by the CEPD are red, indicating an overheated economy, yellow-blue, representing sluggishness and blue, pointing to recession.

Hu Chung-ying, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, attributed the declines in the major economic indexes for October to various key factors at home and abroad, such as the central bank's interest rate hikes, the effects of typhoons, soaring world oil prices that surged to nearly US$60 a barrel, growth in the local wholesale price index (WPI) and fewer work days in the month.

Statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that the WPI increased by an annual growth rate of 12.02 percent last month -- the highest single-month growth rate since 1980.
In October, outbound shipments expanded by only 7.7 percent in value, a noticeable drop from September's 15 percent, according to the DGBAS tallies.

As signs are clear that both the domestic and world economies have slowed in the second half of this year, an economist said it is not a surprise development and suggested that there is nothing to worry about.

Chou Chi, chief of the economic forecast center at the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research, said that business conditions at home are expected to remain stable through the end of this year with a slim chance of a further worsening.
Chou, however, pointed out that a much-anticipated strengthening of mainland China's renminbi next year will be a major element that will affect Taiwan's business climate for the whole of 2005.

The fluctuations in the value of the mainland currency will have a profound impact on the competitive edge of Taiwan companies, as many of them use the mainland as a manufacturing base for their exports to other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-JAPAN NUCLEAR SAFETY CONFERENCE TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 19th Taiwan-Japan nuclear safety conference will open Nov. 29 in Taipei with some 170 government officials, experts specialized in nuclear power generation and management of radioactive materials, and representatives of related businesses participating.

Officials of the state-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower), which is organizing the conference, said the main topics to be discussed at the meeting will include the construction, operation and maintenance of nuclear power plants, the management of radioactive waste and used nuclear fuel, radiation protection and prevention, emergency management, nuclear power policies and transparency of information.
Taiwan will be represented by officials of the Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council, the Institute of Nuclear Energy Research and Taipower at the two-day meeting, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISM CONFERENCE STAGED ON KINMEN

TEXT.P: The 2004 Taiwan Tourisn Conference opened on the outlying island of Kinmen Friday, gathering together more than 300 members of the visitors associations from all over Taiwan.
Later that day they toured the island in preparation for a meeting Saturday to exchange views on ways to promote tourism.
The conference is expected to release an announcement upon its close calling for sightseeing exchanges between Kinmen and mainland China and an upgrading of Taiwan's domestic tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-SWEDEN DOUBLE-TAXATION AVOIDANCE PACT TO TAKE EFFECT NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: A double-taxation avoidance pact between Taiwan and Sweden has been ratified by the Swedish parliament and is set to take effect Jan. 1 next year, according to an official from Taiwan's representative office here.

The Swedish parliament ratified the pact Nov. 11 and a copy was presented to Taipei Representative to Sweden Chiu Chung-ren in exchange for a copy ratified by Taiwan's legislature, which is the last step before the pact enters into force.
The official said Sweden is Taiwan's biggest trade partner in Scandinavia. About 40 Taiwan companies operate in Sweden and two-way trade reached US$1 billion last year.
The pact will further promote bilateral trade, said the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARGENTINA, PORTUGAL ADVANCE TO SECOND ROUND OF FUTSAL CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: Argentina and Portugal joined six other nations Friday to advance to the second round of the FIFA Futsal World Championship by defeating their respective rivals in the preliminaries.
Argentina beat Iran 6:1, while Portugal blanked Cuba 5: 0 in the last two games of the first round of the two-week championship that opened in Taipei Nov. 21.
The other six countries that secured berths in the second round are Spain, Ukraine, Brazil, the United States, Italy and the Czech Republic.
The second round of the tournament will begin Nov. 28 and will run through Dec. 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: CUSTODY SOUGHT FOR MAN SUSPECTED OF PLANTING BOMBS AROUND TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A prosecutor sought court approval Friday to take into custody a man suspected of planting bombs around Taipei in the last year.
Cheng Ke-sheng, a prosecutor at the Taipei District Court, said Yang Ju-men, the suspected bomber, should be taken into custody to prevent him for jumping bail or tampering with evidence.
Yang accompanied his brother to a police station in Taipei Thursday evening and waited outside as his brother told police that he is the wanted bomber.

His brother also asked for a reward of NT$500,000 offered by police for information leading to the arrest of the bomber, who has planted at least 17 explosive devices since last November, with notes on them expressing opposition to the government's policy of opening the local market to foreign rice, earning himself the nickname "the rice bomber" in the newspapers.
No-one has been hurt by Yang's explosives.
The police offered the reward only Wednesday after making public a picture of the rice bomber caught on a surveillance camera.
Yang denied his brother's allegations but tests found that his DNA matches that of specimens found on evidence collected from the crime sites.
Born into a farming family in southern Taiwan, police believe Yang has the motive to oppose the government's market-opening policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Nov. 27, or the 16th day of the 10th month of the year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1505: Ivan III, Russia's first tsar and also known as "Ivan the Great," dies at the age of 65. His victories against the Tatars laid the foundation for eventual Russian unity.
1662: Charles II, king of England, Scotland and Ireland, sells Dunkirk, a seaport in northern France on the English Channel, to King Louis XIV of France. In World War II, more than 330,000 Allied troops were evacuated from its beaches in the face of enemy fire.
1701: Anders Celsius, the Swedish astronomer who invented the Celsius temperature scale, is born.
1919: A massive meteor lands in Lake Michigan.
1921: Yen Fu, a noted translator who introduced western science and literature to China, dies in his home town in Fujian Province at the age of 67.
1926: Communists revolt in Java, Indonesia.
1927: Mao Zedong leads his followers to Chingkangshan in China's Kiangsi Province where he begins to establish a base for the Chinese Communist Party.
1930: The "Wushe Incident" breaks out in central Taiwan when a group of aboriginal citizens launch a rebellion against Japanese rule, killing 134 Japanese.
1940: Chinese-American actor and martial arts expert Bruce Lee is born.
1947: The Republic of China and the United States sign a relief treaty in Nanking under which US$30 million-worth of material will be shipped to Taiwan.
1950: United Nations troops retreat southward in Korea.
1953: President Syngman Rhee of the Republic of Korea arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1953: American playwright Eugene O'Neill, winner of the Nobel Prize in literature in 1936 and four-time winner of the Pulitzer Prize, dies at the age of 65.
1962: Britain agrees to provide arms to India to resist Communist Chinese aggression.
1967: President Charles de Gaulle of France vetoes British entry into the European Common Market.
1974: The ruling Kuomintang of the ROC confers the Chungshan Medal, its highest decoration for meritorious service, on Madame Chiang Kai-shek for her outstanding contribution toward national goals and ideals.
1975: ROC Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan and his Dominican counterpart, Ramon Emilio Jimenez, sign the Sino-Dominican Cultural Agreement.
1978: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt are jointly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for their efforts toward bringing about a settlement to the Arab-Israeli conflict.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda resigns after being defeated in a party poll.
1979: The ROC Olympic Committee lodges a strong protest with the International Olympic Committee against the postal ballot on the China representation issue, calling it a violation of the Olympic spirit and legal procedures.
1979: Saint Vincent gains independence from Britain.
1994: Israel establishes diplomatic relations with Jordan.
1996: A gas explosion in a coal mine in Shanxi Province in mainland China kills more than 91 miners.
1996: South Africa says it will switch full diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing on Jan. 1, 1998.
1999: Taiwan's Rene Liu, winner of the Best Actress Award at the 1999 Asia-Pacific Film Festival in Bangkok, says that she has been overwhelmed with happiness since learning she had won the award.
2000: King Harald of Norway opens the Laerdal Tunnel, the world's longest road tunnel at 16.9 kilometers.
2001: The National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) announces the establishment of a cancer research center under the leadership of its vice president, Hsieh Chang-yao.
2001: Visiting Republic of China Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Chairwoman Chang Fu-mei pledges that the ROC government will never forget the descendants of ROC nationals living in northern Thailand. She makes the remarks at the closing ceremony of the seventh Chinese-language teacher's seminar held in a village in the northern province of Chiang Rai where a group of former ROC Army soldiers have lived for over 50 years after retreating from mainland China in 1949 following defeat by the Chinese communists.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The way (of truth) is like a great road; it is not difficult to know it. The evil is only that men will not seek it. Go home and seek it, and you will have an abundance of teachers."

DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Ukraine Court to Rule on Election.
The Supreme Court on Thursday temporarily blocked publication of disputed presidential election results naming Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovich the winner, bolstering opposition supporters, who say pro-Western contender Viktor Yushchenko won.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROMOTING FRUITS IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) is currently sponsoring a two-week activity in a Hong Kong chain supermarket to promote Taiwan fruits.
TAITRA began the promotion activity at 50 PARKnSHOP stores in Hong Kong Nov. 25 at the commission of the Council of Agriculture.
The focus of the promotion activity is on Taiwan's seasonal fruits, including oranges, papayas, grapefruits, pineapples, starfruit, guavas and pomelos, TAITRA officials said.

They noted that Hong Kong has been a major market for Taiwan's agricultural products. They also noted that PARKnSHOP is the largest chain store in Hong Kong and that it also distributes fruits to the mainland.

The officials further said they hope the two-week promotion activities will help upgrade the image of Taiwan agricultural products and expand their market share in Hong Kong as well as help them make inroads into the markets of the Greater Pearl River Delta in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER EXPECTS PEIYI EXPRESSWAY TO BE COMPLETED TWO MONTHS EARLY

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun on Saturday expressed the hope that the Peiyi Expressway project could be completed two months ahead of schedule.
Construction work on the 31-km Peiyi Expressway, which connects Shihting in Taipei County and Suao in the northeastern county of Ilan, is scheduled to be completed in December 2005.

While inspecting the project in Ilan County, Yu pointed out that he had always demanded during his term as Ilan magistrate that public construction projects be completed three months ahead of schedule.

Yu said he hopes the engineering team of the Peiyi Expressway project will step up the pace and have the project completed two month earlier in order to provide time to deal with any problems that may arise.
The 12.9-km Shueishan Tunnel, the centerpiece of the project, was bored through in September. It is the longest highway tunnel in Asia and the fifth longest in the world.
After the freeway is completed, driving from Taipei to Ilan will take only 40 minutes, compared with more than two hours required at present.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CONSTITUTION NECESSARY FOR TAIWAN'S SURVIVAL: FORMER PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Denying Taiwan the right to have a new constitution is tantamount to denying Taiwan the right to survive, former President Lee Teng-hui claimed Saturday.

Speaking at the opening of an international seminar on a new constitution for Taiwan, the former president said that the current Republic of China Constitution is an impediment to Taiwan's democratic development and that the Taiwan people need to discard it.
Taiwan's democracy will be suffocated to death if the current ROC Constitution is not done away with and a new one is not set in its place, Lee continued.

Lee boasted that he amended the ROC Constitution six times during his 12-year presidency to give back to the people the right to rule the country, adding that he found during his time in office that he was facing a stone wall whenever he tried to further Taiwan's democracy.

Lee said the ROC Constitution defines a territory for the nation that overlaps with territory that other countries claim sovereignty over, which he claimed has resulted in contradictions and conflict. He added that instead of improving the country's stability, the ROC Constitution gives Beijing the excuse to claim sovereignty over Taiwan, and therefore plunges the country and the region into crisis.

Furthermore, Lee claimed that the ROC Constitution was crafted without the participation or approval of the Taiwan people, adding that it goes against the notion of democracy to impose this constitution on the people.

Claiming that the people's right to write their own constitution is a basic human right acknowledged by the United Nations, Lee urged the world to support Taiwan's bid to create a new constitution which he said will lay the groundwork for the country's future development.
The two-day seminar organized by the Taiwan Advocates, a private think tank founded by Lee in 2001, has drawn 28 domestic and 17 foreign scholars.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-GREEN' MAJORITY IN LEGISLATURE NEEDED TO END UNREST: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday called for the public to support the "pan-green camp" in the Dec. 11 elections to help it form a majority in the new legislature and end the political uncertainties and social unrest with constitutional reform.
Chen made the call at the opening of an international seminar on a new constitution for Taiwan. Former President Lee Teng-hui also spoke at the seminar held at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.

Asking for the public support for the "pan green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), Chen stressed that Taiwan needs a suitable constitution to deal with the fast changing world and to secure its survival and sustainable development.

The president said that he is determined to hold a referendum on putting forth a new constitution for Taiwan by the end of 2006 and to hold another referendum on implementing it, on May 20, 2008, when his current term ends.
He vowed to put an end to the current political instability and social unrest in Taiwan with a new constitution if the "pan green camp" wins a majority in the 225-member Legislative Yuan.
If the "pan green camp" can win more than half the seats, he continued, a constitutional re-engineering task force will begin operations immediately after the elections.
He also urged the international community to realize that the constitutional reform in Taiwan is key to helping create peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region and the rest of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOTE ALLOCATION STRATEGY BOUND TO FAIL FOR 'PAN-BLUE': DPP WHIP

TEXT.P: The vote allocation strategy is bound to fail for the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) , a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) predicted Saturday.

Tsai Huang-liang, DPP whip in the Legislative Yuan, made the remarks amid reports that the ruling and opposition political parties have both adopted the ballot allocation strategy under the current multiple-seat constituency election system to ensure that as many of their candidates as possible get elected in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
The DPP has decided to use the strategy in 13 constituencies, and it will also work with its ally Taiwan Solidarity Union in four of these constituencies.

With only two weeks to go before election day, the KMT and the PFP have agreed to use the strategy in eight cities and counties -- namely the cities of Kaohsiung and Chiayi, and the counties of Nantou, Tainan, Ilan, Lienchiang (Matsu), Hualien and Taitung.

PFP Chairman James Soong said Saturday that the two parties will make final assessments and plans on large constituencies, such as Taipei City, Taipei County and Taoyuan County, one week before the elections.

However, DPP whip Tsai said that the opposition political parties have their own axes to grind and that it will be difficult for them to use the strategy. Moreover, the "pan-blue alliance" has never used the strategy before, and their supporters tend to vote based on a individual candidate's merits and not on party affiliation, he continued, adding that the non-cooperative attitude of the individual candidates of the opposition parties also exacerbates the situation.
Tsai said that the DPP has used the vote allocation strategy for years and that the party's supporters have better teamwork spirit, which he claimed will ensure that the strategy works for his party.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR PRESIDENT TO STEP DOWN FROM DPP CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan on Saturday challenged President Chen Shui-bian to resign from his post as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in order to end the "party-state" era in Taiwan.

During a campaign rally in Taichung County, Lien said the DPP has recently focused its criticism of the KMT on the "party-state" system during the period of KMT rule while at the same time trying to build its own "party-state."

Lien pointed to President Chen's concurrent role as DPP chairman and to the fact that all the Cabinet ministers are acting as campaigners in the Dec. 11 legislative elections to back up his claims of the DPP's intentions to build a "party-state."
Lien demanded that Chen step down from the DPP chairmanship and that the DPP remove itself from all media operations, state-run enterprises and financial institutions to set a proper example.

He said that the country has lost its direction after four years DPP rule, with the Republic of China founding father Sun Yat-sen being called a "foreigner" and the history of the ROC being defined as "ancient history."
The KMT chairman said that the Dec. 11 elections are not only a chance for the people to choose their legislators, but also a moment for them to decide the future of the country.

He said the elections are about whether the ROC will continue to exist, whether peace will be achieved across the Taiwan Strait, whether the country will move toward dictatorship and demagoguery, and whether reconciliation will arrive in Taiwan society.

Lien criticized the DPP government for avoiding a number of serious problems facing the country, saying the DPP has so far failed to satisfactorily respond to doubts over the presidential election-eve shooting of Chen and the NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA LENDING HAND IN SELLING ORANGES

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) is lending a hand to help promote the sale of oranges in a bumper harvest year.

The Council of Agriculture (COA) estimated that total production of oranges is expected to reach 230,000 tons this year, up 13 percent from last year. Although the COA has activated its purchase mechanism to deal with the overproduction, the move has not been sufficient to offset the losses to orange growers caused by slumping prices.
The TAITRA, which is mainly responsible for export promotion, has therefore decided to pitch in by helping sell oranges at home and overseas.

Taiwan's oranges mainly go to Southeast Asia, Hong Kong and mainland China, and the TAITRA recently invited importers from Singapore to come to Taiwan to taste the oranges and bring some samples back home. The two sides are now discussing export prices, and TAITRA officials have said they are optimistic that a deal can be clinched.

The officials noted that Taiwan oranges are sweet and succulent, although some foreign buyers have complained that it is troublesome to eat them because of their thick skin and have thought that selling them as juice might be a good idea.
The officials said that they have persuaded businesspeople to deliver large juice mixers when they export oranges, and to sell both oranges and orange juice.

Meanwhile, noting that the annual "information month" activity to be held at the Taipei World Trade Center in early December always attracts large crowds, the officials said that they have invited fruit growers from southern Taiwan to set up pavilions selling oranges and orange juice outside the exhibition sites.
They estimated that at least 130 tons of oranges could be sold during the Dec.4-12 exhibition period.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR CALLS FOR A NEW CONSTITUTION TO CONFIRM TAIWAN'S SOVEREIGNTY

TEXT.P: A scholar called for a new constitution to confirm Taiwan's sovereignty during a seminar Saturday organized by the Taiwan Advocates, a private think tank, to beat the drums for a new constitution for the country.

Lee Yung-chih, a professor of history at National Taiwan University, said Taiwan belongs to the people living on the island, and not China, adding that this fact will be more clear when the Taiwan people deny that they are Chinese.

Under Beijing's threat of the use of force against the country, Lee claimed, many Taiwanese are afraid of admitting they are Taiwanese. Instead, they have claimed their country to be the Republic of China, which doesn't exist, according to Lee.

Although the ROC Constitution has been amended six times, Lee said, it will never be able to suit the needs of Taiwan because it wasn't originally formulated for the country. Taiwan therefore needs its own constitution which is made for it and has nothing to do with China.

Chen Tzu-yang, a law professor at National Taipei University, said at the seminar that a constitution formulated in 1991 by a National Assembly elected in Taiwan is the first example of a constitution created by the Taiwan people, regardless of what name was given to that constitution.

As to a new constitution for Taiwan, which President Chen Shui-bian has vowed to promulgate by 2008, it should define the country's system of government and the division of power between the central and local governments, as well as ensure a separate and independent judiciary, the law professor said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN SPEAKER TURNS DOWN CONTROL YUAN POST

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng on Saturday turned down President Chen Shui-bian's offer to appoint him to head the Control Yuan.
Wang said he is not interested in becoming the Control Yuan president as he is one of the at-large legislative candidates nominated by the opposition Kuomintang.
Wang made the remarks in response to inquiries by reporters while hosting the opening ceremony of a national tennis tournament in Kaohsiung City.
President Chen is expected to nominate candidates for 27 Control Yuan seats, as well as for the presidency and vice presidency of the watchdog body, by mid-December.

While campaigning for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party candidates for the Dec. 11 legislative elections in Hsinchu last Friday, Chen said he was considering nominating Wang for the post of Control Yuan president.
The present legislature is expected to vote on the nominations before its term expires on Jan. 31, 2005.
The new Control Yuan members will assume office on Feb. 1, 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: UTAH GOVERNOR TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The governor of the U.S. state of Utah is set to arrive in Taiwan Sunday at the head of a six-member delegation for a four-day visit, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Saturday.

Governor Olene Walker is coming to Taiwan to sign a cooperation agreement with the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the officials said. She is also scheduled to pay visits to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Mainland Affairs Council and the American Institute in Taiwan.
Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen and Taiwan Provincial Governor Lin Kuang-hua are scheduled to host parties in honor of the visiting governor.
Utah established sisterhood with Taiwan Province in 1980 and several cities in Utah also maintained sisterhood with their Taiwan counterparts.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARKET VALUE OF LISTED FIRMS FALLS NT$539.2 BILLION FOR THE WEEK

TEXT.P: The combined market value of listed companies in Taiwan dropped NT$539.2 billion (US$16.72 billion) , or 3.93 percent, over the previous week, according to a report released Saturday by the Taiwan Stock Exchange Co. (TSEC).
The drop was mainly due to the appreciation of the new Taiwan dollar and weak buying support by foreign institutional investors, the TSEC said in the report.

The market value of listed companies amounted to NT$13.17 trillion at the end of Friday's trading, with the weighted index finishing 4.11 percent lower than a week earlier at 5,778.65, on a turnover of NT$345.99 billion.
Share prices for all 20 categories moved down this week, with the exception of steel and iron, cement, and composite shares, the report said.

While the steel and iron sector performed well, with stocks moving up 1.88 percent, electronics, banking and insurance, and electrical appliances shares were among the weakest performers, falling 5.02 percent, 4.19 percent and 3.74 percent, respectively.
There have been 225 trading days on the Taiwan Stock Exchange so far this year, with a combined turnover of NT$22.62 trillion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECO HELPS OUT AT YWCA CHARITY BAZAAR IN BANGKOK
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Nov. 27 (CNA) (By Wu Hsie-chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Thailand participated in a high-profile charity bazaar held by the Young Women's Christian Association (YWCA) in Bangkok Saturday.

Peng Shuei-ying, wife of the head of TECO, Taiwan's de facto embassy in Thailand in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, said that goods donated by Taiwan businesses operating in Thailand were popular at the bazaar, with the three booths set up for the donations enjoying brisk sales.

The annual bazaar, entering its 51th year, was organized by wives of ambassadors to Thailand of more than 30 countries to raise money for the elderly, poor and challenged people, as well as women and children welfare organizations in the Southeast Asian country.
At last year's YWCA bazaar, Taiwan raised more than 140,000 Thai baht (US$3,550) , the largest amount of any of the countries taking part in the event, Peng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOTERS URGED TO CHOOSE LEGISLATORS BASED ON THREE GOOD ATTRIBUTES

TEXT.P: A civic organization has called for voters to cast their ballots for candidates in the Dec. 11 elections based on three good attributes.

The Association of Elite Councilors, which was formed to nurture political leaders at the grass-roots level, urged voters in a press conference Saturday to choose legislative candidates with good upbringing, professional training and strength who are ready to fight against the irrational.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said that Taiwan needs more quality legislators to address the current chaotic situation in the Legislative Yuan.
He said that the current election system tends to encourage those who are willing to create disturbances and attract media attention.
He urged voters to choose legislative candidates based on the three good attributes so as to let the nation move forward toward a promising future.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST BUDGET AIRLINE EDGES INTO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Nov. 27 (CNA) (By S.J. Kang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: JetStar Asia, a budget airline based in Singapore, confirmed a media report Saturday that it will open a regular route between Taipei and Singapore in December to provide travelers with cheaper trips between the two cities.

The opening of the route will make JetStar Asia the first low-cost airline to edge into the Taiwan air travel market, an executive for the carrier said, noting that the company is confident of making handsome earnings from the lucrative route -- one of the most popular in Asia.
JetStar Asia will make public the exact ticket price and the date of the route opening in two weeks, the executive said.
Business sources forecast that JetStar Asia's cheaper ticket prices will have a noticeable impact on other airlines that fly between Taipei and Singapore.

However, China Airlines and EVA Airways Corp., Taiwan's two largest carriers, claimed that they are not worried about the entry of JetStar Asia, on the grounds that the consumers they target are different.
In addition to Taipei, the budget airline is also planning to offer flight services to Hong Kong, Shanghai, Jakarta, Manila and other destinations in the region from January next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURISM AGENTS CALL FOR CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES VIA 'MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: Representatives from the domestic tourism industry signed a declaration Saturday on the frontline island of Kinmen, urging the government to allow tourist exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China via the existing "mini three links."

More than 300 officials of tourist associations from 25 cities and counties around Taiwan inked the declaration, calling on the government to relax the rules governing the "mini three links" -- the direct trade, postal and transportation links between the Taiwan-held islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Fujian Province -- to bolster bilateral tourist exchanges, forge peace and boost understanding between the two sides.
The representatives demanded in the document that the government allow people from Taiwan to take pleasure trips to mainland China via Kinmen or Matsu using only their Republic of China passport.
They also urged the government to allow mainland citizens to visit Taiwan for sight-seeing or business purposes via the two offshore islands instead of via Hong Kong or Macau as currently required.
Such moves will help Kinmen and Matsu build a security and tourist corridor in the Taiwan Strait, they said.

Lai Cheng-ying, chairman of the Taiwan Federation of Visitors Associations, expressed their hope that Kinmen and Matsu could be turned into a transshipment hub in two-way travel and for an eventual full opening of tourist exchanges between Taiwan and the mainland.

In the face of the expected inflows of visitors from Fujian Province in the wake of the mainland authorities giving the go-ahead, Lai said that the Taiwan tourism industry representatives really hope that the government will make the moves swiftly to help inject a new lease on life into the domestic tourism industry.
The tourism agents from across Taiwan were taking part in the 2004 Taiwan Tourism Conference on Kinmen, which opened a day earlier.
According to news reaching here, the Fujian tourism authorities have recently approved five local tourist agencies to operate tourist trips to Taiwan's Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKERS CRITICIZE PRESIDENT FOR REVEALING INTELLIGENCE INFO

TEXT.P: Two opposition People First Party (PFP) legislators urged President Chen Shui-bian Saturday not to let out military secrets.

Lawmakers Liu Wen-hsiung, convener of PFP caucus in the Legislative Yuan, and Lee Tung-hao criticized President Chen for telling Japanese Interchange Association Chairman Reijiro Hattori on Nov. 19 that Taiwan tipped Tokyo off about the intrusion of a mainland Chinese nuclear-powered submarine into Japanese territorial waters Nov. 10. Japan protested to the mainland Chinese government about the submarine intrusion, and Beijing apologized for the incident Nov. 16.

The two PFP lawmakers said that as the head of state, Chen should not reveal the nation's intelligence work or the level of its intelligence capabilities as this is detrimental to the nation's security interests.

They also urged the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to rebut Beijing's allegations that Taiwan bribed Vanuatuan Prime Minister Serge Vohor into agreeing on Nov. 3 to establish diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

Since that date, a diplomatic tug-of-war has continued in Port-Vila, capital of Vanuatu, with diplomats from Taipei and Beijing competing against each other to woo leaders of the tiny south Pacific island nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HEAPS PRAISE ON PREMIER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday lauded Premier Yu Shyi-kun for being a good campaign strategist and a man who knows how to run a country.

The president made the remarks while stumping for legislative candidates from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the northeastern county of Ilan, where Yu served two terms as magistrate and enjoys a high-level of popularity.

Chen urged Ilan voters to throw their weight behind the candidates of the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, in the Dec. 11 legislative elections so that the camp can gain a clear majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan and thus facilitate the pushing through of the premier's administrative agenda.

Lauding Yu as the "No. 1 premier, " Chen said that the criticism by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" that the DPP administration "knows only how to campaign and doesn't know how to run a country" is unfair to the premier, as well as a serious insult to the people of Ilan.

In fact, Chen said, the premier knows both how to campaign and how to run a country, pointing out that Yu won both times he ran for a Taiwan Provincial Council seat and both times he ran for the post of Ilan County magistrate.
"Yu also contributed a great deal to my re-election in the March 20 presidential election," the president noted.

On Yu's performance as premier, the president praised him as a man "with ability and determination, " pointing out that during his premiership, he has seen the completion of the 12.9-km Shueishan Tunnel, the most difficult part in the construction of the 31-km Peiyi Expressway linking Shihting in Taipei County and Suao in the northeastern county of Ilan, launched successful dredging operations in the Keelung River, and improved the tap water quality in Kaohsiung, all of which were projects left unfinished by the previous Kuomintang administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' TO HOLD PARADE DEC. 5

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is planning to hold a large-scale parade on Dec. 5 to boost the morale of the "pan-blue alliance" ahead of the Dec. 11 legislative elections, KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said Saturday.
Lin said the party aims to rally more than 100,000 supporters of the KMT, People First Party (PFP) and New Party.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong are expected to lead the parade, Lin said.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, will also hold similar parades on Dec. 4 and Dec. 5, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: RDEC CHIEF OUTLINES 3 PRINCIPLES FOR CONSTITUTIONAL RE-ENGINEERING

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) said Saturday that constitutional re-engineering in Taiwan should be based on three principles.

Yeh Jiunn-rong said the three principles are broadening participation in the discussions, broadening the areas to be discussed, and establishing a new schedule for the re-engineering. On the third principle, he pointed to the six amendments to the current
Constitution which he said were passed quickly to deal with urgent political problems and thus overlooked important issues.

Yeh, who holds a doctorate in law from Yale University, made the remarks at an international symposium in Taipei on a new constitution for Taiwan. The symposium was sponsored by the Taiwan Advocates, a local think tank.

The two-day meeting has drawn 17 scholars from Japan, the United States, Germany, France and the Czech Republic, as well as 28 domestic scholars. Twenty-two papers are expected to be delivered at the symposium.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO SET UP NEW RADIO NETWORK TO SERVE FOREIGNERS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The government is planning to integrate the resources of the two state-owned radio stations to set up a multilingual "Voice of Taiwan" radio network to serve foreign nationals in Taiwan, the Government Information Office director-general said Saturday.
Lin Chia-lung unveiled the plan while addressing a Mandarin and Taiwanese story-telling competition for foreigners hosted by the state-owned Radio Taiwan International (RTI).
Lin pointed out that the RTI, which receives NT$500 million (US$15.6 million) in government funding every year, is mainly responsible for overseas broadcasting.

To serve foreign nationals residing in Taiwan and help them better understand the island, the government will set up a new radio network by combining the resources of the RTI and the other state-owned radio station, Voice of Han Broadcasting Network, Lin said.
The "Voice of Taiwan" will broadcast programs in a number of different languages, including Mandarin, Taiwanese, English and Japanese, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH HEAD URGES TAIWAN SOCIETY TO TREAT AIDS PATIENTS WITH COMPASSION

TEXT.P: Taiwan society shouldn't discriminate against AIDS patients and should instead accept them and show deep concern for them in order to help them deal with their illness, the minister of the Department of Health (DOH) said Saturday.
Chen Chien-jen made the remarks at a news conference held by World Vision Taiwan to announce an anti-AIDS activity called "Life Lesson."

During the news conference, Chen pointed out that on average, ten people around the world are infected with HIV every minute, and that there are currently more than five thousand HIV carriers in Taiwan.

World Health Organization experts have warned that AIDS is likely to become rampant in Asia in the future, Chen said, adding that the people of Taiwan need to deal with the issue and to treat AIDS sufferers with more compassion.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA RISKY FOR TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN AND FAMILIES: POLICE

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China as well as their family members are at high risk of being robbed, kidnapped or even murdered, police authorities said Saturday.

According to statistics provided by the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to police, a total of 72 Taiwan businesspeople or members of their families have been killed in mainland China since 1991, while 167 others remain missing.

In 1998 alone, a record high of 13 Taiwan people were murdered in mainland China, while another nine were killed in 1999. So far this year, eight Taiwan citizens have been killed on the mainland, including a recent case in Dongguan, Guangdong Province.
Among the 167 missing persons, 34 were reported in 2003, with the same number having been reported already this year, police said.

In addition, a total of 57 Taiwan citizens have been kidnapped or abducted on the mainland over the past 13 years, while 82 others have been shot, wounded or blackmailed, according to the SEF statistics.
The SEF is a quasi-official organization that deals with exchanges with mainland China in the absence of government-to-government contacts between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Big Iraqi parties are urging delay in Jan. 30 voting.
Some of Iraq's most powerful political groups, including the party led by the interim prime minister, called Friday for a six-month delay in elections scheduled for Jan. 30, citing concerns over security. The list of groups includes some that have been among the strongest backers of American policy in Iraq, and their call gives sudden momentum to those arguing for a postponement. The two main Kurdish parties supported the delay request, marking the first time the Kurds, closely allied with the Americans, have taken a clear stand on the issue.
Wall Street Journal: Will energy costs' pinch scuttle holiday spending?
Analysts are weighing whether the extra cost of energy will cause consumers to cut down their holiday spendings. They worry, too, that the effect will hit hit hardest the lower-income earners. Gasoline prices have shot up more than 60 percent from a year ago, and the cost of home heating oil has doubled in some parts of the U.S. So far, consumers' faith in the economy has remained fairly unscathed in the face of these rising costs. Americans' spending behavior has been relatively robust heading into the 2004 holiday shopping season. (Lillian Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR NOV. 28 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Nov. 28:
08:30, The international seminar on a new constitution for Taiwan will continue at Grand Hotel in Taipei.
10:30, The 2004 Taiwan Teddy Bear Show and the 2004 Taiwan Teddy Bear Creative Awards will be held at Grand Formosa Regent Taipei.
14: 00, The Formosa Heart will hold a seminar on the history of China and Taiwan at Go Go Go Union Office in Taipei.
15: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a campaign rally in Hualien City to stump for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative candidates.
15: 50, Former President Lee Teng-hui will chair a roundtable seminar on a new constitution for Taiwan at Grand Hotel in Taipei.
17:20, The closing ceremony of the international seminar on a new constitution for Taiwan will be held at Grand Hotel in Taipei.
18: 05, President Chen Shui-bian will attend the congress of Tainan First Senior High School Alumni Association in Taipei at the Armed Forces Officers Club.
19: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a campaign rally in Kangshan, Kaohsiung County to canvass support for DPP legislative candidates.
19: 30, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a campaign rally in Kaohsiung City to canvass support for DPP legislative candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Nov. 28, or the 17th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Ferdinand Magellan, Portuguese navigator, passes from the Atlantic Ocean into the Pacific via the strait which bears his name.
1582: William Shakespeare, English playwright and poet whose body of works is considered the greatest in English literature, marries Anne Hathaway.
1821: Panama proclaims independence from Spain and joins the Republic of Colombia.
1897: Germany occupies Kiao-Chow in northern China.
1912: Albania declares its independence after 400 years of Turkish rule.
1919: Nancy Astor is elected as a member of parliament for Plymouth, becoming Britain's first woman MP.
1943: U.S. President Franklin Roosevelt, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Soviet leader Joseph Stalin meet in Tehran for their first meeting to chart the future Allied course for World War Two.
1945: Dwight F. Davis, American politician and donor of the Davis Cup tennis trophy, dies at the age of 66. He was also U.S. governor general of the Philippines from 1929 to 1932.
1950: The Korean War takes a devastating new turn today when an estimated 200,000 Chinese troops pour over the River Yalu.
1951: Representatives from the United Nations and North Korea meet at Panmunjom and agree that the 38th Parallel will be the final dividing line between North and South Korea.
1958: A Republic of China missile base is inaugurated after Goddess of Victory (Hercules) missiles were installed at Linkou, Taipei.
1958: The United States announces the test-launch of its first intercontinental ballistic missile.
1960: Mauritania proclaims its independence and becomes the Islamic Republic of Mauritania.
1962: Wilhemina, queen of the Netherlands who sought refuge in England during World War II, dies at the age of 82. She abdicated in 1948 in favor of her daughter Juliana.
1967: All horse-racing is banned in Britain due to an outbreak of foot and mouth disease.
1971: Wafi Tell, Jordanian prime minister, is shot by Black September terrorists in Cairo while he is on an official visit.
1974: Vice President Yen Chia-kan and Mrs. Yen leave for Managua to attend the inauguration of Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle as the new president of the Republic of Nicaragua.
1975: Fretilin, the left-wing Revolutionary Front for an Independent East Timor, declares East Timor independent from Indonesia.
1979: An Air Zealand DC-10 crashes in Antarctica, killing all 258 people on board.
1985: Communist China formally applies for membership in the Asian Development Bank.
1987: A South African Airways Boeing 747 plunges into the Indian Ocean off the coast of Mauritius, killing all 160 people on board, including 30 passengers from Taiwan.
1990: Margaret Thatcher, British prime minister since May, 1979, hands her resignation to Queen Elizabeth II. Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major is later formally appointed to take her place.
1998: Claude Roussel, co-founder of Agence France-Presse, dies at the age of 79.
1999: Economic Minister Wang Chih-kang says in Seattle that Australia and France have indicated their support for Taiwan's early entry into the World Trade Organization.
2000: Rescuers struggle to find survivors after devastating floods and landslides on the island of Sumatra kill more than 100 people in Indonesia.
2001: The Republic of China and Japan reach an agreement at the 26th ROC-Japan Economic and Trade Meeting to strengthen bilateral exchanges and economic cooperation.
2001: Taiwan becomes a permanent cooperative member of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT).
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The people are the most important element (in a country); the Spirits of the land and the grain are next; the ruler is the least important."
