DOC.HEADLINE: 500 ABSCONDERS NABBED IN 1 MONTH WITH HELP OF VIETNAMESE OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: In a sweeping operation, Taiwan police authorities have managed to round nearly 500 absconders in a one-month period, with the help of Vietnamese officials, sources from the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Sunday.

Taiwan police authorities, backed up by labor affairs officials from the Vietnam Economic and Culture Office (VECO) in Taipei and Vietnamese labor brokers, successfully nabbed during the recent one-month period nearly 500 Vietnamese laborers or caregivers who had absconded from their Taiwanese employers, CLA officials said.

Under mounting pressure from the Taiwan authorities, who had threatened to freeze imports of Vietnamese laborers if absconding was not checked before the end of 2004, the Vietnamese authorities have summoned some 100 labor brokerage personnel from Vietnam to Taiwan to help find the Vietnamese absconders, who were believed to be still in Taiwan.
Equipped with maps and the absconders' ID information, the Vietnamese labor brokerage agents, divided into groups of six, left no stone unturned in their search.
In one "lucky" raid, eight Vietnamese absconders were nabbed in one single action, a VECO official said.

The Vietnamese labor brokers were efficient because they had detailed information about the absconders, including addresses and telephone numbers of their direct relatives back in Vietnam. Since most of the Vietnamese workers regularly send money back to their hometowns, "it's easy to find them via their contact information, " the VECO official said.
Reading the Taiwan maps and sorting out directions were pretty much the hardest part of the action, he added.

VECO authorities said Saturday that it would be no problem for them to achieve the goal of 2,000 absconders nabbed by the end of this year that was set by CLA as a condition to prevent Taiwan from adopting a freeze on the import of Vietnamese laborers.

The action was taken after a visit to Taiwan in October by Nguyen Luong Trao, Vietnam's deputy minister of labor, war invalids and social welfare, who promised the CLA that he would see to it that the problem was tackled in a timely manner.

According to CLA talles, 11,000 out of the some 84,000 Vietnamese workers currently in Taiwan had absconded as of the end of October. Since about half of all the absconded foreign laborers in Taiwan are Vietnamese nationals, Vietnam posted the highest rate of absconding among all foreign laborers as of the end of August in terms of nationality, followed by the Philippines and Thailand.

The sweeping action was further aided by the fact that the Vietnamese government agreed to pay for the airfares home -- about NT$8,000 (US$248) -- for each absconder, who will be repatriated immediately, and the fact that the Vietnamese labor brokers were warned that their licenses would be revoked if they failed to cooperate, according to Kuo Fang-yu, director-general of the CLA Employment and Vocational Trading Administration.
The CLA in May suspended the introduction of Vietnamese fishermen and crew members into Taiwan in response to the group's high absconding rate.

Although Vietnam is not the largest source of foreign laborers in Taiwan, Vietnamese workers have continued to top the list in terms of number of absconders who have not been found, according to CLA tallies.

Taiwan had about 302,000 legal foreign laborers at the end of June, with 102,000 from Thailand, 86,000 from the Philippines, 72,000 from Vietnam, 40,000 from Indonesia, 36 from Mongolia and 22 from Malaysia.

Indonesia, because it failed to comply with a CLA request to cut the exorbitant brokerage fees charged by employment agencies in its country, has not been allowed to export any laborers to Taiwan since Aug. 1, 2002.

The manufacturing sector has absorbed the largest number of foreign laborers, followed by the caregiving sector and the construction industry. A few thousand of these foreign laborers also serve as maids.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY LECTURER NABBED FOR PRODUCING AMPHETAMINE IN SCHOOL LAB

TEXT.P: A lecturer at a science-technology university in Taipei County was nabbed Saturday for producing illicit drugs at the laboratory where he teaches, police reported Sunday.

The university teacher, surnamed Fang, who has double masters degrees in mechanics and chemistry from a U.S. university, was caught red-handed with his accomplices during a police raid at the lab Saturday night, said police authorities from Panchiao and Hsinchuang cities.

Fang, 42, was apprehended along with several of his accomplices, including a drug pusher nicknamed "White Monkey." Also seized at the lab were 14 kg of amphetamine, 148 kg of semi-finished amphetamine and gear and instruments that they used to produce the drugs.
According to Cheng Hsin-hung, chief prosecutor with the Panchiao District Prosecutor's Office, investigators had been tailing Fang and "White Monkey" for three months before conducting the raid.
Police believe Fang was lured by the enticement of big profits into running the risk of producing amphetamine using the lab of the institute where he teaches as a production hub.
Police said they are tracking his other accomplices and trying to find out who Fang and "White Monkey" channeling the drugs to.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST STRENGTHEN DEFENSES BEFORE BUILDING A NEW NATION: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan must improve its national defensive strength and its people's determination to protect the island if it wants to build a new nation, a U.S. scholar said in Taipei Sunday, adding that "the United States will support a determined democratic Taiwan."
John J. Tkacik, senior research fellow at the Asia Studies Center of the Heritage Foundation, made the remarks at a seminar to discuss issues related to enacting a new constitution for the nation.

Emphasizing that Washington can only "work seriously" if Taiwan just wants to be protected by the United States and to treat itself as an outsider of its national defense, the scholar said that the island is not an ally that has signed treaties with the United States and that the Taiwan Relations Act is only Washington's self-commitment toward Taiwan.

Saying that both enacting a new constitution and revising the contents of the existing Constitution are Taiwan's business, Tkacik noted that as a foreigner, his only concern is whether the issue will make mainland China attack Taiwan.

According to a senior U.S.-China expert, Charles Freeman, said "enacting a constitution means independence" and noted that the mainland sees "a declaration of Taiwan independence the same as a declaration of war."
Tkacik further said that based on an assessment of the mainland's military ability, "China is guaranteed to use its force" and "will use its force to attack."

Pointing out that if Taiwan wants to build a new nation, the first step is to strengthen its national defenses and the determination of its younger generation to protect the island, the scholar said, adding that only then should the island establish the new governmental system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHERMEN SAFE AFTER EXPLOSION OFF COSTA RICA COAST: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Eight crew members of a Taiwanese fishing vessel that exploded Friday off the Costa Rican coast were reported safe after being rescued by a nearby Belize-registered fishing boat, an official of the Fishery Administration under the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Sunday.

The official said that the COA will contact the Ministry of Foreign Affairs as soon as possible and request that the ministry's representatives stationed in Costa Rica do whatever they can to help the rescued crewmen.
According to wire service reports, the Pingtung-registered "Shin Jyi Wang" exploded 92 km off the Costa Rican coast and the eight crewmen were missing.
However, the official added that the crew abandoned ship after they failed to put out a fire caused by the explosion and were then rescued by a Belize fishing boat.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH FILM FESTIVAL HONORS TAIWAN SOUND ENGINEER
DOC.DATELINE: Nantes, France, Nov. 28 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-shao and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Tu Tu-chih, an award-winning Taiwan sound engineer, is the theme figure of the ongoing 26th International Tri-Continental Film Festival in Nantes, France, organizers said Saturday.

International film festivals traditionally focus attention on directors and actors or actresses. Few film festivals have ever selected backstage personnel as their theme figures. Nantes film festival organizers said they have selected Tu as this year's theme figure mainly because they want to recognize his professional accomplishments and to emphasize the importance of team spirit in film production.
Tu, a winner of the 2004 Taiwan National Literary and Arts Awards, said he was honored to be featured at the festival.

At the invitation of the festival organizers, Tu used synthesizers and other equipment to create sound for a 1919 silent movie directed by American director David Wark Griffith screened Saturday evening, winning much acclaim from film industry professionals who were gathered in Nantes for the festival.
In a eulogy delivered after Tu's performance, Yang Teh-chang, a noted Taiwan director, said Tu is a perfectionist who devotes all his energy into his work.

"Tu has never been daunted by setbacks and challenges in his work. He has always tried to learn useful lessons from flops and finally attained a pinnacle in a profession he loves very much," said Yang, who has collaborated with Tu on many films.

Speaking on the same occasion, Wong Kar Wei, a Hong Kong director, said Tu is one of the best screen recording masters he has ever collaborated with. "I'm very pleased with the Nantes film festival organizers' decision to honor Tu and exhibit some of his screen recording works this year."

Tu is the first movie professional to have received Taiwan's National Literary and Arts Awards. He also won an award at the 2001 Cannes Film Festival for his work on the movie "What Time Is It There?"

DOC.HEADLINE: RICE IMPORTS HAVE NOT AFFECTED DOMESTIC MARKET: COA

TEXT.P: Rice imports have so far not affected the domestic rice market, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Sunday.
Since Taiwan was admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in January 2002, it has been required to import up to 144,720 metric tons of rice annually.

But only 35 percent of the mandatory amount has been opened for the private sector to import, with the remaining 65 percent imported by the government for stockpiling for later distribution in accordance with the domestic market supply and demand situation.
As a result, COA officials said, the domestic rice market has so far not been affected by the restricted market opening measures.

In addition, the officials went on, the COA has adopted various other measures to protect rice farmers' rights and interests and maintain domestic market stability, including raising subsidies for rice paddy owners and farmers whose paddies are compulsorily left fallow, upgrading the quality of locally produced rice and promoting rice exports.

Noting that sustainable development of the rice farming industry is a government policy goal, the officials said the government is determined to develop a globally competitive rice production industry and protect rice farmers' legitimate rights and interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TEACHER CHANG' LIFELINE TURNS 35 YEARS OLD

TEXT.P: The "Teacher Chang" lifeline turned 35 years old Sunday, having provided consultations to some 1.7 million callers around Taiwan.

The telephone hotline has given consultations to 1.71 million people over the past 35 years, with the number of consultation services totaling 60,758 in 2004, a 15-fold increase compared with the 4,094 posted in the inaugural year, said officials from China Youth Corps (CYC), sponsor of the lifeline.
Most of the "Teacher Chang" consultations have been provided via telephone calls, although "Teacher Chang" also provides consulting via other means, including face-to-face talks, letters and e-mail.
Except for the first year, female callers have outnumbered male callers throughout the past 34 years, and most of the callers have been students, followed by jobless adults, CYC officials said.

In the last 10 years, according to a breakdown compiled by the CYC, some 17,000 high school students called "Teacher Chang" for help or consulting, followed by 14,000 university students and 12,000 junior college students, to vent their fear or spleen, or to seek expert advice.
The issues that the callers have presented range from family or household problems, romantic affairs, other personal relations and other matters, in that order.
October and July are traditionally the busiest months for the service, CYC officials said.
The "Teacher Chang" lifeline runs affiliated operations in 13 cities and counties around the island, with some 130 consultants and 939 volunteers regularly working in the system.

Over the past three decades, some 10,000 people who have received consultations have returned to "Teacher Chang" to work as volunteers. Of the total, 78 percent are females, mostly aged over 40, CYC officials said.

The CYC, founded by the late President Chiang Ching-kuo in an effort to strengthen services to the nation's youth population, organized a party at the Chientan Youth Activity Center Sunday to mark "Teacher Chang's" 35th anniversary.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN BRIDES FORM SUPPORTERS GROUP FOR DPP LEGISLATIVE CANDIDATE
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung, southern Taiwan, Nov. 28 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of foreign brides of local residents in the Pingtung area have formed a supporters group Sunday to throw their support behind a Democratic Progressive Party legislative candidate, even though they have no right to vote in Taiwan.

The 10-odd foreign brides, clad in traditional Indonesian, Filipino and Vietnamese costume, said during a campaign rally of DPP legislative candidate Pan Meng-an that although they have no right to vote, they will prod their husbands and other Taiwan relatives into voting for Pan, who they claimed "will make a good lawmaker because he takes good care of Taiwan's foreign nationals."
The show of support was a shot in the arm for Pan, who, according to local election analysis, has no clear majority.
Welcoming the foreign brides' support, Pan said that he has been abroad for many years doing business and knows only too well how lonely a foreign expatriate can feel living in a foreign land.

Pan said that the purpose of his establishing the Hemp Garden Community Education and Culture Center in Pingtung several years ago was mainly to provide a shelter and hub for foreign brides in the Pingtung area.

Over the years, Pan said, the center has offered Taiwanese language classes and other cultural classes for the foreign brides, helping them better adapt to Taiwan society and their new Taiwan families.

Pan added that it is one of his center's goals to take better care of the mothers of the so-called "New Taiwanese" -- the children of Taiwan locals and their foreign brides -- so that the "New Taiwanese" can receive better education and their foreign mothers can find Taiwan to be a good new home.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEB SITE RATING FOUNDATION TO BE INAUGURATED TO PROTECT KIDS

TEXT.P: An Internet Web site rating foundation, composed of representatives from the government, portal operators and public-interest groups, will be inaugurated Monday in an attempt to ensure that the Internet will not adversely affect local youngsters.

The establishment of the foundation is part of the Government Information Office's (GIO's) efforts to create a safe Web environment for local children and adolescents following its promulgation of Web content rating regulations in April this year.

The foundation's board members will include officials from the GIO, the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of Transportation and Communication, portal operators such as Chunghwa Telecom Co., Seednet, yam.com, Yahoo! and ETToday, as well as public-interest groups dedicated to promoting children's welfare.
GIO officials said the enforcement of a Web rating system is urgent because the number of local Web surfers aged under 12 has broken the 1 million mark.

The foundation will work out a Web rating system that will require operators to mark out "restricted" Web sites and to help parents set codes on their home computers to stop their children gaining access to Web sites with violence, sex and drug references, the officials said.
According to a GIO study, the number of local Web surfers aged below 12 has reached 1.06 million and 92.3 percent of children aged between 12 and 15 have Internet experience.
The GIO also conducted a public opinion survey of 1,095 adult residents around the island from Nov.15-16 to explore their opinions about the implementation of a Web rating system.
The survey results show that 89.4 percent of the respondents support the proposal that the GIO require portal operators to mark out "restricted" Web sites to be subject to close monitoring.

Meanwhile, 85 percent said they support the proposal that the GIO encourage local parents to set secret codes on their home computers to prevent children and juveniles from surfing pornographic Web sites.
Generally speaking, GIO officials said, local residents fully support the GIO's plan to introduce the rating system.

The survey also had some other noteworthy findings, including that women are more supportive of the Web rating system than their male counterparts and that the support rate is particularly high among young and better educated respondents.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN TO REVISE LAW TO GRANT VISA-FREE ENTRY FOR ROC CITIZENS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Nov. 28 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Japan will revise its entry and exit law to pave the way for granting visa-free privilege to Taiwan citizens for six months starting from March 2005, the Japanese Yomiuri Shimbun daily reported Sunday.

The temporary visa-free measure is mainly aimed at attracting more Taiwan visitors to the EXPO 2005 Aichi -- an eco-friendly world exposition to be held in the Japanese prefecture Aichi March 25-Sept. 25, the paper said.
According to the paper, the Japanese government will consider whether to permanently offer visa-free entry to Taiwan citizens based on the implementation results during the six-month period.

Taiwan has long offered visa-free entry to Japanese citizens. Japan has so far not reciprocated because under the current Japanese exit and entry law, the Japanese government can only offer visa-free privilege to citizens of countries with which Japan maintains diplomatic relations.

As Japan switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972, offering visa-free privilege to Republic of China citizens requires an amendment to its existing law. The Japanese government has decided to add a clause to the law allowing citizens from "officially designated areas" to enjoy the same visa-free privilege, according to previous media reports.
Taiwan has been Japan's second largest tourist source after South Korea and the number of Taiwan visitors to Japan is expected to break the 1 million mark this year.
Japan intends to attract 1.5 million foreign visitors to the EXPO 2005 Aichi, with 300,000 or one-fifth of visitors expected to come from Taiwan.

Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi took the initiative to tell Lee Yuan-tseh, Taiwan's representative to the Nov. 20-21 informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Santiago, Chile, that his administration has tentatively decided to offer visa-free entry to ROC citizens during the Aichi expo period.
The Yomiuri Shimbun reported Sunday that the Japanese government will refer a draft law revision bill to the Diet early next year for the proposed visa-free privilege for Taiwan citizens.
A total of 122 countries and many international organizations, including the United Nations and its affiliates, will exhibit eco-friendly technologies and products at the Aichi expo.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERANS AFFAIRS COMMISSION TO BE MERGED WITH DEFENSE MINISTRY: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday the Veterans Affairs Commission (VAC) will merge with the Ministry of National Defense (MND) under the government's sweeping restructuring plan.

Chen made the remarks while stumping for Lu Po-chi, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) candidate for the Dec. 11 legislative elections in the Hualien County constituency in eastern Taiwan.

Chen's statement came a day after an opposition party chairman warned that if the "pan-green" camp of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union wins a clear majority in the new legislature, the VAC would definitely be phased out.

Chen said he felt regret that the opposition politician had made such a false and irresponsible claim simply for instigating retired soldiers' anti-government and anti-A-bian (Chen's nickname) sentiments and thus winning their votes in the upcoming elections.
Chen said the Cabinet's restructuring plan complies with the general world trend and is aimed at upgrading administrative efficiency and Taiwan's overall competitiveness in the global market.

The United States, Japan, Great Britain and France far outpace Taiwan in terms of their spaces and populations but the numbers of their government departments are less than Taiwan's, Chen said, adding that Taiwan must streamline its government structure to cut red tape and enhance operational efficiency.
According to the Cabinet's restructuring plan, its current 36 departments will be integrated into 13 ministries plus four commissions and five independent agencies.

While the number of Cabinet agencies will be trimmed, Chen said, the VAC will not disappear. "Instead, it will be upgraded to merge with the MND to become the Ministry of National Defense and Veterans Affairs," Chen explained.

He further said the existing veterans hospitals and sheltering centers for elderly veterans will never be phased out as the opposition politician has claimed. Moreover, he said the government will further improve welfare services and care for retired military servicemen.
Meanwhile, Chen said Taiwan now has five ethnic groups -- native Taiwanese, Hakka, Aborigines, mainlanders and naturalized foreigners.

"Despite our ethnic diversity, we should stand united to safeguard national security. National unity is critical to sustainable national development. All of the residents on this island, regardless of their ethnic origins and birth places, are masters of Taiwan. This country neither has oppressors nor the oppressed," Chen added.
He also reminded local people that the Republic of China existed in mainland China before 1949, moved its seat to Taiwan in 1949 and has since taken roots in Taiwan.

"Nowadays, the Republic of China refers to Taiwan and Taiwan refers to the Republic of China, " Chen said, adding that the two terms are identical. "We must have a clear understanding of national identity, then we can love this land and love this country.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET ASSIGNS 40 ADDITIONAL POLICE OFFICERS TO WORK IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun has directed the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) to assign 40 more police officers to work in Taichung to help improve the central Taiwan city's public order, Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Sunday.

Chen said the premier gave the directive after Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu asked the central government to deploy 20 additional police officers in Taichung earlier in the day. Hu made the request after two men were killed and three others injured in a Mafia-style shootout in a teahouse in Taichung City the previous day.

Hu attributed the city's deteriorating order and rising crime rate mainly to its insufficient police force. However, Chen said Taichung's police force does fall behind that in other major Taiwan cities. In Taichung, a police officer serves an average of 420 citizens, compared to 426 in Tainan City and 418 in Hsinchu City.

"In response to Hu's request, Premier Yu has instructed the MOI to deploy 40 more police officers in Taichung. The figure doubles the Hu-requested number," Chen said, adding that the Cabinet hopes Mayor Hu can take immediate steps to improve the city's public order and safeguard people's personal safety.

Chen pointed out that major reasons behind Taichung's worsening public order and mounting crime rate lie in the city's rampant sex trade and underground companies specializing in using violent means to coercing debtors to repay debts.
In his view, Chen said the Taichung City Government should target those special businesses and areas for intensified crackdown in order to improve the city's public order and curb its crime rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT VOWS TO CONTINUE CAMPAIGN FOR NEW CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Sunday that the controversy over Taiwan's sovereignty has affected Taiwan's survival and national development and that he is determined to continue his campaign for writing a new constitution for Taiwan.
Lee made the remarks at the closing ceremony of a two-day international seminar on Taiwan's new constitution drive, organized by the Taiwan Advocates, a private think tank led by Lee.

Noting that Taiwan's status is an issue left unsolved after World War II, Lee said the international community should not sit idle while Taiwan is being suppressed diplomatically and threatened militarily by mainland China.

"The 23 million peace-loving Taiwan people have set a model in establishing a prosperous vibrant democracy over the past five decades and the world should respect Taiwan people's desire to build a normal, complete country, " Lee said, adding that Taiwan's sovereignty belongs to the 23 million people living on this island, not to Beijing.
The international community should assist in resolving this sovereignty dispute then can Asia have permanent peace, Lee said.

He further said he is pleased to learn that all foreign scholars participating in the seminar supporting Taiwan's drive to write a new constitution that fits the island's present status quo to facilitate its sustainable national development.

After to days of discussions, Lee said, the theoretical basis for the campaign to rectify Taiwan's name and write a new constitution has become firmer and clearer. He further said he will dedicate the rest of his life to push for realization of the goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN RULES OUT REFERENDUM ON INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday Taiwan does not need to hold a referendum on whether to declare independence because it is already an independent sovereign state.
Chen made the remarks while stumping for the five ruling Democratic Progressive Party candidate for the Dec. 11 legislative elections in the Kaohsiung County constituency in southern Taiwan.
Chen's declaration came after some heavyweight opposition politicians' dared him to hold an "independence" referendum.
Chen said only those who doubt Taiwan's sovereign status will call for an independence referendum.

In his view, Chen said, what Taiwan needs are referendums on whether to be ruled by China, whether to become a province of China and whether to accept Beijing's "one country, two systems" unification scheme.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS

New York Times: Parliament says votes in Ukraine were not valid
Ukraine's Parliament, meeting in a stormy special session, voted overwhelmingly Saturday that last Sunday's presidential runoff did not reflect the will of the people, and more narrowly to declare the results invalid. But the legislators failed to set a date for a new election. Parliament, the Supreme Rada, does not have the authority to overturn the election results, which according to the government, made Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich the country's next president. But the vote - even the debate itself - signaled the swelling dissatisfaction over an election marred by accusations of wholesale fraud.
Wall Street Journal: Ukrainian Parliament declares Presidential Election invalid
Ukraine's Parliament on Saturday declared invalid the disputed presidential election that triggered a week of growing street protests and legal maneuvers, raising the possibility that a new vote could be held in this former Soviet republic. Parliament's decision isn't binding, but it clearly demonstrated rising dissatisfaction with the announced outcome. The U.S. and other Western nations contend the vote was marred by massive fraud.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Nov. 29, or the 18th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1314: Philip IV, the king of France known as "Philip the Fair," dies at the age of 46. His reign was marked by controversy with the papacy and expansion of royal prerogative. He expelled all Jews from France and seized their property.
1516: Italian painter Giovanni Bellini dies at the age of 86. He made Venice a center of art rivaling Florence. His works include "Saint Francis in Ecstasy."
1780: Maria Theresa, Queen of Hungary and Bohemia and the widow of Holy Roman Emperor Francis I, dies. She was a key figure in the politics of 18th-century Europe and has been described as "the most human of the Hapsburgs."
1832: Louisa May Alcott, the American novelist best remembered for "Little Women," is born.
1864: At least 150 Indian warriors, women and children are killed at Sand Creek, Colorado Territory, by 750 U.S. cavalrymen under the command of Col. John M. Chivingston.
1890: The first Japanese Diet, consisting of a House of Peers and a House of Representatives, is opened in Japan.
1924: Italian composer Giacomo Puccini dies at the age of 66. His works include "La Boheme" and "Tosca."
1929: Adm. Richard E. Byrd, the noted American explorer, flies over the South Pole following his triumphant first flight over the North Pole in 1926.
1932: Jacques Chirac, French statesman and prime minister, is born. He became president in 1995, succeeding Francois Mitterrand.
1943: The communists set up a temporary government in Jajce, Yugoslavia (now in Bosnia-Herzegovina), with Josip Broz Tito as its leader.
1950: The first Taipei City Council is established, with Huang Chi-jui as speaker.
1954: The United States turns over the first batch of Saber jet fighters to the Republic of China Air Force prior to the signing of the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty on Dec. 3 in Washington, D.C.
1963: U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson appoints a commission headed by Chief Justice Earl Warren to probe the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
1966: A republic is proclaimed in Burundi after King Ntare IV is overthrown.
1966: The U.N. General Assembly for the 16th time votes by a substantial majority to bar the Beijing regime from the United Nations.
1971: Kuo Yu-tsai, director of the anti-communist Chinese-language "Chengkung Daily" newspaper in Saigon, is shot and killed by two female Vietcong guerrillas.
1974: Peng Teh-huai, former deputy prime minister of Communist China, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 76.
1975: Walter Montenegoro, the Republic of Bolivia's ambassador-designate to the ROC, arrives in Taiwan to assume his post.
1986: British-born American actor Cary Grant dies at the age of 82. He was the epitome of the elegant leading man, starring in films such as "The Philadelphia Story," "Arsenic and Old Lace," "To Catch a Thief" and "North by Northwest."
1987: A Korean passenger plane explodes above the border between Thailand and Burma, killing all 115 people aboard.
1989: Nadia Comaneci, Romanian gymnast and Olympic gold medalist, escapes to Hungary and asks for political asylum.
1990: The U.N. Security Council approves Resolution 678, authorizing member governments to use "all necessary force" to guarantee Iraq's complete withdrawal from Kuwait by Jan. 15 the following year.
1990: Germany begins airlifting food to Moscow.
1999: The ROC Navy takes delivery of the YTB-51, a new locally built harbor tugboat, as part of its warship modernization program.
Motse's lesson of the day: "To accomplish anything whatsoever, one must have standards. None has yet accomplished anything without them. The gentlemen fulfilling their duties as generals and councilors have their standards. Even the artisans performing their tasks have their standards."

DOC.HEADLINE: YUNLIN COUNCIL SPEAKER INDICTED ON VOTE-BUYING CHARGES

TEXT.P: The speaker of the Yunlin County Council was indicted Monday on charges of violating the Public Officials Election and Recall Law, according to sources from the Yunlin District Prosecutors Office.

Chen Ching-hsiu was charged for hosting a banquet at a restaurant in Yunlin on the evening of Nov. 5 to drum up support for Chang Shuo-wen, a legislative candidate from the opposition Kuomintang. The event, according to Yunlin prosecutors, was in obvious violation of statutes of the Election and Recall Law.
The prosecutors, who said they had gathered solid evidence and witnesses before making the indictment, are seeking a prison sentence of one and a half years for Chen.
Twelve other people, including Chen's secretary, Hsieh Kun-chou, were also indicted for co-sponsoring the banquet, which the prosecutors have deemed to be a vote-buying activity.
About 150 people were entertained at the banquet, the prosecutors said, adding that 17 of them were questioned in the case, with eight admitting to having attended the dinner for free.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CIVILIAN EXCHANGES CONTINUE TO INCREASE

TEXT.P: Civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait have continued to increase this year, according to a report Monday by Beijing's official Xinhua News Agency.

Quoting tallies compiled by mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office, the report said that Taiwan people made 2.71 million visits to the mainland in the first nine months of this year, up 42.9 percent from the year-earlier level.
During the same period, mainland Chinese citizens made 107,216 visits to Taiwan, marking a year-on-year increase of 23.64 percent.

The report further said that in the first 10 months of this year, mainland Chinese professionals made 22,876 visits to Taiwan for 3,242 cross-strait exchange projects. The number of mainland visitors in this category marked an annual growth rate of 48.29 percent, while the number of exchange projects increased 70.72 percent from the year-earlier level.

Education Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam sees a greater role for Special Assistance Plan (SAP) schools at the forefront of promoting Chinese language and culture following the decision to adopt a new approach to learning the language.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS AGAIN CALLS FOR KMT TO CHANGE PARTY EMBLEM

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) again on Monday called for the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to change its party emblem to avoid any confusion with the national emblem of the Republic of China.

Noting that changing the ROC national emblem would be much more difficult a matter than changing the KMT's party emblem, DPP party whip Tsai Huang-liang said that it is the KMT's duty to differentiate its party emblem from that of the nation.

Tsai quoted President Chen Shui-bian as saying at a campaign rally the day before that if the KMT stubbornly refuses to change its emblem, the DPP will then take action to force it to do so once the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union wins a majority in the Legislative Yuan in the Dec. 11 elections.

President Chen Shui-bian said one week ago at a DPP campaign rally that the KMT party emblem is "too close" to the national emblem on the ROC national flag and that he would like to have the KMT change its party emblem to avoid confusion.

Responding to the president's calls, Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai said that the government will see to it that the National Emblem Law is amended in three months to pave the way for the government to legally require the KMT to change its party emblem.
Chen Chi-mai added that the revised National Emblem Law will be much clearer than the existing one and will have exact punishments set out for violators.

According to Chen Chi-mai, the government will move to have the National Emblem Law revised to make it illegal for any political party, private organization or business group to use the national symbol commercially. The revision will state that the symbol is national property and that only the government has the legal right to its use.

In response to President Chen's demand that the KMT change its party logo in three months, KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said the next day that the president does not need to wait three months, because "we are not changing anything."

Chang said that the KMT party emblem is a form of property with history and is protected by the ROC Constitution. "Only by showing respect for history, the law and the opposition can the Republic of China prove itself to be a nation of law and order," Chang argued.
Chang called for President Chen not to use the state apparatus to suppress the opposition and stop using destructive rhetoric during the current election campaign season.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINES

TEXT.P: New York Times: Iran backs away from demands on A-bomb fuel

Iran on Sunday backed off a demand to operate uranium enrichment equipment that could be used either for energy purposes or in a nuclear bomb-making project, European and Iranian officials said.The Iranian retreat appeare to salvage a nuclear agreement reached Nov. 15 between Iran and France, Britain and Germany to freeze all of Iran's uranium enrichment, conversion and reprocessing activities. It also paves the way for the 35 countries that make up the ruling board of the International Atomic Energy Agencyto pass a resolution that will be only mildly critical of Iran's nuclear program.
Wall Street Journal: A shopping frenzy, but not at Wal-Mart

Near-record crowds turned out for the holiday shopping season's Thanksgiving weekend kickoff, bringing with them unexpectedly robust sales gains to many malls and retail chains across the country. However, Wal-Mart on Saturday slashed its prediction for November sales growth, citing disappointing holiday sales at its stores. Wal-Mart predicted that November same-store sales in the U.S. would grow by only 0.7% over a year ago, far less than the 2% to 4% rise the retailer had expected. J.C. Penney Co. and Sears, Roebuck & Co. al so remained cautious about overall holiday sales, despite dazzling customer turnout.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SENT TO AIT OFFICE TO HANDLE SUSPICIOUS PACKAGE

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) officials notified police Monday after receiving a suspicious looking package earlier in the day.
Ta-an District police and bomb squad officers were immediately sent to the AIT Taipei office on Hsinyi Road to deal with the unmarked parcel.
The AIT is the United States' de facto embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.
The bomb squad discovered that the package only contained a letter and two bottles of water. The bottled water was then examined and found to contain no dangerous substances.
The police handed the letter to the AIT officials, who said that it was an appeal letter, the contents of which they declined to disclose.
The AIT officials said they notified the police of the suspicious package in accordance with the U.S. government's standard counter-terrorissm procedures.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 6.61 points to close at 5,785.26.
The bourse opened at 5,797.95 and fluctuated between 5,812.17 and 5,756.41 during trading. A total of 2.75 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$59.89 billion (US$1.86 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 1.7 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares and textile stocks, both at 1 percent, and cement stocks at 0.7 percent.

The four other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.2 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 397 to 238, with 146 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' APPEALS COURT RULING ON CASE AGAINST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) Monday appealed a court ruling which rejected their bid to annul the re-election of President Chen Shui-bian and his running mate, Vice President Annette Lu.

Lodging the appeal with the Supreme Court, a "pan-blue" legal team led by lawyer Lee Tzung-teh claimed that the Taiwan High Court ruling was based on a misconstruction of the law, improper grounds and inadequate review of evidence.

The Taiwan High Court on Nov. 4 ruled that "pan-blue" presidential candidate Lien Chan and his running mate, James Soong, failed to prove their claims that the ballot counting in the March 20 election was not accurate and that Chen and Lu had deliberately prevented some voters from exercising their right to vote.

Lee argued that the high court had misconstrued the meaning of "inaccurate vote count" set down in the President and Vice President Election and Recall Law by only examining whether the vote count was correct and whether there was a mix-up of valid and invalid ballots.
Lee said the court did not check if any of the ballots were cast by a fill-in, by a voter who had already voted once, by someone with no right to vote, or by a phantom voter.

He accused the high court of ignoring the scientific evidence presented by the plaintiffs and adopting a report by U.S. forensic expert Henry Lee as the only basis in determining that the March 19 shooting of Chen and Lu was not a political ploy to win sympathy votes.

In addition, he said, the high court did not review crucial facts such as the lists of registered voters, evidence related to the election-eve shooting and evidence concerning the activation of the "national security mechanism" after the shooting.

Commenting on the move by the "pan-blue alliance, " ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang questioned the opposition's purpose in filing an appeal when it continues to suspect that there is political interference in the judicial system.
Cheng said most of the points raised by the "pan-blue alliance" to support its appeal suit were already clarified during hearings held by the high court.
Tsai Huang-liang, whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said Lien and Soong are only trying to evade their responsibility in losing the election by dragging out the legal process.

Meanwhile, Lee Shang-ren, director of the Taiwan Solidarity Union's policy center, urged Lien and Soong to admit their defeat and step down from the leadership of the KMT and PFP to facilitate a rebirth of the two parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December gained 70 points to close at 5,810, with 25,406 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January moved up 46 points to finish at 5,805, with 99 contracts traded, while March futures gained 57 points to finish at 5,796, with 20 contracts traded.
June futures gained 11 points to finish at 5,760 with 10 contracts traded, while September futures moved up 19 points to close at 5,719, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,740 for December, 5,759 for January, 5,739 for March, 5,749 for June and 5,700 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

December TE futures moved up 2.3 points to close at 215.8, with 3,207 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 0.7 points to finish at 216, with 19 contract transactions. March TE futures gained 1.95 points to close at 215, with two contracts traded, while September TE futures moved up 7.3 points to end at 218.85, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for June.

December TF futures gained 11.4 points to finish at 991.6, with 5,653 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 7.2 points to end at 991, with 65 contracts traded. March TF future lost 6.8 points to finish at 983.2, with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG, MACAU RESIDENTS CAN APPLY FOR ROC VISAS ONLINE FROM JAN. 1

TEXT.P: Hong Kong and Macau residents will be allowed to apply for Taiwan visas on the Internet from Jan. 1, 2005, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Monday.
Chiu made the announcement after MAC commissioners passed a package of revisions to the existing regulations governing visits and immigration by Hong Kong and Macau citizens earlier in the day.

According to the revised rules, Chiu said, Hong Kong and Macau residents can visit the Republic of China government's Web site at www.gov.tw or the Ministry of the Interior Immigration Bureau's Web site at www.immigration.gov.tw to get information or apply for entry permits from Jan. 1.

Under the new rules, those who apply for visas online can pick up the permits at Chung Hwa Travel Service in Hong Kong, at Chung Hwa Travel Service's office at Hong Kong International Airport, or at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Macau.

The visas will take effect a day after the issue date and will remain valid for three months, Chiu said, adding that applicants can visit Taiwan twice during the three-month period for a stay of up to 14 days each time.
Chiu said the new measures are part of the government's efforts to facilitate visits by Hong Kong and Macau residents and to promote Taiwan's civilian exchanges with the two areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE INVESTORS WELCOME TO BUILD OFFSHORE DESALINATION PLANTS

TEXT.P: The private sector is welcome to invest in the building of desalination plants in offshore areas to help the government redress water supply problems in these particular areas, the Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Monday.

The Cabinet-level CEPD convened a meeting Monday, exclusively on the development of desalination plants on the islands of Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu, where drought often occurs and where the number of suitable sites for building dams or reservoirs is limited.

During the meeting, according to CEPD officials, Premier Yu Shyi-kun gave a three-point directive to facilitate the development of desalination plants in order to redress the water supply problem in the three offshore areas.

In accordance with the government's plans of encouraging the private sector to take part in public construction and development projects, Yu said, private investors are welcome to build desalination plants on these three islands, adding that firstly, they will be allowed to operate other related businesses that will help lower their overall costs in building and operating the desalination plants.

Secondly, Yu said, the desalinated water that the private investors produce will be bought back by the government at guaranteed prices. In Kinmen and Matsu, the central government will offer subsidies to the private desalination plants to make up for their income shortfalls, while in Penghu, water prices will be finalized after the desalination plant investors negotiate with the Taiwan Water Co.

Thirdly, the desalination plants should be built on public lands, Yu said, adding that if no suitable sites on public lands are available, then private lands will be acquired at the government's expense.
The Water Resources Agency (WRA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs has been placed in charge of the desalination plant development project.

Under the project, the WRA plans to have a desalination plant with a production capacity of 2,000 tons of fresh water per day built in each of Kinmen and Matsu, and a plant capable of producing 10,000 tons of fresh water per day built in Penghu.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-GREEN CAMP' CAN WIN 113 SEATS IN UPCOMING ELECTIONS: DPP POLL

TEXT.P: The "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will be able to win a total of 113 seats in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, a DPP official predicted Monday.
Pan Yi-hsuan, director of the DPP's Public Opinion Survey Center, said his estimate was based on the results of the party's latest public opinion poll.
According to the poll results, Pan said, the DPP can win an estimated 97 seats, including regional, at-large and overseas community seats, while the TSU can win 16 seats.

Meanwhile, she said, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party will capture 98 seats, with the KMT garnering 67 seats, the PFP 30 seats and the New Party one seat.

Quoting the results of the latest DPP survey, Pan said the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) will be able to win seven seats and the remaining seven seats in the 225-seat legislature will be snatched by independents.

In the 2001 legislative elections, the "pan-green camp" won 100 seats (87 DPP seats plus 13 TSU seats) ; the "pan-blue alliance" took 115 seats (68 KMT seats plus 46 PFP seats and one New Party seat) ; the NPSU secured seven seats; and the remaining three seats were captured by independents.

According to the DPP's estimate, Pan said, the "pan-green camp" can seize 13 more seats this time around, while the number of seats to be secured by the "pan-blue alliance" could decline by 17 from the 2001-level.
Pan said the DPP has so far conducted three large-scale opinion surveys to gauge the various political groups' election prospects.

"The survey results show that the numbers of seats to be won by the PFP and the New Party remain almost the same in all three polls, while the KMT shows a downward trend, " Pan said, adding that any decline in the number of KMT seats could be attributed to the fact that some of their supporters have turned to support several noted independent hopefuls, such as Li Ao, Cheng Li-wen and Shih Ming-teh.

In contrast, Pan said the "pan-green camp's" support rate has been rising steadily thanks to President Chen Shui-bian's barnstorming-style campaign and the camp's joint campaign and ballot allocation strategies.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNET RATING FOUNDATION INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: A foundation set up jointly by representatives from the government, Internet portal operators and public interest groups to enforce an Internet rating system was inaugurated Monday, according to the Government Information Office (GIO).

The foundation, named the Taiwan Internet Content Promotion Foundation, whose goal is to create a safe Web environment to protect underaged Internet surfers from illegal Web content, will attempt to implement a rating system similar to the ones used for TV, movies and publications, said GIO Director-General Lin Chia-lung.

The rating system will require local Web site operators to mark out "restricted" sites inappropriate for children and adolescents and help parents set up codes on their computers to prevent younger family members from gaining access to certain sites, Lin said.

In 2004, the number of Internet surfers aged under 12 has reached 1.06 million and more than 92 percent of children aged between 12 and 15 have Internet experience, according to statistics released by the GIO.
The establishment of the foundation is a three-month effort by the public interest groups and the government, which also promulgated regulations regarding Web content ratings in April.

Most people, particularly women and the well-educated, are opening their arms to the notion of Internet rating, with the results of a survey conducted by the GIO earlier this month showing that more than 85 percent of the respondents support such a rating system.

Lai Fei-pi, an electrical engineering professor from National Taiwan University, was elected the foundation's chairman of the board of directors by the board members, who include representatives of the GIO, Chunghwa Telecom Co., and Microsoft Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, KMT TO HOLD MASSIVE RALLIES THIS WEEKEND

TEXT.P: Both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) are set to hold large-scale rallies at the weekend in a last-ditch effort to boost their chances in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
DPP Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan said his party plans to gather 100,000 supporters for a rally scheduled for Saturday in Taipei.
He said the rally will take the form of a carnival displaying the theme of "protecting Taiwan for its well-being."

That evening, both President Chen Shui-bian and former President Lee Teng-hui will attend another DPP rally in Kaohsiung to promote their goal of having the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and Taiwan Solidarity Union win a majority of the seats in the Legislative Yuan.
On Sunday, the DPP will send campaign jeeps around the central counties of Taichung, Changhua and Nantou to drum up support for its candidates.
Not to be outdone, the KMT also plans to mobilize at least 100,000 supporters for a rally Sunday in Taipei to boost the morale of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party.
KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said the rally will highlight the theme of "uniting to protect the country and save Taiwan."

Chang said the KMT must stand up to safeguard the Republic of China, claiming that the DPP has made evident its intention to destroy the Republic of China over the past four-and-a-half years since it came to power.
Chang accused the DPP of denying ROC history and ROC founding father Sun Yat-sen of their due status and of attempting to change the national emblem.

Gordon Brown is to intensify his crackdown on corporate tax avoidance with punitive action aimed at deterring advisers from flouting disclosure requirements.
