which backs Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovych in the disputed presidential election, set a December referendum on autonomy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG ASKS CABINET TO BOOST CITY POLICE FORCE

TEXT.P: In the face of deteriorating public order in the central city of Taichung, Mayor Jason Hu appealed to the central government Monday again for a boost in the number of police assigned to his city.
At a meeting of top city officials, Hu complained that Taichung has suffered a serious lack of police for years, saying that this is why his administration has not been able to maintain order.
The city was shaken by yet another gangster shootout Saturday in which two men were shot dead and three others were injured. The case was the fourth to occur in Taichung in the last six months.

A day after the bloody shooting, Hu asked the central government to deploy additional police officers in his city. He received a response from the premier that same day, who directed the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) to assign an additional 40 police officers to Taichung.

The additional police force went on duty Monday, but Hu claimed the 40-strong force is too small to clean up the city that has been inundated with vicious criminals involved in prostitution, drugs, gambling and illegal guns.

Hu cited the latest MOI report as saying that Taichung's crime rate has been the highest among all cities around the country for the past 12 years and complained that the central government has failed to carry out a promise it made last year to supplement Taichung City's police force to a ratio of 1: 350 -- with one police officer serving every 350 citizens.
At present, there is only one police officer for every 420 citizens in Taichung, according to official statistics.

Hu added that criminal gangs are the cause of most major social problems in Taichung. To improve public order, Hu suggested launching a large-scale police operation in a time span of three to six months to crack down on illegal organizations.
The mayor added that the relevant authorities would have to mobilize some 3,000 to 4,000 personnel to effectively crack down on crime in his city.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORD SIZE ON GOODS LABELS SHOULD BE ENLARGED: CONSUMER'S FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: As Taiwan society continues to age, the word size on merchandise labels should be enlarged, Consumer Foundation (CF) Chairman Lee Feng-ao said Monday.

Some of the words used on labels are so small it is difficult for consumers to read, Lee said, adding that if buyers are harmed by products because the words on the label are too small, the manufacturers should assume responsibility.

In response to Lee's call, officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs said that they will suggest an amendment to relevant laws to regulate word size used on labels for dangerous goods. (Nick Huang)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S ASSETS PUT IN TRUST: CONTROL YUAN REPORT

TEXT.P: All of President Chen Shui-bian's assets have been put in trust, with the exception of deposits amounting to NT$540,000 (US$16,770) under the name of his wife Wu Shu-jen, according to a report released Monday by the Control Yuan.
As shown in the report disclosing the assets of public officials, three properties registered under Chen's name in Taipei City and Tainan County have been put in trust.

Also in trust are stocks with a combined face value of NT$8.19 million under Wu's name, as well as deposits amounting to NT$28.83 million under Chen's name and another NT$12.69 million under Wu's name.
Chen promised to put his assets in trust during the run-up to the March 20 presidential election after the first lady was attacked for improperly engaging in stock trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGE NUMBER OF VIETNAMESE WORKERS ON THE RUN: CLA

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has not fully ruled out the possibility of freezing imports of workers from Vietnam in view of their high ratio of absconding, a CLA spokesman said Monday.

Although the Vietnamese authorities sent officials to Taiwan to help resolve the problem in October, the spokesman said the CLA has not completely given up the idea of banning imports of Vietnamese laborers to Taiwan.
The CLA has decided to temporarily stop allowing in more Vietnamese workers and will continue to gauge the situation before making a final decision, he said.

Citing statistics provided by the Vietnamese authorities, Kuo Fang-yu, director-general of the CLA's Employment and Vocational Training Administration, said that the Vietnamese authorities helped track down more than 260 Vietnamese laborers on the run in Taiwan in the first two weeks of this month, with a further 100 found in the third week.
Taiwan government statistics show that as of the end of September, more than 7,900 Vietnamese workers had absconded from their workplace.

Vietnamese laborers had recorded an absconding rate of 9.39 percent as of the end of August, markedly higher than the 2.5 percent and 1.6 percent of workers from the Philippines and Thailand, respectively.
At present, there are more than 300,000 foreign workers in Taiwan, with those from Thailand accounting for the largest share of about 10 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SEEK INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION IN RECYCLING NUCLEAR WASTE

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs to cooperate with the international community in recycling its nuclear waste, the chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Atomic Energy (CAE) said Monday.
Ou Yang Ming-sheng made the remarks in a two-day Taiwan-Japan seminar on nuclear safety that opened in Taipei Monday.

The seminar is being sponsored by the Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower), with 21 Japanese delegates led by Susumu Takato, executive vice president of Chugoku Electric Power Company and around 150 delegates from Taipower, CAE and the Institute of Nuclear Energy Research participating.

Ou Yang noted that there are more than 50 nuclear generator units in Japan and that the country is more advanced than Taiwan in terms of nuclear safety, nuclear waste storage, low-radioactive nuclear waste disposal and the recycling of nuclear waste.
Takato, for his part, noted that Japan is short on energy resources and has had to make long-term planning for energy, as well as promoting energy and nuclear power education.
In addition, Japan is also taking steps to recycle its nuclear waste with the aim of cutting down on the purchase of uranium, he said.
Ou Yang said that the uranium Taiwan uses in nuclear power plants can be recycled repeatedly if the country had the relevant sophisticated technology.

He said that although a recycling factory for nuclear waste in Japan has yet to be completed, Japan has enough nuclear waste to make such a venture viable, while Taiwan's three nuclear power plants with six generating units do not produce enough nuclear waste to carry out recycling on a commercial scale.
For this reason, he went on, Taiwan needs to cooperate with the international community to make recycling possible, on a mutually beneficial basis.

He said that when the amount of nuclear waste produced in Taiwan becomes commercially viable, its handling would be better dealt with through international cooperation, pointing out that both France and Russia have sophisticated technology in this field.

According to figures produced by the CAE's Fuel Cycle and Materials Administration, there are currently 97,672 barrels of nuclear waste stored on outlying Orchid Island, with a further 86,254 barrels stored at the country's three nuclear power plants.

DOC.HEADLINE: TV, RADIO ELECTION CAMPAIGN ADS TO BE BANNED FROM DEC. 1

TEXT.P: Television and radio stations will be banned from broadcasting legislative election campaign commercials from Dec. 1, when the 10-day official campaign period for the Dec. 11 legislative elections will begin, the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Monday.
"From Dec. 1, political parties, individual legislative candidates and third parties will be prohibited from airing commercials on TV and radio channels, " said CEC Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung.
From that date, Chang went on, TV and radio stations will also be prohibited from campaigning for any individual candidates in their programs.

According to the television and radio broadcasting law, Chang said, violators will face fines. The fines for cable TV stations could reach a maximum of NT$500,000, while law-breaking terrestrial TV stations could be slapped with fines of up to NT$1 million.

Chang made the remarks after opposition Kuomintang and People First Party legislative whips -- Huang Teh-fu, Huang Chao-shun, Liu Wen-hsiung and Lee Tung-hao -- paid a visit to the CEC to gain a better understanding of the ban on TV and radio campaign commercials during the official campaign period.

Chang said the law requires TV and radio stations to deal with news events regarding individual candidates and their parties impartially and fairly. The law also forbids them from broadcasting campaign commercials put up by individual candidates, political parties or third parties during the official campaign period. TV and radio stations are also not allowed to campaign for any parties or candidates in their programs during the period, Chang explained.

From Dec. 1, Chang said the Government Information Office (GIO) will closely monitor all TV and radio news programs. If any are found to have violated the principles of fairness and impartiality, the GIO will send the monitoring videotapes to the CEC for review.

Meanwhile, Chang said, all CEC commission members will meet Dec. 1 to more clearly set out standards for determining whether a TV or radio program has violated the "no campaign" regulations and whether news programs have been fair and impartial.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESTRICTIONS EASED FOR MAINLAND SPOUSES OF FOREIGN PROFESSIONALS

TEXT.P: Restrictions on the entry of the mainland Chinese spouses of foreign professionals are to be further eased, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Monday.
Chiu made the remarks after MAC commissioners passed a package of revisions to the regulations governing the entry to Taiwan of mainland Chinese citizens at a meeting held earlier in the day.
According to the revised rules, such mainland spouses will no longer be required to give up their mainland passports or other travel papers to the Taiwan authorities.

Under the new rules, foreign professionals' direct supervisors or their corporate CEOs, regardless of nationality, can serve as guarantors of their mainland spouses. According to the existing law, guarantors can only be Taiwan nationals and must meet many other qualifications.
Chiu said the relaxation is a response to a request by the European Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, which asked the government earlier this year to ease the restrictions.

The new rules will be implemented after the Cabinet endorses them in the near future, Chiu said, adding that the MAC hopes the eased rules will make Taiwan more attractive to foreign high-tech professionals.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM URGES AUSTRALIA NOT TO INTERFERE IN VANUATU'S INTERNAL AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Monday he called in Australia's representative to Taipei recently to urge Australia not to interfere with Vanuatu's decision to forge diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

Citing wire service reports that Canberra is cutting its aid to Vanuatu, Chen claimed this is evidence that Australia is currying favor with Beijing by leaning on the South Pacific state to renege on its diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
Chen said he has told Australia's representative to Taipei that Canberra should not poke its nose into Vanuatu's ties with Taiwan.

Noting that Beijing is offering Vanuatu aid of US$32 million per year in an attempt to dissuade it from entering diplomatic ties with Taiwan, Chen said Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kao Ying-mao, who is in Port Vila, the capital of Vanuatu, will see to it that Vanuatu does not reverse it decision.

Although the diplomatic war-of-tug between Taiwan and mainland China is still going on in Vanuatu, Chen claimed his ministry has neither put a foot wrong nor has it lost anything thus far, while the mainland is almost at the end of its wits about how to woo Vanuatu.
The minister urged the public to give Taiwan's diplomats a big hand for their struggle with Beijing over Vanuatu.
Vanuatu Prime Minister Serge Vohor visited Taipei and forged an agreement Nov. 4 to set up diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

Refusing to accept the fact, Beijing has since scrambled to dissuade Port Vila from recognizing Taipei, even though Taiwan diplomats have already arrived there and have raised the country's flag at their hotel to mark the inception of diplomatic ties between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ALLOW SECURITIES FIRMS TO INVEST IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The government will allow domestic securities companies to invest in their mainland China counterparts, according to a revised draft regulation passed Monday by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said that under the new regulations, which still need to be approved by the Executive Yuan, securities firms that meet the following qualifications will be allowed to invest in mainland securities firms:

-- Their net worth published in their latest financial reports should exceed NT$7 billion (US$217.39 million) and should exceed their capital stocks. In addition, the securities firms should not have been disciplined by the Financial Supervisory Commission, the Taiwan Stock Exchange, the Gretai Securities Market or the Taiwan Futures Exchange for a specific time period.
-- The capital adequacy ratio of the securities companies over the past three months should be higher than 200 percent; and

-- In terms of investment ceilings, the securities companies should not invest more than 10 percent of their net worth and the holding shares should not be less than 25 percent of the total shares issued by the mainland securities firms.
The MAC estimated that 16 domestic securities firms will meet the qualifications.

However, Chiu noted that at the present stage, the mainland insists on signing a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on cross-strait financial supervision before it will allow Taiwan securities firms to invest there.
But he said that judging from the experience of other countries, signing an MOU with the host government will not necessarily guarantee the supervisory operations.

Chiu expressed the hope that the mainland authorities will accept the goodwill of Taiwan and revise its regulations so that the talent and resources of Taiwan securities firms can make inroads into the mainland soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT UNVEILS NEW SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM FOR OVERSEAS STUDY

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved Monday a full scholarship program for students pursuing doctoral and post-doctoral degrees overseas in 12 top-end disciplines.
According to National Science Council Vice Chairman Liao Chun-chen, the program will be expanded to send 1,000 students abroad a year in three years.
Registration for the scholarships will be accepted from Dec. 15 to Jan. 20 and the list of successful candidates will be announced March 20, Liao said.
Registration will be open both to those who have obtained admission to an overseas university and to those who have not, Liao said.

The fields covered by the scholarship will include basic science, biomedical technology, image display technology, digital content, information and communications technology, semiconductors, energy technology, the environment, maritime studies and natural disasters, nanotechnology and top-end materials, major services, international law and politics, and humanities and art.
Successful candidates will receive full funding for their tuition and miscellaneous fees, while their cost of living subsidies will vary according to where they study, Liao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER FACING CHALLENGES, DIFFICULTIES: GENERAL MANAGER

TEXT.P: The state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) is facing transformation difficulties and rising operating costs, so much so that simply increasing electricity fee may not be enough to deal with the situation, a company executive said Monday.
Taipower General Manager Chen Kuei-ming made the remarks at the 19th Taiwan-Japan nuclear power security seminar while giving a speech on the company's business prospects and development direction.
Chen said that the company will focus on high-efficiency and cost-effective power generation and will devote itself to diversification and globalization in its pursuit of privatization.

Vowing that Taipower will continue to increase power supplies in line with government policy by improving infrastructure and promoting alternative energy sources, Chen, however, pointed out that the company is facing critical problems on a number of fronts, including market liberalization, privatization, rising costs and the handling of nuclear waste.

According to Chen, the government's legislation on nuclear power security and relevant facilities has made noticeable progress in recent years, but the issue of nuclear waste disposal has long been a major headache for the company and its biggest challenge.

In an effort to satisfy the country's growing demand for power, Taipower will have to increase its supply by 4 percent each year over the next 10 years, he said, pointing out that if expenditure on infrastructure improvement projects are added, the company will have to spend more than NT$100 billion (about US$3 billion) per year.

To serve that end, he went on, Taipower needs to build sound finances. However, troubled by continuously rising fuel prices, in particular the price of coal, in the international market, the company has come under strong financial pressure, he noted.
Chen said the company will not be able to meet its profit target for this year, given the fact that it has had to pay extra fuel costs to the tune of NT$20 billion.
If Taipower cannot recoup the additional spending, the company is set to report a loss next year -- the first of its kind since it began operations in 1946, he added.

Despite the fact that the company has not yet made a final decision on when to raise its power rates, he predicted that an adjustment might be necessary in order to sustain its operations. However, he stressed that the company will take public opinion, national development and its own business into detailed account when mulling a rate hike.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS WILL NOT INVOLVE INDEPENDENCE/UNIFICATION

TEXT.P: The constitutional re-engineering project promoted by President Chen Shui-bian will not involve the issue of independence or unification with mainland China, an official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) reiterated Monday.
Wang Shu-fen, director of the DPP's Department of Chinese Affairs, made the remarks while attending a peace forum sponsored by the Foundation on International and Cross-strait Studies.

Wang noted that Chen said in his May 20 inauguration speech that he would abide by his "four noes plus one" pledge of his first inaugural speech in 2000 -- referring to no declaration of independence as long as Beijing does not use force to take Taiwan, no change of the nation's name, no introduction of the "state-to-state" theory in the Constitution, no referendum on the issue of independence or unification, and no abolition of the National Unification Guidelines.

The president also pledged in May that the constitutional re-engineering project will not touch upon national sovereignty, territory or the subject of independence/unification before the nation reaches a consensus on these issues, she said.

Wang said the president's pledges on national sovereignty, territory, and the subject of unification vs independence were not simply expedient remarks and that the "four noes plus one" is unlikely to change.

She noted that a new constitution that the party wants to write will be aimed not at handling the issue of independence vs unification and not at resolving cross-strait relations, but will concern the election system and party politics, the relations between the executive and legislative branches, the checks-and-balances mechanism, and the relationship between central and local government.

She said Beijing need not question the sincerity of the DPP in pushing for cross-strait exchanges and the resumption of cross-strait dialogues, nor should it have rejected the many peace overtures extended by the DPP administration since 2000.

She said the peoples on both sides of the Taiwan Strait have different views on Taiwan's national sovereignty issue, but a respect for the status quo along with both sides working on their internal and cross-strait development would meet the aspirations of the international community and would be in the best interests of both sides of the strait.
The participants in the forum were mostly positive about Hsu's remarks.

Tamkang University Professor Chang Wu-yueh said that if the constitutional reforms promoted by the DPP renege on Chen's inauguration pledges, it will be difficult to expect a good response from Beijing, but if they stick to the president's promises, then the cross-strait risks should be under control.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPACT OF RISING LOCAL CURRENCY NEEDS TO BE HEEDED: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: A rising new Taiwan dollar may lead to a worsening in the competitive edge of local companies and a flight of Taiwan capital, according to scholars and industry sources.

Kung Ming-hsin, a division chief at the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (ITRI) , said that the price of many Taiwan-made products quoted in U.S. dollars for export to other countries, except for the United States, will still become lower on a rapidly falling greenback due to different currency exchange rates.

Although export-oriented Taiwan companies operating in mainland China will benefit from a cheaper renminbi -- which is closely pegged to the U.S. dollar -- Kung pointed out, however, that businesses based at home will become increasingly less competitive.
In addition, he warned against a negative impact on Taiwan's overall economic development in the face of a possible capital flight to the mainland.

Lo Huai-chia, an executive of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers's Association, said that, however, that the impact on Taiwan exporters will be little, as many of them are producing in mainland China and delivering their products from there.

Meanwhile, the new Taiwan dollar ended at NT$32.155 against the U.S. dollar Monday on the Taipei foreign exchange market, down by NT$0.06 from Friday's finish, amid rampant rumors that the Taipei-based Central Bank of China had intervened.

S. T. Chen, general manager of the Chinatrust Commercial Bank, said that the chances are high that the mainland currency will go up in value. But he added that it is hard to predict the precise timing and range, on the grounds that the mainland authorities will have the final say rather than market forces on the issue.

ITRI President Wu Rong-i forecast last week that an appreciation of the renminbi is just a matter of time under strong pressure from the United States, Japan and the European Union to cool down the mainland's overheated economy.

Although speculation over a stronger mainland currency has fueled an influx of hot money into the Asian market, pushing up the new Taiwan dollar and keeping some pressure on the domestic export sector, Wu said that the rising new Taiwan dollar has in turn diluted growing inflationary pressure at home.

According to Wu, the rise in value of the local currency has offset some increased costs of imported products. He forecast that the growth rate on Taiwan's wholesale price index will largely fall to just about 2 percent for the whole of 2005 and that the consumer price index will show slight growth of 1.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONSLAUGHT OF ALIEN RED FIRE ANTS UNDER CONTROL: CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: An onslaught of red fire ants at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway to the world, has been brought under control and has not affected flight safety, the director of the airport said Monday.

Wei Sheng-chi said that since the red ants -- an alien species not native to Taiwan -- were found in the grass neighboring the airport tarmac, the airport immediately started prevention measures, checkings the cables of major facilities and navigation radar every day to ensure they are not being destroyed by the imported pests.

However, when it was found that the ants had spread back to the airport from the original area of infestation -- a township near the airport -- the authorities began another wave of attack and brought the ants under control with pesticide.
To effectively put an end to the threat of the pests, Wei said the airport needs to cooperate with several villages of the adjacent Tayuan township in Taoyuan County.
Wei made the statement amid media reports that the ant hazard has caused problems with radar equipment and tarmac peripherals, which could affect flight safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FILMS MAKE DEBUTS AT INDIAN INTERNATIONAL FILM FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Five Taiwan feature films will make their debuts Tuesday at the 35th India International Film Festival in Goa, an island off the coast of western India, an official from the Government Information Office (GIO) said Monday.

It is the first time that Taiwan-produced movies have been screened in an Indian film festival and although they are not in competition. They are being screened as part of the 5th Films in Country Focus feature, which is designed to promote the understanding of different countries through their films.

The five Taiwanese films chosen by the GIO to play at Goa are all realistic depictions of local life and are excellent examples of innovative narrative techniques, according to the anonymous GIO official.

The first film, to be screened Tuesday, is Formula-17, by Ying-jung Chen. Simon C. Hsieh, the director of the Information Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Center in New Delhi, will give a speech about the overall view of Taiwan's film industry before the screening.
Taiwan is the only country whose films are being shown at this year's country focus feature.

Noting that India has the world's largest movie audience, the GIO official said Taiwan film makers are trying hard to make inroads into the India market and that hopefully, the Goa festival will set them off on the right foot.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan Dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, losing NT$0.06 to close at NT$32.155.
A total of US$819 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$32.172 and fluctuated between NT$32.105 and NT$32.205.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15% OF LABORERS IN NOISY WORK CONDITIONS HAVE HEARING PROBLEMS: CLA

TEXT.P: Up to 15 percent of laborers who work in noisy environments have impaired hearing that could affect their language communication ability, according to the results of a survey released Monday by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).
The impairment will increase with age, the CLA survey also found, with 13 percent of those between 26 and 35 complaining of hearing problems, while the ratio is 29 percent for those over 55.

The CLA's Institute of Occupational Safety and Health said that the institute has collected hearing information on more than 37,000 laborers working under noisy conditions and has found that laborers in three trades -- construction, rubber product manufacturing and the textile sector -- suffer the highest hearing damage risks.

The hearing impairment is often exacerbated due to lack of detection, and even when finally detected, might be beyond repair, the institute said, urging employers to reduce noise levels in the workplace and to provide annual hearing checks for workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASEAN ASIAN TRADING BLOC PLAN WILL NOT AFFECT TAIWAN: MOE

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Monday that a plan by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) to establish an Asian trading bloc will not have much effect on Taiwan.

On the heels of the annual summit of the 10-member ASEAN plus three other Asian countries -- mainland China, Japan, and South Korea -- which opened that day in the Laotian capital of Vientiane, it was reported that India may also be invited to take part in the trading bloc, making a trade entity on a par with Europe and the United States.
Asked whether Taiwan, as the only country left out, will become economically marginalized, Ho was optimistic.
She said that although ASEAN plus three has set a grand goal of making a free trade area, the differences among the countries are so great that it will be difficult to achieve the goal.

She noted that many countries have become keen on economic integration, mainly because the World Trade Organization (WTO) talks in Cancun collapsed and they are worried about the slow progress of the WTO, although regional integration will heighten the cost of world trade.

She further said that the mainstay of Taiwan exports today is IT products, and that over 70 percent of the IT product market countries -- including Taiwan -- have signed Information Technology Agreements enabling them to enjoy tariff-free treatment on IT products. No matter which countries sign a free trade agreement, they will not affect Taiwan's IT exports, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Nov. 30, or the 19th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1835: American novelist Mark Twain is born as Samuel Langhorne Clemens. He is most famous for "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1874: Sir Winston Churchill, the English statesman who, as prime minister, steered Britain through World War Two, is born.
1900: Oscar Wilde, the noted Irish wit and playwright, dies in poverty and exile in Paris at the age of 46, having penned his most famous works, four plays titled "Lady Windermere's Fan," "A Woman of No Importance," "An Ideal Husband" and "The Importance of Being Earnest."
1925: The United States sends warships to Hankow in China's Hupeh Province to prevent communist attacks on foreigners.
1945: The Soviet Union postpones the withdrawal of its troops from Manchuria until Jan. 3, 1946.
1949: Chungking falls, and Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek leaves Chungking for Chengtu.
1957: President Ahmed Sukarno of Indonesia escapes an assassination attempt.
1966: Barbados proclaims independence from Britain.
1967: The last British troops are withdrawn and the People's Republic of South Yemen is proclaimed, with its capital at Aden.
1971: Beijing and Washington announce simultaneously that U.S. President Richard Nixon will visit the Chinese mainland Feb. 21, 1972.
1975: A group of some 40 executives from 25 international companies in the United States, Europe and Japan, headed by former U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Orville Freeman, arrive in Taipei to explore investment opportunities.
1975: Dahomey changes its name to the People's Republic of Benin.
1976: Lt. Gen. Ko Kwang Do, vice chief of staff of the Republic of Korea, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1978: The London Times ceases publication due to a strike by its workers. The newspaper would resume publication Nov. 13, 1979.
1979: The ROC government decides to develop trade relations with several Eastern European countries.
1983: Dutch brewery millionaire Alfred Heineken is kidnapped in Amsterdam.
1986: Protesters storm the ROC's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to greet outlawed dissident Hsu Hsin-liang who tries to go through customs by force, leading to a clash with riot police.
1988: Yasser Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, is refused a visa to enter the United States in order to address the U.N. General Assembly in New York.
1989: Rebels attack Cory Aquino's presidential palace and seize parts of three military bases in the Philippines.
1989: The Red Army Faction, a left-wing German terrorist group, blows up Alfred Herrhausen, the head of Deutsche Bank in Frankfurt.
1991: Dr. Kuan Wei-yen, an outstanding Chinese scholar and scientist residing abroad, arrives in Taipei to accept a job offer, becoming the first mainland Chinese citizen to do so.
1992: Li Peng, Communist China's prime minister, arrives in Hanoi for a visit.
1993: The ROC signs an investment promotion and protection pact with Argentina to strengthen economic ties with South America.
1999: Taiwan's opposition elder statesman Huang Hsin-chieh dies of heart-related problems at National Taiwan University Hospital at the age of 72.
1999: Peng Tso-kwei, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, files his resignation, citing differences with the government over the country's farmland policies as a reason for his decision.
2000: Korean relatives who have been separated for over 50 years because of the division of the Korean peninsula into North and South Korea are reunited in Pyongyang, North Korea.
2001: The Tainan District Court sentences Kuomintang legislator Liao Fu-peng to six years in prison for counterfeiting securities, documents and chops, and committing fraud.
Motse's lesson of the day: "Now, the government of the empire and those of the large states do not observe their standards. This shows the governors are even less intelligent than the artisans."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OPPOSES ANY REFERENDUM ON MOVE TOWARD INDEPENDENCE: STATE DEPT.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 29 (CNA) (By W.C. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department responded Monday to President Chen Shui-bian's recent remarks about holding a referendum in 2006 on a new constitution for Taiwan, saying that Washington opposes any changes to Taiwan's status or moves toward independence through referendum.

"Our primary interest is in maintaining stability across the Taiwan Strait, and the United States is opposed to any unilateral steps that would change the status quo, " State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said while responding to a reporter's question at a daily press briefing.
"We are opposed to any referendum that would change Taiwan's status or move towards independence," the spokesman said.
President Chen said Nov. 27 that he will hold a referendum on a new constitution for Taiwan in 2006 and that the new constitution will be promulgated on May 20, 2008.

Chen also said that if the "pan-green camp, " which groups the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union, is able to gain a majority in the Legislative Yuan in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, he will put an end to disorder in Taiwan, including by creating a new constitution for Taiwan.

Pointing out that President Chen had pledged in his inauguration address in 2000 not to declare independence; not to change the name of Taiwan's government; not to add the state-to-state theory to the constitution; and not to promote a referendum on the issue of independence versus unification, and that he reaffirmed the pledge in his 2004 inauguration speech, Boucher said the United States appreciates Chen's pledge and his subsequent reaffirmations of it.
"We take those reaffirmations and that pledge very seriously, particularly as they apply to this referendum on a new constitution," he further said.

Emphasizing that Washington has always held the position that cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue is important to peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait area, Boucher said the U.S. administration has consistently urged the two sides to work to resume dialogue.
"We believe that such efforts should continue. We do not support Taiwan independence," he added.

Asked whether he sees President Chen's remarks on promoting a referendum on a new constitution in 2006 as a violation of his earlier pledge, Boucher said that Washington's view is that the president's pledges "are very important and need to be respected."
"As far as whether any other ideas or proposals contradict that or not, I think he'll have to explain," the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times:Asean speeds up economic linkages.
Asean leaders began their summit here yesterday by sealing key pacts to push the pace of economic integration within the grouping and with China, while also agreeing to launch a much-discussed East Asian Summit.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Asean and China sign the Free Trade Agreement.
Southeast Asian countries moved a step closer to forging their own European-style single market, and also signed deals with China towards creating the world's largest free-trade area by 2010.
The six-year plan foresees the removal of tariffs for products by 2010 for ASEAN's six more developed members -- Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand -- and 2015 for less-developed Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN STICKS FIRM TO HIS PLEDGE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has reaffirmed his commitment to maintaining the status quo across the Taiwan Strait on many occasions, and that commitment will remain in place through the rest of his term, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General James Huang said Tuesday.

Huang was responding to remarks by U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher on Monday that Washington is "opposed to any referendum that would change Taiwan's status or move towards independence" and that it takes Chen's pledge very seriously.
Boucher reiterated the U.S. position after President Chen said over the weekend that he would hold a referendum on a new constitution for Taiwan in 2006.

Huang pointed out that Chen has reaffirmed his commitment to maintaining the status quo on many occasions, such as in his inauguration speech for a second term on May 20 and his National Day address on Oct. 10.
This commitment will not change during the rest of President Chen's term in office, Huang said.

Huang said that phasing out the National Assembly and allowing for popular referendums on constitutional amendments is one of the items in the proposed constitutional reform package passed by the Legislative Yuan in August, and not a personal idea of President Chen.

Huang said this new mechanism for amending the ROC Constitution will not violate the pledge made by President Chen, who has repeatedly emphasized that the constitutional re-engineering effort will be carried out according to the existing constitutional system.
While promoting constitutional re-engineering in the future, the government will step up its communication with the international community in order to avoid any misunderstanding, Huang said.

Chen promised in his first inauguration address in 2000 that he would not declare independence, not change the name of Taiwan's government, not add the state-to-state theory to the ROC Constitution, and not promote a referendum on the issue of independence versus unification.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS MINISTER TO VISIT U.S. CAPITAL NEXT WEEK
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 29 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh is scheduled to arrive in Washington, D.C. Dec. 8 to attend an international seminar and meet with U.S. trade and economics officials, business sources said Monday.

Ho will attend a seminar to be organized by the Institute for International Economics, a noted U.S. think tank, and deliver a speech to American business executives at the invitation of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council which groups U.S. companies with interests in Taiwan.

This will be Ho's first visit to the U.S. capital since she assumed her current post in May this year. During her stay, Ho is also expected to meet with Bush administration officials from the U.S. Trade Representative Office and the Department of Commerce, the sources said.

Because of Beijing's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, few ROC ministers have been able to visit Washington, D.C. The ROC representative office in the United States has remained low-key concerning Ho's upcoming visit.
In a telephone interview with the CNA's Washington office Monday, Ho confirmed reports about her forthcoming U.S. visit. Nevertheless, she said her itinerary is still in the works.

Ho said the main purpose of her visit is to conduct direct dialogue with representatives of major U.S. business groups, briefing them on improvements in Taiwan's investment climate and lobbying U.S. high-tech companies, particularly those in the biotechnology, digital content and semiconductor industries, to use Taiwan as their Asian operations hub.

As U.S. President George W. Bush is still organizing his new administrative team for his second term, Ho said she is not sure at the moment which U.S. officials she will meet during her upcoming Washington visit.

Ho's visit marks yet another breakthrough in the high-level Taiwan-U.S. economic exchanges following the re-opening Monday in the U.S. capital of the sub-Cabinet-level trade consultations under the bilateral Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) after a six-year hiatus.

The ongoing sub-Cabinet TIFA meeting is focusing on issues regarding Taiwan's intellectual property rights (IPR) protection and further liberalization of its telecommunication market. The meeting is expected to achieve breakthroughs in some trade fields. If all goes well, the United States is likely to remove Taiwan from its Special 301 "priority watch" list for IPR violations monitoring next spring.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Red Cross finds detainee abuse in Guantanamo
The International Committee of the Red Cross has charged in confidential reports to the United States government that the American military has intentionally used psychological and sometimes physical coercion "tantamount to torture" on prisoners at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. A Red Cross inspection team composed of humanitarian workers visited Guantanamo last June asserted that some doctors and other medical workers at Guantanamo were participating in planning for interrogations, in what the report called "a flagrant violation of medical ethics."
Wall Street Journal: Saudi to add oil-output capacity
Saudi Arabia's oil minister confirmed plans to boost the kingdom's production capacity by as much as 14 percent, to 12.5 million barrels a day, during the next few years, in a bid to keep up with surging demand and fortify the nation's influential role as the world's producer of last resort.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: ASEAN finalizes plans for pan-Asian bloc; Leaders hope for trade group to rival EU, U.S.
South-east Asian leaders finalized visionary pacts with China and Indian at their summit that opened Monday, hoping for a pan-Asian trade block to rival Europe and the United States, even as the region grapples with terrorism and epidemics such as bird flu.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Nuclear Agency Praises Iran; IAEA Supports Arms Pact, Won't Seek Sanctions
The International Atomic Energy Agency praised Iran yesterday for suspending its uranium-enrichment work and removed an immediate threat of sanctions against the Islamic republic, which built its program in secret over 18 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD NUMBER OF SPOONBILLS GRACING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The wetlands in the southern Taiwan county of Tainan still boast the largest number of black-faced spoonbills in the world, with a total of 727 of the rare migratory having arrived there to winter as of last Friday.

According to the private Happy Family organization, which groups wild bird fans to promote wildlife conservation, a total of 605 black-faced spoonbills have been sighted at the Chiku wetlands, while another 122 have been sighted near the Sitsao wetlands area of Tainan City so far this year.
According to a global survey conducted in January of this year, only 1,206 black-faced spoonbills remain in the world.

The wading birds usually begin arriving in Taiwan to spend the winter after Mid-Autumn Festival. They then start heading back north to their breeding grounds along the border between North Korea and South Korea between March and April the following year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Kuchma Opens Door to a New Election.
Bowing to pressure, outgoing President Leonid Kuchma said Monday that repeating the disputed presidential election might be the only way out of a crisis that has badly split Ukraine.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.005 to close at NT$32.205.
A total of US$1.004 billion changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$32.203 and was traded between NT$32.117 and NT$32.285.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low but closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 59.5 points to close at 5,844.76.
The bourse opened at 5,770.81 and fluctuated between 5,844.76 and 5,722.18 during trading. A total of 3.07 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$65.87 billion (US$2.04 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by construction issues and foodstuff issues, both at 1.2 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and cement stocks, both at 0.7 percent, and textile stocks at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 365 to 261, with 161 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM UNRELATED TO INDEPENDENCE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The planned constitutional re-engineering project in Taiwan will not involve issues of independence versus unification, or a change of territorial boundaries or the country's official name, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday.

Yu noted that President Chen Shui-bian made the point very clear in his inauguration speech for his second term on May 20, when the president said he hoped to present the people of Taiwan with a new constitution in 2008.
The purpose of the reform, as stated in the president's inauguration address, is to achieve a constitution that is "timely, relevant and viable," according to Yu.
Chen said over the weekend that he would hold a referendum in 2006 to let the people vote on the new constitution which, if approved, would be implemented on May 20, 2008.

In response to this proposal, U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher reiterated on Monday that Washington is "opposed to any referendum that would change Taiwan's status or move towards independence" and that Washington takes Chen's May 20 pledge very seriously.

Lee Ying-yuan, deputy secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said President Chen will never go back on his pledges, which include not to declare independence, not to change the name of the country, not to add the state-to-state theory to the Republic of China Constitution, and not to promote a referendum on the issue of independence versus unification.
President Chen has repeated many times that Taiwan is already an independent sovereign state and does not require a referendum on independence, Lee said.
As the majority of people in Taiwan are known to oppose unification with mainland China, a referendum on unification is also unnecessary, Lee added.

Opposition Kuomintang spokesman Chang Jung-kung said the United States is concerned about Taiwan's plan to reform the ROC Constitution because it is related to the question of whether a war will break out across the Taiwan Strait.
Accusing President Chen of playing with words, Chang said Chen has confused Washington as to whether he means to amend or redo the ROC Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMIC GROWTH FORECAST AT 5% FOR 2005: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth rate and unemployment rate for 2005 have been forecast at 5 percent and 4 percent, respectively, by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The CEPD forecast that per-capita income will reach US$14,900 next year, while the country's consumer price index (CPI) and its core CPI will increase no more than 2 percent and 1.5 percent, respectively.

In addition, the CEPD also estimated that the country will post an average economic growth rate of 4.9 percent and an unemployment rate of 4 percent, respectively, for the period from 2005 through 2008, when per-capita income is expected to hit US$17,700.

CEPD Vice Chairman Yeh Ming-feng said that relevant government agencies will do their best to meet the set targets in the knowledge-based era while facing several challenges, including dealing with a graying population, carrying out environmental protection measures, promoting ethnic harmony, upgrading industry and achieving sustainable national development amid fierce foreign competition.

According to Yeh, dealing effectively with several major issues, including structural unemployment, resource consumption, natural disaster and epidemic disease control, pollution, cross-strait competition and relations, and high oil prices, are of key importance in Taiwan's continued economic growth
He said that based on the concept of building Taiwan into a"green silicon island, " the government will tackle these issues with greater innovation, care and tolerance.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Tuesday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December losing one point to close at 5,809, with 44,352 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January moved up five points to finish at 5,810, with 173 contracts traded, while March futures gained four points to finish at 5,800, with 21 contracts traded.
June futures gained seven points to finish at 5,780, with six contracts traded, while September futures moved down 24 points to close at 5,700, with six contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,810 for December, 5,805 for January, 5,796 for March, 5,773 for June and 5,724 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
December TE futures moved down 1.3 points to close at 214.5, with 5,281 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 2.8 points to finish at 213.2, with 22 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

December TF futures gained 7.6 points to finish at 999.2, with 9,843 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up seven points to end at 998, with 280 contracts traded. March TF future remained unchanged at 990.2, with one contract changing hands, while June TF futures moved down 22.6 points to end at 985, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SIGNS LARGEST TOURIST INVESTMENT BOT CASE

TEXT.P: Tourism authorities concluded a NT$10.34 billion (US$321.57 million) deal with an international investment company Tuesday to develop the Dapeng Bay National Scenic Area in southern Taiwan, the country's largest tourism-oriented build-operate-transfer (BOT) case.

The contract was signed by Hsieh Wei-chun, chief of the Tourist Bureau's Dapeng Bay National Scenic Area Administration under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, and Dapeng Bay International Investment Chairman Pan Chung-kuang, with Tourism Bureau Director-General Su Chen-tien, as well as acting Pingtung Magistrate Wu Ying-wen, witnessing the ceremony.

The Dapeng Bay development project, covering a 257-hectare region made up of wetland, lagoon and sea water, is Taiwan's largest BOT investment in terms of the area scale and investment, while it also contains the most multi-dimensional development packages, according to the Tourism Bureau.

Tourism officials said the projects will be carried out in two stages, with the first stage focusing on the construction of a marina and port zone facilities, including a fisherman's wharf and a seaside restaurant; an artificial peninsula that will be home to a museum of history and literature, a leisure and entertainment center, a water world and an international convention center equipped with a tourist hotel; a golf resort; and a large parking lot.
Construction work for the first-stage development is scheduled to finish by the end of 2012, with the second stage scheduled for completion eight years later, according to the officials.
They noted that the planned second-stage development will center on work to build a southern Taiwan leisure-oriented coastal area, an ecological educational park and an educational hall.

The Dapeng Bay National Scenic Area, set up in November 1997, is located on the southern coast and borders Donggang and Linbien townships in Pingtung. A natural, wildlife-rich area spanning 1,438 hectares of land, lagoon and sea, it includes Dapeng Bay -- the only cystiform lagoon in Taiwan, according to the area administration.
The Tourism Bureau has assessed that once the development project is completed, the scenic area will dominate the island's tourism market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ATTEND PACIFIC TUNA COMMISSION MEETING

TEXT.P: Taiwan will organize an official group to attend the first meeting of the West and Central Pacific Tuna Commission as a formal member of the regional organization, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

MOFA Department of International Organizations Deputy Director-General Chie Wen-chi said the meeting is slated to open Dec. 9 and added that the Taiwan delegation will comprise officials of MOFA and of the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture.
Chie said Taiwan signed a convention to set up a regional commission dedicated to tuna conservation and the development of the tuna industry, along with another 28 countries.
The convention passed the legislature May 21, with President Chen Shui-bian promulgating it June 25, Chie said.
Chie also said that the United States and Japan are expected to join the organization next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ORDERS STRINGENT CRACKDOWN ON VOTE BUYING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday ordered law enforcement authorities to step up a crackdown on vote-buying ahead of the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Addressing the weekly meeting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) Central Standing Committee, Chen noted that the election campaign will enter its final stage Wednesday, when official campaign activities begin.
This is also the time when vote-buying activities are especially prevalent, Chen said.

While the government successfully prevented a number of candidates with "black gold" backgrounds from being elected during the last legislative elections in 2001 by enforcing a series of operations against vote-buying, it must step up its effort this time to stop the corrupt practice from coming back into fashion, Chen said.
He said the crackdown will be based on evidence and not partisanship.
Meanwhile, he announced that he will take part in a large-scale DPP rally scheduled for Saturday.
Chen said the DPP must unite the people of Taiwan as it did Feb.
28, when more than a million people held hands to form a human chain stretching from the northernmost to the southernmost tip of the island to protest the missile threat from mainland China.
He called on supporters to attend the upcoming parade around Taipei City "for the security of Taiwan and the well-being of its 23 million people." (Y.F. Low)

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 REFERENDUM ON NEW CONSTITUTION WON'T BREACH PLEDGE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday his administration's plan to hold a referendum in 2006 on a draft new constitution to be implemented May 20, 2008 completely complies with the nation's constitutional system and will by no means breach his May 20 inauguration pledge.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a visiting U.S. congressional delegation headed by Rep. John Culberson (R-Texas).
He also took advantage of the meeting to reaffirm his commitment to maintaining the status quo across the Taiwan Strait through the rest of his term in office.

Chen's reaffirmation came a day after U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said that the U.S. government is opposed to any referendum that would change Taiwan's status or move toward independence. Boucher reiterated the U.S. position after Chen said Nov. 27 that he will hold a referendum on a new constitution for Taiwan in 2006.

During his meeting with the U.S. congressional delegation, Chen said the policy guidelines outlined in his May 20 second inauguration speech, his Oct. 10 National Day address and his Nov. 10 10-point directive for his administration's cross-strait policy and constitutional re-engineering plan have not undergone any change and will remain intact through the end of his tenure.
He assured the U.S. congressmen that his administration will strictly follow Taiwan's existing constitution-amending procedures in writing a new constitution that fits Taiwan's present situation.

Under the existing mechanism, the new constitution draft requires the consent of three-quarters of the legislators before it can be referred to a "functional National Assembly" for further review and approval.

According to a legislative reform package passed by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan in August this year, Chen said the first and last "functional National Assembly" will be elected next year to vote on the draft new constitution.

If all goes well, he went on, the draft new constitution will again be put up for a nationwide referendum in 2006. If passed, the new constitution will be put into force on the day of the conclusion of his tenure -- May 20, 2008.

According to the new constitution, Chen said, the "functional National Assembly" will be phased out and all future constitution-amending bills passed by the legislature will be subject to national referendum rather than approval by the "functional National Assembly."

In conclusion, Chen said, his constitutional re-engineering plan is fully compliant with Taiwan's constitutional procedures and will not violate the content or spirit of his May 20 inauguration speech, National Day address and Nov. 10 directives. "Our promises remain in place and will not be subjected to any change, " he added.

Chen reiterated that he hopes the "pan-green camp" of his Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union can win a clear majority in the Dec. 11 legislative elections to facilitate his policy initiatives, including legislative reform and constitutional re-engineering.

Once the "pan-green camp" controls a legislative majority, Chen went on, Taiwan will be more confident in dealing with cross-strait relations and the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be more likely to resume dialogue to maintain regional peace and stability.

Other members of the U.S. congressional delegation include Rep. John Carter (R-Texas) and Rep. Phil Gingrey (R-GA), as well as former Congressman Greg Laughlin and their aides. They arrived in Taipei earlier in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUB-CABINET-LEVEL TAIWAN-U.S. TIFA TALKS RESUME AFTER 6-YEAR HIATUS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Nov. 29 (CNA) (By Winnie Chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Sub-Cabinet-level Taiwan-U.S. trade consultations under the bilateral Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) resumed Monday after a six-year hiatus.

The two-day meeting is being held at the U.S. Trade Representative Office in Washington, D.C., with Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Josette Sheeran Shiner serving as the chief U.S. delegate and Chen Ruey-long, vice economics minister, heading the Taiwan delegation.

The primary goal of the Taiwan delegation is to lobby the United States to remove Taiwan from its Special 301 "priority watch" list for IPR violations monitoring, while the U.S. delegation is expected to push Taiwan to further liberalize its telecommunication and pharmaceutical markets.
The TIFA trade consultation is the highest-level official Taiwan-U.S. economic meeting. The talks had been suspend since 1998 due to U.S. discontent with Taiwan's alleged sloppy IPR enforcement.
With Taiwan having made tremendous progress in cracking down on commercial piracy and in IPR protection, the U.S. government finally agreed to resume TIFA talks this year.
If all goes smoothly, sources close to Taiwan's representative office said, the U.S. government will agree to take Taiwan off its Special 301 "priority watch" list next spring.

The Taiwan delegation to the ongoing TIFA meeting is composed of officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Council of Agriculture, the Directorate General of Telecommunications, the Bureau of National Health Insurance Bureau, the Board of Foreign Trade and the nation's representative office in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PROMOTE FRUIT IN HONG KONG, JAPAN, MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will launch a series of activities next month to promote seasonal Taiwan fruit in Hong Kong, Japan and mainland China, officials said Tuesday.
The first of these promotional activities will kick off Dec. 16 in 50 Hong Kong supermarkets, the officials said.
While 200 tons of mandarins are expected to be on sale in the two-week activity, other seasonal fruit will include oranges, papayas, grapefruit, pineapples, starfruit, guavas and pomelos.

A promotional sale of Taiwan grapes and mango jelly will start Dec. 18 in 60 supermarkets in Japan's Kanto, Kinki and Kyushu areas, and the COA is negotiating with Japanese buyers on the possibility of expanding the sale to other fruit such as mandarins, the official said.
Meanwhile, the COA also plans to hold a promotional activity in mainland China's Guangdong Province, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: YUNLIN SECTION OF CENTRAL SCIENCE PARK TO BREAK GROUND DEC. 2

TEXT.P: An infrastructure development project for the Yunlin section of the Central Taiwan Science Park is set to break ground Dec. 2, officials said Tuesday.

The Yunlin section, with a total area of 96 hectares, is expected to start operations in 2006 at the earliest after the infrastructure development has been completed, according to Yang Wen-ke, deputy director of the Central Taiwan Science Park Administration.
Yang said it is mainly designed for leasing to manufacturers in the biotechnology, optoelectronics and communications sectors.
It has the capacity to accommodate 10 to 15 manufacturers, Yang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIN YUAN GROUP TAIWAN'S LARGEST BUSINESS IN 2003: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The Lin Yuan Group was Taiwan's largest business in 2003, with assets value totaling NT$2.38 trillion (US$72 billion) , according to survey results made public Tuesday by the China Credit Information Service Ltd. (CCIS).

The Mega Holdings Group and the Chinatrust Group lagged behind in second and third places, with assets standing at NT$1.78 trillion and NT$1.57 trillion, respectively, according to the survey results. The First Financial Holdings Company and the Hsin Kuang Group were the fourth and fifth wealthiest groups.
The combined assets value of the country's 250 wealthiest groups amounted to NT$31.62 trillion last year, an average of NT$120 billion per group, up from the 2002 level of NT$113.4 billion.
The leading 250 largest enterprises conducted total business worth NT$12.19 trillion in 2003, higher than the country's gross national product of NT$10.17 trillion for the same year.

At the same time, the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) was ranked as Taiwan's No. 1 group in terms of revenues in 2003, posting NT$938.7 billion (US$28.2 billion) , according to the CCIS poll findings. FPG was the sole manufacturing group to make the top 10 business groups list in terms of assets, achieving seventh spot.

FPG was followed by Lin Yuan, with NT$534.8 billion in second and the Hon Hai Group, with NT$ 479 billion in third, in terms of revenues, the survey shows. Lin Yuan maintained the same ranking it had in 2002, while Hon Hai moved up from sixth spot.
The MiTAC Group maintained its 2002 ranking of fourth, with NT$379.4 billion in revenues, ahead of Quanta Group, with NT$361.5 billion in fifth, a surge from the previous year's 12th place.
Of Taiwan's 10 largest business groups in terms of revenues, there were eight manufacturing companies -- four from the hi-tech sector and four from traditional businesses, the results show.

Hon Hai, Taiwan's largest contract electronics maker, was selected as the country's most successful business in globalization out of 250 groups surveyed, in terms of overseas assets, business revenues and profits.

Hon Hai had the largest number of 294 branches and affiliates abroad last year. It also had 62 factories in Europe, the United States and Asia, as well as 71 distribution centers around the world, well outperforming other groups with overseas operations.
Hon Hai was followed by Delta Electronics in second and LITE-ON in third. The Acer Group, Taiwan's largest computer firm, grabbed fourth spot, while MiTAC seized fifth place.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING USING ECONOMIC CLOUT TO 'MARGINALIZE' TAIWAN: MOFA

TEXT.P: Mainland China is stepping up its efforts to marginalize Taiwan by signing multilateral or bilateral free trade agreements with other countries, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said Tuesday.
Lu was commenting on Beijing's signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) in Vientiane, Laos, the previous day.

"The new accord marks yet another move by Beijing to use economic means to marginalize Taiwan, " Lu said, adding that relevant government agencies will communicate with ASEAN countries through the proper channels and work out response strategies to cope with the new situation.

Chieh Wen-chi, deputy director of the MOFA's International Organizations Department, said the new mainland China-ASEAN FTA is not expected to have a significant adverse impact on Taiwan because the World Trade Organization (WTO) imposes many restrictions on such regional pacts.
If the FTA imposes stringent discrimination against non-members, Chieh said, the existing multilateral international trading system will not tolerate its existence.

While the signing of the FTA may signal a step forward in the regional integration of East Asia, Chieh said he is convinced that major countries in the region will eventually come to a new understanding of Taiwan's important role in the region.
With Taiwan's economic strength and quality manpower resources, Chieh said, Taiwan will be able to play a constructive role in East Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC POSTS NAMES OF LEGISLATIVE CANDIDATES FOR DEC. 11 ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung posted the names of the legislative candidates running in the Dec. 11 elections on the commission's bulletin board Tuesday on the eve of the start of the 10-day official campaign period.

Also posted on the CEC bulletin board was the legally sanctioned timeframe for campaign activities. The official campaign period starts from Dec. 1 and will last through Dec. 10., with the daily campaign time from 7 a.m. through 10 p.m.

A total of 493 hopefuls passed the qualification screening and completed a drawing of lots to determine the order in which their names will appear on the ballots. Among the hopefuls, 386 will vie for regional and aboriginal legislative seats, while 89 will compete for at-large seats and 18 will run for overseas community seats.
Speaking at a news conference, Chang said television and radio stations will be barred from broadcasting legislative election campaign commercials from Dec. 1.

"Starting tomorrow, individual legislative candidates and third parties should not air campaign commercials on TV or radio channels, otherwise they will violate the Public Officials Election and Recall Law," Chang said.
From Dec. 1, Chang went on, TV and radio stations will also be barred from giving full-length live broadcasts of any campaign rally.

"They can only broadcast selected scenes in their news programs," Chang said, adding that all CEC commissioners will meet Wednesday to more clearly set out standards for determining whether a TV or radio program has violated the "no campaign" regulations and whether news programs have been fair and impartial.

According to the television and radio broadcasting law, Chang said, violators will face varying fines for violations. The fines for cable TV stations could reach a maximum of NT$500,000, while law-breaking terrestrial TV stations could be slapped with fines of up to NT$1 million.

Chang said the law requires TV and radio stations to deal with news events regarding individual candidates and their parties impartially and fairly. The law also forbids them from broadcasting campaign commercials put up by individual candidates, political parties or third parties during the official campaign period. TV and radio stations are also not allowed to campaign for any parties or candidates in their programs during the period.

From Dec. 1, Chang said the Government Information Office (GIO) will closely monitor all TV and radio news programs. If any are found to have violated the principles of fairness and impartiality, the GIO will send the monitoring videotapes to the CEC for review.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 AICA CONFERENCE TO OPEN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2004 conference of the International Association of Art Critics (AICA) is slated to open Thursday in Taipei, the first time that the annual event will be held in Taiwan, organizers said Tuesday.

More than 60 AICA members from 28 countries will take part in the international conference and President Chen Shui-bian will give a speech at the opening, according to Lin Cheng-i, general secretary of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs, co-organizer of the event along with the Republic of China Art Critics Association.

AICA President Henry Meyric Hughes said that it will also be the third time the organization's annual conference has been hosted in Asia, after the 1998 meeting in Tokyo and the 1995 meeting in Macau.

Hughes said that experts will discuss issues related to artistic developments in the region in the face of the emergence of bloc trading and the formation of political alliances this year. A total of 28 papers will be presented at the conference, he added.
Hughes and some AICA members paid a visit to the National Palace Museum and the Hua Shan Artistic Creation Park earlier that same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, AUSTRONESIAN DIPLOMATIC ALLIES TO INK HEALTH COMMUNIQUE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and five of its diplomatic partners from Austronesia will sign a communique in Taipei Wednesday to bolster bilateral health and medical cooperation and exchanges, a spokesman for the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said Tuesday.

According to the official, ministers, representatives and specialists from the Republic of Kiribati, the Marshall Islands, Palau, Tuvalu and the Solomon Islands will take part in the health ministers' meeting with their Taiwan counterpart.

In addition to providing substantive and enhanced medical assistance to the people of those countries through inking the communique and other cooperative ventures, the official said, the DOH also hopes to help promote Taiwan's image and status on the world stage and to make the country into a health and medical information and research center for Austronesian countries.

The participants will exchange opinions and discuss ways to prevent and control some of the common diseases and health problems among the aboriginal peoples of these countries, such as alcoholism, diabetes and obesity.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOODWILL IS KEY TO CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said in a recent interview with the monthly magazine "China Review" that goodwill is the key to the resumption of cross-Taiwan Strait talks.

In the interview, carried in the edition that will be put on newsstands Wednesday, Wu said that President Chen Shui-bian has repeatedly offered goodwill overtures to mainland China since he assumed office May 20, 2000, but Beijing has never reciprocated.
Beijing should not try to squeeze Taiwan's international space when Taiwan is seeking to improve the cross-strait relations with goodwill proposals, Wu said.

Noting that Taiwan does not rule out any topics to be discussed in cross-strait talks, including the "one China" issue, the country's top mainland policy planner said that it is difficult for Taiwan to accept the "one China" as a prerequisite to the dialogue as demanded by Beijing.

Given that the "one China" issue is a basic problem for both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the two parties should first create an ambiguous environment and start negotiations with non-political issues, such as a liquidation accord for their currencies, the signing of a Taiwan businessmen's investment protection guarantee agreement, a double taxation avoidance accord, an intellectual property rights protection pact, direct cross-strait trade, transportation and postal service links, cross-strait tourism and repatriation of illegal immigrants, among others, he proposed.

Many problems have emerged from the cross-strait exchanges and should be dealt with quickly, Wu pointed out, adding that Taiwan is trying to promote a sound development of cross-strait ties and to make them move toward cooperative ties.
An uncertain, unstable and unfriendly cross-strait relationship is harmful to both Taiwan and the mainland, he stressed.

Referring to a plan initiated by Chen to establish a framework for cross-strait peace and stability and to set up a committee for cross-strait peace and development, Wu said that relevant government agencies are making preparations and that action is expected to be launched after the Dec. 11 legislative elections because the government does not want to let the issues become topics of electoral campaigns, which may make the situation even more complicated.

The government will have a better position to promote cross-strait relations after the "pan green camp" formed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union wins a majority of legislative seats in the upcoming elections, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 45 LAWMAKERS FAIL WATCHDOG GROUP'S ATTENDANCE, INTEGRITY EVALUATIONS

TEXT.P: The Taipei Society, a private self-proclaimed legislative watchdog organization, issued an evaluation report on incumbent legislators Tuesday, 11 days ahead of the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

The evaluation was based on lawmakers' attendance at various committee meetings during the past two legislative sessions, as well as on three negative indexes -- conflict of interest, inappropriate deeds or remarks, and involvement in corruption or other criminal cases.
In terms of those indexes, the Taipei Society flunked 45 incumbent lawmakers from across the political spectrum and 62 others were put on the "negative watch list."

The flunked lawmakers referred to those whose attendance rates fell below 50 percent, as well as those whose attendance rates were above 50 percent but who were connected with two or more of the three negative indexes.
The "negative watch list" includes lawmakers with low attendance rates and connection with one of the negative indexes.

Among the flunked legislators, one is an independent, 16 are opposition Kuomintang (KMT) members, 12 are from the opposition People First Party (PFP) , seven each are from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) and two are from the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

Chang Mao-kuei, a research fellow with Academia Sinica's Institute of Social Sciences, who authored the evaluation report, said KMT Legislator Ho Chih-hui, who tops the "flunked" list, should return his annual legislative stipend of NT$8.5 million because he has seldom attended legislative committee meetings and has been indicted over corruption charges. Chang also urged Ho, who has been nominated by the KMT to seek re-election in the Miaoli County constituency, to make a public apology to taxpayers.

Chang said all the "flunked" lawmakers should give public explanations of their low attendance rates and their improper deeds and words, as well as their failure to avoid conflicts of interest and their roles in corruption and criminal cases.
He also urged those who failed to attend at least 20 percent of legislative committee meetings to refund their legislative stipends.

The evaluation report also unveiled a "positive list" of 39 lawmakers who have high attendance rates and are believed to be less likely to be connected with negative indexes. Among them, 15 are DPP members, 11 each are from the KMT and the PFP, one is from the TSU and one is an independent.
