DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE ELECTION CAMPAIGN TO BEGIN, LAW ENFORCEMENT STEPPED UP

TEXT.P: Campaign activities for the Dec. 11 legislative elections will officially begin Wednesday and run through until the election eve amid stepped up law enforcement, police authorities said Tuesday.
According to a spokesman for the National Police Administration, campaigning will be allowed from 7 a.m. through 10 p.m. each day during the period from Dec. 1 to Dec. 10.

In an effort to wipe out irregularities, violence and vote-buying and to protect the personal safety of all candidates and secure a smooth election, law enforcement has been stepped up across Taiwan, he said.

Citing the newest survey results, Chang Chun-hsiung, secretary- general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said he is cautiously optimistic that the DPP will seize 101 seats in the 225-member Legislative Yuan -- the target set by President Chen Shui-bian.

Along with the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , the "pan green camp" will be able to grab at least 113 seats to form a majority in the sixth legislature, laying a foundation for sweeping reforms, Chang said.
A TSU official said that his party has a potential of capturing 24 seats in the elections with 17 having been secured.
Meanwhile, the opposition "pan blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) is also striving to retain their present majority in the next Legislative Yuan.

Liao Feng-teh, director of the KMT's Organization Development Committee, forecast that the KMT will win about 79 seats. In a bid to garner as many seats as possible, the KMT is considering resorting to a vote-allocation strategy among its supporters, he added.
The PFP has set a goal of winning between 35 and 40 seats in order to achieve a "pan blue" majority in the legislature in cooperation with the KMT.

An official of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) claimed that the party stands a good chance of garnering as many as 20 seats amid fierce competition between the "pan blue alliance" and the "pan green camp, " especially when both sides launch their mechanisms to allocate votes among their backers.

A total of 387 eligible candidates will contest the upcoming legislative election, vying for 168 regional seats and eight aboriginal seats. The remaining eight overseas Chinese seats and 41 at-large seats will be allocated to the various parties according to the number of votes they garner.
The DPP has recommended 92 candidates for regional seats, followed by the KMT, with 74. The PFP is fielding 41, while the TSU and the NPSU are fielding 30 and 26 hopefuls, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-NICARAGUA FTA 2ND-ROUND TALKS OPEN IN SAN FRANCISCO
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Nov. 29 (CNA) (By Chiang Yin and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Delegates from Taiwan and Nicaragua started a second round of free trade agreement (FTA) talks Monday in San Francisco.

Officials of Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said the negotiations are divided into five panels that will discuss animal and plant health inspection and quarantine, investment, telecommunications and the protection of intellectual property rights.
The MOEA hopes to conclude the talks and sign an FTA accord by the end of the first half of next year, they added.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long and his Nicaraguan counterpart Alejandro Arguello are jointly chairing the negotiations on behalf of their respective governments at the meeting, which will run through Dec. 3, the officials said.

Officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the MOEA, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Justice, the Department of Health, the Council of Agriculture, the Financial Supervisory Commission and the Directorate General of Telecommunications make up the bulk of the Taiwan delegation.

According to Chen, Taiwan and Nicaragua exchanged customs tariff reduction lists for agricultural and farm products prior to the San Francisco negotiations, which will help two-way substantive talks conclude sooner.
The two countries finished their first round of FTA talks in late September in Taipei, making Nicaragua a would-be second FTA partner of Taiwan, after Panama.
Taiwan-Nicaragua trade in the first 10 months of this year totaled US$226 million, up by 117 percent over the previous year's level.
